DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHER HONORED FOR IMPROVING DIAGNOSES OF BLOOD VESSEL TUMORS

TEXT.P: A researcher at the National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan has won the Hiwin Science Award Saturday for developing a method to help detect blood vessel tumors, called hemangiomas, in brain.

Tsai Tsung-han, who has just won his master's degree in mechanical engineering from Tsing Hua, will receive a gold medal in addition to NT$800,000 (US$24,177) cash award, according to an executive of the Hiwin Technologies Corp. which sponsors the prize.

Tsai developed the method to predict the rupture location of hemangiomas in the brain based on the theory that the development of tumors on blood vessel will inevitably change the blood flow in the vessel, and thereby betray their existence.

With the help of the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, Tsai analyzed the brain images, made by magnetic resonance imaging angiography, of patients who suffered from the burst of hemangiomas , and found regular subtle changes in blood flow of these patients.
Based on his analyses, Tsai can predict with an accuracy of between 60 percent and 80 percent, the rupture place of the blood vessel tumors and thereby help with their diagnosis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 1, or the 14th day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1572: The Dutch War for Independence from Spain begins.
1578: William Harvey, British physician and anatomist who discovered the circulation of blood, is born.
1815: Prince Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, Prussian statesman and first chancellor of the German Empire, is born.
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1924: Adolf Hitler is sentenced by a court to five years in jail for high treason. He was released on Dec. 20.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1930: Yen Hsi-shan, Feng Yu-hsiang and Li Tsung-jen revolt against the ROC National Government.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a "Three Principles of the People" Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to all levels of the nation's governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1945: U.S. forces invade the Japanese island of Okinawa.
1959: The Dalai Lama arrives in India from Tibet.
1960: The United State launches Tiros I, its first weather satellite.
1965: King Hussein of Jordan appoints Prince Hassan, his younger brother, as his heir.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States.
1975: Cambodian President Lon Nol flees to Indonesia as Khmer Rouge guerrillas close in on Phnom Penh.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan visits the Taiwan Machinery Show at the grounds of the China External Trade Development Council.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1986: The new Value Added Tax (VAT) system is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1992: President George Bush pledges that the United States will help finance the 24-billion dollar international aid fund for the former Soviet Union.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Britain proposes slaughtering 15,000 of its cattle every week for the next six years in order to fight mad cow disease.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
1998: Israel accepts a United Nations resolution calling for its withdrawal from south Lebanon.
2000: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that he expects the party will rise again by winning the elections for legislators and county magistrates in two years and by regaining the presidency in 2004.
2001: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presents a "Key to Taipei" to Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama, saying that "the city always welcomes you and is always opened to you."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other hand, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG COUNTY DEPUTY MAGISTRATE DETAINED ON CORRUPTION CHARGES

TEXT.P: Taitung County Deputy Magistrate Huang Fa-lou was taken into custody early Sunday on charges of corruption after public prosecutors with the Taitung District Court interrogated him over his involvement in a construction contract bid rigging case four years ago.

The prosecutors suspected that Huang had received kickbacks after bid rigging in the awarding of contracts for construction projects while he was acting head of Taitung County's Dajen township in 2003.
After searching Huang's home and office, prosecutors brought him to the Public Prosecutors' Office for questioning regarding his role in the corruption case.

To prevent collusion between Huang and other defendants, and in view of the fact that the offense carries a minimum sentence of seven years imprisonment, the court granted the prosecutors' request to detain Huang.

Individuals in 14 of Taitung County's 16 townships have been under investigation for receiving kickbacks and allowing bid rigging and bidder collusion in local government procedures for awarding construction contracts five years ago.
Three former heads of the townships of Tungho, Chenkung and Changbin have been sentenced to lengthy prison terms upon conviction for corruption by the district court.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT CHAIRMAN TO INVITE SPEAKER AS RUNNING MATE IN 2008 RACE

TEXT.P: Former main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that he will invite Legislature Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to be his running mate and jointly challenge the 2008 presidential election.

Ma, who is widely viewed as the KMT's best bet in the 2008 race, is poised to register candidacy for the KMT presidential primary. He said Sunday he would like to have Wang as his running mate even if Wang does not register for the KMT primary. Registraton for the KMT primary will begin April 3.
Wang was formerly a KMT vice chairman.
Ma made the remarks while taking the Taiwan High Speed Railway from Taipei to the southern city of Tainan.

Responding to a reporter's inquiry as to whether Ma was worried that Wang, who has recently expressed his explicit intention to run in the 2008 presidency, may announce his candidacy as an independent, Ma said he reckons Wang "will probably not do this."

Meanwhile, Ma, who resigned as the KMT chairman Feb. 13 upon being charged over allegedly lining his pockets during his time as Taipei mayor with NT$11 million (US$332,684) from a special allowance fund set aside for the mayor's discretionary use, would not speculate on the possible outcome of a court hearing April 3 when the Taipei District Court addresses his indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TYPHOON FORMED BUT POSES NO IMMEDIATE THREAT: CWB

TEXT.P: A new typhoon formed Sunday morning, dubbed "Kong-Rey", but as of Sunday does not pose an immediate threat to Taiwan given its distance from the island, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

The depression system-turned typhoon, located about 880 kilometers east southeast to Guam, was moving in a northwestern direction toward Taiwan at a speed of 17 kilometers per hour as of 2 p.m. Sunday, CWB meteorologists said.
Owing to the typhoon's distance from Taiwan, the weather bureau said it remains to be seen how it will develop and its possible impact on Taiwan in the following several days.
It is the first typhoon reported in the western Pacific this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-KOREA FREE TRADE PACT TO HAVE ADVERSE IMPACT ON TAIWAN: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The imminent signing of a free trade agreement between the United States and South Korea will definitely have an adverse impact on Taiwan, which has been a major rival to South Korea in terms of industrial production and export trade, Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Sunday.

It is certain that the U.S.-South Korea free trade pact -- expected to be signed shortly as bilateral talks are slated to wrap up by Monday -- will have an effect on Taiwan, although how much and to what extent remain to be seen, Chen said.

It is believed that the U.S.-South Korea agreement will have little impact on Taiwan's agriculture sector, though South Korea may increase its imports of U.S. agricultural products under the stipulations of the agreement, which might have the side effect of benefiting Taiwan in terms of the island's imports, Chen analyzed.
The U.S.-Korea FTA will also have minor impact on Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry since the export of most IT products is duty-free under international practices, Chen said.
As to other industrial sectors, Chen said, the Economics Ministry will pay close attention to the contents of the U.S.-Korea FTA to see how it will affect related sectors in Taiwan's economy.

He added that the Economics Ministry is watching closely to determine whether the U.S.-Korea FTA will prompt more U.S. companies to invest in South Korea or bring about closer cooperation in business and trade sectors between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES JAPAN WILL RECIPROCATE BY OPENING DOOR TO TAIWAN PORK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's animal husbandry industry executives expressed hopes Sunday that Japan will reciprocate by opening its door to Taiwan pork exports since Japan has been exporting many of its agricultural products in large quantities to Taiwan.

Huang Chin-jung, chairman of the non-profit National Animal Industry Foundation, who recently led a Taiwan delegation to visit agricultural operations on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido, said governments of various levels are striving to root out foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) from Taiwan's farms in the hope that the disease will be eradicated once and for all within a couple of years, meaning that Taiwanese-produced pork will again be allowed access to Japan's meat markets.
Taiwan's pork exports have been barred from Japan since 1997 after an outbreak of FMD on animal farms around the island that same year.

Under concerted government efforts, some areas, including the offshore county of Penghu, have successfully eradicated FMD through organic means instead of using vaccination, Huang said, adding that all animal farms in Taiwan are expected to stop vaccinating their cultured livestock by August 2008 -- at the same time also paving the way for Taiwan to become an FMD-free country, Huang noted.

During last week's trip to Hokkaido, Huang said, members of the Taiwan delegation of animal farm operators met with their Japanese counterparts and were told that the farmers associations from Hokkaido have enjoyed brisk businesses exporting their produce and output to Taiwan, including Chinese yams, dairy products, grape wine and other agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOLS WITH EXCELLENT ENERGY EDUCATION PROGRAMS TO BE CITED

TEXT.P: The screening process will soon begin to select the winners of the 2007 eminence and excellence awards for elementary and junior high schools with the best energy education programs, Bureau of Energy officials under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Sunday.
The bureau's annual selection of award winners is now in its ninth year. The deadline for submitting entries for this year is set for April 2.
National Taiwan Normal University, organizer of the event, will invite experts from different sectors to screen applicants in three stages.
One school each from Taiwan's northern, central, southern and eastern regions will emerge as an eminence award winner. The four winners will each receive a citation and a NT$100,000 cash prize.
Four additional winners of the excellence awards will be selected from the four regions. They will each get NT$50,000 plus a citation.
The Bureau of Energy initiated the school energy education awards program in 1999 as part of Taiwan's support for international efforts -- represented by the Kyoto Protocol -- to slow global warming.
To date, 169 countries have joined the protocol, which became effective in February 2006, with the notable exceptions of the United States and Australia.

Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the protocol, the government in Taipei has taken a series of positive steps, including drawing up a plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to the 2000 levels by 2020.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-CONSTIPATION DRUG SALES HALTED DUE TO SIDE EFFECTS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has revoked the commercial license for Zelmac, a drug for women to relieve constipation, and demanded an immediate recall of the drug from store shelves because it may cause angina and raise the chances of stroke and heart diseases, an official said Sunday.

The DOH imposed the sales ban after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) revoked import licenses of the drug and requested that the Swiss pharmaceutical maker Novartis, which makes Zelmac, suspended sales of the drug due to side effects it may cause, the official added.
Zelmac, which is currently available in more than 30 countries, gained regulatory approval for sale in Taiwan's market in 2003, according to the official.

Since the use of Zelmac is not covered in the National Health Insurance Program and the number of users is limited, the DOH estimates that not many people will be affected by the suspension of the sales of the drug, which is used mainly for short-term treatment of women under the age of 65 with constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome, the official said.

The DOH official urged those taking the drug to consult with their doctors to see whether they should find alternative drugs, while calling on those taking Zelmac and seeing the symptoms of angina and other heart diseases to inform the DOH via the National Reporting System of Adverse Drug Reactions in Taiwan.

A spokesman for the Novartis in Taiwan said that his company decided to pull the drug off of shelves in Taiwan's market in response to the DOH demand. According to a U.S. study, 13 out of 11,600 patients treated with Zelmac suffered potentially ischemia heart disease and angina as compared to one out of 7,000 people treated with placebos.
The Novartis said the statistically significant imbalance of cardiovascular events between patients taking Zelmac and those taking a placebo prompted the FDA to take the action.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS PONDER ETHICAL ISSUE OF BIOBANK PLANS

TEXT.P: A group of academics and medical professionals gathered Sunday to ponder ethical issues and related controversies that might arise from the establishment of a national biobank.

Speaking at a colloquium organized by the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan, Tsai Tu-chien, director of Taipei Medical University's Institute of Medical Humanities, said more legal professionals are needed to pitch in to build a legal framework concerning human genome studies and possible establishment of a biobank in Taiwan.

Building a legal framework -- aimed at supervising the biobank in terms of ethical and related issues -- will at least help alleviate doubts harbored by aboriginal people and help win their trust regarding the planned biobank, Tsai added.

An Academia Sinica plan to construct a "Taiwanese Biobank" -- based on a pool of native genes, and with the aims of running massive, cross-generation studies to understand the interconnections between Taiwanese and the local environment, and enhancing the efficacy of disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment -- was shelved last year after human rights groups intervened to voice aboriginal people's doubts and anger regarding the plan.

Meanwhile, Lee Jui-chuan, director of National Central University's Institute of Philosophy, said the indigenous people as well as the general public are hesitant to embrace the plan due to fears that their genes and genetic data might be abused, resulting in their privacy being infringed or their families stigmatized.

Lee suggested that together with the establishment of the "Taiwanese Biobank, " there should be a feedback mechanism to allow genetic donors to be reasonably rewarded if any commercial dividends result from the establishment of the biobank.

Also speaking at the colloquium, Lee Tsung-hsi, director of National Dong Hwa University's Institute for Financial and Economic Law Studies, said current laws and statutes in this country are insufficient to govern the establishment and operations of a human genome center.

He said related laws and statutes should be beefed up since research on the human genome involves the protection of privacy of individuals and their families, and well as patent rights, rewards, and business interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST MUSEUM ON CITY COUNCIL HISTORY OPENS IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: A museum featuring the political history of the Tainan City government in southern Taiwan -- the first museum of its kind in Taiwan -- opened Sunday.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Tainan Mayor Hsu Tian-tsair and Tainan City Council Speaker Huang Yu-wen jointly presided over the inauguration of the museum, which is housed in the 72-year-old former Tainan City Council hall.

To mark the museum's inauguration, the city government organized an exhibition featuring relevant historical materials, including the history of the city council, council speakers and members, city mayors, local elections, development of local autonomy in Tainan City, Tainan City' present and past, the Tainan Canal and the folk tales belonging to Tainan City.

A city government official said the exhibition also showcases the most precious historical documents and materials related to local autonomy from 1946 to 1998, as well as the city's history and literary archives of the past century.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP EXHORTS UNDERPRIVILEGED STUDENTS TO STUDY HARD

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu, who is running in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's 2008 presidential primary, encouraged disadvantaged school children Sunday to study hard to make a difference in their lives.
Lu made the remarks while presiding over the opening of a "Little Scholars Educational Camp" at Hsinpu Elementary School in Taoyuan County as part of her community outreach activities.
The camp is part of a project she and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng jointly initiated to provide more educational resources to children of impoverished families.

In view of a widening digital divide between rich and poor school children, Lu has invited Wang to launch similar camps around the country to help disadvantaged children get access to after-school tutoring free of charge. Such children include: those from families with low income, those born to foreign espouses and those from single-parent or aboriginal families, as well as those raised by their grandparents.
On Sunday Lu also attended the inauguration of six associations supportive of her presidential bid in the northern county where she once served as magistrate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDATE FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP TO RETIRE AFTER 2008 PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: A former vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Sunday that if he is elected KMT chairman, he will consider retirement after the 2008 presidential election no matter whether the KMT ticket wins or loses the election.

Speaking in a TV debate with another contender for the KMT chairmanship, Wu Poh- hsiung said that if elected KMT chairman, he would be willing to quit the post to accept responsibility if the party loses the presidential election in 2008.
"Even if the party wins the election, I would consider retiring, because after completing my task, I would have no regrets in doing so," he said.

Wu said he found it "traumatic" to see former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, whom he described as a man noted for his "integrity and clean image" in Taiwan's political circle, indicted on charges of embezzling special funds designated for use at his discretion while he served as Taipei mayor.
Wu added that after careful consideration, he decided that the best way to help the KMT win the 2008 presidential election would be for him to become the next KMT chairman.
"If I evade such a responsibility, I would regret it for the rest of my life," he said, adding that if, by serving as KMT chairman, he can help the party return to power, he will "die a happy man."

At the TV debate held by TVBS, Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, another contender for the KMT chairmanship, said that, if elected the next KMT chairwoman, she would support the KMT presidential candidate with the greatest chances of defeating the opponent from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the 2008 election.
She acknowledged that she will back Ma as the KMT presidential nominee because he is currently seen as having the greatest chance of winning the election.
The KMT chairmanship became vacant after Ma resigned in mid-February following his indictment on charges of corruption by a public prosecutor.

Wu served as acting chairman for one month in his capacity as the most senior vice chairman among the KMT's four deputies before resigning his post on March 14. Vice Chairman Chiang Ping-kun is now the acting KMT chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUAN FOREIGN MINISTER WELCOME TO VISIT TAIWAN ANYTIME: MOFA

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan Minister of Foreign Affairs Samuel Santos is welcome to visit Taipei at his convenience, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chieh-yeh said Sunday.

Wang made the remarks after a local newspaper reported earlier in the day that Santos had canceled his plans to visit Taiwan at the head of a delegation to discuss feasible bilateral cooperative projects in various fields.

Santos signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with his Taiwanese counterpart, James Huang, at Managua International Airport Jan. 11 on bilateral trade and investment cooperation, with President Chen Shui-bian acting as witness.

On that occasion, he also announced that he would headed a delegation of officials and business executives to visit Taiwan in March to flesh out details on future cooperation. The MOU was the first diplomatic document Nicaragua has singed with a foreign government after Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega took office a day earlier.
Due to his busy schedule, Santos failed to come to Taiwan in March. Wang affirmed Sunday that Taiwan will welcome Santos' visit at any time of his convenience.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's ambassador to Nicaragua, Hung Ming-ta, said Santos has rescheduled his Taiwan travel plan to late April.

Hung told the CNA correspondent stationed in Panama City by phone that Santos now plans to depart Managua for Taipei in late April to deliver on his promise to visit Taiwan. Nevertheless, Hung said, the exact itinerary of Santos's planned visit has yet to be finalized.
Hung also said the Nicaraguan government has decided in principle to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan while seeking to develop commercial ties with China.

According to Hung, Ortega has indeed expressed an interest in forging relations with China. "But Ortega has not used the term of 'resuming diplomatic ties with China' as claimed by the news media, " he added.

Noting that Taiwan respects Nicaragua's foreign policy, Hung said Taiwan would be pleased to see Nicaragua develop commercial ties with other countries, including China. "We would not oppose our diplomatic allies forging unofficial or non-diplomatic links with China, " he added.
In the run-up to the Nicaraguan presidential election last year, Hung recalled that Ortega's Sandinista party had indeed considered "resuming" diplomatic ties with China if it returned to power.

Through his assiduous efforts, Hung said he managed to meet with Ortega three times before the latter's inauguration, including a meeting held at his home, and obtained Ortega's verbal promise to maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
As a result, Hung said Ortega assured President Chen after his inauguration that Nicaragua's diplomatic relations with Taiwan will remain unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO ADDRESS NEW CHALLENGES TO ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: To ensure economic growth in the 21st century, the government needs to adopt new strategies to grapple with emerging challenges, such as graying population and degradation of the environment and the atmosphere, a business celebrity said Sunday.

Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) -- the world's top contract chip maker -- made the remarks while delivering a keynote speech titled "Emerging Challenges to Economic Growth" at the Ketagalan Institute in Taipei City.

Chang said that market economics were victorious in the 20th century, as western Europe, Japan, Asia's Four Little Dragons, China, Russia, and eastern Europe all experienced substantial economic growth by following in the footsteps of the U.S. in moving towards market economies.

He added that Taiwan could improve its economic performance by means of conducting educational and legislative reforms, bolstering infrastructure development, and promoting cultural, artistic and moral values.

He said that the emerging challenges to economic growth include depletion of water and other natural resources, the degradation of the environment, pollution of the atmosphere, the impact from global economic competition, graying populations, and the people's high expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE ACTIVISTS CALL FOR REDESIGNATION OF MEMORIAL HALL

TEXT.P: A group of pro-independence activists erected a new signboard at a memorial park dedicated to the late President Chiang Kai-shek in downtown Taipei Sunday to push the government to rename the complex as the "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park."

The activists, led by Peter Wang, convener of the 908 Taiwan Republic Campaign, urged the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration to respond positively to their call for dismantling the stone walls of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex and redesignating it as the "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park" before the end of this month.
Otherwise, Wang said his organization will demolish the wall on its own in May.

Wang and his followers held a ceremonial ritual at the main entrance to the complex to symbolize their determination to topple the "feudalistic walls" and push for the opening of the location as a "democracy plaza." At the end of the ritual, they erected a wooden signboard near the gate that reads "Taiwan Democracy Memorial Park." The signboard was removed by security guards shortly afterwards.

The ceremonial ritual took place a day after the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) staged a protest march through Taipei to defend Chiang whom the DPP administration has begun harshly criticizing -- 32 years after his death.

Earlier this year, President Chen Shui-bian said at an occasion marking the 60th anniversary of the tragic 228 Incident that Chiang was responsible for the suppression of the mass uprising on the island in 1947 against his government's rule that claimed as many as 30,000 lives.

The KMT-organized protest came as the DPP administration has stepped up its efforts to remove Chiang's statues from public places throughout Taiwan and remove references to China from state-run companies and institutions.

Chanting "Love Taiwan, defend the Republic of China," the largely elderly crowd circled around the large square that surround the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, housing a massive bronze statue of the former leader, who once ruled China.
Chiang, who died in 1975, has been a controversial figure in Taiwan since fleeing here in 1949 with his KMT government after losing a civil war to Mao Zedong's Communists on the Chinese mainland.
The DPP administration plans to rename the landmark hall in central Taipei and has pushed for the island to use Taiwan as its title for membership in international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT IDENTIFIES MAJOR OBSTACLES TO TAIWAN'S NATIONAL GOAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that the previous "party-state" system, cultism and greater China consciousness have been major stumbling blocks to Taiwan's ultimate goal of becoming a normal and complete modern country.

Speaking at a ceremony marking the seventh anniversary of Ketagalan Institute, Chen said those stumbling blocks have also threatened the goal of defending Taiwan's democratic status quo and peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Under the party-center governing system which characterized the previous Kuomintang (KMT) rule, Chen said the interests of the ruling party took precedence over the national interests. As a result, the military served the ruling party's interests and the public money and properties were often used for partisan interests.

Noting that such a system violates the democratic principles that require fair competition among different political parties and separation of the state and the ruling party, Chen said his administration opposes such a system and is thus determined to push the KMT to return its ill-gotten party assets to the national coffers.

Chen further said that his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opposes cultism. Against this backdrop, he said, the DPP administration feels compelled to shed light on the late President Chiang Kai-shek's suppression of human rights and hold him responsible for the infamous 228 Incident of 1947 in which many innocent people were killed brutally.

In order to safeguard Taiwan's distinct identity and its hard-won democratic system, Chen said, his administration must push for the birth of a new constitution that fits Taiwan's situation and must get rid of reference to China from state-own companies and various institutions.

"All these efforts are aimed at preserving Taiwan's democratic status quo and its separate national identity as well as safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait, " Chen said, adding that none of these actions have anything to do with fanning ethnic rifts and conflicts.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Poor Nations to Bear Brunt as World Warms
The world's richest countries, which have contributed by far the most to the atmospheric changes linked to global warming, are already spending billions of dollars to limit their own risks from its worst consequences, like drought and rising seas. @@But despite longstanding treaty commitments to help poor countries deal with warming, these industrial powers are spending just tens of millions of dollars on ways to limit climate and coastal hazards in the world's most vulnerable regions - most of them close to the equator and overwhelmingly poor.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Bagnasco: No to civil union bill.
Italian Episcopal Conference chief Archbishop Angelo Bagnasco reiterated the church's opposition to a proposed civil union bill which will give rights to cohabiting couples, including gay ones. If approved, he said, the bill will lower moral values.

The ceremonial ritual took place a day after the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) staged a protest march through Taipei to defend Chiang whom the DPP administration has begun harshly criticizing -- 32 years after his death.

The KMT-organized protest came as the DPP administration has stepped up its efforts to remove Chiang's statues from public places throughout Taiwan and remove references to China from state-run companies and institutions.

Chanting "Love Taiwan, defend the Republic of China," the largely elderly crowd circled around the large square that surround the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, housing a massive bronze statue of the former leader, who once ruled China.
Chiang, who died in 1975, has been a controversial figure in Taiwan since fleeing here in 1949 with his KMT government after losing a civil war to Mao Zedong's Communists on the Chinese mainland.
The DPP administration plans to rename the landmark hall in central Taipei and has pushed for the island to use Taiwan as its title for membership in international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT IDENTIFIES MAJOR OBSTACLES TO TAIWAN'S NATIONAL GOAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that the previous "party-state" system, cultism and greater China consciousness have been major stumbling blocks to Taiwan's ultimate goal of becoming a normal and complete modern country.

Speaking at a ceremony marking the seventh anniversary of Ketagalan Institute, Chen said those stumbling blocks have also threatened the goal of defending Taiwan's democratic status quo and peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Under the party-center governing system which characterized the previous Kuomintang (KMT) rule, Chen said the interests of the ruling party took precedence over the national interests. As a result, the military served the ruling party's interests and the public money and properties were often used for partisan interests.

Noting that such a system violates the democratic principles that require fair competition among different political parties and separation of the state and the ruling party, Chen said his administration opposes such a system and is thus determined to push the KMT to return its ill-gotten party assets to the national coffers.

Chen further said that his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opposes cultism. Against this backdrop, he said, the DPP administration feels compelled to shed light on the late President Chiang Kai-shek's suppression of human rights and hold him responsible for the infamous 228 Incident of 1947 in which many innocent people were killed brutally.

In order to safeguard Taiwan's distinct identity and its hard-won democratic system, Chen said, his administration must push for the birth of a new constitution that fits Taiwan's situation and must get rid of reference to China from state-own companies and various institutions.

"All these efforts are aimed at preserving Taiwan's democratic status quo and its separate national identity as well as safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait, " Chen said, adding that none of these actions have anything to do with fanning ethnic rifts and conflicts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 2, or the 15th day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new U.S. currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: Britain's Admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro- French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, the Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, the French realist novelist whose books include "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, the American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first U.S. movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is re-elected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falkland Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with ROC President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to Taipei. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian denies that he sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainalnd China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.
2001: Exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama says in Taipei that he wants to pursue "a genuine autonomy" for Tibet, not independence. He makes the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
CABINET TO UNVEIL INVESTIGATIVE REPORT ON NCC TRANSGRESSIONS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will soon unveil an investigative report on legal infractions or transgressions by commissioners of the controversial National Communications Commission (NCC), an official said Monday.

According to the official who preferred anonymity, the Executive Yuan formed a special task force in mid-February to investigate whether the NCC was guilty of dereliction of duty or in violation of any laws in reaching an out-of-court settlement late last year with Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC) over a 2004 decision by the Government Information Office to reclaim two BCC-controlled radio channels.

The task force was headed by Minister-with-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung. After more than a month of intensive probes, the official said, the task force has come up with a comprehensive investigative report that identifies 10 transgressions involving various NCC members.

Noting that revoking the BCC control of the two radio channels is the government's established policy, the official said the NCC is not authorized to override the Executive Yuan's decision by settling the issue with BCC out of court.

Moreover, the official said the task force discovered other transgressions, including three commissioners illegally taking part-time jobs and one other commissioner having his son serve as his officially paid chauffeur.

The report also pointed out that two commissioners were present at meetings screening ownership transfers of two opposition Kuomintang-owned media outlets -- China Television Co. and BCC -- in violation of the principle of avoiding conflicts of interest. The two commissioners have ties with the two KMT-held media organizations.

Claiming that all of these transgressions are very serious violations of existing laws and ethical rules, the official said the task force has recommended penalties for law-breaking commissioners, including suspending them from their jobs or referring the cases to the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Functionaries or the Control Yuan for censure and discipline.
Some of the more serious cases may be referred to judicial authorities to determine whether the commissioners in question have violated existing laws against graft and corruption, the official added.

The planned release of the NCC transgressions report comes at a time when the media regulatory body has been under fire for its decision last Friday to fine two cable TV channels -- TVBS and TVBS-N -- and demand the resignation of the TVBS president over the mishandling and broadcasting of a gangster's video, with some arguing the punishment was not harsh enough and others criticizing the commission for "crossing the line."

The Executive Yuan official said the timing is purely coincidental as the task force began the probes into the NCC legal transgressions long before the outbreak of the recent "gangster's footage" controversy.

The NCC was created last year, with commissioners recommended by major political parties in proportion to the number of seats the parties hold in the Legislative Yuan. Such a partisan-based formation has been declared unconstitutional by the Council of Grand Justices, which has set Dec. 31, 2008 as deadline for disbanding the body. The NCC commissioners already determined to step down when the tenure of the current legislators expires Jan. 31, 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN AGAINST FOOT-AND-MOUTH DISEASE ENTERS CRITICAL PERIOD

TEXT.P: The campaign to rid the country of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) has entered a critical period, with hog ranches around Taiwan gradually halting the vaccination of their pigs in five phases beginning Monday.

Council of Agriculture (COA) officials in charge of animal health inspection and quarantine urged local hog and swine farmers to cooperate with the government in efforts to wipe out the highly contagious animal disease once and for all.
FMD is one of the most contagious diseases among mammals and has a great potential for causing severe economic losses. It affects cloven-hoofed animals.
A major FMD outbreak in March 1997 dealt a severe blow to Taiwan's hog industry, as FMD-affected countries are banned from exporting pork and related products.

The outbreak 10 years ago led to the culling of millions of hogs, and all pig farmers have since been required to have their animals vaccinated regularly. Thanks to the concerted efforts of the public and private sectors, no further FMD cases have been reported since February 2001.
On May 22, 2004, the Paris-based World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) recognized Taiwan as an "FMD-free zone with vaccination."

The government's ultimate goal is to obtain OIE certification as an "FMD-free zone without vaccination" in two years, COA officials said, adding that to attain this goal, local hog ranches must stop vaccinating their livestock in a gradual manner beginning this month.

On an experimental basis, inoculation of pigs raised on the outlying island of Penghu has been suspended since March 2006. As the program has proceeded smoothly, the COA has decided to expand the experiment to hog farms on Taiwan proper in five stages.

Each stage will last for four months. In the first stage, only hogs raised in the center pen of each ranch should stop receiving FMD inoculation. Those hogs will be subject to close surveillance for health checks.

In the second stage, inoculation should stop for pigs in one pen in each barn, and in the third stage, vaccination should cease for pigs in one-third of pens in each barn. In the fourth stage, inoculation should stop for pigs in half of the pens in each barn.

In the first four states, inoculation of stud pigs and grass-eating herbivores, including cattle, goat and deer, will not be ceased. If all goes well, the vaccination cessation project will enter the fifth and final stage in August 2008, with an across-the-board suspension of inoculation.

According to OIE regulations, a country can be listed as "FMD-free without vaccination" only if no vaccination has been administered for a full year and if no new FMD cases have been reported during that period, which means that Taiwan may reclaim "FMD-free zone without vaccination" status in 2009 at the earliest.

After Taiwan was declared an "FMD-free zone with vaccination" in 2004, pork exports to Japan were partially resumed -- for cooked or processed pork products -- with an annual value of about NT$100 million (about US$3.03 million).
Prior to the 1997 epidemic, Taiwan raised more than 14 million hogs a year, with annual production value amounting to NT$100 billion, half of which was generated from pork exports to Japan.

The disease has had a seriously adverse impact on Taiwan's livestock and foodstuff industries. Over the past decade, Taiwan's annual hog production has dropped steadily, to only 7.09 million hogs last year, with the industry's total annual production value falling to below NT$60 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER BLASTS MINISTER OVER SEXUAL HARASSMENT IN MILITARY

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislator demanded Monday that Defense Minister Lee Jye "give the country an explanation" over allegations of the widespread existence of sexual harassment in the military.

Hsueh Ling accused Lee of "leadership failure" which she said has allowed the problem of sexual harassment to continue in the military, adding that this has in turn caused military discipline "to go down the drain."

At a news conference that she called at the Legislative Yuan, Hsueh said several female officers have raised complaints with her about inappropriate behavior by Vice Adm. Chao Lien-ti, including forcing female officers to kiss him during soirees of military personnel and their partners.

Chao, currently the head of an electronic intelligence office under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), was accused of forcing several female subordinates to kiss him at gatherings last December and February of this year.

Chao was also accused in unsigned complaint letters of abusing his power by using three cars along with three chauffeurs at the MND's expense. One of the cars was reportedly used exclusively to serve his wife, Hsueh quoted a front- page China Times report as saying.

Noting that female members of the military have long suffered sexist remarks and offensive behavior, Hsueh said the military should be an equal-opportunity workplace, adding that she does not exclude the possibility of disclosing more cases of similar sexual harassment in the military if the MND fails to tackle the Chao case appropriately.

Responding to Hsueh's accusation, Deputy Defense Minister Chu Kai-sheng confirmed that Chao has already been transferred and that investigations have begun into Chao's alleged inappropriate behavior and abuse of his position.

DOC.HEADLINE: TVBS CHIEF STEPS DOWN AMID OUTCRY OVER STAGED GANGSTER VIDEO

TEXT.P: TVBS General Manager Lee Tao quit Monday, two days after the National Communications Commission (NCC) ordered him to step down over TVBS' broadcasting of a staged video on March 26.

In a brief statement, Lee said he regrets deeply and feels sorry for failing to find out in time that a taped death threat purported to have been sent to TVBS by a wanted gangster was actually made by a TVBS reporter.
Noting that TVBS crew members are all excellent journalists, Lee appealed to the public to give them a second chance to mend their ways and prove their great abilities.
The outspoken critic of President Chen Shui also said he hopes his resignation will calm down those politicians offended by TVBS in the past and stop them from further trying "to wipe out TVBS."
The controversial tape in which a gun-flaunting gangster threatens to kill another mobster in a personal feud caused a public outcry.

Although the gangster was nabbed by police on March 29 before he could carry out his threat, the controversy didn't die down because the police found the tape was shot with the help of a TVBS reporter.

Although the TVBS management argued that the reporter pulled the wool over their eyes by falsely claiming that the tape had been made by the gangster and sent to him, the public, not to mention politicians from President Chen on down who had been criticised by TVBS, have jumped at the chance to push the NCC to revoke the TV station's operating license.

The NCC, which has been criticized by these politicians as being too lenient in imposing a "paltry" NT$1 million (US$30,211) fine on TVBS, was challenged by TVBS supporters for ordering the replacement of Lee Tao, claiming that the NCC has exceeded its authority by interfering with the governance of a private company.

Lee's decision to quit on his own Monday obviously will spare NCC the trouble of finding a legal basis for its decision to force him to step down, although it has yet to convince TVBS critics that the punishment is the most the commission can hand down within its authority.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL INVESTIGATION TASK FORCE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A special investigation team of the Supreme Prosecutors Office formally began operations Monday in the fight against serious law offenses that could profoundly affect the country's development.

State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming, Vice Minister of Justice Lee Chin-yung, and Chen Yun-nan, director of the special investigation team, jointly hosted a ceremony marking the task force's inauguration.
The special team, with around 40 members, including nine experienced prosecutors respected for their great virtue and abilities in cracking down on crime, is being headed by Chen Yun-nan.

Under the Court Organic Law, Lee said, the team is in charge of probes into alleged bribery and other irregularities involving the president, vice president, heads of the five government branches -- the Executive Yuan, the Legislative Yuan, the Judicial Yuan, the Examination Yuan and the Control Yuan -- as well as generals and Cabinet members.

The team is also commissioned to take charge of efforts to crack down on illicit practices related to national elections, including the presidential election and the legislative elections, as well as major corruption and economic crimes.
According to the law, the head of the investigation task force is designated by the state public prosecutor-general from a pool of six to 15 prosecutors named to serve on the team.

While conducting a probe into an alleged crime, the prosecutors may launch searches and interrogations, issue warrants to bring suspects into custody, and present indictments at any place in the country.
Whenever the special team concludes a probe, it is then the state public prosecutor-general's duty to present the results of the probe to the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER NOT TO RUN IN KMT PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday he will not run in the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) primary for the 2008 presidential election because the party's rules are custom-made to cater to a "certain individual" and therefore cannot ensure a fair contest.

Wang, a former KMT vice chairman, made the announcement in an unusual reading out of a statement at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan a day after former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said he will run in the next presidential election even if he is convicted of corruption in the first trial.

As the KMT charter stipulates that any party member who is convicted in the first trial is not eligible to run in any political election under the party's banner, Ma's insistence on joining the presidential election would require a revision to the party charter.

Wang lamented that the KMT has been dominated by a minority ethnic group since it moved its seat to Taiwan from China in 1949. As this phenomenon has never been addressed, he said, the party has failed to win grass-roots majority support, which eventually resulted in its loss of power in the 2000 presidential election.
If the party continues to ignore this problem, Wang said, this will definitely affect the party's performance in the upcoming legislative and presidential elections.

Anticipating that Ma will register his candidacy for the KMT presidential primary in the coming days, Wang reminded his party that the district court will also begin proceedings on Ma's alleged special allowance fund misappropriation case this week.

Warning that the court proceedings could cast clouds over the party's prospects in the 2008 presidential election, Wang said the party should urgently establish a crisis management mechanism to ensure that the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance" will not be absent from the 2008 race because of judicial or political factors.

At this critical moment, Wang said, the party needs forward-looking planning. As to Ma's announcement of his intention to invite Wang to serve as his running mate, Wang said he will not consider such an offer at the moment.
Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of embezzling NT$11 million (US$332,684) from a special allowance fund budgeted for his discretionary use during his term as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN FAILS TO ADDRESS DONATION SOLICITATION ISSUE: MOI

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Monday the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, has not done anything to deal with donation solicitation by a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Lee made the remarks after DPP Legislator Sue Huang asked about an announcement by Shih Ming-teh the previous day that he will begin the next stage of a campaign to depose President Chen Shui-bian and that he will solicit new donations for the cause.

Huang alleged that Shih solicited donations from the public illegally last August, with the amount collected in a short period of time surpassing NT$100 million (US$3.03 million), and that the government has failed to address the situation properly.

Shih's "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign staged a mass sit-in in front of the Presidential Office for days in September. At one point, he led large numbers of "red shirt" protestors to encircle the president's official residence and the Presidential Office to demand that the president resign over a series of alleged scandals surrounding his family members and close aides.
Lee noted that cash given to those taking part in presidential, legislative and other types of elections as well as political activities is categorized as political donations.

Those who solicit donations must open special accounts at the Control Yuan in order to be able to receive the money, but Shih's campaign has not opened an account, and this is why the Ministry of the Interior has turned the case over to the Control Yuan, Lee said.
According to the Political Donation Law, the Control Yuan is responsible for the auditing and the meting out of fines. However, Lee lamented, the Control Yuan "has so far done nothing."
In response, an official of the Control Yuan said Monday that it cannot deal with the matter in view of the fact that the Control Yuan seats have yet to be filled.

The seats have remained vacant since the term of the previous Control Yuan members expired in January 2005. The opposition-controlled legislature has continued to refuse to confirm the president's list of nominees to serve on the Control Yuan.

Hsieh Yu-nan, director of the Control Yuan's Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Department, said Monday that under the Political Donation Law, those who open up special accounts must be political parties, political groups or candidates in elections, adding that whether Shih, as the head of the campaign, falls within this category remains to be discussed.
A committee comprised of Control Yuan members should first decide whether Shih's activities should be regulated under the law, Hsieh said.

Hsieh also said that he had asked Shih about how the donated money has been spent last year. The campaign headquarters sent a message to the Control Yuan, saying that it had spent about half of the collected money. The Control Yuan has not kept track of the campaign's expenses since the protests petered out late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MEN NABBED IN KINMEN FOR ILLEGAL ENTRY

TEXT.P: A resident of the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen and two of his brothers- in-law from China were nabbed early Monday morning for illegally entering into Republic of China territory, officials from Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Kinmen station said Monday.

Yeh Chien-lung, 31, a resident of Kinmen's Chinhu rural township, was monitored by a CGA radar while accompanying two Chinese men -- identified as Liu Zhengshun, 27 and Liu Zhengyong, 24, who are Yeh's brothers-in-law from the southern Chinese province of Hunan -- in an attempt to sneak into Kinmen aboard a Fujian fishing boat at 1: 56 a.m. Monday.

The three men -- apprehended for attempting to land on a beach in Liehyu, a small island to the west of Kinmen, without entrance papers -- were handed over to the Kinmen District Prosecutor's Office for questioning, CGA officials said.

According to Yeh, he traveled to Xiamen City in Fujian Province two days ago to meet with the Liu brothers before the three set off from Xiamen for Kinmen Sunday night aboard a Fujian fishing boat with the idea that the Liu brothers could visit Kinmen and enjoy a leisurely tour after visiting Yeh's wife -- their sister -- and the Yehs' new born baby.

Due to difficulties in applying travel documents to Kinmen, the Liu brothers decided to travel illegally -- each paying 10,000 Chinese yuan to the Fujian fishing boat owner for a sail from Xiamen to Kinmen. Yeh himself also paid 2,000 yuan for accompanying the Liu brothers on the trip, according to Yeh.

Lee Nien-chiao, head of the CGA Kinmen operation, said the Kinmen coast guard forces have stepped up patrol and surveillance efforts recently as Kinmen has entered a foggy season, which provides smugglers with golden opportunities to operate unseen.
