DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI CITY HOLDS INTERNATIONAL CAMPING ACTIVITY

TEXT.P: Chiayi City is holding a four-day international camping activity at the city's Lan Tan camping area from April 1-4 to celebrate the centennial anniversary of (international scout), a local official said Monday.

Over 100 scouts have been invited by the city government to join the activity, including 24 scouts from Japan's Yokohama City, 13 from Japan's Nagoya City, two from the Philippines, and 76 scouts from Chiayi City.

Toshio Sekido, leader of the Yokohama team said that he has visited Taiwan many times but that most of his team members are visiting for the first time. Sekido also said that he has been impressed by Chiayi City's beautiful scenery and friendly people.

One of the members of the Yokohama team, an elementary school teacher, invited each scout taking part in the camping activity to search for the "Ma Tzou Tao", which used to serve as a road for horse-drawn vehicles in the city in the past. "The road is now a very meaningful place for the people of Yokohama City, which has a population of 3.5 million," she added.

On the first day of the camping activity, the scouts engaged in folk culture exchanges and several outdoor activities. Chiayi City's scouts demonstrated the folk crafts of making flour miniatures, costa cards and colored scarves, while the scouts from Japan made delicate zoris and origami birds under the guidance of teachers.
During the four-day activity, the scouts will visit Chiayi Park and Chiayi City God Temple and Museum as well as Alishan to experience Taiwan's wonderful mountain scenery, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed marginally higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 0.58 points to close at 7,884.99.

The bourse opened at 7,888.17, and fluctuated between 7,931.99 and 7,866.59 during the day's trading. A total of 4.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.04 billion (US$3.47 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.

Machinery and electronics shares remained unchanged, while three other stocks gained ground, with textile stocks moved up 1.0 percent, foodstuff issues up 0.9 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares up 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 646 to 472, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPRINTS GREATLY REDUCED MOTORBIKE THEFTS: TAIPEI POLICE

TEXT.P: Imprinting identification numbers on motorbikes has greatly reduced thefts, the Taipei City Police Department (TCPD) said Monday.

The National Police Agency last March launched a program that provides motorcycle owners with free imprinting of a serial engine number or license plate number on several parts of their bikes, with the aim of discouraging thieves by making disposal of their loot more difficult.

TCPD tallies showed that it has assisted in the imprinting of 215,000 motorcycles since the beginning of the program. Officials said the reported number of motorbike thefts from July 2006 to Feb. 2007 in its precinct has dropped by 12.62 percent compared to the same period a year earlier: specifically, from 6995 cases to 6112.

The government has this year made motorbike imprinting compulsory by making it a condition for vehicle license renewal and ordering that motorbike manufacturers put identification numbers on their products firsthand.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Clinton Shatters Record for Fundraising; Edwards Also Passes 1st-Quarter Benchmark.
Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton (D-N.Y.) raised $26 million in the first quarter of the year, almost three times as much as any politician has previously raised at this point in a presidential election, officials with her campaign announced yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINI THORACOSCOPE HELPS REDUCE PNEUMOTHORAX RELAPSE RATE

TEXT.P: The mini thoracoscope has been used in clinical treatment of pneumothorax since 2001 and has helped reduce the relapse rate from 8 percent to 2 percent, sources at National Taiwan University Hospital said Monday.

Chen Jin-shing, an expert on thoracoscopic surgery in the NTUH's Department of Surgery, explained that the hospital began using the mini thoracoscope because it allows for minimally invasive surgery, adding that the hospital's staff have refined the operation process by using a new adhesive to reduce the chance of relapse.

Conventionally, talcum powder is used to create an adhesive effect in the surgical process, he noted. But the hospital staff came up with the idea of replacing talcum powder with the antibiotic "Minocycline, " which proved to be even more effective while also facilitating recovery. The cost of the new method is also much lower than the conventional method, he added.
According to Chen, some 250 patients have been treated with the new method at NTUH, and most of them were released within four days after undergoing surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE AND MORE PEOPLE ACCEPT CREMATION OF LOVED ONES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Concepts of interment have evidently undergone dramatic changes over the past decade given that the cremation ratio rose to 85.6 percent in 2006, a survey on burial behavior published by the Ministry of the Interior showed Monday.
Vice Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang announced the results of the survey in the run-up to the Tombsweeping Day, which falls on April 5.

Chien noted that the cremation ratio was 58.67 percent in 1997. The figure rose to 85.6 percent in 2006, showing that the public's ideas about interment have undergone dramatic changes and that cremation, not traditional burial, is now the mainstream choice.
The survey also showed that expenses for burials have decreased by NT$13,612 (US$412.5) over the past 10 years, noting that the expenses averaged NT$354,145 in 2006, down from NT$367,757 in 1997.

The survey also found that those who followed the dress code of a traditional funeral accounted for 56.4 percent, and those who wore white, grey, black or less colorful dress accounted for 40.7 percent, although those who said the ideal mourning dress should be less colorful than usual accounted for 63 percent, and those who can accept that funerals will be held after the cremation of the loved ones accounted for 48.2 percent.

The number of bereaved families asking that funeral service operators take care of all funeral-related matters accounted for 63.5 percent, while those who asked for part of the matters of a funeral accounted for 23.1 percent, while two percent of the families took care of funeral matters themselves.
Chien noted that Taiwan has entered an era in which society is graying and fewer children are being born. Funeral services will become ever more important given this trend, he argued.

Huang Li-shin, director of the MOI's Department of Civil Affairs, said that to upgrade the quality of funeral parlor operations, the ministry will actively help local governments to conduct assessments of funeral parlor operators.

The ministry commissioned Nanhua University in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, to conduct the survey on burial behavior between Aug. 1 and Oct. 15, 2006. A total of 1.009 effective questionnaires were collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF BLASTS EX-KMT HEAD FOR SEEKING PRESIDENCY AMID INDICTMENT

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun criticized Monday former Kuomintang (KMT) chief Ma Ying-jeou as a "hypocrite" and said that a political figure so lacking in integrity falls far short of the requirements of the presidency.

Yu made the remarks to reporters after Ma said a day earlier that he is resolved to take part in the 2008 presidential election even if he is convicted in the first trial of corruption charges over allegedly embezzling NT$11 million from a special municipal monthly allowance fund earmarked for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

Pointing out that Ma has always been harsh in demanding that DPP figures behave themselves, Yu accused Ma of lacking self-reflection and called him an "unclean hypocrite" that does not deserve to become Taiwan's president.
Ma's embezzlement trial will begin Tuesday in the Taipei District Court.

Speaking during an interview with the Taipei-based China Television Company Monday, Ma said that his remarks concerning his determination to participate in the upcoming presidential election were made clear Feb. 13, shortly after he was indicted over embezzlement charges earlier that same day.
Ma also suggested that some 6,500 government agency chiefs and department heads might soon find themselves mired in the same situation in the near future.
Ma, the KMT aspirant thought most likely able to beat his DPP rival, stepped down from the KMT's top post Feb. 13 and immediately announced the opening of his presidential campaign.

According to Ma, despite the corruption charges, many KMT members still want him to represent the party in the next presidential election on the grounds that the KMT's rules are much stricter than Republic of China law, which views the indicted as not guilty before a final conviction on the third trial.

Although KMT regulations exclude indicted members from running in any elections, Ma said that the purpose of the party's "exclusion rules" are "somehow different" in nature from the reason for his embezzlement charges.
"We will not hopelessly wait for death while our rivals are doing everything possible to destroy us," Ma claimed.

But Ma stressed that the KMT's intention to modify its "exclusion regulations" at this time is "very inappropriate" if it were out of an effort to secure his chances of running in the next presidential race.

The proposed regulation revision must be made with a broader vision to make it a general rule that could bail out many incumbent or retired government officials who might find themselves in similar legal trouble due to their special allowances or government subsidies, he opined.

Meanwhile, the KMT's legislative caucus displayed its full support for Ma's presidential bid despite his corruption charges, with caucus members questioning why DPP heavyweights -- Vice President Annette, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former premiers Frank Hsieh and Yu -- haven't been probed for their use of special discretionary accounts.
Ma must take part in the 2008 presidential election in the face of such a government and the investigation and judicial system, they said.

Echoing KMT lawmakers' views, their People First Party (PFP) counterparts said that they also back Ma to run in the next presidential race, as "Ma remains the most suitable hopeful" for the KMT-PFP alliance that was formally set up in January.

Tseng Tsahn-deng, legislative caucus whip of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), however, lashed out at Ma for what he called "Ma's intention to deceive voters through political mobilization."
If Ma insists on running in the coming presidential race while still on trial, it will be obvious that the ex-KMT chairman is seeking to evade prosecution through vying for presidency, Tseng said.
A political leader in a modern society must not harbor such a mindset attempting to blur the lines between politics and the judiciary, he contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: New Generation of Qaeda Chiefs Is Seen on Rise
As Al Qaeda rebuilds in Pakistans tribal areas, a new generation of leaders has emerged under Osama bin Laden to cement control over the networks operations, according to American intelligence and counterterrorism officials.
The new leaders rose from within the organization after the death or capture of the operatives that built Al Qaeda before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, leading to surprise and dismay within United States intelligence agencies about the groups ability to rebound from an American- led offensive.
Wall Street Journal:Fill Up With Ethanol? One Obstacle Is Big Oil
President Bush, domestic auto makers, farmers and others tout ethanol as a home- grown alternative to imported oil. Across the Midwest, plants that make the fuel out of corn are multiplying at a torrid pace. Yet so far, only a tiny fraction of U.S. service stations let a driver fill up with ethanol. There are a number of reasons, but one big one is resistance from oil companies.
Although some oil executives voice enthusiasm for alternative fuels, oil-company policies make it harder for many service stations to stock a fuel called E85, a blend of 85% ethanol and 15% gasoline.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 15 points to close at 7,849, with 38,270 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May increased 21 points to finish at 7,852, with 810 contracts traded, while June decreased two points to end at 7,834, with 55 contract transactions. September futures increased 24 points to close at 7,649, with 140 contracts traded, and December futures gained 37 points to close at 7,666, with nine contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,834 for April, 7,831 for May, 7,836 for June, 7,625 for September and 7,629 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

April TE futures increased 0.6 points to close at 332.7 points, with 3,483 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 0.1 points to close at 331.4, with 43 contract transactions. June TE futures decreased 0.6 to close at 331 points, with six contracts traded, and September TE futures increased 2.4 points to end at 325, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures moved down five points to close at 976, with 1,881 contracts traded, while May TF futures decreased four points to finish at 978, with 16 contract transactions. September futures remained unchanged at 970.4, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR COMPLAINS OF UNFAIR COMPETITION IN PARTY PRIMARY

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) confirmed Tuesday that she will not seek the KMT's nomination for the year-end legislative election because she believes she would never have the opportunity to fairly compete in the party primary.
KMT Legislator Joanna Lei told reporters that a comrade who may become her rival in a same district at the party primary has threatened to do everything to cause her to fall into disgrace.
Lei said she had filed a complaint with the KMT authorities concerning the threats but received no response.

KMT authorities also turned a blind eye to her warning that party primaries in some districts could be affected by "nominal members" recruited by certain politicians with the specific purpose of helping them win primary elections, Lei continued.
According to Lei, after exhausting all possible avenues, she has come to the conclusion that she could never get a level playing field in the party primary.

Therefore, Lei said, she has decided not to join the primary to seek the party's nomination for the year-end election, but will instead concentrate on doing a good job during the remaining 10 months of her current term as a legislator.
Lei stressed that she will neither register as a candidate in any other district, nor compete with other KMT members for a seat in the legislature as one of the party's legislators-at-large.

Pressed on the reason for her decision, Lei said KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih has made it clear that legislators of the New Party (NP) who joined the KMT in 2004 will not be permitted to seek the party's appointment as a legislator-at-large.

Lei and two other NP lawmakers joined the KMT in October 2004 shortly before the last legislative election. The trio kept dual party membership until August 2005 when they formally relinquished their NP memberships.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO DO MAJOR CHECKS ON COLLECTED ITEMS: MUSEUM CURATOR

TEXT.P: The National Palace of Museum said Monday that it has no plan to check its collections on a large scale in the near future.

The world-renowned museum was responding to suggestions by two lawmakers of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) who asked for more random checks as well as more collected items be checked to ensure the safety of the museum's priceless treasures.

Museum Curator Lin Mun-lee said that the museum had recently been preoccupied with a series of activities, including the 80th anniversary of the founding of the museum in Beijing and the reopening ceremony after the most comprehensive renovation since it was reestablished in November 1965 following the move of its vast trove of treasures to Taiwan.

Lin noted that the museum has no time for a large-scale study of its inventory. Moreover, since 2001, the museum has conducted random checks every season of every year to ensure that it keeps track of the collected items.
If it is necessary for large-scale monitoring, then the museum must report to the Executive Yuan and notify the Council for Cultural Affairs of its handling of the matter, Lin said.

KMT Legislators Lee Ching-an and Kuo Su-chun visited the National Palace Museum Monday to learn about the collections of the museum and their preservation in the wake of recent reports that "The Jaded Cabbage, " one of the top jade attractions of the museum, may have been damaged, although when it was damaged was not certain.

Museum officials said random checks on collected items became institutionalized in 2001. Between 2001 and 2007, the palace conducted 24 random checks, looking over an average of 1,400 to 1,700 items annually. The last major check was conducted in 1991.
The two lawmakers said that 24 checks are simply too few given that there are 650,000 collected items in the museum.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-TAIWAN BORN PRESIDENT LIKELY IN 2008: EX-KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: A non-native born president is very likely to be produced in the 2008 Taiwanese presidential election as more and more natives have forsworn notions of ethnic identity, former main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.
Ma made the comments in an exclusive interview on a program of the Taipei-based China Television Co.

Ma, the son of a mainlander who relocated to Taiwan with the KMT regime in the late 1940s after the KMT lost control of the Chinese mainland in a civil war, said that he does not believe that his background as a second-generation mainlander in Taiwan would hinder his presidential bid.

"I don't think that being a mainlander's descendant will hobble my aspiration to become a president now that a growing number of Taiwanese people are not paying attention to the ethnic background of presidential candidates," he said.
According to Ma, his running in the next presidential election would serve as a test as whether or not Taiwan society has really left ethnic disputes behind.
"I have confidence in Taiwan's people, and the country would have no future if it could not walk away from the shadow cast by the ethnic rift," he said.

Ma, the hopeful most likely to represent the KMT in the next presidential contest, stressed that he will first ask Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT stalwart, to join him on the ticket if he wins the party's nomination.

Although Ma was unsure whether Wang would accept his invitation to be his running mate, Ma said that he is very sure that the KMT cannot afford a split in the next presidential race if it wants to win back power.

Should he be elected president, Ma said he will focus his efforts on improving Taiwan's economy and relaxing restrictions on Taiwanese companies' China-bound investments, and on bolstering cross-Taiwan Strait economic exchanges.

Ma resigned from the KMT chairmanship and formally proclaimed his presidential ambitions Feb. 13, shortly after he was indicted on corruption charges earlier that same day by Taipei prosecutors over an alleged misuse of a special municipal monthly allowance designated for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.
Ma's trial for allegedly embezzling those funds will begin in the Taipei District Court Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS TO PROPOSE AMENDMENT TO COURT ORGANIC LAW

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will propose an amendment to the Court Organic Law to endow the Prosecutors' Personnel Review Committee (PPRC) with the substantial right to review planned personnel adjustments in the prosecutorial system, two KMT lawmakers said Monday.

Legislators Kao Su-po and Joanna C. Lei made the announcement at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, explaining that they proposed the amendment after the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) decided March 28 to replace 12 chief prosecutors in high and district prosecutors offices, including high-profile Hsieh Wen-ting, chief prosecutor of the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office, without seeking a consensus from the PPRC.

Kao said no one knew Hsieh would be subject to the reshuffle before March 28, noting that the move is directly responsible for the absence of nine of 17 PPRC members from a committee meeting debating the MOJ decision.

Kao described the reshuffle as the "Wednesday Massacre, " comparing it with the "Saturday Night Massacre" of Oct. 20, 1973, when then president of the United States, Richard M. Nixon, compelled the attorney general and his deputy to resign due to his own alleged involvement in the Watergate scandal.

Kao said that the existing Article 51 of the Court Organic Law states that the minister of justice has the right to make decisions on personnel adjustments, but needs to consult with the PPRC in advance.

Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin, however, nullified the PPRC's consultative function in accordance with an attempt by the Democratic Progressive Party government to line up chief prosecutors whose legal opinions favor the first lady, Wu Shu-jen, who is on trial for indictment on charges of embezzlement from a special state affairs fund set aside for the president's discretionary use, the lawmaker accused.

In this regard, Lei said, the KMT legislative caucus has decided to push for an amendment to the article to endow the PPRC, which is at present only a consultant organization to the minister of justice, with the power to screen personnel before a proposed reshuffle.
Lei added that the KMT caucus will submit the bill on the amendment to the legislative procedures committee for it to be placed on the agenda of the legislative session.

Meanwhile, in response to media inquiries on the move to transfer Hsieh away from his current position, Shih explained that the High Prosecutors Office needs to reinforce its operations in the fields of sexual offense monitoring, prisoners' human rights, and protection of the victims of crimes, which will collectively require the promotion of a new leader.
Shih also expressed his gratitude to Hsieh for his contributions, while denying that Hsieh is being replaced because of his alleged inability to fulfill recent orders.

Media reprots speculated that Hsieh's transfer might be the result of political interference, as the chief prosecutor is in charge of a probe into the first lady's alleged embezzlement. Media reports claimed that the Presidential Office had applied pressure to the prosecutor in an attempt to make him drop the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS URGED 'NOT TO GET INFLATED EGOS'
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/07 22:40:30 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A candidate for the chairmanship of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged the party's two presidential hopefuls -- former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng -- "not to get inflated egos."
Drawing on his own experience, Wu Poh-hsiung, former KMT vice chairman, said he had withdrawn from a 1994 election to help James Soong become Taiwan's first governor elected by popular vote.
"By inflating their egos, Ma and Wang will only hurt the party," Wu warned.

He acknowledged that the KMT has something to learn from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) because no matter how fierce the intraparty competition is among its candidates, the DPP will close ranks to present a united front after the party primaries.
Wu said he wished to become the KMT chairman because that would be the best way for him to help the party choose the candidate with the greatest chance of winning the 2008 presidential election.
He reiterated that if he is elected KMT chairman, he will consider retirement after the 2008 election, no matter whether the KMT ticket wins or loses the election.
Wu made the remarks on a trip to Taitung County to canvass votes from rank-and- file KMT members in the April 7 KMT chairmanship by-election. He is running against KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu.

The KMT chairmanship became vacant after Ma resigned in mid-February following his indictment on charges of embezzlement by a public prosecutor with regard to the alleged misuse of special mayoral funds during his two terms as Taipei mayor.

Wu served as acting chairman for one month in his capacity as the most senior vice chairman among the KMT's four deputies before resigning his post on March 14. Vice Chairman Chiang Ping-kun is now the acting KMT chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTORBIKE THEFTS DECREASE THANKS TO ID NUMBER IMPRINTING PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The number of motorbike thefts in Taipei has decreased considerably since police began a free service to mark vehicle identification numbers on components of motorcycles and scooters, a spokesman for the Taipei City Police Bureau said Tuesday.

Citing statistics, the spokesman pointed out that police in Taipei have etched vehicle serial numbers on 215,900 motorbikes since July last year, making it more difficult for thieves to sell their loot.

He said that between July 2006 and February this year, 6,112 motorbikes were reported as stolen, representing a drop of 12.62 percent, compared with the corresponding period from July 2005 to February 2006.
The spokesman added that police will continue to provide the free service at a number of imprinting stations in the city.
Statistics show that there are more than 11 million motorcycles and scooters in Taiwan, with approximately 700,000 new motorbikes sold on the domestic market each year.
An average of 200,000 motorbikes are stolen in Taiwan each year. Most stolen bikes are disassembled, with their parts being sold in China, the Philippines and West African countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP PROPOSES TAIWANESE DRAFT CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: A draft constitution which names the country Taiwan and adopts a parliamentary system of the government has been signed by 75 lawmakers and will be proposed to the legislature Tuesday, a civil society group that initiated the draft announced Monday.
The Constitution Reform Alliance held a news conference to unveil the draft constitution that defines the country's territory asthe area to which the Constitution is applied.
The alliance said such a provision contains the concept of 'existing national boundaries', a phrase in the Constitution of the Republic of China, and is in line with existing conditions.
The draft offers no definition of the national flag as the current ROC Constitution does, stipulating that it be defined by statue.
According to the draft, the president of Taiwan is a nominal head of state elected by a presidential recommendation committee and serving a five-year term.
The highest executive body of the state will be the Cabinet, the draft says, with the premier elected by members of the lower house of the parliament and formally appointed by the president.
Given the support of one-third its members, the lower house can put forward a motion of non-confidence against the Cabinet six months after the latter's formation, the draft says.

While the lower house stands as the major body that represents the citizens' sovereignty, a senate is elected by local autonomous bodies and indigenous people to prevent an over-concentration of power in the lower house, the alliance said.
The draft allows for future amendments to the Constitution to be ratified by a relative majority in a referendum.
Hung Yu-hung, General Convener of the alliance, described the draft asa 100 percent civil society proposalthat had not been sponsored by any political party.
Our next step will be to meet with political and opinion leaders and make constitutional reform a national movement, Hung said.

He criticized theSecond Republicdraft constitution co-authored by former Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung and unveiled half a month ago for retaining the General Provision of the ROC Constitution.
Trong R. Chai, Acting Chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, at the conference said the parliamentary system mapped out in the draft speaks to the current needs of the country.

The 148-article draft is divided into four chapters: the rights of the people, the principles of the state and the Constitution, the relations between the central government and local bodies, and the enforcement and amendment of the Constitution.

Hung said 75 lawmakers, mostly from the DPP and its pan-green ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, will bring up the draft with the Procedure Committee of the legislature Tuesday, and he called on the committee not to block it from being discussed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ASSIST SOLOMON ISLANDS IN EARTHQUAKE RELIEF: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan will offer all necessary assistance to its South Pacific ally of the Solomon Islands which was rattled by a tsunami unleashed by a massive undersea earthquake earlier in the day.
Chen said he has directed Taiwan's embassy in that country to convey sympathy and concern, and to express Taiwan's willingness to assist in post-disaster relief and rehabilitation.

Foreign wire service reports said that a magnitude-8 earthquake struck between the islands of Bougainville and New Georgia, unleashing a tsunami that pounded the western Solomon Islands on Monday, destroying entire villages and killing an estimated 15 people.

The reports quoted witnesses as saying that the wall of water triggered by the 8.0-magnitude quake was up to five meters high, and that it swamped towns, flattened homes, and sparked panic among residents of the South Pacific state.
Solomon Islands deputy police commissioner Peter Marshall said a plane would fly over the devastated area later Monday to assess damage, the reports said.

Meanwhile, Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare was quoted as having said Monday that his government was dispatching tents, food and water to victims of the tsunami-devastated west of the country.
"I would like to assure our people that as soon as the full report on the extent of the destruction is known, cabinet will decide on further assistance," Sogavare said in an address to the nation.

A team of officials and members of the Red Cross were dispatched to the western town of Munda to arrange assistance to the region, where officials said at least 15 people had been killed, foreign wire service reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA DAYBOOK FOR APRIL 3, 2007

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEX-RELATED STUDIES CAN BENEFIT SOCIETY: PROFESSOR

TEXT.P: Sex-related studies are greatly beneficial to Taiwanese society as many social problems are related to sex, according to a professor at Shu-Te University's Graduate School of Human Sexuality.
Lin Yen-chin, the director of the only school of its kind in Taiwan and Asia, made the remarks Saturday at a press conference aimed at recruiting new doctorate students.
The graduate school opened last year and recruited three students for its doctorate program -- two of whom are medical doctors while the other is an instructor at an air force college.
Two students present at the press conference said that Taiwanese society is too conservative and that people in Taiwan have many misperceptions regarding sex.
Noting that the general public has a limited understanding of studies of sexuality, Lin said that sex plays a very important role in human relationships, and in some pressing problems.

Lin pointed out that her school conducts research on the impact of sex among humans. The scope of the research includes sex education, sex therapy, sex consultation, as well as sex and society, she noted.
Sex assaults, sexual harassment and domestic violence are also covered, she added, adding that all such research can produce benefits for society.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY TO SUBSIDIZE 1,000 SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will earmark NT$80 million(US$2.4 million) this year for a project to subsidize 1,000 local elementary and junior high schools, MOE officials said Monday.
The announcement came after Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng kicked off the project with a press conference held at an elementary school in Pingtung county, southern Taiwan.
The project is part of the MOE's efforts to promote physical and art education at schools in remote areas, according to the officials.
Tu said that last year, the ministry subsidized 800 elementary and junior high schools in remote areas to purchase books, as well as equipment for physical and musical education.
This year, the education ministry has increased the number of schools to 1,000, and will provide additional budget support to these schools for the purchase of books, Tu added.
The 1,000 schools were selected from 15 out of 25 cities and counties, the minister said, adding that each school will receive an average subsidy of NT$80,000.
The project highlights the importance that the ministry attaches to the students' physical and artistic education, Tu said, expressing hope that the schools will maximize their use of the subsidy.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS DEFEND FISHING SUBSIDIES FOR RESOURCE CONSERVATION

TEXT.P: Fishing subsidies for purposes of environmental protection and marine resource conservation should be allowed, while subsidized fishing operations should be prohibited, officials from the Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture said Monday.

The officials made the remarks after Taiwan was labeled as one of the world's leading subsidizers of fishing operations following a strong stand in opposition to a comprehensive ban on government subsidies to fishing fleets at the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Japan and South Korea also strongly opposed the ban at WTO negotiations recently held in Geneva, Switzerland, the officials noted.
Taiwanese representatives will continue to explain Taiwan's stance on the issue to the international community, the officials stated.

Taiwan provides far fewer fishing subsidies than Japan and South Korea, the officials stressed, adding that Taiwan ranks 20th in the world and 11th in Asia in terms of government subsidies for fishing operations, while globally, Japan is in first place and South Korea in 12th.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTORBIKE THEFTS DECREASE THANKS TO ID NUMBER IMPRINTING PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The number of motorbike thefts in Taipei has decreased considerably since police began a free service to mark vehicle identification numbers on components of motorcycles and scooters, a spokesman for the Taipei City Police Bureau said Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ASSIST SOLOMON ISLANDS IN EARTHQUAKE RELIEF: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan will offer all necessary assistance to its South Pacific ally of the Solomon Islands which was rattled by a tsunami unleashed by a massive undersea earthquake earlier in the day.
Chen said he has directed Taiwan's embassy in that country to convey sympathy and concern, and to express Taiwan's willingness to assist in post-disaster relief and rehabilitation.

Foreign wire service reports said that a magnitude-8 earthquake struck between the islands of Bougainville and New Georgia, unleashing a tsunami that pounded the western Solomon Islands on Monday, destroying entire villages and killing an estimated 15 people.

The reports quoted witnesses as saying that the wall of water triggered by the 8.0-magnitude quake was up to five meters high, and that it swamped towns, flattened homes, and sparked panic among residents of the South Pacific state.
Solomon Islands deputy police commissioner Peter Marshall said a plane would fly over the devastated area later Monday to assess damage, the reports said.

Meanwhile, Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare was quoted as having said Monday that his government was dispatching tents, food and water to victims of the tsunami-devastated west of the country.
"I would like to assure our people that as soon as the full report on the extent of the destruction is known, cabinet will decide on further assistance," Sogavare said in an address to the nation.

A team of officials and members of the Red Cross were dispatched to the western town of Munda to arrange assistance to the region, where officials said at least 15 people had been killed, foreign wire service reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEX-RELATED STUDIES CAN BENEFIT SOCIETY: PROFESSOR

TEXT.P: Sex-related studies are greatly beneficial to Taiwanese society as many social problems are related to sex, according to a professor at Shu-Te University's Graduate School of Human Sexuality.
Lin Yen-chin, the director of the only school of its kind in Taiwan and Asia, made the remarks Saturday at a press conference aimed at recruiting new doctorate students.
The graduate school opened last year and recruited three students for its doctorate program -- two of whom are medical doctors while the other is an instructor at an air force college.
Two students present at the press conference said that Taiwanese society is too conservative and that people in Taiwan have many misperceptions regarding sex.
Noting that the general public has a limited understanding of studies of sexuality, Lin said that sex plays a very important role in human relationships, and in some pressing problems.

Lin pointed out that her school conducts research on the impact of sex among humans. The scope of the research includes sex education, sex therapy, sex consultation, as well as sex and society, she noted.
Sex assaults, sexual harassment and domestic violence are also covered, she added, adding that all such research can produce benefits for society.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 3, or the 16th day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1859: The Hsiahai Chenghwang Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taiwan, is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1881: Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian statesman who became prime minister in 1945 and led Italy during its successful post-war reconstruction, is born.
1882: Jesse James, head of the notorious outlaw James Gang and mastermind of countless bank and train robberies, is gunned down by Robert Ford, one of his own gang, at his home in St. Joseph, Missouri.
1897: German composer Johannes Brahms dies in Vienna at the age of 64. His works, which blended classical tradition with the new romantic impulse, include concertos, symphonies, chamber music, and choral compositions.
1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1922: Joseph Stalin is appointed general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1933: Four Britons in two Westland biplanes make the first flight over the peak of Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help reconstruction after World War II.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.
1971: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cameroon.
1973: The International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors Association opens its 12th convention in Taipei.
1975: S. K Chow, ROC minister of state, leaves for Riyadh to express the condolences of the Chinese government in the death of King Faisal.
1975: The Free China Relief Association marks its 25th anniversary.
1975: The ROC Control Yuan passes a resolution impeaching Hsu Chi-wei, commissioner of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1976: An 11-member Japanese Diet mission including former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi, arrives in Taipei to mark the first anniversary of the death of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: Dr. Montanaro, Paraguayan minister of the Interior, arrives in Taipei for Chiang's memorial services.
1982: Bueno Aires celebrates the invasion of the Falkland Islands while the United Nations says Argentina must pull out.
1991: Martha Graham, American dancer and choreographer, dies at the age of 97. A central figure in modern dance, she founded the Dance Repertory Theatre in New York City in 1930.
1992: Two weeks after a non-communist parliament is elected, Albanian President Ramiz Alia resigns.
1996: A plane carrying US Commerce Secretary Ron Brown crashes in stormy weather on a hillside outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing all 33 aboard.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng says that the KMT has agreed to let Defense Minister Tang Fei serve as President-elect Chen Shui-bian's premier in his "personal capacity."
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Liberian President Charles Taylor signed a joint communique Tuesday calling on all nations to resolve international differences through dialogue, negotiations and other peaceful means.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIPEI MAYOR'S CORRUPTION TRIAL OPENS

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said he had not intended to embezzle public funds and expressed the hope that justice will vindicate him as the first court hearing on his corruption trial opened at the Taipei District Court Tuesday.
Ma was indicted Feb. 13 for allegedly embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$338,500) from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use while serving as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.
Ma, as well as Yu Wen, a secretary of the Taipei City Government, appeared at the court as defendants in the case.

Outside the court, there were clashes between Ma's supporters and opponents. Scores of Ma's supporters shouted slogans such as "justice returns innocence to Ma" and "fair trial, " while Peter Wang, convener of the pro-independence 908 Taiwan Republic Campaign, questioned the different treatment given to different individuals under the judicial system, calling Ma names for insisting on running in next year's presidential election.
When asked by presiding judge Tsai Shou-shun how they plead, Ma responded by saying: "I have done nothing wrong, " while Yu pleaded not guilty.

Ma said that he had considered that the half of the "special allowance fund" that went directly into his bank accounts and for which only receipts were required for reimbursement purposes were not public funds, but instead of the nature of subsidies for local government heads as is customary for more than 6,000 ranking officials around the country.
Ma said that he had never personally handled the reimbursement process of the special allowance fund and that he had not intended or acted to do things illegally.
Prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen said in the indictment that Ma received NT$10.23 million in special allowances during his first term from December 1998 to December 2003.

However, expenditure records from Ma's bank accounts show that he spent only NT$3.49 million of that amount and failed to return the unspent portion -- NT$6.74 million -- to the national coffers, Hou continued.
From January 2004 through July 2006, Ma used NT$630,000 of the NT$5.06 million fund and kept the remaining NT$4.43 million in his account, according to Hou.
Hou contended that the unspent money during Ma's two terms, totaling NT$11.7 million, should be considered as "gains from embezzlement."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
KMT FACES TOUGH TASK AHEAD AS LEGISLATIVE CANDIDACY REGISTRATION ENDS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has a critical task ahead with the closure of candidacy registration for party nomination for the year-end legislative elections, analysts said Tuesday.

As many electoral districts saw more than one aspirant register for party nomination for the "single-member constituency" legislative elections, analysts said KMT executives will have a hard time choosing the party's candidates for those areas while maintaining party harmony and unity.

KMT Secretary-General Wu Duen-yi said the party central will do its best to choose the candidates with the best prospects through mediation. For those districts where negotiations fail to produce a candidate, he said, an institutionalized mechanism for selecting a candidate will be employed.
"The mechanism can either be a series of public opinion polls or public opinion polls plus a vote by party members," Wu said.

Initial tallies show that Taipei City's third district as well as Hsinchu City and the "plains Aborigines" community will be the most hotly contested areas, with four contenders vying for the KMT's nomination to represent the party. Seven other areas have three hopefuls competing for the party's nomination.
Meanwhile, five of the incumbent KMT legislators -- Chou Shou-hsun, Chiu Yi, Joanna C. Lei, Chang Li-shan and Lin Nan-sheng -- didn't register for the party primaries.
Among them, Chou is likely to be drafted by the KMT to run in Taipei City's Tatung-Shihlin district, which has traditionally been a stronghold of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chiu, a controversial lawmaker from the southern port city of Kaohsiung, didn't register mainly because he will soon be incarcerated for his role in a violent protest at the Kaohsiung District Court back in 2004.
Lei reportedly has dropped her re-election bid because she does not want to compete against a KMT colleague in the same district in Taipei County.

Chang, a first-term lawmaker from southern Yunlin County, didn't register because she has yet to decide whether she wants to run for re-election, and Lin from the southern city of Tainan said he didn't register primarily due to his "reluctance to sabotage party unity."

The year-end legislative elections will mark the first time that a"single-member constituency, two votes" electoral system is introduced. As the number of legislative seats will be nearly halved from the current 225 to 113 under the new system, competition within major parties and between parties in the elections is expected to be intense.

KMT Secretary-General Wu said the party headquarters plans to draft Chou Shou- hsun to run in Taipei City's Tatung-Shihlin district as he is believed to have the best chance of defeating the ruling DPP's candidate. As five other KMT members have registered for the party primary in the district, Wu said mediation is needed to pave the way for Chou's entry into the race in the district.
"We are hopeful that the mediation can succeed so that the process can serve as a model for other electoral districts to emulate," Wu said.
Under the new electoral system, Wu said, it is imperative that a single party hopeful runs for a single regional seat in each constituency.

"We should pull out all the stops to prevent defeated contenders in the party primaries from running on their own because a split vote among our grass-roots supporters would result in victory for someone else," Wu said.
As to whether any KMT primary loser is likely to quit the party and run under the DPP banner, Wu said the possibility is very low, if not nil.
"The DPP would only welcome those who can win in the general elections. At the moment, only one of our legislators, Lee Sen-zong, meets such a prerequisite, and just barely," he observed.
Besides mediating among KMT aspirants, Wu acknowledged that the party must simultaneously give priority to consultations with its "pan-blue" ally -- the People First Party (PFP).

Legislative sources said mediating to produce a single "pan-blue" candidate in certain areas will be a tall order, particularly in Taichung County's Tali constituency and Kaohsiung City's Tsoying-Nantzu district.

While PFP executives prefer to field a single "pan-blue" candidate in disputed areas, the sources said, their counterparts would like to resolve the disputes by holding public opinion polls or some other mutually acceptable way.
"Anyway, working out a compromise will be a tough test of both sides' political wisdom and willpower, " said a KMT official who preferred anonymity.

Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said he believes that if the proposal to hold the next legislative elections simultaneously with the presidential election early next year is adopted, the possibility of "pan-blue" legislative hopefuls running on their own without the party's endorsement will be lower, because the general political atmosphere in such a scenario would favor unity instead of division.
"The trend will be even more evident if former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou is formally nominated to represent the 'pan-blue alliance' in the next presidential election," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's presidential primary formally kicked off Tuesday, with former chairman Ma Ying-jeou being the first one to send someone to pick up a registration form.

Ma, who appeared at the Taipei District Court as a defendant in a corruption trial the same day, was unable to pick up the registration form himself. Nine KMT city councilmen, including such mavericks as Lin Yi-hua and Wu Chih-kang, came on his behalf.

The nine councilmen arrived at the KMT headquarters at 9:09 a.m., an auspicious time as the number nine is considered lucky in Chinese culture and the "Jeou" in the former Taipei mayor's name means "nine" in Chinese.

According to the primary process promulgated by the KMT, all aspirants can pick up forms from April 3-5 and register from May 19-22. Those who take part in the presidential primary have to put forward a deposit of NT$7 million (US$212,000) . The aspirants must pay NT$2 million when they pick up the forms, and the money will not be returned even if the aspirants do not register.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, the other possible KMT presidential aspirant, said Monday that he will not run in the KMT's primary for the 2008 presidential election because the party's rules are custom-made to cater to a "certain individual" and therefore cannot ensure a fair contest.
Wang, a former KMT vice chairman, made the announcement one day after Ma said he will run in the next presidential election even if he is convicted of corruption in the first trial.
Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of embezzling NT$11.17 million from a special allowance fund budgeted for his discretionary use during his term as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ACCEPTS GIO HEAD'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang accepted Tuesday Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Cheng Wen-tang's offer to resign over a controversy surrounding his disputed role regarding the sale of shares in the state-run Taiwan Television Enterprise (TTV).

Cheng has come under attack by opposition lawmakers in recent days after Sumio Hasegawa, a representative of Japan's Fuji TV network, accused the GIO head early this week of attempting to persuade him, during a Jan. 17 dinner gathering in Taipei, to sell the TTV shares that his company holds to the Taipei-based Liberty Time Group by citing the group's good relations with the Democratic Progressive Party administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REITERATES OPENNESS TO PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATION MEDIATION

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang reiterated Tuesday that he is willing to accept President Chen Shui-bian's mediation of a ticket for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for the 2008 presidential election.
"So long as the DPP unity can be maintained, I will accept whatever approach adopted by Chen in mediation," Su said, adding that he is open to Chen's mediation.

Su made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan when he was asked about the result of the poll published by the United Daily News earlier the same day. The poll shows that former Premier Frank Hsieh's approval rating has surged since the party's four bigwigs -- Su, Hsieh, Vice President Annette Lu and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun -- formally registered their bids last month.
"We have conducted our own public opinion polls, and the results are different," Su said.
However, he added that "we'll attached importance to all kinds of views and use them for reference."
The result of the public opinion poll showed that Hsieh is leading among the four DPP contenders bidding to represent the party in next year's presidential election.
According to the poll, Hsieh's approval rating among all eligible voters stands at 26 percent, surpassing Su, whose rating is 23 percent, for the first time.

The gap between the two widened to 10 percentage points among voters excluding those in favor of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) or People First Party (PFP) with approval rating for Su standing at 20 percent and rating for Hsieh standing at 30 percent. Both Lu and Yu trailed far behind Su and Hsieh in the March 30-April 1 poll on all eligible voters or on voters excluding KMT or PFP supporters.
Su said that if he wins the right to represent the DPP in next year's presidential election, he is willing to invite any of the other three aspirants to serve as his running mate.
He said that he will choose someone who will "take care of Taiwan's interests" and help form a ticket that has the best chance of winning the election.

However, Su stopped short of saying that he would serve as a running mate if any of the other aspirants win the party's nomination, only mentioning that "as a party member, I'll definitely stump for the nominee."
He said that the most urgent task is to take care of Taiwan's sovereignty and security and to continue to develop the economy as well as a fairer and more just society.
Su said he envisions "making Taiwan better, warmer and more just, " and not "jockeying for major posts at the expense of principles."

DOC.HEADLINE: AFTER-SCHOOL CARE EXPECTED TO BE EXTENDED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Elementary schools in Taipei City will be permitted to extend their after-school care for one hour to 7:00 p.m. under a new measure that is expected to be implemented soon, the city director of education said Tuesday.

However, Wu Ching-ji added that while the city government supports the idea to prolong the current child care courses at public elementary schools for the need of working parents who are unable to look after their children after the school day ends, it will respect each school administrations' decision on whether to extend their after-school care.
The department is informing all concerned schools around the city of the new measure, Wu added.

Wu made the announcement at a press conference held by the Federation of Parents Associations in Taipei City at the city hall. The group suggested that as the number of double-income families and single-parent families has been on a rise in the city, the municipal government should work to create a safe environment for children from such families to wait for their parents to get off work.
Many working parents are forced to send their children to private after-school classes or cram schools to provide them with supervision until the work day ends, according to the federation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POPULATION DENSITY SECOND HIGHEST IN WORLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's population density, at 632 people per square kilometer, is the second highest in the world among countries with a population of at least 10 million, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Bangladesh tops the list with a population density of 985 people per square kilometer.

Among the 25 cities and counties in Taiwan, the population density of the two largest municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- is the highest, at nearly 10,000 people per square kilometer, according to the DGBAS statistics.

The tallies indicate that Taiwan's population stood at 22.87 million at the end of 2006, up 106,000 from the level at the end of the previous year. During the year, there was a net natural increase of 69,000. Taiwan also registered a net social increase of 38,000 people, mainly due to the significant increase in immigration to the country.
The figures also showed that Taiwan's urban population stood at 15.92 million at of the end of 2006, accounting for 69.6 percent of the total population.
Meanwhile, the combined population of Taipei City and Keelung City accounted for 30 percent of the island's total population at the end of 2006, according to the tallies.

Telecom Italia has become a new center of political storm since Monday when a report revealed that the nation's biggest telecommunication group could fall in hands of Americans. DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY HELICOPTER CRASHES IN KAOHSIUNGN MOUNTAIN AREA

TEXT.P: An army helicopter crashed in southern Kaohsiung County's Chishan mountain region Tuesday, officials from the county government's fire department said.
Firefighters have been mobilized for rescue operations, the officials said, adding that the cause of the crash has yet to be determined.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCLEMENT WEATHER TO CONTINUE UNTIL THURSDAY: CWB

TEXT.P: The arrival of a continental polar air mass has brought inclement weather to most parts of Taiwan, and weather conditions are not expected to improve until April 5, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said in a forecast Tuesday.

According to the CWB, the cold front has brought showers to many parts of Taiwan and pushed the mercury down, with Danshui in northern Taiwan recording a temperature of 12.5 Celsius early Tuesday -- the lowest among all cities and townships in the country.
CWB meteorologists said that there will be a 60 percent to 70 percent chance of showers for most parts of Taiwan over the next two days and that mountainous areas might see heavy rain.
They forecast daytime temperatures Wednesday of around 16 degrees Celsius in the north, 20 degrees in the eastern part of the island, and 23 degrees in the south.
Temperatures are expected to rise from April 5, but northern Taiwan will continue to experience showers, the meteorologists said. By Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 47.92 points to close at 7,932.91.

The bourse opened at 7,894.87 and fluctuated between 7,932.91 and 7,879.88 during the day's trading. A total of 4.49 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$118.65 billion (US$3.58 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent, construction issues and textile stocks both at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with cement stocks decreasing 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 625 to 468, with 214 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 KILLED IN ARMY HELICOPTER CRASH

TEXT.P: Two people were killed in an army helicopter crash in southern Kaohsiung County's Chishan mountain region Tuesday, officials from the county government's fire department said.
The helicopter hit a transmission tower of the police-operated Public Radio System probably because of poor visibility amid heavy rain, the officials said.
Firefighters have been mobilized for rescue operations, the officials said, adding that determining the cause of the crash requires further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.098 and fluctuated between NT$33.070 and NT$33.124.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 70 points to close at 7,919, with 33,861 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May increased 62 points to finish at 7,914, with 586 contracts traded, while June futures gained 81 points to end at 7,905, with 45 contract transactions. Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

No transactions were recorded for December.
