International Herald Tribune : A bitter battle for Endesa ends.
The German energy giant E.ON agreed to drop its ?42.4 billion offer for Endesa in exchange for a promise from rival bidders to sell it part of the Spanish utility's assets. The decision ended an 18-month fight that raised questions about the commitment of member countries to Europe's open market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC, LIBYA SIGN AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The state-owned CPC Corp, Taiwan and Libyan National Oil Corp. (NOC) has signed an exploration and production sharing agreement to tap an oil field in the North African nation, CPC officials announced Tuesday.
Officials said that CPC Chairman Pan Wen-yen signed the agreement in Libya Monday, which they said will help the company's bid to set up a bridgehead for oil exploration in North Africa.

The officials noted that Libya is a major oil-producing country in North Africa and the CPC in recent years has been actively soliciting chances to explore the Libyan oil fields. It won the bid to explore Murzug 162 in southern Libya last December.

Officials noted that the CPC is planning to invest US$34 million over the next three years to drill three exploratory wells and conduct explorations. If this proves successful, it is estimated that the oil reserves could yield 500 million oil barrels.

According to the agreement, the first-stage will require five years for exploration and if no oil is found during that period, then the CPC will have to forfeit exploration right of the oil field, but if oil is found, then the development and production period will continue 25 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR LAUNCHES TAIPEI-SAIPAN SCHEDULED CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICE

TEXT.P: Eva Air, one of Taiwan's major international airlines, launched a scheduled charter service Tuesday between Taipei and Saipan -- the largest island in the Northern Marianas, a U.S. Commonwealth territory in the West Pacific.
The airline will operate two non-stop charter flights between Taipei and Saipan every week.

According to Eva Air, the flights will depart from Taipei at 10:30 p.m. every Tuesday and Saturday and land in Saipan four hours later. They will take off from Saipan for the return trips at 6:30 a.m. every Wednesday and Sunday.
The Taipei-Saipan charter service will use an Airbus 330-200, which seats 252 passengers, including 24 in business class seating.

In celebration of the launch of the service, Eva Air will select two lucky passengers from each flight between April 7 and April 17 through the drawing of lots and offer each of them a Nintendo Wii game console.
Eva Air has indicated that it plans to operate the new direct service for at least one year and then reassess market demand.
The airline previously served the Taipei-Saipan route with charter flights in 1997.
The new route is expected to bring more than 20,000 Taiwanese tourists to the Northern Marianas each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO PROMOTE INTEGRATION OF IT IN AUTOMOBILE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has vowed to help the local automobile industry integrate information technology to boost the industry's added value and expand its global market share.

Economic Affairs Minister Steve R.L. Chen made the pledge at the opening ceremony Monday for the 2007 International Auto Parts & Accessories Show (TAIPEI AMPA) and the 2007 Taipei International Automobile Electronics Show (AutoTronics Taipei 2007) at the Taipei International Convention Center.
A total of 2,301 booths have been set up at the two shows, which have drawn 995 companies from 15 countries to participate and will run until April 5.
The auto parts industry plays an important role in Taiwan's economy, with the sector's exports totalling US$4.15 billion for 2006, up 3.8 percent over the previous year, Chen said.

Chen noted that according to data compiled by IC Insight, a U.S.-based market research organization, automobile electronics accounts for 20 percent of production costs in the automotive industry, with the figure expected to rise to 40 percent by 2010 and 50 percent in 2015, adding that by that time, global production of automobile electronics is forecast to reach US$400 billion.

The Industrial Development Bureau under the MOEA is working on improving the auto parts industry's research and development, while the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration is working on an assistance project concerning automobile electronics technology, and the Bureau of Foreign Trade is helping auto parts companies expand their market share, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGED TO DEMOCRATICALLY SELECT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) urged Tuesday the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to produce its candidate for the presidency in a democratic way and refrain from "designating a successor" to President Chen Shui-bian.

TAUP Chairman Tsai Ting-kuei made a call at the TAUP-held press conference while expressing the association's concern over the outcome of the 2008 presidential election, which Tsai said will decide Taiwan's future development.
Four aspirants are vying for the DPP candidacy for the next presidency: Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, and former Premier Frank Hsieh.

Tsai expressed hope that President Chen would not designate a successor, and suggested the DPP redesign its primary system. He suggested that the party put forward a policy issue for national debate and push for a referendum on such policy issue whenever it is seeking a candidate for a major election.
Tsai further suggested that the DPP invite those who endorse its referendum proposals to join the party primary vote.

Tsai said he believes that this candidate selection approach can also help the DPP realize its goal of holding referendum on certain critical issues, such as forcing the main opposition Kuomintang to return its ill-gotten assets to national coffers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER AGREES TO GIO CHIEF'S RESIGNATION
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 3 (CNA) 04/03/07 19:46:55 (By Flor Wang) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday that he has agreed to accept Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Cheng Wen-tsang's resignation over his disputed role in a share release case involving Taiwan Television Enterprise (TTV).

Su said that he decided to accept Cheng's resignation after reading through an investigative report by Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen on the contentious case that has drawn flak from opposition lawmakers who blasted Cheng for seeking to pressure an executive of Japan's Fuji TV network to sell that company's shares in the TTV to a local investor during a Jan. 17 dinner banquet in Taipei.

Sumio Hasegawa, a Fuji TV representative, in a news conference last Sunday accused Cheng of attempting to persuade him to sell Fuji's holding of TTV shares to the Taipei-based Liberty Times Group, which Cheng claimed is Fuji TV's best choice for the newspaper's good relations with the Democratic Progressive Party government.

"It was indeed improper for Cheng to host the dinner banquet," Su acknowledged, but he added that "Cheng did not mean to intervene in the matter, which is evident in that the Japanese TV company did not sell its TTV shares to the Liberty Times."
The Fuji TV network eventually sold its TTV shares to a private company set up by former TTV Chairman Lai Kuo-chou, who was dismissed from the post in March.
According to Su, Cheng tendered his resignation Monday out of concern that the Cabinet's image might be affected due to his controversial role in the case.
The premier said that he was reluctant to accept Cheng's resignation and praised his efforts and hard work over the past one-plus year.
However, Su failed to answer reporters' questions touching on who will replace Cheng.

According to Tsai, no one in the government has been found to exploit an official capacity or government policy to force Hasegawa or anyone else to make any decision regarding anything during the banquet, in which Minister of Economic Affairs Steven R. L. Chen and Liberty Times representatives were also present.
"It is apparent that Fuji TV was not been affected by Cheng as it sold its holding of TTV shares to a private company," Tsai pointed out.

Fielding questions from opposition lawmakers during a question-and-answer session earlier the same day in the Legislative Yuan, Su denied that he was aware of the Jan. 17 banquet beforehand, and ruled out allegations that he gave Cheng a free hand to handle the TTV shares case saying that he did not instruct Cheng to host the banquet.
Su said that he has read through a report made by the Executive Yuan on the controversy and stressed that he will render a fair judgment after acquiring a full understanding of the event. ENDITEM/jnc

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: High Court Faults EPA Inaction on Emissions; Critics of Bush Stance on Warming Claim Victory
The Supreme Court rebuked the Bush administration yesterday for refusing to regulate greenhouse gas emissions, siding with environmentalists in the court's first examination of the phenomenon of global warming.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 KILLED, 1 WOUNDED, 2 MISSING IN ARMY HELICOPTER CRASH

TEXT.P: The crash of an army UH-1H helicopter has killed five of eight military officers on board, while injuring another one, in the Chungliao mountain region in Chishan Township of the southern county of Kaohsiung, military sources said Tuesday.
Two officers aboard are are still missing.

The dead were all senior officers of an army airborn cavelry brigade, including Brigade Chief Col. Chen Min-tung, Lt. Col. Ma Wen-pin, Lt. Col. Lai Yu-hung, Capt. Wu Ming-chung, who was the copilot, and Chief Technician Luo Ming-hua, military spokesman Wu Chih-fang said.

Wu said that the military helicopter took off at 15: 52 p.m. from the Kueijen base in Tainan County to perform an air surveillance drill. It lost contact eight minutes later and the military received a report of its crash at 16:30 p.m.
The helicopter crashed onto Chungliao Second Road in Chishan after hitting a transmission tower owned by the police-operated Public Radio System. No civilians were injured during the incident.
Wu said the army has grounded all of its aircraft, and launched an investigation into the crash.
A preliminary report suggests that the crash was probably caused by bad mountain weather leading to low visibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL YOUTH COMMISSION RECRUITS YOUTH TRAVEL VOLUNTEERS

TEXT.P: In an effort to promote youth tourism in Taiwan, the National Youth Commission (NYC) is recruiting 120 youth travel volunteers aged between 18 to 30 to help with the campaign, an NYC official said Tuesday.

The NYC plans to recruit 120 volunteers specialized in different fields, including 20 each for news reporting, computer operations, international tourism promotion, and 50 to promote Taiwan's campus life. Hopefuls are welcome to register through April 14.

To enhance cultural and tourism exchanges between Taiwan and Japan, the NYC is also going to solicit 10 international travel volunteers to spur Japanese youths to visit Taiwan. To be eligible, applicants must be Japanese nationals, reside in Taiwan and speak both Chinese and Japanese language fluently, the official said.
Those interested in applying for travel volunteers are required to possess experience in blog writing, Website management and international cultural exchanges, the official added.
Those selected will be require to attend a training session slated for April 27-28, after which they will be presented with certificates by the NYC and begin to carry out volunteer services.
Additionally, the NYC will grant them a certificate of service and a free study tour around Taiwan.
Application forms are available at the Website www.youthtravel.tw

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO EXPAND 'GARDENER PROGRAM' TO LURE MORE FARMING POPULATION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday it will expand its "Gardener Program" this year to attract more young people to pursue careers in the agricultural sector.

The "Gardener Program, " which was launched last August for the firms time, is designed with the aim of encouraging people -- especially those aged between 35 and 55 -- to enter the agricultural sector in an attempt to inject new blood into the ageing rural population, COA officials said.
Encouraged by public warm response to the project last year, the officials said, more training classes will be opened this time around.

This year, the council will open additional classes on the country's agricultural policies, agriculture-related industries, crop planting know-houw and developmental potential, the officials said, adding that during the classes, outstanding farmers will be invited to share their experience in growing crops with trainees.
People interested in taking part in the program can visit the council's Web site at agredu.coa.gov.tw to obtain registration forms, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOPS EAST ASIA IN PATENT-POPULATION RATIO

TEXT.P: Taiwan has topped all other East Asian countries in the patent award ranking, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The statistics show that between 2000 and 2004, Taiwan recorded an average ratio of 30.17 patents per 100,000 population -- the highest among all East Asian countries.

CEPD officials pointed out that Taiwan's average has surpassed Japan's 28.54 patents per 100,000 population, Singapore's 9.87, South Korea's 8.67, and is following closely behind the average of 33.56 for the United States.

Statistics also show that in 2004 Taiwan's expenditures on research and development accounted for 2.44 percent of the nation's gross domestic product -- behind only Japan and South Korea, but ahead of Singapore.
The officials said these figures prove that Taiwan has been playing an important role as a leading supplier of innovative technology in East Asia's production chain and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL UNIVERSITY INKS DEAL WITH MONGOLIAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: A medical university in Taiwan has inked a cooperation deal with a counterpart in Mongolia as part of efforts to help improve the dental health of the Moguls, an university spokesman said Tuesday.

The deal came after officials from Chung Shan Medical University and its College of Oral Medicine met with Bazar Amarsaikhan, Dean of School of Dentistry under Health Sciences University of Mongolia Monday in Taichung city, central Taiwan.
Chung Shan Medical University said that it will send a medical team to Mongolia this summer to provide voluntary dental services to locals.
The university will also encourage its students to go to Mongolia and promote hygiene awareness, according to the spokesman.
Meanwhile, the university will offer scholarships to Mongolian medical students and help them come to Taiwan to learn advanced dental practices, the spokesman noted.

With a shortage of medical professionals, poor hygiene and outdated hospital facilities, more than 300,000 Moguls are forced to seek medical help in neighboring countries every year, the spokesman explained.
Mongolia already sends many of its doctors to Taiwan each year, despite the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries, the spokesman pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIPEI MAYOR KNEW FUNDS WERE PUBLIC: PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: The prosecutor who indicted former Taipei mayor Ma Ying-jeou on embezzlement charges said Tuesday that Ma admitted knowing, while being arraigned, that the "special allowance fund" for the local government head is a "public fund."
Prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen made the remarks after the first court hearing of Ma's corruption trial ended at the Taipei District Court after three hours.
Outside the court, scores of Ma's supporters and opponents clashed as policemen tried to separate them, with some cheering Ma on while others derided him.

Ma said during the court hearing that he always thought that half of the "special allowance fund" went directly to his bank accounts required only receipts for reimbursement and were not "public fund, " but a personal subsidy extended to local government heads, to which he, well as to more than 6,000 ranking officials around the nation, was entitled.
But Hou noted that when first arraigned last November 14, Ma did admit that the special allowance was a "public fund" that should be used for official duties.
If Ma had any doubts about this point, he should ask the panel of judges at the Taipei District Court for a video tape of the arraignment.

Presiding judge Tsai Shou-shun asked Ma and Yu Wen, a secretary of the Taipei City government and another defendant in the case, how they pleaded. Ma said that he had no intention to do anything illegal as the prosecution alleged, while Yu pleaded not guilty.

Ma contested that Prosecutor Hou did not go deep enough to learn the nature of "special allowance fund," saying that whether the money is properly defined as public funds or a private subsidy is not yet unequivocally clear, that this point is important to reaching a conclusion as to the question of his alleged corruption, and that the lack of clarity constitutes a "major flaw" on the part of Prosecutor Hou.
Ma said that during his two terms as mayor between 1998 and 2006, he executed numerous budgets amounting to more than NT$260 billion, and he couldn't possibly know the details of each budget project.
He noted that he had never handled the reimbursement of the "special allowance fund, " which was left for the cashiers at the Taipei City Government.

He was never told to deplete the fund or return the unused portion, and that before the probe on the case, he had never read related interpretations concerning the use of the "special allowance fund." He was "completely in the dark about the fund use, " and had not "deliberately" embezzled the fund as alleged by the prosecution.
Ma also said that during his public service over the past two decades, he had donated NT$68 million to public charity, far exceeding the amount the prosecution believes he has embezzled.

The Global Views Weekly, a prestigious magazine in Taiwan, rated him as the No. 1 local government chief in terms of integrity in assessing the city and county chiefs in Taiwan, Ma said, adding that he has been proud of his clean record.
Presiding judge Tsai Shou-shun set the next court hearing for April 17.
Ma was indicted Feb. 13 on charges of embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$338,500) from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use while he served as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.
Prosecutor Hou said in the indictment that Ma received NT$10.23 million in special allowances during his first term of office, December 1998-December 2003.

However, expenditure records from Ma's bank accounts show that he spent only NT$3.49 million of that amount and failed to return the unspent portion -- NT$6.74 million -- to the national coffers, Hou continued.
From January 2004 through July 2006, Ma used NT$630,000 of the NT$5.06 million fund and kept the remaining NT$4.43 million in his account.
Hou contends that the unspent money during his two terms, totaling NT$11.17 million, should be considered "gains from embezzlement."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES US$200,000 IN QUAKE RELIEF TO SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has donated US$200,000 to the Solomon Islands as part of its humanitarian relief efforts to aid its South Pacific ally's earthquake victims, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Tuesday.
The donation came after a tsunami spawned by a 8.0-magnitude undersea earthquake hit the western Solomon Islands Monday, leaving at least 15 people dead.

Taiwan's ambassador to the Solomon Islands has visited the country's prime minister office and expressed condolences on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Su Tseng-chang, and Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang, the spokesman noted.

The MOFA also urged prospective Taiwanese visitors to the Solomon Islands to avoid traveling in the disaster areas, remain alert, and to be aware of locally issued earthquake or tsunami warnings, the spokesman pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY-DESIGNATE VOWS TO IMPROVE U.S.-TAIWAN TIES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu has vowed to continue improving relations between the United States and Taiwan after assuming the post of Taiwan's representative to the U.S.
Wu made the remarks as he received a delegation consisting of California State Assembly leaders at his office Monday.
Wu thanked the assembly for passing a resolution in 2004 in support of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).
Wu said that many Taiwanese elites received a higher education in the U.S. and therefore have special feeling towards the country.
Noting that both Taiwan and the U.S. benefit from their traditional friendship, Wu said that he will continue to strengthen bilateral relations.
He also pointed out that China often uses a carrot-and-stick tactics against Taiwan, making goodwill gestures while at the same time deploying missiles and submarines to target Taiwan, he stressed.

This year, China has increased its defense budget by 17.8 percent over last year, Wu said, adding that the expansion of Chinese military power poses a threat to Taiwan as well as to security in the Asia Pacific region.
In recent years, Beijing has spared no efforts in blocking Taiwan's participation in international organizations, including the United Nations and the WHO, he noted.
Taiwan is often unfairly and unjustly treated when engaging in many international activities hosted by non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and private sector due to China's intervention, Wu said.
Taiwan's recent moves to replace the names of state-run enterprises bearing the term "Chinese" or "China" with "Taiwanese" or "Taiwan" has raised concerns internationally, Wu stated.

In contrast, the international community remains silent when Beijing asked organizers of many international events to force Taiwanese participants to drop the official title of Taiwan -- the Republic of China -- Wu said, stressing that this is not fair to democratically governed Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-KOREA FTA TO HAVE US$2 BILLION IMPACT ON TAIWAN: CEPD

TEXT.P: The soon-to-be signed free trade agreement (FTA) between the United States and South Korea will have an estimated US$2 billion impact on Taiwan, which is equivalent to about 5 percent of Taiwan's total exports, a spokesman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.

The U.S. and South Korea reached an agreement on the free trade pact Monday, and U.S. President Bush has sent the agreement to the U.S. Congress for approval. Once signed, the U.S.-Korea FTA is expected to increase the value of trade between the two countries by tens of billions of dollars for both sides and help invigorate South Korea's economy.

The CEPD spokesman said the estimated US$2 billion impact comes from items exported by both South Korea and Taiwan to the U.S., adding that the government will keep an eye on other possible impacts such as a loss of export orders and foreign investment.
The preliminary estimate was research made by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research at the request of the CEPD.

According to the research, many of South Korea's bulk quantity exports, such as automobiles to U.S. will not directly influence the exports of Taiwanese firms, as South Korea exports whole vehicles, while Taiwan exports mainly auto parts.
A spokesman of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said the U.S.-South Korea FTA will have less influence on Taiwan's information
technology industry, but might prompt American investors to
consider South Korea a better investment environment than Taiwan,
adding that MOEA hopes for a breakthrough in signing a free trade
agreement with the U.S. in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLD NT$500, NT$1,000 BILLS TO STOP CIRCULATION AUG. 1

TEXT.P: Old NT$500 and old NT$1,000 banknotes lacking aholographic foil membrane will be pulled from circulation Aug. 1, a spokesman of the Central Bank said Tuesday.

The spokesman reminded people to exchange old NT$500 and old NT$1,000 banknotes for new ones at financial institutes before July 31. After that date, the Bank of Taiwan will be the only financial institute where people will be able to exchange old notes.

Most NT$500 and NT$1,000 bills that people have now are of the new variety, the spokesman said, adding that the new bills were printed with dark brown as the dominant color, while one thousand-dollar notes remained blue, albeit with additional counterfeit detection measures.

The spokesman said there is a holographic foil membrane on right side of the new note's front side, while the original color-changing security thread has been replaced with a wider security holographic thread on the back, right of the note.
Additionally, the Arabic numerals on the back of the new notes are printed with light changing oil-based ink that changes from gold to green, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD'S DEPARTURE USELESS IN CLARIFYING TTV CONTROVERSY: PFP

TEXT.P: The resignation of Cheng Wen-tsang as Government Information Office (GIO) minister cannot help clarify his role in a controversy regarding the sale of shares in Taiwan Television Enterprise (TTV), opposition lawmakers claimed Tuesday.

Lee Hung-chun, spokesman for the opposition People First Party (PFP) , made the comments after Premier Su Tseng-chang approved Cheng's resignation. Lee voiced the PFP's doubts as to why the Executive Yuan failed to quickly punish Cheng after the contentious case was brought to light late last month.

Sumio Hasegawa, a representative of Japan's Fuji TV network, accused Cheng, in a news conference held March 25, of trying to persuade him to sell the TTV shares that his company held to the local Liberty Times during a Jan. 17 dinner banquet in Taipei. Minister of Economic Affairs Steven R. L. Chen and Liberty Times executives were also present in the gathering, he said.
Sumio expressed his surprise that a Taiwanese government official could meddle in such a commercial matter and said Cheng's interference would be called a "scandal" if this were to occur in Japan.

Arguing that Cheng's voluntary resignation did not clarify nor bring an end to the matter, Lee demanded that Cheng provide a full explanation of why he feted a person involved in the proposed sale at the banquet.

Despite Su's approval of Cheng's resignation earlier in the same day, Lee said, it remains difficult to explain the controversial case to the public. He also accused Su of being forced to dismiss Cheng out of mounting public pressure.
Should the Executive Yuan fail to clear up the matter, the PFP will thoroughly oppose the release of government-owned TTV shares, Lee said.

Hsu Shao-ping, legislative caucus whip of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), and KMT Legislator Joanna C. Lei, insisted that Su remove Cheng and that the government halt its planned release of TTV shares until all suspicious aspects of the case have been clarified.
Commenting on Su's approval of Cheng's departure, Hsu said that such a development was expected by the KMT's legislative caucus, but they questioned why Minister Chen has not also been disciplined.
Although Cheng has to assume most of the fault for the case, Hsu said that Minister Chen also must assume responsibility for his share of the wrongdoing.

Hsu concluded that the party will wait and weigh its next move as a group of KMT legislative caucus members have filed suit against Su and Cheng for neglect of duty, and the party wants to see what punishment Su will mete out to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Justices Say E.P.A. Has Power to Act on Harmful Gases
In one of its most important environmental decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday that the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases in automobile emissions.
The court further ruled that the agency could not sidestep its authority to regulate the greenhouse gases that contribute to global climate change unless it could provide a scientific basis for its refusal.
The 5-to-4 decision was a strong rebuke to the Bush administration, which has maintained that it does not have the right to regulate carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases under the Clean Air Act, and that even if it did, it would not use the authority.
Wall Street Journal: Court Rulings Could Hit Utilities, Auto Makers
In a decision that could mark a turning point in the national debate over climate change, a divided Supreme Court ruled that carbon dioxide and other so- called greenhouse gases are air pollutants under the Clean Air Act, and that the Bush administration broke the law in its refusal to limit emissions of those gases.
The 5-4 decision was a victory for environmental groups, which had pushed for such a ruling, and a blow to the nation's auto and utility industries, among others, as well as the White House. The Bush administration has steadfastly opposed mandatory curbs on the emission of greenhouse gases, which most scientists believe contribute to global warming.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY TO U.S. ASSUMES OFFICE APRIL 14

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to the United States is scheduled to arrive in Washington, D.C. April 14 to assume office, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Tuesday.

According to the officials, the MOFA is set to hold a swearing-in ceremony April 12 for Joseph Wu -- outgoing Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) chairman -- to take his oath of office prior to his departure for the United States.
Wu paid to a visit to the MOFA headquarters Tuesday to be briefed on his new job by relevant officials as part of preparations for the new assignment, the MOFA officials said.

Wu, a political scientist who holds a doctoral degree from Ohio State University, is scheduled to meet with local journalists and foreign correspondents stationed in Taipei over a cup of tea Wednesday. He is expected to reflect on his experiences as the country's top China policy planner over the past three years and the agenda for his new post, an MAC official said.
Meanwhile, David Ta-wei Lee, outgoing representative to the United States is scheduled to leave Washington, D.C. April 12 for Ottawa to take over as Taiwan's new representative to Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA DAYBOOK FOR APRIL 4, 2007

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 4, or the 17th day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in a Brussels station.
1905: An earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the American civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1973: The Republic of China and the Khmer Republic conclude a temporary air transport agreement with an exchange of notes in Phnom Penh.
1974: The 21-member women's national basketball team returns after a tour of the United States and Brazil. The team won 24 games and lost six.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Botswana.
1974: U.S. Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy and his wife leave Taipei for retirement. He is succeeded by Ambassador Leonard Unger.
1976: Chinese at home and abroad mark the first anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek with solemn ceremonies, tributes and prayers.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1989: The Ministry of Education approves the applications of three mainlanders to visit Taiwan.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the run-up to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter at Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
1999: At the conclusion of a weeklong visit to Taiwan, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan urges Beijing to abandon threatening Taiwan with military aggression.
2000: Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi reiterates that his country's stance of supporting the Republic of China in international forums will never change.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, meets with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in Taipei to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK BOX FROM CRASHED ARMY CHOPPER RECOVERED

TEXT.P: The black box from an army UH-1H helicopter that crashed into a radio tower in bad weather in the mountainous region of southern Kaohsiung County Tuesday afternoon was recovered later the same day, officials said Wednesday.
The black box has been turned over to the Army Command for decoding in the hopes of securing valuable clues into how the crash happened, the officials said.

The chopper crashed onto a road in mountainous Chishan township in Kaohsiung County after hitting a radio tower owned by the police-operated Public Radio System amid heavy fog and rain, killing five senior officers and leaving three missing. No civilians were injured in the mishap.

More than 100 firefighters, police officers and military personnel have been mobilized for the search and rescue mission. They braved inclement weather to search for the missing throughout Tuesday night. Helicopters from the National Airborne Service Corps joined the search mission at 6 a.m. Wednesday.

The chopper from the Army's Airborne and Special Operations Command took off from the Kueijen air base in southern Tainan County at 3: 52 p.m. Tuesday for an airborne surveillance drill. It lost contact eight minutes later and the military received a report of its crash at 4:30 p.m.

The deceased officers were all from an army airborne cavalry brigade, one of the country's most elite military units. Among them were Col. Chen Ming-tung, head of the Airborne Cavalry Brigade 601 who was known for his diligence and was expected to be promoted to the rank of major general soon.
The other four were Lt. Col. Ma Wen-pin, head of an attack battalion; Lt. Col. Lai Yu-hung, a chief staff officer; Capt. Wu Ming-chung, a co-pilot; and Sgt. Maj. Luo Ming-hua, a chief technician.
Military spokesman Wu Chi-fang said that although the cause of the crash has yet to be determined, the army has grounded all of its UH-1H helicopters, pending thorough security checks.
An initial investigative report said the crash was probably caused by bad mountain weather leading to low visibility. Analysts said the age of the aircraft may have also be a factor.

The bodies of the deceased officers were first sent to a hospital affiliated with I-Shou University in Kaohsiung County's Yenchao township. Defense Minister Lee Jye visited the hospital to pay tribute to the deceased and extend his condolences to their bereaved family members.

Noting that the deceased had sacrificed their lives while flying a training mission, Lee said the military will offer the best possible pecuniary aid for their bereaved families. Lee also said the military will continue the search for the three missing officers.
Tuesday's crash was the third mishap involving the U.S.-built UH-1H chopper model since it was introduced into Taiwan in the early 1970s.

On Dec. 27, 1974, a UH-1H crashed in Lungkang in northern Taoyuan County, killing three lieutenant generals and leaving then-Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Yu Hao-chang seriously injured. Another lieutenant general on board also sustained severe injuries in the accident.

The second mishap occurred May 3, 1986 when two UH-1Hs collided in mid-air during a military review, killing all 18 paratroopers aboard. The disaster has come to be known as the "503 Calamity." Then-paratroop brigade chief Teng Chu- lin, who is now the country's representative to Poland, didn't take a single day off for three months as he insisted on accompanying the emotionally traumatized paratroop unit in passing their darkest days following the tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MORE BODIES FOUND AT MILITARY HELICOPTER CRASH SITE

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye offered his condolences for the death of eight military officers at the Kaohsiung Military General Hospital Wednesday after the bodies of three people reported missing in the crash of a military helicopter were found earlier in the day.

Rescue personnel found the three bodies in the early morning near the crashed UH-1H helicopter and the radio Public Radio System transmission tower that it had hit. The bodies were later identified as those of the three reported missing of eight military officers aboard the aircraft. The burned remains of the other five were found at the crash site earlier.

The helicopter crashed into the transmission tower in the Chungliao mountainous region of Chishan Township in the southern county of Kaohsiung Tuesday afternoon while performing a surveillance training mission, killing all eight senior officers from an army airborne cavalry brigade, one of the most elite military units.

The deceased include Col. Chen Ming-tung, head of the Airborne Cavalry Brigade 601, who was expected to be promoted to major general soon; Maj. Lin Kuo-chun, deputy chief of the brigade; Lt. Col. Ma Wen-pin, head of an attack battalion; Lt. Col. Lai Yu-hung, a chief staff officer; Maj. Chu Chih-hua, a company commander; Maj. Liu Tien-shun, pilot; Capt. Wu Ming-chung, a co-pilot; and Sgt. Maj. Luo Ming-hua, a chief technician. By Elizabeth Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL FUNDS SYSTEM NEEDS TO BE OVERHAULED: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that the system of the "special allowance funds" designated for public office holders' discretionary use is intrinsically flawed and that the whole system needs to be overhauled.

Commenting on former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's indictment for allegedly embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$338,500) from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use while serving as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006, Lu said the "special allowance funds" system is a decades-old practice that needs to be examined and revised.
"It is controversial as different people have used and interpreted it differently," she said.
Lu said Ma is not the only former or sitting official to have been affected by the defective special allowance fund system.
The vice president, however, offered no opinion on how the "special allowance funds" system should be overhauled.

Ma appeared at a hearing on his corruption trial at the Taipei District Court Tuesday, during which he said he had not intended to embezzle public funds and expressed the hope that justice will vindicate him.

Stressing that he had done nothing wrong, Ma said he had considered that the half of the "special allowance fund" that went directly into his bank accounts and for which only receipts were required for reimbursement purposes were not public funds, but instead of the nature of subsidies for local government heads as is customary for more than 6,000 ranking officials around the country.

Ma, who had doubled as chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, resigned from the KMT chairmanship Feb. 13 upon being indicted for allegedly lining his pockets during his time as Taipei mayor with a special allowance fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPENSATION TO BE PROVIDED FOR CHOPPER CRASH DEATHS: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The family members of each of the eight military officers killed in a helicopter crash in the southern county of Kaohsiung Tuesday will receive around NT$15 million (US$452,900) as compensation for the death of their loved ones, the defense minister said Wednesday.

Lee Jye informed the bereaved of the compensation while extending his condolences to them at the Kaohsiung Military General Hospital where the bodies have been sent. He also promised to ground all UH-1H helicopters until thorough safety checks are conducted.

A UH-1H helicopter hit a transmission tower in the mountainous region of the county Tuesday afternoon, killing all eight elite members of an Army airborne cavalry brigade on board. Lee admitted that the helicopter was old and poorly equipped, but he also suggested that bad weather may have been probably the cause of the accident.
Lee said that it is difficult to pilot the UH-1H helicopter in conditions of low visibility because the chopper is not equipped with an automatic pilot system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PRAISES NEW TAIWAN REP TO U.S.

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang praised the country's new representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, for his devotion to and abilities in handling international and Chinese affairs, saying he believes that Wu will be able to convey the Taiwan people's will swiftly and precisely to the U.S. government and people.

Su praised Wu as a seasoned technocrat with commendable cultural literacy who has been a deputy chief of staff to President Chen Shui-bian and the head of Taiwan's top cross-strait policy-planning body.

The premier said that China has been the main obstacle in the development of Taiwan' foreign relations. As chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, Su said, Wu has performed exceptionally well in the face of Beijing's suppression and containment schemes against Taiwan on the political, diplomatic and military fronts.

Wu should be lauded for his efforts in safeguarding Taiwan's overall interests, faithfully reflecting the Taiwan people's will, pushing for cross-strait negotiations, and laying the country's cross-strait economic and trade policies, as well as helping stabilize the cross-strait situation, Su said.
Wu is scheduled to arrive in Washington, D.C. April 14 to assume his new post.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 71.7 points to close at 8,004.61.

The bourse opened at 7,888.17 and fluctuated between 8,021.59 and 7,970.46 during the day's trading. A total of 4.99 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$132.97 billion (US$4.01 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.5 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, textile stocks at 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent, and construction issues at 0.2 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 597 to 530, with 184 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALY URGED TO GRANT VISA-FREE TREATMENT TO TAIWAN CITIZENS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has urged Italy to grant visa-free treatment to Taiwan citizens on a reciprocal basis.
Noting that Italy has been one of the world's most popular tourist destinations, Chen said Taiwan citizens made a total of 215,000 visits to Italy last year.
Given the fact that Taiwan has long offered 30-day, visa-free entry for Italian citizens, Chen said Italy should reciprocate Taiwan's goodwill by offering similar treatment to Taiwan citizens.
Chen made the remarks earlier this week while receiving an Italian parliamentary delegation headed by Cesare Campa, deputy head of a pro-Taiwan group in the Italian congress.

Expressing his gratitude for the delegation members' generous support for Taiwan's cause both in the Italian parliament and the international arena over the years, Chen said he is hopeful that they can continue helping to push Italy to sign a cooperative agreement with Taiwan on avoidance of double taxation and prevention of tax evasion to facilitate mutual investment.
Chen said Taiwan has signed such agreements with several European countries, including Britain, the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark and Sweden.

Despite the absence of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Italy, Chen said Italy approved Vice President Annette Lu's transit stop in 2002 and a similar transit stop for him in March 2005 to attend the late Pope John Paul II's funeral.

"We are grateful for the Italian government's hospitality, and it is hoped that all of our senior officials will be able to gain easy access to visit Italy or make transit stops there in the future, " Chen said.

Meanwhile, Chen took the opportunity to praise the European Union for its continued arms embargo against China. Eighteen years ago, the E.U. imposed the arms ban after the infamous Tiananmen Massacre, in which Chinese troops brutally crushed a pro-democracy demonstration.

Although 18 years have passed, Chen said, China has made no progress in its human rights record and has continued to suppress political dissidents and human rights activists. In 2005, China even passed a so-called Anti-Secession Law to create a legal basis for the use of force against Taiwan if it perceives that the island is moving toward independence.
Against this backdrop, Chen said he takes pleasure in seeing the European Union rightfully maintain its arms embargo against China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCHOOLCHILDREN NOT EATING ENOUGH VEGGIES: CANCER FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Most schoolchildren in Taiwan do not eat sufficient amounts of fruits and vegetables for lunch, the Formosa Cancer Foundation (FCF) said Wednesday.

While the Department of Health suggests that children should eat at least three servings of vegetables and two servings of fruit per day, an FCF survey conducted in March found that 70 percent of elementary schools provide only 0.5 servings or less of vegetables in their prepared lunches for students.
Worse still, the survey found, 75 percent of students at these elementary schools do not eat the full portion of vegetables served to them, said Lai Chi- ming, executive director of the FCF.
The FCF conducted the poll from March 1-16, interviewing teachers and nutritionists from 301 elementary schools randomly chosen around the island.

The poll found that less than 10 percent of the surveyed schools provide their students with fruit in every lunch meal, while nearly 70 percent of the schools provide fruit in only one or two lunch meals per week.

The poll also found that many schoolchildren seldom finish the school lunches served to them, with the reasons mentioned including "not having time to eat fruit," "the lunches are not tasty," and "the servings are too large."
About half of the students at the surveyed schools were found to have grown fond of packed lunches sold outside the school, according to Lai.
Lai attributed this to the fact that boxed lunches sold by vendors or restaurants outside the school are higher in fat content and usually very spicy, which he said students find attractive.

Nearly 60 percent of the teachers at the surveyed schools said they think that most students make unhealthy choices for lunch, which Lai said could be one of the reasons behind the growing obesity problem among schoolchildren.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS CRITICIZE RELOCATION PLAN

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) criticized Wednesday a plan to relocate five Cabinet units from Taipei City to Hsinchuang in Taipei County, northern Taiwan, while the plan triggered a strong protest from Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu.

Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang told the Legislative Yuan in a briefing the previous day that a preliminary plan has been worked out to relocate the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), the Department of Health, the Council for Hakka Affairs, the Council of Indigenous Peoples, and the Public Construction Commission to Hsinchuang.

KMT Legislator Huang Chao-shun said at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan that the plan shows the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has no intention of carrying out its proposal to relocate the capital city to southern Taiwan.

While mentioning that Chen had promised during her mayoral election campaign last December to do her utmost to push for the relocation of the CLA to the southern port city, Huang urged the mayor to stand up and fight for her promise to be realized.

At Kaohsiung City Hall, Chen, who initiated the idea to relocate the CLA to Kaohsiung while serving as CLA chairwoman, expressed her strong opposition to the central government's relocation proposal while pledging to fight for her cause.
Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) suggested that the relocation of the Cabinet units be carried out based on geographic and functional concerns.

TSU caucus whip Tseng Tsang-teng questioned why the government doesn't want to move the CLA and the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sport to Kaohsiung, when the southern city has the highest number of industrial workers in the country and as Tsoying in the city is famous for producing national athletes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI TO EMPLOY VILLAGE, BOROUGH OFFICIALS IN FIGHT AGAINST CHILD ABUSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is planning to include village and borough heads, their aides, as well as residential building doormen as "notifiers" who can work to help police in cases of child abuse, MOI officials said Wednesday.

Based on concerns that the number of child abuse cases has continued to rise, the MOI plans to increase the number of people who can help monitor and inform the police and other related agencies of suspected cases, MOI officials said.

In addition to medical professionals, social workers and nursery workers, who are "responsible" for notifying police and hospitals upon the discovery of a case of child abuse, MOI officials said, village and borough heads, their aides, as well as doormen of residential buildings will probably be asked to become "notifiers" since these particular groups of people usually have closer contact with residents in the neighborhoods.

MOI officials, however, discounted a United Daily News report Wednesday that said that village or borough chiefs will be subject to a "heavy penalty" should they fail to report a case of child abuse in their areas.

MOI officials said that only "responsible" notifiers, namely medical professionals, social workers, nursery workers and police, are subject to fines -- ranging from NT$6,000 to NT$30,000 -- if they are found to have been negligent in reporting child abuse cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAR EAST AIR TRANSPORT ANNOUNCES NEW WAVE OF AIR FARE CUTS

TEXT.P: The Far East Air Transport Corp. announced Wednesday a second wave of air fare cuts, although the cuts will not be as great as those in the first wave.

Trans Asia Airways announced that it would follow suit, cutting air fares next week at the earliest, while Mandarin Airlines and Uni Airways Corp. said that they will act after observing market response.
Far East Air Transport officials said that the price cut will be limited to Taipei-Kaohsiung and Taipei-Tainan flights between Mondays and Thursdays.

Between April 9 and May 31, air fares on the Taipei-Tainan route, between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. will be cut by 19 percent to around NT$1,588 (US$48). Air fares for Taipei-Kaohsiung flights after 6 p.m. will be cut to NT$1,688, or around 24 percent discount.
The officials said that all discount air fares will have to be booked via the Web site of the Far East Air Transport or an on-site travel service operator www.ezfly.com.

Far East announced its first wave of discount air fares last month, saying that passengers ordering air tickets for Taipei-Kaohsiung on Saturdays and Sundays via Internet, will pay NT$1,510, a nearly 30 percent discount on the NT$2,120 ticket price. The price of a ticket on the high-speed rail system for the same destination costs NT$1,490.
The air fare for a Taipei-Tainan route will be cut to NT$1,350 from NT$1,960, making it the same price for the high-speed rail system, the officials said.
Far East officials said that the first wave of discount promotions has borne positive results, raising the average occupancy rate on weekends by around 25 percent.
Whether the first wave of air fare discounts, targeting tourists, will be extended remains to be seen, the officials said.

Faced with the steep competition from the 345-km high-speed rail system which was inaugurated early this year, all air carriers have resorted to air fare cuts on long-haul routes. The high-speed rail system reduces the travel time between Taipei and Kaohsiung to 90 minutes from the previous four hours and half.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKER QUESTIONS CPC'S FLOATING OIL PRICING SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) questioned whether there are any irregularities involved in the state-owned CPC Corp., Taiwan's floating pricing mechanism.

Tseng Tsahn-deng, DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, noted that since the CPC adopted the floating pricing mechanism earlier this year, the company's surplus has jumped to NT$3.63 billion (US$110 million) from losses of around NT$1.36 billion in January and February.
Tseng raised the question as the CPC announced that the petroleum price would be raised by NT$0.4 per liter, and the diesel price would be raised by NT$0.7 per liter starting Wednesday.
He noted that the CPC originally listed its losses for 2007 as NT$3.42 billion, but then adjusted its budget estimates for this year to show a surplus of NT$14.43 billion.
But Tseng also pointed out that the CPC recorded a surplus of NT$16.53 billion in 2006, even though it wasn't yet practicing the new system.

He said that he worried that the CPC has used the floating pricing mechanism to frequently and unnecessarily adjust the oil price, adding that the real problems of the company may lie with its "poor management."
In response, CPC officials said that the floating pricing system better reflects petroleum market fluctuations, and has helped make the company profitable.
They also said that compared with neighboring countries in Asia, Taiwan still maintains the lowest petroleum prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.035 to close at NT$33.081.
A total of US$762 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.112 and fluctuated between NT$33.060 and NT$33.144.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 80 points to close at 7,999, with 38,073 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May increased 76 points to finish at 7,990, with 881 contracts traded, while June futures gained 76 points to end at 7,981, with 55 contract transactions. September futures moved up 66 points to close at 7,781, with 63 contracts traded, while December futures increased 67 points to finish at 7,795, with 19 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 7,919 for April, 7,914 for May, 7,905 for June, 7,715 for September and 7,728 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

April TE futures increased 2.9 points to close at 338.3 points, with 3,698 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 3.25 points to finish at 337.4, with 74 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 4.75 points to end at 337, with one contract traded, while September TE futures increased 3.65 points to end at 329.7, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures moved up 19.4 points to close at 1,009, with 3,219 contracts traded, while May TF futures gained 21.2 points to finish at 1,009.2, with 27 contract transactions. September TF futures moved up 9.2 points to end at 1,001.8, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY TO BID FOR RIGHT TO ISSUE SPORTS LOTTERY

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Wednesday that she will convey to the Executive Yuan the city's hopes of issuing a sports lottery to help balance the development of southern and northern Taiwan.

Chen made the remarks during a question-and-answer session at the Kaohsiung City Council when city councilman Lin Wu-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party urged the mayor to advocate for the right to run a sports lottery.
Chen promised that the city's Bureau of Finance and Bank of Kaohsiung will make preparations for such a presentation.

She also said that the city government will apply for the right to run a sports lottery in mid-April, saying that it will help to promote the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung and balance regional development in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP CALLS FOR BUILDING SAFETY, HAPPINESS FOR TAIWAN'S MINORS

TEXT.P: The Child Welfare League Foundation laid out Wednesday its three core pursuits: the "survival, health and safety" of Taiwan's minors, and its hope that all youngsters will be happy and safe on Women's and Children's Day.

Foundation officials urged parents to spend at least 30 minutes daily with their children, hug them for at least three minutes every day, praise them three times every day and listen to them for three minutes every day.
Most importantly, if children are to feel secure, they must be able to access adult assistance within three minutes, in a safe environment, if need arises, foundation officials urged.

According to a nationwide investigation conducted by the foundation on Taiwanese children's human rights in 2006, the index for local children's survival rights scored only 49 points, the worst score among all the areas surveyed and markedly below the 60-point passing threshold.

Last year, a total of 10,094 children and teenagers were reported as abused to relevant authorities, 13 of whom died as a result of abuse and 31 of whom were killed along with their parents in incidents of filicide-suicide, statistics compiled by the Children's Bureau of the Ministry of the Interior showed.
This means that on average, one child would be abused by an adult every 52 minutes in Taiwan, and one child would be killed every eight days, according to the bureau's tallies.

In the first quarter of this year, five children in Taiwan died from maltreatment, nearly one-third of last year's number, foundation officials said, expressing their grave concern that many Taiwanese children find themselves in similar situations given that some 20 percent of children surveyed acknowledged that they are often beaten or harshly punished by their parents.

Citing the investigation's findings, foundation officials said that 46 percent of Taiwanese children often feel upset, that 70 percent worry about infectious diseases and a similar percentage are concerned about threats to their personal safety, such as kidnapping. On average, one child dies from accident every 1.4 days in Taiwan, they added.

Earlier the same day, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmakers asked the government to pay greater heed and provide greater assistance to issues pertaining to children's interests and rights at a news conference in the Legislative Yuan.

Some 3.17 million Taiwanese children face safety threats stemming from poor facilities at school, deteriorating public order, traffic disorder, and school yard bullying, in addition to physical deficiencies, family economic straits, scholastic burdens and corporal punishment.

According to TSU legislative caucus whip Tseng Tsahn-deng, nationwide there are some 40,000 local children are being raised by their grandparents, 100,000 mentally or physically retarded children, and 200,000 children being reared in single-parent households.

Last year, 6,602 sexual offenses cases involving minors under 18 years old were reported to the authorities, and 1.28 million children were concerned that they might be kidnapped, Tseng said, pointing out that these relatively high numbers indicate that Taiwan children are not growing up in a safe and secure environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAMBOO ART EXHIBITION BEING HELD IN YILAN COUNTY

TEXT.P: A Bamboo Art Exhibition being held at the National Center for Traditional Arts in Yilan County has put on display some 300 masterpieces by 50 of Taiwan's bamboo handicraft artists.
The exhibition opened last weekend and will last three months, closing at the end of June.
To manifest the theme of the exhibition, organizers have decorated the exhibition area with more than 1,000 bamboo plants.

They have also built a large maze covering more than 1,100 square meters with 20,000 bamboo sticks. With its intricate interconnecting passages, it is said to be the largest bamboo maze in Taiwan, and great fun for visitors willing to accept the challenge to find their way out.
In addition to exhibits of masterpieces by bamboo artists, there are pavilions designated for children's toys, household items, furniture and musical instruments -- all made of bamboo.

Each pavilion will have bamboo artists to give on-site demonstrations of how the different bamboo items are made. The music instrument pavilion will present a few music performances each day, using bamboo pipes and concussion instruments.
Several bamboo artists will be on hand in a classroom to answer visitors' questions about bamboo and its usefulness.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Childless couples to face new IVF hurdle
IVF clinics that produce twins and triplets in more than one in ten pregnancies will face disciplinary action under plans to cut multiple births announced yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO AUSTRALIA HOLDS SEMINAR FOR TAIWANESE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Cultural Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Australia recently held a seminar for Taiwanese students attending four universities in Sydney, according to reports from Australia.

The reports said the seminar was held on behalf of the Ministry of Education to support Taiwanese students in Sydney and announce the launch of a Web page providing important information on contacts, subsidies, and job opportunities for Taiwanese students on the division's official Web site: http://www.cultural.teco.org.au.

The seminar at the Culture Center of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Sydney was attended by more than 100 Taiwanese students, and hosted by chairmen of four universities' Taiwanese student associations.
During the seminar, the reports said, Teco staff members explained the services of the office and answered students' questions on topics such as military service and subsidies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS CAUTION TOMB SWEEPERS TO GUARD AGAINST SKIN INFECTIONS

TEXT.P: Members of the public who observe the tomb sweeping custom to pay homage to the memory of their ancestors should take precautions to guard against skin infections, a dermatologist in Taichung cautioned Wednesday.

Chen Chun-yi, who runs a skin clinic, told reporters that the number of patients he and his colleagues have treated in the past few days has increased 30 percent, with most of them suffering from infections as a result of either sunburn or mosquito and other insect bites sustained during their tomb sweeping trips.

According to Chen, these patients have told him that they swept their ancestors' tombs ahead of the April 5 Tomb Sweeping Day because they wanted to avoid the traffic congestion over the long weekend.

Failing to protect themselves against insects and the sun, many of them contracted acute skin infections, developed rashes all over their bodies and suffered from headaches, breathing difficulty, perspiration and localized lymphadenitis.

Chen said that April is the month when mosquitos and other insects thrive, and that tomb sweepers should wear a pair of light colored trousers and a jacket to guard against stings from mosquitos and rove beetles, plus a hat to shield themselves from direct exposure to the sun.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 320,000 ELIGIBLE TO VOTE IN KMT CHAIRMAN BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: A total of 324,347 main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) members are eligible to vote to select a chairman in the April 7 by-election, KMT officials said Wednesday.

According to Huang Chung-hsien, director of the KMT's organization and development department, the party will set up 486 polling stations across the country, with the largest in northern Taipei County capable of accommodating 5,057 voters, and the smallest, on outlying Wuchiu Island, braced to receive 15 voters.

Huang said that the KMT is opening many polling stations in hopes of attracting at least of 40 percent of eligible party members to cast their ballots in the race, in which former acting Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and lawmaker Hung Hsiu-chu are vying for the party's top post.

The largest number of KMT party members eligible to vote are found in Taipei County, which has 44,552, followed by 30,422 in neighboring Taoyuan County. Offshore Lienchiang County, where the Matsu Islands are located, has the fewest eligible KMT members, with just 1,012.

Former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou voluntarily stepped down from the post Feb. 13 after being indicted by Taipei prosecutors earlier that same day for his alleged mishandling of funds from a special municipal monthly allowance designated for his discretionary use when serving as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.
Ma proclaimed his desire to take part in the 2008 presidential election immediately after the corruption charges were filed against him.
The first day of Ma's embezzlement trial was opened Tuesday at the Taipei District Court, during which the former KMT chairman maintained his innocence.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'X PARTICLE' CONFIRMED AS HIGGS BOSONS

TEXT.P: The "X particle" observed by a U.S. laboratory has been confirmed by a trio of researchers from Taiwan and the United States as one of the hypothetical Higgs bosons, academic sources reported Wednesday.
They emphasized that the finding may not only subvert the long- exiting "standard model" in particle physics, but also make way for the discovery of dark matters.

The results of the three -- He Xiao-gang of National Taiwan University (NTU) , Jusak Tandean of University of La Verne, and G. Valencia of Iowa State University -- have been published in the renowned science journal Physical Review Letters in its Feb. 23 issue.

The X particle was first observed in 2005 at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab) during a failed search for dark matter. The unknown substance has puzzled physicists ever since because none of the dominant theories is capable of accounting for its characteristics.
After numerous calculations and comparisons, the trio asserted that the particle fits all the constraints of a Higgs bosons under the "next-to-minimal super- symmetric standard model."

The "standard model" of particle physics suggested in 1974 that there should be a series of "elementary particles, " including the boson hypothesized by Peter Higgs in 1964. However, to date, although all other particles have been found, the Higgs boson was yet to be discovered.

Later in the 1980's, a new theory, the "next-to-minimal super-symmetric standard model" was introduced, with a new assumption that there should seven kinds of Higgs boson particles, and every elementary particle should have a unique counterpart, a super-symmetric particle.
Since then, neither the seven Higgs bosons nor the super-symmetric particles have been observed.

He, of NTU, noted that even though they didn't find "the" standard model Higgs boson, they found "something of even greater significance," which means that by confirming particle X to be one of the seven Higgs bosons they cannot only assert the existence of other Higgs bosons, but also expand the theoretical foundations of particle physics from the standard model to the next-to-minimal super-symmetric standard model.

He added that by sustaining the next-to-minimal super-symmetric standard model with their findings, the research on dark matter would enter a new stage -- because the theory also assumed that the dark matter should be formed by super- symmetric particles.
"If the Higgs bosons exist, the super-symmetric particles may also exist," he predicted.

He said that the physicists require still more physical evidence to sustain the theory and that the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) project coming online in November, and the International Linear Collider (ILC) still in the planning stages, could reveal further evidence pointing to the existence of other unknown particles.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ADOPTS EXCLUSIVE POLLING FORMAT FOR LAWMAKER PRIMARY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) adopted Wednesday a polling format designed to exclude voters at the other half of the political spectrum from its primary poll for district-elected legislators.
The polling reform program initiated by the DPP's Acting Chairman Trong R. Chai was slightly modified before passing the party's Central Standing Committee.

The DPP's primary system takes into account both telephone polls involving general citizens and voting by party members. Chai's original proposal suggested that the questionnaire first ask the surveyed about their party inclinations.

To that question, those answering that they share political beliefs with the DPP, Taiwan Solidarity Union or pan-green camp will be included, while those identifying with the Kuomintang, People First Party, New Party or the pan-blue camp will not, according to DPP sources.

Chai suggested that those who identify with no any political party in the first question be asked the second question: "Would you consider supporting the DPP's representative if he or she is a good candidate? "and that those who answer in the affirmative will be included.

During the committee meeting, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said that those who choose to identify with "others" in the first question should have a second chance to have their opinions included.

According to sources that attended the meeting, committee members reached a consensus and agreed on the change after the party's Public Opinion Survey Center Director Chang Yu-feng said Yang's proposal would result in the inclusion of less than another one percent of interviewees in the district-elected primary poll.

A similar format for the DPP's presidential primary poll, aiming at excluding 30 percent of voters, was also confirmed by the committee after it passed the party's Central Executive Committee a week earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER TOUTS LOCALLY-PRODUCED 'BETEL NUT COFFEE'

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh helped market locally-produced, so-called "betel nut coffee" in the southern city of Kaohsiung Wednesday as a means of promoting interactions between coffee traders and local growers.

Hsieh said during a promotional event for the agricultural product from Neiwuan, Pingtung County in southern Taiwan, that he volunteered to serve as a spokesman for "betel nut coffee" last month during a visit to Neiwuan, where he drank the local coffee for the first time, and learned that the coffee is grown under betel nut trees -- a method of cultivation consistent with the idea of "co- existence" in nature.

Given that the coffee, named because it is grown under betel nut trees, is as sweet as the popular Kukeng Coffee from Yulin County, Hsieh said he wishes to attract more local coffee lovers to buy the Neiwuan product to help increase income of betel nut farmers in the township.

In Taiwan, there are tens of thousands of people producing and trading betel nut, Hsieh said, noting that as the government no longer encourages betel nut production after the tropical trees were found to be the prime culprit responsible for frequent landslides on the island, so growers are not entitled to any governmental assistant programs.

Due to financial concerns, some of the farmers began to grow coffee under their betel nut trees. "Now they are all happy to produce high-quality coffee, " said the former premier who is running to become the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate in the 2008 presidential election.

Saying that Taiwan imports NT$1.7 billion (US$51 million) worth of coffee on average each year, Hsieh said that if one-third of that coffee came from local sources it would bring an additional NT$600 million in annual revenue.
Coffee plantations cover more than 217 hectares of land in southern Taiwan, generating an annual revenue of some NT$8.59 million.

State legislatures are rewriting legislation governing organ donations in one of the most ambitious initiatives in at least 20 years to alleviate the chronic shortage of kidneys, livers and other body parts, an effort that some doctors and ethicists fear tilts too far toward allowing organs to be taken.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS OF FISH DIE IN TAINAN CANAL AFTER VIOLENT STORM

TEXT.P: Thousands of dead fish have surfaced in the Tainan Canal after a violent storm swept across the southern Taiwan city two days ago and washed a large volume of untreated sewage into the five-kilometer-long canal.
Officials from the Environmental Protection Bureau of the Tainan city government said Wednesday that they have scooped up three metric tons of dead fish for sanitary disposal.
The officials said the heavy rains caused the untreated sewage to overflow into the Tainan Canal, killing an estimated 10,000 fish, including milkfish, large- scale mullet and Oreochomis.
They explained that the sewage depleted oxygen reserves in the canal's water, making it impossible for the fish to survive.
The Tainan Canal was a major embarrassment for the city during the 1990s due to the stench from sludge discharged by households into the canal.

After the city government built a new sewage system along the 80-year-old canal three years ago, fish gradually came back to the canal, which has since become the waterway used for the annual dragon boat race each June.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: No Longer Waiting for Rain, an Arid West Takes Action
A Western drought that began in 1999 has continued after the respite of a couple of wet years that now feel like a cruel tease. But this time people in the driest states are not just scanning the skies and hoping for rescue.
Some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned or under way in four states, the biggest expansion in the Wests quest for water in decades. Among them is a proposed 280-mile pipeline that would direct water to Las Vegas from northern Nevada. A proposed reservoir just north of the California-Mexico border would correct an inefficient water delivery system that allows excess water to pass to Mexico.
Wall Street Journal:Respirator Testing Gets an Adjustment
The face of America is getting fatter and longer, and that's become a pain in the neck for Les Boord.
Mr. Boord is an engineer at the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, a federal agency dedicated to preventing workplace injuries. On the outskirts of this city long associated with steel making, he runs a 100-person lab that tests and certifies gas masks and other devices that protect workers from inhaling chemicals, dust, fumes and other harmful substances.
But finding people with facial features that match the average face in today's diverse workplace has become more difficult as the American mug has grown wider and more varied.
