Italian ruling coalition Unione expressed its opposition to holding referendum on electoral reforms. Party leaders of the coalition said in a meeting with Premier Romano Prodi that the referendum is not an adequate way to achieve needed reform goals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TVBS ADVERTISERS URGED TO SUSPEND COMMERCIALS FOR ONE WEEK

TEXT.P: Advertisers on TVBS, a local cable TV station, are urged to suspend their commercials for one week to give the public an opportunity to reflect on TVBS' broadcast of a staged video, according to a statement issued by the Taiwan Advertisers' Association.
The association called on advertisers Wednesday to put on hold their TV commercials slated to be aired between April 20-26 or transfer the commercials to other media, the statement said.
Advertisers in Taiwan should not use viewership or readership rates as the only gauge to decide upon the placement of their advertisements, the association pointed out.
Doing so has forced local media to create sensational news stories and attempt to scoop media rivals in order to boost their viewership or readership rates, the association explained.
Companies should also take into account social responsibility as they market their products, the association stated.

Noting that satellite and cable TV channels are scarce resources that belong to all the people in Taiwan, the association said that inappropriate uses of the channels are harmful to the public interest.
It is inappropriate for TVBS to allow itself to be used by a gangster to issue death threats to his mob boss, the association said.
With this incident, the station has violated the principles of news reporting, misled the public, and caused social unrest, the association said, adding that TVBS should be harshly condemned.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA CONSERVES TWO ENDANGERED FERNS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Forestry Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture (COA) has successfully bred two endangered fern species endemic to Taiwan, earning worldwide acclaim, institute officials said Wednesday.
The institute made the announcement Tuesday after six years of research on the reproduction of the two fern species -- Archangiopteris somai Hayata and Archangiopteris itoi Shieh.
The two species can be dated back 180 million years and are endemic to Taiwan, the institute pointed out.
There are fewer than 1,000 Archangiopteris somai Hayata remaining, while Archangiopteris itoi Shieh numbers less than 100, the institute stressed.

Archangiopteris somai Hayata is found in only two areas of Taiwan -- Wulai, in the northern county of Taipei, and Lien-hua-chi forest, in the central county of Nantou, officials said, adding that Archangiopteris itoi Shieh can only be seen in Wulai area.
The institute published the results of their research last year in Fern Gazette, published by the British Pteridological Society, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPI UP 0.97% IN Q1: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) in the first quarter of this year rose 0.97 percent over the same period of 2006, lower than the projected 1.4 percent growth rate, an official from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
If the core consumer price is eliminated, the annual growth rate of the CPI would be 0.68 percent, the official said at a press conference, adding that this represents moderate growth.
The CPI saw an annual increase of 0.83 percent in March, the official said, attributing the rise to higher prices of fuel, cigarettes, oil, and some Chinese herbal medicines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO INVITE MORE JAPANESE BANANA IMPORTERS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung office of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) plans to invite more Japanese banana importers to Taiwan as a part of efforts to promote local banana exports, TAITRA officials said Wednesday.
Japan is one of the major overseas markets for Taiwan's agricultural products, the officials said, adding that bananas are particularly welcomed by Japanese.

The Kaohsiung office has invited several Japanese companies to visit Taiwanese banana plantations in early February and organized a meeting for them to increase bilateral understandings and mutual trust, the officials noted.
Having received positive responses from Japanese companies, the TAITRA plans to organize more meetings to further promote Taiwan's bananas, the officials said.
In 2006, the export value of Taiwan's fruits was greater than US$34.3 million, the officials said, adding that the Japanese market accounted for the half of that total.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL RANKS THIRD IN WORLD FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves stood at US$267.48 billion as of the end of March, securing for the nation its status as the world's third largest foreign exchange holder, according to statistics released Wednesday by Taiwan's central bank -- the Taipei-based Central Bank of China.
Bank officials pointed out that the figure represented a decrease of US$502 million from February, mainly because many foreign investors sold more than they bought on Taiwan's stock market.
They noted that Taiwan's US$267.48 billion came next only to China's US$1.66 trillion, recorded at the end of December last year, and Japan's US$884 billion, recorded a the end of February.
Other statistics show that Russia's gold and foreign currency reserves totaled US$332.6 billion as of the end of March, with its foreign exchange reserves for February standing at US$221 billion.
South Korea recorded foreign currency reserves of US$243.4 billion in March, followed by India's US$190.4 billion for the same month.
Singapore's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$140.2 billion for February, ahead of Hong Kong's US$132.8 billion for the same month.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER HEADS FOR U.S. TO ATTEND MOTHER'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh departed for the United States Wednesday evening to attend his mother's funeral.

Sources close to Hsieh said Hsieh's mother died at his brother's home in Los Angeles at the age of 87. According to the sources, Hsieh's family will arrange a simple funeral for his mother in line with her wishes.

Hsieh's mother was known to be a modest, self-effacing woman who raised five children on limited family resources. Thanks to her wisdom and tenacity, Hsieh once recalled, she had managed to provide a warm and stable environment in which her children grew up healthy, receiving good educations.
President Chen Shui-bian has issued a posthumous commendation in honor of Hsieh's mother.

Hsieh, a human rights lawyer-turned politician who once served as premier, lawmaker and mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, is currently competing for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run in the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET WANTS ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENTS SIMPLIFIED

TEXT.P: Rapid environmental impact assessment procedures should be drawn up to allow urgent major construction programs to proceed quickly, a Cabinet panel on economic development suggested Wednesday.

Concerned by the progress of three major construction programs -- a steel plant invested in by the Taiwan Plastics Group and two petrochemical plants of the CPC Corporation -- the inter-ministry panel urged the Environment Protection Administration (EPA) to "make an overall review of current environmental impact assessment regulations and practices, " said Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairwomen Ho Mei-yueh, who is a member of the panel headed by Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen.
The panel asked the EPA to come up with a report within a month for further discussion in the panel, Ho said, adding that the report should address three concerns.

First, Ho said, the EPA should consider drawing up rapid environmental impact assessment procedures for high priority major programs "provided that environmental protection standards are not compromised, " she said. Ho also stated, "Not all the cases should be treated the same."

Second, according to the panel's recommendation, the range and criteria of environmental impact assessments should be determined by the environmental impact assessment committee at the outset and should not be changed thereafter unless absolutely necessary.
Third, cases should be referred to the environmental impact assessment committee for a decision if no conclusion is reached through a certain number of case examination sessions, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO U.S.

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his commitments to the United States and the world Wednesday, saying he would never back away from promises and guarantees made to the U.S. government and the free world.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a visiting U.S. congressional delegation, headed by Congressman Lincoln Davis (D-Tenn.).

Noting that maintaining peace, stability and security in the Taiwan Strait is his administration's inescapable duty and mission, Chen said he has consistently honored his promise with regard to this major policy goal.

Chen was referring to his now famous "five noes" pledge outlined in his 2000 inaugural speech which states that so long as China has no intention to use force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan's independence, not change Taiwan's national title or national flag, not hold a referendum on the "independence vs. unification" issue, not enshrine the special "state-to-state" concept in the Constitution, and not abolish the National Unification Council and the National Unification Guidelines.
The United States and the free world attach great importance to Chen's "five noes" pledge because China has repeatedly threatened to attack Taiwan should it seek formal independence.

During his talks with the visiting U.S. congressional delegation, Chen assured them that Taiwan will spare no efforts to beef up its military might for the sake of maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait and safeguarding its national security.
Chen also took the occasion to renew his call for the U.S. government to sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan for mutual benefits.

Noting that Taiwan is America's eighth largest trading partner, Chen said he is convinced that if a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement deal is struck, the two countries would be able to further strenghthen bilateral trade and economic cooperation based on the current basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 6, or the 19th day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1199: Richard I, king of England known as "The Lion-Hearted," dies at the age of 42 from an infected wound received while besieging Chaluz Castle during the Crusades. He was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath, which was to change the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun with the rotations of a propeller, is born.
1896: A modern version of the ancient Olympic Games is opened in Athens, initiated by French aristocrat Baron Pierre de Coubertin, whose goal was to stimulate interest in physical fitness and promote understanding between nations.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were destroyed during the attack, including the National Library with its countless medieval manuscripts.
1945: U.S. naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing or injuring more than 300 people.
1963: The Executive Yuan proclaims December 25 "Constitution Day" and a national holiday.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada, succeeding Lester B. Pearson.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1976: Millionaire recluse Howard Hughes dies in a plane while being flown to a hospital, leaving a fortune of US$2 billion.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo renews his call to communist cadres and mainland China military personnel to rise up against the Maoist regime following the April 5 riots at Tienanmen Square in Beijing.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: A missile hits a plane as it attempts to land in Rwanda, killing all people onboard, including President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi and President Jubenal Habyarimana of Rwanda.
1998 Citicorp merges with Travelers Group Inc., becoming the largest corporation in the world in terms of assets. The new firm is worth more than US$70 billion.
1999: Indonesian President B.J. Habibie assures visiting ROC Economics Minister Wang Shih-kang that his administration will take all necessary measures to protect Taiwan investors in Indonesia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bien says that the administration under his leadership will honor all accords and commitments that have already been inked with foreign countries.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, calls on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and expresses his gratitude for Lee's promotion of increased Taiwan-Tibet exchanges during his term in office.
2004: Lithuanian President Rolandas Paksas is impeached by the Parliament, making him the first European popularly elected president to step down due to impeachment.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To allow people to go to battle without first instructing them is to betray them."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO OPEN SPORTS CAR RACING, HORSE RACING: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government plans to open sports car racing and horse racing in southern Taiwan to help rev up the region's economic vitality, an economic planning official said Thursday.

Chang Ching-sen, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said the council is collaborating with the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) in drafting a comprehensive plan for opening special competitive sports in central and southern parts of the island to boost the regional economy.
The plans for opening sports car racing and horse racing will be unveiled in June as the first step to implementing the new economic-stimulus measures, Chang said.
As opening horse racing will require revisions to existing laws while sports car racing need not, Chang said, sports car racing is likely to be introduced first.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRECKAGE OF CHOPPER TO BE RE-ASSEMBLED TO DETERMINE CAUSE OF CRASH

TEXT.P: The wreckage of an Army helicopter that crashed into a radio tower in a remote mountain region in southern Kaohsiung County Tuesday will be re-assembled to facilitate investigations into the cause of the crash, military sources said Friday.

All the debris of the crashed UH-1H chopper from the Army's Airborne and Special Operations Command (ASPC) has been recovered and sent back to the Kueijen Army Base in neighboring Tainan County for re-assembling, the sources said.

The ASPC is scheduled to hold consultation meetings in the next few days to discuss repair of the damaged radio tower owned by the police-operated Public Radio System and compensation for owners of banana ranches destroyed in the crash, the sources said.

The flight mishap claimed the lives of all the eight Army officers aboard. Five of the bodies were recovered at the crash site Tuesday, but rescuers didn't locate the remaining three until Wednesday noon when they were discovered lodged in the girders of the radio tower, which the helicopter had collided with in bad mountain weather.
The crashed helicopter's flight recorders, commonly known as "black boxes, " have also been recovered and turned over to the investigators looking into the crash.

The crashed helicopter was manufactured in 1974. Under a cooperation deal with U.S.-based Bell Helicopter, the military's Aero-Industry Development Center -- the forerunner of the present-day Aerospace Industry Development Corp. -- has built a total of 118 UH-1Hs since 1969.

Despite the age of the aircraft, Defense Minister Lee Jye said after the latest flight disaster that the fleet of UH-1H choppers is still a reliable part of the country's airborne arsenal and suggested that the cause of Tuesday's crash was most likely bad weather, rather than the aging aircraft.

Nevertheless, Lee said that all the remaining UH-1Hs have been grounded for thorough safety checks. He also said a detailed investigation report about the cause of the crash will be unveiled at a news conference next Tuesday.
According to the minister, the family of each officer killed in the crash will receive compensation of at least NT$15 million (US$453,360).

Meanwhile, Army authorities said they are hopeful that the mishap will inspire a change in the military's arms procurement policy which tends to give top priority to the Navy's and the Air Force's arsenal shopping lists.

Army sources said the Army already came up with a plan in 1998 to replace the UH-1Hs with new UH-60/S-70 Black Hawk helicopters developed by Sikorsky Co., but the plan was later halted because the local agent of another U.S. manufacturer strongly lobbied for its helicopter type.

The utility helicopter replacement plan has not been resumed since that time because the Army later decided to give priority to purchasing new Apache AH-64D assault helicopters. However, according to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang, the military has yet to send any budget proposal for purchasing either new utility helicopters or assault choppers.
Anyway, Army officials said they hope both legislators and members of the public will throw greater support behind the Army's weaponry procurement projects in the future.

: The Straits Times: Competition body backs moves to remove fee guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY REP TO U.S. TO BECOME TAIWAN'S TOP TRADE NEGOTIATOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 5 (CNA) 04/06/07 12:19:09 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States, John C.C. Deng, who has recently been appointed as the country's first top international trade negotiator, is scheduled to return to Taiwan April 18 to assume his new post.

Deng, who has served in the past as director of the Economic Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council and deputy permanent representative to the World Trade Organization, is expected to formally assume his new post as head of the Office of Trade Negotiations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs -- a position with the rank and title of ambassador, soon after his return to Taipei.

The Office of Trade Negotiations, which was officially established March 30, is tasked with dealing with international trade talks, including talks on the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement between Taiwan and the United States and talks on the signing of free trade agreements (FTAs) with foreign countries under the framework of the World Trade Organization.

Deng said that his most immediate tasks will be making various mechanisms of his office operational; sorting out ways of coordinating with relevant Cabinet agencies; accelerating work associated with FTA talks with the Dominican Republic and pushing forward work to contribute to making the Doha Round of talks succeed.

Meanwhile, Deng said, he envisages establishing a consultation and communication mechanism with the business and industrial sectors with the aim of tapping the ideas and visions of members of these sectors.
In his new post, Deng will head a staff of 25, including two deputy chief negotiators, three senior negotiators and seven negotiators.

In the future, Deng said, he will also be required to give reports directly to an Executive Yuan international affairs strategy task force headed by Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen. The task force, grouping heads of eight to nine Cabinet agencies, will be responsible for discussing and shaping Taiwan's positions in all international talks and negotiations, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
GOV'T SET TO ACCELERATE UPGRADING OF TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Eighteen of Taiwan's traditional industries have been targeted under a government-initiated "mega investment" project aimed at helping them upgrade their manufacturing structures and know-how as well as increase output and sales.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has decided to allocate NT$15 billion (US$454.55 million) this year to initiate plans for industrial upgrading, under which 18 selected core manufacturing businesses, including metal and petrochemical processing, machinery manufacturing, textiles, plastics and biopharmaceuticals, will be assisted in efforts to integrate vertically, cooperate across sectors, and explore export markets.

Under these plans, Taiwan's traditional manufacturing industries -- which posted annual output of NT$4.92 trillion in 1995 and gradually increased to NT$7.2 trillion in 2005 -- are expected to achieve annual production totalling NT$10.59 trillion by 2015, MOEA officials said.

The MOEA is pushing for the implementation of these plans given the challenges and bottlenecks facing the industries as a result of economic globalization and the impact of the rises of China and other developing economies, including imbalances in workforce supply and demand; insufficient engagement in research and development; and insufficient resources backup from the government, the officials said.

The MOEA plans will include efforts to increase subsidies, improve traditional manufacturing industries' investment environment, help sharpen traditional manufacturing industries' international competitiveness and accelerate these industries' overall growth.

To help traditional manufacturing industries upgrade, the MOEA will also help train skilled workers, including those responsible for quality control; push for QC verification and product licensing; help with research and development of innovative products and technologies; provide long-term soft loans; and help open up markets abroad, the MOEA officials said.

The 18 traditional manufacturing industries that have been selected for the upgrading program involve the production of iron and steel, auto parts, machine tools, mechanical parts and components, industrial robots, flat panel displaying and semiconductor equipment, metal products, petrochemicals, LCD materials, plastics, biopharmaceuticals, textiles, glass, footwear, health foods, furniture, pulp and paper processing, as well as printing, according to the officials.

It is envisaged that with the implementation of these plans, Taiwan will become one of the three largest machine tool producers in the world by 2015, the world's third largest bicycle producer, and one of the top 10 petrochemical producing countries, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NOT FAVORING ANY SPECIFIC DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian dismissed as "fabricated" reports that he has favored a specific individual from among the four presidential aspirants of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The president was responding to reports by the Apple Daily, a local tabloid, during his visit to his hometown in Tainan County.

The reports said that Chen has met with DPP heavyweights over the past several days during which he expressed the hope that they will help Premier Su more. The reports said that this showed his formal endorsement of Su.
But the president didn't say if he will continue to mediate among the four hopefuls -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su, former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun.

The Presidential Office earlier termed the reports as "purely speculation." The office said in a press release that the president has always wanted the four to engage in a "fair" competition so as to produce a candidate that has the best chance of winning the 2008 presidential election.
"The president will by no means have preset stance on who should represent the DPP to run for president," the press release said.

Meanwhile, Vice President Lu said that the reports are "misinformation, " adding that she believes Chen's recent meetings with legislators were aimed at learning about the situation regarding the year-end legislative elections so as to facilitate coordination among the legislative hopefuls.
DPP Chairman Yu said that he has never heard that President Chen endorses Su and that he couldn't comment on the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: British government questions Rome police on dealing with soccer fans' confrontation.
The British government expressed concern over the policing of a soccer match between Rome and Manchester United in Rome Wednesday, and asked for reports from Italian and British police on dealing with confrontations between fans in which 18 English citizens were injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TERMINATES CONTRACT WITH U.S. PR FIRM BGR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 5 (CNA) 04/06/07 17:07:39 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top representative in the United States, David Tawei Lee, confirmed Thursday that the Republic of China government has terminated a contract with U.S. public relations firm Barbour Griffith & Rogers (BGR) , a year before the three-year contract expires.
Lee, nevertheless, stressed that the reasons behind the earlier-than-planned rescinding of the BGR hiring contract are not those claimed by the China Times in a report Friday in Taipei.

Lee said the report was untrue particularly in its claim that his office, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington, D.C., has rescinded the contract with BGR under pressure exerted by officials from the U.S. State Department.
As to what were the real "reasons, " the outgoing envoy said it's inconvenient for him to disclose them.

Meanwhile, Taiwan Vice President Annette Lu said Friday in Taipei that it is essential now for the government to launch an overall review of Taiwan's hiring U.S. PR firms to smooth U.S.-Taiwan connections.

Several PR firms have been hired as part of the communications channels between Taiwan and the United States. The PR firms major tasks include smoothing communications between Taiwan and the U.S. Congress and government and enabling the United States to better understand Taiwan's interest in promoting democracy, human rights and peace at home and internationally.

Tacitly referring to BGR, Lu said some U.S. PR firms are prohibitively and unreasonably expensive to hire, adding that she has expressed her opinions on this concern to President Chen Shui-bian as well.

Lu said that U.S.-Taiwan relations have been up and down over the past several years, although it is true that "diplomacy is an extension of a country's domestic affairs, " adding that diplomatic work will become smoother once domestic issues are successfully handled.

Lu said the government should let the people be the government's diplomatic backup, adding that a fully-fledged democracy with a developed and flourishing economy is the best diplomatic weapon that a country can have, instead of spending a fortune to hire certain individuals to lobby for Taiwan. Unconfirmed sources have said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs signed a three-year contract with BGR in March 2005, under which the ministry was to pay US$4.5 million to the Washington-based PR firm from 2005 to 2008 for its lobbying efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELOCATION OF FIVE AGENCIES TO HSINCHUANG A 'MISCONCEPTION': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that it is a misconception that five Cabinet agencies, including the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , will be relocated from Taipei City to Hsinchuang of Taipei County under an Executive Yuan plan.

Su said it is still too early to speculate whether the CLA, Department of Health, Council for Hakka Affairs, Council of Indigenous Peoples and the Public Construction Commission will be relocated to Hsinchuang, since the administration has just begun information collection and investigations to look into the feasibility of the relocation project.

Su noted that Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said recently in a briefing at the Legislative Yuan that the administration has been pondering how plots of state-owned land in Taipei County should be used after being taken back by the government -- remarks that probably have been misconceived as the administration was planning to have those five Cabinet agencies relocated to Hsinchuang.

The premier quoted Lee as saying that some NT$600 million (US$18.18 million) could be saved in rent if the state-owned land can be developed to house the five Cabinet agencies, which are "snails without shells" -- meaning they don't have any offices that are their own property.

Lee reportedly told the legislators last week that a preliminary plan has been worked out to relocate the five agencies to Hsinchuang after the plots of land are retrieved. Lee's remarks drew a strong protest from Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, who initiated the idea of relocating the CLA to the southern port city of Kaohsiung while serving as CLA chairwoman.

Expressing her strong opposition to the central government's relocation proposal, Chen pledged to fight for her cause, saying that Kaohsiung is the most worthy and suitable city to host the CLA as it has the largest proportion of laborers of any city in Taiwan, with 80 percent of its residents being working class.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP BACKS OPENING OF CAR AND HORSE RACING: PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Responding to a media report that the Cabinet is planning to open sports car racing and horse racing in central and southern Taiwan, the ruling party chief said Friday that his party will back the project as long as it stimulates local economies and benefits the people.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun made the comments while answering questions from reporters after it was reported a day earlier that the Executive Yuan is expected to allow competitive race events to be held in central and southern Taiwan beginning in June.

Chang Ching-sen, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, told CNA Thursday that opening sports car racing and horse racing will be a boon for seven cities and counties in central and southern regions as well as the offshore county of Penghu, but particularly the central Yunlin County.
Car racing is likely to be opened first as it requires no revisions to existing laws, Chang said.

Pointing out that the Executive Yuan must first craft comprehensive complementary measures to mitigate the impact of the planned opening measure on public order and social morals, Yu said that the DPP would certainly support the plan as long as it is beneficial to society.

DPP legislative caucus whip Wang Hsing-nan said the same day that the party's caucus in the Legislative Yuan is in favor of the idea, and contended that the measure should be able to help revitalize local economies and strike a balance in regional development.
He opined that the government should follow the example set by Hong Kong and Macau by allocating a certain percentage of earnings to helping minorities and the underprivileged.
Kuo Su-chun, a member of the main opposition Kuomintang's legislative caucus, criticized the DPP government for its near-slightness in announcing the car racing and horse racing opening policy.

No wonder that the announcement stirred up public suspicion that this plan is aimed at soliciting votes for the ruling DPP in coming elections, as the government as yet lacks a concrete blueprint, Kuo said.

Over the past seven years, she said, the DPP administration has been incompetent when it comes to bolstering Taiwan's economy because it lacks an across-the- board stimulation package, but it now wants to bolster economic development in central and southern Taiwan by allowing profiteering businesses.
The government has to provide the pubic with a detailed explanation of its plans to step up law enforcement if the opening leads to a deterioration in social order, she argued.

Lee Hung-chun, spokesman for the opposition People First Party, questioned why the Executive Yuan unveiled the policy now instead of working with opposition lawmakers to delve further into a long-stalled bill aimed at allowing the establishment of casinos on outlying islands.

Lee said that he wonders why the Executive Yuan suddenly agreed to open sports car racing and horse racing after having long opposed the proposal to set up casinos on offshore islands due to national security concerns.
The PFP lawmaker suggested the DPP administration not go too far just to solicit votes in the coming legislative and presidential elections.
Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative caucus whip Yin Ling-ying urged the government to thoroughly assess all tourism-related opening issues, and carefully gauge possible adverse effects.
The government must not focus its attention only on economic benefits while turning a blind eye to possible negative side effects, such as the deterioration in public order, she said.

Following in others' footsteps does not guarantee success if the government's planned opening measures lack the vision to integrate local features and characters, she argued, adding that such efforts may actually lead to greater problems down the road.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO DRUM UP SUPPORT FOR REFERENDUM ON KMT'S ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that the party will sponsor 100 speeches around the island to drum up support for its campaign to retrieve the ill-gotten assets of the Kuomintang through a national referendum.
Yu said at a news conference that the speeches will kick off in Kaohsiung Saturday, on the 18th anniversary of pro-democracy activist Cheng Nan-jung's death.

In 1989, Cheng was charged with insurrection for reprinting a draft constitution for the Republic of Taiwan. Cheng refused to appear in court, and when police arrived to arrest him on April 7, he committed suicide by self-immolation.

Yu criticized the KMT for refusing to return its ill-gotten assets to the nation, saying that a proposed bill to retrieve ill-gotten assets of the political party has been blocked by the opposition-controlled legislature, and that is why the DPP has to resort to retrieval through a national referendum.

He noted that the first-stage of signature-collection to make this a valid proposal had been successful, but the campaign will need at least 830,000 signatures in the second-stage to make it to a national referendum.
The DPP has set a goal of collecting one million signatures by July, but Yu acknowledged that it is falling behind in reaching that goal.
The party hopes to drum up support through the worldwide speeches, he said.

As party chairmen, Yu should be responsible for soliciting 5,000 signatures, but he said that he is willing to raise the quota by 10 times to 50,000 signatures, urging all party members to step up their efforts and to make this their top priority.
Yu said that the DPP administration has ruled the nation for seven years, but that public trust in the party has been compromised because a number of the party's promises have fallen through.
He expressed the hope that the party will stick to its guns on this matter at least, saying that the matter depends on "will and determination."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAR RACING NOT ON TRACK: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang denied Friday a media report that the government will soon open sports car racing and horse racing, saying that there is not even the slightest possibility of this happening in the near future.

Su made the remarks during an inspection of central Yunlin County after CNA reported a day earlier that the government is planning to allow sports car racing and horse racing in central and southern Taiwan, beginning in June.

Chang Ching-sen, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, was quoted as saying that car racing is expected to be allowed before horse racing, and that Yulin County stands a good chance of first benefiting from the planned opening.
Stressing that the reported opening is still very far away from being realized, Su said that the government has to craft a comprehensive program and revise laws first.

Although Yunlin County is very keen to host car racing or horse racing events, Su said that the issue must be fully explored on the legal, tourism, animal protection and gambling-related fronts in advance.
In addition, he said, the sentiment of the local residents on the outlying Penghu County also must be heeded as Penghu has long sought government permission to set up casinos. ENDITEM/jnc

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC OPINION SOUGHT ON AMENDMENTS TO INTELLIGENT PROPERTY LAW

TEXT.P: The Intelligent Property Office (IPO) has launched an online forum at its Web site, inviting the public to submit their opinions on proposed revisions to Intellectual Property Laws, an IPO official said Friday.

The IPO plans to have legislation related to patent, trademark right and copyright revised in response to the development of new technologies and changes in the global environment surrounding intelligent property rights, according to the official.

The official said that the current Patent Law, promulgated in July, 2004, does not allow for patents on animal or plant inventions, but a resolution passed by the Executive Yuan's Biotechnology Industry Guidance Task force requires the IPO to change it.
While considering new developments touching on enforcement of compulsory licenses for pharmaceutical and medical device patents, the IPO decided to revise the Patent Law.

As for the Trademark Law, although it has undergone several revisions, room remains for improvements in the implementation of the law, and the IPO is set to make adjustments consistent with the Trademark Law Treaty adopted by the World Intellectual Property Organization, the official said.
He added that since problems arose in November 1997 concerning Copyright provisions in dealing with copyright agencies, the law has also been in need of revision.

The official said that to ensure that amendments to relevant laws are made more comprehensive, the IPO will hold public hearings, forums and make relevant documents and materials available to the general public, all in order to gather valuable information on public opinions for the Office's reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO SET UP CAMPAIGN OFFICE NEXT TUESDAY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang will set up a campaign office next Tuesday as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) primary to choose its candidate for the 2008 presidential election gradually shifts into high gear.
As the premier must attend the Legislative Yuan for a question-and-answer session that day, he will not be able to attend its opening.

Former Taipei City Councilman Lan Shih-tsung will serve as the director of the office, located at the intersection of Xinyi Road and Jinshan South Road, while DPP Legislator Lin Yu-sheng will serve as office spokesman.
Lan said that the office will initially be divided into two divisions: campaign literature and organization. Time permitting, he hopes to include divisions on women's issues and social welfare.

Su is the third of four DPP presidential hopefuls to announce the launch of a campaign office, following former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi- kun. Vice President Annette Lu is the only one who has yet to announce the launch of a campaign office.

According to the DPP's primary mechanism, party members will vote in early May, which will account for 30 percent of the final tally, after which a series of public opinion polls accounting for the remaining 70 percent will be held. The winner of the combined polls will be announced as the party's presidential candidate May 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER WARNS KMT ON ETHNIC, PARTY ASSETS ISSUES

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng warned Friday the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on issues related to ethnicity and its assets, suggesting that the party must iron out response mechanisms to deal with all possible scenarios.
Wang made the comments while answering questions from reporters in central Changhua County, where he attended a seminar on preventing domestic violence sponsored by county authorities.

According to Wang, the KMT faces three major thorny issues in the short term and must ready itself for possible consequences arising from issues of ethnicity, party assets and former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's embezzlement trial, as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will undoubtedly rehash these issues to secure victory in the coming legislative and presidential elections.

As the DPP has been promoting a public endorsement campaign on what it called the KMT's illegally acquired party assets in hopes of putting the issue to a national referendum to be held along with the March 2008 presidential election, the KMT must not sit idle. The party has to properly handle these issue in the face of the DPP's predictable electioneering, Wang said.
Additionally, Wang said, the KMT also must be wary of negative developments in Ma's trial on corruption charges, and should set up a fast-response team to deal with issues arising from this case.
Wang, a KMT stalwart, also wished Ma the best in the party's presidential primary, in which Wang will not be participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEFEATS CHINA IN DAVIS CUP FIRST ROUND PLAY-OFFS

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis player Lu Yen-hsun, defeated China's Sun Peng in the first round play-offs of the 2007 Davis Cup Tennis Tournament, at the National Taiwan University's Sports Center Friday.

Lu, in high spirits and enjoying the home court advantage, beat Sun in five sets 3-6, 6-2, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2 to take the first match of the contest, clenching Taiwan's first victory after losing to Thailand 3-2 in February in the first round.

The victory came at a heavy price as Lu -- competing with pre-existing injuries -- saw his condition deteriorate throughout the day, said Kan Su-yuan, the team's athletic trainer. He added that Lu will not compete during the rest of matches against China out of concern that he might further aggravate his injures.
China and Taiwan will continue their on court battles until April 8 in Taipei, with four more single's matches remaining to determine the overall winner.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUTCH ASSOCIATION TO DONATE AMBULANCE TO KEELUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Belgium, April 6 (CNA) 04/06/07 21:35:54 (By P.C. Tang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The Netherlands-Taiwan Association, together with Rotary clubs in Holland and Taiwan, will donate an ambulance to Keelung City's volunteer fire fighting team, Taiwan's representative to the Netherlands Wang Yu-yuan told CNA correspondent in Brussels Friday.

The association's president Peter Pex and vice president Ruud Hoorweg initiated the donation drive with US$5,000, Wang said, adding that the Rotary clubs of South Holland, Taipei, Taipei Tienmu, and the Rotary Foundation all contributed to the purchase of an ambulance for the volunteer fire fighting team, which receives no government subsidies.
The ambulance is to be delivered this week, and the association has also promised to donate NT$50,000 (US$1,500) to St. Annes' Home for Seriously Retarded Children in Tienmu, Taipei City.
Wang said he had feasted Pex and Hoorweg April 4 to express gratitude in advance.
The Netherlands-Taiwan association, established in 1973 by a group of Dutch friendly to Taiwan has made great contributions to Taiwan-Netherlands relations, said Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC EMPHASIZES OIL AND GAS EXPLORATION

TEXT.P: The state-owned oil company CPC Corporation, Taiwan will invest at least NT$16 billion (US$482.66 million) in overseas oil and gas exploration during the next five years, said company Chairman Pan Wenent.

An oil company's domain is incomplete without exploration,Pan said, adding the CPC's objective is to become an international energy conglomerate with businesses including exploration, oil and gas sales and petrochemistry.

The CPC now operates at 9 foreign oil and gas fields in 6 countries including Ecuador, Indonesia, Venezuela, Australia, Chad and the United States. It has also won the bid for a Libyan field last year.
The CPC said that through explorations and mergers it aims to acquire an additional two fields and the equivalent of 10 million barrels of oil per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMALE OFFICER TRANSFERRED ON MERIT: COAST GUARD UNIT

TEXT.P: A Coast Guard Administrative unit on the frontline island of Kinmen stated Friday that a female officer posted to a harbor position here was transferred in recognition of her excellent job performance rather than any other reason.

The statement issued by the 9th Corps of the Central Coastal Patrol Office of the Coast Guard Administration said Lieutenant Pai Tsai-rung was transformed last month from her position as chief of the Shuitou wharf security post to be chief of staff for the 3rd Corps in Taichung, central Taiwan, to satisfy her desire to work near her Taichung home.
That wish was granted because her excellent job performance stood her in good stead during the Coast Guard Administration's regular staff reshuffle, the statement read.

The statement contradicts a feminist group's complaint that Pai, who assumed her job at Shuitou seven months ago, was forced to leave Kinmen after her male next- in-command at the check station was discovered stealing her underwear as a fetish.
According to the statement, reassignment from chief of a security post to the chief of staff of a corps is a promotion for Pai rather than a disciplinary action.

As for that male officer who stole Pai's underwear, the statement made clear that for demonstrating behavior unbecoming a military leader he has been transferred to a non-leadership position, but will not be otherwise disciplined.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES PROTECTION FOR MIGRATING BUTTERFLIES

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the public to keep an eye out for migrating euploea butterflies as he inspected a migratory route used by the colorful creatures in Linnei, Yunlin County Friday.

Premier Su made the remarks during a tour of Yunlin county to attend a euploea butterfly festival sponsored by Linnei township. Su, together with Yunlin Country Magistrate Su Chih-feng, also promoted papaya and other agricultural produce of Linnei township during the tour.

Su later listened to a briefing by Lee Tai-ming, director general of the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, about protective measures the bureau has adopted to safeguard the butterflies.
Lee noted that each year the butterflies pass a section of the Formosa Freeway in Linnei, Yunlin county on their northbound migration route.

The bureau has erected protective screens -- 200 meters in length and 2.5 meters high -- between the Jhushan and Douliou interchanges, as well as ultraviolet lights along the Linnei section to guide the butterflies around a heavily trafficked freeway bridge, all in a bid to preserve the good name of Taiwan as a butterfly kingdom.

Bureau officials noted that these measures, the first-ever along freeways in Taiwan to protect butterflies, were implemented at the suggestion of environmental researchers at I-shou University in Kaohsiung County.
Such large-scale protective measures for migrating butterflies are very unusual, even in other countries, officials said.
The premier spoke positively about what he saw, saying "If we love the beautiful butterflies, we must not harm them."
As the weather conditions over the past days have been variable, the number of the butterflies flying along the route has been less than expected.
It is estimated that the number of butterflies will peak between April 14 and April 19, though a further delay is possible.

The bureau stated that it has decided that the outer northbound lane on the Linei section of the freeway it may be temporarily closed if the average number of euploea butterflies passing over it exceeds 2,000 per minute.

According to previous surveys, at least one million euploea butterflies migrate every year from northern Taiwan to the south of the island, wintering near Kaohsiung or Taitung before flying back north in the spring.

The butterflies usually pass over the Linnei freeway section between mid-March and mid-April. In a single observation period on April 3, 2005, researchers recorded some 11,500 euploea butterflies per minute flying over the freeway: the equivalent of over one million butterflies in a single day.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS SECOND MATCH AGAINST CHINA IN DAVIS CUP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei tenis player Wang Yeu-tzuoo defeated his Chinese rival Yu Xinyuan in the second single's match of the 2007 Davis Cup in Taipei Friday, giving Taiwan a 2-0 advantage over China in the first round of the play-offs.

Wang, who has been absent from the court for four months due to an injured foot, cruised to victory 6-3, 6-2, 6-4 against Yu, who ranks outside of the top 500 in the world but is the best player taking the court for China.
Wang's victory was the second of the day for Chinese Taipei and brings the host team within one match of clenching a berth in the final of the Asia /Oceania Zone Group 1 in the 2007 Davis Cup.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 7, or the 20th day of the Second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first university in central Europe.
1827: John Waller, a chemist in northern England, sells the first matches, which he invented.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek resumes the Northward Expedition at the order of the National Government.
1932: A National Emergency Conference in Loyang decides on continued resistance against Japanese aggression.
1934: Mahatma Gandhi suspends his campaign of civil disobedience against British rule in India.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by U.S. aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jackie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1963: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is set up with Marshal Tito as president for life.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other locations around Taiwan to begin handling traffic violation cases.
1976: Simon Kuznets, 1971 Nobel Prize winner for economics, arrives in Taipei for a three-week-visit.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Guofeng as premier and to depose Deng Xiaoping as deputy premier after riots in Beijing.
1976: Hishan M. Nazer, Saudi Arabian minister of planning, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter backpedals on building the Neutron bomb.
1979: The International Olympic Committee decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting Communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1987: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces that American diplomats will not occupy the new embassy in Moscow until he is sure that it is secure against Soviet eavesdropping.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a U.S.-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
1998: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund agree on a package of measures to get a US$43 billion bailout package on track.
1999: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho urges the government to step up its international publicity drive to buttress global awareness of the Republic of China.
2000: Almost two-dozen founding members of the hard-line Independence Party announce their decision to drop out of the party because they say that the party has completed its mission.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, receives a set of CNA file photos, including one showing he in the arms of his mother along with his father and his elder brother.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is dishonorable. When there is no justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is also dishonorable."
