The statement contradicts a feminist group's complaint that Pai, who assumed her job at Shuitou seven months ago, was forced to leave Kinmen after her male next- in-command at the check station was discovered stealing her underwear as a fetish.
According to the statement, reassignment from chief of a security post to the chief of staff of a corps is a promotion for Pai rather than a disciplinary action.

As for that male officer who stole Pai's underwear, the statement made clear that for demonstrating behavior unbecoming a military leader he has been transferred to a non-leadership position, but will not be otherwise disciplined.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES PROTECTION FOR MIGRATING BUTTERFLIES

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the public to keep an eye out for migrating euploea butterflies as he inspected a migratory route used by the colorful creatures in Linnei, Yunlin County Friday.

Premier Su made the remarks during a tour of Yunlin county to attend a euploea butterfly festival sponsored by Linnei township. Su, together with Yunlin Country Magistrate Su Chih-feng, also promoted papaya and other agricultural produce of Linnei township during the tour.

Su later listened to a briefing by Lee Tai-ming, director general of the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, about protective measures the bureau has adopted to safeguard the butterflies.
Lee noted that each year the butterflies pass a section of the Formosa Freeway in Linnei, Yunlin county on their northbound migration route.

The bureau has erected protective screens -- 200 meters in length and 2.5 meters high -- between the Jhushan and Douliou interchanges, as well as ultraviolet lights along the Linnei section to guide the butterflies around a heavily trafficked freeway bridge, all in a bid to preserve the good name of Taiwan as a butterfly kingdom.

Bureau officials noted that these measures, the first-ever along freeways in Taiwan to protect butterflies, were implemented at the suggestion of environmental researchers at I-shou University in Kaohsiung County.
Such large-scale protective measures for migrating butterflies are very unusual, even in other countries, officials said.
The premier spoke positively about what he saw, saying "If we love the beautiful butterflies, we must not harm them."
As the weather conditions over the past days have been variable, the number of the butterflies flying along the route has been less than expected.
It is estimated that the number of butterflies will peak between April 14 and April 19, though a further delay is possible.

The bureau stated that it has decided that the outer northbound lane on the Linei section of the freeway it may be temporarily closed if the average number of euploea butterflies passing over it exceeds 2,000 per minute.

According to previous surveys, at least one million euploea butterflies migrate every year from northern Taiwan to the south of the island, wintering near Kaohsiung or Taitung before flying back north in the spring.

The butterflies usually pass over the Linnei freeway section between mid-March and mid-April. In a single observation period on April 3, 2005, researchers recorded some 11,500 euploea butterflies per minute flying over the freeway: the equivalent of over one million butterflies in a single day.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS SECOND MATCH AGAINST CHINA IN DAVIS CUP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei tenis player Wang Yeu-tzuoo defeated his Chinese rival Yu Xinyuan in the second single's match of the 2007 Davis Cup in Taipei Friday, giving Taiwan a 2-0 advantage over China in the first round of the play-offs.

Wang, who has been absent from the court for four months due to an injured foot, cruised to victory 6-3, 6-2, 6-4 against Yu, who ranks outside of the top 500 in the world but is the best player taking the court for China.
Wang's victory was the second of the day for Chinese Taipei and brings the host team within one match of clenching a berth in the final of the Asia /Oceania Zone Group 1 in the 2007 Davis Cup.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times U.N. panel issues bleakest world report on warming
Top climate experts issued their bleakest forecasts yet about global warming on Friday, ranging from hunger in Africa to a thaw of Himalayan glaciers in a study that may add pressure on governments to act.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRASS MOUNTAIN CHATEAU DAMAGED IN BLAZE

TEXT.P: The Grass Mountain Chateau on scenic Ynagmingshan in suburban Taipei, which was the late President Chiang Kai-shek's first official residence in Taiwan, was partially destroyed by a fire late Friday, Taipei City government officials said Saturday.

Initial investigations showed that the chateau's main exhibition hall spanning about 660 square meters had been completely engulfed in flames in the fire, which broke out at around 0: 20 a.m., municipal firefighting department officials said. They added that the cause of the fire has yet to be determined.

The department's Yangming outpost sent fire engines to the scene immediately after receiving an emergency call from security guards at the chateau, the officials said, adding that as the flames were very high, more fire gear from neighboring Shihlin, Shihpei and Huagang outposts were sent to help put out the fire which was brought under control at around 1:30 a.m.
According to the officials, their firefighting efforts were impeded by several factors, including a water shortage, heavy night fog, and the area's rugged terrain.

The city government has listed the 87-year-old chateau as a protected heritage site. The chateau was built in 1920 by Taiwan Sugar Corp. in preparation for a visit by then-Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito. Historical records show that Hirohito stayed at the house for only one hour and 50 minutes. The chateau later served as a spa villa for social celebrities during the period of Japanese colonial rule.

In December 1949, the Republic of China government moved its seat to Taipei, and President Chiang Kai-shek chose to stay at the chateau, making it Taiwan's first presidential residence. The president and his wife lived at the house until May 1950 when a new house was built in Taipei's Shihlin district. The chateau later served as the first couple's summer villa.

As several major government decisions were made during the Chiang's stay at the chateau, the Taipei City government decided Dec. 19, 2002 to list the house as a building of historical significance and officially named it the "Grass Mountain Chateau."

The building has since served as a cultural activity center that encompasses an exhibition hall, a conference room, a performance stage, a restaurant and reception area, and a management center. the mid-night fire mainly damaged the exhibition hall and the restaurant and reception area, known as Meilu Hall and Yingho Hall, respectively.
Municipal police authorities have begun investigating the cause of the fire.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Billions face dire risk from global warming, say experts.
Top climate scientists issued their bleakest assessment yet on global warming yesterday, with a warning that billions of people could go thirsty as water supplies dry up and millions more may starve as farmlands become deserts.
The Lianhe Zaobao: 30% species face extinction if earth's temperatures adds 2 deg C.
The United Nation's report warned about 30 percent species will face extinction if add 2 degrees centigrade (deg. C) to the earth's average temperatures than 80's and 90's.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO INVITE AMBASSADORS, REPS ON BIRDWATCHING TRIP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has arranged a birdwatching trip for ambassadors and representatives in Taiwan, MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Saturday.
Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang will accompany them to the scenic Aowanda National Forest Recreation Area in Nantou County in central Taiwan late this month, Wang said.
The ministry hopes that they will gain a greater appreciation of Taiwan's beautiful landscape and learn more about the island's environmental protection efforts, he added.
He noted that Aowanda is famous for its autumn scenes of colorful maple trees, adding that every March and April, it is also one of the best places in Taiwan for birdwatching.
"The diplomatic personnel will surely be impressed by Taiwan's natural beauty during their visit to Aowanda," Wang said.
He added that during their visit, they will have the chance to see Formosa Magpie, which briefly appear in Aowanda every April.

The Formosa Magpie is a leading contender to be chosen as Taiwan's national bird in a contest being sponsored by the Taiwan Association of Sustainable Ecological Engineering Development. The other three top contenders are the Yellow Tit, the Swinhoe's Pheasant and the Mikado Pheasant.

The MOFA arranges for diplomats and representatives to travel around Taiwan every year, with the aim of introducing the natural beauty of the island to foreign friends, Wang said. In recent years, trips have been arranged to the outlying Kinmen Island and Green Island.
The birdwatching trip was originally scheduled to take place at the end of March, but because Huang visited St. Lucia during that time, the trip was rescheduled for April 26-27.
Ambassadors and representative from 25 countries are expected to join the birdwatching trip, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MEMBERS GO TO POLLS FOR CHAIRMANSHIP BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) chairmanship by-election was held Saturday, with over 337,000 members around Taiwan and overseas casting ballots for one or the other of the two candidates -- former KMT acting Chairman Wu Poh- hsiung and Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu.

Honorary Chairman Lien Chan cast his ballot along with Wu and Hung. He called the election a milestone in the party's democratization, praising the candidates for showing respect for each other in their campaigning for the sake of the party unity.

"Both candidates have demonstrated what a decent election is, and that makes the election significant, " Lien said, adding that regardless of who wins, the person chosen as the new head of the party is expected to be able to push for cooperation between former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng -- two KMT aspirants for the presidency.
According to the KMT regulations, the person who wins will assume the post April 11 and serve until August 2009 when the party holds its 18th national congress.
Out of concerns about a possible low turnout due to cloudy weather and a four- day holiday, Ma urged party members to vote, while casting his ballot.

The number of eligible voters in this chairmanship by-election is much lower than that of the previous election in July 16, 2005, when 524,488 of the over 1 million eligible voters cast ballots. There are fewer eligible voters this time around because the KMT amended its election regulations under Ma's leadership, making only those party members who have paid their membership fees eligible to vote.

A total of 486 voting stations were set up around the country for Saturday's by- election, with the largest located at Changho Middle School in Taipei County, for 5,057 voters, and the smallest in Wushiu on the outlying island of Kinmen, for 15 voters.

Huang Chung-hsien, chief of the KMT organization and development department, expressed the hope that the turnout for this by-election will be around 40 percent and thus surpass the 19 percent turnout for the chairmanship election of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Jan. 15, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIRWAYS, CAL EXPECTED TO SEE ROBUST PROFIT GROWTH THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The nation's two largest air carriers are expected to see robust profit growth after fuel price pressure eases, analysts said Saturday.
Both China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways Corp. reported lackluster performance last year due to soaring oil prices, although fuel price pressures began to ease in the fourth quarter.
EVA Airways's revenue for 2006 totaled NT$93.9 billion (US$2.84 billion), up 6 percent from the previous year.
The second-largest air carrier reported a pre-tax profit of NT$650 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of NT$1.47 billion in the third quarter.
EVA Airways reported an after-tax net loss of NT$1.68 billion in 2006, which was less than expected.
CAL, the largest air carrier, reported revenue of NT$121.99 billion last year, up 12 percent from the previous year. After-tax net profit was NT$738 million, up 14.43 percent over the previous year.
Analysts said that average oil prices this year are expected to be lower than last year, which they said will ease pressure on air carriers.

In addition, the prospect of more cross-strait charter flights at times other than during the Chinese New Year, Tombsweeping Day, Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-Autumn Festival holidays will also be a boost for the two air carriers.
Analysts estimated that EVA Airways' revenue will be NT$92.14 billion this year, with a pre-tax net profit of NT$1.09 billion, while CAL will register a profit of NT$2.08 billion for the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUCCESSFUL ALUMNUS OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Lee Shu-ken, a successful alumnus of Yung An Elementary School in eastern Taitung County, has been offering scholarships to the school's students for 20 years to encourage them to utilize their talents, study and achieve, the school's principal, Yang Huei-mei, said Saturday.
Lee, who started his own homestay business in his hometown of Taitung County decades ago, offers NT$200,000 (US$6,046) in scholarship money annually, Yang said.

The school set up the Lee Shu-ken Scholarship and a strict scholarship committee to examine which students are qualified to receive scholarship money. Nearly 70 percent of students at the school have received scholarship money, ranging from NT$100 to NT$5,000.

The scholarship money is used to help students pay their registration fees or school lunches and to award students who perform well, Yang said, adding that eight students have received over NT$10,000 in scholarship money.
For example, fifth-grade student Wang Wei-chin, has been awarded NT$34,875 in scholarship money for her excellent performance in school and sports.
Some students are able to relieve the financial burden on their families with the scholarship money, Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION CALLS FOR DONATIONS TO AID TO ABORIGINAL CHILDREN

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan has recently begun its annual campaign aimed at raising funds for educational aid to aboriginal children living in remote mountain areas in central Taiwan.

This is the ninth year that the charity organization is holding the campaign in cooperation with Starbucks Taiwan, a joint venture between U.S. coffee giant Starbucks Corp. and the Taiwan-based Uni-President Enterprises Corp., to help kids living in poverty to receive an education.

A donation of NT$1,000 (US$30) allows an aboriginal child to take after-school courses, while a donation of NT$2,500 can help one poor child pay tuition for one semester, according to World Vision Taiwan.

For this year, a World Vision Taiwan executive said Saturday, the organization plans to assist 3,650 aboriginal children living in the educational resources- poor Hoping village in Taichung County, as well as in Hsinyi and Jenai villages in Nantou County, to go to school and take after-school courses.
Last year, the campaign raised over NT$4.2 million, which allowed 1,900 aboriginal children living in the three remote villages to go to school, World Vision Taiwan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANNING FOR TAICHUNG AIRPORT SHOULD HAVE BROAD VISION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the planning of the Taichung Airport should have broad vision and take into consideration prospective Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan, according to Legislator Yang Chiung-ying of the opposition Kuomintang.

Yang, her legislative colleagues Kuo Chun-ming and Hsieh Ming-yuan from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, as well as DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung attended a briefing for President Chen. The president, accompanied by Premier Su Tseng-chang, inspected the Taichung Airport, which was converted from an air base.
Talks with China on the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists for sightseeing are reportedly in the final stage.

According to Legislator Yang, the president thinks that the facilities of the airport are still not up to par with those of international airports, that the software and hardware equipment must be improved, and that facilities for outbound traffic should be upgraded.

Yang noted that many local people are worried that Taichung Airport, although called an international airport, has only a very limited number of international charter flights. Its function as a domestic airport has gradually decreased, especially since the inauguration of the high-speed rail system early this year. They urged the government to help step up software and hardware improvements so that it will not remain an airport for only charter flights.

These local people suggested an extension of a planned mass rapid transit system line to connect it to the airport, as well as the construction of additional runways and hangars at the airport, and the opening of cargo services to facilitate the export of goods of manufacturers in the Central Taiwan Science Park.

According to Civil Aeronautics Administration statistics, there are around 30,000 passengers every month on domestic flights to and from the airport, mainly going to and from Taiwan's offshore islands.
On international charter flights, there are more than 40,000 passengers every month, mainly to Hong Kong, Macau and Vietnam, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRASSROOTS FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS' OVERDUE LOAN RATIO DOWN TO 7.91%

TEXT.P: The credit departments of the country's farmers' and fishermen's associations had an average overdue loan ratio of 7.91 percent at the end of February, down 0.1 percentage points from the previous month's level, according to official statistics released Saturday.

The total amount in non-performing loans was NT$52.7 billion (US$1.6 billion) at the end of February, down NT$500 million from the previous month's level, the statistics compiled by the Bureau of Agricultural Finance under the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture indicate.

The total assets of the farmers' and fishermen's associations stood at NT$1.58 trillion as of the end of February, up NT$5.7 billion from the previous month's figure, while the credit departments' net worth increased NT$300 million to NT$85.4 billion.

The credit departments' total outstanding deposits amounted to NT$1.37 trillion as of the end of February, up NT$1.8 billion from the previous month, and the outstanding loans totaled NT$666.7 billion, up NT$2.8 billion.

The overdue loan ratio of the credit departments of the farmers' and fishermen's associations peaked at 19.33 percent as of the end of 2001, and the ratio has since decreased after major efforts to improve the financial structure of the grassroots financial institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Climate change puts 30 percent of species in planet at risks of extinction.
A United Nations climate change report warns that some 30 percent of fauna and flora species in the planet are at risks of extinction due to global warming.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH URGES YOUNG PEOPLE TO AVOID DRUGS, PRACTICE SAFE SEX

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) on Saturday urged youths to stay away from drugs and practice safe sex.

Lin Ting, deputy chief of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, made the appeal amid reports that police arrested drug dealers at the annual Spring Scream music and arts festival which kicked off early this week in the resort area of Kenting in southern Pingtung County.
Li noted that the number of young people who have been infected with HIV through sexual activity has risen rapidly and that drug use often increases the risks of contracting the disease.
A recent survey conducted by the DOH shows that more than 20 percent of young people who have had sexual intercourse in the past month have not practiced safe sex.

DOH statistics also show that over the past year, 394 young people between the age of 15 and 24 were confirmed to have been infected with HIV. The number of people infected with HIV in this age group has increased steadily in recent years, mainly because of the practice of unsafe sex, Lin said.

Lin said that drug dealers often use such events as the Spring Scream to sell their goods, adding that the atmosphere at such events could lure young people to try drugs, which he claimed often leads to unsafe sex.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CENTRAL LIBRARY TO HOLD BOOK SHOWS TO PROMOTE READING

TEXT.P: The National Central Library is slated to hold several book shows of different themes in 2007 to promote reading, with the first book show set to be launched April 21 in the reading room on the library's second floor, a spokesman for the library said Saturday.

The first show will run through July 1 and be followed by book shows on the themes of "Old Photos of Local Places" to be held July 3-Sep. 30, "Reading France" to run from Oct. 2-31, and "Research Methods and Thesis Writing" to be held Nov. 2-Dec. 31.
About 120 to 160 books will be exhibited at each show, and the list of the books being displayed at shows will be posted on the library's Web site, the spokesman said.

The spokesman said the book shows are aimed at encouraging the public to utilize the library more and cultivate the habit of reading as part of efforts to create a "learning society" where "anyone can read books anywhere."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS TAICHUNG FOR BRIEFING ON SHUINAN DEVELOPMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited Taichung City, central Taiwan, Saturday with Premier Su Tseng-chang to receive a briefing from the city government on plans to develop the vast plot of land where the old Shuinan Airport once stood.

The development project, formed after the airport facilities were relocated to the Chingchuankang Airport in March 2004, thus leaving approximately 250 hectares of land vacant, drew Chen's attention after Richard Li, a Hong Kong business tycoon whose father is Asia's richest man, Li Ka-shing, appeared interested in the project during his visit to the site of the former airport last month.

Talking about the development project, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said work on carrying out the project has long been put off because of the problem of covering the cost of at least NT$7 billion (US$211.64 million) of work to relocate the Air Force second logistic command center away from the Shuinan airport site.

The Shuinan airport was built during the period of Japanese colonial rule of the island to serve as a military airport. It was taken over after the end of World War Two by the ROC Air Force, which established the logistic command center and an aviation industrial development center at the airport.

From that time until 1980, all Taiwan-produced aircraft were manufactured and underwent tests at the airport, according to the city government. As Taichung expanded, the airport's relative location shifted from the outskirts to the center of the city. It is now situated near the Central Taiwan Science Park, Fengchia University and the Aerospace Industrial Development Corp., which designed and built Taiwan's Indigenous Defense Fighters.

As the airport's existence was often blamed for hindering the city's land traffic and urban development, the city government kicked off efforts after the relocation of the airport facilities in 2004 to develop the place into a modern urban center that has been planned to house a university city, a trading exhibition center, an exclusive residential district and a forest park.
After the briefing, Hu cited President Chen as saying that the central government will do something to address the problem that has hindered the development project from proceeding for years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Counselor To Gonzales Announces Resignation; Goodling Had Refused to Testify on Prosecutor Firing.
The senior counselor to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales submitted her resignation yesterday, becoming the third high-ranking Justice Department aide to quit in the aftermath of the firings of eight U.S. attorneys.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Scientists Detail Climate Changes, Poles to Tropics
From the poles to the tropics, the earths climate and ecosystems are already being shaped by the atmospheric buildup of greenhouse gases and face inevitable, possibly profound, alteration, the worlds leading scientific panel on climate change said Friday.
In its most detailed portrait of the effects of climate change driven by human activities, the panel predicted widening droughts in southern Europe and the Middle East, sub-Saharan Africa, the American Southwest and Mexico, and flooding that could imperil low-lying islands and the crowded river deltas of southern Asia. It stressed that many of the regions facing the greatest risks were among the worlds poorest.
Wall Street Journal:A Blow in Court Adds to Threats Facing Vonage
A few years ago, Vonage Holdings Corp. founder Jeffrey Citron promised to revolutionize the telephone business by using the Internet to carry cheap phone calls. Sure enough, Internet calling exploded in popularity. But Vonage is fighting for its life.
A federal judge said Friday Vonage must stop signing up new customers unless it avoids infringing on patents held by Verizon Communications Inc. While the ruling stopped short of shutting down service to Vonage's 2.2 million existing customers, a lawyer for Vonage, Roger Warin, called it almost as devastating. "It's the difference of cutting off oxygen as opposed to the bullet in the head," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WU POH-HSIUNG WINS KMT CHAIRMANSHIP BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Former acting chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , Wu Poh-hsiung, won Saturday's KMT chairmanship by-election by a landslide.
Wu garnered 156,499 votes, or 86.97 percent of the 181,374 votes cast, beating his only rival, Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, who managed 23,447 votes.
Wu said after the victory that he'll "do his utmost to promote party solidarity after assuming his new post April 11."
Wu also said that the "new task will be the beginning of responsibility," vowing to promote party affairs in an "impartial manner."

The new chairman will immediately face the daunting task of coordinating between the two KMT presidential aspirants -- former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng -- in the hopes of helping the party win the 2008 presidential election.

The other task will be coordinating among legislative hopefuls for the year-end legislative elections, for which a new "single-member constituency and two votes" electoral system will be adopted, under which the number of seats in the legislature will be halved to 113.

Wu, 68, was widely favored to win this election given his solid background in politics. He has served as Taoyuan County magistrate, Taipei mayor, Minister without portfolio, minister of the interior, secretary-general of the Presidential Office and vice chairman of the KMT.
Wu and Hung hugged each other to show the reconciliation between them after the election. Wu also presented Hung with a birthday cake to wish her happiness, as Saturday happened to be her birthday.

A total of 337,467 KMT members around Taiwan and overseas were eligible to cast ballots in the by-election, which became necessary after Ma resigned from his post upon being indicted in early February for allegedly embezzling public funds.
The voter turnout rate was 53 percent, better than the estimate of 40 percent by the KMT's original estimate in view of the inclement weather and the fact it is a long weekend.
Hung, who came to the party's headquarters to watch the vote count after the polls closed at 4 p.m., conceded defeat before the count was finished as she trailed by a large margin.
Hung said she fared worse than she had expected, but she added that "to take part is itself a victory."
Hung said that she was not satisfied with reports which described the by- election as a "a battle between proxies, " meaning that Ma favored Wu while she joined the election at the urging of Wang.

She said that her relations with Wu will not change after the election, pointing out that there weren't any clashes during the campaign period, although she did find that there are some things about the party that need to be improved.
She stressed that she will not bid for an at-large seat in the year-end legislative elections, adding that between now and December, she has several months to think about her next step or next job.

After seeing People First Party Chairman James Soong send a floral basket to Wu at 5 p.m. to congratulate him for his victory, Hung also jokingly said that Soong should be fair and also send her a floral basket to comfort the loser and wish her happiness on her birthday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRASS MOUNTAIN CHATEAU TO BE RESTORED: CITY CULTURAL CHIEF

TEXT.P: The late President Chiang Kai-shek's first official residence in Taiwan, which was badly damaged in a fire just after midnight Friday, will definitely be restored to its past glory, Taipei City's culture chief said Saturday.

Lee Yung-ping, director of the Department of Cultural Affairs of the Taipei City government, made the remarks after the Grass Mountain Chateau on scenic Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei was almost completely engulfed in the fire that broke out at around 12: 20 a.m.

The style of the 660-square-meter main building, on an estate covering about 1,815 square meters, is typical of Japanese architecture of the 1920s. The wall of the entrance to the main building is made of stone, with Japanese wooden structure inside.
The fire destroyed more than half of the main building, with the wooden interior being completely burnt. The stone wall remains intact.

Total damage is estimated at roughly NT$36 million (US$1.09 million) , Lee said, adding that the municipal cultural department will invite experts and scholars to form a special panel to investigate the extent of the damage and flesh out a restoration plan.

Noting that the city government had conducted an elaborate study on the chateau's architectural structure and interior design before formally listing it as a protected heritage site in 2002, Lee said she believes it won't be very difficult to restore it to its original glory.

As to the exhibits on display in its main hall, Lee said, reproduction will not be a problem given the fact that nearly all of the items were replicas. Nevertheless, she added that the question of what exhibits will be displayed inside the restored building will be open for further discussion by experts and scholars.
Lee said the special panel, to be composed of three to six academics and architectural specialists, will hold its first meeting Monday or Tuesday.

As the fire happened at a time when Taipei's politicians have been squabbling over whether to preserve the late President Chiang's legacy or wipe it out after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) branded him as the main perpetrator of the infamous 228 Incident of 1947, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said he will ask municipal police officers to step up patrols in and around the chateau as well as at other buildings dedicated to the memory of Chiang, including the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hal, the Shihlin Domicile and the Yangming Residence.
Hau refrained from speculation about the cause of the fire, saying an investigation team has been formed to probe why and how the blaze had broken out in the first place.

Since the chateau has been designated as a heritage site, Hau said it should not become a target of criticism. "People of different political stripes or affiliations should all work for preservation of cultural heritage and historical relics." he added.

The municipal firefighting department's Yangming outpost sent fire engines to the scene immediately after receiving an emergency call from security guards at the chateau round midnight, city officials said, adding that as the flames were very high, more fire gear from neighboring Shihlin, Shihpei and Huagang outposts were sent to help put out the fire which was brought under control at around 1:30 a.m.
According to the officials, their firefighting efforts were impeded by several factors, including a water shortage, heavy night fog, and the area's rugged terrain.

The city government has listed the 87-year-old estate as a protected heritage site. The chateau was built in 1920 by Taiwan Sugar Corp. in preparation for a visit by then-Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito. Historical records show that Hirohito stayed at the house for only one hour and 50 minutes. The chateau later served as a spa villa for social celebrities during the period of Japanese colonial rule.

In December 1949, the Republic of China government moved its seat to Taipei, and President Chiang Kai-shek chose to stay at the chateau, making it Taiwan's first presidential residence. The president and his wife lived at the house until May 1950 when a new house was built in Taipei's Shihlin district. The chateau later served as the first couple's summer villa.

As several major government decisions were made during the Chiang's stay at the chateau, the Taipei City government decided Dec. 19, 2002 to list the house as a building of historical significance and officially named it the "Grass Mountain Chateau."

The building has since served as a cultural activity center that encompasses an exhibition hall, a small-scale showroom, a multifunctional auditorium, a performance area, a semi-open air coffee shop , and a management center. The mid-night fire damaged all the exhibition hall and showrooms as well as the coffee shop, known as Meilu Hall and Yingho Hall, respectively.
The city government has commissioned the Buddhist Fo Kuang University to manage the chateau since 2002 and the cooperation contract is scheduled to expire at the end of June this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBI REMINDS INTERNET USERS TO BE ON GUARD AGAINST PHISHING

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CBI) reminded people Saturday to be aware of the criminal activity of phishing when using the Internet.

A CBI spokesman said phishers usually send e-mails with a hyperlink to a bogus Web site falsely claiming to be that of a legitimate enterprise. Users are then tricked into handing over their personal information, such as credit card numbers, which the phishers then use to withdraw money from the users' accounts.
There have been many victims of phantom withdrawals by phishers, the spokesman said, adding that people have been duped out of millions of dollars in total.
The spokesman said that Internet users should be sure that the Web site they are visiting is legitimate, especially if they locate the Web sites via the use of search engines.

He also reminded users not to click onto links to unknown Web sites, and not to open emails from unknown senders. In addition, he recommended that people regularly change their passwords and use authorized software as a precaution against phishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAVYWEIGHTS HOPE NEW CHAIRMAN TO STRIVE FOR PARTY UNITY

TEXT.P: Former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou expressed the hope Saturday that the newly-elected KMT chairman, Wu Poh-hsiung, will attach importance to party unity and reform after assuming the post, while Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight, expressed the wish that Wu will make efforts to improve the party's image.

Wu won Saturday's KMT chairmanship by-election by garnering 156,000 votes. His only rival, Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, received just 23,000 votes. After learning about Wu's victory during his visit to the southern county of Kaohsiung, Ma said that he expects the chairman-elect to help the party win back power in the 2008 presidential election.

Also in Kaohsiung County, Wang urged KMT members during his visit to his hometown of Luchu Village to do their utmost to maintain the party's image, while calling for the new leadership to reconsider a proposal to amend the party's charter to allow the nomination of a member who is found guilty of a law offense in a district court to represent the KMT in a major election like the presidential election.
Wang claimed the proposal, aimed at allowing Ma, who is on trial for allegedly embezzling public funds, to join the KMT primary for the presidential election, has triggered criticism in society.
Ma was indicted Feb. 13 for allegedly embezzling NT$11.17 million from a special allowance fund budgeted for his discretionary use during his term as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006.
Both Ma and Wang are aspirants for the KMT's nomination to represent the party in the next presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP URGES NEW KMT CHIEF NOT TO BOYCOTT 2007 BUDGET BILL

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday she looks forward to seeing the main opposition Kuomintang no longer boycott the central government's 2007 budget bill under its new chairman.
Lu made the remarks after Wu Poh-hsiung, a seasoned politician, won a landslide in his party's chairmanship by-election earlier in the day.

Noting that a number of critical bills have been stalled in the opposition- controlled Legislative Yuan, Lu said she keenly hopes that the Wu-led KMT will no longer boycott the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's policy initiatives at every turn.

The KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally -- the People First Party, jointly control a slim majority in the legislature and have often blocked the Cabinet- proposed bills from even being discussed on the legisaltive floor over the past seven years.

Lu, who is bidding to represent the DPP in the 2008 presidential election, said it is hoped that the KMT can from now on act as the country's loyal opposition and engage in peaceful and rational competition with the ruling DPP with visionary policy proposals. As the first step, Lu said, Wu can help manage an early passage by the legislature of the central government's 2007 budget bill which should have been approved before the last legislative session ended in late January.

Responding to Singaporean Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew's recent criticism that Taiwan's pursuit of independence and a new constitution is a dead-end that would lead to nowhere, Lu said Taiwan has long been an independent sovereign country and need not waste time any more on a debate over whether it should seek independence.

As to constitutional re-engineering, Lu said it's all too common in a democratic country where the government is entitled to tailor its constitutional system to cater to its changing political and social situations.

Lu further said the drive to promote Taiwanese identity is not aimed at confronting with China. "Instead, we treat China as a distant relative and a close neighbor that both can benefit from peaceful engagement in various fields,: she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITY COUNCILOR CALLS FOR NO HASTE IN DECIDING CHATEAU'S FATE

TEXT.P: An opposition Taipei City councilor urged the municipal government Saturday to refrain from hastily deciding to restore a badly damaged chateau "to its past glory" simply because a late president once briefly lived there.

Chien Yu-yen, a first-time councilwoman from the tiny Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , made the remarks after Lee Yung-ping, director of the city government's Department of Cultural Affairs, said earlier in the day that the Grass Mountain Chateau on Yang ming shand in suburban Tipei, which was partially destroyed by a fire just after midnight Friday, will definitely be restored since it is listed as a protected heritage site.

Chien advised Lee of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to wait at least until after an investigation report on the cause of the fire is completed to evaluate whether the 87-year-old chateau should be rebuilt with taxpayers' money.

While the KMT-controlled city government has touted the Japanese-style chateau as the late President Chiang Kai-shek's first official residence in Taiwan, Chien said that to the best of her knowledge, Chiang had lived at a villa in Tahsi in northern Taoyuan County for nearly two months after fleeing to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland in June 1949 before moving to Grass Mountain Chateau.

During Chiang's authoritarian rule of Taiwan, Chien said, he had built more than 37 chateaus in scenic spots around Taiwan, with the exception of Granss Mountain Chateau which was built in 1920 during the era of Japanese colonial rule.

"It is worth thinking whether we should presever so many legacies of a 'dictator' whom the Democratic Progressive Party administration has branded as the key perpetrator of the infamous 228 Incident of 1947, " Chien said, adding that it is hoped that the municipal cultural bureau can refrain from adopting an ideology-based approach to deal with the "heritage sites" issue.

In her view, Chien said, the city government has not attached similar importance to the preservation of the city's other cultural heritage sites, such as Chungshan Bridge, Taiwan railway relics and Talungtung cultural relics.

"The cultural affairs department should give the top priority to all city dwellers' interest in deciding the chateau's fate and should not blindly spend huge public funds to preserve anything related with the late dictator," she added.
The cause of the fire that engulfed the Grass Mountain Chateau's main building is still under investiogations.

The city government has commissioned the Buddhist Fo Kuang University to manage the chateau since 2002 and the cooperation contract is scheduled to expire at the end of June this year. Chien said whether the university should be held responsible for compensation for the fire damage also deserves a study.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS' REACTIONS MIXED TO REVISING PARTY 'EXCLUSION' RULES

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) had mixed responses Sunday to a proposal that the party modify a rule excluding indicted members from taking part in any elections, with some expressing concern that doing so would erode the party's image and affect its chances in December's legislative polls.

Light was shed on the issue after Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng issued Saturday a statement congratulating KMT Chairman-elect Wu Poh-hsiung and warning the KMT central about revising its "exclusion rules."
The KMT central should refrain from making the revision, as the move might spark a split within the party and push it to backtrack, Wang argued in the statement.

Wang issued the call, aimed at Wu, who has long been viewed as supportive of former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou -- the most likely KMT candidate in the March 2008 presidential election despite his embezzlement charges in mid-February, which prompted him to resign from the party's top post.
Despite corruption charges, Ma has repeatedly expressed his desire to run in the next presidential election, and last week picked up a registration form for the KMT's presidential primary.

Wang, also a KMT heavyweight who harbors his own presidential ambitions, did not pick up the registration form, meaning that he would not join the party's presidential primary and will miss out on the chance to be nominated by the KMT.

Taoyuan Magistrate Chu Li-lun, a member of the KMT who maintains good relations with Ma, said the same day that it is up to the party's delegates to decide whether or not a rule change should be implemented.

"It is necessary to continue with party reform which should be dictated by the KMT's actual needs rather than the ruling party's election strategies, " Chu said, adding that the matter must be jointly determined by party delegates.
Chu said he does not agree with Wang's viewpoint that a regulation amendment will push the KMT to split, but added that every member in the party is free to air his or her own opinion for discussion.

Echoing Chu's comments, KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, who is widely taken to be a protege of Ma, opined that no one, neither the party central, could determine whether or not the regulations should be modified.

As a democratic political party, the issue must be decided after being fully studied by delegates in the party's national congress slated for June, Lai said, adding that it is still too early to discuss the matter now.

In contrast, KMT Legislator Ho Tsai-feng urged Wu to carefully and wisely deal with the proposal regarding an amendment to the party's "exclusion" regulations, as it may hinder the party's chances in the year-end legislative election, which also will serve as a litmus test for the March 2008 presidential election.

Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , commented later the same day in southern Kaohsiung City that the KMT's intention to revise the party's regulations to firm up Ma's chances of participating in the next presidential election clearly showed that the party does not deserve the people's trust.

Former Premier and former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, a DPP heavyweight vying for the party's nomination for the coming presidential, said during a campaign stop in Kaohsiung County that the KMT's rule change plan fully reflects the party's hopelessness, and that the people of Taiwan must not allow such a corrupt political party to regain power in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF TO RETURN FROM U.S. TUESDAY

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong who flew to San Francisco after ending up in a far behind third place in the election of Taipei mayor last December, will return to Taipei Tuesday, PFP lawmaker Daniel Hwang said Sunday.

Hwang said he and other PFP lawmakers believed Soong who declared his quit from politics after the Dec. 7 election will pull his weight in pushing for the cooperation of PFP and Kuomintang in the forthcoming legislative elections. After leaving the island for four months, Hwang said he is sure that Soong has figured out some ways to help the country and his party or he would not come back at this time.

He would not elaborate on whether Soong will help Kuomintang and PFP to enter joint candidates with the best hope in the year end legislative election or whether Soong will use his personal influence to push for the cooperation between the two KMT presidential hopefuls, former KMT chief Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, in the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI DEFEATS CHINA IN DAVIS CUP

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei which entered Sunday's games with 2 to 1 lead over China saw China catching up from behind in Sunday's first match after its player Lu Yen- hsun who was plagued by injury to his foot was knocked down by his Chinese opponent Yu Xinyuan 4-6, 5-7, 6-2 and 6-7.
Fortunately its player Wang Yeu-tzuoo won the deciding fifth match against Chinese player Sung Peng 6-4, 7-5 and 6-3 and secured a place for Taiwan in the Asia-Oceania Zone Group 1.
The three-day event was the first Davis Cup ever staged in Taipei and had drawn much public attention because it pit the host team against Chinese team.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 10, or the 23rd day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1938: More than 99 percent of Austrian voters in a referendum cast their ballots in favor of a merger with Germany.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander-in- chief of all the Free French forces.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo- chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The U.S. Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: The USS Thresher, an American atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the American government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach an accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1991: Georgia becomes the latest of the Soviet republics wishing to break away from central control.
1996: Mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's visit to France is marred by a diplomatic wrangle with his French counterpart Alain Juppe over human rights in Beijing.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan.
2001: The 13th annual convention of the Overseas Chinese Council in Asia opens in Osaka, Japan, with more than 400 delegates from the Asia-Pacific region participating.
2002: Vice President Annette Lu wins a civil suit against the Taipei-based Journalist weekly, for damage to her image arising from a false report carried by the magazine.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possesses moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to, but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
CABINET SEEKS TO PRESERVE SANATORIUM BUT MAKES NO GUARANTEE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet expressed its willingness Monday to save the 70-year-old Losheng leprosarium from being dismantled to make way for a Taipei metro depot project, but fell short of satisfying patients and preservationists by making mandatory its request that the Taipei County Government suspend the demolition.

As the April 16 departure deadline for patients with Hansen's disease still living in the Losheng Sanatorium, in Hsinchuang City, Taipei County, draws near, a group of patients and activists visited the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission and demanded that an alternative retaining 90 percent of the existing 4-hectare compound be adopted.

Chairman of the commission Wu Tse-cheng said in a joint news conference with petitioners that he will do his best to communicate with Taipei County Government and Taipei City's Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DORST) so as to provide "at least one to two more months" for a better solution to be worked out.
He said the three agencies have been meeting and seeking technically feasible measures to meet the 90 percent preservation demand.
"We will try to preserve as much as possible and will explain to the public where preservation is for technical reasons not feasible," he said.

Lee Tien-pei, president of the patients' self-help organization, said he was disappointed with Wu's stance, saying the Executive Yuan should immediately issue formal instructions ordering the Taipei County Government to halt demolition.
However, Wu declined the request, saying "there must be mutual respects between agencies."

Cheng Wen-lung, a lawyer from the Legal Aid Foundation, appealed to what he called the two key persons in determining whether the sanatorium remains in place after April 16: Premier Su Tseng-chang and Taipei County Magistrate Chou His-wei.
Cheng said Magistrate Chou must not order the demolition before a renewed assessment over the whole project is completed, "otherwise he will be condemned in history."

He called on Su to publicly meet with the patients and listen to their wishes and opinions, as well as to order a halt to the eviction, "so to remove uncertainties afflicting society and the patients."

The leprosarium was built in 1930 by Japanese colonizers to treat patients with Hansen's disease in segregation, and the Kuomintang regime in its early years in Taiwan inherited the policy. In later years, patients were later allowed to leave the sanitarium, but many, having lived in chronic isolation and faced discrimination had little choice but to stay, long since grew accustomed to the settings.
Several dozen elderly patients still live in the compound and are resisting the government's plan to relocate them to a nearby high-rise hospital.

Preservationists have been advocating for the patients' right to stay and say that as the only leper colony in Taiwan, the institution provides living testimony to past indignities endured by the patients and is thus of great historical and cultural value.

DOC.HEADLINE: BCC REFUSES TO GIVE BACK TWO RADIO FREQUENCIES

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) urged the National Communications Commission (NCC) Monday to maintain its status as an independent agency and ignore the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's demand that the NCC take back two radio frequencies being used by the BCC.
The BCC said in a statement that if the government keeps pressing the NCC to take back the two frequencies, the BCC will resort to administrative litigation and demand state compensation.

The BBC explained that in 2004, the Government Information Office had agreed to a corrective measure proposed by the Control Yuan -- the nation's highest watchdog body -- that the BCC give back the radio frequency being used by its Formosa Network when the company's digital broadcasting begins commercial operations.

The statement pointed out that BCC has not yet applied for commercial digital broadcasting, and therefore the government would be "eating its own words" if it requires the BCC to give back the frequency.

The statement further noted that the NCC has not reclaimed another radio frequency being used by the BCC's Wave 96, a music network, mainly because an assessment by the NCC has led to the conclusion that the BCC would have a great chance of winning a court battle to claim state compensation if the NCC takes back the frequency.
The BCC used to be a broadcasting company owned by the Kuomintang (KMT), which held power in Taiwan for 51 years until 2000.

The company was founded as the Central Broadcasting System in Nanjing in 1928 and adopted its current name in 1947. It moved to Taiwan in 1949 when the Kuomintang government lost a civil war against the Chinese Communists.
The BCC, which has the most radio network services in Taiwan, became a privately owned company unrelated to the KMT in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PROMOTE ETHANOL-BLENDED GASOLINE

TEXT.P: Ethanol-blended gasoline will be available at seven gas stations in Taipei beginning in September, energy authorities said Monday.

Part of a pioneer project to promote biomass energy, the seven stations that provide E3 ethanol-blended gasoline - 97 percent of gasoline and 3 percent of ethanol - will serve mostly governmental vehicles but also welcome private cars, said Yeh Huey-ching, Chief of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Yeh said since the ethanol-blended gasoline, estimated to cost NT$30 per liter, is more expensive than gasoline, the ministry will draft a bill that allows subsidization for ethanol-blended gasoline by June, adding details of the bill still need to be worked out.
Also, the MOEA has chosen Chiayi and Taoyuan counties as"Green Counties", where public buses will use diesel with 1 percent bio, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ON PAR WITH OTHER COUNTRIES IN PACE OF WARMING: CWB

TEXT.P: Taiwan is on par with other countries around the world in terms of warming, a senior official of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Monday.
Wu Teh-jung, director of the CWB's Weather Forecast Center, made the remarks while delivering a report at the Legislative Yuan's standing Committee on Science, Technology and Information.

During the session, lawmakers asked Wu's view on some media reports claiming that Taiwan has outpaced the rest of the world with climatic change causing its average temperature to rise at double the global average in recent years.

In response, Wu said such reports are misleading. According to Wu, the global average temperature incorporates sea surface temperatures, but rises in global surface temperatures more double the overall average. Therefore, he said, Taiwan hasn't surpassed any other country given its pace of warming.

On lawmakers' complaints that the CWB's weather forecasts were not accurate enough, CWB Director-General Hsin Chiang-lin said it's hard to achieve a 100 percent accuracy in weather forecasting given the stochastic nature of temperature.

As a matter of fact, Hsin said the CWB has continue improving the quality and accuracy of its weather forecasts in recent years. The CWB no longer lags behind its counterparts in other countries in typhoon forecasting, particularly regarding a typhoon's course, Hsin said proudly, adding that the results of various public opinion surveys showed that 80 percent of local residents were satisfied with the CWB's round-the-clock weather forecasting service.

While some people blamed the CWB for failing to forecast a squall that struck certain parts of western Taiwan April 2, Hsin said it is very difficult to forecast a squall the day before because squalls tend to gather in just three to four hours.
A squall is a sudden, sharp increase in wind speed usually associated with active weather, such as rain showers, thunderstorms or heavy snow.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ANNOUNCES 2 NEW APPOINTMENTS

TEXT.P: Chen Ming-tong, a former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) who is now a professor of National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of National Development, will serve as the MAC chairman, Executive Yuan Deputy Secretary-General Chen Mei-ling said Monday.
Chen Mei-ling also announced the Executive Yuan's decision to appoint Legislator Chen Ching-jun of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as vice minister of transportation and communications.
Chen Ming-tong will succeed Joseph Wu as the country's top China policy planner. Wu has been appointed to serve as Taiwan's top representative to the United States.

As his transfer to new job requires the approval of National Taiwan University, Chen Ming-tong refrained from issuing any comment on his new assignment. He just said whether he would accept his new job will depend on whether the school would allow him to work for the MAC on loan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 NCC COMMISSIONERS SHOULD BE SUSPENDED FOR VIOLATIONS: CABINET

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has ordered that two commissioners of the National Communications Commission (NCC) be suspended from their jobs for violating conflict of interest laws.

Executive Yuan Deputy Secretary-General Chen Mei-ling made the announcement at a news conference Monday in which an investigation report on the body's legal infractions and certain controversial decisions were unveiled.

According to the report, NCC commissioners Wu Chung-chi and Liu Kung-chung should be suspended for violating the law requiring that public functionaries avoid conflicts of interest as well as the Civil Service Law and the NCC Organic Law, both of which demand ethical integrity.

Pointing out that Liu had hired an in-law and that Wu had hired his son to serve as their chauffeurs using government-provided cars, Chen said both of them should be suspended from their jobs pending further probes by the Control Yuan to determine how much they should be fined and whether they should be permanently fired.
Chen said the Central Personnel Administration will soon refer the conflicts of interest cases involving the two NCC commissioners to the Control Yuan for further investigations.

Meanwhile, Chen said, the Executive Yuan will serve a written admonition to both NCC Chairman Su Yeong-chin and Vice Chairman Liu Chung-teh as they had signed the official documents endorsing the two commissioners' illegal hiring of their relatives as chauffeurs.
Chen further said that if NCC commissioners are disgruntled with the Executive Yuan's sanctions, they can seek remedies in accordance with the law.

The report authored by a special panel headed by Minister-without- Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung also outlined several other major legal transgressions the NCC needs to deal with and some loose ends it needs to tie up.

First of all, the report slammed the NCC for its inaction toward the notorious "tarred duck" incident involving a controversial cable TV station, TVBS. The channel broadcast a story late last year claiming that some local poultry slaughterhouses had used asphalt to remove duck feathers. The report caused a widespread health concerns and caused severe slumps in duck sales and prices. However, the story later turned out to be a false alarm as laboratory tests showed no trace of the harmful substance. The NCC has so far not investigated the case nor handed out any punishment to the TV station.
Terming the NCC's inaction as dereliction of duty, the report demanded that the NCC immediately look into the case and mete out due penalties.

Moreover, the report said the NCC's recent punitive measures toward mishandling and broadcasting of a gangster's video by TVBS and its affiliated channel TVBS-N were not harsh enough to meet the public's expectations. It demanded that the NCC renew probes and hand out punishments accordingly if any new evidence surfaces about criminal activities behind this case.

The report also demanded that the NCC cease operations of its petition committee which the report termed as "overstepping the NCC's authority." Since the Executive Yuan has not yet laid out guidelines for the administrative appeal system involving independently run organs like the NCC, the report said, the NCC should not have set up a petition committee to handle appeals about its disciplinary sanctions. The report said the NCC petition committee should hand over all relevant files to the Executive Yuan's Petition Committee within one month.

The report also demanded that the NCC get back in two months two radio frequencies it previously gave to Broadcasting Corp. of China, which used to be owned by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and whose properties were partly snatched up by improper means during the period of KMT authoritarian rule. The retrieval is in compliance with the principle that radio frequencies are public assets, the report added.

Noting that supervision of Web site and Web domain name registration is the duty of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the report said the NCC is not eligible to formulate relevant rules and therefore should scrap its preparatory work in this regard.

As to moonlighting, the report said the NCC Organic Law has clear regulations which require NCC commissioners to strictly abide by the principles of avoiding conflicts of interest. Individual commissioners should quit their moonlighting jobs if they do not comply with relevant stipulations, it added.

While the NCC is screening various license applications or disciplinary sanctions, the report said, individual commissioners who have ties with those cases should refrain from joining discussions or votes in line with the conflict of interest avoidance principle. As some commissioners failed to follow this principle previously, the report reminded all members not to repeat their wrongdoings.
In support of the government's crime-fighting campaign, the report asked the NCC to establish a "telecommunications figurehead" data bank and pull out all the stops to prevent phone fraud.

The report also blamed the NCC for its recent letters to local elementary and junior high schools demanding them to allow for the establishment of mobile phone base stations on their campuses, which caused a panic among school authorities and parents. Although the issue has been clarified, the report said, the NCC should see to it that similar mistakes do happen again.

As the Council of Grand Justices has declared the NCC's partisan-based formation as unconstitutional and set Dec. 31, 2008 as its "sunset" or "closure" date, the report urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to pass amendments to the NCC Organic Law during its current session to pave the way for the birth of a new NCC that meets all legal and constitutional requirements.
The current NCC is made up of commissioners recommended by political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC MAY SEEK CONSTITUTIONALITY RULING ON SUSPENSION OF COMMISSIONERS

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) said Tuesday it may seek a ruling on the constitutionality of the Executive Yuan's demand that two of its commissioners be suspended from their jobs for violating a conflict of interest law.

The NCC made the remarks a day after the Executive Yuan announced that NCC commissioners Wu Chung-chi and Liu Kung-chung should be suspended for violating the spirit of the conflict of interest law by hiring close relatives to serve as their chauffeurs in government-provided cars.

Executive Yuan Deputy Secretary-General Chen Mei-ling said at a news conference Monday that the Central Personnel Administration will soon refer the cases to the Control Yuan to determine how much they should be fined and whether they should be fired.

The NCC will hold a meeting Tuesday to discuss response measures, including whether to ask the Council of Grand Justices to rule whether the Executive Yuan's demand to suspend its commissioners is constitutional, an NCC spokesman said.

In addition to informing the Executive Yuan of its conclusions, the spokesman said, the NCC will also furnish the Legislative Yuan with a copy of its letter to the executive branch since the appointment of NCC commissioners was approved by the legislature in the first place.

Stressing that the NCC is an independent body which is not under the jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan, the spokesman argued that the Executive Yuan doesn't have the power to suspend NCC commissioners.

After conducting a thorough probe into the NCC's operations, a special panel headed by Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung also came up with a report Monday that outlined several other major legal transgressions the NCC needs to deal with and some loose ends it needs to tie up, including probes into the notorious "tarred duck" false alarm, the gangster threat video incident, the phase-out of the NCC petition committee, and retrieval of two radio frequencies given to Taipei-based Broadcasting Corp. of China.
In xxxx, the Council of Grand Justices declared the NCC's partisan-based formation as unconstitutional and set Dec. 31, 2008 as its "sunset" or "closure" date.
The current NCC is made up of commissioners recommended by political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature.
NCC commissioners have decided to step down en masse Jan. 31, 2008 when the term of the current legislature expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRASS MOUNTAIN CHATEAU TO BE FULLY RESTORED WITHIN 2 YEARS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The late President Chiang Kai-shek's first official residence in Taiwan, which was badly damaged in a fire late Friday night, will be restored to its past glory within two years, Taipei City's culture chief said Tuesday.

Lee Yung-ping, director of the Department of Cultural Affairs of the Taipei City government, said an emergency response panel has been formed in line with the cultural properties protection law and other regulations to prepare for the restoration of the Grass Mountain Chateau on scenic Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei.
According to an initial estimate, Lee said, the restoration project will cost between NT$30 million (US$909,090) and NT$50 million.
She added that Lee Chung-yao, an authority in historical relics and heritage site restoration, has agreed to take charge of the Grass Mountain Chateau rehabilitation project.
The 83-year-old traditional architectural restoration master also played a leading role in the chateau's first large-scale face-lift a few years ago, Lee said.

The special panel is also composed of legal experts and specialists familiar with Japanese architectural styles and features, Lee said, adding that she is confident that the rehabilitation project will proceed smoothly and be successful in fully restoring the building's charm and glory.

The style of the 660-square-meter main building, on an estate covering about 1,815 square meters, is typical of Japanese architecture of the 1920s. The wall of the entrance to the main building is made of stone, with Japanese wooden structure inside.

The fire destroyed more than half of the main building, with the wooden interior being completely burnt. The stone wall remains intact. Total damage is estimated at roughly NT$36 million (US$1.09 million), Lee said.

The city government listed the building as a protected heritage site in 2002, and it has since served as a cultural activity center that encompasses an exhibition hall, a small-scale showroom, a multifunctional auditorium, a performance area, a semi-open air coffee shop, and a management center. The mid- night fire damaged the exhibition hall, known as Meilu Hall, and the coffee shop, known as Yingho Hall.
The city government commissioned the Buddhist Fo Kuang University to manage the chateau in 2002, and the cooperation contract is scheduled to expire at the end of June this year.

The chateau was built in 1920 by Taiwan Sugar Corp. in preparation for a visit by then-Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito. Historical records show that Hirohito stayed at the house for only one hour and 50 minutes. The chateau later served as a spa villa for social celebrities during the period of Japanese colonial rule.

In December 1949, the Republic of China government moved its seat to Taipei, and President Chiang Kai-shek chose to stay at the chateau, making it Taiwan's first presidential residence. The president and his wife lived at the house until May 1950 when a new house was built in Taipei's Shihlin district. The chateau later served as the first couple's summer villa.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY ATTRIBUTES CHOPPER CRASH TO HUMAN FACTORS

TEXT.P: The crash of an Army UH-1H helicopter in a remote mountain region in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan a week ago could primarily be attributed to human factors, a senior military officer said Tuesday.

Wang Kuo-chiang, commander of the Army's Airborne and Special Operations Command (ASPC), made the remarks at a news conference held at the Ministry of National Defense on the flight mishap in which the helicopter struck a radio tower and crashed in mid-air, resulting in the death of all eight officers aboard.

Quoting an investigation report by a special military team, Wang said the tragedy could be attributed to a combination of factors, including the pilot's failure to gauge the height of the tower, the crew's poor emergency response skills, and the pilot's failure to alter course or return to base when weather condition's suddenly turned for the worse.
All the debris of the crashed UH-1H chopper were sent back to the Kueijen Army Base in neighboring Tainan County for re-assembling to facilitate probes into the cause of the disaster.

The flight mishap claimed the lives of all the eight Army officers aboard. Five of the bodies were recovered at the crash site Tuesday, but rescuers didn't locate the remaining three until Wednesday noon when they were discovered lodged in the girders of the radio tower, which the helicopter had collided with in bad mountain weather.

The crashed helicopter was manufactured in 1974. Under a cooperation deal with U.S.-based Bell Helicopter, the military's Aero-Industry Development Center -- the forerunner of the present-day Aerospace Industry Development Corp. -- has built a total of 118 UH-1Hs since 1969.

First Gentleman Jose Miguel Arroyo underwent open heart surgery at the St. Lukes Medical Center (SLMC) in Quezon City last night where he was rushed from Baguio City after complaining of severe abdominal pains. He was admitted to the hospital at noon yesterday.

The Presidents husband, Jose Miguel Mike Arroyo, was going through a high-risk surgery Monday night at the St. Lukes Medical Center in Quezon City for aortic aneurism, ABS-CBN reported.

: The Straits Times: Ministers and civil servants get pay rise of up to 33%.

The annual salaries of the ministers and top civil servants will be increased by 25 percent equally, Singapore Government announced yesterday.
