DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN RETURNS FROM UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, who went to the United States shortly after his defeat in the Taipei mayoral election last December, returned to Taiwan Tuesday.

Upon his arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, he was greeted by Wu Poh-hsiung, who won the Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship by-election last Saturday, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih, Deputy Legislative Speaker Chung Jung-chi, PFP legislators as well as Soong's supporters.
Soong said that there are many issues that require cooperation and consultations between the KMT and the PFP and that the two parties will communicate with each other on these issues.

Soong gave a low-key response when asked about political issues, especially about questions concerning a possible presidential ticket of former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, or a Wang-Ma ticket.
PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun said that Soong talked with Wu for 20 minutes, touching on Taiwan's current situation and the future direction of cooperation between the two parties.

On whom Soong will support in the 2008 presidential election, Lee said Soong is friends with both Wang and Ma and that it is not appropriate to talk about the question now, adding that the only consensus is to win the election next year through cooperation between the two parties. Wu also refrained from talking about the matter.
Wang had wanted to come to greet Soong, but couldn't come because of his especially tight schedule Tuesday, Lee said.
More than 50 supporters quarreled with aviation police briefly after the latter tried to stop them from unfurling red banners to welcome Soong. Police later moved back to avoid a possible clash.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 8.17 points to close at 8,048.39.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,064.54 and closed at the day's low of 8,002.49. A total of 4.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$113.68 billion (US$3.44 billion).
Four of eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks, foodstuff issues and paper and pulp issues all moving up 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares increasing 0.1 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks, machinery and electronics shares and construction issues all moving down 0.3 percent, and banking and financial shares decreasing 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 676 to 466, with 178 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T HOPES NICARAGUAN FOREIGN MINISTER CAN VISIT SOON: MOFA

TEXT.P: The government hopes Nicaraguan Minister of Foreign Affairs Samuel Santos can visit Taiwan soon to discuss the feasibility of bilateral cooperative projects in various fields, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
Simon Ko, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs, made the remarks after Santos postponed his visit to Taiwan originally scheduled for late March.

At a regular press conference held at the MOFA's office, Ko attributed Santo's delaying his visit to his busy schedule, noting that he has to help the new Nicaraguan government plan for many policies.

Noting that Taiwan's government has not received any details of planned cooperative projects from the Nicaraguan government, Ko said concrete cooperation between the two countries will have to be discussed during Santo's Taiwan visit.

According to Ko, President Chen Shui-bian became aware of Nicaragua's urgent medical needs during his visit to the Central American country in January to attend Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega's inauguration and managed to send medical groups to Nicaragua and Saint Kitts and Nevis to offer voluntary medical care in late March through MOFA's International Cooperation and Development Fund.
The service provided by Taiwan's medical groups has received a warm response from the Nicaraguan government and people, Ko added.

During Chen's visit to Nicaragua in January, Santos and his Taiwanese counterpart, James Huang, signed a memorandum of understanding, with the two sides promising to maintain diplomatic ties. On that occasion, Santos was invited to visit Taiwan in March to materialize the cooperative projects between the two countries, an invitation that Santos accepted immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved down 19 points to close at 8,053, with 30,335 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May dropped 10 points to finish at 8,050, with 1,465 contracts traded, while June futures decreased 22 points to close at 8,033, with 70 contract transactions. September futures moved down 10 points to finish at 7,838, with 74 contracts traded, while December futures lost four points to close at 7,849, with six contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,072 for April, 8,060 for May, 8,055 for June, 7,848 for September and 7,853 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

April TE futures lost 1.2 points to close at 339.1 points, with 2,370 contracts traded, while May TE futures moved down 1.05 points to finish at 338, with 81 contract transactions. June TE futures decreased 0.65 points to close at 337.6, with one contract traded, while September TE futures dropped 3.1 points to finish at 329.8, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures moved down 7.6 points to close at 1005.8, with 1,964 contracts traded, while May TF futures dropped 8.2 points to finish at 1008.6, with 33 contract transactions. June TF futures decreased 6.4 points to close at 1006.6, with two contracts traded, while September TF futures lost 6.8 points to close at 998.2, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Killing of Adjmal shocks Italy.
The killing of Italian journalist Daniele Mastrogiacomo's Afghan interpreter Adjmal Nashkabandi by the Taliban shocked Italy. The opposition urged Premier Romano Prodi to explain his administration's efforts for rescuing Mastrogiacomo at the parliament. Adjmal was abducted by Taliban militants last month together with Mastrogiacomo, who was released alone 15 days after being held hostage in exchange of the release of five Taliban figures in Afghan jails and with a ransom of two million U.S. dollars, according to mediators.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THIRD LARGEST SOURCE OF IMPORTS INTO CHINA FOR JAN.-FEB. PERIOD

TEXT.P: Statistics compiled by China's customs show that Taiwan was the third largest source of imports into China, behind only Japan and South Korea, for the first two months of this year, a Ministry of Economic Affairs spokesman said Tuesday.

The statistics show that 10.36 percent of all imports into China for the period came from Taiwan, down 0.98 percentage points from the figure for the same period a year earlier, while 13.91 percent of imports into China came from Japan, and 11.59 percent came from South Korea.

China's exports grew 41.66 percent year-on-year for the period, while imports rose 20.43 percent, the spokesman said. Imports from Japan, South Korea and Taiwan grew 20.48 percent, 19.53 percent, and 10.05 percent, respectively, for the period, he added.

Taiwan, South Korea and Japan are in keen competition in the Chinese market, with two of the top three products exported to China from each of the three countries being integrated circuits and liquid crystal display devices.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTS DOWN 2.1 PERCENT YEAR-ON-YEAR IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Due to a decline in imports of mechanical and electrical products, imports of capital goods for the first quarter amounted to US$7.43 billion, down 2.1 percent year-on-year, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Finance.
Officials of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday that the tallies show a slowdown to some degree in Taiwan's economic expansion.

According to import and export tallies for March provided by customs authorities, Taiwan's foreign trade for the month amounted to US$37.31 billion, up 9.5 percent year-on-year. Exports amounted to US$19.76 billion for the month, up 10.4 percent, while imports totalled US$17.55 billion, up 8.5 percent, for a trade surplus of US$$2.22 billion.

According to the tallies, among the main export products for March, exports of steel and iron products increased 41.9 percent over the same month a year earlier, exports of chemical products rose 9.3 percent, and electrical appliance exports posted growth of 21.1 percent growth, while exports of information and telecommunications equipment and optical instruments declined 18.5 percent and 14.4 percent, respectively.
As for major import goods, imports of metal products and transportation equipment rose 63.9 percent and 57.5 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, moving up NT$0.016 to close at NT$33.088.
A total of US$811 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.07 and fluctuated between NT$33.015 and NT$33.098.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE BUDGETS NT$100 MILLION TO PROMOTE STUDENT READING HABITS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education has budgeted NT$100 million (US$3.02 million) to buy books and renovate reading facilities at elementary and junior high schools in remote places, education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said Tuesday.
Tu made the announcement at Taitung County's Wen Chuan Elementary School where the county's storytelling association and MOE held a ceremony to kick off the promotional project.
MOE's 2007 reading promotion budget will help 300 elementary schools and 219 junior high schools in remote places buy books and create better reading environments, Tu said.

By way of example, Tu explained to the school's students how materials expand and contract with temperature changes by telling the classical Arthurian legend story of "The Sword in the Stone, " and encouraged students to save time for learning from extracurricular readings.
During the ceremony, Tu gave two oars symbolizing navigation to representatives of the nation's 21 storytelling groups in acknowledgement of their leading roles in promoting positive reading habits.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER DENOUNCES CHINESE OFFICIALS' PRESENCE IN TAIWAN GROUP

TEXT.P: Legislator Huang Chao-hui of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the government and Taiwanese business leaders Tuesday "not to recognize, follow or participate in" a forming federaton of Taiwanese businessmen's associations in China, and to boycott the organization.

Huang made the call at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan while suggesting businessmen operating in China withdraw their investments back to Taiwan when Beijing shows reluctance to protect their rights and interests. He denounced China's attempt to ally with Taiwanese business people against Taiwan's government by posting ranking officials in the planned business group.

A formal ceremony marking the establishment of the controversial federation is scheduled to be held April 15 in Beijing, with Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office of State Council, to serve as honorary chairman of the new organization.

He Shizhong, director of the Chinese office's Economic Bureau, will be the group's vice chairman and secretary-general, Huang said, questioning the purpose of the two Chinese officials' presence in an organization being formed to defend and safeguard the right and interests of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China.

Huang argued that while Taiwanese businessmen's associations around China have been sparing no efforts to protect Taiwanese interests on the mainland, the forming business federation is "trapped by Beijing's 'one China' scheme disguised in the federation's organic constitution' which stipulates the leadership of the federation has to respect the "one China" principle and advocate China's idea of unification.

Huang questioned how an organization founded for the purpose of "national unification" will work to fight for Taiwanese business people's rights and interests as China has never stopped trying to annex Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTRIES BEING ACCEPTED FOR KINMEN'S LIAOLO BAY SWIM RACE

TEXT.P: Organizers of the 2007 Liaolo Bay Swim Race said Tuesday that those who wish to join the contest have until June 30 to submit their entries along with necessary fees.
The 3,000-meter swim -- an annual event now in its fifth year -- will take place July 29 in Liaolo Bay on the south side of outlying Kinmen island.
The event is being jointly held by the Kinmen County government, the Kinmen County Sports Association and Kinmen County Stadium.
Information about the swim race can be obtained by calling Kinmen County Stadium at (08)231-1229.
Contestants must be in good health and at least 10 years old to qualify for the race. A maximum 500 swimmers will be divided into different age groups for the long-distance swim.
An additional leisure group of no more than 1,500 swimmers will be allowed to take part in the event to challenge themselves.

According to the organizers, all participants in the race will receive souvenirs, including a swim cap for each swimmer, a bottle of kaoliang -- a fiery liquor distilled from sorghum -- for each member of a team with 25 swimmers or more, and additional prizes for the six largest teams having at least 25 swimmers each.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAPACITY TO DEAL WITH EMERGENCY STRENGTHENED AFTER DRILL: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the government's capacity to deal with an emergency has been upgraded through a simulated drill.

The president made the remarks after completion of the first-stage of the drill sponsored by the National Security Council (NSC) at a command center in Taipei. Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang and related government officials also participated in the drill on short notice.
"Only through careful planning in peacetime can we prepare ourselves well for war," the president said.
He added that repeated drills also help to discover problems and find ways to solve them, thus avoiding unnecessary losses in times of war.
Meanwhile, the NSC denied reports that the drill has anything to do with political situation or the 2008 presidential election.

The NSC was responding to reports by the China Times, a local newspaper, that said the drill was designed with nearly 200 scenarios against a domestic background in which Ma Ying-jeou, former chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), loses the 2008 presidential election and his supporters, refusing to concede defeat, stage a massive protest. As a result Taiwan is thrown into chaos.
The NSC said that such reports are groundless and pure fabrication.

The NSC explained that the drill envisioned a scenario in which major political and economic changes take place in China and international clashes erupt due to competition for valuable sources in the Asia and Pacific waters, leading in turn to a bold move by China to launch a lightning attack on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAYOR INDICTED FOR STEERING PROFITS TO CONTRACTOR

TEXT.P: Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair was indicted Tuesday for awarding undue profits to a construction company, with prosecutors asking that he be given a 12-year prison term, according to the Tainan Prosecutors Office.

The Tainan Prosecutors Office brought the indictment against Hsu after wrapping up its lengthy probe into the case, initiated by tip offs from the municipal public work affairs bureau and a letter signed by over 10 city councilors accusing Hsu of unlawfully favoring the construction company which won a contract to build the city's underground malls.

Although three Tainan mayors had involved in the underground mall project, Hsu is the only one indicted in the case for allegedly using his position to profit NT$200 million for the company since the construction project kicked off more than a decade ago during the tenure of former Mayor Shih Chih-ming.

Nine other suspects, including three officials and ex-officials of the Tainan city government, and six employees from the construction company were also indicted on charges ranging from corruption and illicit profiteering to document forgery, prosecutors said.

According to prosecutors, the investigation showed that Hsu, who took over the mayoral post in Dec. 2001, allegedly instructed municipal officials in charge of the construction project to conspire with the company's manager, surnamed Kuo, to chalk up illegal profits, although the municipal public work affairs bureau and supervisory agents of the construction plan had discovered the plot and tried to stop them.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post: U.S. Troops Weary of Militia in Sadr City; Learning to Live With the Mahdi Army. Training Police in Sadr City. BAGHDAD -- No, there have been no problems, the police commander was telling the armor-laden American soldiers squeezed into his office in the vast Shiite enclave of Sadr City. Except, he said, for the text-messaged death threats he often received from militia members.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE SPORTS OFFICIAL VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Hu Jiayan, a deputy director of China's State Sports General Administration (SSGA), arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for an eight-day visit.

Hu, heading a 10-member delegation comprised of several other SSGA officials, Chinese Olympic Committee executives, and other sports officials from the Shandong and Hubei provinces, made the trip to attend a meeting with the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee to exchange views on sporting interactions between Taiwan and China.

Upon their arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Hu and other members of the delegation all declined to comment on the widely-discussed issue of whether or not the torch of the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing will also travel through Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRASS MOUNTAIN CHATEAU VERY LIKELY TARGET OF ARSON ATTACK

TEXT.P: It is "very likely" that the historic Grass Mountain Chateau on scenic Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei was destroyed by an arson attack, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday, adding that a police task force will be formed to look into it.

Hau made the announcement after the City Fire Department came out with a preliminary conclusion from its investigation into the Friday night fire that gutted much of the 660-square-meter main building of the chateau -- the first official residence of the late Chiang Kai-shek in Taiwan.

Hau indicated that investigators found a kind of accelerant at the fire site and oil-stained residue outside the building. From that evidence, experts concluded that fire was set to the house from the outdoor dining area.
Fire Department officials said it is not usual to see a fire that breaks out so quickly and violently damage more than half of the structure, leaving the wooden interior completely consumed.

Hau would not offer any conjecture over the reasons why people acted to damage the protected heritage site before police find one. He stressed the chateau is not only a historic building, but also a priceless cultural and tourist attraction.

A cultural spot is "innocent" in disputes over an historical figure's conduct, the mayor said, noting the case has been listed as a major criminal offense, and that those involved may face punishment by imprisonment of 3 to 10 years.

The chateau was built in 1920 by Taiwan Sugar Corp. in preparation for a visit by then-Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito. Historical records show that the prince stayed at the house for only one hour and 50 minutes. Latter, the chateau was turned into a spa villa for social celebrities during the period of Japanese colonial rule.

In December 1949, the Republic of China seat of government moved to Taipei and President Chiang chose to stay at the house until May 1950 when a new residence was built in Taipei's Shihlin district. The chateau later served as a summer villa for Chiang and his wife.
The city government listed the house as a protected heritage site in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR VOWS TO EMBRACE CENTRAL GOV'T UNIT RELOCATIONS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu pledged Tuesday that the southern Taiwan city will embrace central government agencies relocated to Kaohsiung, stressing that municipal authorities will do their utmost to find suitable spaces for them.
Chen made the pledge following a municipal meeting and expressed her appreciation for the Kaohsiung city council's decision a day earlier to create a task force to promote relocation.

Apart from the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and the Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture (COA) , the Kaohsiung city council also added the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports to its list of agencies that might be relocated on the grounds that the city is to host an international sports event in 2009, she noted.
In addition, she said, the Kaohsiung city government is setting its sights on relocating the Examination Yuan and the Control Yuan, Chinese Petroleum Corp. and Taiwan Power Company to Kaohsiung.

Relaying the Executive Yuan's firm stance on achieving a "regional balance" and of developing "twin nuclei" in northern and southern Taiwan, Chen said that the CLA's proposed relocation to Kaohsiung is of great significance to the city's 600,000 workers as it should then be able to better address local laborers' needs and enhance their interests and rights.

Pointing out that the Kaohsiung municipal authorities have identified a good location for the CLA to construct an office building, Chen said that the CLA's relocation is just a matter of time, adding that a local fishermen's training center in Chienchen district has been designated to house the COA's Fisheries Agency.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and President Chen Shui-bian rekindled the central government agency relocation plan along with a name rectification drive for state-run companies and public establishments earlier this year.
Opposition parties have criticized the ruling DPP for rehashing what they described as ideological issues meant only to solicit voter support as the legislative and presidential elections approach.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY OFFICIALS PUNISHED FOR HELICOPTER CRASH

TEXT.P: The Army Commanding General Chao Shih-chang and the commander of the Army's Airborne and Special Operations Command Wang Kuo-chiang were assigned demerits over the recent crash of an Army helicopter in southern Taiwan which resulted in the loss of eight elite officers.

Hsu Tai-sheng, director of the Joint Operation Training and Doctrine Office under the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , made the announcement Tuesday after the Army released its report regarding the causes of the crash of the Army UH-1H helicopter, which hit a transmission tower in the remote mountain region in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan last week.
The Minister of National Defense Lee Jye has since demanded that all aircraft of the same type be grounded for further security checks.
An Army official said the Army will also require in the future that both chiefs and deputy chiefs of a same unit not board the same aircraft.
The MND report attributed the plane's crash to a sudden change of the weather in the region that day and an inability on the part of the pilot and crew members to respond to the emergency.
Meanwhile, Army officials added that they will resume as soon as possible the operations of other UH-1H helicopters, but did not elaborate on when that might be.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 500 PAIRS OF FAKE NAME BRAND SHOES IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Police in central Taiwan have impounded 500 pairs of name brand shoes after searching a home in the Hsitun District of Taichung city, a spokesman for the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Tuesday.

The spokesman said that the CIB's crime prevention center in central Taiwan had received a tip in early April that students hired by a counterfeit ring had been seen peddling fake Nike and Adidas sports shoes in the night market outside Fengchia University.

He said a student peddler would let would-be buyers go through a catalogue of fake name brand shoes, and that once the customers decided on the shoes they wanted, a runner would rush to a distribution center by motorcycle to get the goods.

According to the spokesman, agents with the CIB's anti-crime center in central Taiwan obtained a search warrant and raided a distribution center quartered in a home Monday. They seized 500 pairs of fake shoes under six name brands: Nike, Adidas, Puma, Gucci, Royal and New Balance.
The police have detained a student peddler, surnamed Lo, for questioning and are trying to locate the leader of the counterfeit ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ACTIVATES MECHANISM TO ENSURE STABLE SUPPLY OF GRAVEL

TEXT.P: The government has activated a mechanism to ensure a steady supply of sand and gravel on the market, the Public Construction Commission of the Executive Yuan said Tuesday.
Commission officials said the Ministry of Justice has closely monitored price fluctuations of gravel in the construction market and acted severely in cases of hoarding.

The government also encourages imports from the Philippines to help relieve the shortage of gravel resulting from China's export ban of its sand and gravel, which came into effect March 1, commission officials said.

Officials noted that the government knew last December that China would soon ban its gravel exports. The Mainland Affairs Council, the nation's top China policy charter, has commissioned the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council to discuss the matter with China.

As construction companies complained that they could only manage until the end of this month at most, and that "one fourth of planned housing complexes cannot begin construction because of the shortage of the main building material, " the government has taken several measures to ensure a steady supply on a long-term basis.

Those measures include assistance to construction companies to import 3 million cubic meters of gravel from the Philippines and coordinating with water resource officials to urgently increase river dredging to supply an additional 4.5 million cubic meters of gravel.
Taiwan began to import sand and gravel from China six years ago, and until recently nearly one-third of its market needs were filled by imports from China.

China's Ministry of Commerce and General Administration of Customs announced in April 2006 that it would ban the export of natural sand starting May 1, 2006, but postponed the date to March 1 this year after Chinese suppliers asked for more time to cushion the impact on their businesses.
The supply shortage has caused the prices of sand and gravel in Taiwan to rise steadily in recent months, according to market analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER FAVORS OPENING SPORTS RACING

TEXT.P: The government supports promoting sports racing activities, such as car racing and yachting, in Taiwan, but the proposal has yet to be fully assessed, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday.

Su made the remarks during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan while fielding questions from main Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Liao Wan-ju, after a government planned opening of car racing and horse racing in central or southern Taiwan, unveiled last weekend, stirred up heated debate.

According to Su, the government backs a well-planned opening of car racing or yachting with an aim of bolstering tourism-related businesses, while the horse- racing proposal is out of the question due to animal protection concerns.
"For the time being, the entire project is still on the drawing board," he made clear.

Chang Ching-sen, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, shed light last Friday on a government plan to open car racing and horse racing in central or southern regions, beginning in June, in an effort to revive local economies and strike a balance in regional development.

But the idea drew flak from KMT lawmakers, who criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party administration for rash policy-making and called it a tactic to win voter support in the run up to the legislative and presidential elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES SHOULD PASS ENGLISH TEST: BLUE-CAMP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang said Tuesday that he will propose a revision to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law, requiring that future presidential candidates pass the general English proficiency test at the intermediate level.
Hsieh stressed that since the president has to represent the country's interests at many international occasions, a certain level of English speaking capability is a must.

Hsieh said the country's general English proficiency test (GEPT) has been divided into five categories: elementary, intermediate, high-intermediate, advanced and superior, and he will propose that future presidential candidates only pass the intermediate level of English proficiency, which is roughly equivalent to the English ability of a junior high school graduate.

Noting that currently Taiwan's public servants have to pass the GEPT test when seeking a promotion, and even taxi drivers are strengthening their English proficiency, Hsieh said requiring presidential candidates to understand and be able to participating in simple English conversations with foreigners at international events is quite reasonable.

Hsieh said he will also conduct public hearings to seek the opinions of the experts and the general public in this regard and will ask for the Grand Justice's explanation on whether the proposal would violate the Constitution.

Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Hsiao Bi- kim blasted Hsieh's proposal, describing it as an international joke, which she said does not conform to international practice and would violate the Constitution.
Hsiao noted that voters will have their own way to gauge a presidential candidate's global vision, and it should not be proven by tests.
In addition, she added, one's global vision is not well reflected in language ability.
Hsiao went on that she has never heard of another country requiring their presidential candidates to have certain degree of proficiency in a foreign language.

Even if some foreign leaders are proficient in English, they will certainly speak in their own languages at such occasions to underscore their own country's national identity, Hsiao said, adding that Hsieh's proposal both violates the Constitution and constitutes a discrimination against the country's national language.

DOC.HEADLINE: CERTIFIED TEACHERS ONLY HALF HIRED AS REGULAR FACULTY MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Only 54 percent of more than 125,000 certified teachers currently work a regular faculty members in public schools of all kinds, excluding colleges and universities, around Taiwan in 2007, according to a report released Tuesday by the Ministry of Education.
The annual report on teacher cultivation indicated that 46,154 of the persons holding official teaching certificates, or 36 percent, were not serve at any schools last year.

Professor Kuo Lung-hsin of National Taiwan Normal University, who is one of the authors of the report, opined that adeclining birth has resulted in a decreasing demand for teachers in elementary schools in the past years, and that the situation is likely to worsen with the number of enrollees in elementary schools around the country expected to drop to 190,000 in the 2012 academic year, down from 290,000 in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 HAN KUANG DRILL TARGETS 2012 MILITARY SCENARIOS

TEXT.P: The 23rd Han Kuang military exercise will be based on a simulation focusing on a 2012 cross-Taiwan Strait military situation, an officer of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday.

The MND's Deputy Chief of the General Staff for the Operations and Planning, Chiu Kuo-cheng, said at a news conference held by MND to explain issues related to the 23rd Han Kaung drill slated for April and May this year.

The scenario assumes that Taiwan will have to defend itself from a Chinese invasion launched in 2012 due to Taiwan's refusal to participate in unification talks, and that there will have been no progress in arm procurements by that time, Chiu said, adding that this year's Han Kuang drill has two phases: full- scale maneuvers and computer war game simulations.

According to Chiu, the full-scale maneuvers will be carried out in Penghu, Hualien, Yilan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Changhua and Pingtung areas as scheduled by MND, some of which will be open at certain times to the public. The computer war game simulations will proceed for five consecutive days at all command centers, Chiu added.
Chiu said this year's Han Kaung drill requires the participation of all national defense forces in order to test their combat readiness to face future joint warfare operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE IN TAINAN BUST ILLEGAL ARSENAL, ARREST SIX MEN

TEXT.P: Police in Tainan city uncovered an illegal arsenal Tuesday and arrested six men belonging to a ring involved in the production of illegal firearms and ammunition.

A spokesman for the Tainan police station said that agents with the criminal investigation division raided two locations in Tainan city and Tainan County, arresting ring leader Yeh Ho-chiang and five accomplices: Chiu Yu-chiang, Su Jen-po, Su Hsiu-min, Huang Chao-chun and Tseng Feng-jung.
According to the spokesman, the ring leader is a repeat offender who had been twice arrested for violations of the Statute Regulating Firearms, Ammunition, Knives and Other Deadly Weapons.
The agents also seized five firearms, some 100 rounds of ammunition and more than 1,000 half-finished cartridges.

Under the Statute Regulating Firearms, Ammunition, Knives and Other Deadly Weapons, amended in January 2005, those who produce firearms or explosives without permission from government authorities can be subjected to at least seven years in prison plus a fine of NT$30 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION TO APPEAL AGAINST DECISION TO SACK MEMBERS

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) will appeal against the Executive Yuan's decision to sack two of its members, NCC Vice Chairman Liu Tsung-teh said Tuesday.

Liu said the order issued by the Executive Yuan the previous day has not yet been delivered to the NCC, however, the NCC believes that the Executive Yuan has exceeded its power to order the sack of two NCC members and thereby will not take the decision lying down.
The two NCC members were sacked for using their relatives as chauffeurs of their cars at the expense of the NCC.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT STRATEGIST PREDICTS UNEASY YEAR AHEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan faces an uneasy year ahead in its relations with Washington and Beijing, Chang Rung-kung, a Kuomintang strategist warned Tuesday.

By naming former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu as Taipei's representative to the United States and nominatiing Chen Min-tung to fill the vacancy left by Wu at MAC, Chang who serves as the deputy director of KMT Policy Coordination Committee said President Chen is determined to push for Taiwan's "de jure independence" and make it a center issue in the 2008 presidential elections.

Noting that Joseph Wu is a supporter of Taiwan independence, Chang said his appointment is a deviation from the country's long-lasting tradition of having someone loyal to the Republic of China to defend Taiwan's interest in Washington, and is sure to aggravate Washington's concerns that Taiwan's movement toward independence will strain ties with China.
Those concerns will inevitably undermine Taiwan's ties with the United States, Chang warned.

By nominating Chen Min-tung, author of the so-called second republic constitution for Taiwan, to be the MAC chief, Chang said the president betrayed his intention to make constitution rewriting an issue in his last year of office.

These appointments as well as the president's declaration March 4 that Taiwan wants independence and a new constitution, which Chang claimed is the closest the president has ever gone to formally declaring Taiwan's independence since taking office seven years ago, highlight the president's campaign to push for Taiwan's de jure independence and bode ill for the country's future in the year ahead, Chang said.

New York Times: Huge Protest in Iraq Demands U.S. Withdraw
Tens of thousands of protesters loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, the Shiite cleric, took to the streets of the holy city of Najaf on Monday in an extraordinarily disciplined rally to demand an end to the American military presence in Iraq, burning American flags and chanting Death to America!
Residents said that the angry, boisterous demonstration was the largest in Najaf, the heart of Shiite religious power, since the American-led invasion in 2003. It took place on the fourth anniversary of the fall of Baghdad, and it was an obvious effort by Mr. Sadr to show the extent of his influence here in Iraq, even though he did not appear at the rally. Mr. Sadr went underground after the American military began a new security push in Baghdad on Feb. 14, and his whereabouts are unknown.
Wall Street Journal:Bring Stag Revelry To Eastern Europe
When they joined the European Union in 2004, countries such as Estonia, Slovakia and Lithuania dreamed of an influx of wealthy Western tourists eager to explore their historic cities. What they got were gangs of British cutting loose with soon- to-be bridegrooms and brides.
Adam Burrows and 21 of his friends traveled to this former Soviet republic on the Baltic Sea two weekends ago to celebrate his coming wedding.
British bachelor and bachelorette parties are moving farther afield. With low- cost airlines offering cheap fares to Eastern Europe, some of the EU's newest members are discovering the drunken underbelly of British tourism. enditem

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 11, or the 24th day of the February of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the U.S. politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers control of the Philippines to the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: U.S. forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the U.N. Charter.
1951: U.S. President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his command, including that of U.N. forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops captures the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of Communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
1997: Turin Cathedral is engulfed by flames, but firefighters manage to save the famous Turin Shroud.
2000: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement endorse the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.
2001: The Executive Yuan signs an agreement with the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei to enact regulations to prevent double taxation on Dutch people working in Taiwan as well as those from Taiwan in the Netherlands.
2002: The European Parliament passes a pro-Taiwan resolution urging mainland China to dismantle missile deployment against Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 ELECTIONS WON'T CHANGE UNITED STATES' 'ONE CHINA' POLICY: RICE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 10 (CNA) 04/11/07 13:12:29 (By Lee Chia-fei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The outcomes of the U.S. and Taiwan presidential elections in 2008 will not change the United States' longstanding "one China" policy, U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Tuesday

Responding to reporters' questions at the State Department, Rice said the United States expects that neither China nor Taiwan will take any steps to unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
The news conference was held for journalists from around the world taking part in the Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists sponsored by the International Visitor Leadership Program.

Asked if the U.S. policy of providing Taiwan with weapons for its self-defense needs would change if cross-strait tensions were triggered by moves by Taiwan toward de jure independence, Rice said that Washington expects both sides of the Taiwan Strait to respect the "one China" policy, adding that "we have obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act to help Taiwan defend itself, and we will carry out those obligations through the military cooperation that we have with Taiwan."

Rice said she does not believe that anyone would benefit from the outbreak of conflict in the Taiwan Strait, adding that Washington has repeatedly stated its polices regarding the Taiwan Strait and has made clear that it supports cross- strait dialogue and cross-strait interactions.
"There actually is a lot of trade and economic development across the straits, and I think that is also a buffer against conflict," she continued.
"It's my very strong view that this should not and will not change as a result of '08 because it's been a standing policy of the United States for many, many years," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM WORKERS' UNION MEMBERS PROTEST LAYOFF MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: Several executive members of the state-run Chunghwa Telecom Co. Workers' Union petitioned Wednesday against the management's ongoing "inhumane" movement to lay off workers in a drive to streamline the company.

In front of the Legislative Yuan, the protesters chanted slogans, such as "foreign investors profiteering, workers wailing, " while calling for the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), which holds a 36-percent stake in the company, to replace its designated chairman, Ho Chen-tan, who they claimed has been using "inhumane" means of all kinds since 2006 to lay off workers in order to "please" foreign investors.
In the streamlining movement, Ho ordered that 1,600 workers be laid off in a two-week period at the start of this month, Chunghwa Telecom Workers' Union Secretary-General Chuang Ping-tang said.

Under the directive, Chuang noted, executives of various Chunghwa Telecom units were assigned "a layoff quota" which forced them to press "targeted" workers to leave by all possible means, including changing workers' positions at will and forcing public service personnel into marketing the company's products.

Chuang said a 48-year-old technician at Chunghwa Telecom's generator room in Fengshan, Kaohsiung County committed suicide by hanging last September because of the workplace pressures. Tan left behind a wife, young daughters and elderly parents.

Legislator Lai Shin-yuan of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union received the petition on behalf of her party and criticized the company which generates annual profits of around NT$40 billion (US$1.2 billion) for its violation of an agreement that it signed with the workers' union in 2005 when it began the process of privatization. The agreement stipulates that no workers are to be laid off within five years of its signing.
The Chunghwa Telecom Workers' Union demanded that the MOTC replace Ho at once, otherwise it will mobilize 5,000 members to stage a protest at the ministry headquarters May 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN ATHLETE LAUNCHES NEW 'WALK TO STAY HEALTHY' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Veteran Taiwan female athlete Chi Cheng launched a new "walk to stay healthy" campaign Wednesday, calling for all residents in Taiwan to walk 10,000 steps each day to stay fit and healthy.

Chi, who earned the nickname "the flying antelope" for breaking records at world track and field events several decades ago, said at a news conference that she now walks to stay fit and that rapid walking even helped cure her urinary tract infection.
Chi broke the 100-meter and 200-meter sprint world records in the 1970s.

In her first "walk to live longer" campaign launched five years ago, Chi urged people to walk 5,000 steps a day to stay fit and healthy. Chi also suggested that interested people buy pedometers to keep track of the number of steps they take each day.

According to Lien Chin-chien, executive director of the Hope Foundation established by Chi five years ago, more than 20,000 pedometers were sold around Taiwan last year, indicating that an increasing number of people have grown fond of walking and keeping track of how many steps they take.
Lien quoted a Hope Foundation member who is a medical professional as saying that walking 10,000 steps a day can surely help prevent many chronic diseases.
Chi, who launched the Taiwan Walk Day on Nov. 11, 2006, said she will again lead people from 25 cities and counties around the country to "walk to stay healthy" on Nov. 11 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 42 points to close at 8,095, with 32,416 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May gained 37 points to finish at 8,087, with 1,330 contracts traded, while June futures increased 52 points to close at 8,085, with 54 contract transactions. Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
