DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION AND RULING PARTIES REACH CONSENSUS ON 'CHIP PASSPORT'

TEXT.P: Legislators of the ruling and opposition parties reached a consensus Wednesday regarding the upgrading of the Republic of China passport to a "chip passport" in the near future.
The legislators reached the consensus while screening the clauses of proposed revisions to the passport statute at the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , who is also chairman of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Compatriot Affairs Committee, noted that the "chip passport" will not contain the fingerprint and iris pattern information of the passport holders as "biometric passports" do, adding that there is no need for the public to worry about leakage of their biometric information.

Hsu further said that the information included in the "chip passports" will be the same as that already included in current passports and that the new passports will better protect the holders' personal information.
Hsu said that more than 30 countries have issued "chip passports" and that if Taiwan nationals have such passports, it will facilitate their entry into these countries.

As to whether the "chip passports" will be more expensive than the ones currently issued, Hsu said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has allocated funds to cover the increased cost of producing the "chip passports" and that there will not be a price hike in applying for the new passports.
According to Hsu, the MOFA has earmarked NT$146 million (US$4.42 million) for producing chip passports and another NT$52 million for apparatus to read such passports.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CONFIDENT ABOUT IMPLEMENTATION OF 'GOOD HOUSEKEEPING PROJECT'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that she delivers on her promises with action and that she is certain that some 100,000 "good housekeepers" will be produced before the end of her term to help boost the women's labor force participation rate and to help share household chores as well.

Lu said that so far, some 70,000 housekeepers -- including workers specializing in senior care and care for the physically or mentally challenged, child care workers, and workers specializing in home management -- have been trained under a three-pronged project that she has seen to be carried out since April 2006.
She said she is confident that the goal of having 100,000 "good housekeepers" trained will be achieved before her term expires in May 2008.
Lu made the remarks while addressing a ceremony marking the commencement of a home manager training workshop in a junior high school in Taipei County.
She said that of Taiwan's female population of 11.28 million, about 4.3 million are working women. Of the 4.3 million working women, some 70 percent have been working in the service sector.
There are about 400,000 double-income households islandwide, which will need the help of housekeepers, she added.

Meanwhile, she said, there are some 400,000 women who no longer work because they got married or had children, and there are some 560,000 single-parent families, most of which consist of a mother and child.
Members of these groups may need to seek employment as housekeepers, she speculated.

The "Good Housekeeping Project" -- put forward by Lu in 2005 and introduced by the Council for Economic Planning and Developent in April 2006 -- is aimed at providing women with training in senior care, child care and home management to enhance their employment opportunities, with the goal of training 100,000 professional housekeepers over a two-year period.

So far, under the "Good Housekeeping Project, " more than 18,000 people have completed training as care givers for seniors or physically or mentally- challenged people, while some 42,000 child care workers and 8,000 workers specializing in home management have completed training, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 36.06 points to close at 8,084.45.

The bourse opened at 8,048.34 and fluctuated between 8,105.82 and 8,055.67 during the day's trading. A total of 4.29 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$114.01 billion (US$3.45 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.4 percent, construction issues at 0.5 percent, and textile stocks at 0.3 percent.

Three of the other major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.8 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 575 to 569, with 178 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN AIRLINES TO END FLIGHT SERVICES ON TAIPEI-TAICHUNG ROUTE

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) agreed Wednesday to Mandarin Airlines' request to end its flight services on the Taipei-Taichung route from May 1 and said that those who have already booked flights on the route can have their money refunded in full.

CAA officials said the decision was made after the administration came to the conclusion that offering flight services on the route was no longer profitable given the alternative transportation choices available.

Mandarin Airlines is currently the only air carrier operating flight services on the Taipei-Taichung route. UNI Airways Corp. ended its flight services on the route in July 2004 due to decreasing passenger numbers.

According to CAA statistics, Mandarin Airlines suffered losses amounting to NT$45 million (US$1.36 million) in 2006 on the Taipei-Taichung route. The airline said that after high-speed rail transportation services began Jan. 5, the passenger occupancy percentage of each flight on the route dropped to 16 percent between January and March and slid to 4.3 percent in April.

It costs NT$700 for a single high-speed rail trip between Taipei and Taichung, which takes around one hour. In comparison, a one-way air ticket on the route costs NT$1,342, with passengers spending about 50 minutes on the plane.
Mandarin Airlines officials said that the company has decided to focus more on boosting its international flight services based at the Taichung Airport after quitting the Taipei-Taichung route.
At present, the airline operates regular passenger flight services between the central Taiwan city and Hong Kong, as well as to Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SECURITY ROBOT 'SEQ-1' DEVELOPED BY ITRI AND SHIN KONG SECURITY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has developed a new security robot, called "SeQ-1," in collaboration with the Shin Kong Security Co., an ITRI spokesman said Wednesday.
The SeQ-1 robot will soon join the national security system, the spokesman said, adding that the name "SeQ-1" refers to the robot's "security" role as well as its "Q&A" function and cute appearance.
According to the spokesman, the SeQ-1 robot has a futuristic external form, an agile head which can turn easily, and large LED eyes that turn on automatically in the dark.

ITRI integrated an "environment security system" into SeQ-1's robot platform system which enables the robot to have immediate interaction with security monitoring systems and marks a big difference between the SeQ-1 and foreign security robots, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Diabetics cured by stem-cell treatment Diabetics using stem-cell therapy have been able to stop taking insulin injections for the first time, after their bodies started to produce the hormone naturally again.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, moving up NT$0.007 to close at NT$33.095.
A total of US$1.004 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.09 and fluctuated between NT$33.067 and NT$33.105.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS HAVE MIXED OPINIONS ON CHINESE YUAN CONVERSION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Legislators from across the political spectrum had mixed opinions Wednesday about whether the government should open Chinese yuan exchange services on Taiwan proper.

In light of the fact that Taiwan may soon fully open its doors to Chinese tourists, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) proposed that before a cross-strait cash settlement agreement is signed, certain selected Taiwan banking institutions be authorized by the Taipei-based Central Bank of China and the Financial Supervisory Commission to offer Chinese yuan exchange services on a trial basis.

Disagreeing with the proposal, opposition People First Party Legislator Liu Yi- ju said it would be prohibitively inconvenient for Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan to exchange Chinese currency at "selected" banks in appointed places, adding that the restrictive measure would only contribute to increasing the amount of counterfeit Chinese currency in circulation in Taiwan, which would in turn jeopardize Taiwan's financial order.

Liu suggested that Taiwan seek to build a cross-strait cash settlement mechanism by cooperating with the Bank of China (Hong Kong) Co., which was authorized by Beijing three-and-a-half years ago to conduct free conversions between the Chinese yuan and foreign currencies.

After the ruling and opposition lawmakers failed to reach any consensus on the issue, DPP Legislator Chang Ching-hui, who presided over Wednesday's session, ruled that the issue should be debated again after negotiations between the ruling and opposition camps are completed.
Unconfirmed reports have said that Taiwan residents may have amassed a total of more than 100 billion Chinese yuan (US$3.03 billion) over the past several years.

The accumulation of Chinese currency in Taiwan can be attributed to a combination of factors, including China's chronic trade deficit with Taiwan and the inclination of Taiwan businesspeople operating in China to bring home Chinese yuan, the sources said.

In March 2004, the central bank began to allow each local citizen to bring in up to 6,000 yuan per homecoming visit, and the amount was raised to 20,000 yuan in October 2005. According to an estimate by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, local people have made a total of more than 12 million visits to China over the past three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRUKU TRIBE LAUNCHES TRIBAL LANGUAGE DICTIONARY

TEXT.P: Hualien County's Hsioulin Township Office held a book launch for an abridged dictionary and textbooks of Truku tribal language at the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) in Taipei City early Wednesday.
CIP Deputy Chairman Icyang Parod attended the book launch to congratulate the Turuku tribe on its success in converting its verbal language into written text.

Parod said that after Truku was officially recognized as a Taiwanese aboriginal tribe in January 2004, Hsioulin Township office invited tribal scholars and respected elders to edit this dictionary. The completion of the dictionary is a monument to the tribe, Parod added.

Hsioulin Township head Hsu Shu-yin said at the book launch that the tribe took the initiative in editing its own dictionary and textbooks. In addition to the book launch, Hsu said the township will hold family tour activities on weekends from April 14-June 17 to promote tribal culture and industry.

Activities including an ecology tour, tribal music appreciation, hunting, bamboo shoot picking, and a tribal antique exhibition, will be held at the county's Pratan Tourist Center, Mukumugi Visitor Center, and cultural parks, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMENDMENT TO MENTAL HEALTH LAW PASSES COMMITTEE SCREENING

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Sanitation, Environment and Social Welfare Committee passed Wednesday an amendment to the Mental Health Law of 1990, seeking to provide better protection of the rights of mental patients.

The amendment would add new clauses to penalize those who abandon family members with mental illnesses, mistreat them physically or spiritually, keep them in an environment where they could easily be harmed, or force them to marry.

Violators of the proposed new clauses would be subject to a fine of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000. In addition, authorities may publicize the names of the offenders and require that they receive eight to 50 hours of counseling on family education at a fee.
The amendment would also abolish a provision in Clause 30 that allows teaching hospitals to perform chemical castrations on mental patients through a long- acting implant of hormonal drugs.
The proposed change is based on arguments that forced chemical castration violates the rights of mental patients, and new drugs are available to provide more effective treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAVYWEIGHTS CALL FOR UNITY

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan called Wednesday for "unity and cooperation" among party members to embrace victory in future elections.

Lien issued the call during a ceremony at the KMT headquarters in which Wu Poh- hsiung took over the helm of the party after winning a landslide in a chairmanship by-election last week. Former Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and KMT- affiliated Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng were also present.
Commenting on the 2008 presidential election, Lien stressed the need for unity if the KMT hopes to take back power. Taiwan has markedly moved backwards over the past seven years, he said.

"As long as every party member is able to speak out frankly and sincerely for the sake of Taiwan's interests, democracy and future, there is nothing which cannot be achieved, " Lien said, expressing his hope that all party members will fully support the yet to be formed KMT presidential ticket.
Lien hailed Wu as a "wise, broad-minded, courageous and enthusiastic" man capable of leading the KMT forward.
Ma praised the recent KMT chairman by-election as a "gentleman's race," and called Wu's election a deep reflection of the party's wide ethnic diversity. Wu is a Hakka Taiwanese.

Ma, who enjoys widespread public support and is the most likely KMT candidate to run in the next presidential contest, reiterated that he will invite Wang to serve as his running mate -- in keeping with an agreement forged between Ma and Wang in prior negotiations mediated by Lien and Wu -- if he wins the party's nomination.
"The KMT cannot afford another split in the 2008 presidential election," Ma insisted.
For his part, Wu promised to make an all-out effort to serve the KMT and the country and called for all comrades' backing and cooperation as fierce challenges are ahead of the party.

"The KMT should apologize to the Taiwan people who have suffered setbacks in many fields due to its defeat to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the 2000 presidential election due to a split, " Wu said, adding that he is prepared "to help pair up a most qualified KMT ticket in the coming presidential race."
"Both Ma and Wang are fair-minded and the KMT's great assets," Wu said.
"From now on, let's forget all the unpleasant in the past and embark on a new beginning," he added.

Wang, who said a day earlier that he would issue a statement clamoring for continuous and visionary KMT reform Wednesday at Wu's inauguration ceremony, fell short of doing so, and only congratulated Wu on his election and voiced hope that the KMT could secure a victory in December's legislative election and the 2008 presidential election.

The legislative speaker said Tuesday that he would spell out to the KMT, for its own good, something from the depths of his heart because the party cannot apply one set of rules to others but a different set for itself.

Ma and Wang were strong opponents vying for the KMT's presidential nomination, but Wang failed to pick up a registration form to take part in the party's presidential primary while Ma did -- a development which means that Wang is out of the primary. But it remains unclear whether Wang would form with Ma a KMT presidential ticket.
Speculation has arisen that Wang might choose to run as an independent in the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIQUE INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY BECOMES TTV'S BIGGEST SHAREHOLDER

TEXT.P: Unique International Technology Inc. became the largest shareholder of the Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd. (TTV), one of the four terrestrial networks on the island, after it bought 25.77 percent of the government's stakes in the TTV in an open bidding Wednesday.

Unique International Technology offered NT$1.74 billion (US$53.73 million), or NT$24.1 per share, beating three possible rivals in bidding held at the headquarters of the Taiwan Cooperative Bank. The three other aspirants were ERA Communications, Hungpan Construction and snack giant Want Want, which offered NT$23.02, NT$22.68 and NT$22.31 per share respectively.

Another potential buyer, Dafeng TV Ltd., withdrew from the bidding at the last minute Tuesday because it is partially owned by foreigners who are not allowed to operate a terrestrial television station like TTV.

During a report to a government qualification screening panel recently, Unique said that it already possesses 14.4 percent of the TTV shares. In addition, it shares the same ideals as Lai Kuo-chou, former TTV chairman and son-in-law of former President Lee Teng-hui, who has obtained 4.84 percent of TTV shares from TTV's former Japanese shareholder.

At the time, Unique officials said that if it wins the open bidding, it would become TTV's dominating shareholder, avoiding a possible ownership battle that would risk undermining the company's competitive edge.
Teng Mei-hua, vice president of Unique International Technology, said Wednesday that the company will make the best of TTV's brand name and resources.

She noted that Unique TV started with capitalization of only NT$300,000, but the company made it big by targeting specific viewing groups, and that it will continue applying this approach after it becomes the biggest shareholder in the 45-year old terrestrial network.

Meanwhile, Cabinet spokeswoman Chen Mei-lin said that the bidding was held in a "transparent and smooth" manner. The media kept abreast of the bidding process through a video hookup to the conference room where the bidding took place.
On whether the Executive Yuan was satisfied with the Unique's offer, Chen said that it is not appropriate for her to comment on whether the offer is up to market value.

Chen noted that it will take about one month for the Unique International Technology to obtain the shares, saying that it will sign an agreement with Taiwan Cooperative Bank Friday and post a deposit of NT$70 million to demonstrate that it will not renege on the deal after winning the bid. The company will then have to file a request with the National Communications Commission before it can obtain the TTV shares.
Chen said that the second-stage share release of TTV targeting the public and staff of TTV is expected to be completed this November.
A number of state-controlled banks own around 47 percent of the TTV shares. They have recently begun selling the shares under a government privatization plan.

The government's plan to sell off the TTV shares drew public attention after the Ministry of Finance, which manages the government's stocks in the company, decided on March 21 to replace Lai Kuo-chou, who was appointed by the ministry to act as the government's representative at the TTV, on the grounds that he was purchasing TTV stocks from several private investors in an attempt to take over the company.

However, Lai accused the Executive Yuan of pulling strings in an attempt to help the private Liberty Times group win control of the TTV because of the close association between Liberty Times' founder and Democratic Progressive Party government leaders.

His accusation was backed up by TTV's former Japanese stock investor Fuji Television Network, whose representative in Taiwan claimed at a March 25 news conference that Cheng Wen-tsang, then-minister of the Government Information Office, tried to persuade him to sell Fuji's stocks to Liberty Times at a dinner party in January when a new policy forbidding foreign ownership in terrestrial television entered into force.

Cheng, who was also a member of the government panel in charge of examining the potential bidders' qualifications, denied the accusation but nonetheless withdrew from the panel and resigned from his GIO post on April 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCH INSTITUTES COOPERATE IN BID FOR MEDICAL RESOURCES BALANCE

TEXT.P: The National Health Research Institute (NHRI) forged cooperative ties with Tainan City-based National Cheng Kung University Hospital (NCKUH) Wednesday in a drive to seek a better balance in medical resources distribution across the northern and southern parts of Taiwan.

NHRI President Kenneth K. Wu and National Cheng Kung University President Lai Ming-chao signed the cooperation agreement in a ceremony also attended by Legislator Lai Ching-teh, who has spared no efforts promoting draft legislation for the cancer prevention and control act and establishment of a cancer research institute in southern Taiwan.

Cooperation between the institutions will focus on clinical cancer research and the southern Taiwan research facility's formation, which it is believed will help enhance cancer prevention and control efforts.

NCKUH President Chen Chih-hung indicated that cancer has been the leading cause of death in Taiwan. Moreover, the researchers have found that people in different regions on island are affected with different kinds of cancer.

For example, he said people living in the southern area are prone to cancer affecting liver, lung, skin and bladder, and cancer patients in the south are likely to be affected by the disease in different ways from those in the north.

NCKUH Cancer Center Director Chou Chen-yang explained that in the north, the hepatitis B virus is often found to be the culprit in causing liver cancer, while liver cancer patients in the south were mostly found to affected by the disease because of hepatitis C virus infection.
Chou further said the number of oral cancer patients in southern Taiwan is much larger than that in the north.

Under the cooperation agreement, the NHRI will open a clinical research cooperative ward at NCKUH in the second half of this year and dispatch eight of its cancer experts to the hospital for cancer research programs, according to the institute which has already similar research-oriented wards at three major hospitals in Taipei -- Taipei Veterans General Hospital, Tri-Service General Hospital, and National Taiwan University Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIQUE MAY COOPERATE WITH OTHER MEDIA NETWORKS IN RUNNING TTV

TEXT.P: Unique International Technology Inc. said Wednesday that it is not ruling out the possibility of cooperating with other media networks after becoming the biggest shareholder of the Taiwan Television Enterprises Ltd. (TTV).

Unique made the remarks in a written statement after it won 25.77 percent of the government's stakes in the 45-year-old television company, one of the four terrestrial networks in Taiwan, in open bidding earlier in the day by offering NT$1.74 billion (US$53.73 million), or NT$24.1 per share, beating three rivals.

Unique, which started with a small TV channel dedicated to financial and economic news, said that it has long-term contacts with a former Japanese partner in the TTV, and that the Japanese shareholder has sold its 14.4 percent of its shares to the Unique.
With the new addition, Unique will possess 40.17 percent of the shares, the company said in the statement.

The company said that it will run the TTV with professionalism based on its specialty in financial and economic areas. It will also protect the rights of TTV staff based on respect of the labor-management relations.

Asked whether Unique will form an alliance with other media networks, the company said that it will not rule out the possibility of cooperating with them, saying that it has things to learn from them.

Wednesday's offering was the first-stage release of the government's stakes in the TTV. The government will begin to promote a second-stage stock release next month, offering around 19 percent of its stakes to the public as well as TTV staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP SUES CITY GOV'T OVER OLD TREES FELLING

TEXT.P: An alliance of civic groups in Taipei dedicated to the protection of forests said Wednesday that it is suing officials of the Taipei City Government for not protecting decades-old trees at the Songshan Tobacco Factory, where the city government will build a large sports stadium.

Members of the Taipei Tobacco Factory Public Park Promotion Alliance staged a skit in front of the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office, hinting that Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin is planting young trees with left hand while cutting older trees with his right.

Pan Han-shen, secretary-general of the Green Party Taiwan, which joined with other like-minded groups to form the alliance, noted that the Taipei City Government failed to protect the 353 trees around the factory, which were planted during the period of Japanese colonial rule in Taiwan and are supposed to be protected by the government.

With the city government failing to list the 353 trees as protected, and instead listing only 136, Pan said the alliance had grounds to sue officials for forgery and dereliction of duty, and asked that all of the transplanting task be stopped.

As the site for the "big Dome" sports stadium is one of the few forested areas left in Taipei and has long been considered the "lungs of the city, " the alliance has staged many protests against the city government in order to protect the few oasis in this metropolitan city.

Pan said they are not opposed to a sports stadium, however, a survey conducted by the city government in 2002 did not mention that the development project would include department stores, shopping malls, office buildings and several five-star hotels outside the stadium.

Noting that this project is now far from public expectations of a sports stadium, Pan said the alliance has won the endorsement of many villagers near the Sungshan Tobacco Factory for their campaign dubbed: "We want forests, and not commercial complexes, " and the campaign is still underway.

DOC.HEADLINE: USING RESTYLANE SUB Q FOR BREAST ENLARGEMENT IS AGAINST LAW: DOH

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) warned Wednesday it is illegal for plastic surgeons in Taiwan to use Restylane Sub Q -- a non-animal hyaluronic acid gel -- for breast enlargement operations.

Liao Chi-jou Liao, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, said that doctors who perform such non-surgical treatment will be referred to the Committee for Disciplinary Sanctions of Physicians in accordance with Article 25 of the Physicians Law.
Liao explained that the DOH has only allowed plastic surgery clinics to inject small amounts of Restylane Sub Q to remove wrinkles or enhance facial contours.

The health official stressed that the DOH has not given doctors permission to inject Sub Q gel into the breast tissue because a breast enlargement operation usually requires more than 100 cc of the gel, which may not always stay where it should.

"Unless a doctor who has performed such an operation can present convincing documents to prove that Sub Q gel is harmless when used for breast enlargement, he or she will face disciplinary measures according to law," Liao said.
He urged women contemplating breast augmentation to consider carefully the risk of Sub Q injection.

Liao gave the warning after a plastic surgery clinic touted the advantage of Sub Q for breast enlargement by asking a porno movie actress who underwent such an operation to present herself as an example.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY-DESIGNATE URGED TO CONVEY TAIWAN PEOPLE'S VOICE TO THE WORLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, said Wednesday that President Chen Shui-bian has expressed hope that after he assumes his post later this month, he would truly convey to the world the unfair treatment under which Taiwan's people are suffering.
Wu, who is now chairman of Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks after attending a farewell party thrown by the MAC for him.

According to Wu, President Chen received him Tuesday and instructed him to strengthen communications with administrative and legislative branches of U.S. government in diverse aspects, including Taiwan's need of defense assistance from the United States.

Concerning the president's recent "four wants" declaration for the country -- seeking independence, changing the country's official designation, formulating a new constitution and strengthening the development -- which has caused great concern within the U.S. government, Wu said he will accurately convey the president's real thoughts in this regard if given the opportunity.

As for some Taiwanese expatriates in the U.S. who have expressed worry about his close ties with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Wu stressed that he is the Republic of China government's representative in U.S. and he is glad to extend help to any ROC national living in the United States.
Wu went on that he will be responsible for explaining clearly the various policies of ROC government to Taiwanese communities in America in order to clarify their misunderstandings of the government.
In addition to Taiwanese communities in U.S., Wu said he will also strengthen communications with various think tanks based in U.S. to accurately transmit the voice of Taiwan's people to the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: 3 Generals Spurn the Position of War 'Czar'. Bush Seeks Overseer For Iraq, Afghanistan.
The White House wants to appoint a high-powered czar to oversee the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan with authority to issue directions to the Pentagon, the State Department and other agencies, but it has had trouble finding anyone able and willing to take the job, according to people close to the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Panel Said to Alter Finding on Voter Fraud
A federal panel responsible for conducting election research played down the findings of experts who concluded last year that there was little voter fraud around the nation, according to a review of the original report obtained by The New York Times.
Instead, the panel, the Election Assistance Commission, issued a report that said the pervasiveness of fraud was open to debate.
Wall Street Journal:David Hasselhoff May Have Driven This Fine Vehicle!
Rob Dyrdek, a 32-year-old professional skateboarder and MTV reality-show star, got a recent reminder of how low he is on the celebrity totem pole.
Last month Mr. Dyrdek, who stars in the show "Rob and Big," gave a friend permission to use his name to peddle Mr. Dyrdek's old car, a 2000 Mercedes-Benz CL500, on eBay. The highest bid: $29,600, nearly $9,000 below the Kelley Blue Book value. "I ain't Brad Pitt, and this ain't Donald Trump's CL," Mr. Dyrdek concedes. His friend, who now owns the car, plans to relist it in the next few weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASTRONOMERS OBSERVE STAR FORMATION TRIGGERED BY MASSIVE STARS

TEXT.P: Two local astronomers have observed and proved for the first time that existing massive stars can trigger the formation of a series of new stars, verifying a longstanding hypothesis of such a possibility, sources at National Central University (NCU) said Wednesday.
The findings have been published by the U.S.-based monthly "The Astrophysical Journal" in its March issue.

Lee Hsu-tai and Chen Wen-ping, both from NCU's Institute of Astronomy, had searched the skies for evidence supporting the hypothesis for several years before discovering in early 2006 that two separate stars, in the constellations Orion and Lacerta, had "helped" the formation of young stars within a radius of several hundred light-years.

During an interview with members of the local press earlier this week, Lee explained that the astronomers have long proposed the possibility that the radiation emitted by a massive star -- which by definition means one with a mass of at least ten times that of the sun -- could compress the molecular clouds around it and prompt the formation of low- and intermediate-mass stars inside the condensed clouds.

In independent observations of the two massive stars, the astronomers found that the massive stars had each "pushed" back a vast patch of cloud -- leaving traces of either bright-rimmed clouds or comet-shaped ones, and that some stars already existed in between the massive stars and the vast clouds, with other stars forming inside the bright-rimmed and comet-shaped clouds.
Lee noted that the age of the new stars are in inverse proportion to their distance from the massive star, which means those nearer to the massive star have existed for a longer period of time.
"Such a distribution of age-distance demonstrates that these smaller stars are gradually brought into existence by the massive one, " Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DISSATISFIED WITH PERFORMANCE OF STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: Lawmakers called for the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to step up monitoring of several state-owned enterprises to improve their lackluster performance.
The legislators made the appeal at a legislative committee while listening to the MOEA and its affiliated agencies report on the execution of its budgets in 2006 and the first three months in 2007.

The legislators were concerned that six state-owned enterprises under the MOEA -- CPC Corp., Taiwan, Taiwan Power Co., Taiwan Sugar Co., Taiwan Water Corp., CSBC, Taiwan, and Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) -- reported revenues of NT$1.29 trillion and expenditures of NT$1.3 trillion with pre-tax losses of NT$12.55 billion, which was a far cry from its original estimate of NT$8 billion surplus, mainly because of the surging cost of purchasing crude oil by the CPC.

The six state-owned enterprises recorded revenues of NT$291.04 billion and expenditures of NT$289.13 billion with a pre-tax surplus of NT$1.91 billion in the first three months this year, mainly because of the implementation of a floating oil price mechanism which was put into practice early this year.

Legislator Lin Cheng-feng of the opposition Kuomintang said that although Taisugar, the largest land owner in Taiwan, showed a surplus, it was due mainly to land sales as its businesses have continued to lose money.
Since the sugar industry is no longer a government monopoly enterprise, he suggested that it close doors and turn over its land to the National Property Administration under the Ministry of Finance.
Taisugar President Lin Chung-hung said that the company has been losing money because its operations are constrained by government policy, although it has done a good job in land management.
Legislator Chang Hwa-kuan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that the AIDC has lost NT$5.2 billion, or more than half of its capitalization, since 1995.

Except for products sold to the Ministry of National Defense, Chang said, the AIDC has lost money on all other product lines, and therefore the MOEA should replace the company's chairman Feng Shih-kuan, or she will push to have the AIDC's budget cut.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY 5 NAMED BICYCLE DAY WITH EVENTS GOING ON IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) has dubbed May 5 "Bicycle Day", it announced Wednesday.
Mass cycling events will be held in both Taipei City and County on that day and everybody is welcome, said NCPFS Chairman Yang Jongher.
"Cycling is a sport that can help one achieve maximum health with minimum cost," Yang said.

Cycling Life-Style Foundation Chairman King Liu said the number of cyclists in Taiwan has been increasing in recent years and many local authorities are enthusiastic about building bicycle paths, which "are good for the promotion of the sport", he said.

Liu, who is also the chairman of the Giant Bicycles, said it took several years of promotion efforts to bring Taiwan in line with countries such as the United States, the Netherlands, Spain, Belgium, Italy and France and recognize a bicycle day.

The Bicycle Day cycling event in Taipei County will take place at 8:30 in the morning outside of the Shihsanhang Museum of Archaeology, while that of Taipei City will set out at 9: 00 on Renai Road between the city government building and Jingfu Gate, Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CONFIRMS COA UNIT RELOCATION TO KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang confirmed Wednesday that the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will soon be relocated to Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan.
Su confirmed the move during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan, which was also attended by COA officials.
According to COA Deputy Minister Lee Jen-chyuan, personnel at the COA's Fisheries Administration will begin relocating to Kaohsiung in October this year at the earliest.
In the near future, the COA will have different units scattered across Taiwan in line with the Executive Yuan's efforts to strike a balance in development in northern, central and southern regions.

A group of about 60 administration officials will be the first to move to Kaohsiung, with the rest of the staff following in several phases, said Fisheries Administration Deputy Director-General Sha Chih-i.
According to Sha, the administration presently has more than 200 officials stationed in northern Taiwan, with 99 percent of them residing in Taipei.

The administration will eventually station some 70 workers in Taipei for regular service, he said, adding that job vacancies that arise due to the departure of Taipei-based will not be immediately filled, but instead the positions will be held open and filled by workers in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER PROPOSES TOUR PACKAGE FEATURING CHIANG

TEXT.P: Despite an ongoing controversy surrounding the late President Chiang Kai-shek, a ruling party lawmaker Wednesday asked government authorities to draw up tour packages featuring Chiang in an effort to lure more tourists from home and abroad.

Yeh Yi-jin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the proposal during a question-and-answer session of the Legislative Yuan, with Janice Seh- jen Lai, director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, promising to come up with a package within a week.
Yeh suggested the Tourism Bureau work on such a package in response to an anticipated opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, as everything related to Chiang is of great interest to them.

Although Chiang's first official residence Grass Mountain Chateau -- later transformed into a public leisure space with a restaurant and an exhibition room displaying favorite dishes and items of the Chiang family -- was badly damaged in a suspicious fire late last Friday, Yeh said that many resort villas of Chiang still can be found scattered in the rest of Taiwan.
"The Tourism Bureau should focus its efforts on developing packages featuring Chiang to better attract Chinese tourists in anticipation of that opening," Yeh said.
Echoing Yeh's idea, main opposition Kuomintang lawmaker Wang Yu-ting expressed her support for the proposal.

Wang also criticized tourism authorities for lacking a vision to explore Taiwan's resources and potential in this field. There are 13 national scenic areas across the country, but they need to be better programmed and promoted to court more tourists, she pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZOO VET HAS FOREARM BITTEN OFF BY CROCODILE

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung municipal zoo veterinarian had his left forearm bitten off by a crocodile Wednesday, but surgeons are operating to reattach the limb, retrieved after a policeman shot dead the crocodile, according to various sources.
A Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital surgeon said the medical team is optimistic about the operation to reattach the limb.

He said that while thegolden timefor such surgeries falls within six hours of injury, the operation on Chang began slightly more than an hour after the incident. However, he said, the extent to which the reattached arm will be functional is uncertain.
The attack occurred in the afternoon at Shou Shan Zoo when senior official and veterinarian Chang Po-yu was treating a sick crocodile and removing an anesthetic needle, zoo nurse Huang Shu-chen said.
The surgeon said that the 38-year-old Chang was conscious and that the arm was severed about 5 cm below the elbow.

Emergency Service officers said a police officer had to shoot dead the crocodile using a pistol from several meters away in order to retrieve Chang's severed forearm, which was still held in its mouth, so that the forearm could be put on ice and rushed to the hospital.
Zoo officials said that Chang is an experienced and caring vet who had previously risked his life entering the cages of lions and tigers in order to save them from a flood.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN EVALUATES HIS OWN ADMINISTRATIVE TERM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that for more than 2,600 days, he has daily urged himself to set the national administration in motion, and that he was satisfied with certain accomplishments made during his term.

In answer to questions concerning his own assessment posed by more and more guests, Chen spoke of his impressions of his term while receiving executives of the Taiwan chapter of the Lions Club International at the Presidential Office.

Chen said that he and his team have achieved many of their goals thanks to public support. There surely are a number of things in need of improvement and reflection, but he is more than satisfied with three important accomplishments realized during his term.

The first, Chen said, is the peaceful transfer of power, making Taiwan a genuinely democratic country; the second is the nationalization of armed forces to prevent national defense from being used by a certain political party or individual, and thereby securing Taiwan from the threat of a military coup; and third, holding a successful referendum to deepen Taiwan's democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK EXCHANGE CHAIRMAN SIGNS MOU WITH INDIAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) Chairman Gordon S. Chen has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on bilateral cooperation with his counterpart of the Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai, India, a TSE spokesman said Wednesday.

According to the spokesman, Chen signed the MOU Wednesday on the sideline of the 32nd Annual Conference of International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) being held in Mumbai which will run until April 12.

Chen also met with Vijit Supinit, chairman of the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET), earlier this week on the sideline of the IOSCO conference to reach a consensus on future substantive cooperation, including futures trade cooperation and exchanges of information.
During their talks, Supinit said that Thailand's securities and futures markets are structured like those of Germany, Italy and Spain ro ensure a high degree of operational efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG RESIDENTS URGED TO JOIN APRIL 15 HIKE

TEXT.P: Organizers of the 2007 spring hike in Taichung urged the city's residents Wednesday to join the annual event, scheduled for mid-April, to visit Mother Nature and enjoy various outdoor activities.

Executives of the Vitalon Group, a beverage enterprise, said they hope some 10,000 people will join the hike, which will set off at 7:15 a.m. April 15 from the Central Taiwan University of Science and Technology.
Hikers will walk along an eight-kilometer route in the Dakeng scenic area, according to the organizers.
The various outdoor activities will include performances by renowned singers, charity sales, riddling, body painting and free health check-ups.
Vitalon will provide free beverages plus a hat and other souvenirs for each participant.

The organizers also said that they will give away laptops, digital cameras, electronic translation dictionaries and bicycles near the end of the hike. The winners will be determined through the drawing of lots.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM DENIES LAYOFF ACCUSATION

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom Co. strongly denied an accusation that management has been "inhumanely" laying off its workers to downsize the company, according to a statement issued by the company Wednesday.
The statement came after the company's labor union staged a demonstration against the layoffs earlier that day in front of the Legislative Yuan.
The workers also called for the replacement of the chairman, Ho Chen-tan, who was designated by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

Chunghwa Telecom stated that it did not refuse to negotiate with the union as accused. In fact, the two sides reached a consensus on employee performance measurements in two meetings convened Dec. 8 and Dec. 12 last year, the statement noted.
The actions the company has taken to adjust its organizational structure are aimed at improving service quality, the statement said, adding that they have not violated any laws.

Following privatization the company needs to streamline its operations to enhance competitiveness, the statement said. The company has adopted a preferential layoff policy that the statement claims meets the expectations of its employees.
The statement also complained that some union members have frequently tried to interfere in the company's operations in the lead up to national elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRUKU TRIBE LAUNCHES TRIBAL LANGUAGE DICTIONARY

TEXT.P: Hualien County's Hsioulin Township Office held a book launch for an abridged dictionary and textbooks of Truku tribal language at the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) in Taipei City early Wednesday.
CIP Deputy Chairman Icyang Parod attended the book launch to congratulate the Turuku tribe on its success in converting its verbal language into written text.

Parod said that after Truku was officially recognized as a Taiwanese aboriginal tribe in January 2004, Hsioulin Township office invited tribal scholars and respected elders to edit this dictionary. The completion of the dictionary is a monument to the tribe, Parod added.

Hsioulin Township head Hsu Shu-yin said at the book launch that the tribe took the initiative in editing its own dictionary and textbooks. In addition to the book launch, Hsu said the township will hold family tour activities on weekends from April 14-June 17 to promote tribal culture and industry.

Activities including an ecology tour, tribal music appreciation, hunting, bamboo shoot picking, and a tribal antique exhibition, will be held at the county's Pratan Tourist Center, Mukumugi Visitor Center, and cultural parks, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SANATORIUM WILL SURVIVE, FOR AT LEAST A WHILE

TEXT.P: The Losheng Sanatorium will not be immediately demolished after the previously set April 16 deadline, Taipei County Magistrate Chou His-wei said Wednesday after Premier Su Tseng-chang promised in a meeting with patients and preservationists to find solutions.
However, Chou claimed that the Executive Yuan should take full responsibility for any delay in the opening of Hsinchuang Line of the Taipei metro system caused by its policy change.
The Hsinchuang leprosarium, which still houses several dozen patients, was completed in 1930 by Japanese colonizers; it is now in the way of a Taipei metro depot construction project.

The campaign to preserve the leprosarium for the sake of the patients' human rights and its own historical and cultural value has increasingly gathered momentum over the past few weeks, as April 16 was set as the date after which the Taipei County Government could, at any time, conduct a forceful demolition of most of the buildings and relocate those patients who refuse to move.
Patients and preservationist were able Wednesday to speak face to face with Su after holding three protests outside of the premier's residence since early March.

During the meeting Su promised that the government would do its utmost to promote the adoption of a project option that would retain 90 percent of the existing compound while still avoiding a delay to the opening of the metro line, Cabinet spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling said.

Chen said it will take one or two months for the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission to communicate with Taipei County Government and Taipei City's Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DORST) to work out a solution acceptable to all parties concerned.
The current plan would retain 41.6 percent of the existing 4-hectare compound, but preservationists argued that it would destroy the oldest and most valuable parts of the sanatorium.

Preservationists welcomed Su's response, but said the plan to hold a parade this coming Sunday afternoon, starting at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, to voice support for the preservation of Losheng will not be changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ENVOY TO U.S. SET TO ARRIVE IN D.C. APRIL 15

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to the United States Joseph Wu said Wednesday he is scheduled to arrive in Washington, D.C. April 15 to assume office.

Wu made the remarks while attending a farewell party given by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) in his honor. For the past three-plus years, Wu has headed the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward China.

After taking up his new post, Wu said he will cash in on his experience as Taiwan's top China policy planner to help U.S. authorities better understand Taiwan's stance on relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Event: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) news briefing Date and Time: 10:30 a.m., Thursday, April 12, 2007 Place: MOFA Press center, 1st Floor, No.2, Ketagalan Blvd., Taipei City Host and/or main speakers: MOFA spokesman Wang Chien-yeh and Lee Chuan-tung, director of MOFA's Asia Pacific Affairs Department Organizers: MOFA Press contact: (02)2348-2703 Disclaimer:

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET STICKS TO ITS GUNS REGARDING NCC MEMBERS SUSPENSIONS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan reaffirmed its decision Wednesday to suspend two commissioners of the National Communications Commission (NCC) for violating conflict of interest laws.

Executive Yuan spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling said NCC commissioners Wu Chung-chi and Liu Kung-chung have been suspended from their jobs pending a Control Yuan review after which they could be fined and sacked.

Against this backdrop, Chen said the two are no longer NCC commissioners and can receive neither salaries nor perks from the NCC. Any decision or action either takes concerning NCC affairs is invalid, Chen said, adding that if either takes part in an NCC meeting, any decisions reached may be invalidated.

"Wu and Liu, of course, are free to seek remedies by appealing their cases in accordance with existing laws. But until relevant courts rule on their appeals, the Executive Yuan's punitive measures regarding their legal transgressions remain in force. They should not continue acting as NCC members; to do so would affect NCC operations," Chen explained.

As Liu hired an in-law and Wu hired his son to serve as chauffeurs of government-provided cars at the NCC expense, Chen said that both violated laws demanding that officials avoid conflicts of interest, and the Civil Service Law, which requires ethical integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURGERY ON CROCODILE-BITTEN VET SUCCESSFUL: HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: A zoo veterinarian whose left forearm was bitten off by a crocodile Wednesday has undergone a successful limb reattachment operation, Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital said Thursday.

Meanwhile, officials of the Kaohsiung municipal Shou Shan Zoo said the male Nile crocodile, which had to be shot twice with a police officer's pistol before it would let go of the severed arm, appeared to be intact thanks to its thick armor, though a more thorough check will need to be conducted later. It was previously assumed to have been shot dead.

The incident took place Wednesday afternoon when senior veterinarian Chang Po-yu was trying to remove anesthetic needles from the crocodile, which seemed inactive and anorectic for about a week, prompting Chang to check its health, according to zoo officials.

While Chang was rushed to the hospital, a police officer was called to shoot the crocodile in order to retrieve the severed arm still held in its mouth. Upon being shot the second time, the crocodile violently swung its head and flung the limb over the railing and out of the compound.
The medical team said it was fortunate that the forearm was retrieved quickly enough to attempt a reattachment operation.

An overnight operation successfully reconnected most of the blood vessels, nerves and muscles, a hospital spokesman said, adding that infection is the primary risk facing the patient, who will remain in the Intensive Care Unit for at least the next week or two.
The spokesman also said that it would take several years of rehabilitation to bring the injured arm back to even 80 percent of functionality, which is the best that can hoped for.
Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu Thursday morning visited Chang, who was able to wave with his healthy right hand to cameras from his sickbed after the operation.
The city's Labor Standards Inspection Office has ordered the zoo not to allow its staff to enter the crocodile compound before it produces a report on improving its working practices.
The incident made the crocodile a popular attraction, drawing more-then-usual visitors to the scene, many of whom crossed the security cordon around the compound to get a better view.

In related events, several newspapers published graphic images featuring the crocodile holding a severed arm in its mouth, sparking outcry by lawmakers, scholars and the Government Information Office (GIO).

Wang Hsing-nan, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislature whip, said the press has shown no self-constraint at all and the DPP caucus will not rule out drafting a new law to regulate the print press.
An act governing publishing, seen as a relic of the authoritarian era, was abolished in 1999.

Kuomintang lawmaker Hsu Shao-ping said three out of the four national major daily newspapers, the China Times, the United Daily News and the Apple Daily, should apologize to the public for running the bloody pictures. Only the Liberty Times blurred the broken arm in its publication.
Kuan Chung-hsiang, a communications scholar and Chairman of the Media Watch Foundation, said such a "disgusting" lack of discretion will only cause public resentment of the newspapers.
Lo Shih-hung, associate professor at the Graduate Institute of Telecommunications of the National Chung Cheng University, encouraged readers to call newspapers to voice protest.
The GIO, in a news release, called on the media to exercise self-restraint, and for civil society groups to help monitor media practices.

The release said the GIO had previously suggested that the Ministry of the Interior draft an amendment to the Child and Juvenile Welfare Law to ban media practices of this sort, which may harm the nation's youth.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TESTS HYDROGEN-POWERED MINI-TRAIN

TEXT.P: The National Science and Technology Museum in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan has successfully tested a mini-train using power generated by a hydrogen fuel-cell, according to a Radio Taiwan International report released Thursday.
The train, the first of its kind in the world, is part of the museum's efforts to promote environmental protection.
The mini-train is not only environmentally friendly, it is also safe, makes little noise, and need not be re-charged often.

Lee Yuan-tze, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry who retired from the presidency of Academia Sinica, took a test ride on Wednesday. He said that with a decrease in available energy resources, it is important for scientists to develop renewable energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELIEVED AS JAPAN UPHOLDS STANCE

TEXT.P: The government is glad to see Japan stick to its guns while engaging with China on issues concerning Taiwan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chien- yeh said Thursday.

Wang was referring to a Tokyo-Beijing joint communique issued after a high-level meeting between Japanese Prime Minister Shintaro Abe and his Chinese counterpart Wen Jiabao in Tokyo the day before, in which Japan reaffirmed its commitment to the two countries' 1972 joint communique in dealing with relations with Taiwan.
Wang said the government is relieved that Japan has neither retreated from its original stance nor made any fundamental changes in its policy regarding Taiwan.

In the 1972 Sino-Japanese joint communique, Japan said it will abide by the "One China" policy in dealing with Taiwan. Before Wen headed for Japan Wednesday on a three-day visit to help thaw relations as the two countries work to reverse a deterioration in ties caused in part by disagreements over history, speculation had it that China might force Japan to make a new commitment, limiting its substantive ties with Taiwan.

Noting that Taiwan has advocated parallel development of Taipei-Tokyo and Tokyo-Beijing relations, Wang said Japan should never seek to further ties with Beijing at the expense of engagement with Taiwan, a long-time trading partner of Japan.

Pointing out that a cordial Taiwan-Japanese relationship holds the key to Asia- Pacific stability and prosperity, Wang said he is convinced that substantive relations between the two countries will continue to progress in the future.

In a speech delivered at the Japanese Diet Thursday, the Chinese premier urged Japan's parliament not to forget Tokyo's wartime aggression even as the two Asian powers mend their strained ties and bolster thriving business relations. Wen also warned the Japanese not to meddle in Beijing's relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 13, or the 26th day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1732: Frederick North, the English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803 and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochin China to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of China's Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1906: Samuel Beckett, Irish dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1969, is born.
1919: British troops under the command of Brig. Gen. Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of an atomic reactor at Taiwan's National Tsinghwa University in Hsinchu, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," becoming the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1980: Twenty-three-year-old Spanish golfer Severiano Ballesteros becomes the first European and also the youngest person ever to win the U.S. Masters in Augusta, Georgia.
1982: U.S. Secretary of State Alexander Haig returns to Washington following failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1995: The Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
1999: Willi Stoph, chairman of the Council of Ministers of the former German Democratic Republic, dies at the age of 84.
2000: The World Trade Organization ranks Taiwan as the world's 14th-largest exporting country and the 15th largest importing country in terms of merchandise in 1999.
2000: The International Monetary Fund ranks the people of Taiwan as the 18th richest people in the world, with the nation's annual per capita income based on purchasing power parity expected to reach US$16,854 in 2000.
2001: U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) arrives in the Republic of China at the head of a four-member delegation making a five-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
U.S. URGES TAIWAN TO APPLY TO JOIN WHA AS OBSERVER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) 04/13/07 13:20:37 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: U.S. State Department officials said Thursday that it would be more appropriate for Taiwan to seek accession to the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the decision- making body of the World Health Organization (WHO), as an observer, rather than seeking to join the WHO as a full member under the name "Taiwan."

The State Department officials in charge of East Asian affairs said that the United States has always encouraged Taiwan to seek "meaningful participation" in international organizations and has believed that the people of Taiwan are capable of making extraordinary contributions to the world health arena and that they should enjoy the same relevant rights as other citizens in the global community.

They said the 23 million Taiwan people's opportunities to make contributions to world health affairs will be impeded if Taiwan is barred from "meaningful participation" in WHO activities, adding that Taiwan is entitled to that right and privilege.

However, the officials also said that it is the United States' set policy not to support Taiwan's pursuit of joining international organizations where statehood is required for membership, adding that the United States supports Taiwan's seeking to join the WHA as an observer.

The State Department officials made the remarks after Taiwan's foreign minister, James Huang, confirmed in Taipei Thursday that President Chen Shui-bian had written a letter to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan the day before in which the president stressed that based on the WHO's spirit of protecting the health of all peoples around the world and the notion that medical care knows no borders, Taiwan has every right to apply to join the WHO as a full member.

As a matter of strategy, Huang said, Taiwan will adopt a three-pronged approach this year to facilitate its bid to join the world health regulatory body, specifically continuing to seek observer status in the WHA; continuing to seek "meaningful participation" in WHO technical conferences; and applying for full membership in the WHO under the name "Taiwan."

Meanwhile, the State Department officials reiterated the U.S. stance on cross- strait relations, saying that the United States does not support Taiwan independence and opposes any unilateral changes to the status quo across the Taiwan Strait by either Taiwan or China.

President Chen's "five noes" pledge announced in his inaugural speech in 2000 has been the bedrock of regional peace and stability in East Asia, they said, adding that whether Chen will deliver on his promise of not seeking independence will be a good test of his leadership, reliability, and his ability to handle foreign relations, protect Taiwan's interests and secure cross-strait stability.
They stressed that seeking to join the WHO as a full member under the name "Taiwan" does not comply with President Chen's pledge.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ENVOY TO U.S. TAKES OATH OF OFFICE

TEXT.P: Joseph Wu, who just stepped down as Mainland Affairs Council chairman, was sworn in Thursday as Taiwan's new representative to the United States, and promised to strengthen Taiwan's relations with the U.S.
The swearing-in ceremony was held at the office of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), with Foreign Minister James Huang standing as witness.

Huang expressed hope that Wu would strengthen communications with both the U.S. government and the American private sector to reduce misunderstandings between the two countries and build mutual trust for bilateral benefit.
Hailing Wu as an experienced and well educated public servant, Huang said Wu was responsible for foreign affairs when he served as Presidential Office deputy secretary-general.

During his tenure as chairman of Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Wu was in charge of explaining Taiwan's policies toward China to the United States, Japan and European countries, Huang added, expressing optimism that U.S.-Taiwan ties will be further boosted after Wu takes over his job.
Wu will leave for the United States April 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE MAN RECEIVES SUSPENDED SENTENCE FOR SWEARING AT OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: A Japanese citizen has received a suspended sentence of 30 days in detention for cursing at officials during immigration inspection at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport more than a year ago, aviation police sources said Friday.
The man, who is married to a Taiwanese woman and often travels back and forth between Taiwan and Japan, is also barred from visiting Taiwan for five years, according to the court ruling.

On a trip to Taiwan in September 2005, the man became so enraged by what he called the snail-paced immigration inspection at the Taoyuan airport that he burst into a volley of curses when an immigration officer began checking his travel documents.
Immigration authorities later filed a lawsuit against him. After more than a year of judicial proceedings, the Taoyuan District Court handed down its ruling earlier this week.
According to the ruling, the man had violated Article 140 of Taiwan's Criminal Code which bans anyone from insulting a public official during the legal discharge of his or her official duties.

Immigration officials said they felt compelled to file the lawsuit to defend the government's prestige and public authority. They expressed regret that the Japanese man has never shown any signs of remorse for his actions and has fought the charges by filing petitions with many local government agencies, including the Tourism Bureau, over the past year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS TO INTENSIFY SEARCH FOR TECH FIRM CEO

TEXT.P: Prosecutors said Friday they will step up the search for the chairman of Inventec Appliances Corp., a local handset maker that also produces iPod music players for Apple Inc., as part of their probes into the company's suspected involvement in insider trading.

After checking with immigration, law enforcement officers from the Panchiao Prosecutor's Office said they believe that Inventec Appliances Chairman Chang Ching-sung is still in Taiwan, while the company's president Lee Chia-en is in China.
More than 200 prosecutors and investigators raided Inventec Appliances Thursday afternoon to search for evidence to support charges of alleged insider trading.

A total of 17 members of the company's management staff, including its vice president and spokesman, Chen Hung-lieh, and the heads of the company's Shanghai and Nanjing factories, Ho Tai-shui and Lai Chen-hsing, were brought back to the Panchiao District Prosecutors Office for questioning. The interrogations continued to midnight.
In the raid at the company's headquarters in Wugu, Taipei County and at the homes of Inventec senior executives, a massive collection of corporate documents and accounting books were also seized.

A spokesman for the Panchiao District Prosecutors Office said law enforcement authorities launched the raid after receiving reliable information that pointed to high-ranking Inventec managers manipulating the company's stock prices.

A large portion of Inventec Appliances turnover for last year was derived from the popular iPod digital music player for Apple Inc., while its handset business accounted for only about 10 percent of the company's 2006 revenues, according to corporate accounting records.
The company's business turnover for the first quarter plunged substantially, while its work force had also been cut by more than 10 percent to about 13,817 as of the end of March.

Inventec Appliances is the latest in a spate of listed technology companies under investigation for suspected insider trading, following Veutron Corp., a memory module and scanner maker in Powerchip Group, and BenQ Corp. Inventec Appliances is 45 percent owned by computer maker Inventec Corp.

Ministry of Justice (MOJ) officials said streamlining the financial market and cracking down on major economic crimes have been the major targets of prosecutorial investigations over the past half year.

In the future, the officials said, prosecution authorities will continue giving priority to dealing with five types of crime, with an aim to realizing the MOJ- set target of pursuing 40 suspected economic and financial irregularities by the end of this year, including at least 10 definitive cases.

That means that prosecutors will tackle at least four major corporate scandals in the coming months since they have already been in an intensive quest for alleged legal transgressions by six listed corporations in the past six months, including Veutron, BenQ, Inventec Appliances, Rebar Group, Chinatrust Financial Group and China Development Financial Holding Co.

According to MOJ officials, the financial crimes to be cracked down will include insider trading and stock price manipulation, embezzlement of corporate funds, accounting fraud and illegal lending, illegal corporate mergers and takeovers, as well as illegal private equity transactions and capital solicitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS URGED TO SHOW SOLIDARITY

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called Friday for solidarity among the party's four presidential aspirants and urged their close aides to show restraint by not attacking other hopefuls.

Ker Chien-ming, caucus whip of the DPP in the legislature, said that with the party's upcoming presidential primary, attacks among the hopefuls -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- have become more fierce.

Ker noted that the party's presidential primary is set to kick off in May, with a party member vote and a series of public opinion polls to be held before the party's presidential candidate is announced May 30.
He urged the presidential hopefuls to stop their close aides from attacking other hopefuls, adding that rifts caused now by such attacks may prove too large to heal later.
He said that the DPP will only survive with solidarity, noting that the Kuomintang is "waiting in the wings" to take advantage of any errors the DPP may make.

He also expressed the hope that President Chen Shui-bian will continue to coordinate among the four DPP heavyweights after they take part Saturday in the first of two scheduled platform presentations.
Legislator Wang Sing-nan, another DPP caucus whip, said that continued fighting among the four aspirants will disappoint supporters and have disastrous consequences.
DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said that the four hopefuls should not forget that the primary will produce only one candidate to represent the party in the 2008 presidential election.

A prospective national leader should display a graceful manner, she said, expressing regret that the four aspirants have resorted to attacking one another. She added that such attacks will make it difficult to convince voters that they can trust the DPP candidate in the presidential election, regardless of who that candidate may be.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 72.9 points to close at 8,002.3.
The bourse opened at 8,100.08 and fluctuated between 8,108.5 and 7,999.69 during trading. A total of 4.55 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$114.99 billion (US$3.47 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 3 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent, construction issues at 0.5 percent, and textile stocks at 0.3 percent.
The one other major stock category gained ground, with cement shares moving up 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 880 to 295, with 147 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA, DOH OFFICIALS REACH CONSENSUS ON NEED TO ESTABLISH HEALTH POLICE

TEXT.P: Officials from the National Police Administration (NPA) and the Department of Health (DOH) reached a consensus Friday on the establishment of "health police" to help stem the rampant flow of illicit, counterfeit and bogus medications in the country.

The officials reached the consensus after engaging in a debate at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan sponsored by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao on which governmental agency should be responsible for cracking down on the flow and production of illicit drugs as well as counterfeit and bogus medications.

At the news conference, Lai said that there is only an average of one investigator for every 40,000 people in Taiwan in terms of finding and cracking down on illicit drugs and counterfeit or bogus medications, while penalties for violations are too light and cases of prosecution of such crimes too few.

Lai said the number of cases involving counterfeit or bogus medications in Taiwan has increased about 50 percent over the past three years, with the number of uncovered cases probably being much higher.
He lamented that although it is stipulated in the DOH organizational law that a health police force should be established, such a force has never been set up.

Lai said he will propose that the legislature request a health police force be established within a specific period of time, that a counterfeit medication task force be set up, and that police forces' performance in cracking down on counterfeit medications be included in their annual performance reports.

Liao Chi-chou, director of the DOH Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, said that transactions in Taiwan's pharmaceutical market total about NT$80 billion (US$2.42 billion) annually and that the DOH has had a hard time stamping out the trade in counterfeit or bogus medications because the profits to be made are even higher than in illicit drug trafficking and because the punishments under the law are too light.
Liao said the DOH would be pleased to cooperate with the NPA to jointly establish a health police force as long as there is a sufficient budget.

Chen Po-hsun, a section chief of the NPA Department of Economic Affairs, said the NPA has agreed to have "liaison windows" established to help crack down on the flow and production of illicit drugs as well as counterfeit and bogus medications.

Despite their differences on the issue, the NPA and DOH officials came to a consensus that it is imperative that a health police force be established in the near future to tackle the problem of counterfeit and bogus medications.
The two sides, however, remained divided on how the health police force should be set up and under which governmental agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANANAS RETURN TO SOUTH KOREAN MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/07 15:46:33 (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan bananas, with their delightful flavor and aroma, have returned to the South Korean market after a 10-year hiatus.
Kang Yi-chih, director of the Taiwan Trade Center in Seoul, held a news conference in the South Korean capital Friday to promote the first batch of Taiwan bananas arriving in the country in a decade.
Taiwan bananas and pineapples were served to the reporters and other guests at the news conference.

Kan noted that taste and aroma are what make Taiwan bananas stand out among products from other countries, adding that with South Korea's economic rebound since the Asian financial crisis in the late 1990s, South Koreans are now willing to pay more for high-quality agriculture produce.
A decade ago, Taiwan bananas couldn't compete in the South Korean market with cheaper bananas from the Philippines and Ecuador and had to bow out of the market.
