DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SU TO STEP ASIDE IF LIN YI-HSIUNG BIDS FOR PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that he will step aside to let Lin Yi-hsiung -- one of the pioneers of the democratic movement in Taiwan who is widely respected within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- run for the presidency of the country if Lin decides to do so.

Su made the remarks in a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan when asked by Legislator Lee Chia-chin of the opposition Kuomintang whether or not he would support a presidential bid by Lin by withdrawing from the DPP primary for the 2008 presidential election.

Su said Lin is the politician he respects the most and that Lin has made a great contribution to the development of Taiwan's democratic politics while sacrificing a great deal for the democratic movement. He said he admires Lin's great tolerance and his charitable manner toward those who harmed him and his family, noting that if Lin decides to run for president, he will step aside and give Lin his full support.

Lin served as DPP chairman from 1998-2000, during which time he helped Chen Shui-bian win the 2000 presidential election, ending the Kuomintang's five- decade hold on power. However, since that election, Lin has gradually pulled himself out of the political scene.

Lin renounced his DPP membership Jan. 24, 2006 in a statement, in which he said constant inter-party conflict and hostility over the past several years has led to ethnic divisions and social unrest. Expressing his disappointment with the DPP and other domestic political parties, Lin declared that he has no intention of serving in the DPP's administration or running for public office for the party.
Earlier on Friday, a "Lin's Friends" association was founded in a bid to gather support around Taiwan for a planned move to persuade Lin to participate in the presidential election next year.

Asked about the new campaign, Vice President Annette Lu, one of the four DPP aspirants for the presidency, declined to make a comment, only saying that if Lin decides to run for president in 2008, he won't represent the DPP because he has already quit the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS CALLS FOR OPPOSITION'S SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called Friday for the opposition parties to support Taiwan's seeking to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as a full member under the name "Taiwan."

The DPP lawmakers made the call after President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, Chiou I-jen, confirmed Thursday that the president had written a letter to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan the day before in which he stressed that based on the WHO's spirit of protecting the health of all peoples around the world and the notion that medical care knows no borders, Taiwan has every right to apply to join the WHO as a full member.

Speaking at a news conference, Ker Chien-ming, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said it has been a longstanding goal of the DPP administration to seek Taiwan's accession to the WHO and the United Nations under the name "Taiwan."
Unfortunately, Ker added, there has been very little progress made in this regard over the past years due to China's obstruction.
Ker expressed the hope that the opposition parties will join hands with the ruling DPP to jointly safeguard the health of all the people of Taiwan.

Chen Chung-hsin, director of the DPP Department of International Affairs, said that more than 100 legislators from across the political spectrum signed proposal last year to support Taiwan's bid to join the WHO as a full member under the name "Taiwan, " while 95 percent of the Taiwan people agreed that Taiwan should be admitted into the WHO -- facts indicating that protecting the health of all of the residents of Taiwan equates to protecting an important human right.

Wang Hsin-nan, another whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said that Taiwan's attempts to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the WHO's decision-making body, as an observer, have all failed over the past 10 years, even during the height of the scourge of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), because of Beijing's obstruction.

Wang said Taiwan, as a dynamic economic powerhouse and a sovereign state with a population of 23 million, should be admitted into the WHO as a full member. He called for the opposition parties not to "cooperate" with China to jointly suppress Taiwan.

Noting that Taiwan had managed to secure only "second-hand" medical and quarantine information during the SARS and bird flu outbreaks due to China's interference, DPP Legislator Huang Wei-che said that Taiwan should be allowed to have dialogue with the WHO and have access to WHO meetings on the grounds that health issues are life-and-death human rights issues.

Meanwhile, Chang Jung-kung, deputy director-general of the opposition Kuomintang's Policy Committee, criticized President Chen for writing to the WHO chief about Taiwan applying to join the WHO as full member under the name "Taiwan, " saying that the move is unrealistic and nothing but a scheme designed to invite even greater obstruction from China on the diplomatic front so as to help the DPP win "sympathy votes" in the upcoming major elections in the country.

In a written message issued in response to Chen's letter to the WHO chief, Chang said it is explicitly clear in the current international situation, including the United States' adhering strongly to its "one China" policy, that Taiwan has no chance of joining the WHO as a full member under the name "Taiwan" since statehood is required for membership in the world health regulatory body.
Chang said he sees the Chen administration's WHO bid not as a sincere bid to join the organization but as "a one side, one country plot."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES DPP HOPEFULS TO ENGAGE IN 'GENTLEMAN'S BATTLE'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the four presidential aspirants of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday to avoid attacking one another and to engage in a "gentleman's battle."

President Chen issued the appeal in a press release as the four hopefuls -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- have begun to attack one another more fiercely ahead of the party's upcoming presidential primary.

The latest incident revolved around Hsieh and former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, who criticized Su Thursday for "flip-flopping" in his stances on the planned construction of the Suhua Freeway and the planned demolition of the Losheng Sanatorium.

Su retorted by saying such attacks are mean-spirited, adding that Yu, during his premiership, proposed a budget and started construction of the freeway, and Hsieh, his predecessor, allocated funds for construction of the freeway. He further said that he wondered whether he would have to face the problem today if his two predecessors had handled the issue well, according to news reports.

Faced with a mounting war of words among the four aspirants, the president said that he issued the four-point statement "in a somber mood" on the eve of the first of two platform presentations for the four presidential hopefuls.
Presidential Office sources said that the president will only watch the platform presentation Saturday and will not speak during it.

The president expressed the hope that all the DPP's presidential aspirants will realize that the voters and the party's supporters have "high expectations" of them and that they themselves or their close aides should "show restraint in their actions and their words."
Chen stressed that there are no differences in basic policy line among the aspirants and that all within the party have followed the ideal of "Taiwan- centric consciousness."

The stances of the hopefuls on public issues may be different, but they can engage in serious examination and discussion of them, the president said, adding that he hopes to see more discussion on public issues in Saturday's presentation.

Noting that the DPP has ruled the nation for nearly seven years, Chen said that all four aspirants have led in the administrative team before and that they should shoulder part of the responsibility for its performance.

He stressed that the performance of the administration is the concerted efforts of all and that all should share the responsibility if there are things that need improvement, instead of passing the buck to others.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved down 87 points to close at 7,990, with 46,821 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May decreased 85 points to finish at 7,982, with 4,302 contracts traded, while June futures lost 85 points to end at 7,968, with 55 contract transactions. September futures moved down 95 points to close at 7,762, with 147 contracts traded, while December futures dropped 85 points to finish at 7,788, with 11 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,077 for April, 8,067 for May, 8,053 for June, 7,857 for September and 7,873 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

April TE futures decreased 3.55 points to close at 338.1 points, with 3,064 contracts traded, while May TE futures dropped 3.25 points to finish at 336.6, with 600 contract transactions. June TE futures dropped 3.5 points to end at 336.1, with three contract transactions, while September TE futures moved down 1.45 points to end at 330, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRONIC THERMOMETERS TO BE SUBJECT TO VERIFICATION FROM 2008

TEXT.P: In light of a wider use of electronic thermometers, the commodity regulatory authority has mapped out a plan in which such products will be subject to verification from 2008 to ensure their accuracy, an official said Friday.

The decision was made in response to the prevalence of electronic thermometers, itself a result of global limits on the use of mercury thermometers amid mounting concerns that mercury could pose a health threat to individuals and endanger the ecology and wildlife, the official from the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) said.

According to the official, the BSMI has formulated regulations for implementing verification and inspection procedures and stepped up the procurement of relevant testing facilities aimed at including electronic thermometers in the scope its work beginning Jan. 1, 2008.
Currently, only mercury thermometers are categorized as legal temperature measuring instruments and subject to verification.

According to the BSMI-drafted regulations, all contact electronic thermometers will be required to pass an accuracy test measuring the temperatures 35.5, 37 and 41 degree Celsius, in an environment in which the ambient temperature is 23 degree Celsius (plus or minus 5 degree Celsius ) , relative humidity is 50 (plus or minus 20) .The maximum permissible error during verification of the thermometers is plus and minus 0.1 degree Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL MOTORCYCLE TRADE FAIR TO OPEN MAY 18

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taiwan International Motorcycle Industry Show is scheduled to take place May 18-20 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall 3, with some 160 exhibitors from Taiwan and abroad presenting their latest motorbike models and accessories.
According the organizer, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), the exhibitors will use 385 booths, an increase of 25 percent over last year's exhibition.

These exhibitors include local agents of renowned motorcycle brand names, such as Japan's Yamaha, Italy's Ducati, Bimota and Piaggio, as well as suppliers of motorcycle parts and components from Taiwan, China, Pakistan, India and Vietnam.
TAITRA officials said that Germany's BMW Group and Austria's Kiska, a design agency, will come to the show to look for business partners in Taiwan.

In addition to booths showcasing complete motorcycles, scooters, parts, accessories, and production and inspection equipment, the show will present 100 fancy, dressed-up motorcycles remodeled in Taiwan in hopes of looking for buyers and promoting opportunities for parts manufacturers to do remodeling jobs.
There will be four seminars at the exhibition site to help participants in the show keep pace with new trends in the motorcycle industry.

Gerald Kiska, chief executive officer of Kiska Design, will give a lecture on "Motorcycle Design"; Chuck Crone, director of special projects and sourced vehicles at America's Polaris Co., will speak on "Opportunities to Supply Major All-Terrain Vehicle Manufacturers"; Jacques Compagne, secretary-general of the Association of the European Motorcycle Manufacturers, will talk about "Motorcycle Market in the Europe"; George Lin, president of Taiwan Golden Bee Co., will discuss "Global Opportunities for Taiwan Motorcycle Industry."

DOC.HEADLINE: ULTRA RUNNER PROMOTES SPORT WITH 'ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION' MINDSET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ultra-endurance marathoner Kevin Lin called for the public Friday to adopt an environmental protection mindset while engaging in sports.

At a colloquium sponsored by the Government Information Office (GIO), Lin, 30, who has been running over the past 20 years and set many world records by crossing the Sahara Desert's grueling 7,300 kilometers by foot with two other marathoners early this year, called for professional and amateur athletes alike to help protect natural resources around the globe.

Noting that some 10,080 liters of air will be compromised by the combustion of each liter of gasoline, Lin said it is everybody's responsibility to protect the environment and cherish global natural resources, especially now when the environment is increasingly being compromised.

Lin, along with an American and a Canadian, ran 111 consecutive days to cross the Sahara, enduring strong winds, which can abruptly raise sandstorms, making it difficult to see and breathe, and extreme temperatures, which might peak as high as 38 degrees Celsius during the day but dip below freezing at night, on the trek, which was originally scheduled to finish in 80 days.

At several points in their trek, Lin said, the trekkers stopped near sparsely populated wells to talk with villagers and nomads about the difficulties they face finding water -- prompting them to plan a fund-raiser for the non-profit group H2O Africa, which was established to raise awareness about the need for clean water throughout the African continent.
Lin said peoples around the world should love and help each other and in particular, help African peoples to secure access to clean water.

He said that running in "extreme" places around the world, including the North Pole, has helped him realize that one does not know how big the world is without going out to experience it, and that one does not realize how valuable life is without risking it.

Lin said he will see to it that a life foundation for athletes is established within 10 years as a means to thank his mentor, Pan Jui-keng, to give back to Taiwanese society, and to financially help top-level athletes so that they can devote themselves to competitions abroad without worry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ENJOY 6% ECONOMIC GROWTH IF POWER CHANGED: FORMER KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: If political power changes hands in Taiwan following the 2008 presidential election, the country could expect an annual economic growth rates of 6 percent from the following year on, and the national per capita income will increase to US$20,000 by the year 2011, said Ma Ying-jeou, a former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairman, Friday.

Taiwan's economic growth has slowed significantly since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took the power in 2000, Ma claimed, attributing the economic slowdown to "political unrest" caused by an "unstable government" implementing "uncertain policies."

Ma made the remarks during his address at a ceremony marking the establishment of a non-profit association for Chinese regional economic and strategic development, composed of members from the industrial, political and academic sectors of the island, including KMT Legislators Lee Chi-chu and Chu Feng-chi, and scholars from National Taiwan University and National Chengchi University.

According to Wang Tiao-chun, director of the preparatory committee of the association, the new organization is based on the idea of pushing for economic exchanges in the "greater Chinese economic zone" comprised of China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan, as well as promoting global cooperation and development.

With that goal in mind, Wang said they hope key industrial and commercial groups from the four main parties, and Singapore and the United States as well, will all cross political barriers to join the organization in an effort to boost regional development.

Addressing Taiwan's economic development, Ma said that there were too many Cabinet shuffles over the past seven years to allow most of the government's policies to be carried out, pointing out that in the seven-year period, five different persons have held the premier's post, there have been six ministers of finance, six ministers of economic affairs, and seven chiefs of the government information office.

The frequent personnel shuffles have resulted in uncertainty in the implementation of key governmental policies, such as the on-again-off-again construction of the fourth nuclear-power plant, the former Taipei mayor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER SUPPLIES IN CENTRAL TAIWAN SUFFICIENT FOR FIRST PART OF 2007

TEXT.P: Water supplies in central Taiwan will be sufficient in the first part of this year, the Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.
Agency officials noted that central Taiwan will need around 2.6 million tons of water per day, but this amount will be available thanks to plentiful rainfall during the first quarter.

Officials said that Taichung can supply 1.3 million tons of water daily, which is enough to meet demands, but noted that the Tachia River, the main source of water, often becomes turbid after downpours since the devastating Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake, and that turbidity could affect water quality, and thus supply.
In addition, the launch of the Central Taiwan Science Park has made demands for water soar and heightened the risk of water shortages.

The Central Taiwan Science Park needs 282,000 tons of water daily, but when the first-stage work of the Holi water purification plant is completed at the end of 2009, water supply should no longer pose a problem.

Meanwhile, the development of the Changpin Industrial Zone has not been as rapid as expected, with only one third of the estimated manufacturers entering the zone, resulting in a lesser amount of daily water use at around 8,000 tons.

To effectively use water sources in the region, officials have reviewed and adjusted the water supply. But overall, the household and industrial use of water in Changhua are gradually exceeding available supplies.

In the Yunlin Technology Industrial park, the daily water needs is around 300,000 tons, which is supplied by Chichi River, but as there is no reservoir the industrial park has to rely on water from irrigation systems during the dry season.
To deal with the future need for massive water inputs at the industrial park, the agency is actively tapping other water resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLDING MOTH FOUND IN IMPORTED NEW ZEALAND APPLES

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Friday that they have for the first time detected colding moth in a batch of imported apples from New Zealand.

Officials from the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said that they detected a live colding moth larvae when inspecting a batch of New Zealand apples at Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan Thursday.
The larvae was sent to the Department of Entomology of National Chung Hsing University for examination and confirmed as colding moth.
The 1,029 cartons of Fuji apples from New Zealand were determined to have failed the quarantine inspection.
According to regulations concerning the handling of apples imported from countries and regions with colding moths, this batch of apples will be either returned or destroyed.

Taiwan will also temporarily suspend imports of New Zealand apples until Wellington looks into reasons for the pest's presence, adopts measures to improve inspections, and notifies Taiwan that it is now free of colding moth. Until such steps are taken, its apples will not be allowed to enter Taiwan.
Officials said Taiwan has notified New Zealand to suspend its apple export operations and that the bureau will step up inspection and quarantine measures of imported apples.
Statistics show that in 2006 apples from New Zealand accounted for 12.3 percent of all apples imported into Taiwan.

Taiwan has imported New Zealand apples for more than a decade, and this is the first time that colding moth was found, officials said. Taiwan has not found this pest in apples from other countries this year, they added.
Officials said that apples with quarantine certification issued by New Zealand before April 13 should be shipped before April 17 and that no more apples should be shipped after that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVENUES OF TAIWAN TOBACCO AND LIQUOR CORP. FALL: AUDIT

TEXT.P: An audit showing that total revenues of state-run Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTL) in 2005 decreased by NT$4.9 billion (US$148 million) over the previous year, with revenues in tobacco and liquor both falling, Auditor-General Su Chen-ping said Friday.

The decline in TTL's 2005 business turnover was caused by the implementation of the Tobacco and Liquor Tax Act in 2002 that allowed for private breweries and distilleries, and the market was flooded by counterfeit and smuggled products, Su said, adding that TTL's failure to expand into global markets is also a reason for its decline.

The report shows the TTL's total revenues from tobacco sales declined by more than NT$2.1 billion, falling 7.5 percent, while revenues from best-selling tobacco products dropped by 20 percent, and sales of new products fell by 50-80 percent year-on-year. While total revenues from liquor decreased NT$2.4 billion, or 19.35 percent, mostly in sales of Kaoliang liquor.
The report shows that rice wine breweries owned by TTL are operating at less than 20 percent of capacity, a decline apparently greater than that in 2004.
Su said the Ministry of Audit has urged the TTL to come up with solutions for better operations, and marketing strategies to improve its revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN CITY, COUNTY DESIRE MERGER TO CABINET-CONTROLLED MUNICIPALITY

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih said Friday that the county should merge with Tainan City to form a single municipality and be placed under the direct authority of the Executive Yuan.

Su told a press conference that Tainan County and City should follow the example of Taichung City and County in central Taiwan by reqquesting that Tainan City and County become a special municipality under the Cabinet.

Taichung County and City councils formally requested in 2002 that the two administrative areas be allowed to merge into a single municipality under the direct jurisdiction of the Cabinet, but the central government has not yet reached a final decision.

Su said it is important that Tainan City and County be merged and upgraded to the same status as Taipei and Kaohsiung, otherwise the area will eventually become a satellite of the southern Taiwan port city, Kaohsiung.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai echoed Su's call, saying that he too has long called for a merger between Tainan City and County.

Hsu pointed out that as a city rich in history and culture, Tainan deserves to be a municipality under the direct control of the Cabinet, just as Kyoto, Japan, enjoys a higher status than other cities due to its cultural heritage.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGEST-EVER CHINESE DRUG SMUGGLING RING RAIDED

TEXT.P: Police seized 34 kg of amphetamine, 130 kg of ketamine, and some 280,000 MDMA pills, and arrested six drug smuggling suspects during a Thursday night raid on a warehouse in the northern port city of Keelung, said police officers of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Friday.

Police said that they were surprised by sheer volume of the various drugs smuggled from China, which were seized in a record-breaking raid. Such a quantity of drugs could supply the needs of approximately 1 million addicts, they added.

According to the CIB, a drug smuggling ring involved in the case had successfully shipped drugs from China to the island three times. The organization was also found to be running a trading company as a money laundering front.
An investigation into the origins of the drugs, how the drugs made the way into Taiwan, and the ring's drug trading network has been launched.

DOC.HEADLINE: BULLET TRAIN SERVICE AFFECTING OTHER TRANSPORTATION BUSINESSES

TEXT.P: The inauguration of Taiwan's first high-speed rail system has resulted in a lower number of passengers using the other means of transportation to travel the western part of Taiwan, according to officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The airliners have been the hardest hit, the officials said, adding that the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has announced that all domestic flight services will soon cease operations at Taichung Airport in central Taiwan.
The announcement came after the CAA approved Wednesday a Mandarin Airlines plan to cease servicing the Taipei-Taichung route May 1.
The airline company reported losses totaling NT$45 million (US$1.36 million) in 2006 on the route.

Mandarin Airlines, the only aviation company currently operating the Taipei- Taichung route, follows in the footstep of UNI Airways Corp., which ceased servicing the route in July 2004 due to falling passenger numbers.

The average passenger occupancy rate for all flight services on the Taipei- Taichung route slid to 24.8 percent in February from last December's 37.4 percent, while that on the Taipei-Chiayi route dropped from 63.4 percent to 46 percent during the same period, officials said.
These two routes have suffered most following the opening of the high-speed rail, the officials continued.
A total of 2.08 million people took the high-speed train between Jan. 5 and early March, officials noted, adding that the daily passenger volume averages at 33,161.
At the same time, the number of passengers taking the traditional railway shrank from 14.57 million in last December to 13.57 million in February, a drop of 6.9 percent, the officials stated.
Freeway bus services saw a very small decline in the number of passengers at 0.75 percent, according to officials.
The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will continue to monitor the situation and formulate policies to minimize the impact, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE HIGH SCHOOL TO PERFORM IN TAICHUNG'S MATSU FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Yasugi Senior High School in Japan's Tottori Prefecture has been invited to perform in Taichung County's Matzu International Cultural Festival, which runs until May 12, Taichung County Magistrate C.S. Huang said at a news conference Friday.

After the news conference, dancers from the school performed aJapanese traditional dance -- kojin kagura -- presenting a story adapted from a Japanese myth to visitors at the private Mingtai Senior High School in the county's Wufeng Township.
Huang said its next performance will be at the Chen Lan Temple -- the famous Matsu temple -- in the county's Tachia Township Saturday morning.

Tottori Prefecture and Taichung County have had frequent interactions and exchanges, especially in economy and agriculture, Huang said, adding that he hopes to expand the range of interactions to include culture, education, art, and tourism to benefit both countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI LAND IN TENDER SOLD FOR HIGH PRICE

TEXT.P: The Bank of Taiwan Friday sold by tender 11 plots of land across Taiwan, with one in the downtown Taipei Zhongzheng District hitting an NT$880,300 (US$26,540) per square-meter record for the district's residential area, the bank said.

According to information released by the bank, the plot of land at Taipei's Guling Street measuring nearly a thousandpings- a unit of area each equaling around 3.3057 square meters - was won by the listed Rich Development Co. Ltd with an NT$2,789 million bid, NT$1,229 million higher than the upset price.

Bank officials said such a high price was largely a result of the recent release of the government's 12-year compulsory education policy, because the plot of land containing residential and commercial areas is expected to fall within the catchment area of the nearby, highly rated Jianguo High School.
11 of the 17 plots of land available sold for a total of NT$3,132 million, bank officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 DETAINED IN PROBES INTO SUSPECTED INVENTEC STOCKS INSIDER TRADING

TEXT.P: Five people, including three vice presidents of Inventec Appliances Corp.-- a local handset manufacturing company that also produces iPod music players for Apple Inc., were taken into custody Friday to facilitate probes into the company's suspected involvement in insider trading.

However, the company's chairman, Chang Ching-sung, who is one of the prime targets in the suspected insider trading investigations, flew out of Taiwan two hours before prosecutors raided the company's headquarters in Wugu, Taipei County and the homes of several corporate executives Thursday afternoon.

Prosecutors said they have kept a close track of Inventec Appliances Corp.'s operations for some time, but have refrained from imposing any overseas travel ban on the company's senior executives for fear of alerting them and thereby hindering subsequent investigations.
They denied that any law enforcement officer leaked information about an impending raid on the company to any of the company's executives.
Another target of probe, Inventec Appliances President Lee Chia-en, is now in China. Prosecutors said once Chang and Lee return to Taiwan, they will be subpoenaed for questioning.
Both Lee's wife Chang Su-wei and his younger brother Lee Chia-chung have been held in incommunicado over their suspected roles in the alleged insider trading of the company's stocks.

Also detained were the company's three vice presidents -- Chen Hung-lieh, who concurrently serves as corporate spokesman, Chuang Chin-tai, and Tseng Ching-an who concurrently serves as the company's chief financer.

Of the 17 people who were brought back to the Panchiao Prosecutors Office for questioning, six were released after overnight interrogations. The remaining six were released on bail ranging between NT$5 million and NT$100,000.
More than 200 prosecutors and investigators were mobilized to raid Inventec Appliances Thursday afternoon in search for evidence supportive of charges on insider trading.
In the raid, a massive collection of corporate documents and accounting books were also seized, prosecutors said.

A spokesman for the Panchiao District Prosecutors Office said law enforcement authorities launched the raid after receiving reliable information that pointed to high-ranking Inventec managers manipulating the company's stock prices.

A large portion of Inventec Appliances turnover for last year was derived from the popular iPod digital music player for Apple Inc., while its handset business accounted for only about 10 percent of the company's 2006 revenues, according to corporate accounting records.
The company's business turnover for the first quarter plunged substantially, while its work force had also been cut by more than 10 percent to about 13,817 as of the end of March.

Inventec Appliances is the latest in a spate of listed technology companies under investigation for suspected insider trading, following Veutron Corp., a memory module and scanner maker in Powerchip Group, and BenQ Corp. Inventec Appliances is 45 percent owned by computer maker Inventec Corp.

Ministry of Justice (MOJ) officials said streamlining the financial market and cracking down on major economic crimes have been the major targets of prosecutorial investigations over the past half year.

In the future, the officials said, prosecution authorities will continue giving priority to dealing with five types of crime, with an aim to realizing the MOJ- set target of pursuing 40 suspected economic and financial irregularities by the end of this year, including at least 10 definitive cases.

That means that prosecutors will tackle at least four major corporate scandals in the coming months since they have already been in an intensive quest for alleged legal transgressions by six listed corporations in the past six months, including Veutron, BenQ, Inventec Appliances, Rebar Group, Chinatrust Financial Group and China Development Financial Holding Co.

According to MOJ officials, the financial crimes to be cracked down will include insider trading and stock price manipulation, embezzlement of corporate funds, accounting fraud and illegal lending, illegal corporate mergers and takeovers, as well as illegal private equity transactions and capital solicitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6,000 RUNNERS TO COMPETE IN 2007 TAINAN INTERNATIONAL MARATHON

TEXT.P: The 2007 Tainan International Marathon will take place Sunday in the city of Tainan, with 6,000 runners taking part, including 200 foreign athletes from 14 countries, Tainan Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai said Friday.

Hsu told a press conference that the foreign runners are coming from countries including the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany, Greece, Portugal, Ireland, Hungary, Japan, the Philippines and Hong Kong.

He said the city government has invited world-class long-distance runners to the race, including Bernard Mutai from Kenya, Oksana K. Lokhlove from Russia, and China's medal-winning female marathoner Hu Xiuying.

The race will start at 6 a.m. April 15 at the plaza in front of the Tainan city government building. The event will be divided into four categories: the 42.2-km marathon, the 21.1-km half marathon, the 10-km race and the 3-km leisure run.
The route of the race allows runners to pass many historical and cultural relics within the city, according to the mayor.

The first place winners in the men's and women's divisions of the full marathon race will each receive a cash prize of NT$50,000. Other prizes will be NT$30,000 for second place winners, NT$20,000 for third place winners, NT$15,000 for fourth place winners and NT$10,000 for fifth place winners.
Those placing first to fifth in the men's and women's divisions of the half marathon race will also be entitled to cash prizes ranging from NT$10,000 to NT$4,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAIN PARASITES CAUSE 30-YEAR HEADACHE

TEXT.P: An invasion by parasites in a woman's brain caused her headaches and occasional epilepsy for 30 years until a brain operation earlier this year, a Taipei County hospital said Friday.

Neurosurgeon Yen Ching-hua of the Far Eastern Memorial Hospital reported on the case in a news conference, saying the operation removed four calcified tumors from the 67-year-old woman's right occipital lobe; an analysis of the tumors found calcified cestodes.

He said that cases of parasites invading into brain are rare outside of agricultural areas having polluted water, poorly processed food and bad sanitation. In Taiwan such cases have occasionally occurred in the past but are rarely seen now,he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST GRAND JUSTICES ARE AFFLUENT: CONTROL YUAN REPORT

TEXT.P: A number of the country's grand justices are billionaires, while several others have seen their family assets increase substantially over the past year, according to the latest asset disclosure reports filed with the Control Yuan, the country's supreme watchdog body.
A newly published Control Yuan report shows that all grand justices have filed their 2006 assets disclosure reports, and most of them are in clover.

The report shows that Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, who concurrently serves as a grand justice, ranks among the three richest grand justices in terms of family assets. Weng's bank deposits increased NT$3.28 million to reach NT$19.25 million at the end of last year.

Weng was one of the senior government officials who came under fire last year over alleged misuse of special allowance funds set aside for their discretionary use. The asset disclosure report shows that Weng continued to deposit his special allowance fund into his bank account last year.
Over the past year, Weng's state bond holdings decreased by more than NT$10 million, while his real estate holdings remained unchanged.

According to the asset disclosure report, grand justice Tseng You-tien should be very interested in real estate investment. He reported possession of four houses and two plots of land in metropolitan Taipei in 2005 and his real estate holdings have increased significantly in 2006 by securing five plots of land in Hsinchu County's Chupei City where land prices have skyrocketed in recent years thanks to industrial development and the opening of high-speed Bullet Train services.

Grand justice Hsu Pi-hu also reported an enormous increase in family assets in the past year. In the 2005 report, Hsu had just NT$738,544 in bank deposit plus NT$102,181 securities holdings. In 2006, his bank deposit swelled to NT$5.67 million and his securities holdings also zoomed to NT$5.36 million.

Grand justice Lai Ying-jaw posted a nearly NT$8 million increase in his bank deposit last year, with the amount reaching NT$58.07 million at the end of 2006. He didn't have any securities or real estate holdings.

Meanwhile, Academia Sinica President Chi-huey Wong is also a wealthy man, possessing a house and two plots of land in the United States in addition to nearly NT$40 million in bank deposits and securities holdings.

Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen has more than NT$13.65 million in bank deposits, marking an increase of NT$4 million from his 2005 deposits. In line with Premier Su Tseng-chang's demand, Chen already placed part of his stock holdings into trust. His overall stock holdings remained almost same at NT$12.75 million, of which NT$59.49 million worth of stocks have been put into trust.

According to the asset disclosure report, many of Taiwan's overseas envoys are also wealthy. All of the 12 ambassadors or overseas representatives who filed their annual assets disclosure reports recently possess more than NT$10 million (US$303,030) in family assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOLITION OF SANATORIUM SUSPENDED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang has announced that the demolition of the Losheng Sanatorium will be suspended and the Executive Yuan will strive to retain 90 percent of the four-hectare compound.
The announcement came after Su visited the sanatorium in the northern county of Taipei Thursday for the first time in his capacity as premier.
The sanatorium was constructed in 1930 by Japanese colonizers for the segregation and treatment of persons with Hansen's disease, and now is home to several dozen elderly patients.
One day ahead of the visit, Su received sanatorium patients and preservationists at the Executive Yuan to discuss possible solutions.

Su said at the sanatorium that the Cabinet will ask the Taipei county government not to carry out the dismantlement as originally scheduled on April 16 to make way for a Taipei metro depot construction project.
Meanwhile, Su stressed that the construction project will not be postponed, promising that the Cabinet will provide subsidies to cover the extra costs incurred by the preservation of the sanatorium.

The premier also apologized to the patients, saying that the government did not fully realize the significance of the sanatorium and did not communicate well with patients during the decision-making process in 1994.
Su said that now engineering experts will have more time to come up with a win- win plan respecting the needs of both sanatorium and construction project.
He also urged all parties concerned to replace confrontation with communication and to help transform Taiwan into a country that safeguards human rights and culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MUST SEEK PERMISSION OVER OLYMPIC TORCH: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council has said that China must seek Taiwan's permission to have the 2008 Olympic torch relay pass through Taiwan, according to a Radio Taiwan International report issued Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun made the remarks to discount rumors that the International Olympic Committee has included Taiwan in the 2008 Olympic torch relay route.

Liu said, "If the Olympic torch route is to pass through Taiwan, the International Olympic Committee has to go through the formalities and seek permission from us. Under the condition of benefiting cross-strait relations, we believe that the torch relay will proceed very smoothly without compromising Taiwan's sovereignty."
Liu said that Taiwan belongs to the International Olympic Committee as an independent country. He said the committee should therefore follow procedure and respect Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 14, or the 27th day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1629: Christiaan Huygens, the Dutch physicist and astronomer, is born. He discovered Saturn's rings in 1655, pioneered the use of pendulum in clocks in 1657, and formulated Huygens' principle.
1865: US President Abraham Lincoln is failing fast after being shot in the back of the head at point-blank range by actor John Wilkes Booth, a Confederate fanatic, at the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C. He died the next day and was succeeded by Andrew Johnson.
1889: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and author of a 12-volume work entitled "A Study of History," is born.
1903: The typhus vaccine is discovered by Dr. Harry Plotz in New York.
1912: The Titanic strikes an iceberg and sinks in the North Atlantic, killing 1,500 people.
1941: Condemning the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui of the Republic of China declares that Outer Mongolia and the northeastern provinces are Chinese territory and that the Soviet-Japanese statement is not binding on China.
1945: US bombers pound Japan's Imperial Palace during World War II.
1949: The Taiwan provincial administration announces a decision to carry out the "37.5 Percent Farm Rental Reduction" and the "Land-to-the-Tiller" policies.
1956: USS Saratoga, a US Navy aircraft carrier which joined the fleet in 1927 as the largest warship in the world, is formally decommissioned.
1956: The first videotape is demonstrated in Chicago.
1962: French Prime Minister Michel Debre resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1971: The new Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: The first satellite observation station in the Republic of China is inaugurated at National Cheng Kung University.
1973: President Nguyen Van Thieu of the Republic of Vietnam leaves Taipei for home after a three-day visit.
1973: Dr. Jesus Soto Amesty, chairman of the Venezuela Senate Foreign Policy Committee, arrives in Taipei for a ten-day visit.
1975: Sikkim abolishes its monarchy and seeks full Indian statehood.
1976: A total of 3,460 students from 642 middle schools compete in the Taiwan Area Games.
1977: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
1982: Armed bandit Lee Shih-khe robs the Land Bank of Taiwan's Kuting Branch in Taipei City of more than NT$5 million, a major criminal case at that time.
1988: The Soviet Union ends its intervention in Afghanistan and allows its troops to withdraw.
1993: On International Women's Day, a Chinese newspaper asks 100 women what they would most like to be. Sixty say that they want to be men.
1994: Two US F-15 fighters shoot down two American helicopters over northern Iraq killing 26 people.
1999: Pakistan test-fires a 2,000-km range ballistic missile.
2000: Ovidio Manuel Barbosa Pequeno, the new Sao Tome and Principe ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: A four-member U.S. Senate delegation led by Sen. Phil Gramm (R-TX) arrives in Taipei to begin a three-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To be poor without complaining is not easy; but it is easy to be rich without being proud."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI LAND IN TENDER SOLD FOR HIGH PRICE

TEXT.P: The Bank of Taiwan Friday sold by tender 11 plots of land across Taiwan, with one in the downtown Taipei Zhongzheng District hitting an NT$880,300 (US$26,540) per square-meter record for the district's residential area, the bank said.

According to information released by the bank, the plot of land at Taipei's Guling Street measuring nearly a thousand"pings"- a unit of area each equaling around 3.3057 square meters - was won by the listed Rich Development Co. Ltd with an NT$2,789 million bid, NT$1,229 million higher than the upset price.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE VOLUME AT TAICHUNG FTZ RISING STEADILY

TEXT.P: Two-way trading volume at the Taichung Free Trade Zone (FTZ) in 2006 totalled 672,000 tons, with the value of the imports and exports amounting to NT$8.41 billion (US$254.04 million) , according to statistics released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Saturday.
MOTC tallies showed that Taichung FTZ was the most remarkable among the country's five free trade zones in terms of trade volume in 2006.

In line with a statute governing FTZ establishment and management unveiled in 2003, five free trade zones have been opened at the country's four major sea ports -- Keelung, Kaohsiung, Taipei (Bali) and Taichung -- and at Taoyuan International Airport.
MOTC statistics indicated that the combined export and import trade at the five FTZs increased significantly both in terms of volume and value in 2006 from the year-earlier levels.
It is estimated that the combined import and export volume at the five zones can reach 802,000 tons, with a value totaling NT$112.2 billion, MOTC officials said.
At present, there are nine companies at Keelung FTZ, 15 at Kaohsiung FTZ, 11 at Taichung FTZ, one at Taipei FTZ and 20 at Taoyuan Aviation FTZ.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA ANNOUNCES JOB TRANSFERS FOR 193 SENIOR POLICE OFFICERS

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) has announced a massive personnel reshuffle involving 193 high-ranking police officers as part of its efforts to upgrade operational efficiency in maintaining law and order, an official said Saturday.
In the unprecedented reshuffle, deputy chiefs from 10 city and county police bureaus around the country will be transferred to serve as division chiefs at the NPA headquarters, the NPA official said.

Meanwhile, he added, seven NPA division chiefs or specialists will be reassigned to serve as deputy heads at county, harbor and aviation police bureaus or heads of township and village police precincts.

Among others, Keelung Harbor Bureau Deputy Director Cho cheng-liang will take over as deputy head of the Hsinchu City Police Bureau and Tsai Shih-yi, chief secretary at the Taipei County Police Bureau will fill the position left vacant by Cho's job transfer.

The personnel reshuffle also includes the rotation of 38 deputy chiefs of city and county police bureaus. Among them is Chan Yung-mao, deputy director of the Yilan County Police Bureau, who will be reassigned as Taoyuan County Police Bureau deputy chief.

According to the NPA official, the reshuffle scheme was fleshed out by NPA Director-General Hou Yu-ih along with his two deputies as well as the NPA chief secretary, head of the Criminal Investigation Bureau and NPA personnel department chief.

"They have gauged a combination of factors in personnel replacement, including competence, character, ethical integrity, merits and achievements, as well as regional balance, seniority and commuting convenience, " the official explained, adding that all job transfers are set for completion April 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA CHIEF TO VISIT WASHINGTON ON FTA PUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) 04/14/07 13:18:35 (By Lin Chiehyu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor affairs administrator is set to arrive in Washington, D.C. Sunday to push for the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the two countries, trade sources said Friday.

Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Lee Ying-yuan will meet with Bush administration officials, deliver speeches to U.S. think tanks and lobby congressional support for the signing of an FTA during his visit, the sources said.
According to the sources, Lee will focus his talks on labor-related topics that are one of the U.S. major concerns in gauging whether to sign an FTA with Taiwan.

Previous U.S. State Department human rights reports have mentioned problems in Taiwan's migrant worker management and welfare services and perks for wage earners. Lee is expected to brief U.S. officials and think tank scholars on Taiwan's labor policy and its efforts to improve welfare benefits for both native wage earners and foreign laborers in the hope of "clarifying misperceptions and misunderstandings."

According to Taiwan officials stationed in Washington, D.C., the office of the U.S. Trade Representative has never explicitly stated that Taiwan's labor conditions are a hindrance to the signing of an FTA.
The officials also said that Taiwan's Labor Standards Law provides "lofty and adequate norms and standards" for treatment of wage earners.
"We believe that Lee's briefing on our achievements in labor rights protection will contribute to the FTA drive, " said an official from the Taiwan representative office in Washington, D.C.

In an interview with CNA, John C.C. Deng, Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States who will soon depart for home to take over as Taiwan's first top international trade negotiator, said Lee's U.S. visit is a wise move in the promotion of an FTA.

"The push for a Taiwan-U.S. FTA requires concerted efforts of all government departments. It would be very helpful if the heads of various administrative agencies can come to the U.S. capital for direct dialogue with their American counterparts, " Deng said, adding that besides trade and labor departments, the Environmental Protection Administration should also send delegates to Washington, D.C. for direct communications on Taiwan's needs.

According to Lee's itinerary, he will deliver a speech April 17 on upgrading Asian labor standards at the Center for National Policy, a U.S. think tank dedicated to research and debate on issues of U.S. national interests. He will also attend a seminar at the U.S. Heritage Foundation, another Washington-based think tank.
Before wrapping up his trip April 19, Lee will brief Taiwanese journalists posted in Washington, D.C. on the purposes and accomplishments of his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR DEPARTMENT STORES SEE REVENUE DECREASE IN Q1

TEXT.P: First quarter revenues for major department stores in Taipei City decreased compared with the same period of last year, according to statistics made public Saturday.

The statistics showed that the revenues of SOGO Department Store's business turnover decreased by 4 percent, while both Shin Kong Mitsukoshi and Dayeh Takashimaya department stores registered a 5 percent drop in their first quarter turnover.
Dayeh Takashimaya executives attributed the decrease mainly to an abundance of department stores in the city and a reluctance on the part of consumers to make purchases over the past few months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Saturday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April moved up 77 points to close at 8,067, with 17,797 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May rose 78 points to finish at 8,060, with 3,103 contracts traded, while June futures increased 71 points to close at 8,039, with 21 contract transactions. September futures gained 71 points to finish at 8,039, with 21 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 56 points to close at 8,044, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Saturday at 7,990 for April, 7,982 for May, 7,968 for June, 7,762 for September and 7,788 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

April TE futures gained 2.35 points to close at 340.45, with 1,183 contracts traded, while May TE futures increased 2.5 points to finish at 339.1, with 162 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

April TF futures moved up 5.2 points to close at 992.4, with 949 contracts traded, while May TF futures rose 7.6 points to finish at 995.6, with 218 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-DPP CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR ELECTION OF SUPRA-PARTY PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said Saturday that the president to be elected in 2008 should be a non-partisan politician and he urged possible candidates to work toward ending the bitter strife among the various political parties.

Lin made the remarks while leading a group of nuclear-free activists in distributing leaflets in Taichung City, central Taiwan, to solicit support for his campaign to seek revisions to the Referendum Law.
Lin claims that a cap in the Referendum Law makes proposing a referendum and passing it very difficult.

Lin noted that the law stipulates that a referendum proposal should obtain the endorsement of more than 5 percent of the country's citizens, much higher than the 1.5 percent required to present a presidential candidate.
Lin's ultimate goal is to allow the public to have a say in deciding the future of the country's Fourth Nuclear Power Plant. He has been a staunch supporter of the policy to make Taiwan nuclear-free.
According to Lin, the implementation of referendums will be the next step in Taiwan's democratization.
Commenting on the fighting among the political parties, Lin said it is no surprise, especially when elections are approaching.

Saying that a reduction of political conflicts is vital for the presidential election in 2008, Lin called for the election of a supra-party leader who can contribute to benign competition among the political parties rather than to fuel more partisan confrontation.
Lin said he has no plans to run in the 2008 election himself, but he did not totally exclude the option of running in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 42.82 points to close at 8,045.12.

The bourse opened at 8,027.42 and fluctuated between 8,045.12 and 8,016.04 during the day's trading. A total of 3.43 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$75.02 billion (US$2.27 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.6 percent, followed by construction issues at 2.4 percent, textile stocks at 1.1 percent, cement stocks at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent.
Banking and financial shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 756 to 353, with 209 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR RESUMPTION OF NEW ZEALAND APPLE IMPORTS: COA

TEXT.P: There is no timetable on any resumption of New Zealand apple imports to Taiwan, an official of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday.

Yeh Ying, deputy director of COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, made the remarks after Taiwan suspended New Zealand apple imports due to a codling moth larvae found in a batch of New Zealand apples that arrived Thursday at Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan.
The 1,029 cartons of Fuji apples from New Zealand were determined to have failed the quarantine inspection.
Yeh said the COA notified the New Zealand Commerce and Industrial Office in Taipei and that the office sent staff to investigate the matter.
"Taiwan will decide when to resume imports of New Zealand apples after reviewing its progress in the eradication of agriculture pests," she said.
According to regulations concerning the handling of apples imported from countries and regions with codling moths, the contaminated apples will be either returned or destroyed.

Taiwan will also temporarily suspend imports of New Zealand apples until Wellington looks into the reasons for the pest's presence, adopts measures to improve inspections and notifies Taiwan that it is free of codling moths. Until such steps are taken, its apples will not be allowed to enter Taiwan.
Yeh noted that the codling moth lays eggs on apples and the larvae feed on the fruit, burrowing into the fruit before leaving to overwinter and pupate elsewhere.
If the moth adapts to Taiwan's climate, it could attack apples, pears and peaches, causing great damage, Yeh added.

She pointed out that the United States has imported a lot of tropical fruit from Central and Southern America, which often carries the Mediterranean fruit fly, so that California and Florida see their fruit crops affected from time to time.

Taiwan has no Mediterranean fruit fly, but does have the oriental fruit fly, which affects more than 30 fruits. Taiwan fruit has therefore to be fumigated before export to kill any oriental fruit fly larvae.
Statistics show that in 2006, apples from New Zealand accounted for 12.3 percent of all apples imported into Taiwan.

Taiwan has imported New Zealand apples for more than a decade, and this is the first time that codling moth has been found, COA officials said. Taiwan has not found this pest in apples from other countries this year, COA officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONNEL ADJUSTMENT FOR REPRESENTATIVE OFFICES ABROAD
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Canada, April 13 (CNA) 04/14/07 17:29:33 (By George Wu and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The economic division chief under the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Canada is to take over the same post at the Taipei Representative Office in the European Union and Belgium, a TECO spokesman said Friday.
Chang Chun-fu will depart Saturday from Ottawa to Brussels to assume his new position, the spokesman said.

The job transfer was decided by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the spokesman went on, adding that Chang's position in Canada will be taken over at the end of April by Yang Hung-chih, the incumbent director-general of the International Cooperation Office under the MOEA.

Chang has served at the Intellectual Property Office and the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the MOEA and, has worked at the Taipei Representative Offices in the United States and Indonesia, as well as Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Saturday, moving up NT$0.005 to close at NT$33.106.
A total of US$253 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. dollar opened at NT$33.101 and fluctuated between NT$33.1 and NT$33.12.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL AID WORKERS RESCUED FROM GROUNDED FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: All of the Taiwan medical aid workers aboard a stricken Taiwanese fishing boat that hit a reef while conducting relief work for tsunami victims in the Solomon Islands have been rescued, a diplomatic official said Saturday.
According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Wang Chien-yeh, a U.S. Navy helicopter lifted 20 people off the grounded Yufa 201, including four Taiwanese medical workers.

The aid workers were sent by the Taiwan International Health Action (Taiwan IHA), an ad hoc inter-agency body founded by the MOFA and the Department of Health early last year to help with international disaster relief work.

Quoting Republic of China Ambassador to the Solomon Islands George Chan, Wang said the Taiwanese fishing vessel had been returning to the western town of Gizo after delivering aid supplies to the Pacific island nation's outlying islands Friday when it hit a reef.

Chan immediately asked the Solomon Islands authorities to arrange for a rescue, Wang said, adding that the U.S. chopper helped lift the Red Cross workers and the Taiwan IHA team off the ship. "We were told that our aid workers were safely evacuated, " Wang said, adding that they have returned to Honiara, capital of the Solomon Islands.
Also rescued from the ship were 13 Red Cross workers from New Zealand and the Solomon Islands, as well as two patients and an injured Yufa crew member, he said.

The other crewmen remained on the grounded vessel, Wang said, adding that Chan asked the Solomon Islands' maritime disaster relief center to seek the assistance of Malaysian ships operating in the region to help tow the Yufa to a nearby port for repair.

The accident came as the Solomon Islands declared April 23 a national day of mourning for 43 people killed when a magnitude-8.1 earthquake triggered a tsunami that crashed through coastal villages earlier this month. Another 7,000 people have been left homeless. Taiwan has donated funds and sent personnel to assist in post-tsunami relief and rehabilitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI URGED TO APOLOGIZE FOR GRAFT IN M-TAIWAN PROJECT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/07 18:25:40 (KMT) demanded Saturday that the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the opposition Kuomintang explain how alleged graft involving its official will affect the country's future competitiveness, and apologize to the public.

KMT legislative caucus whips made the call at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan after prosecutors discovered that the "M-Taiwan" broadband Internet network construction project, one of the government's 10 new major national construction programs, might have been stained by graft. The project includes a broadband channel construction plan aimed at overcoming the "LastMile" establishment challenge.
The MOI's Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) has budgeted NT$30 billion (US$906.48 million) to subsidize local governments in "fanning out" broadband wires and cables for the "LastMile" project.

The suspected malfeasance was discovered during an investigation by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office and the Civil Service Ethics Department under the Ministry of Justice into another graft allegation involving CPA official Chang Ho-ping.
Chang was detained Friday on suspicion of allowing certain contractors to make profits after receiving dinner invitations from them.

Legislator Hsu Shao-ping, a KMT caucus whip, said the "M-Taiwan" plan, with its government budget of over NT$60 billion and numerous trading opportunities, has become a machine that is vacuuming "sweat money" out of the pockets of the public.

According to Hsu, the "M-Taiwan" project is aimed at establishing a high-quality broadband Internet network throughout the country to provide cheap high-speed Internet connection services in efforts to boost the production value of Taiwan's telecommunication sector.
KMT Legislator Joanna Lei pointed out that the project, comprised of many smaller construction programs, has being carried out on loans of more than NT$60 billion.

Out of concern that Chang might be guilty of other similar malpractice while serving as the head of the CPA public construction division, the KMT legislative caucus urged the Executive Yuan to take steps to cleanse all other major public construction projects of graft.
In response to the call, Executive Yuan spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling said the alleged graft case will not affect the "M-Taiwan" project, which is being implemented as scheduled.
Chen noted that the prosecution has begun a probe into the case and said if evidence shows the CPA official had actually accepted improper dining invitations, it would be "only his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Government to tighten labor security bill.
The Cabinet meeting approved a draft bill Friday to tighten labor security regulations after four workers were killed on the same day in four different job accidents around the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS TRADE BARBS OVER TAIWAN BUSINESS ASSOCIATION IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the ruling and opposition parties traded barbs Saturday over the soon-to-be inaugurated Taiwanese chamber of commerce in China.

Legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) asked if the establishment of the first national-level association of Taiwan businessmen investing in China is scheduled Monday to coincide with a China visit by Lien Chan, honorary chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), that day.
DPP Legislator Gao Jyh-peng asked if this means that the KMT is singing a duet with the Communist Party of China (CPC) to help the latter's "united front" campaign against Taiwan.

Gao noted that Chang Han-wen, a Taiwanese businessman operating in Guangdong Province in southern China who headed a supporters group for Lien's presidential bid in the 2004 presidential election, will serve as the chairman of the group.

High-ranking Chinese officials will also play roles in the association, Gao said, noting that Chen Yunlin, the director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, has been chosen to serve as honorary chairman of the new organization, while He Shizong, director of the office's Economic Bureau, will be the group's vice chairman and secretary-general.
Gao said that Lien has only announced his itinerary for one day in China and asked what he plans to do for the remaining days of his stay in China.
Lien's visit reportedly will mainly be to attend the third Cross-Strait Economic and Cultural Forum in Beijing from April 28-29 and to meet Chinese President Hu Jintao.
"China has obviously completed its scheme to control Taiwanese businessmen investing in China," Gao said.

DPP Legislator Kao Chien-chih claimed that the KMT has promoted absentee voting in the legislature in an attempt to collaborate with the CPC and is using every means to try to win the 2008 presidential election.

But Hsu Shao-ping, KMT caucus whip in the legislature, pointed out that this is not Lien's first trip to China and said that if the DPP is pointing fingers whenever KMT officials visit China, the government "should not discuss cross- strait policy any more."
She also claimed that the KMT is promoting absentee voting mainly for those voters in Taiwan who cannot make it to polling stations and not for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China.

She cited the examples of policemen, military personnel, jail wardens and election officials who sometimes cannot vote because of their work. As for Taiwan businessmen in China. the KMT is considering pushing for charter flights for them to make it easier for them to return to Taiwan to vote in elections, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS SUGGEST REFERENDUM ON DECIDING GAMBLING DISTRICT

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmakers suggested Saturday that the central government decide location of gambling district according to results of referendum suggested to hold in each county and city.

Charles C. Chiang and Hsueh Ling came up with the suggestion to let people decide if they want their residence to have a gambling district, and allow the central government to consider in priority the places that win more approvals in referendum results.

The suggested idea was brought up after Premier Su Tseng-chang said that he was "not against" the idea of having a referendum about ban lifting of gambling industry in response to lawmaker Kuo Chun-ming's questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOSHENG SANATORIUM ACTIVISTS LOBBY INTERNATIONAL SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Activists dedicated to saving the Losheng leprosarium said Saturday that officials of the United Nations and the U.S. State Department have promised to lobby support for the survival of the sanatorium.

Members of the patients' self-help organization made the remarks at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan after concluding a trip to the U.N. headquarters and the U.S. State Department in the last two weeks.

The activists said they were soliciting support to preserve 90 percent of the 4-hectare Losheng leprosarium as previously promised by the Cabinet, which is at odds with the Taipei county government on the matter. The county government plans to demolish the sanatorium, which was built during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan, to make way for a metro construction project.

Yang You-jen, leader of the lobbying delegation, noted that the government has been expressing its hope of entering the U.N. and the World Health Organization (WHO) during the last decade. However, Yang claimed that it has been violating U.N. and WHO practice regarding the settlement of lepers.

The government's move not only runs counter to the world trend of protecting patients' rights, but also goes against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's promise to protect human rights, Yang claimed.

Other members of the lobbying group said the preservation of the Losheng leprosarium is now not only a matter for Taiwan, but has attracted much attention from around the world due to the historical and cultural value of the sanatorium. They urged Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei not to continue "bullying" less-privileged citizens in exchange for commercial development.

Chou claimed that the decision to tear down the sanatorium was made by Premier Su Tseng-chang during his tenure as Taipei county magistrate and that Su decided to change his past policy simply because he is planning to run in the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL DPP PRESIDENTIAL ASPIRANTS OPPOSE UNIFICATION WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: The four presidential aspirants of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) might differ on many issues, but they all agree that Taiwan is a sovereign, independent country that should not unify with China.

The four hopefuls -- Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Premier Su Tseng-chang and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- echoed the views in response to questions on whether they favor unification with China and on their views on promoting the nation's diplomatic work, in the first of two forums sponsored by the DPP to give the public a chance to hear a little about their respective platforms.
Yu said unification with China is not an option and that it would mean Taiwan being swallowed up by China and being relegated to a province.
He also said Taiwan enjoys important strategic value and should forge alliances with other democratic countries.
"There should be an Asia-Pacific strategy before a China strategy," he added.

Su said Taiwan's future should be decided by its people and that no Taiwanese will favor unification with China. If elected president, he will continue to push for Taiwan-centric consciousness, he added.
Su also said that although Taiwan maintains diplomatic relations with only 24 countries, Taiwan's economic muscle should help it on the difficult diplomatic front.

Hsieh claimed that Ma Ying-jeou, former chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the most likely bet of the party in the 2008 presidential election, is now echoing the DPP's long-standing stance that Taiwan's future should be decided by its people.
But he said the distinction between the DPP and the KMT is that that the former advocates moving toward independence, while the KMT advocates eventual unification with China.

Hsieh said that although the number of countries that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan is limited, Taiwan has a vibrant economy that will help it seek a diplomatic breakthrough amid China's relentless obstruction.
Lu said that there is no question about Taiwan being a sovereign, independent country, noting that its first popular presidential election was held in 1996.

She also said that democracy is what makes Taiwan stands out and that the nation should promote its democratic ideals, which, combined with the vibrant private sector, will make Taiwan shine in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT UNDERGOES MINOR HEART SURGERY

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui underwent minor heart surgery Saturday at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
Doctors inserted a balloon to help open his narrowed arteries to allow them to implant stents more easily. Altogether, the former president, 84, has had 11 stents implanted.
Doctors said the surgery went smoothly and that Lee was recovering well, although he will stay in the hospital for two or three days for observation.
Lee has had heart surgery three times before. Doctors considered his age would not allow a coronary bypass surgery and conducted less invasive cauterization surgery.
Lee went to the hospital for a checkup last month and was diagnosed with a narrowed coronary artery.
