New York Times: E-Mail Listed Possible G.O.P. Replacements for Attorneys
A Justice Department e-mail message released on Friday shows that the former chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales proposed replacement candidates for United States attorneys nearly a year before they were dismissed in December 2006. The department has repeatedly stated that no successors were selected before the dismissals.
The Jan. 9, 2006, e-mail message, written by D. Kyle Sampson, who resigned last month as the top aide to Mr. Gonzales, identified five Bush administration officials, most of them Justice Department employees, whose names were sent to the White House for consideration as possible replacements for prosecutors slated for dismissal.
Wall Street Journal:Panel Ties CA Founder to Huge Fraud
A special committee of the board of directors has accused Charles Wang, founder and former chairman of Computer Associates International Inc., of directing and participating in fraudulent accounting during the 1980s and 1990s.
The committee's report, filed late Friday afternoon in Chancery Court in Delaware, is the first investigation that publicly ties Mr. Wang to what the government has described as a $2.2 billion accounting fraud. The committee recommended that the Islandia, N.Y., software company, which has changed its name to CA Inc., file suit to recover at least $500 million from Mr. Wang in costs related to his conduct, including a $225 million payment CA made to a government-ordered restitution fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL ASPIRANTS PUBLICIZE SOCIAL WELFARE INITIATIVES

TEXT.P: The four presidential aspirants of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) outlined their various social welfare promotion initiatives Saturday at a televised platform presentation.

The DPP hosted the first of two platform presentations for its four presidential hopefuls -- Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Premier Su Tseng-chang and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- who are bidding to represent the party in the 2008 election. Each hopeful had six minutes to present their political ideas and administrative plans followed by a question-and-answer session.

During the session, Minister without Portfolio Fu Li-yen brought up three questions concerning social welfare practice -- asking what are the DPP's core ideas in the promotion of social policies and what are the hopefuls' core ideas on the issue, as well as what kinds of social welfare would they promote as priority if elected in 2008.

Hsieh, a former premier, said the DPP government has placed social welfare, care for the less-privileged, economic growth, social fairness and justice as priorities. He said economic growth, social justice and fairness, as well as culture and environment, should be treated equally in the formation of social welfare policies.

He said that while serving as premier, he raised the government stipend for elderly farmers from NT$4,000 (US$120) per month to NT$5,000. However, the stipend is still smaller than a similar subsidy of NT$13,000 for veterans.
If he wins the presidential election, Hsieh said he will make efforts to push for the legislation of a national pension system to ensure more equitable distribution of national resources, Hsieh said.

Yu, who served as premier from 2002 to early 2005, said that during his premiership, a draft national pension bill was referred to the legislature but has since been shelved due to partisan strife. According to that bill, a monthly pension of NT$7,500 was proposed for every retiree. As social conditions change, he said, the amount is now no longer able to support a pensioner. Against this backdrop, he adovated that the pension be raised to NT$10,000 per month.
Yu also proposed a "Happiness in Taiwan" program during the presentation as part of efforts to promote a so-called green economy.

Lu, the only female presidential aspirant in the DPP, spoke of the "Good Housekeeping Project" she put forward in 2005 and which was adopted by the Council for Economic Planning and Development in April 2006 to provide women with training in care for the elderly, child care, and home management to enhance their employment opportunities as professional housekeepers for working mothers.
Lu also said if she becomes president in 2008, she will try to resolve problems including a dropping birth rate, which is changing the population structure of the country.
The problem of the aging society was also touched upon by Su, who revealed that Taiwan has currently 2.29 million senior citizens aged over 65, over 200,000 of whom suffer from dementia.
If he is elected president, Su said, he will continue efforts to implement the ongoing "Mega Investment, Mega Warmth" project covering care for the elderly and less-privileged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO STRESS DEMOCRATIC VALUES

TEXT.P: Academics at a seminar on Taiwan-Japan-China ties said Saturday that Taiwan should show more concern toward democratization in other countries while strengthening democratic alliances with the United States and Japan.

They made the remarks at a seminar held in Taipei the day after Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao concluded a three-day "ice-melting" trip to Japan, in which Wen and his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe pledged to strengthen bilateral relations.

Lo Fu-chuan, chairman of the Association of East Asia Relations, a quasi- official organization established to deal with Japan on behalf of Republic of China government in the absence of diplomatic ties, noted that relations among Taiwan, Japan and China are an important part of Asia's interaction.

Recently, Japan has put more effort into getting involved in Asian affairs and has established closer ties with the United States, India and the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, focusing especially on their common values in democratization.
Lee Ming-chun, deputy secretary-general of the Taiwanese Society of International Law, claimed there is no more hegemony in Asia, where China, Japan, India and Australia all play important roles.

China and Japan need to ponder a new policy in the face of the changing Asian situation, while Taiwan should not focus foreign ties only with Japan, the U.S. and China, but should instead develop diverse relations.

Lin Cheng-yi, a researcher of the Institute of European and American Studies under the Academia Sinica, said ties between Taiwan and Japan have been well maintained since the Democratic Progressive Party took power and he called on the government to continue strengthening relations with Japan.
Tamkang University Associate Professor Chang Wu-yueh said Taiwan should consider how to keep its economic advantage amid the growing call for Asian integration.

He suggested that Taiwan show more concern to other countries' democratic development, especially China, adding that only when the two countries reach consensus in democracy can peaceful relations between the two be assured.

Saying that Japan-China and Taiwan-Japan relations are not a zero-sum game, Loh Chih-cheng, a professor at Soochow University, said he sees no need for Japan to sacrifice Taiwan's interests in exchange for an improvement of its ties with China.
According to a recent survey, the people of both Taiwan and Japan see each other as friendly countries, which Loh described as an important fundamental for Taiwan-Japan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTERS MARCH IN TAIPEI AGAINST CABLE TV STATION

TEXT.P: Major pro-Taiwan independence groups organized a protest march in downtown Taipei Saturday to push for TVBS cable TV station to shut down and pull out of the Taiwan media market over what they called the station's repeated unprofessional news reporting.

Hundreds of their supporters were gathered in front of the Control Yuan and then marched through several major streets to reach TVBS head office on Pateh Road where they staged skits to mock the station and urge it to bow out of the local media market.

The leader of the demonstration, Peter Wang, also read to Premier Su Tseng-chang a statement carrying three demands for the Executive Yuan -- to apologize for its mishandling of TVBS, to terminate the operations of the "unconstitutional" National Communications Commission and to suspend the licenses of television stations owned partially or fully by China.
Wang also accused TVBS of having served as China's spokesman in Taiwan by frequently making false accusations against government leaders and broadcasting staged footage to disturb public order.

The organizing groups included the Taiwan Association of University Professors, the 908 Taiwan Republic Campaign and the Taiwan Association for 228 Peace Promotion. Some legislators and city and county councilors from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led "pan-green" camp also took part in the demonstration.

A TVBS spokesman refused to comment on the demands but called on the Taipei city government for better consideration on the impact of the protest on businesses in the area and on rights of TVBS employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD KEEP DEMOCRACY GOING: EX-U.S. CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: As long as Taiwan's democracy and trade continue to grow, "problems will solve themselves," a visiting former U.S. congressional leader said Saturday.

Henry Hyde, a former chairman of the U.S. House International Relations Committee, made the remarks while talking with a number of reporters at his hotel room in Taipei, where he was to attend a Sunday conference to be organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Taiwan's democratization.

Asked for comments on Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering plan, Hyde said that rewriting a new constitution will "present serious problems" as it will increase the tension across Taiwan Strait. He suggested that amendments that bear no military or geopolitical consequences and are highly domestic may be easier accepted as not being a challenge to the status quo.

An active supporter of Taiwan's bid to negotiate a free trade agreement (FTA) with the U.S. during his congressional term, Hyde said a U.S.-Taiwan FTA is inevitable though he did not know how soon will that be in place.
He said things are changing and there needs no hurry. "Just be patient and keep things in balance."
Hyde praised Taiwan's democratic and economic achievement, saying that in Asia "Taiwan is a shining example of progress and stability within the context of a vigorous democracy."
Meanwhile, he reminded Taiwan that China's military buildup is worrisome and has the potential to change the status quo. He urged Taiwan to strengthen its self- defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Excessive Force By Marines Alleged. Afghan Report on Killings of Civilians Is Called Consistent With U.S. Findings. A platoon of elite Marine Special Operations troops reacted with "excessive force" after an ambush in Afghanistan last month, opening fire on pedestrians and civilian vehicles along a 10-mile stretch of road and killing 12 people - including a 4-year-old girl, a 1-year- old boy and three elderly villagers -- an investigation by an Afghan human rights commission alleges.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN WEATHER FORECAST FOR SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Generally unsettled weather will encompass East Asia for much of Sunday, according to a Radio Taiwan International report released Saturday.

A low pressure system will bring morning rain and even snow to parts of Japan. To the south, a storm will begin to develop in southeast China, bringing rain and thunderstorms to the area, including Taiwan.

Tokyo will see highs of 17 degrees with similar temperatures in Seoul and Beijing. Hong Kong could reach up to 28 degrees Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL: BUSH'S 'ATTITUDE' TOWARDS CHEN A KEY

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush's attitude toward President Chen Shui-bian formed out of Chen's unexpected "one country on each side" talk in 2002 remains a major obstacle in bilateral relations, a former aid to U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney suggested Sunday. Stephen Yates, former deputy assistant to Cheney for national security affairs from 2001V2005, made the remark at an international seminar held by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Taiwan' democratization.

In the seminar as well as a conference session that went before it, the hesitation on the part of the United States and international community to give a helping hand to the democratic Taiwan squeezed by a rising China was a central concern.

Hao Pei-chih, a public administration scholar from National Taipei University, said Taiwan's people have a sense of frustration over the country's current situation, especially in comparison with South Korea, as the United States is still hesitant to negotiate a free trade agreement with Taiwan. She wanted to know why.

Yates said he personally feel that the United States at this point has "an attitude towards Taiwan, not a policy or strategy". He said that Chen's talk of both sides of Taiwan Straits as "one country on each side" caught Washington off guard when the top level of the U.S. government was in intensive discussion and debate over the plans to invade Iraq and China loomed as a very important factor to consider.

He said Chen's remark came to U.S. government as a sudden newspaper story rather than an advanced notice through diplomatic channels or a part of public debate ongoing for some time, and that irritated Bush.

Yates said Bush is hard to change his mind once he has had judgement for someone, and Chen was since labeled. He said similar incidents repeated again and again and that has some impact on the way the administration treats Taiwan. But Lo Chih-cheng, Chairman of the Department of Political Science of Soochow University, said sometimes "surprises" may be good. "If Taiwan's going to do something anyway because of some domestic forces," then it is better not to communicate with the U.S. to avoid embarrassment both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL: BUSH'S 'ATTITUDE' TOWARDS CHEN A KEY

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush's attitude toward President Chen Shui-bian formed out of Chen's unexpected "one country on each side" talk in 2002 remains a major obstacle in bilateral relations, a former aid to U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney suggested Sunday. Stephen Yates, former deputy assistant to Cheney for national security affairs from 2001V2005, made the remark at an international seminar held by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Taiwan' democratization.

In the seminar as well as a conference session that went before it, the hesitation on the part of the United States and international community to give a helping hand to the democratic Taiwan squeezed by a rising China was a central concern.

Hao Pei-chih, a public administration scholar from National Taipei University, said Taiwan's people have a sense of frustration over the country's current situation, especially in comparison with South Korea, as the United States is still hesitant to negotiate a free trade agreement with Taiwan. She wanted to know why.

Yates said he personally feel that the United States at this point has "an attitude towards Taiwan, not a policy or strategy". He said that Chen's talk of both sides of Taiwan Straits as "one country on each side" caught Washington off guard when the top level of the U.S. government was in intensive discussion and debate over the plans to invade Iraq and China loomed as a very important factor to consider.

He said Chen's remark came to U.S. government as a sudden newspaper story rather than an advanced notice through diplomatic channels or a part of public debate ongoing for some time, and that irritated Bush.

Yates said Bush is hard to change his mind once he has had judgement for someone, and Chen was since labeled. He said similar incidents repeated again and again and that has some impact on the way the administration treats Taiwan. But Lo Chih-cheng, Chairman of the Department of Political Science of Soochow University, said sometimes "surprises" may be good. "If Taiwan's going to do something anyway because of some domestic forces," then it is better not to communicate with the U.S. to avoid embarrassment both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 16, or the 29th day of the second month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an inspection tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In honor of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925 at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
1999: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang is blasted by other DPP members for his recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.
1999: A field hospital donated by Taiwan opens at the Stenkovee refugee camp outside Skopje, Macedonia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that "maintaining peace and stability and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY TO U.S. ARRIVES IN WASHINGTON TO ASSUME POST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 15 (CNA) 04/16/07 13:17:40 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, arrived to a warm welcome in Washington, D.C. Sunday to assume his post.

Over 100 Taiwanese expatriates, along with Taiwan officials stationed in the United States and officials from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan, met Wu at the airport, welcoming the first Taiwan representative to the United States from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Overwhelmed by the warm welcome from the Taiwanese expatriates who came from all around the greater Washington and Baltimore areas to greet him, Wu said he will do his utmost during his stint in Washington to safeguard the interests of Taiwan and its people.

Wu said he is pleased to be the first DPP representative in the United States but stressed that he is representing Taiwan, the Republic of China, and its 23 million people and will handle U.S.-Taiwan relations based on the principle of protecting and promoting Taiwan's interests to the greatest degree.

On the issue of the DPP administration's seeking constitutional reform to facilitate a Taiwan name rectification plan, Wu said this is part of the progress that Taiwan must make in its democratization process, adding that he will keep the U.S. authorities informed of all relevant developments.

Wu said that topping his agenda in Washington will be enhancing communications with U.S. authorities over the ever-increasing political lobbying efforts by China on Capitol Hill, adding that he will try to bolster Taiwan's preparedness in this regard and also try to increase Taiwan's influence in the U.S. Congress.

Wu, who was Taiwan's top China policy planner before being assigned by President Chen Shui-bian to be the country's new representative in Washington, said that in the face of China's rapid military expansion and economic rise, Taiwan must be more aggressive and adopt pragmatic strategies to let the international community better understand Taiwan and its situation.

Wu said he believes that his background as Mainland Affairs Council head should make him more persuasive when it comes to dialogue with U.S. friends over issues concerning cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

As to Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) -- a longstanding goal that has yet to be realized due to China's obstruction, Wu said he will try his utmost to seek the United States' support and understanding, particularly regarding the unfair treatment that the Taiwan people have faced by being excluded from the world health regulatory body.
Wu noted that only the 23 million people of Taiwan are not represented in the WHO -- a fact that is "unarguably unjust for the Taiwan people."
Consequently, he said, relevant Taiwan officials must seek more pragmatic means to let the Taiwan people have access to the WHO and its activities on a more equal footing.

Meanwhile, AIT Managing Director Barbara Jane Schrage, who welcomed Wu in person upon his arrival at the airport, said the U.S. government welcomes Wu with open arms and believes that given his backround and experience, he will be a capable representative just like his predecessors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER LEADING IN OWN CAMP'S PUBLIC OPINION POLLS

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that public opinion polls conducted by his own camp show that he is ahead of other ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) hopefuls bidding to represent the party in the 2008 presidential election.

Hsieh said that he will not comment on public opinion polls conducted by the media which also showed that he is ahead but that polls conducted by his camp show he is leading the other three DPP presidential hopefuls, namely Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun.
"The public opinion polls go up and down, and as the leading contender, I'll deal with them with humility."
On other hopefuls' questions regarding the results of his camp's polls, Hsieh said that if they have any doubts, they can conduct their own public opinion polls.
Hsieh made the remarks during a visit to a center for physically and mentally challenged children in Taichung, central Taiwan.

According to the DPP's primary mechanism, a party member vote will be held in early May, with the results accounting for 30 percent of the hopefuls' final score, followed by a series of public opinion polls, whose results will account for 70 percent of the hopefuls' final score. The party's presidential candidate will be announced May 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AFFAIRS CHIEF IN WASHINGTON ON FTA PUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 15 (CNA) 04/16/07 15:19:04 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor affairs administrator, Lee Ying-yuan, arrived in Washington, D.C. Sunday to clarify and explain Taiwan's labor policy as part of efforts to pave the way for the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the two countries.

Speaking outside the airport upon his arrival in the U.S. capital, Lee, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said this is the first time that a Taiwan official in charge of labor affairs has come to Washington for talks on labor- related topics which are one of the United States' major concerns in gauging whether to sign an FTA with Taiwan.
Prior to Lee's visit, only officials in charge of economic and trade affairs had traveled to Washington for similar talks.

Lee said Taiwan has advanced regulations governing management and welfare services for both local and migrant workers employed in Taiwan and completed related legislation over the past several years, adding that Taiwan's Labor Standards Law now provides "lofty and adequate norms and standards" for treatment of wage earners.

Lee said that he attaches great importance to his visit in Washington during which he will exchange views with the Bush administration officials, think-tank specialists and members of the U.S. Congress. He added that the current members of the U.S. Congress have payed closer attention to labor affairs and environmental protection issues than their predecessors had.

During his visit, Lee is also expected to brief U.S. officials and think tank scholars on Taiwan's labor policy and its efforts to improve welfare benefits for both domestic wage earners and foreign laborers in the hopes of "clearing up any misconceptions or misunderstandings."

He added that an FTA between Taiwan and the United States will help shore up the volume of two-way trade between the two countries, which will in turn generate more job opportunities in the industrial sectors of the two sides.

Lee, who once served as Taiwan's deputy representative in the United States, would not disclose exactly which U.S. officials he is scheduled to meet with, only saying that all such meetings are being arranged by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington.

According to Lee's itinerary, he will deliver a speech Tuesday on upgrading Asian labor standards at the Center for National Policy, a U.S. think tank dedicated to research and debate on issues concerning U.S. national interests. He will also attend a seminar at the U.S. Heritage Foundation, another Washington-based think tank. Before wrapping up his trip Thursday, Lee will brief Taiwanese journalists posted in Washington, D.C. on the purposes and accomplishments of his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HONORARY CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR BEIJING

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan departed Taipei Monday for China, where he will attend an annual economic and trade forum in Beijing between the Communist Party of China (CPC) and the KMT.
Lien, who was instrumental in initiating a CPC-KMT economic and trade forum two years ago, will also meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao during his stay in Beijing.

Lien's 25-member mission, including Deputy Director of the KMT Policy Coordinating Committee Chang Jung-kung, who will serve as Lien's spokesman during the visit, will join a 70-odd group of Taiwan businessmen operating in China and a group of KMT legislators at the CPC-KMT economic and trade and cultural forum slated for April 28-29.
High on the agenda will be how to facilitate Chinese citizens' tourism trips to Taiwan.

In addition to the forum, Lien will attend a memorial service in Xinzheng, Henan Province, for Huang Ti, the Yellow Emperor who was the first ruler of China according to Chinese legend, as well as visiting Shanghai, Nanjing and Sichuan Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUST STORM FROM CHINA BEGINS AFFECTING AIR QUALITY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A dust storm from China began affecting Taiwan's air quality in the early hours of Monday, with the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) detecting a surging density of air particles in the areas north of Taoyuan, EPA officials said, warning that the air particle density is expected to reach its peak at around 5:00 p.m.

EPA technician Chang Shun-chin said the particle density at 10 a.m. was measured to be 133 micrograms per cubic meter on Kinmen Island, 85 micrograms per cubic meter in Wanli in Taipei County, northern Taiwan, and 69 micrograms per cubic meter on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei City, much higher than usual.

The particle density was usually at the level of around 40 micrograms per cubic meter in Wanli, and about 10 micrograms per cubic meter on Yangmingshan, Chang said. He forecast that the air particle density in Taipei City could reach as high as 250 micrograms per cubic meter Monday afternoon.

While the movement of a high atmospheric pressure system from China passing across Taiwan has been slowing down, the dust storm is expected to continue affecting the island's air quality until Wednesday morning, the EPA officials said, advising people to wear gauze masks when heading outdoors.
They also advised that the elderly and young people refrain from engaging in any outdoor activities over the next two days.
Updated reports on air quality are available on the EPA Web site at http://www.epa.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN SCIENCE PARK HEADS TO MEET IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: The Second Leaders Meeting and the 13th meeting of directors of the Asian Science Park Association (ASPA) will be held in Hsinchu Science Park, in northern Taiwan, April 19-21, officials of the science park administration said Monday.
The officials noted that the meeting is aimed at seeking trade opportunities among the various science parks around Asia by sharing experiences and extending cooperation projects.
The ASPA, initiated in 1997 by Takao Kubo, director of Kawasaki Industrial Promotion Foundation in Japan, currently groups more than 30 major science parks around Asia.

At this year's ASPA Leaders Meeting, Taiwan's National Science Council Chairman Chen Chien-jen will be invited to give a lecture at the opening ceremony, while representatives of Japan's Kanagawa Science Park, Daegu Technopark in Korea, Taiwan's Hsinchu Science Park and the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), as well as other major science parks in Asia will discuss various topics, including cooperation among the science parks, technological innovation and commercialization within the parks, and regional economic development.

During the meeting, Hsinchu Science Park will also sign a memorandum of cooperation with ASPA to strengthen cooperation, including technology transfer, and seek trade opportunities among companies in these science parks.

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but ended lower Monday due to profit-taking pressure, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 1.58 points to close at 8,043.54.

The bourse opened at 8,088.83 and fluctuated between 8,096.84 and 8,030.5 during the day's trading. A total of 4.5 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$112.46 billion (US$3.41 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement issues moving up the most at 4.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp, and plastic and chemical shares both at 1.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, textile stocks at 0.2 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Machinery and electronic shares moved down 0.7 percent, while construction stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 704 to 466, with 157 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER BRUSHES ASIDE ELECTION TICKET RUMOR

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng brushed aside Monday speculation that he has agreed to form a presidential ticket with former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chief Ma Ying-jeou for the 2008 presidential election, saying that a final settlement is still far way off.

Wang, also a member of the main opposition KMT, made the comments at the Legislative Yuan while answering questions from reporters. His remarks came after Ma said a day earlier that a KMT presidential ticket has been in place following a March 7 meeting during which he and Wang agreed to invite each other to team up on a ticket if either is nominated by the party as presidential candidate.
According to Ma, Chan Chun-po, manager of his presidential campaign, paid a visit to Wang on his behalf last week and reiterated his position to the legislative speaker.
In response to Ma's claim that a KMT presidential ticket of himself and Wang has taken shape, Wang said the issue has not been settled and that he would not touch on the issue in the coming months.
"There is no fixed format regarding the KMT ticket in the 2008 presidential race, " Wang said, while denying that he discussed the issue with Chan.

The formation of a ticket between Ma and Wang is expected by KMT supporters who are gravely concerned that a split would boost the chances of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the next presidential contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION GAMBITS TO INCREASE PRIOR TO DPP PRIMARY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday that election gambits will increase in the run-up to the presidential primary of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in May, but that he is sure voters will make their own judgments.

The premier made the remarks following a local cable television report last Friday that another presidential hopeful, former Premier Frank Hsieh, is leading in test public opinion polls conducted by the "pan-green camp" led by the DPP.

In an interview with a local radio station, Su said that all kinds of election gambits will come out before the party's primary with the intention of undermining rivals and strengthening the candidates' own camps.
The media also has its own stance, which is evident to discerning eyes, Su added.

Su said that he has experience about the unreliability of public opinion polls, noting that he won the election for Taipei county magistrate in 1997, despite public opinion polls showing that he was lagging behind by more than 10 percent.
He noted that he has insisted on not verbally attacking other rivals and said the voters will make their decisions based on the character and style of each presidential hopeful.

DPP sources said a recent spat over who is leading among the DPP presidential hopefuls, who include Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh, is aimed at swaying DPP members, hoping that they will eventually cast their votes for the leading contender, even though DPP member votes only account for 30 percent of the hopeful's final score, while a series of public opinion polls will account for 70 percent.
The DPP will announce its candidate May 30.

Su also took the opportunity to defend himself over recent controversy surrounding a planned demolition of the Losheng Sanitarium in Taipei County and the planned construction of a freeway linking Suao and Hualien.
He said his new goal is to preserve 90 percent of the leprosarium and not to postpone a scheduled opening of a mass rapid transit line through the complex.

On criticism of this policy flip-flop, Su noted that the route of a MRT line passing through the leprosarium was planned in 1994 during the previous Kuomintang administration, and that he only held the office of Taipei county magistrate until December 1997. Su ruled in December 2002 that the leprosarium would not be designated a historical site and last month rejected a suggestion by the Council for Cultural Affairs that 90 percent of the complex be preserved.
Su said that both Yu and Hsieh clearly stated during their stints as premier that the matter should be left for coordination between Taipei city and county.
"There is no need to point fingers at others," Su said, adding that as a premier, he has to tackle the problem.

He also claimed that major construction projects and environmental protection cannot co-exist. President Chen Shui-bian first floated the idea of a freeway linking Suao and Hualien when he was campaigning for president, Su said, adding that Yu suspended the construction project because of disputes over its impact on the environment. His predecessor Hsieh did not retract the project, although he proposed an alternative project, Su continued.
He said that as long as the project passes an environmental impact assessment, it will be continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIHLIN DISTRICT SEEKS TO JOIN ASIA-PACIFIC HEALTHY CITIES ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Shihlin District in northern Taipei City has geared up to apply to join the Asia-Pacific Alliance for Healthy Cities under the framework of the World Health Organization, a Taipei city government official said Monday.

A Shihlin Healthy Cities Alliance Bid Promotion Association was established Monday by 80 individuals and organizations from the district to help push for inclusion in the regional healthy cities alliance, said Teng Su-wen, deputy director of the city's Department of Health.
The establishment of the association is aimed at building partnerships and civil participation among the alliance members, Teng said.

She continued that the formation of the alliance was aimed at improving the quality of life in urban communities. It was also aimed at reaffirming that health is a fundamental right and that the attainment of the highest possible level of health requires action by many sectors and that recognizing urbanization as a worldwide phenomenon, she added.
Teng added that the association is scheduled to file an application with the Asia-Pacific Alliance for Healthy Cities in June.

She said that the Shihlin District -- which has the top ratio of "green land" accessibility and availability to district residents among all Taipei districts -- is blessed with the world-renowned National Palace Museum, Yangmingshan National Park, the Zhishanyan Prehistoric Site, the former presidential residence and a large number of trails for hiking -- only a few of many other worthy factors that make the district seen as a great place to live.

The Taipei city government will help push for the district's membership of the alliance along with that of the Beitou District this year, while seeking membership of the Songshan, Zhongshan and Wanhua districts next year, Teng said.
She added that Da-an last year became the first Taipei district to be admitted into the alliance, which currently has 62 member cities from over 10 countries and areas in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL CALLS FOR JAPAN'S COOPERATION IN FACING UP TO CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/07 18:40:19 (By Mike Chang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Japan should cooperate with Taiwan to face up to threat from China, a Taiwan official said in an article carried in Monday's Sankei Shimbun newspaper.
Tung Chen-yuan, vice chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council warned in the article that China was eyeing Japan when it fired a missile to destroy a defunct orbiting satellite Jan. 11.

Tung noted that the missile was fired one day after Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked the European Union not to lift its boycott on arms sales to China and two days after Tokyo upgraded its Defense Agency to a Cabinet-level ministry.

China, which has already deployed more than 1,000 missiles aimed at Taiwan, continues building up its military force rapidly, showing that Beijing is aiming at countries other than Taiwan, according to Tung.
Tung said he is surprised that Tokyo is worried about the threat posed by North Korea while ignoring the more serious threat posed by Beijing.
Tung said Tokyo should cooperate with Taipei to cope with both North Korea and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIREFLY CONSERVATION SPOT IN NANTOU TO UNDERGO TOURIST CONTROL

TEXT.P: With the firefly breeding season about to enter full swing, sightseeing visits to Lienhuache, a popular firefly conservation spot in Yuche township of Nantou County, central Taiwan, will be restricted from late April as part of efforts to protect the insects from human disturbance, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute (TFRI) officials said Monday.

Lienhuache, surrounded by wetlands and old agricultural land where farming activity has not been carried out for many years, is listed as a national treasure because of its abundant and various natural resources. Over the years, the TFRI has worked with local people to revive creeks and forests around Lienhuache, an effort that has proved successful, as the number of lightening bugs has been growing there, TFRI official Wu Chun-hsiung said.

Attracted by the glowworms, more and more tourists are visiting the Lienhuache area during the insect's breeding season in April and May, Wu said, adding that to protect them from human disturbance, the Lienhuache creek conservation association has since last year taken measures to restrict tourist visits to Lienhuache during the "Firefly Festival."
In 2006, more than 10,000 tourists visited Lienhuache to capture the beauty of a night lit by the insect, which only lives in clean natural environments, according to the TFRI.

Wu said those who want to drive to Lienhuache must park in Yuche's Wutsun village, where the association provides services for firefly visitors, including lectures on the bug's life and how to visit the insects without disturbing them.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO PUSH FOR COMBINING NATIONAL REFERENDUM, PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will push for holding a national referendum in tandem with the 2008 presidential election, DPP acting Chairman Trong Chai said Monday.

Chai said that holding a national referendum on such issues as retrieving the ill-gotten assets of the main opposition Kuomintang and joining the United Nations under the name of Taiwan simultaneously with the presidential election will save money and raise the turnout rate for a national referendum.
Other democratic countries such as the United States have adopted such an approach, he said.
KMT spokesman Su Chun-ping dismissed the DPP suggestion as an election gambit and said: "We despise their intention."

KMT Legislator and Policy Committee Executive Director Tseng Yung-chuan said that the Organic Law of the Central Election Commission (CEC) is yet to be passed in the legislature, but the CEC will be able to decide on whether to combine the elections in line with the wishes of the DPP administration, which he said will not conform to "election justice."

Meanwhile, DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung said that President Chen Shui- bian discussed the issue with officials last year and reached a consensus on holding legislative elections and the presidential election in the same year, claiming that doing so would not involve revising the law and would only require an Executive Yuan decision.
If the two elections could be combined with a national referendum, it would be even better, Lin said. But it remains uncertain whether the next legislative and presidential elections can be combined.

The DPP has launched a drive to retrieve the ill-gotten assets of the KMT through a national referendum and has set July as the deadline for collecting 1 million signatures to put it to a national referendum.

In addition, the DPP Central Standing Committee approved a petition proposal to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan through a referendum, and the party has set May 20 to complete the first-stage of collecting 100,000 signatures to make the proposal valid.

President Chen has echoed a call by a nuclear-free promotion group to revise the referendum law to lower the threshold of signatures needed to put an issue to national referendum. The Executive Yuan also discussed the issue in a coordination meeting with the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR MEETS WITH CITY OFFICIALS FROM MARSHALL ISLANDS

TEXT.P: A delegation headed by Mayor Johnny D. Lemari of Kwajalein City of the Marshall Islands visited Taichung Mayor Jason Hu at the latter's office Monday.
Hu extended a warm welcome to the six-member delegation before beginning talks with the visitors on various issues in the fields of trade, economics, culture and education.

After the meeting, Hu said he will encourage local businesses to learn more about the Marshall Islands to facilitate mutual cooperation. He also said that he was very touched that Lemari presented a necklace of shells as a gift to his wife on behalf of former Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua.

Lemari told Hu that he believes it would be wise to investment in the development of solar energy in Kwajalein, where daylight lasts more than 12 hours. He also expressed his hope for the two sister cities will cooperate in the development of the bicycle industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNMANNED CONVENIENCE STORES IN TAIWAN ATTRACT JAPANESE BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: With the handsome profits earned by Taiwan's several unmanned convenience stores, dubbed "Q-Shops, " many enterprises plan to follow suit, including several based in Japan, trade sources said Monday.

Taiwan's first two Q-Shops were set up by the OK convenience chain store last November under a promotion program for intelligent stores presented by the Commerce Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Customers can buy groceries, snacks and drinks from vending machines at the unmanned Q-Shops, using cash or credit cards. Clients can talk to clerks or security guards via intercom at each vending machine if they have any problems with the machines.

According to the statistics, more than 35,000 people made purchases at the two Q-Shops for total transactions of NT$580,000 (US$17,575) since their opening Nov. 28 last year. Only 5 percent of the customers used credit cards.

Yang Hui-wen, a section chief of the Innovative Digitech-Enabled Applications and Services Institute (IDEAS) under the Institute for Information Industry, which offers software assistance to the project, noted that with the unmanned convenience stores reducing significantly their costs in personnel and rent, the Q-Shops had good profit margins, although the transactions were small.

In addition to food, beverages and groceries, the OK group will introduce digital photo printing in order to diversify their operations later this year, said Chang Hung-hao, general manager of the OK group.
Other enterprises, including gas stations, highway rest stations, companies in science parks and some Japanese firms have shown strong interest in following in the OK group's footsteps.

Wang Poh-po, director-general of the MOEA's Commerce Department, said the government might consider authorizing the Q-Shops to offer more services in the future, including handling household registration application.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA SAYS IT HAS CLEARED DIOXIN CONTAMINATION SOURCE IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has prevented dioxin pollution from a defunct chemical factory in Tainan from affecting human health since 2003, an EPA official claimed Monday.

Huang Wan-chu, executive secretary of an EPA committee in charge of a fund for the remediation of polluted soil, made the remarks in response to a report by the Chinese-language China Times that residents living near the site of the closed chemical factory in the southern city have extremely high levels of dioxin in their blood.

A study conducted by National Cheng Kung University at the request of the Tainan city government tested the blood samples of 570 residents living in Tainan's An- nan district, where the chemical factory operated between 1942 and 1982.
The results of the study show that 72 percent of them have much higher levels of dioxin in their blood than the tolerance limit set by the United Nations.
Dioxins are known carcinogens which can cause birth defects, diabetes, immune system abnormalities and many other adverse health effects if they accumulate in the body in large amounts.

Huang pointed out that the EPA has used more than NT$110 million since 2003 to remove contamination sources and monitor soil conditions and water quality in fish ponds around the former site of the now defunct Anshun factory of Taiwan Alkali Industrial Corp.
He also said that in July 2005, the Ministry of Economic Affairs agreed to set aside NT$1.3 billion over five years to help the affected residents.
Huang said the high dioxin levels in the blood of residents near the closed factory was due to the accumulation of toxins over a long period.

The factory in question, which was set up by the Japanese in 1942 to produce hydrochloric acid, caustic soda, and liquid chlorine, became a state-owned company the year after Japan's surrender in 1945.

Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), another state-owned enterprise, bought all the shares of Taiwan Alkali in 1967. The factory was merged in 1983 with CPC's subsidiary, China Petrochemical Development Corp., which went private in 1994.
For decades, residents living around the factory grew farm produce and raised fish in ponds without any knowledge of the pollution hazard.

Recently declassified government documents show that the Ministry of Economic Affairs became aware in 1982 that mercury concentrations in the fish catch from the area exceeded safe levels for human consumption.

Many seriously ill residents have been seeking state compensation on grounds that the factory was owned by the government. They have also complained that the monthly allowance of some NT$1,800 per person from a state fund is too meager to pay for their medical bills and other expenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER REAFFIRMS INTENTION TO VISIT CHINA

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that he will lead a delegation to China "when the time is ripe."
Wang made the remarks in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, where he attended an economic forum amid reports that he will visit China later this month.

He said he has worked for more than a year on China travel plan and that there are a lot of issues to discuss, including direct trade, postal and transport links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan agricultural exports to China and Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan.

Asked whether he will visit China in his capacity as the speaker of the legislature, Wang said that China will probably have reservations about that, although the two sides will coordinate on the most suitable title under which he will be allowed entry.
In addition to visiting Beijing and Shanghai, Wang said he will also visit Xiamen in Fujian Province for the first time to pay his respects at the tomb of his ancestors and visit relatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU GROUP EMBARKS ON CHINA VISIT VIA KINMEN

TEXT.P: A 130-member group from the offshore Penghu County took a maiden charter flight Monday to the outlying Kinmen Island, where they boarded a ferry heading for China's Fujian Province for a four-day visit.

It was the first Penghu delegation to travel to China via the so-called "mini three links" -- direct shipping and trade services between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and Fujian ports of Xiamen, Quanzhou and Mawei that lie opposite on the other side of the Taiwan Strait -- after the central government in Taipei announced April 1 the inclusion of Penghu in the "mini links" program.

The group, composed of Penghu county government officials, councilors and representatives from the local tourism sector, plans to sponsor three rounds of presentations to sell Penghu to locals in Xiamen, Fuzhou and Quanzhou.

Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng saw them off from Shuitou Port and hailed Penghu's inclusion in the "mini links" as mutually beneficial for both Kinmen and Penghu. Lee said that he plans to organize a seminar with the Matsu and Penghu authorities to explore the maximum benefit of the "mini links" for the three outlying islands.

Legislator Lin Ping-kun, who led the delegation, voiced his keen desire for allowing direct weekend cross-strait charter flights from Penghu, making its Makung airport a key hub like the Taoyuan and Kaohsiung international airports that already serve direct charter flights to China on special holidays.
Penghu County Council Speaker Liu Chen Chao-ling called the "mini links via Kinmen" the fastest route for Penghu residents bound for China.

She expressed the hope that direct charter flight services between Makung and Kinmen, which officially kicked off that same day, could be offered on a regular basis in the short term to help attract Chinese tourists to the island and improve the local economy.
Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa also witnessed the ceremony to kick off the maiden Penghu-Kinmen charter flight, operated by UNI Airways, at Makung airport.
Wang called for wider opening by the central government for Penghu in cross- strait exchanges and described Penghu's inclusion in the "mini links," set up in January 2001, as a step forward.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIGHT POLICY AND ENVOY WILL BOOST TAIWAN-U.S. TIES: EX-OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The right policies, represented by an envoy able to communicate effectively with the United States, will "be a boost to Taiwan-U.S. relations," a former Taiwan representative to the United States said Monday.
Chen Chien-jen, who served as the nation's top representative to Washington 2000-2004, made the remarks at a public hearing in the legislature.

Chen noted that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is confident that the new representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, will convey the government's stance and policies faithfully to the U.S., thus mitigating bilateral misunderstanding, which he thinks is a good thing.
He also said that whether the new appointment will provide a boost to Taiwan-U.S. relations hinges on whether the policy is right.

The right policy, coupled with an appropriate envoy, will be a boon, but if it deviates from the right policy, and an envoy cannot faithfully convey the government's stance and policies, relations will suffer.
'Deciding whether the policy is right or wrong will require public examination," he added.
Chen's words came as Wu, former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, arrived at the Washington D.C. Monday to assume his new post.

Wu said that he was glad to be the first DPP member to serve as Taiwan's envoy in the United States, but he stressed that he will represent the country and not serve a particular political party, vowing to keep Taiwan's best interests in mind while dealing with Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Chen, a career diplomat, concurrently served as the representative to the European Union and Belgium from 2004 until his retirement last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Nothing to Hide, Attorney General Insists
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales offered a measured apology for his mistakes in the dismissal of eight United States attorneys, but said in testimony prepared for a Senate hearing on Tuesday that he had nothing to hide and that none of the prosecutors were removed to influence the outcome of a case.
In his testimony, which was released Sunday by the Justice Department, Mr. Gonzales provided an account of his actions that was largely consistent with his past assertions that his role was very limited and his recollection fragmentary.
Wall Street Journal:Questions on Efficacy Cloud a Cancer Vaccine
When Merck & Co. introduced its new vaccine against cervical cancer last June, it gave it one of the biggest pushes any new medicine has received. The company lobbied dozens of states to make the vaccine mandatory for 11- and 12 -year-old girls. It aired TV ads featuring young girls skipping rope while reciting the slogan, "I want to be one less" woman to battle the disease.
The campaign scored some big victories. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention declared all women age 11 to 26 should get the vaccine, called Gardasil. Texas and Virginia passed mandatory -vaccination laws for girls entering the sixth grade. Even after Merck halted its lobbying in February amid criticism, an organization backed by the company continues to push for similar laws, and about 20 states are considering them. The vaccine costs $360 for a three-shot regimen.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Clinton's Campaign Has Most In Bank. Obama Raised More for Primary, Reports Show.
Sen. Barack Obama raised more money than Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton for their Democratic primary clash during the first three months of the year, but Clinton heads into spring with more in her campaign account than all Republican presidential candidates combined.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM MANAGEMENT DEFENDS CHAIRMAN'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: The management of the partially state-owned Chunghwa Telecom Co. issued a written statement Monday in an attempt to push back against an online campaign launched by the company's labor union to bring a no-confidence vote against company Chairman Ho Chen-tan.

In the statement, Chunghwa Telecom management criticized the campaign as a "politically-charged" attempt by the union to mislead non-unionized company employees and stock buyers, as well as the public into believing that management has treated its workers poorly.

The statement also defended Ho's management, arguing that since Ho took office four years ago he has spared no efforts in guiding the company through the challenges posed by privatization and structural reforms. The chairman has also worked to boost the company's post-tax profits above the NT$4 per share level, the statement explained.
Since the company's chairmanship is elected by board members, the management will not approve the labor union's attempt to overthrow the current chairman through a vote of non-confidence.
The Chunghwa Telecom Workers' Union has been protesting against management's efforts to streamline the company by planning to lay off 1,600 workers in the coming years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL WARNING CAUSES TROPICAL FRUIT TO HIT TAIWAN MARKET EARLY

TEXT.P: Global warming does not seem to be treating the people of Taiwan all that badly because a variety of tropical fruits that usually come into season between June and August have this year been ripening since March.

Huang Mei-hua, a section chief in charge of crop production at the Agricultural and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, told reporters Monday that the period from March to May is usually a season of scarce fruit supplies in Taiwan.
She explained, however, that as a result of global warming, various tropical fruits are ripening earlier than normal climate conditions would allow.
Huang noted that papayas, bananas, pineapples and mangoes have been in abundant supply since March, and that another favored tropical fruit, lychee, will begin to hit the market in May.

One good thing about the abundant fruit supply is that although consumers have a great variety to choose from, the prices have remained stable and created handsome profits for fruit farmers, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA TO ATTEND 2ND COURT HEARING ON CORRUPTION CHARGES

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, former chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , will attend a second court hearing on corruption charges Tuesday at the Taipei District Court, Ma's aides said Monday.

According to the aides, Ma's Monday schedule was unaffected by Tuesday's trial, and he was not so nervous this time compared with April 3 when the trial was opened for the first time. Tuesday's court hearing will be opened to the public.

Ma met KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan last week and Lien was relieved to learn of Ma's current situation concerning the lawsuit against him, the aides said, adding that in recent days Ma also discussed with lawyers adopting a strategy with which to better defend himself during the coming trial.

Ma was charged by Taipei prosecutors in mid-February over his alleged embezzlement of NT$11 million from a special municipal monthly allowance designated for his discretionary use during his two terms as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

Ma's ongoing trial on embezzlement charges has cast shadow over his chances of representing the KMT in the 2008 presidential election, as the party's rules presently ban members convicted in the first trial from taking part in any elections.
Despite the embezzlement charges, Ma still picked up earlier this month a registration form for the KMT's presidential primary in a display of his resolve to pursue his presidential bid.

On the other side, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, also a KMT member who harbors a strong presidential ambition, failed to collect the form, provoking grave concern among KMT supporters that Wang might split and run in the next presidential election as an independent instead of pairing up with Ma.

Due to mounting uncertainties about Ma's fate, KMT members of the Kaohsiung County branch suggested Monday that the party prepare two presidential tickets so that it can better cope with the situation in case Ma is unable to take part in the next presidential race.

The KMT will have to mediate between the two tickets if Ma is able to ride out the difficulties lying ahead, they suggested, pointing out that the KMT could field Wang to run in the coming presidential election if Ma is unable to stand for the party.
Wang, who attended an economic seminar with the KMT members in Kaohsiung County Monday, declined to comment the proposal.

According to Wang, Taiwan's people are looking forward to a second transfer of power in 2008, and he urged the KMT to take full precautions against all possible scenarios in the run-up to the next presidential contest.

In response to a rumored presidential ticket with Ma, Wang told reporters earlier the same day in Taipei that such a format "still has a long way to go " and refused to touch on the issue again in the coming months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN DIALYSIS PATIENTS VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A group of Singaporean dialysis patients and their families have arrived in Taiwan to receive treatment and travel in the country, the group's organizer said Monday.
The visit is part of a cooperation agreement between Jen Chi hospital in the capital of Taipei and the Singapore-based Asia Renal Care (ARC) company, a spokesman for the hospital said.
The company has established a blood dialysis center at the hospital, the spokesman noted.

The hospital received the investment partly because of its location in the vicinity of a famous night market in the city, the spokesman claimed, adding that the patient's family members can tour the market during the four-hour wait.
The 19-member group -- seven of whom are patients -- arrived in Taiwan April 14, the spokesman said, adding that the patients were scheduled to check into the hospital earlier in the day.
Saying that Taiwan enjoys some of the highest medical standards in Asia, the spokesman described local medical services as inexpensive and able to attract foreign medical tourism investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO HOPEFULS UNVEIL POLL RESULTS AMID CONTROVERSY

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential hopefuls Monday unveiled the results of polls conducted by their two respective camps, with each claiming greater popularity than the other.

According to the electoral campaign office of former premier Frank Hsieh, two public opinion polls excluding opposition pan-blue camp supporters showed that his popularity exceeding that of Premier Su Tseng-chang, another presidential hopeful. In a Hsieh-camp-conducted poll, which excluded pan-blue supporters, Hsieh led by 9 percent, while his edge over Su reached 23 percent in a "pan- green" supporters-only poll.
The results of a poll released by Su's campaign office showed that Su's popularity slightly outstripped Hsieh's by 0.1 percentage point.
Hsieh and Su find themselves in a toss in terms of poll ratings in the DPP primary, which also includes Vice President Annette Lu and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi- kun.

According to the DPP primary system, popularity among general voters will account for 70 percent of one hopeful's chance in winning party nomination for the presidential election, while the voting results by party members will account for the other 30 percent of the candidate's final score.
Wu Ping-jui, a DPP legislator with close ties to Su, blasted Hsieh's group for what he described as unbearable degree of opinion poll and media manipulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE MAN TO BE PROSECUTED FOR SEXUAL HARASSMENT

TEXT.P: Aviation police at Taoyuan International Airport detained a Japanese man Monday for sexually harassing an airline stewardess on a Cathay Pacific Airways flight from Japan.

A spokesman for the Aviation Police Office under the National Police Agency confirmed that police at the airport have taken the Japanese visitor into custody and will file a charge against him for violation of the Sexual Harassment Prevention Act.
According to the spokesman, the unnamed individual is a mechanical engineer who frequently travels to Taiwan from Japan to do maintenance work.

The man already seemed intoxicated when he asked for another alcoholic drink from a Philippine stewardess and, against her will, fondled her chest and abdomen while the airplane was taxiing on a runway at Taoyuan International Airport.
The stewardess insisted on pressing charges against him, while her colleague -- a Japanese stewardess -- was willing to bear witness to the incident.
According to Article 25 of the Sexual Harassment Prevention Act of 2005, the Japanese offender could face a prison term of up to two years, plus a fine of up to NT$100,000 (US$3,010).

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD COMES UP WITH NT$33.4 B. DEVELOPMENT PLAN FOR 3 PORTS

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has come up with a pump-priming plan aimed at accelerating the development of three of the country's major sea ports.

According to the plan approved by all of the CEPD commissioners at a meeting Monday, the government and the private sector will invest up to NT$33.4 billion (US$1.01 billion) over the next four years to boost the development of three northern and northeastern ports -- Keelung Harbor, Taipei Harbor and Suao Harbor.

The stimulus plan also covers the development of a two-kilometer-long, 250-meter-wide waterway at Taipei Harbor for yachting and other maritime recreational activities as part of the government's efforts to turn the nearby region into a tourism and leisure hub, CEPD officials said.

The plan calls for an outlay of NT$5.98 billion from the national treasury and NT$3.63 billion from the private sector for the Keelung Harbor development, which will include construction of a new highway linking the port to other cities and the extension of a coastal embankment.
For the Taipei Harbor development, a total outlay of NT$23.07 billion will be needed for land reclamation as well as embankment and infrastructure construction.

As to the development of Suao Harbor in the northeastern county of Yilan, it will require an estimated NT$788 million, with the government contributing about NT$258 million and the remaining invested by provate and state-owned enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 17, or the first day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through a dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist, and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves initial military aid US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with The Congo.
1968: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging U.S. protection for noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: East Pakistanis declare their homeland an independent nation which they rename Bangladesh. Sheik Mujibur Rahman serves as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military levels in Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
1999: An ROC humanitarian relief delegation returns to Taipei after a visit to Macedonia to express concern and offer assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
2000: The Year 2000 Trend Setting & Technology Conference is held in Taipei with more than 100 experts and industrialists from home and abroad participating.
2000: The Republic of China Finance Ministry allows two local insurance companies to set up offices in mainland China, marking the first mainland foray for the island's insurance industry.
2001: The Taipei Bank is chosen over four other hopefuls by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to issue both traditional and computerized charity lotteries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

For the Taipei Harbor development, a total outlay of NT$23.07 billion will be needed for land reclamation as well as embankment and infrastructure construction.

As to the development of Suao Harbor in the northeastern county of Yilan, it will require an estimated NT$788 million, with the government contributing about NT$258 million and the remaining invested by provate and state-owned enterprises.
