DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO INITIATE REFERENDUM LAW AMENDMENTS TO LOWER LEGAL THRESHOLDS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will initiate draft amendments to the Referendum Law aimed at lowering the legal thresholds for holding a popular vote on issues of national concern, a party whip said Tuesday.

Ker Chien-ming, the DPP legislative caucus convener, made the remarks a day after the caucus and the Executive Yuan reached a consensus on the steps to realize the goal of overhauling the Referendum Law.
According to Ker, the DPP legislative caucus will discuss how the legal thresholds should be adjusted in the coming few days and come up with a final package of draft amendments by April 23.
The package will then be referred to the legislative floor for deliberation and approval. "Hopefully, the package can be assigned to a relevant standing committee to screen by April 27," Ker added.
Noting that the existing legal thresholds for holding a national referendum are prohibitively high, Ker said critical revisions are needed to make the law relevant and viable.
Besides lowering the legal thresholds, Ker said the mandatory referendum review committee should also be abolished.

The current law stipulates that the signatures of at least 0.5 percent of eligible voters in the last presidential election are needed for a referendum proposal to be initiated. After passing the threshold, the signatures of 5 percent of the eligible voters must be collected within six months for a referendum to be held. Moreover, half of the total number of eligible voters must cast ballots for the referendum result to be declared valid.

An anti-nuclear group known as the Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association, led by former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, has proposed that the legal threshold for making the petition for a referendum valid be lowered to 100 eligible voters and that the number of signatures needed to be collected to put the proposal to a referendum be cut to 1.5 percent of eligible voters.

In response, Ker said the 100 signatures-threshold for proposing a referendum is too low. "Should that be adopted, I'm afraid there could be an astronomical list of topics to be put to a popular vote," he cautioned.
Ker said the DPP legislative caucus will make a thorough review before drawing up new legal thresholds.

President Chen Shui-bian said last week that he has given his full support to the ongoing campaign relaunched by the Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association to push for an overhaul of the Referendum Law.

Stressing that referendums are a manifestation of the universal value of democracy and the fundamental exercise of human rights, Chen said the current Referendum Law virtually deprives local people of their democratic rights and should therefore be revised to live up to its promise. He urged the Legislative Yuan to amend the law and get rid of all unreasonable stipulations by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET SUPPORTS HOLDING PRESIDENTIAL, LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS TOGETHER

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan supports the proposal of having the next legislative and presidential elections held simultaneously, Cabinet spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling said Tuesday.

Chen made the remarks after Lin Chia-lung, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said a day earlier that the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the DPP share a consensus that the next presidential and legislative elections as well as referendums on some major issues of national concern should be held at the same time "to save financial and social costs."
Echoing Lin's statement, Chen said Taiwan will indeed be better off if it manages to merge some elections to save costs. "We really have too many elections," she noted.
As to when the next presidential and legislative elections will be held, Chen said it is up to the Central Election Commission (CEC) to determine.
Under the current law, the election day for the next legislature must be set six months before the term of the present legislature expires Jan. 31, 2008.

"This means that we can wait until July to work out a schedule for the next legislative elections, " Chen said, adding that as the term of current CEC commissioners will expire June 16, it should be the job of the new CEC commissioners to choose a date for the next legislative elections.

As for DPP acting Chairman Trong Chai's proposal that referendums on the main opposition Kuomintang's "ill-gotten" party assets and the issue of whether the country should apply for U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan" ought to be held alongside the next presidential election, Chen said it all depends on whether enough signatures of eligible voters in support of the proposed referendums can be collected in time.
Meanwhile, CEC spokesman Teng Tien-you said the Executive Yuan's opinion about the schedule of the two upcoming elections can be conveyed to the CEC commissioners for reference.

While the administration and the DPP authority support the idea of holding the next presidential and legislative elections simultaneously, Teng said, the CEC should also respect the opinions of other sectors of society.
"Therefore, it will be left for the new Central Election Commission to be formed in mid-June to decide whether the two elections will be held on the same day," Teng explained.
The president's term will expire May 20, 2008, and the presidential election usually takes place in March of the election year.

DOC.HEADLINE: STARTING SALARIES FOR GRADS WITH MASTER'S DEGREES AVERAGE NT$31,567

TEXT.P: Starting salaries for graduates with master's or doctoral degrees averaged NT$31,567 (US$957) per month last year, up NT$1,363 from the previous year, according to a salary survey on 2006 graduates conducted by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

The results of the survey published Tuesday show that graduates with higher degrees received higher starting salaries. Starting salaries for 2006 graduates with bachelor's degrees averaged NT$26,700, up NT$634 from the figure for the previous year.

In comparison, starting salaries for senior high school or vocational school graduates averaged NT$20,866, up NT$300 over the previous year, while starting salaries for junior high school graduates averaged NT$19,364, also up NT$300.

By trade, graduates working in harbor-related businesses received the highest starting salaries, averaging NT$47,271, followed by those in working for water companies, averaging NT$35,940, those employed by tobacco companies, at NT$34,999, those working for railway or mass rapid transit systems, at NT$33,259, and those working for energy or mining companies, at NT$31,415. Most of the companies are state-owned enterprises.
Graduates received an average starting salary at NT$18,680 at barber shops or beauty parlors, NT$19,713 at bus companies, NT$20,103 at restaurants and NT$20,190 at wood product manufacturing plants.

Officials from the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics said that the number of graduates with master's or doctoral degrees was more than 48,000 in 2006, or three times that of a decade ago, although the average starting salary for them was only about NT$5,000 more than the average starting salary for those with bachelor's degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 84.25 points to close at 7,959.29.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,100.61 and closed at the day's low of 7,952.18. A total of 5.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$132.08 billion (US$3.98 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues and paper and pulp issues both moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares and textile stocks both at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.9 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.
Banking and financial shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,023 to 189, with 131 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CO2 EMISSIONS IN TRANSPORTATION SECTOR DROP IN 2006

TEXT.P: Emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the transportation sector fell by 160,000 tons in 2006 in Taiwan compared with the previous year, according to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , which Tuesday attributed the result to a series of transportation related energy-saving measures.

In keeping with the Kyoto Protocol, an agreement arrived at under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change as part of the world's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions that came into force Feb. 16, 2005, the MOTC began an energy-saving drive targeting vehicles.

As a result of the drive, 39 action plans were brought forward in 2005 to address three goals -- developing "green" transportation systems, slowing the rise in the number and use of motor vehicles, and improving the efficiency of transportation systems, the MOTC said.

For example, to encourage public transportation service operators to introduce low-pollution automobiles, the MOTC provided businesses using environmental- friendly motor vehicles with extra points in their applications for the right to offer commercial transportation services on certain roads, such as the Taipei- Yilan Expressway.

The MOTC Institute of Transportation has also worked to establish a Web site on which to publicize ideas touching on "green transportation" in the hope that more and more people will choose to travel via mass transportation systems, bicycle, or on foot.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP SAYS FEMALE PRESIDENCY SIGN OF PROGRESS FOR TAIWANESE WOMEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday that it would be an achievement and sign of progress for all Taiwanese women if Taiwan's next president were a woman.
Lu made the remarks at the Presidential Office when she received members of a leadership program for outstanding Taiwanese female entrepreneurs living overseas.

A female presidency in Taiwan would eradicate unfair treatment women face in society, Lu said, adding that Taiwan's "time of women" has come, as many high- profile organizations have chairwomen instead of chairmen, including the Taipei 101, Taiwan High Speed Rail, and the Grand Hotel.

Lu noted that Taiwanese women's rights and interests ranked the 19th among 193 countries, and first among Asian countries, in an evaluative report issued by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

Lu said the report shows that Taiwanese women's efforts in economic development have won recognition in the world, and that Taiwan is ready to have a female president after 11 male presidential tenures.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCTU TO LAUNCH INTERNATIONAL GRADUATE PROGRAM ON INDUSTRIAL R&D

TEXT.P: National Chiao-tung University (NCTU) is set to launch an international graduate program on industrial research and development this autumn to train foreign talent for local high-technology companies, sources at the Hsinchu-based university said Tuesday.

Graduate students will be granted with full scholarships from sponsor companies after admission into the program and will be offered posts in sponsors' branch offices in other countries after graduation, according to Wu Chung-yu, president of the university.

Wu said that leading players in the high-tech industry, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., United Microelectronics Corp., and D-Link Corp., have already decided to participate in the program.

The program will begin in September, with an initial enrollment of 50 students, Wu said, adding that the university expects to train some 400 master's and doctoral degree holders under the program over the next four years.
NCTU already provides some 100 courses taught in English, Wu said, adding that the number is expected to increase over the next several years.
While explaining the need for such a program, Wu noted that Taiwan's birthrate has been declining in recent decades, resulting in a growing shortage of high- tech talent in the country.
"The talent pool in Taiwan is just too small to meet the needs of high-tech companies," Wu said, adding that the program is part of the university's solution to the "talent shortage" problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ENTRY TO WHO SHOULD BE PUT ON WHA AGENDA: NGO

TEXT.P: Taiwan's application for full membership at the World Health Organization (WHO) should at least be put on the agenda of the World Health Assembly (WHA) in May for discussion, a non-governmental organization said Tuesday.

The Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan (FMPAT), long committed to advocating for Taiwan's entry to the WHO, held an international press conference to voice support for President Chen Shui-bian's recently announced move to send the application to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan after ten consecutive years of failure in seeking WHA observer status.

"For years Taiwan has been pursuing humble goals: becoming a WHA observer, as supported by the United States and Japan, and making 'meaningful participation', as suggested by European countries. But both approaches have proven unsuccessful due to China's politicization of the issue, " said Wu Shuh-min, President of the FMPAT.

Lo Chih-cheng, Chairman of the Department of Political Science of Soochow University cited the case of East Germany during the Cold War era and called on Chan and the WHO secretariat to respect due process.

Under the then zero-sum relations between the two German republics, East Germany's applications to join the WHO were rejected several times in the late 1960s and early 1970s. However, Lo said, what then WHO director-general Marcolino Gomes Candau did was to refer East Germany's applications to the WHA for it to make decisions, in the recognition that it was not his proper duty to determine whether East Germany enjoyed "statehood" as required by WHO Constitution.
According to the WHO Constitution, a member state is not necessarily a United Nations member but can be admitted upon an approval by a simple majority vote of the WHA.

Chan in a recent interview with the American television network CNN said the WHO's "193 member states still hold on very strongly to the One China principle". Denouncing Chan's claim as false, Lo said that "even if we accepted the notion of [two sides of the Taiwan Strait as] a divided nation, Chan should at least follow the East German example in dealing with Taiwan's application."

Political scientist Wu Chi-chung said there is no so-called "One China" principle held by the WHO against Taiwan's entry, "and if there were, the principle would be discriminatory and racist" because Taiwan is not even accommodated as was East Germany.

Winston Dang, lawmaker and Director of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's International Affairs Department, said the time is right to seek full WHO membership because of growing, high rates of support among Taiwan's people and parliament.

David Huang, former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council and a scholar at Academia Sinica, described Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO as "health apartheid" and called on the WHO to scrap a secret memorandum it signed with China in 2005.
"Even just for the sake of good governance of international organizations, a secret memorandum is simply illegitimate, " Huang said.
The memorandum allows China to have a final say on Taiwan's interactions with the WHO.
"'Meaningful participation' is meaningless for us because it is another country that defines the scope and character of such participation," Huang said.

Meaningful participation has been suggested by some countries to refer to the opportunity for Taiwan to participate in as many WHO-related meetings as possible, regardless of official title or circumstance.
But Taiwan's experts have always been denied or delayed from attending even the most technical meetings, Huang said.

George Liu, a Taiwan Solidarity Union legislator, said Taiwan's entry to the WHO should not be politicized, as "it is a health, moral and human rights issue, " for diseases know no border and contagious disease outbreaks in Taiwan can easily spread around the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WINNER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Desmond Mpilo Tutu, former Anglican Archbishop of South Africa and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, will arrive in Taiwan Wednesday for a weeklong visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chien-yeh said Tuesday.

Wang said the itinerary of Tutu will be arranged by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD), which invited him for the visit. The TFD is a non-profit organization dedicated to the promotion of democracy and human rights in Taiwan and abroad.
On Thursday, Tutu will meet with the family members of victims of the 228 Incident and pay a visit to Lin Yi-hsiung, former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

The 228 Incident refers to an uprising against the corrupt KMT administration under the late President Chiang Kai-shek that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was followed by a bloody crackdown resulting in the deaths of tens of thousands of civilians.

Lin's mother and twin daughters were murdered on Feb. 28, 1980 when he was in jail for his involvement in the Kaohsiung Incident in December 1979, a pro- democracy rally that turned violent. The murder remains unsolved till today.
On Friday, Tutu will meet with Vice President Annette Lu and later ride the high speed rail line to Kaohsiung to visit churches in southern Taiwan.
On April 24, Tutu will deliver a speech on transitional justice and ethnic reconciliation and share the experience of South Africa in this regard.
He will also meet with President Chen Shui-bian April 24 before leaving Taiwan the following day.

Tutu, 75, is a South African cleric and activist who rose to worldwide fame during the 1980s as an opponent of apartheid. Tutu served as the chairman of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) to move the nation along the path of reconciliation, one year after apartheid was done away with in 1994.
The TRC was a crucial component of the transition to full and free democracy in South Africa and, despite some flaws, is generally - though not universally - regarded as successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM PROMOTION GROUP SELLS TAIWAN IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 16 (CNA) 04/17/07 18:40:13 (By J. P. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A tourism promotional group from Taiwan met Monday with over 100 local counterparts in New York on the first leg of a U.S. tour that will take it to Los Angeles and San Francisco in the coming days as the summer travel peak season approaches.

The delegation, composed of officials from the Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) and representatives from Taiwan-based aviation companies and tour agencies, sponsored an audiovisual presentation featuring Taiwan's music, dance and attraction points to New Yorkers as part of its efforts to sell Taiwan to U.S. tourists.
As Beijing is to host the 2008 Olympic Games, Taiwan should grab the chance to promote "theme travel" while the world's attention is focused on the region, tourism executives opined.

According to Chang Cheng-yuan, director of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), North American tourists have in recent years become more aware of Taiwan, and Asia has increasingly turned into a major out-bound travel destination among U. S. visitors.
Thanks to Taiwan's position as a prime transfer hub in Asia, the country is strongly placed to court more tourists from the United States, Chang said.
In the first three months of this year, more than 97,000 business travelers and tourists from North America visited Taiwan, up by 3 percent over the previous year's level, MOTC statistics showed.

TVA Secretary-General Ju Hung-hai voiced his belief that Taipei 101 and the National Palace Museum in Taipei are definitely world-class tourist attractions. A tour package that connects these tourist points in Taipei with interesting spots in central and southern Taiwan would make an intriguing trip for tourists, he said.

Lee Yung-chun, manager of the Taipei-based China Airlines' New York office, echoed Chang's view favoring spreading theme travel in Taiwan. Taiwan's delicious food, spas, and natural scenery are features that should be better packaged to court more foreign visitors, he said.

An executive of the New York chapter of the Pacific Asia Travel Association suggested Taiwan "take the initiative" in finding new ways to lure foreign tourists, besides relying on its natural landscapes.

For instance, he said, Taiwan should be keen to popularize sporting activities, such as rock climbing, water-borne motor racing, and seasonal festivals taking advantage of its beautiful mountains and beaches.

Although the travel industry executive acknowledged that Taiwan faces difficulties in highlighting its attractions due to the proximity to China, Japan and other popular southeast Asian destinations, he contended that Taiwan must show that it possess something unique or interesting that tourists will consider worth exploring.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI FOUNDATION RECEIVES U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL AWARD

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation received an Environmental Award from the United States' Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), a spokesman of the foundation said Tuesday.
The Environmental Award ceremony was held April 17 at the EPA building in San Francisco.

According to the spokesman, the awards were given every year by the EPA's Region 9 to groups or individuals who have made contributions to public health or the environment in the past year in California, Arizona, Nevada, Hawaii, or the Pacific Islands.

A total of 160 groups and individuals were nominated for the award. Among them, Tzu Chi was nominated by Director of San Francisco's Department os Environment, Jared Blumenfeld, and was one of the seven winners in the San francisco Bay Area, and one of 38 winners of the whole region this year, the spokesman said.

The foundation, encouraged by its founder Master Cheng Yen to "convert trash to treasure, " started a recycling business in 1990, the spokesman said, adding that Tzu Chi volunteers had recycled over 1 million pounds of resources along the West Coast of the United States during the previous year.

The award came in recognition of the foundation's efforts in resources recycling, environmental protection education programs at Tzu Chi Academies around the United States, and enthusiastic participation in San Francisco City's environmental protection activities, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME TO SAVOR TAIWAN PINEAPPLES: AGRICULTURAL EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Pineapple growers in Taiwan have received a sweet surprise this year as an effect of global warming -- they have found the tropical fruit has not only grown fast and ripened early, but is also particularly sweet.

Agricultural experts at the Tainan District Agricultural Research and Extension Station noted Tuesday that pineapples, which usually are in season in Taiwan from May to July, have been in abundant supply this year since March.

They pointed out that Taiwan's total pineapple crops have exceeded 12,000 hectares, with most of the pineapple farms located in the four southern Taiwan counties of Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan and Chiayi.
According to the experts, between 70 percent and 80 percent of Taiwan's pineapple acreage is devoted to the most-favored Tainung No. 17 pineapple, also known as the golden diamond pineapple.
This variety, they added, has a thin rind and a tender, golden-yellow flesh that is juicy, rich and sweet, with a sugar content of over 14 percent.

There has been a change in consumers' behavior patterns, the experts continued, adding that while most pineapples were bought by factories and canned in the past, nowadays most consumers prefer to eat the fruit fresh.

Pineapples are low in saturated fat, cholesterol and sodium but rich in fructose and are a good source of dietary fiber, thiamin, Vitamin B6, Vitamin C, calcium, iron, copper, manganese and potassium.
The fruit also has an anti-inflammatory effect and is said to be exceptionally good for joint problems, the experts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS CALL FOR UPGRADING INDUSTRIES AFTER TRADE RATING DROPS

TEXT.P: Taiwanese trade officials warned Tuesday that the country should accelerate the upgrading of its industries amid fierce competition in the world community.

Officials of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) made the appeal after the latest trade report released by World Trade Organization (WTO) showed that Taiwan was the 17th largest trading country in 2006, down a notch from its 2005 rating, and the worst rating in memory.

According to the WTO statistics, Taiwan's trade value totalled US$427 billion last year, accounting for 1.7 percent of the world's total trade, representing a drop of 0.1 percentage point from its share in 2005.
The United States continued to be the world's largest trading country in 2006, followed by Germany, China, Japan, United Kingdom, and France, in that order, according to WTO statistics.
However, CEPD officials revealed that the value of China's exports in the second half of 2006 exceeded for the first time that of U.S., coming second only to that of Germany.
Officials attributed the drop of Taiwan's trade rating to the rise of many developing countries with great potential and the positive trade performances of advanced countries.
In addition, Taiwan's trade volume lagged behind that of the other three Asian tigers -- Singapore, South Korea, and Hong Kong, the officials went on.

Noting that this should be taken as a serious warning and must not be ignored, the officials urged the government to effectively implement those policies already presented which aim at elevating the competitiveness of the island's industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPIDEMIC CEREBROESPINAL MENINGITIS ENTERS PEAK SEASON: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) warned the public Tuesday that epidemic cerebrospinal meningitis has entered peak season with 17 notified cases so far, among which 11 have developed the full-blown disease and two have died.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH Center for Disease Control, said the early symptoms of this form of meningitis, which is caused by a specific bacterium, could be missed, saying that the public should pay attention to such symptoms as fever and skin rashes.
Treatment with antibiotics and other drugs is usually effective against this infection in the initial stage, he added.

Lin said the disease is most prevalent between March and April, noting that there were only four reported cases in the same period of last year with only one confirmed case. There were 25 reported cases in the whole of 2006, among which there were 13 confirmed cases and two deaths.

Lin said that among the 11 confirmed cases this year, three cases are babies not yet a month old, with the remaining eight cases aged between 11 and 86. They are sporadic cases rather than cluster cases, Lin added.
He advised the public to stay away from crowded places such as military barracks or school dormitories and to pay attention to personal hygiene.
People should also get vaccinated if they travel to Africa or other regions listed as infectious places, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA APPEARS IN COURT AGAIN TO FACE TRIAL ON CORRUPTION CHARGE

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou appeared at the Taipei District Court Tuesday for a second court session in his trial on charges of embezzlement.

In response to media inquiries on the session, Ma said he and his lawyers questioned the admissibility of evidence that anti-corruption prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen had submitted to support his indictment of Ma Feb. 13 on charges of embezzling from a special allowance fund designated for his discretionary use while he served as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006.

Ma told reporters that he had never noticed that he was listed as a "defendant" before appearing at a probe on the mayoral allowance Nov. 14 at the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office's anti-corruption center until the inquiry took place. On the notice for him to answer the questioning, Ma said he was classified as a "person of interest."
Therefore, he did not arrive with his own lawyer to defend his rights and interests during questioning, Ma claimed.

Asked whether he had been "misled" to face an "ambush-like probe" without the protection of lawyers, Ma declined to comment, only asking that people following case look into reports of the probe before coming to a decision.

Asserting his innocence, Ma claimed he has never stopped demanding of himself that he stay clean and follow the law since he began his political career two decades ago. His reputation was smeared after the prosecution ignored the evidence in his favor during the probe, said the politician, who has portrayed himself as a political "Mr. Clean."

Soon after being indicted on charges of corruption, Ma resigned from the post of chairman of the opposition Kuomintang and announced his bid to run for the presidency in 2008. He argued if he is found guilty, the same fate will befall almost all government executives and everyone who has ever served as a mayor or county magistrate.

Ma was charged with embezzling NT$11.17 million (US$337,650) from the mayoral special allowance funds by taking advantage of his position. Hou, who brought the high-profile indictment against Ma, rejected an interpretation by the Ministry of Justice last November that special allowance funds for executives of government departments are actually meant as salary subsidies.

At the court, Ma urged the judges to review the long-existing but faulty special allowance fund system and his decision to trust the collective wisdom of "common practices" concerning the use of the funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSUEHSHAN TUNNEL TO BE CLOSED FOR DISASTER CONTROL DRILLS

TEXT.P: The Hsuehshan Tunnel on the Peiyi Freeway will be closed for a four-hour period April 23 and another four-hour period April 25 for seasonal drills focusing on disaster prevention and control in the longest tunnel in Asia, officials of the Taiwan Area National Expressway Bureau announced Tuesday.

The provisional closure, to take place 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. April 23 and 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. April 25, will affect the freeway between Pinglin in Taipei County and Toucheng in Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan, the officials said.

The bureau suggested that drivers planning to travel to Yilan from Taipei at that time to leave the freeway at the Shiting interchange and take highway 106 to Pinglin before taking provincial highway 9 to Yilan.
Drivers from Yilan to Taipei can leave the freeway at the Toucheng interchange and take provincial highway 9 to Pinglin before taking the 106 to Shiting, where they can get back on the freeway.
The 12.9 km Hsuehshan Tunnel was opened to traffic in June 2006 after 15 years of construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA-WANG TICKET UP TO PUBLIC MANDATE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng of the Kuomintang (KMT) said Tuesday that it seems the party is set to nominate former Chairman Ma Ying-jeou as its candidate for the 2008 presidential race, but whether he will serve as Ma's running mate should be determined by the public in the coming months.
Wang made the comments while answering questions from students after delivering a keynote speech at National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences in southern Taiwan.

According to Wang, it is almost certain that Ma will be the candidate fielded by the KMT in the next presidential election. Given current conditions, a Ma-Wang ticket is much more feasible than a Wang-Ma ticket, he pointed out.

That meant, the eventual formation of a Ma-Wang ticket must be determined by receiving some sort of a public mandate in the months ahead, after taking into account party unity and their chances of victory given the treacherous political situation in Taiwan, Wang stated.

Commenting on his earlier proposal that the KMT nominate another candidate to run in the next presidential election if Ma is convicted in the first trial on corruption charges, Wang said that the suggestion does not represent his current personal position and noted that a Wang-Ma ticket is almost certainly out of the question.

Ma and Wang agreed tentatively in March to invite each other to team up on the KMT ticket in the next presidential election no matter who won the party's nomination out of concern that a split would ruin the party's chances of victory.

But Ma has been dogged by an ongoing lawsuit over his alleged embezzlement of NT$11 million in funds from a special municipal monthly allowance earmarked for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

Ma stepped down from the main opposition KMT chairmanship after being indicted in mid-February by Taipei prosecutors on embezzlement charges but immediately announced his bid to pursue presidency following the charges.
Despite corruption charges against him, Ma picked up a registration form early this month for the KMT's presidential primary, highlighting his resolve to pursue his presidential desire.
However Wang did not pick up the registration form, a development which has stirred up concern that he might run as an independent instead of being Ma's running mate.
The Taipei District Court opened hearings on Ma's case April 3 and a second session was held Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO APPLICATION FOR 'TAIWAN' NOT CONTRARY TO 'FOUR NOES' PROMISE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stressed Tuesday that the government's application to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as a full member under the name of "Taiwan" is not contrary to his previous "four noes" promise.
Chen made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with Henry Hyde, ex-chairman of the International Relations Committee of U.S. House of Representatives.

Chen's "four noes" promise, made at his 2000 inauguration, means not declaring Taiwan independence, not changing the ROC's official name, not pushing forth the inclusion of the so-called "state-to-state" description in the Constitution, and not promoting a referendum to change the status quo in regards to the question of independence or unification.
Chen said he wrote a letter to Margaret Chan, director general of the World Health Organization (WHO) April 11, applying to join the WHO as a full member under the title of "Taiwan."

Noting that Taiwan has encountered great difficulty joining international organizations under its official title "ROC," Chen said the name of "Taiwan" is the term most used on international occasions and supported by the majority of Taiwanese people.
Taiwan has sought to join the World Health Assembly, the policy-making body of the WHO, as an observer for the last decade, but has failed to gain entrance due to the opposition of China.
According to Chen, China signed a secret memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the WHO Secretariat in 2005, imposing more limits on Taiwan's entry into the world organization.

Chen said the government's application to join the WHO as a full member under the name of "Taiwan" has been endorsed by more than half of the country's legislators, and according to a survey conducted in March, 94.9 percent of the respondents supported the country's decision to apply to join the WHO under the name "Taiwan."
The president stressed that the health concerns of 23 million people in Taiwan should not be deprived, and disease control efforts should find no loophole in Taiwan.
Taiwan suffered significantly during the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreak in 2003, and therefore should not be excluded from the world disease prevention system, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO ADDRESS PROBLEM OF LOW SALARY FOR COLLEGE GRADS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday that the Executive Yuan is aware of the problem of low starting salaries for university graduates with master's or bachelor's degrees and is taking measures to address the issue.

The premier said that his "Mega Warmth, Mega Investment" project unveiled recently, specifically targets training programs for college students in hopes of nurturing talent to will meet the needs of local enterprises.
The premier made the remarks during a question-and-answer session in the Legislative Yuan.

Opposition Legislator Chao Liang-yen of the People First Party noted that starting salaries for graduates with master's or doctoral degrees averaged NT$31,567 (US$957) per month, and NT$26,700 for those with bachelor's degrees, figures that are even lower than the averages of 10 years ago according to a survey of 2006 graduates conducted by the Council of Labor Affairs.
Chao asked if this has to do with the rapid expansion of universities, resulting in an oversupply of university graduates given current demands.
The premier said that his Cabinet is aware of the problem, saying that since the rapid expansion of universities and graduate schools, the supply and demand did seem to be out of balance.
In addition, students having completed school programs are yet to meet the demands of businesses, resulting in low pay for the newcomers to the job market.

Officials from the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics reported that the number of graduates with master's or doctoral degrees was more than 48,000 in 2006, or three times that of a decade ago, and their average starting salary was only NT$5,000 more than the average starting salary for those holding a bachelor's degree.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PREMIER VOWS NO COMPROMISE IN DPP PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh vowed Tuesday to make no concessions in the presidential primary of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , despite fierce competition from his three rivals.
Hsieh made the pledge in a speech to supporters in Sanchung City, Taipei County, which was also attended by several DPP lawmakers and former government officials.

According to Hsieh, victory in the 2008 presidential election is the ultimate goal of the DPP, which cannot be compromised by lack of party harmony. Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun are also competing for the party's nomination.

"It is true that every one of us wants to win the nomination, but each should also be open-minded and get ready to form a ticket with the successful candidate, " Hsieh said, adding that "lack of party unity must not hobble the DPP's chances of election victory" and that "the party must field the most qualified hopeful."

Meanwhile, DPP members are slated to vote for the party's presidential candidate May 6 along with a vote for legislative candidates, the outcomes of which will be combined with public opinion poll results to decide the candidates.
Hsieh and Su have a noticeable lead over Lu and Yu, according to public opinion polls.
DPP officials have estimated that some 60 percent of party members will take part in the vote, equivalent to around 150,000 ballots.
The largest number -- around 35,000 eligible party voters -- is in Taipei County, followed by Kaohsiung City and Taipei City, each with some 33,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFITS OF STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES TOTAL NT$1.91 BILLION IN Q1

TEXT.P: Pre-tax profits for six state-run enterprises amounted to NT$1.91 billion (US$57.6 million) in the first quarter of this year, according to figures released Tuesday by the Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The Chinese Petroleum Corp. had a profit of NT$6.925 billion; Taiwan Sugar Corp., NT$185 million; Taiwan Water Corp., NT$491 million; Taiwan Shipbuilding Corp., NT$782 million; and Aerospace Industrial Development Corp., NT$31 million, according to the tallies.
The remaining enterprise -- Taiwan Power Co. -- ran a deficit of NT$6.504 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG TO CRACK DOWN ON PROPERTY ADS

TEXT.P: The Taichung city government warned real estate agents Tuesday not to place property ads wherever they like in the city, or they could face a double fine.
City government officials told reporters they have noticed a significant increase in "randomly placed" property ads in Taichung recently as a result of the booming real estate market.
They said such ads not only are against the law but also make the city look ugly.
As a countermeasure, they added, the Environmental Protection Bureau and the Land Administration Bureau under the city government will work together to crack down on illegal property ads.

The officials warned that offenders will first be fined up to NT$6,000 for violation of the Waste Disposal Act and then referred to land administration officials who will determine whether the offenders failed to include their company names in the property ads and thus should be subjected to another fine.

According to the Real Estate Broking Management Act, an unauthorized broker engaged in property sales is liable to a fine of between NT$100,00 and NT$300,000, while a real estate broker failing to provide its name in a property ad will face a fine of between NT$6,000 and NT$300,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:32 Shot Dead on Virginia Tech Campus
Thirty-two people were killed, along with a gunman, and at least 15 injured in two shooting attacks at Virginia Polytechnic Institute on Monday during three hours of horror and chaos on this sprawling campus.
The police and witnesses said some victims were executed with handguns while other students were hurt jumping from upper-story windows of the classroom building where most of the killings occurred. After the second round of killings, the gunman killed himself, the police said.
Wall Street Journal:Mercy Missions Are a Part of War
Capt. Josh Shonkwiler flew fast between jagged peaks, ignoring the automated voice in his headphones that emphatically chanted, "Low Altitude," and trying not to picture the little girl lying gravely wounded in the back of his helicopter.
Or her older brother, who was on the next stretcher, his intestines held in place by a plastic bag taped to his abdomen.
Capt. Shonkwiler tried not to think of the dozens of other people he and his Air Force medical-evacuation crew had picked up over the weeks they had been at war.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Blair prepares for final test as polls plunge to new low Tony Blair is heading towards his final electoral test with Labour on 29 per cent, its lowest rating since he became leader 13 years ago and its most lowly position in the run-up to local elections for more than 20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The shootng at Virginia Polytechnic Institute was the deadliest school shooting in U.S. history.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU GRADUATES FAVORITE HIRES AMONG LOCAL FIRMS: SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/07 21:58:48 (NTU) have replaced those from National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Graduates from National Taiwan University as the favorite new hires among local enterprises, according to the results of a poll released Tuesday.
The survey, conducted by Cheers magazine from March 5 to April 4, questioned the country's top 1,000 enterprises to find out about their corporate practices and hiring preferences.
NTU graduates exceeded for the first time in 10 years their NCKU counterparts as the most sought-after workers by local enterprises.
The magazine executives attributed the change to the abilities of NTU graduates in various fields.

Lee Chu-ying, who is responsable for the survey, noted that the corporations' demands for their workers have shifted from focusing only on specialist skills to also gauging their ability in other related spheres.

National Chiao Tung University graduates came third in the rating, followed by National Tsinghua University, National Chengchi University, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Tamkang University, National Sun Yat-sen University, National Taipei University of Technology and National Central University.
Tamkang University is the only private university to make the top 10 list.

The poll results show that many enterprises hope people in their 20s can strengthen their stability and ability to endure stress. However, some corporations admire new graduates' ability to express themselves.
In addition, more and more corporations require higher education levels for their employees, with 20 percent of those surveyed saying they will give preference to graduates with master's degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT SAYS SHE IS READY TO BE NEXT PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that she is prepared to be Taiwan's next president and the nation's first female head of state.

Addressing participants at a symposium held by National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences and the Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces, Lu urged the public to help her fulfill her dream of getting elected in 2008.
She dismissed her opponents as "not having the nation's future in mind" and claimed to be the only candidate who has a clear overall perspective about Taiwan's sovereignty and its future course.

She criticized her three party primary rivals from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- for their "fierce bickering" over the question of who leads in opinion polls in terms of approval ratings.
She also blasted Ma Ying-jeou, a presidential hopeful from the opposition Kuomintang, claiming that he is busy with nothing else but defending himself in an embezzlement case.
The vice president said she has been advocating gender equality for 35 years and is glad to see that Taiwan now ranks first in Asia and 19th in the world in this respect.
She added that if the nation could write a new chapter in its history by electing a woman to serve as president in 2008, it would greatly enhance Taiwan's visibility in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPERATIONS AT OFFSHORE SHIPPING CENTER DECLINES: MOTC

TEXT.P: The first-quarter operations of the Offshore Shipping Center (OSC) in Kaohsiung Harbor decreased year-on-year, an official of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Tuesday.

The OSC's total operations reached its peak of 674,000 TEUs in 2004, decreased to 661,000 TEUs in 2005 and to 616,000 TEUs in 2006. The 151,000 TEUs from January-March 2007 represented a 5.29 percent drop from the same period of last year and future growth is not likely, the official said.

The official said the OSC, established in 1997, allows carriers to handle direct shipping between Taiwan's Kaohsiung and China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports, but only with cargo heading for third destinations.

With other ports in China gradually improving facilities for big vessels, allowing them to ship directly to America and Europe, the importance of OSC has been reduced and its operations affected, according to the official.

Although the OSC operations decreased, the loading and unloading operations at Kaohsiung Port reached 2.45 million TEUs in the first quarter, moving up 6.99 percent year-on-year, the official said, adding that the growth rate of its transit cargo operations moved up 10.24 percent over the previous year's first quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARLYLE CALLS OFF PLAN TO ACQUIRE TAIWAN'S ASE GROUP

TEXT.P: The U.S.-based Carlyle Group has abandoned a plan to acquire Kaohsiung-based Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc (ASE) because of the difficulty in arriving at a price with ASE for its stocks, an ASE official said Tuesday.

The anonymous ASE official said that after five months of negotiations, the final price offered by Carlyle-- NT$39.5 per share--- was not accepted by ASE whose stock closed at NT$41 per share at Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday.

Carlyle initially offered to acquire all of ASE's 4.6 billion outstanding common shares at NT$39 per share in November. That means it would have purchased the world's No.1 chip packaging and test company for NT$18 billion, which would have been the largest-ever buyout in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. FTA WOULD BE MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL: CLA CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/07 19:26:59 (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor affairs official said Tuesday that the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States would be mutually beneficial for the United States, China and Taiwan.
Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Lee Ying-yuan made the remarks as he wound up a visit to the United States in which he pushed for the signing of an FTA between the two countries.
Lee, who arrived in Washington Sunday, said it is still difficult for the United States to sign an FTA with Taiwan, but added that the situation is "not completely hopeless."
According to Lee, if both sides were to sign an FTA, it would be beneficial for the United States, China and Taiwan and that China should have no reason to oppose it.

He noted that Taiwan is a major investor in China and that each year a great number of Taiwan tourists visit China, spending tens of billions of dollars there. China would indirectly benefit from a Taiwan-U.S. FTA, he said.

Lee noted that the present political atmosphere in the United States is more conservative and that the Democrat-controlled U.S. Congress is more reserved about signing FTAs with other countries. But he added that there are still a lot of U.S. congressmen who sympathize with and support Taiwan.

With the Trade Promotion Authority (TPA)-- a fast-track arrangement that allows the Bush administration to negotiate trade deals and present them to Congress for a simple yes-or-no vote -- approaching its expiration date at the end of June, it is believed that it will be even more difficult for the United States to sign FTAs with other countries after that.

But Lee said he learned from think tanks that Nancy Pelopsi, speaker of the U.S. House, might leave room for compromises on bills that are not related to ideological issues. The possibility that the TPA will be extended cannot be ruled out, he added.
Lee delivered speeches to think tanks and lobbied congressional support for the signing of an FTA during his visit, which will wrap up April 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACE PITCHER MIGHT BE HIRED TO PROMOTE TAIWAN TOURISM

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau might make an offer for Chien-ming Wang, the Taiwan-born starting pitcher for the New York Yankees, to promote Taiwan tourism.
Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said Wednesday that the plan is still in the initial stage and that the method of cooperation will be unveiled "when the time is ripe."
Lai noted that the bureau hired popular singer A-mei to promote Taiwan tourism in Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore and Malaysia last year, with good results.
This year, they asked the pop band F4 to serve as the spokesmen for the bureau in Japan and South Korea, attracting around 300 reporters.

F4 will perform April 22 at the stadium of National Taiwan University in a show that is expected to be attended by around 5,000 fans from Japan and South Korea, with a second performance scheduled for October.

DOC.HEADLINE: YULON, ACER WORK TOGETHER TO EXPAND USED CAR AUCTION MARKET

TEXT.P: The Sinjan Auto Auction (SAA), an affiliate of the Yulon Group, has launched Point of Sale (POS) electronic auction system under a collaboration with Acer Computer aimed at the local and international market for used cars, SAA Chairman Su Ching-yang said Wednesday.
Acer and SAA, the nation's largest used car auctioneer, intend to introduce the system to China, Japan and Thailand, according to Su.

Instead of using a Japanese system, SAA worked with Acer in order to acquire its own technology platform, Su said, adding that the newly launched system will help expand the auction scale for used cars in Taiwan and help it enter the international market, especially China.

China has unlimited market development for second-hand vehicles, with used car sales there increasing for three consecutive years and only a 26.4 percent growth rate in new car sales in 2006, Su quoted statistics of the China Automobile Dealers Association as saying.

Su vowed to make SAA a leading brand in the second-hand car business in Chinese speaking areas and added that the POS system will be introduced to China as long as related regulations can be approved.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAPID TRANSIT LINE IN PINGTUNG COUNTY TO BE ELEVATED

TEXT.P: A 19-km rapid transit rail line linking Pingtung County with the greater Kaohsiung area will be entirely elevated so that there will not be any level crossings causing traffic congestion, Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung announced Wednesday.

Tsao told a press conference that the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has agreed to the county government's request to change the CEPD's original plan by elevating the entire rapid transit line and increasing the budget from NT$5.96 billion to NT$15.25 billion (US$459 million).
The revised plan will not only make 24 level crossings in Pingtung County redundant, but also allow a new highway to be constructed under the rapid transit line, according to Tsao.

He said the project is scheduled for completion in June 2011, and that eventually this rapid transit line will be served by 220 trains a day, linking Pingtung County with the greater Kaohsiung area's rapid transit system and the Taiwan High Speed Rail's terminal at Zuoying.
Many real estate brokers sent representatives to the press conference to learn about the new, revised project because the elevated railway is expected to increase local property values.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIV CARRIERS IN TAICHUNG COUNTY INCREASE TO 540

TEXT.P: The number of reported HIV virus carriers in Taichung increased to 540 by the end of March, Taichung County Deputy Magistrate Chang Chuang-hsi said Wednesday.

Chang told a press conference that statistics compiled by the county government's Public Health Bureau show that seven pregnant women in the county tested positive for HIV last year and that of the seven newborns, three were certified to be free of the HIV virus, while the other four were still being monitored.

According to Chang, statistics also show that 74 percent of the HIV carriers contracted the virus through sexual transmission, while another 23.3 percent were infected due to shared needle use while injecting drugs.
Chang urged Taichung County's residents to keep in mind the importance of safe sex.
He added that both men and women should face the issue squarely, instead of treating the subject as taboo.
The magistrate encouraged the use of condoms to avoid both unwanted pregnancies and HIV transmission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TPCO SETS UP DRUG DETECTION DOG KENNEL

TEXT.P: The Taipei Customs Office (TPCO) established a kennel for drug detection dogs to improve its effectiveness in combating drug smuggling, Director of the Directorate General of Customs Chien Liang-chi said Wednesday.

Chien said a total of five dogs will patrol together with two handlers, joining in drug detection duties at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in July when the three dogs already on site will be joined by two others.

The TPCO discovered 36 kilograms of high quality heroin in the first quarter of 2007, with most of the busts credited to intelligence work and another 25 percent discovered through the use of X-ray machines, Chien said.

The assistance of drug detection dogs will help eliminate blind spots not covered by physical searches or mechanical discovery, and thereby improve detection of contraband drugs including heroin, cocaine, and marijuana, Chien added.

Chien said it is common to utilize dogs' sensitive sense of smell to curb drug smuggling at airports, for up to 30 percent of foreign drug smuggling cases broken by foreign customs are credited to drug detection dogs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LAST CULTURAL CENTER IN FRANCE TO CLOSE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/07 21:18:10 (By Yuan-shao Lo and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) will close April 30 its cultural center in France, Republic of China Representative to France, Michel Lu confirmed Wednesday.
Lu said the center will close because it is hardly used.

The cultural center's collection of 16,000 books will be given to academic institutions in France, including the Institut National des Languages et Civilisations Orientales, the Ecole normale superieure de Lyon, the University of Montpelier and the University of Paris X, Lu said.

The shutdown of the center will not affect bilateral relations between Taiwan and France, Lu said, adding that interaction between the two countries will proceed as scheduled and that there will still be secretaries in charge of overseas affairs.
The center is the last Taiwan-run library and Chinese teaching station in Paris after a library of the Government Information Office was closed in April 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAVILLS GROUP TO ESTABLISH TAIWAN BRANCH

TEXT.P: The international property services group, Savills, will establish a branch in Taiwan to provide counseling services on commercial real estate to local and multinational corporations, Chief Executive Robert McKeller announced Wednesday.
Savills, established in 1855 and headquartered in England, has over 160 branches and more than 15,800 employees in 22 countries.

McKeller said the company is entering the Taiwanese market to tap into business opportunities in Chinese speaking areas, implement the group's global management plans, integrate regional operations, and better serve the needs of Savills' multinational clients.
The establishment of a Taiwanese branch marks an important advance by Savills in expanding its business in the Asia Pacific, McKeller said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW AMENDMENT PROPOSAL AIMS TO CLEAN-UP POLITICS: DPP

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged Wednesday the public not to politicize a DPP-initiated draft amendment to prevent suspected criminals from taking part in presidential elections, saying that it will help to clean-up politics in Taiwan.

DPP legislative caucus whip Wang Hsing-nan made the comments in a Legislative Yuan news conference after a proposed revision to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law, submitted by DPP lawmaker Chen Chin-der, was included a day earlier on the agenda of the Procedure Committee.

Lawmakers of the opposition People First Party (PFP) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union all were absent from the Tuesday meeting, making it possible to railroad the proposed revision through the committee.

Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers have vowed to block the proposed amendment -- widely believed to target former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who is pursuing a presidential bid despite being charged with corruption -- in the upcoming Friday meeting.

According to Wang, DPP lawmakers will be fully mobilized to secure the passage of the draft bill in the Friday meeting, but they will respect whatever decision PFP lawmakers make regarding this matter. The PFP and the KMT set up a new and closer partnership in January, and the two parties have long cooperated in the Legislative Yuan.

Chen called for widespread support from legislative peers for the passage of the proposed amendment, and argued that the KMT has been "hijacked" by Ma as the party currently is seeking to modify its internal regulations banning party members convicted in the first trial from taking part in any elections to keep alive Ma's hopes of running in the next presidential election.
Chen also denied widespread criticism that his proposed amendment to ban candidates convicted in the first trial in presidential elections is intended to target any particular individual.

Meanwhile, it is widely assumed that PFP lawmakers were absent from the Tuesday Procedure Committee meeting due to disputes arising from the May 12 by-election for the Keelung mayorship and December's legislative election despite the fact that the two parties set up a KMT-PFP alliance in January to step up collaboration in the upcoming elections.

Later the same day, KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung promised that he will do his best to "mediate" with the PFP to ensure that PFP legislators are aligned with their KMT counterparts and prepared to reject the draft law amendment Friday in the Legislative Yuan.
Wu questioned whether such "a clause targeting Ma" really serves social justice, and called it a DPP "plot" to squeeze Ma out of the next presidential contest.

In response to speculation that the KMT is planning to relax its regulations excluding convicted party members from taking part in any elections, Wu said that such a change must be approved by party delegates in a national congress, but made it clear that "even if the KMT implements the rule change, it will be for the good of the entire party, and not only for Ma."

According to KMT Secretary-General Wu Duen-yih, the KMT party central will not push through a change in the party charter as any revision must be decided by a two-third majority of party delegates in a national congress.
The KMT is slated to hold its 17th plenary session June 24, a KMT spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, INDIA FORGE TIES TO BOOST TECHNOLOGICAL EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/07 21:47:52 (By Paul Kuo and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China signed a memorandum of understanding with India Wednesday on cooperation in the fields of science and technology, sources at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center (TECC), the ROC's representative office in India, said that day.

The two parties agreed in the accord to promote bilateral cooperation in the fields of nanotechnology, semiconductors, aviation and space, satellite development, biotechnology and agriculture, according to the sources.

The new ties will also facilitate other forms of collaboration between the two sides, such as programs to encourage commercialization of research and development, sustainable development and innovation.

A ceremony was held in Taipei with ROC Representative to India Kao Chen-chun and his Indian counterpart T.P. Seetharam signing the memorandum. Chen Chien-jen, minister of Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC), attended the event.

According to the memorandum, the NSC and India's Cabinet-level Department of Science and Technology will establish a joint committee for work including scientific talent exchanges and the promotion of joint technological development projects.

Chang Ho-chung, chief of the TECC technology division, said the two sides have long had interest in forging cooperative relations and have organized many workshops for cooperative proposals in the fields of genetic research and biochemistry. An Indian official in charge of science and technology affairs who requested anonymity confirmed the signing, saying that the cooperation is only aimed at enhancing the promotion of technological development and mutual bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LOCAL GOVERNMENTS MULL REGIONAL LIGHT RAIL TRANSIT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The heads of three local governments agreed Wednesday to form a task force to study the feasibility of building a light rail rapid transit system for the region covering the city of Hsinchu and the counties of Hsinchu and Miaoli.

Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer, Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin and Miaoli County Magistrate Liu Cheng-Hung held a meeting on the matter, which was also attended by Huang Der-ray, director of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration.

They reached consensus at the meeting that the three administrative areas naturally form a large community and should have a rapid transit system to serve the region and make the life of its residents more convenient.

They decided to set up a NT$6 million fund to allow the task force to conduct a feasibility study on the proposed project, with the four parties each providing NT$1 million and the shortfall of NT$2 million to be filled through a request for aid to the central government.

The three local government heads agreed that regional planning and strategic alliances are trends that will shape the future of Taiwan's administrative areas, and that for the sake of the common interests of the city of Hsinchu and the counties of Hsinchu and Miaoli, it is necessary to assess the feasibility of the light rail transit system as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH AFRICAN ARCHBISHOP ARRIVES FOR WEEK-LONG VISIT

TEXT.P: Former South African Archbishop Desmond Mpilo Tutu arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a week-long visit at the invitation of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.

Tutu, who rose to worldwide fame during the 1980s as an opponent of apartheid and won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984, said he will take in the latest developments in Taiwan and exchange views with local friends on a range of topics of mutual interest, including political and economic affairs and ethnic harmony.

On Thursday, Tutu will visit Machangting, a former execution ground for political prisoners adjacent to the present-day Youth Park in western Taipei, and 228 Peace Memorial Park in downtown Taipei where he will meet with family members of the victims of the infamous 228 Incident, an uprising in Taiwan that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was suppressed by the then-Kuomintang government, resulting in the killing of thousands of civilians.

Tutu is set to meet Friday with Vice President Annette Lu, who was imprisoned for nearly six years for her pro-democracy activities during Taiwan's martial law era. Later that day, he will travel to the southern port city of Kaohsiung via the high-speed rail line.

Tutu will deliver a speech April 24 on South Africa's experiences in seeking transitional justice and ethnic reconciliation following the end of apartheid. As head of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Tutu has played a leading role in his country's post-apartheid campaign to heal historical wounds and boost ethnic harmony.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI'S NOVEL FIRE RETARDANT 'REDDEX' MAKES DEBUT IN HANOVER
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/07 23:12:58 (By Lin Yu-li and Zep Hu)

TEXT.P: A novel fire-resistant insulation material, developed by Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , has made its debut at the ongoing Hanover Messe trade fair, the institute's Europe branch in Berlin reported Wednesday.

The new material, named Reddex, has strong fire-resistant ability, ITRI officials stationed in Berlin said, adding that even at temperatures of 1,000 degrees Celsius, it can still maintain a back-side temperature of about 300 degrees C for over 60 minutes, without either drip-melt or break-up.

Furthermore, they noted, eco-friendly Reddex contains neither halogens nor phosphorous, both of which are widely used in traditional insulation materials, therefore it produces no toxic particles when exposed to flames. Steam is the only by-product, they added.
In addition, the ITRI officials said, the smoke density released by Reddex is only 2.0, only one 1 percent of a safe ceiling of 200.

According to the officials, Reddex has been successfully applied to awide range of products, including paint, coating, paste, film, hoses, coated fabric and other protective insulation used in vehicles and buildings.

The Hanover Messe, started in 1947, has become the largest industrial fair in the world. It is held annually at the Hanover fairground, with the participation of about 6,000 exhibitors and 200,000 visitors per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOL DISPUTES REPORT ABOUT CAUSE OF STUDENTS' CANCER

TEXT.P: A junior high school in Yilan County dismissed as "sheer speculation" Wednesday a media report claiming that electromagnetic waves from a high-voltage power transmission facility in the school's vicinity might be related to the relatively high susceptibility of cancer among its students.

According to the report carried in the Taipei-based China Times daily Tuesday, the Nanao Junior High School has only 200-plus student, but four of its students have been diagnosed with cancer over the past four years, prompting school authorities to wonder whether electromagnetic waves from the nearby high-voltage power transmission facility should be blamed for the phenomenon.
In response, Nanao school principal Wu Ling-mei said the report was full of mistakes.

Wu said that a Nanao student indeed died of cancer eight years ago, not four years ago as reported. As for the remaining three ailing students, Wu said, they were all diagnosed with cancer during their elementary schools and one of them was relocated to Yilan from Taoyuan County.
It requires verification by professional medical experts and scholars to determine whether their illnesses have anything to do with the power transmission facility, Wu said.

Moreover, Wu said, the school has never taken the initiative to collect information about its students' illness for supply to the media nor has it bother to speculate on the possible cause of their diseases.
To the best of her knowledge, Wu said, the China Times reporter had never visited the school before writing the article. Wu said the school has asked the newspaper to correct its misleading report.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LOCAL GOVERNMENTS MULL REGIONAL LIGHT RAIL TRANSIT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The heads of three local governments agreed Wednesday to form a task force to study the feasibility of building a light rail rapid transit system for the region covering the city of Hsinchu and the counties of Hsinchu and Miaoli.

Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer, Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin and Miaoli County Magistrate Liu Cheng-Hung held a meeting on the matter, which was also attended by Huang Der-ray, director of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration.

They reached consensus at the meeting that the three administrative areas naturally form a large community and should have a rapid transit system to serve the region and make the life of its residents more convenient.

They decided to set up a NT$6 million fund to allow the task force to conduct a feasibility study on the proposed project, with the four parties each providing NT$1 million and the shortfall of NT$2 million to be filled through a request for aid to the central government.

The three local government heads agreed that regional planning and strategic alliances are trends that will shape the future of Taiwan's administrative areas, and that for the sake of the common interests of the city of Hsinchu and the counties of Hsinchu and Miaoli, it is necessary to assess the feasibility of the light rail transit system as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, INDIA FORGE TIES TO BOOST TECHNOLOGICAL EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, April 18 (CNA) 04/19/07 10:43:21 (By Paul Kuo and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China signed a memorandum of understanding with India Wednesday on cooperation in the fields of science and technology, sources at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center (TECC), the ROC's representative office in India, said that day.

The two parties agreed in the accord to promote bilateral cooperation in the fields of nanotechnology, semiconductors, aviation and space, satellite development, biotechnology and agriculture, according to the sources.

The new ties will also facilitate other forms of collaboration between the two sides, such as programs to encourage commercialization of research and development, sustainable development and innovation.

A ceremony was held in Taipei with ROC Representative to India Kao Chen-chun and his Indian counterpart T.P. Seetharam signing the memorandum. Chen Chien-jen, minister of Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC), attended the event.

According to the memorandum, the NSC and India's Cabinet-level Department of Science and Technology will establish a joint committee for work including scientific talent exchanges and the promotion of joint technological development projects.

Chang Ho-chung, chief of the TECC technology division, said the two sides have long had interest in forging cooperative relations and have organized many workshops for cooperative proposals in the fields of genetic research and biochemistry. An Indian official in charge of science and technology affairs who requested anonymity confirmed the signing, saying that the cooperation is only aimed at enhancing the promotion of technological development and mutual bilateral exchanges.
