DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 19, or the third day of the third month of the Year of Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species" and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the Republic of China's first president under the new ROC Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a Communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro- democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan- zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The S.S. Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological Cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau transform itself into a "National Bureau of Investigation."
2001: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew says that he will file an application with the government for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TORNADO HITS TAINAN COUNTY

TEXT.P: A tornado hit Tainan County in the early morning hours of Wednesday, with the wind speeds estimated at up to 102 kilometers per hour, tearing down at least 10 homes and leaving livestock dead, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

The tornado occurred at around 1: 40 a.m. and lasted until 2: 09 a.m., bringing strong winds estimated at level 10 on the Beaufort Scale and heavy rains to the southern county, CWB officials said, adding that rain accumulation during the duration of tornado amounted to 30-35 millimeters.

The officials said as tornadoes are so unpredictable, the CWB judged that from the movement of the system on radar screens and from information provided by the general public that the system must be a tornado.

The real cause of the tornado is still unclear, the officials said, adding that tornadoes usually occur when super cold front systems are accompanied by thunder and strong winds. The officials further said that while tornadoes are not unusual in Taiwan in the spring and summer, they rarely cause serious damage.

As tornados always carry strong winds which could easily destroy measurement facilities, it is hard to get reliable measurements of them, the officials said, adding that the CWB does not have an observation booth in the area, so it was impossible to measure the actual level of Wednesday's tornado.
Meanwhile, the CWB said that a cold front is expected to arrive in the country on Sunday and that rain is also forecast for the northern, central, and southern parts of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP OFFICE TO SEND STAFF TO VIRGINIA TECH TO EXTEND CONDOLENCES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) 04/19/07 13:26:20 (By Lin Chieh-yu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in the United States said Wednesday it will send staff members to Virginia Tech University the following day to extend condolences after Monday's shooting rampage which claimed 33 lives, including the gunman's.

The officials from the Republic of China representative office in Washington, D.C. will also meet with Taiwanese students and faculty members at the Virginia Tech campus in Blacksburg, Virginia where the deadliest campus massacre in U.S. history took place, an office spokesman said, adding that if necessary, the officials will offer assistance to them.

The representative office already sent condolence messages to Virginia Tech management by phone on behalf of the ROC government and people shortly after the tragedy, the spokesman said, adding that the office also immediately contacted the school's international student affairs division and the Taiwanese Students Association to get confirmation that all Taiwanese students and professors were safe and unharmed.

Celine Lin, president of the Taiwanese Students Association of Virginia Tech, posted a report on the group's Web site Tuesday saying that each of the Taiwan students and faculty, totaling some 60, had been contacted by phone to establish that they were safe and well.

In Taipei, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Wang Chien-yeh also expressed his sympathies and condolences at a routine news conference Tuesday on behalf of the ROC government over the tragic incident.

ROC Representative to U.S. Joseph Wu has also made phone calls to the Virginia State Government, State Assembly and federal congressional members from the state to express his condolences, said Pi Tsu-an, a secretary at the ROC representative office in Washington, D.C. The ROC's Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng has also faxed a condolence letter to Virginia Tech University President Charles W. Steger, Pi said.
When the representative office staff members visit the school Thursday, Pi said, they will pass on a condolence letter from Wu to the school's management.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINING WHO UNDER NAME 'TAIWAN' IS WILL OF THE PEOPLE: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Joining the World Health Organization (WHO) under the name "Taiwan" is the will of the people of Taiwan, with 95 percent of the population supporting the idea, Minister of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) James Huang said Thursday.

Huang made the remarks while attending a book presentation by the Taiwan International Health Action, a government-funded organization set up to provide medical assistance to Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

No matter how difficult the bid for WHO membership might be, Huang vowed to make every effort to let other countries know through Taiwan's diplomatic allies and other channels that it is wrong to shut Taiwan out of the health organization.

He noted that the government has for the past decade humbly bid to join the WHO as an observer, which the United States and Japan has supported, and to "participate in a meaningful way" in the WHO's activities, as suggested by European countries, but both approaches have proven unsuccessful due to China's obstruction.
Since China signed a memorandum with the WHO in 2005, which allows China to have the final say on Taiwan's interactions with the organization, the situation has become even worse, Huang noted.

Meaningful participation has been suggested by some countries as meaning the opportunity for Taiwan to participate in as many WHO-related meetings as possible, regardless of its official title or the circumstances, he said.
However, he continued, permission for experts from Taiwan to attend even meetings on technical issues has consistently been denied or delayed.
Taiwan has become even more marginalized, and this is why it has decided to push for membership under the name "Taiwan," Huang said.
WHO Director-General Margaret Chan, in a recent interview with CNN, said the WHO's "193 member states still hold on very strongly to the one China principle".

DOC.HEADLINE: MINIMUM WAGE TO BE RAISED IN SECOND HALF OF YEAR: CLA CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) 04/19/07 16:12:51 (By Michelle Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's minimum wage will be adjusted in the second half of this year, probably July 1, to make it more commensurate with Taiwan's general economic situation and consumer price index, a visiting labor official said Wednesday.

Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lee Ying-yuan, who is visiting Washington, D.C. to lobby for support for Taiwan's drive to sign a free trade agreement with the United States, made the remarks while meeting with Taiwanese journalists stationed in the U.S. capital over a cup of tea.

After extensive consultations with major industrial and commercial associations, labor unions, and academic groups, Lee said a consensus has been forged for a measured adjustment of the country's minimum wage, which has been frozen at NT$15,840 (US$480) per month, or NT$66 per hour for a decade.

In view of the more than 50 percent growth in Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) for the past 10 years, Lee said, the minimum wage should be raised appropriately to let all wage earners enjoy the fruits of economic growth.

The planned adjustment is tentatively set for implementation in the second half of this year, Lee said, adding that July 1 is the most favored starting day. But he added that the exact timing for the implementation can be readily changed based on practical considerations.

As to the adjustment range, Lee said, a combination of factors, including the increase in the average consumer price index over the past decade, Taiwan's general economic growth as well as the possible adverse impact on local industries' competitiveness, should be taken into consideration when deciding on the level of the minimum wage increase.

While the business community has declared that 5 percent is the maximum level they are willing to accept for an upward adjustment, labor groups want a far larger hike, Lee said, adding that he once proposed at a Legislative Yuan session that the minimum wage be raised to 40 percent of the average salary of all workers in the country. If adopted, the minimum wage would be increased to NT$17,600 per month, representing a hike of 11 percent over the current level.
"Anyway, many elements should be taken into account, and the final adjustment figure should be announced by the premier himself, " Lee said.

Noting that under Taiwan's new portable pension system adopted some two years ago, employers are required to deposit a monthly pension reserve fund equivalent to 6 percent of an employee's salary, Lee said, the measure is to some extent tantamount to offering a pay raise. "This element should also be taken into consideration when deciding the minimum wage adjustment range," he added.
Meanwhile, Lee said Taiwan could refer to the past U.S. practice in basic wage adjustment in which its minimum wage was raised by 7.25 percent in three stages during a 26-month interval.

Lee arrived in the U.S. capital Sunday for an FTA-lobbying visit, during which he has met with Bush administration officials, congressional leaders and think tank scholars to brief them on Taiwan's labor policies and welfare services as part of his efforts to clear the way for signing a bilateral free trade pact. He will wrap up his visit Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PIGS KILLED CRUELLY AT OVER 70% OF TAIWAN SLAUGHTERHOUSES: REPORT

TEXT.P: A report released Thursday by an animal rights organization claims that more than 70 percent of public slaughterhouses in Taiwan still kill pigs in a cruel manner.

Chu Tzeng-hung, chairman of the Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan (EAST) , released the findings of the organization's study of slaughterhouses around the country conducted over a three-year period dating back to 2004.

After watching a video made by the EAST about how Taiwan's slaughterhouses kill their pigs, several lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union promised to propose an amendment to the Animal Protection Law so as to bring animals raised for economic purposes under the law's protection.

According to Tzeng, only six of the 27 public slaughterhouses around Taiwan kill their pigs in a humane way, namely by making the pigs lose consciousness with an electric shock so that they feel no pain when they are slaughtered.

The pigs at the other slaughterhouses are killed in a cruel manner, Tzeng said, explaining that the pigs are first hung upside down by one of their legs and then beaten unconscious with a stick before being slaughtered.
At the press conference, several of the woman lawmakers were brought to tears while watching the video on how cruelly the animals are treated.

Hsiao Bi-khim, a DPP legislator, said that as a ruling party lawmaker, she feels ashamed that the government has failed to punish the owners of the slaughterhouses that treat the animals so mercilessly. She promised to work with other lawmakers to push for an amendment to the Animal Protection Law to bring animals raised for economic purposes under the law's protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI MAN RECEIVES TZU CHI BONE MARROW DONATION
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/07 17:00:28 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A 19-year-old Shanghai man underwent bone marrow transplant surgery at a Shanghai hospital early Thursday, receiving 700 ml of stem cells provided by Taiwan's Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center.
Fang Dongwei, who suffers from inherited anemia, was doing fine after the surgery, doctors from the Shanghai Xinhua Hospital said.

In a telephone conversation, Fang told CNA that although he does not know who the donor is, he is profoundly grateful to the unnamed donor and to Taiwan's Tzu Chi Buddhist Compassionate Relief Foundation, which made the transplant possible.
Fang checked into the hospital last November with anemia, which doctors said could be treated only with a bone marrow transplant.
Three months later, the Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center said it had found a compatible Taiwan donor.
Before Fang received the bone marrow transplant, he underwent six rounds of chemotherapy over the past four months to prepare for the donated bone marrow.

According to Liang Hui, director of the hospital's blood department, Fang's body is expected to adapt to the transplanted stem cells in about three weeks and he will be discharged from the hospital after two months of observation if no signs of infection or rejection show during that period.
In late March, a three-year-old Chinese boy received a bone marrow transplant from a Taiwanese donor.
The boy, surnamed Chiu, who also suffers from an inherited form of anemia, received 600 ml of stem cells provided by the Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center.
Shanghai doctors previously predicted that without a bone marrow transplant, the child would not have lived beyond the age of 12.
So far the boy has been doing fine, according to hospital authorities.

The Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Center -- the largest of its kind in Asia -- has built a databank of nearly 300,000 bone marrow samples since its inception in 1993. It has helped more than 300 victims of blood diseases to find donors.
The center now has access to data on more than 10 million donors worldwide after linking with two bone marrow databanks in the United States and Germany late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS IN FULL GEAR TO BLOCK TWO KEY BILLS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has gone into full gear to mobilize party lawmakers in the hope of blocking two key draft bills of great concern to its future in a legislative committee meeting Friday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, said that all party lawmakers have been notified that they must attend the Procedure Committee meeting Friday, in which two bills regarding the handling of the KMT's assets and the banning of convicted individuals from future presidential elections are on the agenda.

The two bills, targeting the KMT's assets and its former chairman, Ma Ying-jeou, who is making a strong presidential bid, were put on the committee's agenda Tuesday as a result of the absence of lawmakers of the People First Party (PFP) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) to block the move.

Tseng said he has confidence that with cooperation from PFP and NPSU lawmakers, they will be able to reject the two draft bills in a concerted move in the Friday meeting. The KMT has been mediating with the PFP and the NPSU on the matter, he noted.

Despite Tseng's call for PFP and NPSU collaboration, it remains unclear whether the two parties will join KMT efforts in killing the two bills. The PFP, in particular, has been at loggerheads with the KMT due to rows arising from the May 12 by-election for Keelung mayor and December's legislative elections, even though the two parties set up a new alliance in January that was supposed to step up cooperation in coming elections.

In response to the KMT's keen desire that PFP lawmakers help block the two bills, PFP legislative caucus whip Fu Kun-chi said that seven or eight PFP legislators have gone abroad and that he is not sure whether they will return home to attend the Friday meeting.

Nevertheless, Fu also said that the "PFP will not make it so that Ma misses the chance to run in the 2008 presidential race " and added that the PFP will hold a meeting later Thursday to discuss how to deal with the situation in Friday's Procedure Committee meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION SOLICITS VIETNAM'S SUPPORT ON REGIONAL INTEGRATION

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation visited Vietnam Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung Wednesday to solicit his country's support for Taiwan's participation in regional economic integration, an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

Deputy Economics Minister Hsieh Fadah, who is part of the delegation organized by the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, was quoted as having said the delegation has explained to Nguyen Taiwan's economic development and the challenges it faces in getting involved with regional integration.

The delegation expressed hope that Vietnam will help Taiwan to be included in the integration and support the concept of a Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) proposed to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, Hsieh said.
Taiwan is the largest foreign investor in Vietnam, but this will be affected if Taiwan is not included in regional economic integration.
The delegation said Taiwan would like to keep its investment in Vietnam, an idea that was welcomed by Nguyen, said Hsieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY REPORTS YEAR'S FIRST MALARIA CASE

TEXT.P: A 28-year-old South African man was diagnosed with malaria after arriving in Taiwan from Singapore in late March, making him the first malaria case reported in Taipei County this year, officials of the county's Public Health Bureau said Thursday.

The man, who arrived in the county's Tamsui township March 30, developed fever April 9 and was diagnosed with malaria, for which he was treated in hospital. He was discharged from the hospital April 16 after recovery from the disease. It was an imported malaria case, the officials said.
There were four imported malaria cases in the county last year, the officials said, adding that the people contracted the disease in Papua New Guinea, Myanmar and Nigeria.

Malaria, a sometimes fatal disease carried by mosquitoes, has been eradicated in Taiwan for more than 40 years, but tallies compiled by the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health show that between 30 and 50 imported cases are still reported every year.

People intending to visit malarial areas such as Africa and Southeast Asia should go to public health offices to get free prophylactic medicine before traveling and should try to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes while overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC AGING SOCIETY STUDY GROUP VISITS COMMUNITIES IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: An aging society study group has concluded a two-day survey in communities in the southern county of Tainan, with the aim of investigating the differences in population aging between urban and rural areas in Taiwan, team members reported Thursday.

The study group, under the auspices of the National Science Council, is led by Minister without Portfolio Lin Wan-i. Researchers from several top universities in Taiwan also participated in the survey.
Lin said that while people aged over 65 only accounted for 7 percent of Taiwan's population in 1993, it will have risen tremendously to 20 percent by 2025.

The government has already started a 10-year geriatric care plan, Lin noted, adding that the effectiveness estimate and progress evaluation provided by the study group will help the government fine-tune the plan so that it can offer better services.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANEL INSPECTS DAMAGED HERITAGE CHATEAU

TEXT.P: The reconstruction of the late President Chiang Kai-shek's first official residence in Taiwan will not be a problem, but finding the right kind of cypress and the original Japanese tiles will be difficult, an emergency response panel said Thursday.

The panel, which comprises structural specialist Tsai Teh-shin and Lee Chung- yao, an authority on historical relics and heritage site restoration, visited the wreckage of the Grass Mountain Chateau on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei, which was badly damaged during a fire earlier this month.
The panel estimated that the cost of the reconstruction will be between NT$30 million (US$909,000) and NT$50 million and will take about two years to complete.
Tsai said that cinders from the fire will have to be collected and preserved. In addition, the issue of fire and earthquake prevention will have to be taken into consideration.

Lee, a traditional architectural restoration master who played a leading role in the building's first large-scale face-lift a few years ago, said he was saddened to see the fire-ravaged site, but as the original design has been kept, "it will be no problem to restore it to its original form, " although the methods and skills will have to be studied.

He noted that there is dirt, wood and lime in Taiwan, but Japanese tiles are no longer produced here. The wooden structure of the original building employed mainly Taiwan cypress and whether to use Taiwan cypress or foreign cypress -- which is three or four times more expensive -- will be up to the Taipei city government to decide, he added.

Lee Yung-ping, director of the city government's Department of Cultural Affairs, claimed that the fire was most likely caused by arson. Police are still investigating if the Buddhist Fo Kuang University, which has been commissioned by the city government to manage the site since 2002, is guilty of negligence or dereliction of duty.
Lee also said the department has erected pickets around the building to bar trespassers prior to the reconstruction work.

The bureau will film the building materials and structure, restoration and reconstruction process in a documentary, Lee added. All badly burned materials, as well as the wreckage, will be kept for display for future generations to learn about the importance of preserving heritage sites, she added.

The style of the 660-square-meter main building of the chateau, on an estate covering about 1,815 square meters, is typical of Japanese architecture of the 1920s. The wall of the entrance to the main building is made of stone, with a Japanese wooden structure inside.
The April 7 fire destroyed more than half of the main building, with the wooden interior being completely burnt. The stone wall remains intact. Total damage is estimated at roughly NT$36 million.

The city government listed the building as a protected heritage site in 2002 and it has since served as a cultural activity center that encompasses an exhibition hall, a small showroom, a multifunction auditorium, a performance area, a semi-open air coffee shop and a management center. The midnight fire damaged the exhibition hall, known as Meilu Hall, and the coffee shop, known as Yingho Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Killer posted videos to TV station, then returned to shooting spree
The gunman who shot dead 32 people at Virginia Tech university paused during his killing spree to post a video manifesto of his grievances to a television station, it emerged last night.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune : Troubled state of Virginia Tech killer was known in 05
Campus authorities were aware 17 months ago of the troubled mental state of Cho Seung-Hui, an imbalance graphically on display in videos and a manifesto he mailed to NBC News.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MORE EMERGENCY DRILLS: NATIONAL TAIWAN UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) responded positively to an unannounced emergency response test conducted by two lawmakers on its campus Wednesday, but will not allow any more such tests by lawmakers in the school, a university official said Thursday.

Fu Li-cheng, secretary-general of the university, pointed out that the school already has an emergency response mechanism and was alarmed by Wednesday's shooting rampage at Virginia Technology University in the United State, which has sisterhood ties with NTU.
Against this background, Fu said his university was told Wednesday by Ministry of Education (MOE) official Ker Hui-chen that a security test might be carried out on its campus at an unspecified date.

In light of the fact that half of the university's security personnel are contracted workers rather than career police officers, Fu said his school considered Wednesday's test a good chance to examine the school's strengths and weaknesses in maintaining campus security.

Fu said his school appreciates the concerns of media and lawmakers over its security, but had no advance knowledge that the test had been conceived by the two lawmakers, who made a hoax call to the police saying that three NTU students had been taken hostage by gunmen on campus.

The official said the lawmakers and police officers who responded to their hoax call were allowed by university authorities to enter the school Wednesday, but said the university would refuse to allow similar tests in the future.

As a result of the lawmakers' hoax call, 55 police officers equipped with rifles and anti-terrorist gear rushed to the university to handle the purported gunmen, only to be greeted by a crowd of TV cameramen called in by the two lawmakers.

The lawmakers, Lee Chen-nan and Lin Kuo-ching of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, apologized Thursday after being blasted by the media for orchestrating a publicity stunt, fooling the police and causing panic among students.

Ker denied that the MOE played a support role in the two lawmakers' scheme, claiming that all she knew was that the lawmakers, who sit on a legislative committee that controls the ministry's purse strings, wanted to check NTU's security operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GDP EXPECTED TO GROW 4.17 PERCENT IN 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is expected to grow only moderately this year, as the global economic growth will advance at a slower pace than last year, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) predicted Thursday.

CIER researchers forecast that Taiwan's gross domestic product (DGP) will advance 4.17 percent this year, slightly higher than the 4.13 percent that was predicted by the institution late last year, but would be lower than the growth of 4.62 percent posted for 2006.
For 2008, CIER researchers painted a rosier picture, with the DGP growth topping 4.23 percent.

CIER researcher Chou Chi forecast that the 2007 global economic growth will be slower than last year, mainly due to a slower-than-expected U.S. domestic economy, which would reflect a number of negative phenomena, including flat real estate markets.
CIER forecast that consumption in the private sector will grow by 2.8 percent this year, up 1.27 percentage points from the 1.53 percent of 2006.

Domestic investment is seen to grow by 1.82 percent this year, marking a modest growth of 0.2 percent over the year-earlier level, but the substantive domestic investment rate is expected to stand at a low of 15.44 percent this year -- a level still considered too low in this regard.

CIER researchers predicted that domestic investment and export trade of goods and services will all gain momentum in the second half of the year, although private consumption will be unlikely to grow that briskly.

According to a CIER estimate, Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) will register an annual growth of 1.25 percent this year, 0.65 percentage points higher than the year-earlier level, mainly as a result of rising prices of raw materials on the global market.

Meanwhile, the institution forecast that Taiwan's unemployment rate in 2007 will be around 3.91 percent, a slight improvement over the previous year, although the jobless rate is expected to top 4 percent in the third quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESMOND TUTU MEETS FAMILIES OF 228 VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Former Anglican Archbishop of South Africa Desmond Mpilo Tutu met Thursday with family members of victims of Taiwan's 228 Incident of 1947 and said forgiveness is the major road to reconciliation.

Tutu, who became famous during the 1980s as an opponent of apartheid in South Africa and who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984, arrived in Taipei Wednesday with Alexander Boraine, founding father of the International Center for Transitional Justice, for a week-long visit at the invitation of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.

Tutu also visited early Thursday a former execution ground for political prisoners during the period of Taiwan's martial law and the 228 Peace Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei, where he met family members of victims of the 228 Incident, an uprising against the corrupt Kuomintang (KMT) administration that began Feb. 28, 1947, which led to the murder of thousands of civilians.

Tutu told the families of the victims that he was not here to "teach" Taiwan how to resolve the disputes and problems resulting from historical tragedy, but rather to "share" his experiences in this regard.

The method chosen by South Africa was to set up a truth and reconciliation commission to allow the public to know about the reality and to face it, Tutu said, adding that he was glad to hear the stories of the family members of the Taiwanese victims.

Noting that unveiling a country's history and memory is an important beginning, Tutu said allowing the families of the victims to tell their stories is the best way to heal their pain and that in the meantime the country can heal society's pain during the process of pursuing the truth.

He said he saw many South African people who suffered persecution in the past still with anger in their faces and trying to take revenge. However, Tutu added that he saw gentle faces among the Taiwanese sufferers, saying that the suffering of these people brought democracy and human rights to Taiwan.
For his part, Boraine noted that South Africa and Taiwan are far apart geographically but have similar miserable histories and therefore have many voices calling for justice.
Describing the truth as "bitter as herbal medicine," Boraine said however that it can bring healing power to the country and that the process of pursuing the truth can bring hope to the people.

Concluding his visit to the 228 Peace Memorial Hall, Tutu left a note that included the words: "here is acknowledgment of painful history, pray that their beautiful island will become reconciled and healed."

Tutu, who became the first black person to lead the Anglican Church in South Africa Sept. 7, 1986, headed the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission after the end of apartheid. He has also contributed significantly to the safeguarding of democracy and human rights around the world community.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT UPHOLDS RULING FOR PFP CHAIRMAN'S DEFAMATION VICTORY

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court upheld Thursday a ruling of the Taiwan High Court that former President Lee Teng-hui should apologize to James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party, and compensate him for defamation.
The Supreme Court ruled that Lee should run apology ads in three local newspapers for one day and pay NT$2 million (US$60,600) in compensation.

At issue is Lee's insinuation in a public speech that Soong was playing mahjong with friends April 10, 2004 while his followers were fighting with police in a street protest against President Chen Shui-bian's re-election victory the previous month.
Soong filed a defamation suit and the Taipei District Court ruled in November 2005 that Lee should compensate Soong NT$10 million and run ads in nine local newspapers to apologize to him.

The Taiwan High Court ruled in August 2006 that as a former national leader, Lee should know his remarks carry weight, but his insinuation of Soong turning back on his supporters to play mahjong led the public to see Soong as an irresponsible politician, causing him "great emotional distress" and therefore deserving of compensation.
As compensation in previous defamation suits have not exceeded NT$3 million, the high court slashed the amount from NT$10 million to NT$2 million.

In view that the case has been widely publicized, the high court also ruled that the request for running apology ads for three consecutive days in nine local newspapers, which would cost an estimated NT$13 million, should be cut to one day ads on the front pages of three national newspapers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 29TH TOURISM ECONOMY: WTTC

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked the world's 29th largest "tourism economy," with its tourism industry contributing 4.52 percent of its total gross domestic product (GDP) for 2006, an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.

Quoting statistics compiled by the World Travel and Tourism Council (WTCC), the official said that Taiwan had over 3.52 million foreign visitors in 2006, 151,207 of whom came only for sightseeing, an increase of 9.3 percent over the previous year.

Tourists spent US$34.43 billion in 2006, a rise of 5.75 percent year-on-year, higher than the global average of 4.85 percent. Of this amount, direct consumption in transportation, housing and shopping accounted for US$4.19 billion, representing 1.18 percent of the total GDP, according to the statistics, the official said, adding that the amount has helped to create 170,000 jobs.

The official said the tourism industry's good performance indicates that the government's marketing strategy has worked and he added that the CEPD is confident Taiwan tourism will achieve a better ranking in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCIDENTS ON CAMPUS DOWN, BUT BULLYING ON RISE: MOE

TEXT.P: Although the total number of incidents at schools and universities nationwide was down in 2006, the number of reported cases of on-campus bullying was on the rise, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of Education (MOE).

MOE statistics showed that a total of 14,638 incidents were reported last year at all levels of educational facilities around the country, down by 1,190 cases from the 2005 figure. However, the number of incidents involving security maintenance, violence and misconduct accounted for 21.2 percent of the total, or 3,116 cases, which marked a 6.4 percent growth year on year.
Twenty-nine students were killed last year due to on-campus bullying, harassment, extortion, robbery or running away from home, while 1,097 were injured, MOE tallies indicated.
Accidents remained the main cause of student deaths on campus last year, with 648 killed and 7,420 wounded.

The recent shooting that killed more than 30 students and staff by a South Korean student at Virginia Tech in the United States has shocked the entire world, prompting the MOE to stay on high alert against violence on campus.

According to officials from the MOE's Bureau of Students Military Training, the ministry has for some time been running a series of programs aimed at reinforcing order and security at all levels of schools, including the establishment of a contingency monitoring and reporting system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYCOON TO HELP ESTABLISH SCHOOLS FOR CHILDREN IN REMOTE AREAS

TEXT.P: The Yungling Compassionate and Cultural Foundation, established by the chairman of Hong Hai Precision Industry Company, Terry Guo, decided Thursday to spend a fortune to initiate a "hope engineering" project aimed at providing "equal opportunity educations" to children in remote areas.

Guo, founder of the group and one of the 10 richest persons in Taiwan, announced Thursday that he will channel another NT$700 million (US$21.21 million) over the following two years into the foundation to help finance the establishment of schools or after-school classes in rural areas around the island that will enable children in remote areas to access an education that is equal to that available in the cities.
Guo and his daughter, Guo Hsiao-ling, who is chairwoman of the foundation, are scheduled to jointly preside over a ceremony April 22 to mark the opening of the "Hope Schools."

The "Hope Schools" will be established by the Yungling Foundation in cooperation with a charity organization founded by Prof. Lee Chia-tung, National Taitung University and nine other universities around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU TEA GROWERS PROTEST SUBSTANDARD IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Over 1,000 tea growers from Nantou County in central Taiwan are slated to stage a protest Friday in front of the Legislative Yuan against the importation of substandard foreign tea that is seriously threatening their livelihoods.

Lawmaker Lin Yun-sheng, who will lead some 1,600 tea farmers from local townships to demonstrate in front of the Legislative Yuan Friday, said Nantou tea growers want fair competition, but imported low-end foreign products have ruined the home market.
Nantou County is one of Taiwan's major tea production sites, and its Oolong tea is famous around the world.

According to tea farmers from Mingchien township, business losses have amounted to NT$275 million in recent years after at least 24,000 metric tons of foreign- grown tea were imported into Taiwan at low customs rates.

Apart from their financial losses, they said, these substandard foreign goods lack certificates or labels identifying their country-of-origin, or verifying that they have passed strict quarantine controls, and so pose a great risk to the health of Taiwanese consumers.

Lawmaker Tang Huo-shen told a Legislative Yuan news conference early this week that large amounts of cheap foreign tea are being imported into Taiwan everyday, packaged as a locally grown product, and sold on the domestic market.

Last year, more than 25,000 metric tons of tea from China and Vietnam, along with that of other countries, were imported into Taiwan. This low-priced foreign tea, after being disguised as Taiwanese-grown goods, was sold for around NT$350 per kilogram in the domestic market, according to Tang.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTALISTS WARN AGAINST SOME ENERGY-CONSUMING PROJECTS

TEXT.P: If the government approves all major pending development projects, it would become a menace to the world community, several members of a task force commissioned to make environment impact assessment warned Thursday.

Five members of the task force, including Rubin Winkler, Lee Keng-cheng, Hsu Kuang-jung, Chou Chin-cheng and Chan Shun-kuei appealed to the Executive Yuan to make that environment a priority during a news conference. The sixth member, Kuo Hung-yu, although not present, signed his name to the joint written statement.
Members of the task force asked the Executive Yuan not to accommodate the wishes of the big enterprises and turn the task force into a "rubber stamp" that simply endorses development projects.

The task force currently has 21 members comprised of seven members designated by the government, including the minister and vice minister of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), and 14 scholars and experts.
Taiwan, in creating US$1 million worth of gross domestic product, will produce an estimated 8.5 million tons of carbon dioxide, said the members citing statistics released by the EPA,

If several major development projects, including a steel refinery plant, two thermal power plants and one petrochemical park, all pass their environmental impact assessments, emissions of carbon dioxide will surge by 43.44 percent, turning the island into a menace to the world community, which has demonstrated an ever-stronger desire to cut emissions of greenhouse gases. q In addition, water demands associated with major development projects will also be a problem, they said.

An initial estimate shows that water requirements from the industrial sector will increase by 121.7 tons daily to reach 440 million tons annually, equal to the household consumption of nearly 5 million people for the year: an amount equal to all the waters of the Feitsui Reservoir.

Lee expressed concern that additional water for the Central Taiwan Science Park is coming from a reservoir which is being required to cope with the constantly increasing needs of the flat panel factories, and that as factories are being given priority irrigation projects are getting recycled waters. This results in "good water for the industrial sector and poor water for the agricultural sector," Lee claimed.

Chan, concerned about the air quality in central Taiwan, said the area already hosts a thermal power plant, sixth naphtha cracker and the Central Taiwan Science Park. If other development projects, including the Formosa Plastics Group's steel refinery, also pass environmental impact review, the air quality could deteriorate to levels that may compromise public health.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS APOLOGIZES TO NTU, PUBLIC

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) offered an apology Thursday to teachers and students at National Taiwan University (NTU) , and the public, after two DPP lawmakers unexpectedly staged an unauthorized emergency drill on campus a day earlier.
Caucus whips Wang Sing-nan and Wang Tuoh, as well as DPP Legislator Lin Kuo- ching issued the apology during a press conference at the Legislative Yuan.

Wang Sing-nan said that the caucus did not approve of, nor authorize the two lawmakers' call to police with a false report that a gunman had seized two student hostages at NTU to test the police response.

He noted that the lawmakers chose the wrong time to stage the unauthorized drill, which came just days after a student shot 32 people to death before killing himself at Virginia Tech University in the United States.
Wang Tuoh, for his part, stressed that the lawmakers were well-intentioned, but did not think the matter through carefully.

Lin, who initiated the drill with fellow legislator Lee Chen-nan, claimed that they were simply concerned about campus safety and that schools in Taiwan did not conduct drills to guard against terrorist attacks.
Lin apologized to NTU students for causing a disturbance at the university, saying that Lee asked him to go there and that he did not know beforehand that the students were having midterm exams.
Lee did not attend the press conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOUSEHOLD DEBT SITUATION TAKES TURN FOR THE BETTER: CREDIT CO.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's household debt situation will take a turn for the better later this year in light of rising household incomes and other factors, said a credit card company Thursday.

The sitution is easing thanks to a rising per capita income, the continuing appreciation of the New Taiwanese dollar against the U.S. dollar, and a six-year low in the country's unemployment rate -- all of which contribute to a stronger domestic economy, said Wang Yue-hun, a chief researcher with MasterCard Taiwan.

Wang said Taiwan's household debt reached its apex between 2004 and 2005 when each credit card holders held on average four to five credit cards and household debt rose to 95.5 percent of total household income.
In December 2005, said Wang, credit card spending totaled NT$494.7 billion, and by February 2006, about 520,000 consumers faced a combined debt of NT$160 billion in credit or cash card debt.
The situation has noticeably improved since early 2006 in the wake of strong intervention by the government, Wang said.

Wang added that after financial reforms were implemented over the past two years, the overhead and operational costs of lenders and other financial institutions have fallen, which has contributed to shoring up Taiwan's substantive foreign exchange rate competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS PROBES INTO HOAX EMERGENCY DRILL

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang was furious at an unannounced campus emergency drill launched by two lawmakers Wednesday that caused unrest at a local university, Cabinet spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling said Thursday.

Chen made the remarks after ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators Lee Chen-nan and Lin Kuo-ching made a hoax call to police that a gunman had taken two students hostage at National Taiwan University (NTU).

The lawmakers, accompanied by officials from the Ministry of Education (MOE) and the National Police Agency (NPA), claimed at the school that the surprise drill was a test of the university and the police ability to handle such a crisis.

However, Su was furious after learning of the lawmakers' publicity stunt, Chen said, stressing that the act was inappropriate and blaming the lawmakers for forcing education and police officials to cooperate.

In view of an armed student's recent shooting rampage at Virginia Tech university in the United States that claimed 33 lives, Su had already instructed at a Cabinet meeting earlier Wednesday that a set of standard operating procedures be established to protect students' safety, Chen pointed out.
Chen also called on the relevant government agencies to investigate the lawmakers' legal responsibility in causing such chaos and disturbances.
Joyce Feng, dean of NTU's Student Affairs Division, offered her apology after students complained about being startled by the drill, which was held during the school's midterm exam week.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS MAY BE ABSENT FROM VOTE ON KEY BILLS

TEXT.P: Despite a keen desire on the part of the Kuomintang (KMT) that they join forces in a vote Friday on two key bills in a legislative committee, People First Party (PFP) lawmakers said Thursday that they may absent themselves from the vote if the KMT fails to keep its promise regarding upcoming elections.

PFP legislative caucus whip Feng Ting-kuo made the comments after the KMT issued a call earlier the same day urging PFP lawmakers to attend the Procedure Committee meeting and help their KMT peers defeat two key draft bills that are of great concern to the KMT.

The two bills, initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , target the main opposition KMT's assets and could rule out former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's presidential bid. They were successfully placed on the committee's agenda Monday during the absence of PFP and Non-Partisan Solidarity Union lawmakers.
According to Feng, the matter is simple, so long as the KMT lives up to its promise to allot to the PFP 10 regional and three at-large seats in December's legislative elections.
"Should the KMT honor its promise, there will be room for the PFP to alter its decision," Feng said.

PFP lawmaker Wu Ching-chih called on the KMT to stop trying to deceive his party, and voiced his discontent, asking how the KMT could turn a blind eye to the agreement reached late last year with the PFP.
An unidentified PFP lawmaker said that they might not attend the meeting, or might not vote, if the KMT refuses to honor its pledge.
"All PFP legislators will act in concert regarding Friday's vote in the Procedure Committee, based on a consensus that will be reached that same day by the central committee," he said.

KMT officials, including Secretary-General Wu Duen-yih, and legislative caucus whip Hsu Shao-ping, are still pinning their hopes on the PFP and called for continued cooperation at this critical moment despite apparent rows arising from the upcoming elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANIHA PUBLISHES PHOTO ALBUM RECORDING TAIWAN' HUMANITARIAN AID

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Health Action (TaiwanIHA), a government-funded organization to offer international medical aid, published Thursday a photo album recording Taiwan's medical humanitarian aid to foreign countries from 2000 through 2006.

Minister of Health Hou Sheng-mao, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang, Executive Director of the International Center for Migration and Health (ICMH) Manuel Carballo, and several foreign envoys stationed in Taiwan attended the launch of the album, titled "Passion and Care," at MOFA's personnel training center in Taipei.

Hou said the establishment of the TaiwanIHA was a concrete reflection of Taiwan's contribution to the world community, which he said has significantly strengthened Taiwan's relations with other countries.
Huang said Taiwan is striving to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as a full member, and expressed the hope that the world community will extend its support to Taiwan's bid.

Peter Chang, director of the Bureau of International Cooperation of the Department of Health, said since the TaiwanIHA's inception in 2006, it has sent medical delegations to extend aid in more than 10 disasters, including tsunami- struck areas in South Asia and the Solomon Islands, a landslide in the Philippines, earthquake in Indonesia, and flood in Kenya.

According to Chang, during its recent trip to the Solomon Islands, the boat carrying workers from TaiwanIHA and other international humanitarian aid organizations ran aground on the way to the country's capital.
Despite of this and other hazards, Taiwan will not hesitate to extend its helping hand to other countries in need, Chang stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN', 'REPUBLIC OF CHINA' APPEAR ON SAME SET OF STAMPS

TEXT.P: "Taiwan" and the country's official title, "Republic of China", will appear together for the first time on the same set of local stamps, slated for launch April 25, executives from Taiwan Post Co. said Thursday.
This will be the last time that Taiwan's official title will appear on stamps issued by the state-owned company, the executives said.

New York Times:In Reversal, Justices Back Ban on Method of Abortion
The Supreme Court reversed course on abortion on Wednesday, upholding the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act in a 5-to-4 decision that promises to reframe the abortion debate and define the young Roberts court.
The most important vote was that of the newest justice, Samuel A. Alito Jr. In another 5-to-4 decision seven years ago, his predecessor, Justice Sandra Day OConnor, voted to strike down a similar state law. Justice Alitos vote to uphold the federal law made the difference in the outcome announced Wednesday.
Wall Street Journal:As Mumbai Grows, Commuter Trains Turn Deadly
There was a time, just a few years ago, when Jagdish Malwankar had no problem getting a seat on the Valsad express commuter train that takes him to work in the city center.
Today, Mumbai's trains are so overcrowded that one morning in January when he stumbled getting off a train, 10 people fell on him and he broke his foot. Another day recently, in the crush to board, fellow commuters shoved him onto the tracks. Two train cars passed over him before anyone noticed he had fallen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANIHA PUBLISHES PHOTO ALBUM RECORDING TAIWAN' HUMANITARIAN AID

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Health Action (TaiwanIHA), a government-funded organization to offer international medical aid, published Thursday a photo album recording Taiwan's medical humanitarian aid to foreign countries from 2000 through 2006.

Minister of Health Hou Sheng-mao, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang, Executive Director of the International Center for Migration and Health (ICMH) Manuel Carballo, and several foreign envoys stationed in Taiwan attended the launch of the album, titled "Passion and Care," at MOFA's personnel training center in Taipei.

Hou said the establishment of the TaiwanIHA was a concrete reflection of Taiwan's contribution to the world community, which he said has significantly strengthened Taiwan's relations with other countries.
Huang said Taiwan is striving to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as a full member, and expressed the hope that the world community will extend its support to Taiwan's bid.

Peter Chang, director of the Bureau of International Cooperation of the Department of Health, said since the TaiwanIHA's inception in 2006, it has sent medical delegations to extend aid in more than 10 disasters, including tsunami- struck areas in South Asia and the Solomon Islands, a landslide in the Philippines, earthquake in Indonesia, and flood in Kenya.

According to Chang, during its recent trip to the Solomon Islands, the boat carrying workers from TaiwanIHA and other international humanitarian aid organizations ran aground on the way to the country's capital.
Despite of this and other hazards, Taiwan will not hesitate to extend its helping hand to other countries in need, Chang stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 20, or the fourth day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muslims and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The U.S. Congress officially separates the western part of the Michigan Territory, creating a new zone known as the Wisconsin Territory.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor as well as Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, house painter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and was the architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt removes the United States from the gold standard.
1944: Britain's Royal Air Force drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Headquarters is established, with Gen. Sun Li- jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests against nuclear testing by the Soviet Union.
1968: Pierre Elliot Trudeau of the Liberal Party becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 U.S. military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and mainland China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to mainland China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to cooperate on increasing nuclear safety.
1999: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture rejects a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei denies a U.S. media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium range missiles.
2000: Central News Agency President Bill Wang says that CNA will shortly add a commercial information databank to its Internet services.
2000: National Yang Ming University President Tseng Chih-lang announces that he has decided to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer of the post of education minister in the new administration.
2001: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono announces that Japan will issue a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to seek medical treatment for his heart condition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."

DOC.HEADLINE: EU ENVOY URGES TAIWAN TO INVEST MORE IN EUROPE

TEXT.P: Taiwan is welcome to invest more in Europe as the continent has emerged as the world's largest single market with terrific profitability, the new representative of the 25-state European Union (EU) in Taiwan said Friday.

Guy Ledoux, head of the European Economic and Trade Office in Taiwan, which represents EU interests here, pointed out that while the EU is now Taiwan's largest foreign investor, Taiwan's investment in European countries is comparatively low.
According to Ledoux, accumulated EU investment in Taiwan has roughly hit 11.5 billion euro (US$15.64 billion), surpassing the amount invested by either the United States or Japan.

Ledoux said that in contrast, it seems to him that Taiwanese entrepreneurs remain very cautious about launching investment projects in the EU To the best of his knowledge, Ledoux said, Taiwan even lags behind the Philippines in terms of EU investments. He didn't provide exact figures.

On the trade front, Ledoux said Taiwan remains one of the EU's major trading partners, with two-way trade reaching 40 billion euro for 2006, compared to 46 billion euro in EU-India trade and 44 billion euro in EU-Brazil trade.

Looking forward, Ledoux said Taiwan-EU trade will continue to expand in 2007 after posting growth of 6.8 percent last year. In 2006, Ledoux said, Taiwan registered an increase of 10 percent in its exports to the EU, but its imports from the 25-state trade bloc only grew 1.5 percent.
Ledoux said he will give priority to bolstering trade and investment between the EU and Taiwan, with reinforced intellectual property rights (IPR) protection as the primary theme.
On Thursday, Ledoux delivered his first public speech since taking office here six weeks ago at a lunch meeting of the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (ECCT).

Ledoux said in that speech that Taiwan is heading in the right direction with regards to improving IPR protection. However, he added, there are also less encouraging moves, such as compulsory licensing.
Noting that his office will aim to tackle restrictive trade measures adopted by local government authorities, Ledoux said he will step up communications with them to facilitate his work.

While the EU is negotiating bilateral free trade agreements (FTAs) with its key trade partners, including South Korea, India and ASEAN, Ledoux told ECCT members that it will be some time before the EU is able to evaluate the feasibility of signing a similar pact with Taiwan.

Factors affecting the possibility of an FTA being signed between Taiwan and the EU include whether European companies see any need for or benefits from such a deal and whether Taiwan's government is interested in signing such an accord, Ledoux explained.

In his speech, Ledoux also mentioned another task on his agenda, namely urging Taiwan to sign the Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) , which he said would allow European corporations to bid for government tenders in Taiwan as well as give their Taiwanese counterparts access to European government projects.

Taiwan had promised to join the GPA before its accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2002, but it has had difficulties delivering on that promise because of opposition from China over terminology to be used in the contract.

Due to China's reluctance to recognize Taiwan's sovereign status, Taiwan has been unable to conclude GPA negotiations with other WTO members as the issues regarding the titles of its government agencies have not been resolved.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials have said that the government can be flexible with regard to the form of Taiwan's participation in the GPA, but it cannot afford to budge on the nomenclature issue.

"We deserve the same treatment as other member states and will only join the GPA on the condition that our national dignity and sovereignty remain intact, " an official with the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs said earlier this year.
On this issue, Ledoux said he believes that any disputes surrounding the GPA can be settled through negotiations.

Born in Strasbourg, France, Ledoux joined the European Commission-- the EU's executive arm -- in 1990. He has held a number of posts in trade and foreign relations in the Asia Department, the Middle East Department and the European Neighborhood Policy Department. He has also served in Tunisia and South Korea as deputy head of mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY TO U.S. MEETS WITH TAIWAN-FRIENDLY MEMBERS OF CONGRESS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) 04/20/07 13:24:54 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, paid courtesy calls on two leaders of the U.S. Congress Taiwan Caucus Thursday to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
Wu, who formally assumed his post in Washington, D.C. Monday, met with Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) and Shelley Berkley (D-Nev.) at their respective offices on Capitol Hill.
Wu said that although differences exist on certain issues between Taiwan and the United States, Taipei is determined to consult and communicate with Washington in a "frank and sincere manner."

As to Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) and to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States, Wu said that although both goals "may appear impossible at the moment, " he is undaunted by the task and will relentlessly pursue these goals.

Wu said he explained to the two Taiwan Caucus leaders that the the U.S.-South Korea FTA, signed earlier this month, has put Taiwan at a disadvantage and that it will undermine Taiwan's economic development.

Wu expressed his strong wish that the U.S. Congress will bear in mind the "deep and wide" business and trade relations between Taiwan and the United States and push for the signing of an FTA between the two sides.

He further said that in their meeting, Chabot told him that a U.S-Taiwan FTA is in the best interests of the United States and that many members of Congress from both the Democratic and Republican parties are interested in pursuing such a pact.
On the issue of Taiwan's plan to bid for entry into the WHO as a full member under the name "Taiwan, " Chabot said it's "high time" for Taiwan to do so, according to Wu.

Unfortunately, Wu continued, Chabot further said that the People's Republic of China has persistently obstructed Taiwan's bid but that he and other Taiwan Caucus members will nevertheless continue to make efforts relentlessly toward that goal despite the fact that just getting the State Department's support will be a major challenge.

For her part, Berkley told Wu that she and other Taiwan Caucus co-chairs will jointly initiate a proposal shortly to urge the Bush administration to begin working on matters regarding the signing of an FTA with Taiwan and that she anticipates that other members of the caucus will also join the effort in the near future.

Berkley added that three other Taiwan Caucus co-chairs -- Representatives Robert Wexler (D-FLa.) , Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) and Steve Chabot -- will all sign the proposal to push the Bush administration to take concrete steps toward forging an FTA with Taiwan.

On Taiwan's latest plan to seek to join the WHO as a full member under the name "Taiwan, " Berkley told Wu that it is a critical issue as all of Taiwan's 23 million people are entitled to that right and privilege, adding that she supports the "Taiwan" initiative and will try her utmost to help Taiwan reach that goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
NOBEL LAUREATE TUTU TALKS ABOUT RECONCILIATION DURING TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: On an eight-day visit in Taiwan, former South African Anglican Church Archbishop Desmond Mpilo Tutu said he was shaken by the size of a mound that grew out of the soil one shovel scoop at a time to cover the bloodshed of countless shooting executions in the early period of Kuomintang rule, at a site which is now known as Machangting Memorial Park.
"The height [of the mound] is very telling, for it indicates just how many people were shot there. It is a silent but very powerful image," he said.

The 1984 Nobel Peace Prize winner who made a great contribution to ending apartheid in South Africa and facilitating reconciliation made the remarks in an interview with members of the press at the Grand Hotel in Taipei Thursday afternoon during his visit in Taiwan which has been organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy with the theme of transitional justice.

Tutu said he has no specific advice for Taiwan regarding transitional justice but hopes that "the people will learn some of the lessons we learnt, such as that you cannot go on as a country unless you acknowledge your past."

Presented with a question regarding historical truth often being vulnerable to manipulation by politicians, Tutu expressed his confidence in society's ability to find out and face its unpleasant past.

"There are people like ourselves, scholars, and many others, who are able to put forward a correct version of history, and to point out in fact that it does not help to try to deceive yourself, " he said.

"The best way is to look at your past very firmly in the eyes. We need to look at the beast in the eye, then we'll have the opportunity to advance. Otherwise, the beast of the dark past will return to haunt us," he said.

He said that he found that elements of the stories of Taiwan's 228 Incident and White Terror told to him by victims and their family members whom he met with that day echoed what he experienced and saw in South Africa as well as Northern Ireland.
"People tend to think that victims are angry, nurse grudges and are prepared to get revenge. However, the victims I met with have gentle faces, are generous, and really want to move on," he said.

"I think most of all it's the dignity of these people that makes them such an impressive group of people, " he said, adding that the point is that these people want to know what really happened to their loved ones and that it is important that this need is met.
Asked whether he thinks South Africa has moved on, Tutu said that it has, "to some extent."

"We have not arrived at a destination, but reconciliation is not a just destination, it is also a journey. It is a process in which every single one of us is expected to make a contribution, " he explained.

South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) takes an approach that, described by Tutu in his 1999 book "No Future Without Forgiveness", neither seeks a large-scale pursuit of former perpetrators, like what happened in Nuremburg, Germany after World War II, nor simply opts to forget about the past like countries such as Chile did. Instead, the South African system requires that those who participated in repression fully confess to their deeds in the TRC hearings, face-to-face with the victims and their families, in order to be entitled to a pardon.

When it comes to forgiveness on the victim's part, Tutu said, it is not to be expected that those who have suffered will suddenly "like" those who did evil to them. The idea is that "if you don't forgive, you're locking yourself into a position where you're always a victim. But if you're ready to forgive, you're not an object, you're active, and the initiative is yours. You're in charge, " he said.
He further said that he believes people eventually find out the facts. "It is much better and easier to be friends than to be enemies, and peace is much cheaper than war," he added.

Tutu denied a media report that he had not visited Taiwan during the last 12 years due to pressure from China. "No, I am not aware of that, " he replied when asked about the report, saying he has the freedom to talk about any issues, such as Tibet and the Dalai Lama, and will not be stopped by people who try to tell him what not to do.

DOC.HEADLINE: BITTER RIVALRY DOES NOT HELP DPP'S ELECTION CHANCES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called for unity Friday among the four contenders vying to become the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) 2008 presidential candidate, saying that bitter rivalry will not help the DPP win the election.
Chen said unity is the one and only option for the DPP to pursue ahead of the 2008 presidential race.
He described rivals as "mirrors" from which the DPP aspirants can discover their own shortcomings, adding that competition helps broaden people's vision and breadth of mind.
The president said that bitter campaign moves and rhetoric will not make the contenders more popular, adding that they are also unacceptable to DPP members and the contenders' supporters.

Chen called for the four contenders -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- not to underestimate the wisdom and determination of the voters who support the DPP.

Saying that internal competition within the DPP should not be turned into contradiction between the ruling and opposition parties and that temporary rivals should not become eternal enemies, Chen pointed out that only when people know how to "yield" can they manage to "obtain" and only when they are willing to forgo the interests of "their small selves" can they make "big achievements" for the country.

Chen said that only one of the four aspirants will be selected to be the DPP's presidential candidate but that this final decision will not represent victory for only that one person chosen or defeat for the other three. Rather, he said, producing a successful DPP candidate who has the best chance of winning the 2008 presidential race will represent a victory for the whole party as well as for Taiwan's democracy.
The period leading up to the DPP primary is a time when the four aspirants' wisdom and cultivation will be tested, Chen stressed.

Chen is scheduled to travel to the southern city of Chiayi Saturday to listen to the second televised presentation during which the four DPP aspirants will present their views on how to govern the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF TO HOLD TOUR ACTIVITIES FOR CHINESE SPOUSES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will hold a series of social activities for Chinese spouses of Taiwanese citizens to make counseling on everyday life issues available, beginning with a garden party to be held at the end of May in Taichung in central Taiwan, SEF Legal Affairs Director Ho Wu-liang said Friday.

The party follows up on a counseling seminar held in March to help Chinese spouses cope with the challenges they face finding a job or residence, acquiring an identification card, or accessing medical services, Ho said, adding that the SEF will hold other such activities after the garden party.

Ho said the social gatherings allow local officials to learn what problems Chinese spouses have adjusting to life in Taiwan, and to improve services for them. For instance, the Employment Services Center under the Council of Labor Affairs can provide job information to those who already have working qualifications, but needs to overcome any particular barriers that may exist, Ho added.

The SEF initiated a special telephone line in October 2006 to offer counseling and legal services to Chinese spouses, and since then many spouses have made use of this service to seek help from the SEF, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI SENDS BLANKETS, RELIEF GOODS TO PHILIPPINE FIRE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation has twice this month airlifted blankets and other relief goods to the Philippines to help victims of a disastrous fire that occurred in a slum near Manila in early April, a Tzu Chi source said Friday.

Tzu Chi -- Taiwan's largest charity organization -- airlifted 2,000 blankets to the Philippines on April 12. Transportation was provided free of charge thanks to the chairman of the Philippine Airlines, Lucio Tan, who is a Tzu Chi volunteer, the Tzu Chi official said.
Tzu Chi sent another batch of 3,000 blankets and 5,000 packs of first-aid/relief goods to Manila April 14, again aboard a free PA liner provided by Tan.
The slum fire left residents of over 3,000 households homeless, according to Tzu Chi.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY, COUNTY CHIEFS URGED TO SET ASIDE BIKE LANE ON ROAD

TEXT.P: An environmental group called Friday for people in Taipei city and county to write their administrators asking that a bicycle lane on urban roads be set aside to allow cyclists to ride safely to work every day.

The group, which is campaigning for a drive to build a 1-thousand mile trail encircling the island, made the call while announcing an activity slated for April 22 in downtown Taipei to mark Earth Day, observed around the world as a day to raise public awareness of environmental issues.

It is hoped that the "422 Bike on Road" activity will inspire Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei to demonstrate an appreciation of cyclists' need for safe lanes in which to ride, the group's executives said, noting that they will propose during the Sunday event that authorities list bicycles as a class of vehicles permitted to travel on the road.
They will also urge authorities to erase the word of "motor" from the definition of "vehicles" in the existing regulations on road traffic.

At the same time, they will ask city and county governments to build a bike traffic network in the greater Taipei area to facilitate commuting, said the executives who also pointed to "green transportation" as part of the solution to reducing environmental pollution and conserving energy.

The "Bike on Road" event is scheduled to begin at 2: 30 p.m. at the National Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei, with participants from there expected to ride on major roads throughout the capital city.

Even as President Arroyo has committed the full support of the government, United States authorities preferred to wait for the arrival of American pathologists within the week before an autopsy is conducted on the body of American Peace Corps volunteer Julia Campbell.
