Six road workers kidnapped by Abu Sayyaf extremists were found beheaded Thursday in Jolo. The severed heads of the six mostly-Christian workers were found in the jungles of Jolo by soldiers, four days after the workers were seized.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Despite U.S. buildup, 233 slain in Iraq
Suspected Sunni insurgents penetrated the Baghdad security net Wednesday, hitting Shiite targets with four bomb attacks that killed 183 people-the bloodiest day since the U.S. troop increase began nine weeks ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU UNVEILS TOUR PACKAGES FEATURING LATE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Despite the ongoing controversy in Taiwan society surrounding the late President Chiang Kai-shek's legacy, the Tourism Bureau came up Friday with tour packages featuring Chiang in an attempt to lure more Chinese tourists to the country.

The bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communication produced the tour packages in response to an April 11 proposal made by Legislator Yeh Yi-jin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who suggested during a question-and- answer session at the Legislative Yaun that government authorities draw up Chiang-related tour packages exclusively catering to Chinese tourists as everything connected with Chiang is of great interest to them, tourism officials said.

The packages involve some of Chiang's well-known residences around the country, including the Jiaobanshan resort park in northern Taoyuan County, the Shihlin Official Residence in Taipei City, the Hsitsu Bay Chateau in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, the Chengching Building in Kaohsiung City, the Tsuenta Chateau in central Nantou County and the Yangming Chateau in suburban Taipei , according to the officials.

A tourism operator quoted recent tallies as showing that a total of 15,800 Chinese tourists visited Taiwan during the first quarter of this year, down 18 percent from the same period of last year. The decline is possibly due to a new measure requiring that Chinese citizens traveling to Taiwan in tour groups pay at least US$80 per day for boarding and lodging, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesG Scientists prove that salty diet costs lives
Eating less salt reduces the chances of suffering a heart attack or stroke, the first long-term study of salts impact on health confirms today.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PLANS TO UPGRADE MACHINE TOOL INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Eyeing the great potential of Taiwan's machine tool and component industries, the government will allocate NT$630 million (US$19.09 million) over the next four years as part of a plan to enhance the sector's global competitiveness, government officials said Friday.

Based on recent developments, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) forecasts that the annual production of machine tool and parts industries will both reach NT$340 billion by 2015.

In 2006, the overall machinery sector was expected to have a total output of NT$800 billion, and it is hoped to become the next trillion dollar industry, following the semiconductor and color monitor industries, IDB officials said.

The machine tool industry, which plays a crucial role in the overall machinery sector, generated a record high production value of more than NT$100 billion in 2005, officials indicated, adding that this splendid performance pushed the development of machinery components industry to even higher output values, exceeding NT$100 billion in 2005 and NT$125 billion in 2006.

With a view to still greater developments in the promising sector, the IDB plans to initiate an upgrading project, which it hopes will make Taiwan one of the world's three largest manufacturers of machinery components, and the main research and development center for advanced and high-precision machinery components in Asia, the officials said.
The IDB predicted that the project will help establish in Taiwan 10 flagship machine tool enterprises with a production value of more than NT$10 billion each.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Corriere della Sera: Fassino to push for formation of new democratic party.
Secretary General of the Left Democratic Party Piero Fassino announced at the party's congress Thursday to push for the formation of a new democratic party. The head of the largest party in the center-left ruling coalition said that the proposed democratic party is a historical need.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE DARK HOUR' REDUCES CO2 POLLUTION BY 100,000 TONS: TAIPOWER

TEXT.P: Nationwide 1.75 megawatts of electricity were conserved around noon Friday, over and above the amount conserved April 16, the result of a variety of factors, including a"turn-off-the-lights for one hour" campaign, according to the state- owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower).

The additional electrical savings translate into a reduction of 100,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide, comparable to the amount of carbon dioxide that an area of forest covering 442 meters squared would absorb in a year, Taipower officials said.
Quoting islandwide records of electrical consumption, Taipower authorities said that energy use decreased by 56.17 MW islandwide at 12:18 p.m., down from the peak posted on 12 noon of the same day.
By comparison, they said, electrical consumption decreased by 54.42 MW islandwide at 12: 24 p.m. on April 16, down from the peak at 12 noon of the same day.
April 16 was chosen as a basis of comparison because the weather patterns of that day were similar to Friday's weather conditions, they added.

Taipower officials said that the "turn-off-the-lights for one hour" campaign can be considered one of the contributing factors behind the greater decrease in electrical consumption on Friday, compared to April 16.
They said daily energy consumption is determined by a variety of reasons, including weather conditions and the brightness of the day.

Legislator Tien Chiu-chin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party proposed several days ago that Taiwan public should take part in a "turn-off-the-lights for one hour" campaign, switching lights, air conditioners and electrical equipment off from noon to 1 p.m. April 20 in a bid to lessen consumption of energy.

The campaign is part of efforts to mark the April 22 Earth Day, observed around the globe to raise awareness of the environment, particularly at a time when additional efforts are being made around the world to help slow global warming, which scientists attribute to the greenhouse effect, which is a direct result of emissions of carbon dioxide and fossil fuel pollutants.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: China's 11% growth fuels fears of overheating.
China's gross domestic product (GDP) grew 11.1 per cent in the first three months of the year, raising new worries about excesses in an economy that grew by more than 10 per cent for four straight years.
The Lianhe Zaobao: "World.Singapore " formula will upgrade Singapore's development.
Singapore government unveiled new growth formula "World.Singapore" to drive and upgrade the city-state's development.
This new growth formula unveiled by Defense Minister who in charge of the Civil Service, Teo Chee Hean yesterday in the two-day Economic Development Board's 9th International Advisory Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA SLAPS FINES ON ONLINE SALE OF UNLICENSED ENVIRONMENTAL CHEMICALS

TEXT.P: The Environmental Administration (EPA) has imposed fines on 10 individuals for trying to sell unlicensed environmental chemicals online, an EPA official said Friday.

Chen Shu-ling, a section chief with the EPA's Department of Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Substance Management, said the 10 people are repeat offenders who tried to sell unlicensed environmental chemicals through the Yahoo-Kimo and PChome online auction networks.
She added that first-time offenders would usually receive a written admonishment from the EPA, but for repeat offenders, the EPA would likely level fines varying from NT$60,000 to NT$300,000.

Chen said some of the cases involved individuals and pet shop owners who bought mosquito repellent incense and cockroach bait during holiday trips to Japan and then tried to sell their leftover chemicals via the online auction.

The environmental official added that in several cases, the EPA had to mete out harsh fines because the offenders had exaggerated the effectiveness of the unlicensed chemicals in their promotional descriptions, thereby violating regulations governing toxic environmental chemicals.

According to Chen, under Taiwanese law, each passenger is allowed to carry one kilogram of licensed or unlicensed environmental chemicals through the customs by declaring the items on a clearance form.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MA EXCLUSION BILL' FAILS AT LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: A draft amendment to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law pushed by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers failed Friday at the legislative Procedure Committee after opposition parties joined forces to reject it.

The draft bill, widely assumed to target main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) former Chairman Ma Ying-jeou as it would effectively ban him from running in the next presidential race, was blocked by KMT lawmakers and their allies in the People First Party (PFP) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) by a vote of 100 to 97 in favor of a KMT proposal that the committee meeting be adjourned.

PFP legislative caucus whip Fu Kun-chi said caucus members agreed to back the KMT's proposal after the KMT demonstrated good faith earlier the same day with regards to cooperation between the two parties in December's legislative elections and the 2008 presidential election.
PFP lawmaker Feng Ting-kuo said that the KMT has two weeks to delve into the issue pertaining to KMT-PFP cooperation in the coming elections.

If the KMT fails to live up to promises made late last year on the allotment of 10 regional and three at-large seats to the PFP in the year-end legislative election, PFP lawmakers will not attend the next meeting of the Procedure Committee, making it possible for the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), to again place the draft amendment on the agenda, Feng said.

The KMT has struggled since Thursday to persuade PFP and NPSU lawmakers to join forces with the KMT to block the bill in Friday's Procedure Committee meeting from being put forth for a second reading.

Along with the bill aimed at preventing Ma from taking part in the next presidential election, another TSU-proposed bill targeting the KMT's assets was also barred from being assigned for a second reading.
In the face of the two bills' failure at the Procedure Committee, DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming accused the KMT of "working for its own destruction."

TSU legislative caucus whip Tseng Tsahn-deng called the obstruction by the KMT and the PFP "a shame" that renders each "a laughingstock." He then blasted the two parties for "covering up a corrupt criminal."

Ma was indicted in mid-February by Taipei prosecutors on corruption charges in a case related to his alleged embezzlement of some NT$11 million in funds from a special monthly municipal allowance earmarked for his discretionary use during his two terms as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

Ma has reiterated his strong desire to pursue the presidency despite the corruption charges, prompting the DPP to submit the proposed amendment to ban individuals convicted in the first trial from participating in presidential elections.
The Taipei District Court has opened two hearings on Ma's case since early this month. Ma pleaded not guilty and defended himself during the sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WINNER MEETS WITH VP

TEXT.P: Visiting former South African Anglican Church Archbishop Desmond Mpilo Tutu -- the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize winner -- visited the Presidential Office Friday, where he received a warm welcome from Vice President Annette Lu.

During the meeting, Lu informed Tutu of her ongoing campaign for the ruling party nomination to run in the 2008 presidential election and expressed confidence that she would win the battle. In return, Tutu gave his blessing while observing that her male rivals may have to be careful.

Lu told Tutu, who won the Nobel Prize for his contribution to ending apartheid in South Africa and facilitating reconciliation, that she was a member of an international election monitoring group that observed the first fully-demoratic presidential election in South Africa in 1994.
During the trip, Lu said she witnessed how ethnic conflicts were settled in South Africa and how a new country was born in democracy.

Mentioning Tutu's visit the previous day to a historic site marking the 228 Incident of 1947 -- one of the bloodiest chapters in Taiwan's history -- the vice president said although the historic wound remains in the heart of local people, nonetheless they remain tolerant, peace-loving and dedicated to justice.

During the 1949-1987 period, while the Kuomintang regime imposed martial law, she and many other democratic activists were jailed for many years. At the time, no one would have thought that 20 years later, a defense counsel for eight defendants charged with insurrection before a military court would be inviting one of those "insurgents, " to stand for the presidential and vice presidential election and help bring a peaceful, democratic end to that authoritarian regime. Lu was referring to President Chen Shui-bian's invitation of her to team up for the 2000 presidential election.

Tutu said that during his current visit to the island once called Formosa, he feels that there is no hatred in the hearts of family members of the 228 Incident victims. He blessed Taiwan's people, wishing them a peaceful and more harmonious future.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS' PARTY STILL IN PLANNING STAGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Farmers' Association (TFA) Secretary-General Chang Yung-chen said Friday that the association is still considering whether or not to form a farmers' party and has not yet come to a decision.

Chang made the remarks after press reports stated that TFA members will unite with other local farmers' groups to organize their own political party to protest against politicians' long-term ignorance of their interests.
The TFA, which has some 1.8 million members, has been traditionally supportive of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
According to press reports, TFA members plan to field their own candidates for the year-end legislative election.

Responding to the report, Chang said they have not yet decided to form a party, but are considering whether or not farmers around the country should establish a profesional party that differs from the traditional political parties by focusing only on their particular areas of interest, much like the Green Party in Germany.

Chang added that if they really do form a party, they will only seek at-large legislative seats to safeguard the well-being of farmers and will not compete with the country's major political parties for constituency seats; he went on to urge the ruling and opposition parties not to panic over their possible moves.
Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said the same day that the KMT should carefully observe the possible developments with regard to the proposal of farmers forming their own party.
TFA members are reportedly dissatisfied with KMT lawmakers as they have neglected agricultural policies and are not actively promoting bills related to farmers' well-being.

Noting that TFA's movement may diminish the KMT's odds of victory in upcoming elections and its popularity among its grass-root supporters, Wang urged the party's authorities to manage prudently the issue. Wang is a former KMT vice chairman.

Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Wu Po-hsiung said he was not aware of the farmers party proposal and will seek to become better informed on the point. At the same time, however, Wu denied that the KMT has not paid much attention to agricultural affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP REACH INITIAL AGREEMENT ON LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS: PFP

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has agreed to allot five constituencies to be managed by its ally, the People First Party (PFP) , in December's legislative elections, PFP officials said Friday.

The preliminary agreement came after a group of PFP lawmakers led by Chang Hsien-yao, who also serves as director of the party's central policy center, held talks earlier that day with KMT officials prior to a legislative Procedure Committee meeting, in which the KMT needed PFP collaboration to block two bills that are of major concern to it, according to PFP sources.

During the talks, KMT Secretary-General Wu Duen-yih signed a document agreeing to allocate five constituencies for the PFP to run in the year-end legislative elections, the sources said, adding that the two parties will hold more talks in the coming two weeks on cooperation in the remaining constituencies.
It is hoped that all this will help avoid a split between the two parties and secure victory for both parties in future elections, the sources said.

Later in the day, the two draft bills submitted by the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), were rejected by lawmakers of the KMT, the PFP and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union in the committee meeting, crushing "pan-green" efforts to send them to the respective committees for further screening.

The first DPP-proposed bill sought to ban those who are convicted in the first trial from taking part in the country's presidential elections and the second, put forward by the TSU, sought to force the KMT to return its ill-gotten assets to the national coffers.
The first is apparently aimed at former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, a likely and strong candidate to represent the KMT in the next presidential race despite embezzlement charges against him.
Wu admitted that the two parties had reached agreement in some areas with regard to the coming elections, saying that the KMT is "cautiously optimistic" about the outcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CHINA-BOUND INVESTMENT EXCEEDED US$2 BILLION IN Q1: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwanese investment in China reached US$2.08 billion in the first three months of this year, an increase of 17.79 percent over the year-earlier level, according to statistics released Friday by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The Investment Commission approved a total of 258 China-bound investment projects by Taiwanese entrepreneurs during the January-March period.

Meanwhile, a total of 466 inbound investment projects by foreign and overseas Taiwanese investors were approved by the MOEA for an amount of US$1.508 billion during the same period, a decrease of 72.62 percent over the same period of last year.

MOEA officials attributed the drop in foreign direct investment partly to the unusual high amount recorded in the first quarter of last year due to Philips Taiwan's transfer of its shares in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. to its mother company.
If that sale was excluded, foreign direct investment during the first three months registered a 14.38 percent drop over the same period of last year, the officials added.

The number of Taiwan's overseas investment projects excluding China totaled 119 during the period, for a volume of US$508 million, adecrease of 21.34 percent over the year-earlier level, according to MOEA statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE TO BUDGET NT$2.6 BILLION FOR DISADVANTAGED STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education is working on a plan that will budget NT$2.6 billion (US$78.46 million) to help 210,000 disadvantaged students at private universities and colleges from 2008, Political Vice Minister of Education Lu Mu- lin announced Friday.
Lu made the announcement while explaining the government's responsibilities in taking care of disadvantaged students at a seminar held by the Association of Private Universities and Colleges.

The special budget to be taken from the government's subsidies to private schools will be used for students whose family income ranks in the bottom 40 percent of the country, Lu said, adding that the MOE's Department of Higher Education is working on ratings for the subsidy amounts.
Subsidies for disadvantaged students in public universities and colleges will be covered by the schools' own budgets, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POP GROUP F4 EXPECTED TO DRAW 5,000 JAPANESE, KOREAN FANS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Local pop group F4, which has been named as representative of Taiwan's tourist industry this year, has attracted nearly 5,000 fans from Japan and Korea hoping to meet their idols April 22 at National Taiwan University's sports center, an official of the Tourism Bureau said Friday.
The fans will create about NT$100 million-worth of sightseeing revenue for Taiwan, according to a bureau estimate.
F4 will perform and interact with their fans, the official said, adding that the bureau has provided a prize of another meeting tour with F4 to attract more tourists.

Quoting statistics compiled by the bureau, the official said Japanese tourists made 1.16 million visits to Taiwan and Koreans made 196,260 visits. The bureau hopes to attract more visitors from these two countries using the attraction of F4 as a draw.
The bureau will air F4's meeting with fans via the Internet at www.im.tv/myvlog/JVKVtaiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICTIM IN MOCK BANK ROBBERY SEEKING COMPENSATION FROM CHINATRUST

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation is intervening on behalf of a young woman to seek compensation from Chinatrust Commercial Bank for the trauma she suffered as a result of a January mock bank robbery that she believed was real at the time.

Foundation Chairman Cheng Jen-hung told reporters Friday that the woman, whose name he declined to disclose, was trying to remit a sum of money at Chinatrust's Chungshan branch when the bank staged the anti-robbery exercise without giving any prior notice to its customers.

Caught unaware by the exercise, in which a "robber" wielding a gun was right next to her, the woman -- pale-faced and trembling with fear -- nearly collapsed and had difficulty breathing when the exercise was over, according to Cheng.
The woman was hospitalized for 10 days. She is still receiving follow-up treatment and is unable to work.

Chinatrust agreed only to pay her medical expenses and offered two gift vouchers for the Chinatrust Hotel, claiming that the bank was not responsible for the consequences because it was following the instructions of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission in holding the exercise.

Cheng said Chinatrust apparently violated the Consumer Protection Law because it failed to inform its customers in advance of the mock holdup in the first place and then shirked its responsibility of making appropriate compensation to the victim.

The Consumers' Foundation executive pointed out that under the law, the bank should post a clear sign warning its customers when its products or services might pose a danger to their life and health or result in their monetary losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONGHAI TOP IN 2006 REVENUE IN TAIWAN: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A recent survey shows that Honghai Precision Industry Co.'s 2006 net revenue -- NT$868.2 billion (US$26.2 billion) -- ranked top among publicly and privately owned large corporations in Taiwan, a spokesman of the China Credit Information Service (CCIS) said Friday.

Quoting the results of the survey conducted by CCIS, the spokesman said the total revenue of the top 10 corporations in 2006 amounted to NT$5.14 trillion, making it the best ever year and resulting in an average growth rate for each corporation of 24.64 percent, higher than the 2005 rate of 14.38 percent.

The other nine corporations in the top 10 were: the CPC Corp., Taiwan; Cathay Life Insurance; Formosa Petrochemical Corp.; Quanta Computer; Taiwan Post Co.; Taipower Co.; AsusTek Computer; Nan Shan Life Insurance Co.; and the Bureau of National Health Insurance.

According to the spokesman, Honghai topped other corporations for the second year, bringing in NT$100 billion more than the second-place CPC. Honghai posted a 28.51 percent gain in 2006 turnover as compared with its 2005 revenue.
Among the top 10, Asus grew most quickly, rising from 18th place to 8th in a single year, with net revenues of NT$386 billion in 2006, up 114.75 percent, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN DIFFERENT CROPS ENTITLED TO GOVERNMENT COMPENSATION PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has named seven crops -- peanuts, oranges, papayas, pineapples, garlic, onions and bananas -- as the subjects of the government's production registration operations this year in an effort to prevent glut, COA officials said Friday.

Growers of these crops can declare the scale of their planned production this year to the COA Agriculture and Food Agency in order to avail themselves of government compensation if their crops lose their value due to glut on the local market, the officials said.
According to the COA, the production registration system was formed as part of efforts to address the challenging problem of production-marketing imbalances that always affect farmers the worst.

The system allows the government to better control the output of "sensitive crops " -- those which easily trigger price fluctuations in the event of production-marketing unbalance -- and take precautions against over-planting.

If the efforts to prevent glut fail, the COA will purchase the registered crops at 95 percent of their production cost in an attempt to reduce the growers' losses, the COA said, noting that production registration will not ensure profits but will at least lessen the damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY RANKS FIRST IN COMPETITIVENESS: ITRI

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semiconductor industry ranks first in the world in terms of competitiveness, with no other countries expected to rival it over the next few years, an official from the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) said Friday.

Tu Tze-chen, director of the ITRI's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK), said that the "blue ocean strategy" for Taiwan's semiconductor industry is aimed at making other countries think twice about challenging Taiwan's pre- eminent position in this field.

By 2015, Taiwan will have the greatest number of 12-inch wafer fabs in the world, Tu predicted, noting that based on current investment proposals brought up by Taiwan companies, another 27 12-inch wafer fabs are expected to be built in the country in the coming few years.

Chien Chi-sheng, the IEK's research manager on the local semiconductor manufacturing industry, said that the 12-inch wafer has transformed the global wafter manufacturing industry. He explained that manufacturing 12-inch wafers requires advanced production capabilities and that Taiwan has a key advantage in terms of lowering production costs.

Taiwan is facing less and less competition abroad in the field, with major integrated device manufacturers (IDMs) around the world pulling out of advanced process development and fewer new competitors entering the market, Chien explained.

Moreover, most 8-inch wafer fabs around the world will soon be closed down, and the world's major memory chipmaker, U.S.-based Micron Technology Inc., has begun to shift its focus away from the DRAM market, Chien said, adding that all these factors represent a promising future for Taiwan manufacturers.

According to Chien's estimate, there will be 14 12-inch wafer fabs in Taiwan by the end of 2008. By 2009, local wafer foundries and 12-inch wafer manufacturers will be able to increase their monthly production capacity by 387,000 units, he said, adding that this will further boost the production value of Taiwan's wafer manufacturing industry by NT$270 billion (US$8.1 billion).
The output of Taiwan's IC manufacturing industry will surpass NT$1 trillion for the first time in 2009 and exceed NT$2 trillion in the following year, he predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LUXEMBOURG JOINT BUSINESS COUNCIL INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Luxembourg Joint Business Council (TLJBC) was inaugurated Friday, with the long term goal of strengthening trade, business and investment relations between the two sides.

"Establishing linkages between Europe and Asia has not been easy, but we're determined to do it, and Luxembourg is the gateway for Taiwanese businesses into the European market, " council chairman Theodore Huang, who also serves as the Chairman of the National Association of Industry and Commerce.

Representatives from Luxembourg echoed the same opinion. "First of all, Luxembourg can be Taiwan's gateway to the European Union (EU) countries. Secondly, as the financial and logistic center of Europe, [Luxembourg] can be very attractive for Taiwanese companies, " said Pierre Gramegna, Director- General of the Chamber of Commerce of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
Gramegna is among 30 Luxembourg economic mission delegates visiting Taiwan Apr. 19 - 21. If all goes well, he said, a Taiwan business delegation will be visiting Luxembourg this fall.

Luxembourgian businesses appreciate Taiwan's potential to produce top-quality products and its leading role in the Chinese world in democracy, said Marc Solvi, the other TLJBC chairman who is currently CEO of Paul Wurth Group.
"We're not just doing business with Taiwan," he said, adding that the company has a production facility in Kaohsiung from where it exports its products to many other countries around the world.

In the initial stages, the council will try to help businesses from both sides better understand one another, Huang said, adding that Taiwan can help Luxembourg penetrate Asian markets, such as Vietnam.
Economic relations between both sides are looking good, Gramegna said, as there are already Taiwanese companies from more than half dozen fields investing in Luxembourg.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTIONS GARNER ATTENTION AT GENEVA FAIR
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 19 (CNA) 04/20/07 21:58:14 (By Neil Lu and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese students are displaying 23 inventions at the Geneva Inventions Fair, the world's largest event of its kind, which opened Thursday with more than 700 inventors from 42 countries participating.

The Taiwanese inventions include body-shaping underwear, a diamond-shaped super-comfortable mask, headstand machine, wine maturation accelerator, a ball-shaped hidden camera with a 360-degree split-screen and a digital wrench.
The inventions attracted attention from fair visitors and demonstrated the results of reforms in Taiwan's educational system, which now encourages innovation and creative thinking.
Wang Yuan-ren, vice president of Far East University, which sent a team to the fair, said the university applies for patents on more than 200 inventions every year.
Up to 150 of these patents have been recognized, the highest on record among local colleges, Wang claimed.
The school hopes that its students will acquire a global perspective and enhance their competitiveness through participating in this year's event, Wang noted.

The university's students invented an adjustable golf club angle- measuring instrument, a recyclable printed circuit board, a new style of cosmetic facial mask, and scented gold accessories advertised as promoting health.
Taiwan's representative to the WTO Lin Yi-fu and other Taiwanese officials visited the Taiwanese participants.
Taiwan has been a big winner at past events and is expected to win big again this year. The fair was scheduled to hold its awards ceremony Friday.
The Geneva Inventions Fair is one of the world's three largest invention expositions; the others are held in Pittsburgh, the United States and Nuremberg, Germany.
Many countries, including Taiwan, South Korea and Malaysia, have attached great importance to innovation in recent years and have begun to organize similar events.

The Taipei International Invention Show and Technomart, now in its third year, is slated to take place Sept. 27-30 and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) has been promoting the event in Geneva.
Last year, 12 nations took part in the Taipei event, TAITRA officials said, adding that this year, the event aims to set up 1,000 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT DIRECTOR AWARDS U.S. COMPANY AGENTS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Tapei Office Director-General Stephen Young presented awards to two local agents for American products Friday in recognition of their contributions to Taiwan-U.S. trade in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
The AIT's Kaohsiung Branch Office held an award ceremony to honor last year's best importers of U.S. products. The two recipients were IEKAIL Inc. and Youngtec Systems Co.
IEKAIL imports thermal plastic elastomer (TPE), a newly developed material, from the U.S.-based GLS Corporation, IEKAIL President Wang Yong-cheng said, adding that TPE is totally eco-friendly.
Youngtec Systems is the sole agent for several American companies selling industrial automation software, according to Youngtec President Chang Chen- chong said.
Janee Pierre-Louis, the office's Commercial Section Chief, said the two companies are good examples of small- and medium-sized enterprises helping to promote trade between Taiwan and the U.S.
They also help promote the Taiwan market to American exporters, she went on, adding that local companies can use many free services offered by AIT if they want to become agents for American products.
Last year, trade between Taiwan and the U.S. topped US$55 billion. As the U.S.'s eighth-largest trading partner, Taiwan purchased American products and services worth US$22 billion last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Gonzales Endures Harsh Session With Senate Panel
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, trying to salvage his job, endured withering questioning on Thursday from Senate Judiciary Committee members who expressed grave doubts about his truthfulness and judgment in the firing of federal prosecutors.
In more than five hours of often-combative testimony, Mr. Gonzales, grim-faced, clasping his hands and hunched over, struggled to offer a coherent explanation for the dismissals. He apologized for his mistakes in what he said was a flawed process, but defended the removal of eight United States attorneys as proper.
Wall Street Journal:GM's Chinese Partner Looms as a New Rival
Garment company owner Li Xianjin was planning to buy a new Buick this month. "Then I saw the Roewe," a new Chinese-made sedan, he says. "It's quite a bit bigger and more luxurious" and "it looks a lot like a Jaguar."
Mr. Li's change of heart points to a challenge for General Motors Corp. in the world's second- biggest car market. The Roewe's maker, Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp., has been GM's partner in making Buicks in China for a decade, and it has learned a lot from GM. Now the Chinese company, using that know-how and the money earned from selling joint-venture cars, could become a serious competitor.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Senators Chastise Gonzales at Hearing. Members of His Own Party Pile On as Attorney General Defends Firings.
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales came under withering attack from members of his own party yesterday over the dismissals of eight U.S. attorneys, facing the first resignation demand from a Republican member of the Senate Judiciary Committee and doubts from others about his candor and his ability to lead the Justice Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRITERS FROM KINMEN VISITING XIAMEN

TEXT.P: A 21-member delegation of the Kinmen County Writers' Association is on a three- day visit to Xiamen in China's Fujian Province to engage in cultural exchanges with writers from that city.

The delegation departed Friday by boat via the direct cross-Taiwan Strait "three mini-links." Led by Yang Ching-kuo, chairman of the Kinmen County Writers' Association, the delegation comprises two elementary school principals, retired professors and school teachers.
Yang told reporters that the delegation will hold a symposium with members of the Xiamen Writers' Association and discuss a proposal for the two associations to enter a sisterhood relationship.
He said the trip is his association's fourth visit to China, with a view to promoting exchanges between Kinmen writers and their counterparts in Xiamen.

Yang added that when the delegation returns to Kinmen, its members will write about their experiences in Xiamen, and he said he will also invite writers from Xiamen to visit Kinmen and record what they see on the outlying island.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: Finn E. Kydland, winner of the 2004 Nobel Prize in economics, predicted Friday that Taiwan's economy will continue to grow despite China's economic rise.
Kydland, who is visiting Taipei, made the remarks during a courtesy call on President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.

During their talks, Chen expressed worry about Taiwan's economic prospects amid the impact of China's economic rise and the magnetic effect of the vast Chinese market in attracting investment capital.

In response, Kydland said Taiwan need not care too much about the impact of China's economic rise. Most of the effects will be short-lived, Kydland said, adding that Taiwan could continue enjoying terrific economic growth if it adopts economic strategies that encourage innovation and investment while stepping up hardware construction.

Forecasting that Taiwan's current economic slowdown or setback will be "ephemeral, " Kydland said he is convinced that Taiwan's economy will regain strength and vitality over the long run. In his view, Kydland said, Taiwan's economy has not yet reached maturity and still has ample room for growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 21, or the fifth day of the third month of the Year of Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, can be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students clamoring for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the July 1 handover of the British crown colony to communist China.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
1999: A survey conducted by the Switzerland-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan as the least risky area for investment in the world.
1999: Renowned local writer Su Hsueh-lin, winner of the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, dies at the age of 104.
2000: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng wins the title of "Go Sage," the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, an advisor to the National Security Council and a professor at National Chengchi University, is confirmed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
2001: A pro-unification organization urges Taiwan's three main opposition parties to monitor the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to prevent Taiwan from "marching toward independence."
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY CONCLUDES ROUND-THE-CLOCK SIMULATED WARFARE DRILLS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's military has concluded a series of simulated cyber warfare maneuvers in which the various branches of the armed forces conducted mock counterattacks on China's coastal military targets after a simulated surprise attack by China, military sources said Saturday.

The round-the-clock five-day computerized warfare simulation that ended Friday was part of the annual "Han Kuang" series of combined services military exercises aimed at honing combat strategies and battlefield management tactics, the sources said.

This year's cyber war games also marked the first time that Taiwan's armed forces have practiced counterattack strategies and skills in simulated warfare drills, the sources said, adding that in the mock counterattacks, Taiwan troops struck coastal Chinese military targets and booming cities with such weapons as cruise missiles and short-range ballistic missiles.

The military's Joint Operations Command Center, the Joint Operations Training Center, and tactical command offices at various strategic military units took part in the computerized maneuvers, the sources said, adding that a U.S. delegation, headed by former Pacific Command Commander-in-Chief Adm. Dennis C. Blair, was on hand to observe the whole process.
The Ministry of National Defense is scheduled to brief the press on the details of the "Han Kuang 23" cyber warfare maneuvers at its routine news conference next Tuesday, the sources said.

According to the sources, the war game scenario was set in 2012 when China, frustrated by Taiwan's long-term resistance against unification talks, decides to take advantage of Taiwan's procrastination in military arsenal upgrading to accelerate its push for cross-strait unification by launching an all-out surprise attack on Taiwan proper and its outlying island of Penghu.

In the first three days of the simulated Chinese invasion, Taiwan incurred severe human and material losses from China's saturated ballistic missile assault as well as naval and aerial bombardment. Afterwards, Taiwan's armed forces managed to get up to steam to stage counterattacks on China's coastal military targets and its major cities, causing heavy human casualties and major destruction.

In the warfare scenario, the military strikes not only took a heavy toll on the economic well-being of both sides of the Taiwan Strait but also adversely impacted the global economy and caused a worldwide panic. In the end, the United States and other Western countries jointly mediated a ceasefire.
The simulated war games didn't cover the use of nuclear weapons or Taiwan military attacks on China's aircraft carrier battle groups as some media outlets had speculated, the sources said.

Meanwhile, the sources said, the U.S. observation group focused in particular on assessing the Taiwan military personnel's "combat spirit" to see whether their morale has been affected by the prolonged political infighting that has cast a shadow over society since the transition of power between different political parties back in 2000.

In weighing the military's "combat spirit," the sources said, the U.S. delegation wanted to determine whether Taiwan would likely lean toward China and whether any advanced U.S.-built weaponry systems or sophisticated defense strategies would end up in the hands of the Chinese communists.

Following the completion of the cyber warfare maneuvers, the sources said, the military will start a five-day psychological warfare training program aimed at enhancing service members' combat morale, battlefield adaptability and stress management abilities.

The "Han Kuang" series is the largest-scale combined services military exercise to be staged in Taiwan every year. In addition to the computerized war games, it also covers live-fire military maneuvers, which will be held later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO BUILD MORE WIND POWER GENERATORS: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The government plans to build wind power generators on the seas surrounding the island in the near future after it has installed over 100 such facilities on land as part of its standing efforts to develop renewable energy sources, the minister of economic affairs said Saturday.

Steve R. L. Chen revealed the plan at a forum organized by the Chinese-language Economic Daily News on strategies in the face of the approaching era of high oil prices. He said that the government has set the target of 10 percent of the power generated in Taiwan coming from renewable energy sources by the year of 2010.
At present, only 8 percent of the total amount of power generated in the country is from renewable energy sources, Chen said, noting there is still a lot of work to do in this regard.

While Taiwan has to import 98 percent of the energy it needs, the island must take precautions against increasing energy prices in the international market due to the growing energy shortage around the globe, Chen said.
In this regard, Chen said, the government has never ceased in its efforts to develop renewable energy sources and has worked out plans that focus on the development of wind power.

Addressing the government's efforts in reducing greenhouse gas emissions in accordance with a worldwide effort to slow down global warming, the minister said that a draft bill on greenhouse gas emissions reduction has been sent to the Legislative Yuan for review and that the government will soon finalize a draft bill on energy taxation, based on the "pay-per-use" principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ARCHBISHOP TUTU VISITS MEINUNG TOWNSHIP IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Visiting former South African Anglican Church Archbishop Desmond Tutu and his wife visited Meinung Township in Kaohsiung County Saturday to have better understanding of Taiwan's Hakka culture at the invitation of Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing.

Tutu, awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his leading role in the anti- apartheid movement, arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a weeklong visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.

Accompanied by Yang, Tutu and his wife visited producing sites of oil paper umbrellas, and a cultural center to learn traditional Taiwanese toys. The couple were treated Hakka food by Yang. The couple then paid another visit to neighboring Pingtung County at Magistrate Taso Chi-hung' invitation.
On Friday, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu hosted a dinner for Tutu, during which the two of them exchanged ideas on peace and ethnic reconciliation of harmony.

During the dinner, Chen told Tutu that she understands Tutu's efforts in seeking transitional justice in order to step on the path of peace in post-apartheid South Africa, as she herself had served time in prison in the struggle to bring democracy to Taiwan.

In a prayer at the start of the banquet, Tutu urged the Taiwan people to face their painful history in order to heal their wounds and wished for peace and justice for the people of the country, according to Chen.

Tutu will return to Kaohsiung City Sunday to attend a seminar with representatives of various religious groups, during which he and Chen will have a further opportunity to engage in dialogue, according to the Kaohsiung mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION OF EXPRESSWAY HINGES ON ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT: PREZ

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the construction of an expressway to connect Suao and Hualien in eastern Taiwan is necessary but that a prerequisite for its construction is the project passing an environmental impact assessment.
The president made the remarks while addressing the opening of an NGO-sponsored environmental protection conference in Taipei.
He pointed out that the government's set policy is to establish an islandwide expressway network and that the planned Suhua expressway will be a crucial part of it.

But he stressed that if the project fails an environmental impact assessment, it will have to be aborted, saying that "this is the government's unequivocal stance and the stance of past and present premiers."

The president's remarks came in the wake of a recent spat among three presidential contenders of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- namely Premier Su Tseng-chang and his predecessors Frank Hsieh and Yu Shyi-kun -- on who should shoulder the biggest responsibility for the stalling of the long- discussed project.

On the other hand, environmental activists have blasted what they called myopic politicians for using the expressway project as a pork barrel ploy to win voter support in elections without being aware of the disastrous impact on eastern Taiwan's ecology and tourism that the highway's construction would have.
Construction of the Suhua expressway was one of Chen's campaign promises in the presidential elections in 2000 and 2004.

Chen pointed out that there are already two freeways, an expressway, a railway and a high speed railway in western Taiwan. The Peiyi (Taipei-Yilan) expressway has also been inaugurated, making travel from any point in western Taiwan to Yilan in northeastern Taiwan within one day a reality.

In comparison, eastern Taiwan has only one major railway system, which has yet to go electric, Chen said. If the planned Suhua expressway project is aborted, the imbalance in development between eastern and western Taiwan will be even more apparent, he added.
Chen said that construction of the expressway is the will of the people of Hualien.

"Although I said previously that if there is conflict between economic development and environmental protection, I would rather choose the latter, it will be a stripping of the Hualien people's rights to pursue prosperity if the government insists on opposing the project even if it is determined that the impact on the environment will not be that big," the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE YUNUS TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, Hainan, China, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/07 18:02:14 (By Tang Pei-chun & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Muhammad Yunus, winner of the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize, has accepted an invitation to visit Taiwan, the chairman of the Taipei-based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation said Saturday.

Vincent Siew, a former premier of Taiwan, made the announcement at the opening ceremony for the 2007 Boao Forum for Asia (BFA), being held in the coastal town of Boao in China's southernmost province of Hainan. Siew is attending the April 20-21 regional economic event in his capacity as the head of a group of Taiwanese entrepreneurs.

Siew told CNA that he had first come into contact with the renowned banker and economist from Bangladesh ahead of the opening ceremony. During the brief meeting, he invited Yunus to visit Taiwan, he said.

Siew said he recognized Yunus' efforts in assisting millions of people climb out of poverty through a "microcredit" program of offering loans to people who are too poor to qualify for traditional bank loans. He adding that Yunus' efforts have been a great inspiration to people in Taiwan.

Yunus, who is also the founder of the Grameen Bank, drew the attention of all the participants in the forum. He and the bank were jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize last year "for their efforts to create economic and social development from below."

The BFA is a non-governmental, non-profit international organization modeled after the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Driven by China, it was founded by 26 Australasian states on Feb. 27, 2001, and held its first annual meeting in April 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS PUT ON SECOND-LANGUAGE PERFORMANCES

TEXT.P: Taipei City's public and private senior high schools held a joint exhibition of assignments and performances by students in different languages Saturday to showcase their achievements in learning a second foreign language.

Performances were staged at three municipal senior high schools, including performances in German, Spanish and Korean at Taipei Municipal Sungshan Senior High School, where students wore the traditional costumes of different countries to present either plays or singing to the audience.

Performances in French and Latin were staged at Taipei Municipal Hsisung Senior High School, with more than 2,000 students from 27 schools enrolled in French courses participating, and students from the Taipei Municipal First Girl's High School, which is the only school in the city that offers a Latin course.

Meanwhile, performances in Japanese, the language being learned by the most students in Taipei City, were held at Taipei Municipal Chunglun Senior High School, including tea ceremony and flower arrangement demonstrations and a kimono fashion show.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO SCREEN EXPRESSWAY CONSTRUCTION PROJECT NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Saturday that it will convene another meeting to screen a controversial expressway construction project in eastern Taiwan next month at the earliest.

EPA officials made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian said earlier the same day at the opening of an environmental protection conference that construction of the Suhua expressway linking Suao and Hualien is necessary for the sake of balanced development of western and eastern Taiwan but that a prerequisite for its construction is the project passing an environmental impact assessment.

The president's remarks drew flak from the representatives of environmental protection groups taking part in the conference, who vowed to step up lobbying of the members of a 21-member environmental impact task force in an effort to stop the project from going forward.

EPA officials noted that during the first screening meeting in January, 10 members on the environmental impact assessment task force raised questions about the project's impact on the local ecology, geographic fault, economy and culture.
The EPA has therefore asked the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to address their misgivings before April 30, the officials said.
They further said that if the MOTC can provide the necessary details by next week, the second screening meeting will be held as early as the beginning of May.

Chiou Lin-bin, director general of the MOTC's National Expressway Engineering Bureau, said Saturday that if the Suhua expressway project is aborted, the goal of establishing an islandwide expressway network will not be able to be achieved.

He said that his bureau has envisioned the National Expressway No. 5, which currently runs between Nankang, Taipei and Suao, Yilan, stretching to cover the section between Suao and Hualien and then extending to Taitung in the long run.

He noted that the current railway transportation system in eastern Taiwan can hardly relieve the traffic congestion on the present Suao-Hualien Highway and that upgrading the railway system will not solve the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS TRADE BARBS OVER GOOD GOVERNANCE

TEXT.P: Two presidential aspirants of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) traded barbs over what good governance means Saturday in a televised platform forum.
Former Premier Frank Hsieh said that if elected president in the 2008 election, he will form a stable coalition in view of the current plight of a minority government.

Hsieh noted that if the DPP fails to gain control of more than half of the seats in the legislature, he will coordinate with other parties to form a stable coalition, although he declined to touch on how to do so, saying it is a "complex issue." Hsieh later explained that "tolerance" is essential to achieving the end.

Premier Su Tseng-chang challenged Hsieh to disclose now how he would end the political impasse and the perennial squabbling between the ruling and opposition parties, saying that Hsieh can provide his advice on coordination now without waiting to 2008 when he is elected president.

All four DPP hopefuls, including Vice President Annette Lu and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, attended the second and last platform forum sponsored by the DPP prior to the party's presidential primary in May. The forum was held in Chiayi, southern Taiwan. The first one was held in Taipei last Saturday.

They concurred that the minority government has been hampered in carrying out many of its policies, when asked by professor Shih Cheng-feng of Tamkang University why so many supporters feel that that the DPP has failed to deliver on its campaign promises after seven years in power and what they are going to do to ensure happiness for the people if elected president in 2008.

Hsieh noted that if he is elected, he will form a stable coalition with other parties and sign with them an agreement to state clearly in which areas they can cooperate and in which areas they cannot.

Su said that the interests of the public are the most important, adding that if economic development and environmental protection cannot co-exist, he would rather choose the preservation of Taiwan's ecology.
Lu said that the major problem with the administration lies with a bad constitutional system.

Lu noted that after the president appoints the premier, the Executive Yuan possesses great power, except that of national defense and diplomatic policies. But she lamented that the premier's term is too short, noting that there have been five premiers over the past seven years. The five decades of Kuomintang rule also left a litany of problems, which will require time to solve, she added.

Constant bickering in the legislature stemming from the fact that the government is a minority government has also been a hindrance to implementing and carrying out policies, Lu said, adding that globalization is also a challenge.
She said that if elected president, she will push for constitutional reform and party politics, make good use of talent in every field, and work in tune with global trends.

Yu said that the performance of the DPP has not lived up to the public's expectations mainly because it is a minority government, adding, however, that in fact, the DPP has done a credible job, citing the examples of the daunting tasks of constructing the Shuehshan Tunnel and dredging of the Keelung River.
He vowed that if elected, he will make Taiwan a "normal country" and "bring about economic prosperity so that the people will enjoy a high-quality life."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT CHAIRMAN MA REGISTERS FOR PARTY'S PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Former opposition Koumintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou registered Saturday to join the party's primary for the 2008 presidential election.

Ma said that if elected president, he will devote himself to creating a "New Taiwan, " totally different from the one shaped over the past seven years, by using the power given to the president by the law and constitutional system. He described his ideal Taiwan as a country that is "liberal, optimistic, open, and keen on development."

For the registration, Ma handed over NT$7 million (US$211,300), a sum of money to serve as primary operation fees, and a name list of 215,168 KMT members who gave their support for his bid to represent the party in the presidential election.
So far, Ma is the only person to register for the KMT primary.
Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung reiterated his party's sincerity in carrying out proposals listed in an agreement forged by the KMT and its political ally, the People First Party (PFP), Friday.

The agreement came after two weeks of negotiations between the KMT and PFP on the matter of jointly selecting candidates from the two parties with the best chances of winning in the year-end legislative elections.
Wu made the declaration in response to media inquiries at the KMT headquarters where he witnessed Ma's primary registration.

Wu said that KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih has full authorization to deal with issues concerning the KMT-PFP cooperation in terms of the upcoming legislative elections and that the KMT has nothing but sincerity in carrying out every agreement between the two parties.
The KMT and the PFP forged alliance relations Jan. 22 and agreed to jointly work to select candidates who have the best chances of winning seats in the legislative elections.

The PFP had earlier expressed doubts about the KMT's willingness to carry out the January agreement and therefore acted not to cooperate with the KMT during Monday's legislative session, leading to several draft bills against the KMT, including one on ill-gotten party assets, being placed on the legislative agenda.

As they dig for nickel, copper and other commodities in the far corners of the earth, the world's largest mining companies, Rio Tinto PLC and BHP Billiton Ltd., are used to solving geological problems. Here, though, the problems they encountered were political.
North America's largest copper lode is believed to be buried more than a mile beneath Apache Leap, the stark red cliffs that loom above this storied Old West town about an hour east of Phoenix. DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN BUSINESS COUNCIL WELCOMES TAIWAN'S DECISION ON PROMOS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 20 (CNA) 04/21/07 21:13:59 (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council said Friday that it welcomes Taiwan's approval for ProMOS Technologies to build an advanced 0.18-micron chip manufacturing facility in China.

Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the council which is comprised of a large network of companies involved in business between Taiwan and the United States, said that this is "an important and timely decision."
He said that it is vital that leading Taiwan companies like ProMOS are able to actively compete and offer their expertise in all markets around the world, including China's.

But he also said that "it remains critical for the Taiwan government to develop a clear, consistent process for such investments, and to finalize and release new guidelines for the semiconductor industry to replace those that expired in December 2005."

He also urged Taiwan's government to remove the 40 percent equity cap on Taiwan investments in China, saying that "Taiwan does not have the luxury to delay such efforts while its regional competitors continue to innovate and reform. "

He contended that present barriers to cross-strait investment are hurting Taiwan companies, and by extension their U.S. partners, while a liberalized and transparent cross-strait economic relationship would be beneficial no only for Taiwan but also for the many partner companies that rely on Taiwan to research, design, and manufacturer a myriad of goods for consumption in the global market.

ProMOS Technologies became the second company to be granted approval by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) since the government allowed Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers to move 0.18-micron chip manufacturing technology to China in December 2006. The MOEA gave Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. the green light to use 0.18-micron chip manufacturing technology in its factory in Shanghai last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAN TO CYCLE ACROSS EURASIA TO RAISE GLOBAL WARMING AWARENESS

TEXT.P: A 29-year-old Taiwan man will kick off a cross-continent "Bike-To-Protect-Our- Planet" cycling journey from Beijing Sunday to help raise public awareness of the need for joint efforts to slow global warming, organizers said Saturday.
Hsueh Teh-jui said he plans to cycle across Asia and most of Europe to reach Paris in six months to promote his cause.

The "Eurasia cycle tour" has been jointly organized by himself and the Taipei- based Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF) to inspire more people to contribute to global efforts to lower greenhouse gas emissions so as to slow global warming, Hsueh said.
In June 1901, Hsueh said, five people drove from Beijing to Paris to spread the message that the age of the automobile has dawned.

Over the past century, Hsueh said, excessive carbon dioxide emissions from motorized vehicles has led to drastic climate changes that may threaten the sustainability of humans and other lviing species.

"This time around, I want to travel the same route by bicycle to draw attention to the danger that global warming poses and invite concerted efforts from members of the general public to improve the situation," Hsueh said.

Hsueh, who has completed cycling journeys around Taiwan and France over the past few years, will start his Eurasia cycling tour from Tiantan, a Beijing heritage site also known as Temple of Heaven, and travel westward along the Silk Road to reach Kazakhstan via Urumqi, capital of the Chinese province of Xijiang.

Traveling at a speed of 80 to 120 kilometers per day, Hsueh said he is scheduled to arrive at Eiffel Tower in Paris Oct. 15 after cycling through Russia, Ukraine, Poland, Germany, Holland and Belgium.

An EQPF spokesman said the foundation throws full support behind Hsueh's Eurasia concycling journey because they share a common cause of slowing global warming to protect the natural ecological systems on the Earth.

Up-to-date information about Hsueh's cycling journey will be posted online at http: //www.deray.org, the spokesman said, adding that individuals interested in his adventurous tour are welcome to browse the Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PANEL OUTPUT FORECAST TO TOP NT$1 TRILLION FOR 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total display panel output is expected to surpass NT$1 trillion (US$30.17 billion) for 2007, an Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) official said Saturday.

Jim Chung, a research manager with the ITRI's Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK) , forecast that the flat panel display (FPD) industry's output --including all kinds of panels and upstream components and materials -- will reach NT$1.44 trillion for this year, up 13.9 percent over the figure for 2006.
The annual output of Taiwan's FPD industry exceeded NT$1 trillion for the first time last year, reaching NT$1.27 trillion, up 30.8 percent over the year-earlier figure, Chung said.

Total output of large size TFT-LCD panels for 2006 was NT$765.35 billion, up 34.5 percent year-on-year, while that of all kinds of panels was NT$911.56 billion, up 29.1 percent, and that of upstream raw materials was NT$360.4 billion, up 35.5 percent, according to Chung.

He further said that the increase in total output of large size panels was due to the fast growing LCD TV market, while that of small and medium size panels was due to the growing mobile phone and DVD player markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU UNVEILS NEW PARTY CHARTER, PLATFORM

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) came up with new party charter and new party platform Saturday as part of its survival strategy ahead of the year- end legislative election that poses a severe test to its political fate or future.

The new TSU party platform upholds five basic principles and ideals. First and foremost, the party insists that Taiwan's sovereignty rests with its people and advocates a Taiwan-centric national development strategy.

Meanwhile, the party vows to unite Taiwan's diverse ethnic groups with the concept that all residents are new-age Taiwanese who treasure freedom, democracy and human rights as their shared core values.
The new TSU platform also pledges to promote fair competition on the basis of social justice while striving to wipe out money-based politics and establishing a clean and competent government.

The new TSU charter and platform were unveiled in a Taipei rally that was attended by former President Lee Teng-hui, who has been reputed as the party's spiritual leader, and representatives of some social groups.
Addressing the rally, TSU Chairman Huang Kun-hui said the new party charter and platform have set forth new policy direction and development guidelines for the party.
"With the declaration of our new party charter and platform, we are committed to working for the common well-being of our country and people," Huang said.

According to the new TSU charter, Huang went on, the party will pursue a"center- left" policy line and collaborate with middle-class and disadvantaged groups to boost welfare services and benefits for them.

Claiming that Taiwan people's well-being has been compromised due to the protracted political standoff between the country's two major parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- in the past seven years, Huang said this situation should not continue and that the TSU will play a crucial role in pushing for an early end to all partisan strife and rivalry.

The TSU now controls 12 legislative seats and several seats in the Taipei City Council. The party used to be a DPP ally in the Legislative Yuan as both parties support Taiwan independence and a more confrontational approach toward China. But their ties have soured over different partisan interests and certain policy issues, particularly those related with opening to China.

As the year-end legislative election will adopt a new electoral system that is generally believed to be less favorable to small parties, the TSU has tried to foster a new image to woo new fans and has since softened its pro-independence rhetoric. It now give priority to talking about socialism-like policy initiatives, particularly welfare services for disadvantaged groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 22, or the sixth day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: On his way to India with 13 ships, Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvarez Cabral discovers Brazil and claims it for Portugal.
1724: Immanuel Kant, German idealist philosopher and one of history's greatest thinkers, is born. He argued that reason is the means by which the phenomena of experience is translated into understanding. His classic works include "Critique of Pure Reason" and "Critique of Practical Reason."
1870: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian leader of the Bolshevik Revolution and first leader of Communist Russia, is born.
1904: Robert Oppenheimer, American nuclear scientist who developed the atom bomb, is born.
1915: The Germans use poison gas for the first time on British troops on the Western Front during World War I.
1944: Allied forces land on Dutch New Guinea.
1947: Wei Tao-ming becomes governor of the newly established Taiwan Provincial Government.
1951: The first contingent of officers from the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei. Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, the first MAAG chief, would arrive in Taipei later.
1956: Beijing appoints the Dalai Lama as chairman of a committee to prepare Tibet for regional autonomy within Communist China.
1961: The construction of the Taipei Chunghua Bazaar is completed with Gov. Chow Chih-jou of Taiwan Provincial Government presiding over the inauguration ceremony.
1969: American surgeons conduct the first human eye transplant.
1973: President Hammer de Roburt of the Republic of Nauru and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: A Pan American Airlines passenger plane crashes in Bali, Indonesia, killing 107 people.
1975: The first batch of Vietnamese refugees arrive on the western coast of the United States, as South Vietnam falls to the communists.
1980: S.S. Don Juan, a vehicle ferry, collides with a car float and sinks near Mindoro Island in the Philippines, killing some 1,000 people.
1984: Medical researchers working in the United States and France identify a type of human cancer virus that may be the causative agent in the killer disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly passes, at its sixth plenary meeting, the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China and approves the abolishment of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: Gasoline that leaked from a nearby refinery explodes in the sewer system of Guadalajara, Mexico, killing more than 200 people and injuring over 600 others.
1993: The Legislative Yuan ratifies a 1989 ROC-U.S. copyright agreement and passes amendments to the ROC's copyright law that go into effect April 26.
1993: Tongan Prime Minister Baron Vaea and Madame Vaea visit the Republic of China.
1994: Former U.S. President Richard M. Nixon dies of a stroke at the age of 81. He visited mainland China in 1972 and established detente with the USSR. When Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal, he resigned from office Aug. 9, 1974.
1999: Visiting President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov of the Kalmykia Republic meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and expresses interest in creating sisterhood ties between the Russian state and Taipei.
2000: The newly founded People First Party calls for a halt in revamping the ROC Constitution by the National Assembly, branding the draft amendments unconstitutional.
2000: The ROC Foreign Ministry formally approves the appointment of Chen Kuo- huang, director of the Foreign Ministry's Western Asian Affairs Department, as ambassador to Palau.
2001: Nobel laureate Yang Chen-ning is honored as the outstanding alumnus of the century in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, by his alma mater National Tsinghua University.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the rulers encourage education and good manner, the people are easily amenable to government."

The Japan Times: Cops probe scene of 15-hour standoff
Japanese police on Saturday investigated the apartment and surrounding areas in Machida, Tokyo, where a gunman shot himself during a 15-hour standoff, finding four bullet holes in a police patrol car and 22 spent cartridges in the apartment.
