DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE EXPATRIATES IN ITALY SUPPORT BID TO ENTER WHO
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 21 (CNA) 04/22/07 15:56:29 (By K. C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese expatriates living in Italy resolved Saturday to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as a full member under the name "Taiwan."

At a colloquium hosted by Wu Hsiu-chi, president of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in Italy, the expatriates decided that they will write joint letters to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan and Italy's foreign and health ministries to ask the new WHO chief and Italian authorities to consider Taiwan's appeal and support its bid.
Speaking at the gathering, Cheng Hsin, Taiwan's representative in Italy, stressed that medical care knows no borders and that global disease prevention networks should be seamless.
Cheng said that based on the WHO's mission to protect the health of all the peoples around the world, Taiwan has every right to apply to join the WHO as a full member.

He said all 23 million people in Taiwan are entitled to good medical care, as are other peoples around the world, and the last thing that the Taiwanese people would like to see is that Taiwan causes a "rift" in the global disease prevention networks.

Cheng added that due to China's obstruction each of Taiwan's attempts to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the WHO's decision-making body, even as an observer, have failed over the past 10 years.

He called for Taiwanese people at home and abroad, as well as friends of Taiwan, to work together to realize the goal of Taiwan's accession to the WHO as a full member under the name of "Taiwan" at the earliest possible day.

Meanwhile, Chen Chang-fa, head of Italian operations of the European Federation of Taiwan Health Alliance, said that he has traveled to the WHO headquarters in Geneva every year since 2000 to voice support for Taiwan's bid to join the world health regulatory body, and has also observed great pressure applied by Beijing in its determination in barring Taiwan from joining the WHO.

Chen said greater efforts are needed to make the international community aware of the injustice of Taiwan's being excluded from the WHO, and the imperative of integrating the island into the world health system.

Also speaking at the colloquium, Chen Tai-ming, an economics professor of postgraduate classes in Rome, called on China -- which claims to have "risen peacefully" onto the world stage -- to act like a great nation with magnanimity.
As a "great nation, " China should treat its neighbors well, particularly Taiwan, which is like a brother of China's, said Chen Tai-ming.

He said Taiwan's bid to join the WHO as a full member under the name "Taiwan" may appear unrealistic at the moment, but people should be unrelenting, pointing out that so long as they struggle, they exist; and so long as they exist, they have strength.
He added that he is confident that Taiwan -- a world-class economic powerhouse with good medical care a compassionate population -- will eventually succeed in its bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ARCHBISHOP TUTU VISITS ABORIGINAL PAIWAN ARTIFACTS IN PINTUNG

TEXT.P: Former South African Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu and his wife Leah Nomalizo Tutu were greatly impressed by the gorgeous bead decorations displayed by aboriginal Paiwan people during a visit to the tribe in Sandimen township in the southernmost county of Pingtung.

Tutu, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984, accompanied by his wife, headed to Sandimen Saturday for an introduction to aboriginal Paiwan culture after concluding a tour of Meinung Township in Kaohsiung County earlier the same day.
The couple called on a workshop to experience the art of glass bead making and take a close look at various glass bead exhibits.

During their stay, workshop chief Shih Hsiu-chu briefed the visitors on the significance of glass beads in Paiwan tribal culture, while the couple also expressed their admiration for the tribal people's achievements integrating traditional aboriginal culture into the modern economy and even reaching markets overseas.
Tutu and his wife were so pleased by the splendid glass beads that they purchased several pieces of glass bead necklaces and bangles at the store.
In a goodwill gesture, Tutu presented a Swaziland necklace to Shih as a souvenir, while Shih also offered a glass bead necklace in return.

Tutu said that he has greatly enjoyed his current visit to Taiwan and feels that the Taiwanese are very nice, but as he is old and tired he has to cancel a trip to Wanchin Catholic Church in Pintung County scheduled for later that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CLARIFIES STANCE ON OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman reiterated Saturday the council's stance on the 2008 Olympic torch relay and denied having said that the torch, if were to pass through Taiwan, should "arrive" and "depart" from different locations.

In a statement carried on the British Broadcasting Corp's (BBC) Chinese-language website Saturday, Liu Te-hsun said he did not say during a news conference held April 20 that the Olympic torch relay must pass one place beyond Hong Kong or Macau to enter Taiwan and depart from Taiwan via another place also other than Hong Kong and Macau.

Liu said in the BBC online report that he was recently "misquoted" by a Chinese website, which claimed that Liu had spelled out "four major conditions" for the 2008 Olympic torch passing through Taiwan, including that the torch shall not pass through Hong Kong or Macau on its way to and from Taiwan.

Liu said he made known at last Friday's news conference the four "requests" of the MAC regarding the notion about the 2008 Olympic torch relay passing through Taiwan, and adding that the four "requests" were just requests and they should not be interpreted as "conditions."

He reiterated the four requests: the torch must be handled following the protocol of the International Olympic Committee; China must seek Taiwan's permission to have the 2008 Olympic torch relay pass through Taiwan; China must guarantee that Taiwan's sovereignty will not be belittled or compromised; and the torch relay event should be a move conducive to constructive interactions between Taiwan and China.

Explaining the third request, that Taiwan's sovereignty not be belittled or compromised, Liu said that Taiwan belongs to the International Olympic Committee as an independent sports entity and has for years taken part in Olympic competitions under the title of "Chinese Taipei."
Nevertheless, he argued, China has stubbornly insisted on calling Taiwan "China Taipei" -- a title that is unacceptable to Taiwan and its athletes.
Liu called for China to once again to address Taiwan with the title that has been traditionally used by the IOC.

Meanwhile, Liu stressed that as a full IOC member, Taiwan would be proud to be part of the 2008 Olympic torch relay and will cooperate with the IOC in this regard in accordance with IOC traditions and formalities.

President Chen Shui-bian's Chief of Staff Chiou I-jen expressed April 17 that Taiwan will definitely not accept a plan that the 2008 Olympic torch relay pass through Hong Kong or Xiamen in Fujian Province on its way to and from Taiwan, saying that the plan would belittle Taiwan by implying that it is a province of China.

Chiou added, nevertheless, that it would be acceptable to Taiwan if the torch passes a third country before it reaches Taiwan, including Taiwan in an international route, instead of a "domestic" route.
The IOC is in the midst of a 10-day meeting in Beijing, which began April 16, and the torch relay matter is expected to be one of the hottest issues under discussion.
The 2008 Olympic Games are scheduled to be held in Beijing Aug. 8-24.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP RESERVED ABOUT ADVANCING COOPERATION WITH KMT

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) was low keyed Sunday about an agreement reached late last week with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) regarding cooperation in coming elections, but called for bilateral talks on the issue as soon as possible.

Chang Hsien-yao, a PFP lawmaker and director of the party's central policy center, opined that the two parties should first discuss how to coordinate on regional-seat candidacies in December's legislative election two weeks before holding negotiations on further cooperation or a merger -- as was laid out in a pledge that he inked with KMT Secretary-General Wu Duen-yih last Friday.

PFP lawmaker Daniel Hwang Yih-jiau, who also serves as executive director of the party's central policy center, said that the PFP will not rule out the possibility of stepping up cooperation in any form or merging with the KMT.

"No terms or conditions have been fixed or settled with regard to future collaboration between the two parties, " Hwang said and called for two-way talks on the issue as quickly as possible so as to lay a solid foundation for victory in December's legislative election and the 2008 presidential election.

However, both Chang and Hwang were reserved about whether or not all the PFP lawmakers will definitely take part in the next Procedure Committee Tuesday to help the KMT block two draft bills of major concern to it as last Friday.

PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung, who has registered to take part in the May 12 by- election for Keelung mayor, urged the KMT to display greater sincerity on bilateral negotiations, ranging from the Keelung mayoral by-election to the year-end legislative election.
"Trying to do away with the PFP will do no good to the KMT, "Liu warned.

PFP lawmakers and their peers from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union attended Friday's committee meeting to help kill the two bills, after Chang and Wu signed the agreement earlier that day, crushing efforts by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), to ram through the two bills for a second reading.

The first bill, initiated by the DPP, is widely believed to take aim at former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who continues to pursue his presidential bid despite corruption charges against him. The bill would ban individuals convicted in the first trial from running in presidential elections, while the second proposed by the TSU seeks to force the KMT return its "ill-gotten" assets to the nation's coffers.

Ten PFP lawmakers showed up in the Friday Procedure Committee meeting and cast "no" votes against the two bills after Chang and Wu signed a 7-point pledge early that same day, agreeing to jointly field the most electable candidates in December's legislative elections, based on a framework established by the two parties on Jan. 22, when they decided to create a closer alliance to reinforce collaboration.

According to PFP sources, the KMT agreed to allot five constituencies for the PFP to manage in the coming legislative election, while negotiations on cooperation in the rest of the constituencies must be wrapped up within two weeks.

Although the signing of the pledge has temporarily defused tensions between the two parties with regard to the legislative election, observers said that it will take more time to judge whether the two parties have effectively come to a cease fire.
It is extremely difficult to forge across-the-board collaboration between the two parties due to a lack of mutual trust and a conflict of partisan interests, observers said.

According to KMT sources, the eventual goal of the KMT is to secure a majority of the legislature so as to secure Ma's win in the 2008 presidential race, while the PFP is focusing its efforts on bailing out the political careers of PFP lawmakers.
The signing of the 7-point pledge just marked the very beginning of afierce challenge for both parties, the KMT source said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE RAMPANT IN ALL AGE GROUPS: MOJ

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) reported Sunday that 3,114 new cases of domestic violence were reported to the prosecution last year, with abusers, mostly males, coming from all age groups.

According to the MOJ, most of the offenders and victims were husbands and wives. A vast majority of 71 percent of the abusers were jobless men or laborers with low levels of education, and range in age from teens to over 60. On average, only one in 12 abusers is female.
Among male abusers, those aged between 30-50 accounted for 67.5 percent; minors below 20 and elderly over 60 making up of 0.1 percent and 4.8 percent, respectively, the MOI reported.
Some 49 percent of those responsible for domestic violence were illiterate or had only an elementary-level education. Only 29.5 percent were senior high school graduates.

A total of 4,544 suspects were involved in the 3,144 domestic assault cases last year, with 2,237 of them being indicted by prosecutors, said the MOJ, adding that 52 percent of the cases concerned married couples, and another 16 percent involved directly related family members.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE TUTU CALLS FOR CHRISTIANS TO EMULATE BUDDHIST TZU CHI

TEXT.P: Former South African Anglican Church Archbishop Desmond Mpilo Tutu visited the operational headquarters of the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Sunday, coming away with a tremendous appreciation of the contributions that Tzu Chi has made to the world.

Tutu, the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize winner, recognized for his contribution to ending apartheid in South Africa and facilitating reconciliation, and his wife were profoundly impressed with video-audio records and verbal accounts of relief work carried out by Tzu Chi volunteers around the world over the past two decades in an effort to save lives and comfort people traumatized afflicted by natural disasters.
Tutu said the devotion of Tzu Chi volunteers is exemplary of the compassion of Buddhism and unselfish service to mankind.
Tutu's wife was reduced to tears as she saw how Zulu volunteers had reacted to the support services extended to AIDS patients in South Africa under the leadership of Tzu Chi volunteer Pan Ming-shui.

Overwhelmingly moved, Tutu said that South Africa is a Christian country but that Christians there have been relatively more arrogant than Buddhists. He called on Christians to be humble enough to learn from and emulate what the Buddhists have done.
Tutu and his wife arrived in Taiwan April 18 for an eight-day visit at the invitation of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.

The couple have visited Machangting, a former execution ground for political prisoners adjacent to the present-day Youth Park in western Taipei and the 228 Peace Memorial Park in downtown Taipei, as well as meeting with Vice President Annette Lu, who was imprisoned for nearly six years for her pro-democracy activities during Taiwan's martial law era.

Tutu will deliver a speech April 24 on South Africa's experiences in seeking transitional justice and ethnic reconciliation following the end of apartheid. As head of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Tutu has played a leading role in his country's post-apartheid campaign to heal its historical wounds and boost ethnic harmony.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLING REMAINS RAMPANT: KAOHSIUNG CUSTOMS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung customs agents seized contraband products worth over NT$42 million (US$1.2 million) in 249 cases in the first quarter of this year, according to the Kaohsiung Customs Office under the Ministry of Finance.

The high value of the contraband highlights the fact that smuggling remains rampant in the first three months of the year despite a drive launched earlier this year by the Kaohsiung customs authorities to wipe out illicit imports, office officials said.

According to officials, many of the contraband items, including drugs, firearms and unlawful chemical substances were concealed on shipping boats or inside containers, and some pricey contraband goods were also disguised as cheap products by smuggling rings in an attempt to import them at lower tariff rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIND ENERGY CUTS CO2 EMISSIONS IN TAIWAN BY 250,000 TONS A YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, central Taiwan, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/07 19:04:38 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of wind turbines along Taiwan's west coast now surpasses 100, and the renewable energy generated by these units is sufficient to prevent the emission of 250,000 tons of carbon dioxide a year, energy officials said Sunday.

At a ceremony held in the Changhua Coastal Industrial Park to promote the use of wind power, officials from the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said the 103 giant wind turbines located in 13 wind farms along Taiwan's west coast can generate 420 million kilowatt-hours of electricity a year -- enough to power 105,000 households.

The windmills were established by Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), the private-run Tien-Lung Paper Co. and InfraVest Wind Power Group, a German company which entered the market in 2000 as the first wind farm builder in Taiwan.

According to the officials, more windmills are under construction in west coastal areas and the outlying island group of Penghu, with an additional total capacity of 500 megawatts. Each unit will cost at least NT$100 million.

They said Taiwan's coastal areas are ideal for the development of wind power because they have six months of strong northwest winds each year, with an average wind speed of five to six meters per second.
The Bureau of Energy has set the target of generating enough renewable energy to meet 10 percent of Taiwan's electricity needs by 2010, with wind power making up 80 percent of the renewable energy.
Taipower, the sole electricity supplier in Taiwan, began to harness wind energy in 2002 and plans to establish 200 wind turbines in Taiwan and Penghu by 2010.

Taipower's long-term wind power development plant will build an additional 546 wind turbines between 2010 and 2020 in shallow waters off Taiwan's west coast and Penghu, with a total capacity of 1,980 megawatts at an estimated cost of NT$200 million each.
Out of the 546 windmills, 176 will be built off Penghu, and the electricity generated by these units will be transmitted to Taiwan through a 40-km undersea cable.
The other 370 units will be established 10 to 15 km off the coast of Changhua and Yunlin counties, according to Taipower.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRIMARY SYSTEM 'UNFAVORABLE' TO REFORMISTS: FORMER LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Opinion polls conducted under the current system of the ruling Democratic Party (DPP) to determine nominees for 2007 year-end legislative elections are "unfavorable" to reform-minded candidates, a former DPP lawmaker said Sunday.

At a ceremony marking the formal establishment of his campaign office, Lin Cho- shui, who resigned as legislator in November last year to protest the DPP's handling of a corruption scandal implicating President Chen Shui-bian and his wife, said he hopes he can win an extra legislative seat for the DPP by competing in Taipei's No. 1 electoral district.
Lin claimed, however, that the DPP's primary system is unfavorable to him and other reformists.
He expressed fear that the DPP might win only one seat in all the electoral districts in the city of Taipei.
Lin is a former member of the disbanded New Tide Faction within the DPP.
New Tide members were known for their outspokenness in criticizing DPP policies and actions and voicing alternatives.
Other former members of the New Tide Faction, including Legislator Hung Chi- chang and former DPP Legislator Tuan Yi-kang, were on hand to extend their congratulations.

Tuan, former chief convener of New Tide, told reporters that the DPP's primary system is "seriously flawed" and that nominees selected under such a system would face considerable difficulties in the legislative election.

Nominations of candidates during the DPP's primary hinge to a large degree on opinion polls to determine the approval ratings of the candidates. The poll results account for 70 percent in the final calculation of candidate ratings.

The DPP's Central Standing Committee has decided to exclude 50 percent of voters and survey the opinion of only those who have voted for candidates of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, in the last three elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS URGE DISTRICT HOSPITALS TO FOCUS ON SENIOR CARE

TEXT.P: Medical representatives proposed Sunday that district community hospitals should transform into senior care centers in response to the advent of an aging society, thereby solving many problems associated with challenges to hospitals' survival in the face of shrinking market share.

The current environment favors the development of large hospitals and physician clinics, making medium and small hospitals less competitive, said representatives at a symposium organized by National Health Research Institutes and Cardinal Tien Hospital Yung Ho branch.

Such hospitals have been left with no option but to increase their utilization to generate additional income, the representatives said, adding that while the proportion of Taiwan's aged population has soared significantly and now accounts for 10 percent of the total population, it is estimated in 20 years one out five citizens will be a senior; that rapidly aging population is expected to stimulate the demand for elder care services.

A veteran health care professional said that the elderly tend to have chronic illnesses, such as high blood pressure, stoke, diabetes, cataract, osteoporosis and dementia, and that the older adults often have multiple chronic diseases for which they require a variety of medications and treatments.

She added that on average each older person takes four types of medications daily, with others taking as many as six types of medication. Although there are 261 sick beds provided by nursing homes for every 10,000 seniors, only 197 beds have been used on average because most of the aged wish to stay home in the company of their families.

A representative devoted in senior health care research said that senior care services offered in advanced countries feature integrated local medical treatments, and in-home care and social resources.

Under the sponsorship of the Department of Health, a total of 16 hospitals around the country have launched projects aimed at providing integrated senior health care services, including Chiayi Christian Hospital and Cardinal Tien Hospital Yung Ho branch.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUP TO MARK 'SPANK OUT DAY'

TEXT.P: In line with an international "Spank Out Day" April 30, the Humanistic Education Foundation announced Sunday that it will mark the day April 29 in Taiwan by organizing activities in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung.

According to foundation officials, street parades and garden fairs will be held in the three major Taiwan cities on the same day to observe the international movement launched by the Center for Effective Discipline with an aim of raising awareness among Taiwanese parents that corporal punishments are not the only way to discipline children.

Foundation officials expressed hope that Taiwanese parents will find ways to teach and educate their children without physical punishment after attending their activities which suggest local parents get along with their kids through a wide range of games helpful in improving their interactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASPIRANT PUTS FORTH ALTERNATIVE PLAN ON EASTERN TAIWAN DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: A presidential aspirant of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party suggested Sunday that the country seek to follow a "Taiwan Piloting Plan" to develop eastern Taiwan should the controversial freeway connecting Suao and Hualien not be constructed due to environmental considerations.

Frank Hsieh, who had served as premier and Kaohsiung mayor, said he agrees with President Chen Shui-bian that it is essential that the Suhua freeway be built provided that it passes environmental analysis review.

Chen said the day before that it was an established government policy that a round-the-island freeway be built, and that it was essential to build a freeway connecting Suao in the eastern county of Yilan with its neighboring county of Hualien. "However, we cannot go ahead with the project if it fails the environmental review, " Chen said.
Commenting on that, Hsieh said that he has been aware since he was the premier a couple of years ago that the Suhua freeway development project is unlikely to pass the environmental analysis review.

Consequently, Hsieh said, he has been promoting the alternative "Taiwan Piloting Plan", which exclusively aims at developing eastern Taiwan where counties are characterized by relatively small populations in which the natural environment and agriculture are the most valuable assets.
Hsieh envisaged funds being raised and stakeholders consulted under the "Taiwan Piloting Plan", so that signature industries and products with local features might be developed.

Meanwhile, Stanley Yen, chairman of the Ritz Landis hotel group, who is also an environmentalist, said during an event held in Taipei to mark the April 22 Earth Day, that the Suhua freeway development issue is an ethical issue, rather than a political issue.

Yen, who was instrumental in arranging for a visit to eastern Taiwan in March by the management of the top-flight Burj Al Arab Hotel on a business inspection tour, urged politicians to display greater ethical conscience, saying that if Taiwan's people want to be world citizens, they should first learn to be citizens of the Earth and try harder to protect the global environment.

Taking the Beiyi freeway connecting Taipei and Yilan as an example, Yen said that the construction of the Hsuehshan Tunnel, which is part of the Beiyi freeway, left Taiwan's invaluable, millennia-old water resources damaged and the proposed Suhau freeway will intrude into 17 biological sensitive zones. The Beiyi freeway was opened to public traffic last year amid ongoing doubts and disputes over environmental issues.

Yen invited Alwin Zecha, the younger brother of the owner of the seven-star Burj Al Arab Hotel and two-term chairman of the Pacific Asia Travel Association, to visit the eastern county of Taitung. News reports stated that the hotelier from Dubai was initially interested in turning a Taitung hot spring hotel into a new attraction, taking advantage of the natural beauty and white sand of the quiet city by the Pacific Ocean.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SINGAPORE SAID AT ODDS OVER ENVOY SELECTION
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/07 20:26:57 (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Singapore and Taiwan are at odds over each other's diplomatic personnel selection, informed sources said over the weekend.

According to these sources, Singapore has rejected Taiwan's offer to have the former chief of the General Staff serve as its new representative to the city- state on the excuse that "his status is too sensitive."
On the other hand, the sources went on, Singapore proposed assigning a low- echelon official to be its top liaison officer in Taiwan, an offer Taiwan has ruled out.

Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs has so far made no comment on all those reports, while Taiwan's Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Chien-yeh has also refrained from responding to any inquiries about relevant personnel replacement speculation.

As Taiwan's representative to Singapore, Hu Wei-jen, will soon serve out the remainder of a second and final term of office, and Singapore is also planning to reshuffle the lineup of its mission in Taipei, the sources said the two countries had discussed the issue earlier this year.

According to sources, President Chen Shui-bian once told Singapore representative Ker Sin Tze that his administration planned to appoint Lee Tien- yu, a former chief of the General Staff to succeed Hu as Taiwan's representative to Singapore.
Since Taiwan and Singapore have long cooperated in military affairs, Ker was reportedly positive on the replacement proposal and conveyed the message to his home country.

However, the sources said, processing for the planned personnel reshuffle was suspended after Singapore's Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew publicly criticized President Chen last month over his "Four Wants, One Without" doctrine that Lee thought could provoke China with its pro-independence rhetoric. Relations between Taiwan and Singapore have since plunged to a new low, the sources said.

Early this month, sources say, the Singapore Foreign Ministry informed Taiwan through a formal channel of its refusal to accept Lee as Taiwan's new envoy to the city-state, which is why Taiwan's Presidential Office made no mention of Hu's replacement in its recent announcement of Hu's transfer to a new post at home.

Meanwhile, sources say, Singapore has informed Taiwan of its plan to assign Stanley Loh, a press secretary of former Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, as its new representative to Taiwan, and would prefer to make the personnel changeover in July.

In Singapore's personnel hierarchy, Loh's ranking is equivalent to that of a deputy division chief. Unhappy with Singapore's arrangement, sources say Taipei has politely let Singapore know of its disapproval with Loh's appointment.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Taipei and Singapore have tended to maintain friendly and stable relations, with each side traditionally posting a political heavyweight to the other's territory to facilitate communications. However, the rapport between the two countries has come under strain in recent years partly because they do not see eye-to-eye on approaches toward China.

While Singapore is critical of Taiwan's resistance to reconciliation with China at the expense of its sovereign status, Taiwan is dismissive of Singapore's attempts to harmonize its cross-Taiwan Strait policy with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 TRADITIONAL TROUPES TO EMBARK ON PERFORMANCE TOUR IN U.S. CANADA

TEXT.P: Three traditional dance and percussion troupes will depart Taiwan Wednesday for a 35-city performance tour in the United States and Canada as part of the country's cultural diplomacy drive, government sources said Sunday.

The troupes will represent Taiwan during the "Asian Pacific American Heritage Month" in the United States, a celebration of Asians and Pacific islanders and their cultures, said Chang Fu-mei, chairwoman of the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC).

Former U.S. President George H.W. Bush designated May as Asian Pacific American Heritage Month in 1990 and his successor Bill Clinton designated the second week in May as the Taiwanese American Heritage Week in 1999. Clinton did so after lobbying by the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, a Washington-based group dedicated to promoting Taiwan's cause.

The three troupes -- the Jyou Tian Folk Drumming and Arts Group, the Hongsheng Lion Dance Troupe and the Honwa Folk Dance Troupe -- will present acrobatic dragon and lion dances, drum performances and Taiwanese martial arts demonstrations, Chang said.
"The troupes, composed mostly of young people, will give 35 performances in major cities across the U.S. and Canada to offer a look at Taiwan's culture and folk arts," Chang explained.

Meanwhile, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Tzu-pao said the troupes' performance tour is the work of cultural diplomacy, a valuable vehicle to showcase Taiwan's spirit, folk culture and customs, and upgrade its international profile and image.

Praising the troupe members as cultural ambassadors, Yang said they are getting Taiwan's name out there. He further said the United States is an ideal place to embark on cultural diplomacy since its administration has designated the second week in May as an official celebration of Taiwan, giving Taiwan a unique opportunity to boost cultural ties with the U.S.

According to OCAC Chairwoman Chang, some members of the troupes come from troubled backgrounds, even being placed in juvenile reformatory schools. The OCAC works with them closely, and all are in night school in addition to rehearsing dance and drumming routines by day, Chang said, adding that these individuals have successfully transformed themselves.

A number of government agencies, including the OCAC, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Education, the Government Information Office and the National Youth Commission, will jointly finance the troupes' North America tour.

New York Times:In Turnabout, Infant Deaths Climb in South
For decades, Mississippi and neighboring states with large black populations and expanses of enduring poverty made steady progress in reducing infant death. But, in what health experts call an ominous portent, progress has stalled and in recent years the death rate has risen in Mississippi and several other states.
The setbacks have raised questions about the impact of cuts in welfare and Medicaid and of poor access to doctors, and, many doctors say, the growing epidemics of obesity, diabetes and hypertension among potential mothers, some of whom tip the scales here at 300 to 400 pounds.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH AGENCY TO OPEN TRAINING COURSES FOR FEMALE ENTREPRENEURS

TEXT.P: The National Youth Commission (NYC) will hold a series of training courses for prospective female entrepreneurs around the country beginning in May to help women set up their own business, a NYC official said Sunday.
The NYC started up the innovative program to provide women with entrepreneurial guidance in 2000, and over the past seven years the program has attracted 14,000 participants, the official said.

The official added that the program has so far borne fruit in many respects, including providing leadership among government agencies and pushing other agencies to attach greater importance to female entrepreneurs.
For example, following the NYC lead, the Ministry of Labor Affairs initiated the Micro-business Start-up Loan program this year, officials pointed out.

The official quoted a survey conducted by the NYC stating that 90 percent of office ladies said they are interested in starting a business, while only 30 percent of those applying for business start-up loans for young entrepreneurs were women, showing that women were more conservative in dealing with personal finances.

Other figures showed that a total of 390,000 enterprises in Taiwan were headed by women, accounting for 34 percent of the total, while the revenue streams of these companies comprised only 13 percent of the total, the official said, adding that there is still ample room for growth in terms of female business start-up.

The NYC programs are characterized by offering the best guidelines for business practices, and for launching many activities for women in the business sector, including training in writing operating proposals, applying for loans, marketing products, as well as offering consultation and enterprises diagnostic services.

The courses are slated to open May 5, and with the auspices of the NYC, those interested in participating are required to pay only a NT$1,000 enrollment fee, the official said, adding that further information is available on their Web site: www.nyc.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TYCOON INITIATES PROGRAM TO HELP STUDENTS IN REMOTE AREAS

TEXT.P: Terry Guo, founder of the Foxconn Technology Group, promised to donate NT$700 million (US$21.12 million) over two years to help students in remote areas to improve their academic performance.

Guo made the announcement Sunday at the inauguration of the so-called Hope School, a program formulated by the Yungling Foundation which was set up by Guo in 2000 and headed by his daughter Guo Hsiao-ling.

Terry Guo said under the Hope School program, the Yungling Foundation works together with eight universities as well as other education institutions around the island to provide after-school tutoring to students in remote areas to give them a hand up on studying.

Noting that education is the best weapon to fight poverty, the business tycoon who is touted as one of the richest man in Taiwan said he hope the program can help 20,000 students over the next two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOAHSIUNG DEPUTY MAYOR TO ATTEND INT'L SPORTS CONFERENCE IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Cheng Wen-lung is set to head for Beijing Monday for the annual conference of the International World Games Association, Kaohsiung city officials said Sunday.

Cheng will be accompanied by Hsiao Yu-jeng, director-general of the city's Information Department, and Chen I-heng, chief executive officer of the Kaohsiung Organizing Committee for the World Games 2009.

In addition to giving a briefing on Kaohsiung's preparation for the World Games 2009 at the conference, the officials said, Cheng and his entourage will also set up a booth at the revenue of the conference to promote the Kaohsiung World Games 2009.
The officials said, Cheng and his entourage will also take lessons from Beijing's preparation for the 2008 Olympics to stage the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 23, or the seventh day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered by most as the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest the ceding of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become the U.S. ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple, she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: U.S. and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after the South Vietnamese regime's Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
1999: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurates a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.
2000: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord visits People First Party Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the Taiwan Strait situation.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kick off an island-wide tour to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential election.
2001: Computer chip giant Intel signs a memorandum of cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau and the Technology Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
TRADE, TEACHERS' GROUPS CALL FOR MINIMUM WAGE HIKE ASAP

TEXT.P: Trade and teachers' groups urged the government Monday to raise the country's minimum wage, which has been frozen at the same level for a decade, immediately to make it more commensurate with Taiwan's general economic situation and consumer price index.

At a news conference held in the leadup to International Labor Day on May 1, representatives of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Union (TCTU) and National Teachers' Association (NTA) demanded that the government raise the minimum wage immediately to show that the government is concerned about the "survival rights" of lower-echelon workers.

TCTU Chairman Shih Chao-hsien said that over the past several years, enormous amounts of Taiwan capital has flowed overseas at a tremendous pace as a result of a "specious" government policy of financial liberalization. The outflow of capital has in turn compromised domestic workers' rights and interests, he claimed.

Shih added that the country's minimum wage, which has remained at NT$15,840 (US$480) per month, or NT$66 per hour, for 10 years, is not commensurate with current economic realities, including rising inflation. This is a development that has prevented low-level workers from maintaining "a living with dignity" or even securing their basic "rights to survival," he said.
NTA Chairman Wu Chung-tai said that many parents have taken on extra jobs just to try to make ends meet, adding that this moonlighting has had an impact on parent-child relations.

The representatives also called for the administration to institutionalize regular adjustments of the minimum wage and to convene a meeting at least once a year in this regard to keep the minimum wage fully commensurate with the actual economic and social situations. They also resolved that TCTU and NTA members will rally on Labor Day and invite six presidential aspirants from the ruling and opposition parties to make known their resolutions and ideals about the country's labor policy.

Lee Ying-yuan, Taiwan's top official in charge of labor affairs, said earlier this month that the minimum wage will be adjusted in the second half of this year, probably July 1, although the exact timing for the implementation can be readily changed based on practical considerations.

As to the adjustment range, Lee said, a combination of factors, including the increase in the average consumer price index over the past decade, Taiwan's general economic growth as well as the possible adverse impact on local industries' competitiveness, should be taken into consideration when deciding on the level of the minimum wage increase.

While the business community has declared that 5 percent is the maximum level they are willing to accept for an upward adjustment, labor groups want a far larger hike, Lee said, adding that he once proposed at a Legislative Yuan session that the minimum wage be raised to 40 percent of the average salary of all workers in the country. If adopted, the minimum wage would be increased to NT$17,600 per month, representing a hike of 11 percent over the current level.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 67.79 points to close at 8,010.46.

The bourse opened at 8,009.55, and fluctuated between 8,062.7 and 8,006.42 during the day's trading. A total of 4 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$101.85 billion (US$3.08 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at two percent, followed by construction issues at 1.5 percent, machinery and electronic shares at one percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.8 percent, and banking and financial stocks at 0.5 percent.
Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.01 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 615 to 550, with 197 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved up 129 points to close at 8,016, with 41,605 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June rose 126 points to finish at 8,008, with 597 contracts traded, while September futures increased 110 points to close at 7,802, with 214 contract transactions. December futures gained 128 points to close at 7,803, with 16 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 107 points to finish at 7,816, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,887 for May, 7,882 for June, 7,692 for September, 7,675 for December and 7,709 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

May TE futures gained 5.25 points to close at 336.7, with 3,283 contracts traded, while June TE futures rose 5.4 points to finish at 334.8, with 34 contract transactions. September TE futures increased 2.75 points to close at 328.65, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

May TF futures moved up 9.6 points to close at 984.8, with 1,897 contracts traded, while June TF futures gained 10.2 points to finish at 987, with 16 contract transactions.
