DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL LAND RESTORATION PLAN EXPECTED TO EFFECT SEVERAL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: A national land restoration plan put forward recently by the Executive Yuan is expected to have an impact on some domestic industries, particularly the cement processing industry, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Monday.

The plan -- formulated in line with a national land restoration draft bill, which is pending in the legislature -- stipulates that public land in high elevation areas or areas zoned for restoration should not be leased out to private companies for business usage.

Chen Tai-hsiung, a deputy director of the MOEA Bureau of Mines, said that the land restoration plan is seen to have an adverse impact on the cement, iron and steel, and petrochemical processing industries. He added that if the plan is implemented, Taiwan's cement and marble processing industries will be the first to be affected, with many plants in these sectors being forced to close down due to a dearth of raw materials.
Meanwhile, Taiwan Cement Corp., one of the country's major cement producers, does not expect the national land restoration plan to have any immediate impact on its business operations.

A corporate source said that Taiwan Cement has taken out leases on three mine areas around the island for the extraction of hard rocks or softer rocks for the production of cement. The leases don't expire until 2017.

In addition, the source said, according to Taiwan Cement's new extraction contracts with the government, only three percent of the land in the leased rock mining areas is at an elevation of higher than 1,000 meters.
The source added that Taiwan Cement has always been environmentally- conscious and has helped green the mining areas while excavating raw materials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL FAIR TO OPEN THURSDAY

TEXT.P: The seventh Taichung International Travel Fair (TITF) is scheduled to be held April 26-29 at the World Trade Center in the central Taiwan city, with tens of thousands of people expected to visit the fair to hunt for bargain tour packages.

According to the organizers, including the Tourist Bureau and the Taichung City government, those taking part in the fair include the central and all local governments around the country, as well as foreign tourism organizations, and local operators of hotels, travel agencies, theme parks and tourist attractions.

The fair venue will be divided into several exhibition areas, including ones featuring foreign and domestic travel, government efforts in the promotion of tourism, and a stage where foreign performing groups from Ghana, Russia, Ukraine and France will put on shows as part of the fair's activities.

The organizers said Monday that the annual travel fair has successfully increased exchanges between domestic and overseas tourist sectors and boosted Taiwan's tourism development since first being held in 2000. In 2006, 236 businesses and governmental tourism agencies took part in the TITF, which attracted over 70,000 visitors, up 12.5 percent over the previous year's level, the organizers said.
A total of 265 private businesses and governmental units have applied to take part in the 2007 event, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP VOWS TO CRACK DOWN ON VOTE-BUYING PRIOR TO PRIMARY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that if there is evidence to support vote buying allegations in the party's upcoming legislative primary, the party will deal with them harshly.

DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung made the remarks amid reports that the approval ratings for 19 legislative aspirants vying for the at-large seats are close and that the competition is fierce. They will be ensured a berth in the year-end streamlined legislature if they can garner 20,000 votes in the member vote May 6. As such, rumors have it that one ballot is selling for NT$3,000 (US$90.9).

Lin noted that the party has a task force charged with cracking down on vote- buying and that it is probing the rumors, but he also urged the media and the aspirants to refrain from "insinuations" and "exaggerating" election corruption.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Yu Cheng-dao urged the party to get to the bottom of the vote-buying rumors, while his colleague Gao Jyh-peng said that if there are no cash rewards or interference by the government, it will be difficult for the party alone to track down vote-buying.

The new legislature will be elected through a "single-seat constituency, two ballots" system instead of the existing "single vote, multiple-seat constituency" system. Voters will cast two ballots, one for the constituency and another for their favored political party.

The 225-seat legislature will also be halved to 113 members, with 73 seats elected from regional districts, six seats for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

The regional seats will be distributed among the special municipalities, counties and cities according to their populations, with each locality enjoying at least one seat and one legislator elected from each district. The at-large and overseas expatriate seats will be allocated to political parties that win at least 5 percent of the votes cast, according to the proportion of votes they garner.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONALITY LAW WOULD BECOME 'IMMIGRATION FAST TRACK:' DPP LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator expressed worry Monday that an article of the existing Nationality Law could provide a fast track for foreign nationals to become Republic of China citizens.

DPP Legislator Wang Hsin-nan was basing his concern on Item I of Article Three of the Nationality Law, which he said stipulates that foreigners or non-ROC citizens who stay over 183 days per year in Taiwan for five consecutive years are allowed to apply for Republic of China citizenship.

This item, he claimed, might open a convenient door to foreign nationals, particularly foreigners who are hired to work aboard Taiwan fishing vessels; foreign household helpers or caregivers; and foreign laborers hired to work on major national development projects, since these type of people are allowed to stay in Taiwan for up to six years per contract in accordance with a newly passed amendment to an article in the employment services law.
Wang said the legislature must do something on what he described as this contradiction caused by two articles from two different laws.
The Legislative Yuan's Home and Nations Committee will study whether Nationality Law should be revised as proposed by Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEACHERS' ASSOCIATION RESERVES RIGHT TO MAKE UNRULY STUDENTS STAND

TEXT.P: The National Teachers' Association said Monday that teachers can make unruly students stand so that "they can reflect upon their wrongs."

The association issued the clarification after the Apple Daily, a local tabloid, reported that the Ministry of Education will soon publish guidelines for teachers counselling or disciplining students. One claim by the paper was that teachers, when disciplining students, would need their consent.
The teachers will also not be able to demand students to do pushups or frog jumps if the purpose is to punish the students, according to the reports.

Yang Yi-feng, an association official, said that in the future, there will be no such thing as a "disciplinary stand" and that the teachers will only require students "stand to reflect upon themselves."
Since the purpose is for the students to reflect upon themselves, the teachers will not need to obtain the students' consent, he added.

The Legislative Yuan approved a total ban on corporal punishment last December. An attached resolution also asked the Ministry of Education and the National Teachers' Association to work out guidelines on campus discipline.
The association said that after discussions over the last four months, it has mapped out details of the guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHALLENGES KMT TO SUBSTANTIATE ACCUSATIONS OF BUYING TV TIME

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) challenged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday to come up with evidence to substantiate its claims that the DPP presidential hopefuls are "buying" TV news reports.

Lawmaker Wang Tuoh, secretary of the DPP Legislative Caucus, said lies cannot be turned into truth by simply repeating them and that the KMT, which claims three of the four DPP presidential aspirants have offered money to local TV channels in exchange for news coverage of their election campaign, should verify their accusation with evidence or keep quite.

Noting that the source of the accusation was accredited to Yang Tu, director of the KMT's Cultural and Communications Committee, Wang said Yang is the last person who should make the accusation because he himself was financed by Ma Ying-jeou to film a documentary of the 228 Incident about a revolt by the Taiwanese against the KMT regime in 1947, with the purpose of whitewashing KMT's role in the incident.
The film was shot in 2004 when Ma served as mayor of Taipei and before Yang was named the chief of the cultural committee.

Yang was quoted by Monday's United Daily News as saying that among the DPP presidential hopefuls -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Cheng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun -- all except Lu have bought TV news coverage through proxies.
Yang condemned the three DPP hopefuls for infringing on the ethics of journalism and perhaps breaching the law regulating political donations.

The paper also quoted Ba Jien, a manager of the Formosa Television Company Ltd. as saying that politicians are likely to ask for more news coverage while placing their political TV commercials, and that his station is willing to offer KMT politicians the same treatment if they buy commercials from Formosa TV.

Based on Yang's claims, KMT lawmaker Ting Shou-chung asked the National Communications Commission Monday to stem the placement of TV advertisements featuring politicians during the election campaign period.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.029 to close at NT$33.166.
A total of US$1.019 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.137 and hit a high of NT$33.178.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HOPES QUICK PASSAGE OF NATIONAL PENSION BILL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan hopes a draft bill for the National Pension Act will clear the Legislative Yuan by the end of this year, the vice minister of the interior said Monday.

Lin Mei-chu made the remarks during a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan after a local newspaper reported earlier that the bill proposed by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has been delivered to the Executive Yuan for review.

According to the report by the China Times in its Monday edition, the draft bill stipulates that persons aged above 65 who have joined the proposed pension program for 40 years will be entitled to a monthly pension of NT$7,603 (US$229).
Lin said it has so far not yet come to a final decision in terms of the pension amount, nor the date for beginning the program's operation.

Also at the Legislative Yuan, Executive Yuan spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling explained that after receiving the bill from the MOI April 12, the Executive Yuan commissioned Minister without Portfolio Lin Wan-yi to form a task force to review the bill.

The draft bill is expected to be delivered to the Cabinet plenary meeting for certification by May 2, Chen said, adding that the MOI will not file detailed reports on how it will enact the national pension act or when it will begin to operate the pension program until the bill is certified.
This bill proposes that anyone aged 25 to 64 not covered by any form of social insurance be included in the national pension program.

Forty percent of the monthly premium will be paid by the government. For the handicapped, the government subsidy will increase in accordance with the degree of disability. Low-income families will be exempt from the premium, according to the Executive Yuan.

Chen also noted that the Executive Yuan is opposed to any proposals by lawmakers to raise the amount of any of the existing stipend programs before the long- planned national pension program is implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU-TAIWAN TRADE LAST YEAR RECORDS 6.8% GROWTH IN TAIWAN'S FAVOR

TEXT.P: Bilateral trade between Taiwan and the European Union (EU) increased 6.8 percent to 39.4 billion euros (US$53.4 billion) last year, making Taiwan the EU's 14th- largest trading partner worldwide, according to figures released Monday by the European Economic and Trade Office in Taiwan.

In its EU Newsletter for April, the office quoted figures by Eurostat, the EU's statistics office, as showing that Taiwanese exports to the EU for 2006 recorded a growth of 9.7 percent, reaching 26 billion euros.

In contrast, EU exports to Taiwan, valued at 13 billion euros, were far less dynamic, representing growth of only 1.5 percent and leaving a deficit of 13 billion euros for the EU -- almost 20 percent larger than in 2005.
In 2006, Taiwan was the EU's 10th-largest supplier of goods and its 23rd-biggest customer.

Compared with 2005, Taiwan fell four notches last year to become the EU's 14th- largest trading partner worldwide. In Asia, Taiwan was the EU's fifth-largest trading partner, behind China, Japan, South Korea and India.
In 2005, Taiwan was the EU's fourth-largest partner, but last year Taiwan was replaced by India, which recorded a two-way trade of 46 billion euros with the EU.

Citing statistics compiled by Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs, the European Economic and Trade Office pointed out that new EU investment in Taiwan totaled US$7 billion in 2006, accounting for more than half of all new foreign investment in Taiwan.

As a result, accumulated EU direct investment in Taiwan has more than doubled to US$15 billion, accounting for 20 percent of all foreign direct investment in Taiwan and making the EU the largest foreign investor in Taiwan, ahead of the United States and Japan.
The number of Taiwanese visitors to the EU reached a record high of 330,000 last year, representing an increase of 10 percent over 2005.

Approximately 25,000 Taiwanese students are studying in Europe today, including more than 12,000 who enrolled in 2006. Many students from Taiwan have taken advantage of opportunities offered by EU member states and the EU Commission to obtain grants and scholarships.

Guy Ledoux, head of the European Economic and Trade Office in Taiwan, who assumed office in March, said in the newsletter that his office will continue to promote a healthy trade environment in Taiwan for the 25-state EU.
"Dialogue and willingness to resolve trade issues will continue to be the most productive approach," Ledoux said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL INTERPRETATION ON MA'S PRESIDENTIAL BID URGED

TEXT.P: A lawmaker urged the Central Election Commission (CEC) Monday to ask the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) for a constitutional explanation on the bid by former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, an indicted suspect on corruption charges, to run in the 2008 presidential race.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Yu Cheng-tao made the call in a Legislative Yuan news conference, as it is increasingly obvious that Ma is set to become the main opposition KMT's presidential candidate. Ma is widely believed to be a strong contender in the 2008 presidential polls.

Yu called on the CEC to ask the CGJ to rule on Ma's presidential bid after he registers with the CEC to run in the next presidential election or on the constitutionality of his election, to fend off unnecessary rows in the future should he be convicted after his election.

As the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law bans citizens convicted with a prison term of over 10 years in the first trial or those convicted in the third and final trial on corruption charges from running in presidential elections, Yu also urged Ma to drop his presidential bid, as the ex-KMT chief was indicted in mid-February by Taipei prosecutors on corruption charges.
Holding a new presidential election would cost about NT$1.2 billion, he said.

The Taipei District Court has opened two hearings on Ma's case since early this month over his alleged embezzlement of about NT$11 million in funds from a special monthly municipal allowance earmarked for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.
Ma maintains his innocence and has represented himself in his defense during the two sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO RELEASE REPORT ON KMT'S ILL-GOTTEN PARTY ASSETS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will release the results of an investigation into the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) "ill-gotten" party assets April 25, and a Web site publishing the survey outcome will go online that same day, an Executive Yuan official said Monday.

According to the official, the survey on the KMT's illegally or improperly acquired party assets during its authoritarian rule of Taiwan, was completed recently by agencies under the Executive Yuan coordinated by Minister without Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung.

The official said the investigation results will include many categories, including real estate owned by the KMT or its affiliates, revenues of the party's business, and surplus retirement payments for retired KMT personnel whose party employment was considered equivalent to government seniority.

Quoting statistics conducted by the National Property Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the official said the KMT has 685 plots of land registered of a total of 148 hectares, valued at about NT$24.32 billion. Another NT$168 million comes from the party's ownership of the Chientan Youth Activity Center.

Statistics of the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that seven main businesses owned by the KMT gained net revenue of NT$87.1 billion from 1994-2005, the official said, adding that NT$100 million has been paid to 267 retired KMT personnel who were allowed to count their party employment toward their government seniority and received pensions accordingly.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REMAINS NEUTRAL ON DPP PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday he believes that President Chen Shui-bian is neutral on the four contenders bidding to represent the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the 2008 presidential election.
Su made the remarks in an interview with CNA amid reports that Chen is throwing his weight behind Su in the hotly contested primary.

To the best of his knowledge, Su said, Chen has so far kept an "appropriate and congruent distance from each hopeful" in his capacity as the country's head of state and the party's most important figure.
"President Chen has maintained his noble status as the country's head of state and is unlikely to express his personal preference regarding the candidacy choice at the moment, " Su said.

In the DPP primary fray, Su's political rivals have questioned his loyalty toward Chen during last year's "red-shirt" campaign aimed at forcing Chen to step down over corruption allegations and Su's handling of a controversial plan to build an expressway linking the eastern county of Hualien to Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan.
On those two cases, Chen offered prompt and detailed explanations favorable to Su, which led to speculation that Chen backs Su.
Su described the speculation as meaningless. "Chen stood up mainly because he was personally involved in those issues and was in the best position to clarify misunderstandings," he added.
Nonetheless, Su went on, there tends to be good faith between the president and the premier. "Without the president's trust, a premier can't do anything," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CUSTOMS OFFICE UNCOVERS VIAGRA-SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Customs Office (KCO) under the Ministry of Finance uncovered smuggled counterfeit Viagra and sleeping drugs in a container imported from China Monday, a Customs officer said.
Also found in the same container were 194 China-made granite urns that are under import controls, the officer said.
According to the officer, the 13,300 Viagra and 249,000 Stilnox tablets were identified as counterfeit drugs by pharmaceutical company representatives.
The Kaohsiung Customs Office kept the smuggled items for inspection under the Customs Anti-smuggling Act and Pharmaceutical Affairs Act, the officer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-TECH FIRMS HAIL DISABLED EMPLOYEES

TEXT.P: Defying the traditional concept that physically and mentally disabled people are not competitive in the high-tech industry, executives of three local electronic firms hailed them Monday for their efficiency.

The chief executive officers of three companies made the remarks at a press conference held in Taipei to mark the 10th anniversary of the promulgation of the country's Physically and Mentally Disabled Citizens Protection Act.

The CEO of Siliconware Precision Industries Co., the world's third-largest provider of semiconductor assembly and test services, noted that they now hire 139 physically and mentally disabled persons in comparison with the total number of 11,505 employees of the company.
The executive admitted that although physically and mentally disabled people learn things relatively slowly, they are more likely to concentrate.
Citing the example of some aurally impaired employees, the CEO said they can totally focus on their work since they are less likely to be bothered by outside noise.
In addition, they will treasure their jobs more and perform excellently if given the opportunity, the CEO added.

The Chipbond Technology Corp., which is a leading provider of wafer bumping services, was fined for several years for failing to hire a sufficient percentage of physically and mentally disabled persons as stipulated by the law, until it finally hired the required ratio early this year.

A Chipbond executive said the company found the lifetime of the production machines increased, which the firm attributed to the care of the disabled employees. Among the current 1,937 employees of Chipbond, 24 are disabled.
A section chief of Coretronic, a 1,000-employee company dedicated to offering projection and display solutions, said the firm employs 33 physically and mentally disabled persons.
With adequate arrangements, the Coretronic executive said, disability does not cause a hindrance to working ability.

Lee Ying-yuan, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs (COA) , said on the same occasion that the COA's goal for this year is to train some 3,000 physically or mentally disabled persons and to help 3,000 of them to find work in public organizations or private corporations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE JOBLESS RATE IN FIRST THREE MONTHS HITS SIX-YEAR LOW: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The average jobless rate in the first three months of the year hit a six-year low of 3.84 percent, down 0.02 percentage points from the same period of last year, the government reported Monday.

According to officials at the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), the March unemployment rate was 3.94 percent, up 0.16 percentage points from the previous month, thanks mainly to the end of short-term jobs offered during the Chinese New Year holiday and an increase in the number of people seeking new jobs after the holiday.
The number of jobless was 420,000 in March, up 18,000 from the previous month, which the officials said were the second-lowest March figure in nearly six years.

The average number of jobless in the first three months of this year hit a six- year low compared with the average jobless rate of 5.14 percent in the first three months of 2002, 5.09 percent in 2003, 4.53 percent in 2004, 4.16 percent in 2005 and 3.86 percent in 2006.
The officials noted that the number of employed was 10.24 million in March, up 1,000 from February or 215,000 from the same period of last year.

In terms of sectors, the number employed in the service and agriculture sectors increased by 13,000 and 3,000, respectively, while the number of those employed in the industrial sector decreased by 16,000.
Looking ahead, the officials said there will be no structural changes in the job market and predicted continued steady growth and that the jobless rates will drop further in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN SIGNS TAIWAN FUTURE CONVENTION

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun signed a declaration proposed by the pro-independence Southern Taiwan Society Monday, pledging to give birth to a new constitution for Taiwan if he is elected president of the country in the 2008 presidential election.

Signatories of the Taiwan Future Convention declaration are obliged to use all their power to promote the use of major local dialects, including Southern Min, Hakka and aboriginal in educational programs in middle and elementary schools, to strengthen the curriculum on Taiwan's history and literature in middle and elementary schools, and to comprehensively overhaul the contents of textbooks for elementary students.

The signatories also have to recognize that the Republic of China's sovereignty does not extend to China and promise not to recognize academic degrees issued by universities in China during the terms as president.
Yu also added a note to the convention saying that he will do his utmost to change of the name of the country to "Taiwan Republic" during his term as president, should he be elected to the post.

The signing ceremony, held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, was witnessed by society chief Cheng Cheng-yu, who revealed that the two DPP aspirants who have not yet signed, Vice President Annette Lu and former Premier Frank Hsieh, have both expressed their willingness to sign the convention.
Yu was the second aspirant to the DPP presidential nomination to sign the declaration. Premier Su Tseng-chang signed the document April 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIPEI COUNTY TOWNSHIPS OBJECT TO PROPOSED NUCLEAR FUEL STORAGE

TEXT.P: Residents from four of Taipei County's townships voiced strong opposition Monday to a plan by Taiwan's Nuclear Power Plant No. 1 to build a dry-storage facility at the plant site to keep its spent nuclear fuel.

The heads of Wanli, Shihmen, Chinshan and Sanchih townships and some 200 residents gathered in front of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) to protest the proposal by Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) to build the storage facility within the grounds of Nuclear Power Plant No. 1 in Taipei County.
The EPA's Department of Comprehensive Planning is currently assessing the construction plan's possible impact on the environment.

Tsai Chang-ming, president of an inter-township association for the promotion of nuclear power plant safety, said it is not fair to residents of Taipei County because three of Taiwan's four nuclear power plants are located in their county, with the No. 1 plant in Shihmen township, the No. 2 plant in Wanli township, and the No. 4 plant -- still under construction -- in Kungliao township.
Tsai said Taipei County residents are firmly opposed to Taipower's plan to build a spent fuel dry-storage facility at the site of Nuclear Power Plant No. 1.
Shihmen township head Liang Yu-hsueh noted that Taipower has held some 200 briefings in Taipei County in an attempt to convince its residents of the safety of the facility.

"Those Taipei County residents who attended the briefings have not the slightest idea of what a dry-storage facility is about when Taipower asked them whether they would accept the plan, yet Taipower has claimed to EPA officials that the Taipei County residents have demonstrated a high level of acceptance of the plan," Liang said.
Spent nuclear fuel -- a byproduct of the fission of uranium in commercial nuclear plants -- is highly radioactive.

Currently, spent nuclear fuel is stored in deep pools of water at most nuclear power plants. However, by designing facilities for spent nuclear fuel dry storage, the need for maintaining high cost pools can be eliminated.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TOUTS COMPETITIVE EDGE OVER KMT CONTENDER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday he is confident that if he wins the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) mandate to run in the 2008 presdiential election, he will beat his rival from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
Speaking in an interview with CNA, Su said he possesses a competitive edge that will enable him to defeat Ma Ying-jeou -- the KMT's best bet for the next presidency.
"My competitive edge includes political integrity, resoluteness, competence and a distinctive 'Taiwanese flavor, '" he said confidently.

In Taiwan's political map, Su said, the DPP has a firm grip in southern Taiwan while the KMT's power base lies in northern Taiwan. "I'm the only one who has been elected as county magistrate in both southern and northern Taiwan," he said proudly.

Su once served as magistrate of the southernmost county of Pingtung. He had also twice beat his rivals from the KMT-led "pan-blue" camp to win the magistrateship of Taiwan's most populous county -- Taipei County in northern Taiwan whose population accounts for one-sixth of the country's total.

While seeking re-election as Taipei County magistrate, Su said he received support from across the political spectrum. "Both my home county Pingtung and Taipei County can serve as my campaign bases if I'm nominated by the DPP to run for the presidency," he added.

On prosecution authorities' ongoing investigations into several prominent political figures' use of their discretionary special allowance funds, including Su's, the premier said he took the probes in stride.

"Any public figure must withstand stringent test and scrutiny. Moral integrity has been one of my priorities in pursuing political career. I have never come under any question in this regard. If I'm found to have breached or transgressed the law with regard to the use of the special allowance funds set aside for my discretionary use, I would definitely pull out of the presidential race, " Su said categorically.

Prosecutors started to probe how Su and three other DPP presidential contenders -- Vice President annette Lu, DPP Cahirman Yu Shyi-kun and former DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh -- had used their special allowance funds during their stints as local government chiefs after KMT's Ma was indicted Feb. 13 over his alleged misuse of special allowance funds during his tenure as Taipei mayor between 1998 and 2006.

In the past, Su said, Ma projected a clean image and the public hold high expectation of his integrity. Immediately after Ma was elected KMT chairman in 2005, he pushed for his party to formulate a regulation that required its members to quit political posts if they are indicted over corruption charges. As a results, many KMT local government chiefs quit the party after they were indicted on corruption charges.

"However, Ma was lenient toward himself. The KMT invalidated such anti- corruption stipulation right after Ma was indicted, " Su said, adding that the KMT-led "pan-blue" alliance had even thwarted the DPP's recent efforts to revise the current law in a bid to prevent those who are convicted in the first trial to run for the president. Ma has vowed to pursue his presidential bid even if he is convicted in the final trial.

Su also criticized Ma's inconsistence in his attitude toward the KMT assets. "Before Ma was elected KMT chairman, he promised to return the party's ill- gotten assets to the ntional coffers. Once he was elected chairman, he quickly sold out many controversial assets and the legality of those dealings have been called into questioned," Su said.
As to personal competence and decisiveness in policy-making, Su said the devastating 921 earthquake provided a god-send opportunity for comparison of his and Ma's emergency response capabilities.

"When the earthquake happened on Sept. 21, 1999, I was Taipei County magistrate. Two buildings collapsed in the earthquake, while only one building was toppled in Taipei City where Ma was mayor. The collapsed Taipei building has so far not yet been rebuilt, while the two toppled buildings in Taipei County had been completed before I ended my magistrateship tenure," Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL TRAVEL COMPANY FINED FOR QUALITY SERVICE FAILURE

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau announced Monday that it will slap a fine of NT$60,000 (US$1,820) on a travel service company for failing to provide minimum quality service to a group of Chinese tourists.

Bureau officials noted that to embrace fully the opportunities arising from opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists on sightseeing tours, the bureau and travel service operators agreed late last year to promote a program to upgrade travel services. Program measures included the requirement that tour operators spend no less than US$80 daily for each member of a Chinese tourist group, and the age of tour buses used by Chinese tourist groups not exceed seven years.
The officials stressed that the standards aim at ensuring a certain level of quality service for Chinese tourists.

According to the officials, the travel service company recently arranged for a Chinese tourist group to stay at a hotel in Changhua where the expenses for one night's stay were only a little over than NT$500.
But according to the US$80 minimum expenses per day for one Chinese tourist, the accommodations should have cost over NT$1,000 for one night.
Shockingly, one member of the tour group was bitten by a rat while staying in that hotel.

For failing to care properly for the safety of the tourists and ensuring that the tourists met the minimum expense requirement, the bureau has decided to discipline the travel service company, the officials said.
The bureau's announcement came amid reports that travel services and bus operators, disgruntled at the bureau's strict regulations, will rally at the bureau Tuesday to stage a protest.

Bureau officials explained that the requirement that buses used by the Chinese tourist groups not exceed seven years is due to concerns that Chinese tourists usually visit scenic spots as Sun Moon Lake and Mt. Ali, which require travel on mountainous roads, so ensuring that the buses are in good condition is a vital safety consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANDMINE CLEARING BRIGADE BEGINS OPERATIONS IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: The newly-formed landmine clearing brigade of the Kinmen Defense Command began formal operations Monday, with expectations that it will eliminate the threat of landmines from the outlying island, officers of the command said.
The brigade was expanded April 1 from a small team put together by the command last September in a drive to train local talent with mine clearing knowledge and skills.
According to the command there are currently 189 mined areas on Kinmen, and over 4.1 million square meters of land concealing approximately 70,000 explosive units.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE APPROVES AMENDMENT TO FURTHER PROTECT DISABLED PERSONS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved several amendments to the Physically and Mentally Disabled Citizens Protection Act on first reading to further protect the rights of these people Monday.

The amendments were passed at Legislative Yuan's Health, Environment and Social Welfare Committee on the 10th anniversary of the promulgation of the country's Physically and Mentally Disabled Citizens Protection Act.
According to the amendments, the citizens should not abandon, abuse, limit the actions of disabled people or leave the heavily disabled persons in dangerous situations.
People are also banned from obliging these disabled people to beg or commit crimes, exhibit them for commercial purposes, or pressure or seduce them to marry.
According to the proposal of the Ministry of the Interior, violators of the law will face fines ranging from NT$30,000 (US$909) to NT$150,000, and the government may publicly announce their names.
Family members of the physically and mentally disabled people who violate the law should receive between eight to 50 hours of lessons on the care of their dependents, at a charge.
However, committee members were divided on the ratio of the disabled persons that public or private organizations and institutions should hire, and they left this topic for further discussions.

According to the current law, government departments, public schools or corporations whose total number of employees is no less than 50 should employ disabled persons capable of work in no less than two percent of their total number of positions.

Private schools or corporations whose total number of employees is no less than 100 should employ the disabled with working ability for a ratio of no less than one percent of their total number of employees.
The amendments also include a clause advising people not to touch, feed or bother a guide dog when it is guiding a visually impaired people. However, no punishments are codified for violators.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME CHANGES WILL CONTINUE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the name "Taiwan" is the best logo that the Taiwanese people have and that his name "rectification" work will continue to help correct the wrongs of past administrations.

Speaking to a group of visiting representatives of the World Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce at the Presidential Office, Chen said that insisting on a Taiwan- centric consciousness or a "Taiwanese national identity" is now an "irreversible trend."

Saying that the right of the public to use the name "Taiwan" should never be taken away, Chen said the word "Taiwan" is the best, most beautiful and most powerful name that the Taiwanese could ever have used.

In the past, due to some specious political reasons, the name of "Taiwan" had been prohibited, resulting in identity disputes among groups of different political affiliations, as well as Taiwan's confinement in the international community, he said.
This mistake made by the previous Kuomintang administration has been a source of agony for the entire Taiwan population, he added.
The mistake, nevertheless, should not remain unchanged or unchallenged, the president went on.

Chen said the name-changing work will continue, now that the word "Taiwan" is included on Republic of China passports, the name of the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport has been changed to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Chunghwa Post Co. has been changed to Taiwan Post Co.

In the near future, he said, the names of many other state-owned enterprises will also be changed to carry the word "Taiwan, " including Chinese Petroleum Corp. into Taiwan CPC and China Shipbuilding Corp. into Taiwan International Shipbuilding Corp. to make them more identifiable with their country of origin.

Chen called for the support of Taiwanese chambers of commerce scattered around of world to the country's efforts to join the World Health Organization and the United Nations as a full member under the name of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITY COUNCILORS CRITICIZE KAOHSIUNG ZOO FOR MALFUNCTIONS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung municipal Shou Shan Zoo was fiercely criticized by several councilors during a city council question period Monday for what they called poor management, a lack of professionalism and inhumane treatment of animals.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) city councilor Lien Li-jen dressed himself like an orangutan to express concern for the mental condition of zoo orangutan that always hides itself and appears to be afraid of people.
Lien said many animals in the zoo display abnormal behavior, are in poor health and appear solitary or aggressive.
The zoo acts against the global trend in promoting animal welfare, Lien said, suggesting that the zoo, which he describes as poorly-funded and dysfunctional, be closed.
Hung Fu-feng, head of the city government's Economic Affairs Bureau (EAB) , which oversees the zoo, said the bureau will draft a plan to reform the zoo.

Earlier this month, a crocodile in the zoo bit off a veterinarian's left forearm while the vet was attempting to remove anesthetic needles from it. DPP councilor Lee Wen-liang demanded that the EAB clarify responsibilities over the incident and take disciplinary actions accordingly.
He also asked that bureau raise the amount of danger pay for zoo staff.

The male crocodile that attacked the vet was, for 10 years, regarded by the zoo as a Nile crocodile, but after the high-profile incident drew experts' attention was found to be a saltwater crocodile, to the zoo's embarrassment.

In a similar story, a female elephant resident in the zoo for 28 years was recently reported to have been mistaken as male, though the zoo officials said an event five years ago to find it awifewas just a PR activity.
However, Kuomintang (KMT) councilor Mei Tzai-hsing called the "mistake" unforgivable, saying the zoo was inhumane in failing, for decades, to find it a male companion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLANS TO EMBARK ON DIPLOMATIC TOURS IF WINNING DPP PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday he will embark on overseas tours if he wins the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) mandate to run in the 2008 presidential election.
Su made the remarks in an interview with CNA as the DPP presidential primary continued to heat up after two rounds of televised policy debates among the four contenders.

Given Taiwan's diplomatic plight, Su said the government has consistently spared no effort to enhance the country's international profile. If he manages to win the DPP primary, Su said he will visit as many countries as possible, particularly Taiwan's major security and trading partners, in his capacity as the ruling party's candidate for the next presidency.

In the DPP primary fray, Su has often come under fire from the rivaling camps over alleged abuse of his position for electoral gains. Su said he foresaw such a scenario long before the primary race began.

"I offered to quit the premiership when the last legislative session ended early this year. But President Chen Shui-bian asked me to stay to complete many important policy initiatives. Out of good faith between me and the president, I decided to stay, " Su said, adding that he may offer to resign again in case he wins the primary.
"If the situation becomes difficult or unfavorable for me to carry out major policy initiatives, I'll consider stepping down from my current job," Su explained.
As to whether he would reshuffle the Cabinet in short term, Su said it's not on his agenda since the administrative team is working smoothly in high morale.

Su also touted his team's achievement in promoting tourism in innovative ways, including naming the pop band F4 as "tourism ambassador" in attracting tourists from Japanese and South Korea. Just on Sunday, some 5,000 of the group's Japanese and South Korean fans visited Taipei to meet with their idols.

"Over the past few years, we have adopted many new measures to sell Taiwan in a bid to rev up our sluggish tourist industry. Thanks to concerted efforts in the public and private sectors, we have reaped encouraging results. The number of tourist arrivals have increased steadily in the past two years and the number is expected to hit a new high this year," Su said.

Asked about the government's policy on casino business, Su said the government would consider opening the business in the context of promoting tourism. "We would not open gambling for gambling's sake. We would allow for such business only on the premise of attracting foreign tourists," he added.
Touched on foreign private equity groups' increasing interest in acquiring local blue-chip companies, Su said the government will respect market mechanism in dealing with those issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS 'WILL' ATTEND COMMITTEE MEETING

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the People First Party (PFP) will certainly attend the Procedure Committee meeting Tuesday and help block passage of two key draft bills of major concern to the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), a PFP lawmaker said Monday.

Legislator Hwang Yih-jiau, who also serves as the executive director of the PFP's central policy center, gave his assurances that PFP lawmakers will "definitely" take part in the meeting and join forces with their KMT counterparts to prevent the two draft bills from again being included on the legislative agenda.
"There will be no surprise on the part of the PFP, " Hwang said. "The PFP is a political party that lives up to its promises."

Due to the absence of PFP and Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) lawmakers, their peers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , were able at the April 17 committee meeting to push the two bills through for further screening.
One seeks to ban indicted citizens from pursuing presidency, apparently directed at former KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, and the other targets the return of the KMT's ill-gotten assets.

But the two bills were defeated by KMT, PFP and NPSU lawmakers during last Friday's committee session on a KMT-initiated proposal that the meeting be adjourned, after the KMT and the PFP inked a 7-point pledge early that same day on bilateral cooperation in December's legislative election.

In addition to agreeing to allot five constituencies to be handled by the PFP in the legislative election, the KMT also promised the PFP to wrap up two-way coordination in the remaining constituencies within two weeks -- a development that helped bring about a temporary cease fire between the two allied parties.

PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao, who also leads the party's central policy center, urged Monday evening the two parties to open high-level talks as soon as possible to coordinate their actions in the upcoming legislative election.
Chang called on the two parties to examine their relationship strategically so as to free themselves of much of the baggage troubling them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER FAVORS COMBINING ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang voiced agreement Monday with the idea of combining the upcoming legislative and presidential elections, but said the decision to be rendered by the Central Election Commission (CEC) should be respected.
Su made the comments in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

According to Su, the public should be willing to see the two high-profile elections combined as doing so is more cost-effective. The legislative election is set for December this year, while the presidential race is slated for March, 2008.
However, the premier said that he is not in a position to ask the CEC do so because the issue must be decided by the CEC -- the central government agency in charge of national electoral affairs.

What is more, he said, the CEC organic law has been stonewalled in the Legislative Yuan for some time due to the boycott by the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " preventing a new CEC from being set up so as to make a final decision on the issue.

Commenting on another proposal, which would allow public referendums to be held along with presidential elections, Su called the proposal a commonplace measure in all democratic nations and questioned why the main opposition Kuomintang views it as a "monstrosity."

As to an inquiry on whether he would consider resigning from the premiership should he outgun his rivals in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's presidential primary, Su responded that he will fully delve into the matter if he wins the party's nomination.

Stressing that he has stayed as premier under instructions from President Chen Shui-bian, Su said that he will not step down from the post simply because doing so would make it easier for him to vie for the party's presidential nomination by freeing him of a shadow cast by allegations that he can easily allocate administrative resources to campaign for himself or craft policies to lure voter support.
Su also dismissed rumors that there will be a partial re-shuffle of the Cabinet, saying that all present Cabinet members are well placed and that he will not make any adjustments in the short term.

Regarding a DPP central committee proposal that the first two winners in the presidential primary pair up a ticket to run in the next presidential election, he said that "ideals and philosophy" on the administration of the nation are more important to him in terms of selecting a running mate.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ENGLISH LANGUAGE SPECIALIST TO HOLD SEMINAR IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: American English language specialist Lydia Stack began conducting a series of seminars at the Ministry of Education (MOE) Monday afternoon to share effective English teaching methods with elementary and junior high school teachers.
Stack came to Taiwan for five seminars from April 23-27 at the invitation of the MOE with an aim to improve Taiwanese teachers' teaching efficiency.

A specialist in English education for students from kindergarten to grade 12, Stack has consulted on English teaching methods in a number of Asian countries, including Japan and Honk Kong. She is especially involved in teenage English education, curriculum design, learning evaluation, and education standards of English as Second Language (ESL).

In Monday's seminar, Stack pointed out that interactive classroom learning activities help to elicit students' attention and interest, and that group discussions in class are beneficial to boosting students' learning efficiency as they create opportunities for students to practice their skills and help teachers with classroom management.

Teachers in the U.S. use a lot of group discussions in class to help non-English speaking immigrant students, Stack said, adding that she liked the interactive and interesting English teaching methods in Taipei City's Hsinyi Elementary School that she visited earlier before the seminar.
During the seminar, Stack also encouraged extra curricular learning from readings and movie viewings to improve English ability.
Seminars will be held in the coming days in Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, Taichung City, and Chiayi City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO WIN WORLD RECOGNITION BY `SOFT POWER': VP

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to exert its "soft power" and dedicate itself to democracy, peace, human rights, love and the development of advanced technologies to win the world's recognition, Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday.

Lu made the remarks at an assembly of an association promoting cultural and trade exchanges between Taiwan and Mongolia. She also presented credentials to the association's newly elected directors and supervisors at the assembly.

Before its independence from China, Mongolia was able to withstand a great threat from China and eventually became a democratic country, Lu said, adding that this was not an easy task and that Mongolia deserves praise from the people of Taiwan.
She also noted that the Mongolian government and people use modernization to promote democracy and human rights, as well as sharing its culture with the world.
Taiwan, on the other hand, is small, but uses "soft power" to stand strongly in the international community and take great leaps forward in this highly competitive era, the vice president continued.
Taiwan has been under a grave military threat from China for 50 years, but the people of Taiwan have never compromised and face the challenges squarely, Lu said.
As a result, Taiwan has been able to sustain its development and create prosperity and progress, Lu went on, describing Taiwan as "a miracle in the world."

Saying that Taiwan is willing to cooperate and exchange experiences with Mongolia, Lu noted that although the two nations are geographically apart, the distance can be narrowed through the help of the association.

She said Taiwan faces many difficulties in the international arena. However, she added, the 21st Century is an era of globalization and Taiwan will expand its presence wherever there is friendship and justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLIVIA NEWTON-JOHN ENCHANTS TAIWAN FANS WITH TWO CONCERTS

TEXT.P: Olivia Newton-John and her band decided Monday to stay in Taiwan for an extra day to savor Taiwan's delicacies after enchanting more than 9,000 Taiwanese fans in a pair of concerts the previous two nights.

Newton-John, who arrived in Taipei April 19, was scheduled to leave for Singapore for her next leg in her current four-nation Asian tour, but decided to delay her departure to Tuesday afternoon, so that she could have a full extra day free to visit Taipei's night markets and taste some of the unique delicacies recommended by organizers of her performances in Taipei.
The 58-year-old Australian singer gave two concerts in the Taipei Arena on Saturday and Sunday nights and achieved a resounding success.

She led her fans -- most in their 40's to 60's -- back through time with a string of hits from a repertoire of her famous songs, including "Have You Never Been Mellow," "A Little More Love," "Stronger Than Before," "Xanadu," "Magic," "Suddenly," and "Physical."

On her second day in Taipei, Newton-John and her entourage took time out to visit the National Palace Museum. Unable to see much because of the intense media attention, she said she will find another time to visit the museum.

Taipei is the second leg of Newton-John's current Asian tour and the only city to enjoy a pair of concerts. She performed in Hong Kong April 15 before coming to Taipei. She will also give one concert in Singapore April 27, followed by another performance in Kuala Lumpur April 29.
Newton-John's original schedule included one concert in Shanghai April 24 but the performance was later cancelled.
Newton-John settled in Malibu, near Los Angeles after winning a series of Grammy Awards for her work. She has also won numerous Country Music Awards, American Music Awards and People's Choice Awards.
A versatile singer, Newton-John has covered rock songs as well as the gentle folk songs and ballads which formed her early repertoire.
She starred with John Travolta in the 1978 movie Grease, catapulting herself to super-stardom with such hits as "You're The One That I Want," "Summer Nights" and "Hopelessly Devoted To You."
In 1981, she reached the pinnacle of her career with her million-selling single "Physical."
After recuperating from breast cancer surgery in 1992, Newton-John became a staunch supporter of breast cancer awareness charities and has been advocating early detection and treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DPP PRIMARY FRONTRUNNERS SPAT OVER 'ONE CHINA'\

TEXT.P: The two frontrunners in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) primary fray for the 2008 presidential election continued squabbling Monday over the "one China" framework of the country's Constitution.

Premier Su Tseng-chang, who is seeking for the DPP nomination to run for next presidency, said in an interview with CNA that Frank Hsieh, Su's predecessor who is also bidding to represent the DPP in the 2008 election, should clarify his "one China" Constitution framework rhetoric because none of those aspiring for presidency should dodge the issue regarding the country's status.
Su on Hsieh has said on numerous previous occasions that Taiwan's current Constitution has a "one China" framework in which China refers to the Republic of China -- Taiwan's official title.

Claiming that Hsieh's rhetoric has caused confusions and misgivings among many DPP politicians and grassroots supporters, Su said Hsieh should expound on the content of his "one China" framework doctrine.

The pro-independence DPP has been very sensitive to the term "one China" because Beijing has never hesitated to tell the world its ultimate goal of unify Taiwan under the "one China" principle and the almost the entire world perceives "one China" as the People's Republic of China, Beijing's national title.

Su said Hsieh must clarify his stance on the issue; otherwise, he claimed that the DPP would be identical with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) with regard to Taiwan's status and the country's future.

Su trailed behind the top-ranking Hsieh in an opinion poll conducted by alocal newspaper immediately after Saturday's second round of policy debates among the four DPP presidential contenders which also include Vice President Annette Lu and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun. In Saturday's debate, Su and Hsieh already spatted over the "one China" framework issues.
In the interview with CNA, Su was asked whether he is willing to pair with Hsieh if he wins DPP primary, su said the issue regarding "one China" framework should be resolved first.

"For me, political conviction is most important and relevant. It should come first before the pairing-up issue will be addressed. Position, power or fame is not so important for me. I can withdraw from the race if my political ideals and convictions have to be compromised," he added.

In response to Su's challenge for a further explanation of the doctrine, Chao Tien-lin, spokesman for the Hsih campaign, said it is Su himself most obliged to explain his stance on the constitutional reform issues.

"Su had vowed on previous occasions, such as when he assumed office as presidential secretary-general and the DPP chairmanship, not to touch on such sensitive issues as the independence vs. unification debate, change of national title and territory boundaries, " Chao said, adding that Su should explain why he is now so eager to address the constitutional framework issues.

"Hsieh has repeatedly explained that the 'one China' framework is an issue Taiwan must face squarely because it's the shackles Taiwan should cast off and break free, " Chao said, adding that Hsieh called attention to the issue in an aim to have the "one Chian" framework revised, scrapped or overturned, not to uphold it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 24, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The U.S. Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a U.S. ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a pro-Taiwan independence radical.
1970: Mainland China launches its first satellite, the Dong Fang Hong, into orbit.
1970: The Food and Fertilizer Technology Center of the Asian and Pacific Council is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A 16-member Orient Trade Mission of the U.S. Pacific Northwest International Trade Council, led by William Martin, president of the council, arrives in Taipei for a three-day business trip.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1976: The 1976 convention of 4-H Clubs opens in Taipei with more than 300 delegates taking part.
1981: A train encounters a landslide while on its way to Mt. Ali in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1990: West and East Germany agree to set July 2 as the date for economic union, a prelude to full political unification.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan sign a pact on troop reduction along the former Sino-Soviet border.
2000: The ROC National Assembly begins to fade into history after it downgrades itself to a virtual ceremonial organization without much power by passing a series of constitutional amendments during a third reading.
2001: Competition at the Second Asian Physics Olympiad kicks off in Taipei with 81 senior high school students from 12 countries participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 80% PENSIONERS WANT MORE SAY ON PENSION FUND'S USE: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 80 percent of those who have joined the two-year-old portable pension system look forward to having a say in determining how the reserve funds should be used for profit-making, according to the results of an opinion survey released Tuesday.

The survey was conducted by the Securities Investment Trust and Consulting Association (SITCA) in cooperation with the Global View Magazine between March 23 and April 1 to explore local wage earners' knowledge and opinions about the relatively new portable pension system. A total of 1,002 valid samples were collected in the survey, which has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

Among the respondents, 44.5 percent said they are very supportive of the proposal to revise the current law to allow for a say by wage earners on the use of portable pension fund reserves for lucrative investment deals; 36.1 percent said they somewhat support the proposal; and only 16.2 percent gave a negative response.

According to the survey, the number of wage earners who opted for the portable pension system had reached 5.64 million as of April 18, with the total pension fund reserves accumulated under the scheme exceeding NT$140.7 billion (US$4.26 billion) . Moreover, the amount has been increasing by about NT$8 billion per month.
After more than a year of delay, the Legislative Yuan finally passed the statute on the pension fund reserves management and supervision earlier this year.

However, the survey results showed that 65 percent of the respondents were not aware that only the government is authorized to manage the fund and that pensioners are guaranteed a minimum profit equivalent to the interest rate for two-year time deposits at local banks. If the fund's earnings do not reach that level, the government is obliged to make up the difference at the expense of taxpayers, according to the statute.

A SITCA spokesman said the survey results indicated that the government should step up a publicity campaign to help pensioners better understand how the portable pension system operates as well as their legitimate rights under the scheme.

According to the survey, 68 percent said they are not confident of the government's efficacy in running the pension reserve funds, while nearly 80 percent said it is inappropriate to use taxpayer's money to make up the difference if the fund's earnings fall below the set minimum.

Meanwhile, 74 percent said they are willing to accept the consequences if they are allowed to choose investment targets for their pension reserves, and 57 percent said they are confident in their ability to make the right investment decisions.

Noting that many advanced countries allow pensioners to decide on their own on the pension fund investment targets, the SITCA spokesman said the government should follow suit by coming up with draft law revisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE OWNERSHIP OF AIRCRAFT TO BE LEGALIZED

TEXT.P: Private citizens, corporations and social groups will be eligible to own locally registered airplanes, according to a draft package of amendments to the existing Civil Aviation Law that passed the first reading in the legislature Monday.
Private owners, however, will be prohibited from using their aircraft for commercial operations or leasing, civil aviation official said.

Under the terms of the revised law, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) will be required to regularly send staff to inspect personnel, equipment and flight operations of privately-owned aircraft.

At present, wealthy Taiwanese families tend to have their private aircraft registered in foreign countries. Once the proposed revisions are formally enacted, they can legally register their aircraft with the CAA and apply for flights in line with relevant regulations.
According to the results of a recent survey, more than 20 of Taiwan's top 500 corporations have expressed interest in purchasing small airplanes.
The proposed amendments also provide a legal basis for private business groups as well as city and county governments to construct and operate airports.

To date, CAA Director Chang Kuo-cheng said, the Kinmen County government is the only local government to have asked about the feasibility of operating an airport. Kinmen officials dropped the idea after learning that the central government had incurred huge debts from operating Shangyi Airport on the outlying island, Chang said.

The revised law will also allow airline companies to operate small business charter flight services to overseas destinations, but they will be required to use helicopters or aircraft that can carry no more than 19 individuals.

To offer civil aviation companies easier access to capital, the revised law also eases restrictions on foreign investment in local commercial flight, air cargo and ground services. The mandatory ratio of local shareholders will be lowered from two-thirds of the total to 50 percent, and a single foreign shareholder will not be allowed to own more than a quarter of the company's shares.

During a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's transportation committee Monday, some lawmakers expressed concern about the possible adverse impact of the liberalization of private aircraft ownership on domestic flight safety and national security. Civil aviation officials said the government will formulate comprehensive regulations to prevent any market disorder or chaos.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SPEAKS ON STRATEGY TO WIN 2008 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday that a winning strategy for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to win the 2008 presidential election will be to seek continued support in southern Taiwan and a breakthrough in northern Taiwan.

Su, one of the front-runners among the DPP presidential aspirants, made the remarks while explaining his ideals on running the country to supporters in a presentation held at a junior high school in Taipei.

The premier said that it will be a "daunting task" for the party to win the presidential election next year, adding that the party will have to cement its support in southern Taiwan, traditionally the stronghold of the DPP, and seek a breakthrough in northern Taiwan, which has tilted toward the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in past elections.

Su noted that he had previously served as Pingtung County magistrate in southern Taiwan and Taipei County magistrate in northern Taiwan, making him the best presidential hopeful who is familiar with Taiwan's situation "from the northern end to the southern end."

Su also touted his performance during his two terms as Taipei County magistrate, saying that the development of Taipei County outstripped that of Taipei City under then Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who doubled as KMT chairman from 2005 until early this year.

The premier said that the area and population of Taipei County are both larger than those of Taipei City, but it has received less funds than Taipei City. He further said that during his two-term stint, he completed the construction of Fishermen's Wharf in Tamsui, Pali LeftBank Park, Gold Ecological Park in Rueifang township, many schools as well as a bicycle lane network.

He also blasted Ma, who stepped down as KMT chairman in February after being indicted on charges of embezzlement of public funds during his two terms as Taipei mayor between 1998 and 2006, for selling the party's "ill-gotten" assets cheaply. Ma has denied any wrongdoing in the "special allowance fund" case.
Su also criticized Ma for saying that he would stick to his guns in bidding for the presidency even if found guilty in the first trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS NO NEED TO EXPRESS STANCE ON OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY NOW: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan has no need to say at present whether it agrees to host a leg of the Olympic torch relay, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.

Liu Teh-hsun, vice chairman of the nation's body on charting China policy, made the remarks one day after the news agency AFP cited an official of the Beijing Olympic Games organizing committee as saying that Taiwan has tentatively agreed that the torch relay can pass through Taiwan.
Liu denied the claim, saying that "discussions are still ongoing, and we have no need to publicize our stance now."
He noted that as a participant in the Olympic Games, "Taiwan naturally wants to have the honor of taking part in the torch relay."

However he pointed out that Beijing, after being awarded the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games, said that it would designate Taiwan as part of China's "domestic" relay route, rather than as part of the international circuit. He further noted that Beijing has referred to the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee as "Taipei, China," which he said has "troubled us."

Liu said that Taiwan has only made "a request as have the other Olympic members, " which is "to follow the protocol of the Olympic Games." He noted that Taiwan's government must first consent to allowing the torch relay to pass through Taiwan, and that one of the conditions of granting consent is that Taiwan's sovereignty will not be compromised.

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved up 22 points to close at 8,038, with 37,592 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June rose 17 points to finish at 8,025, with 393 contracts traded, while September futures increased 23 points to close at 7,825, with 112 contract transactions. December futures gained 25 points to close at 7,828, with 12 contracts traded, while March futures moved up four points to finish at 7,830, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,016 for May, 8,008 for June, 7,802 for September, 7,803 for December and 7,826 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

May TE futures gained 1.9 points to close at 338.6, with 2,836 contracts traded, while June TE futures rose 1.5 points to finish at 336, with 48 contract transactions. May TF futures moved down 2.6 points to close at 982.2, with 1,710 contracts traded, while June TF futures gained 1.6 points to finish at 985.6, with 12 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH COMMISSION OFFERS TRAINING TO WOMEN ENTREPRENEURS

TEXT.P: Courses offered by the National Youth Commission (NYC) for women entrepreneurs will begin in May, and the organizer expressed the hope that more women interested in beginning their own businesses can join the courses.

Yuan Fang-jung, a section chief at the NYC, noted that since the agency began the training program for women in 2000, a total of 14,000 women have taken the courses, helping many women around the island become successful businesswomen.

Yuan said that the program, which offers various types of courses for women on how to start their own businesses and how to apply for preferential loans, has borne fruit, adding that the NYC has shared its experiences in this regard with other countries at international conventions.

Several successful businesswomen who have participated in the NYC training courses shared their experiences in starting up a business, including a woman who has become famous for her hand-made soaps with creative designs, and another woman who now has a flourishing online business selling dumplings.
Ma Hui-chen, who started her hand-made soap shop with only NT$5,000 (US$151) in Taichung, said she now has a monthly income of NT$300,000 and receives orders from the United States and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 34.55 points to close at 8,045.01.

The bourse opened at 8,011.81 and fluctuated between 8,051.67 and 7,998.22 during the day's trading. A total of 4.03 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$98.56 billion (US$2.97 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.3 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.7 percent, textile stocks at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues decreasing 0.5 percent and banking and financial shares dropping 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 559 to 232, with 567 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERGER OF KMT, PFP NO EASY TASK: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that the merger of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party (PFP) will not be easy, and that a lot of issues will have to be discussed and arranged.

Wang made the remarks on the sidelines of an international symposium on transitional justice and national reconciliation sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) , for which Wang serves as the chairman.

Wang said that the KMT and the PFP, a splinter party of the KMT, will have to "meet, talk and make compromises, " saying that such actions will, to a greater degree, conform to the "political reality."

The year-end legislative elections will see the introduction of a new "single- seat constituency, two ballots" electoral system, replacing the existing "single vote, multiple-seat constituency" system. Voters will cast two ballots, one for their constituency representative and another for their favored political party.

The 225-seat legislature will also be halved to 113 members, with 73 seats elected from regional districts, six seats elected by aboriginal representatives, and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

Faced with a streamlined legislature, the competition among the legislative hopefuls has been especially fierce. Nonetheless, reports have said that the main opposition KMT is willing to yield some at-large seats to the PFP or the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union to forge a formidable opposition alliance.
Asked about the timing for the merge of the opposition parties, Wang said that as long as the parties involved are sincere, then "the sooner the talks begin the better."
