DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC MINISTRY TO SUSPEND GRAVEL EXPORTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs will announce in the near future a decision to suspend exports of gravel and sand in order to stabilize domestic supplies and protect natural resources, MOEA Minister Steve R. L. Chen said Tuesday.

Chen said the policy to suspend exports was crafted under the frame work of the Trade Act and will be implemented two months after the date of its announcement to preempt efforts by other countries to import Taiwanese gravel after China and Indonesia made the resource relatively more scarce by suspending their gravel exports.

Domestic demand for gravel and sand exceeded domestic supply during the period Jan. 1-April 15 this year, with demand reaching 17.89 million cubic meters but supplies cresting at 17.39 million cubic meters, Chen said. The shortfall in supplies was covered by the release of reserves, Chen added.

Chen said the MOEA has increased the number of gravel mining locations in operation from eight last year to 39 this year, and will increase the volume of permitted river gravel dredging to 20 million cubic meters in order to ensure an adequate domestic supply.

Domestic gravel prices have risen since the beginning of this year, Chen said, adding that the MOEA and the Fair Trade Commission will ensure that gravel and sand are sold at fair prices and step up inspections to guard against price gouging and hoarding.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO RECONSIDER MICROWAVE COMMUNICATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's environmentalists are calling on the government to delay plans to issue a license to WiMax operators, the International Taiwan Radio said Tuesday.
WiMax, which stands for Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access, is a wireless digital communications system.
They said the electromagnetic waves emitted by WiMax stations could pose a health hazard to humans. That's despite the fact that there is no evidence to support those claims
The government is planning to spend more than NT$37 billion or more than US$1 billion to build the WiMax stations.
However, environmentalist Chen Jia-hua, said the government should first make sure the stations are safe.
"The industry is not mature enough even in the international community. It is a high-end industry. However, without safety evaluations, the public will all become guinea pigs."
Chen also said Taiwan already has a higher density of wireless communication transmitters than any other country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TELECOMS FIRMS URGED TO CUT TEXT MESSAGING RATES

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation called on the country's telecommunications companies Tuesday to reduce their text messaging rates, which the group said are three to five times higher than those of neighboring countries.

According to foundation chairman Cheng Jen-hung, the six major telecommunications companies in Taiwan charge users an average NT$2.13 (US$0.06) for every text message sent within the same network, compared with China's NT$0.4 and Hong Kong's NT$0.68.
For text messages sent outside of their networks, the six companies charge users NT$2.53 per message on average, which is also higher than China's NT$0.6 and Japan's NT$1.4, Cheng said.

Cheng urged the National Communications Commission (NCC) to pay attention to the issue and work to have local telecommunications companies rationalize their text messaging rates to NT$1.3 per message for intra-network service and NT$1.7 per message for inter-network service -- the most affordable rates currently available through a domestic telecommunication company.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH EXPORT ORDERS HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: The value of Taiwan's export orders hit a new high for a single month at US$28.03 billion in March, up 12.4 percent over the same month last year, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
For the first three months of this year, export orders amounted to US$75.88 billion, up 12.73 percent over the year-earlier level, the tallies show.

In March, the value of export orders for information and communications products saw the greatest increase, rising US$1.31 billion, or 24.59 percent, year-on- year to reach US$6.64 billion, mainly owing to brisk market demand for notebook and desktop computers, MOEA officials said.
The value of export orders for electronic products increased US$620 million, or 11.08 percent, year-on-year, thanks to strong demand for memory products and consumer electronics, the officials said.
Export orders for basic metals and related products amounted to US$2.35 billion, up US$240 million, or 11.34 percent, over the previous year, they said.

While the value of export orders for textiles decreased 0.81 percent year-on- year to US$1.11 billion, those for plastics and related products jumped 16.44 percent to US$1.64 billion, and precision instruments rose 8.24 percent to US$1.77 billion, they said.

By region, export orders from the United States increased 3.61 percent year-on- year to US$6.97 billion, those from Hong Kong and China rose 12.4 percent to US$7.15 billion, Japanese orders climbed 2.94 percent to US$2.8 billion, while those from Europe spiked 24.13 percent to US$5.3 billion, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARGES DROPPED AGAINST EX-KMT CHIEF OVER REMARKS AIMED AT CHEN

TEXT.P: The prosecution decided not to indict former main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou over his remarks last year regarding President Chen Shui- bian amid a presidential recall drive in the legislature, the Taipei Prosecutors Office said Tuesday.

The Taipei Prosecutors Office said there was no evidence that Ma had intention to drive others to commit crimes or to disrupt public order when he claimed in early June, 2006 that "the gun was loaded" and that "Chen would end up in a foul death" at a time when lawmakers were to vote on the presidential recall motion.

The prosecutor in charge of the probe on the case found that Ma's rhetoric was a means of pushing Chen, whom they described as a "corrupt-ridden" president, to step down following a February launch of a recall motion by lawmakers of the KMT and the People First Party.

A group of Tainan city councilors of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party then lodged a complaint against Ma with the Tainan District Prosecutors Office in mid-June of the same year, accusing him of "enticing others to conduct criminal activities by making the remarks."

But the case was transferred to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office, which dealt with it as an allegation against public order and never questioned Ma, as the Article 11 of the Constitution guarantees freedom of speech.

The Taipei prosecutor responsible for handling the case said that relevant remarks made by Ma in the print and electronic media showed what Ma meant is that Chen would lose all public respect -- meaning that he might face the end of his political career -- if the presidential recall motion were to be approved at the Legislative Yuan.

As chief of the main opposition part by that time, Ma had the responsibility of scrutinizing the government's operations for the sake of public interests, although his criticism might sound sensationalistic, the prosecutor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS URGE GOVERNMENT TO UPGRADE VACCINATION POLICY

TEXT.P: Medical professionals urged the government Tuesday to begin to evaluate the possibility of including several new types of vaccine in the existing state- financed inoculation program.

Conveners of the new "Taiwan Vaccine Promotion League", including former Minister of Health Twu Shing-jer, made the call at a press conference the league held to publicize their message that the government's preventive inoculation policy has lagged behind world standards over the past 20 years.

Twu said Taiwan has not progressed since 1984 when it began to freely inoculate newborns with a vaccine against hepatitis B. At the time, it was a cutting edge practice and contributed significantly to Taiwan's efforts to reduce the prevalence of hepatitis and live cancer, he noted.

However, since then, the country's preemptive care practices have not improved. For example, Twu indicated, 74 countries have introduced a vaccine against streptococcus pneumoniae since the World Health Organization released an assessment a few years ago, showing that some 1 million young children aged under 5 in around the world die of streptococcus pneumoniae (S.P.) infection every year.

Seventeen of those nations have even listed inoculation with S.P. vaccine in their state-funded regular inoculation programs Twu added, noting that in comparison, Taiwan has thus far been reluctant to follow suit despite of the fact that drug resistant S.P. infections have become common on the island where antibiotics are over-prescribed.

Pediatrician Lee Pin-ying at the National Taiwan University Hospital blamed ongoing, "outdated" practices associated with preventive inoculation on a lack of funds. Parents of young children must pay for the vaccine against new viruses or bacteria, he said, arguing if all children enjoyed the right to vote, the government would have long since offered them free inoculations just as it provides stipends to the elderly.

In response to the call, Lin Tung, deputy director of the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health (DOH) , admitted that the current level of funding for regular inoculation is inadequate to include new vaccines, saying that the central and local governments allocated a total of NT$570 million (US$17.15 million) for the regular inoculation every year.

However, the DOH has worked out a medium-term plan in a bid for governmental funds that includes new types of vaccines like that against new-type whooping cough and S. P. in the regular inoculation regime for young children, Lin added.

Types of vaccine in the existing regular inoculation practice for children include neonatal hepatitis B vaccine, BCG vaccine, the three-in-one vaccine against diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus, the three-in-one vaccine against measles, mumps and rubella, the vaccine against Japanese encephalitis, and polomyelitis oral vaccine.

Members of the vaccine promotion league also include Lee Ching-yu, a honorary professor at the National Taiwan University's Medical Institute, who is known as the father of vaccine in Taiwan; Lin Chou-yien, president of the Chang Gung Children's Hospital; Huang Fu-yuan, chairman of the Taiwan Pediatric Association; and Chuang Tzai-cheng, director of the vaccine center of the National Health Research Institutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPRESS TRAIN DERAILS NEAR SUAO; PASSENGERS UNHARMED

TEXT.P: An express train, identified as Chukuang No. 69, derailed Tuesday near Suao township on its way to Hualien in eastern Taiwan, but the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) has confirmed that all passengers on board were unharmed.

The train, which left Shulin township in Taipei County at 7: 02 a.m., was approaching the Hsinma Station in Yilan County when the 11th car derailed and was dragged 700 meters over the ties before the train ground to a halt, according to Lin Chin-chuan, a senior TRA official in charge of operations on the Yilan Line.
Fortunately the derailed car remained upright, Lin said, adding that the more than 200 passengers on the train suffered no harm, and that the only damage done occurred to some railway ties.
According to Lin, TRA engineers removed the car with a hydraulic jack five hours later, and another express train took the south-bound passengers to their destinations.
Lin said that initial investigations have ruled out the possibility of human error because the train was traveling through the railway section in question within the speed limit of 40 km per hour.

He acknowledged that TRA engineers had examined the points on the railway section between Tungshan Station and Hsinma Station the previous night, but added that two subsequent test runs were successful and an additional 11 trains all passed through the section without incident.
Lin said a TRA committee in charge of train safety will take over the investigation to establish the cause of the derailment.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CENTRAL WILL NOT DICTATE RULE CHANGE: PARTY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Kuomingtang's (KMT) central committee will not impose a proposed change to its charter regarding the party's requirements for presidential candidates in the upcoming national congress, KMT Secretary-General Wu Duen-yih said Tuesday.

Wu's remarks came amid rampant rumors that the main opposition KMT is planning to modify its charter to secure former party chairman Ma Ying-jeou's chances of taking part in the 2008 presidential election despite being indicted on corruption charges this February. The KMT charter presently bans party members convicted in the first trial from running for office.

According to Wu, the KMT is slated to hold the second conference of its 17th plenary session June 24, at which time party delegates from across the country will deal with charter revision proposals, including the one pertaining to presidential candidacy.

For the KMT, it is a routine to screen proposals to revise the party charter during its plenary sessions every year, and only qualified party delegates at a national congress are entitled to decide on changes, he said, adding that a party task force led by Vice Chairman John C. Kuan is only in charge of collecting opinions with regard to such issues.

Meanwhile, a proposed amendment to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law submitted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was killed early the same day at the legislative Procedure Committee as a result of the joint efforts of KMT lawmakers and their counterparts in the People First Party (PFP).

The bill, which sought to bar citizens convicted on corruption charges from participating in presidential elections, was apparently directed at Ma -- widely assumed to be a strong contender in the 2008 presidential race despite embezzlement charges against him in a case related to funds from a special monthly municipal allowance earmarked for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.

Along with the so-called "Ma exclusion bill, " another bill initiated by the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , an ally of the DPP, to demand that the KMT return its illegally acquired assets to the national coffers was also blocked.

The two draft amendments could pose major setbacks to the main opposition KMT's quest to take back power in the next presidential election. Against that back drop, the KMT needs PFP cooperation to prevent the proposals from clearing the committee for further reading.

PFP and KMT lawmakers vetoed the two bills in a concerted move in Tuesday's committee session after the two parties inked a 7-point pledge late last week regarding cooperation in December's legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECORDS FIRST SEVERE FLU CASE INVOLVING HEALTHCARE WORKERS

TEXT.P: A local physician developed serious complications caused by type A influenza early this month, becoming the country's first case of severe influenza involving healthcare workers this flu season, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) reported Tuesday.

The 32-year-old doctor in Taoyuan County came down with fever April 9 and lost consciousness two days later, when he was hospitalized and diagnosed with pneumonia, neutropenia and septic shock, CDC officials said.

While the doctor was first suspected of suffering from severe acute respiratory syndrome, tests confirmed he was infected with type A influenza, even though he had received flu vaccination, the officials said.

CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting urged the public not to lose confidence in flu vaccines because of the case, noting that flu viruses will usually become less virulent in people who have been vaccinated, thus moderating their symptoms and avoiding serious complications and death.
CDC tallies show that 31 cases of severe influenza have been confirmed in the country this flu season, four of which have resulted in death.
Of these 31 cases, approximately 50 percent have affected children below 10 years of age, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIMULATED WARFARE DRILLS TARGET CHINESE MILITARY: MND

TEXT.P: Officers of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) confirmed Tuesday that the MND's just-concluded simulated computerized warfare drills targeted the Chinese military with missiles in counterattacking a mock surprise assault by China.
The five-day computerized warfare simulation formed part of the large-scale combined forces' "Han Kuang" military exercises which are conducted by the MND annually.

At a press conference held at the MND, Hsu Tai-sheng, director of MND's Joint Operation Training and Doctrine Office, stressed that the the five-day computerized warfare simulation, which began April 16, only targeted Chinese military objectives and none of its civilian installations.

According to MND officers, the computerized warfare simulated a situation in which China attacks Taiwan's warfare command centers, radar stations and missile bases with high-calibre weapons in 2012, then makes a land assault on the island after weakening Taiwan's air and marine combat ability.
In mock counterattacks, Taiwan's troops struck Chinese military targets with missiles, including airports, missile bases and observation and telecommunications installations.
However, the MND did not elaborate what kinds of missiles they were using in the warfare simulation as the officials classified them as confidential.

MND's spokesman Wu Chi-fang noted that the computerized warfare drills only focused on the attacking and defensive sides, and did not include an intervention by the United States. According to Wu, the U.S. military observation delegation, which was here to observe the process, expressed satisfaction regarding the content of the MND's computerized mock drills.

However, Chiu Kuo-cheng, a deputy chief of MND in charge of warfare planning, admitted that the warfare simulation also reflected Taiwan's serious weakness in its anti-missile and anti-submarine measures, which allowed the island's airports, radar stations and missile bases on the west coast to be seriously damaged by Chinese missiles in the simulated warfare, and China's superiority in the number of submarines also posed a serious threat to the security of the island.

A MND report said the experience obtained in the computerized warfare simulation will serve as valuable references for Taiwan's military preparedness in the future, but Taiwan's apparent inferior anti-missile and anti-submarine combat ability represent another urgent matter that the nation's military forces should face.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES TAIWAN PEOPLE TO ENTER JAPAN ON PROPER VISAS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged Taiwan people Tuesday to enter Japan on proper visas, despite the fact that Japan offers visa-free privileges to Taiwan tourists.

According MOFA officials, not all Taiwan people are allowed to enter Japan without a visa. The visa-free treatment is limited to tourists, businessmen, people visiting families or friends and those attending seminars.

Those entering Japan for other reasons, such as attending language schools or engaging in "money-making activities, " including artistic performances, still need to apply for entry visas, MOFA officials said, adding that Taiwan people are not allowed to freely enter or leave Japan with only passports and airplane tickets.

The number of Taiwan people denied entry by Japanese immigration officials has been on the rise recently after Tokyo announced visa-free treatment for Taiwanese tourists in September 2005, the officials said.

In 2006, 942 people from Taiwan were denied entry upon arrival at Japanese airports, most of whom were suspected by the Japanese authorities as intending to engage in other activities not compatible with tourism, the officials said.

Some were also denied entry because they have criminal records and had overstayed their visas in Japan or held fake passports, or because they failed to clearly explain the purpose of their visit, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL WELFARE GROUPS DEMAND POLITICIANS EXERCISE SELF-DISCIPLINE

TEXT.P: Several civil social welfare organizations Tuesday urged the ruling and opposition parties not to propose unrealistic raises in stipend paid to the elderly as the approach of the year-end legislative election and the 2008 presidential election.

The civil groups, including the Parents' Association for Persons with Intellectual Disabilities, the League of Welfare Organizations for Disabled, the League of Welfare Improvement for Older People (LWIOP) , and the Taiwan Association of Family Caregivers, held a joint press conference to release their statements and criticized some politicians for attempting to "buy votes" through raising the dollars attached to various existing stipend programs.

The legislative committees of health, environment and social welfare have decided to screen the existing provisional regulations on welfare subsidies to the elderly Wednesday. It is said that lawmakers have prepared 25 different versions of amendment proposals, all aimed at increasing the elderly's stipend, with some suggesting a raise from the current NT$3,000 (US$90) to NT$4,000, NT$6,000 or even NT$10,000.

Whenever there is an election, there are politicians ready to write checks for those persons who are socially less privileged in an attempt to buy their votes, criticized LWIOP Secretary-General Wu Yu-chin.

But social welfare services can't be confined to the practice of offering stipends, Wu said, noting cash cannot improve people's life, but that can be accomplished given a sound, healthy social welfare system.

While over 90 percent of the government's current social welfare budget is spent covering various kinds of stipend programs, the groups urged ruling and opposition parties to respect the conclusion of the 2006 national conference on sustaining Taiwan's economic development and forgo inflating existing social welfare stipend programs until the long-planned national pension program is implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVEL OPERATORS ANGRY AT RESTRICTIONS ON HOSTING CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Scores of representatives of travel service operators rallied in front of the Tourism Bureau Tuesday to protest what they called "unreasonable restrictions placed on hosting Chinese tourists."
They said that the requirement that operators spend no less than US$80 daily for each member of a Chinese tourist group should be lifted.
The protest came one day after the Tourism Bureau slapped a fine of NT$60,000 (US$1,820) on a local travel agent for failing to provide minimum quality service to a group of Chinese tourists.
The MarcoPolo Travel Service was fined because it had arranged for the tourists to stay at a substandard hotel in central Taiwan, leading to one of the tourists being bitten by a rat.

The protestors are also angry that the Travel Agent Association of the R.O.C. Taiwan is in charge of screening the hosting arrangements of travel agents; the requirement that local travel agents post a NT$2 million bond with the association is similarly unpopular, and the association has requested that the government handle the screening procedures.
The requirement that travel agencies which have not been established for five years old not host Chinese tourist groups should also be scrapped, they demanded.

Tourism Bureau Deputy Director-general Su Tsang-yang, in receiving the protestors, said that requiring minimum expenditures for each member of Chinese groups is aimed at ensuring quality service, and asked for the understanding of travel service operators.
Su also urged the Travel Agent Association to be fair when screening the itineraries travel service operators must submit to host Chinese tour groups in order to a avoid conflict of interest.
The protestors later went to the Legislative Yuan to make their grievances heard.

The Tourism Bureau, in anticipation of a rush of Chinese tourists to Taiwan on sightseeing tours, promoted a quality control campaign with travel service operators last November. The campaign calls for travel operators to promise to spend no less than US$80 daily for each member of a Chinese tourist group, requires that the age of tour buses used by Chinese tourist groups not exceed seven years, and that there be no self-pay tours during the journey.
The campaign came one month after a major traffic incident involving Chinese tourists which left six dead, including s Taiwanese tour guide, and 15 injured.

The tourists from Dalian in Liaoning Province were en route to Shuili from Tungpu in central Nantou County when one of the two buses they were traveling in skidded off the Central Cross-Island Highway and plunged into a ravine.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW RESERVOIR IN HSINCHU TO BE FILLED TO CAPACITY IN JULY

TEXT.P: The Second Boashan reservoir in Hsinchu County, completed a year ago, will be filled to capacity with water in July after a safety evaluation is conducted on the dam in the next two months, water resources officials said Tuesday.
The officials from the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs told reporters that the reservoir is now 61.3 percent full, with the water level at 140.47 meters.

When filled to capacity, the reservoir will hold 32.18 million tons of water and will be able to provide an additional 191,500 tons of water per day for household and industrial use in Hsinchu County, in addition to the 90,000 tons a day currently supplied by the First Baoshan reservoir, located three kilometers to the north, according to the officials.
The two reservoirs, together with the Dapu reservoir, will be able to meet Hsinchu County's water needs until 2021, they added.

The Second Baoshan reservoir is located on the upper reaches of the Shihching stream in Baoshan township. Construction began in 1997 after the government recognized the need to keep pace with growing water demand as a result of the Hsinchu Science Park's second- and third-phase expansion projects.
The First Baoshan Reservoir was completed in June 2006 at a cost of NT$10.5 billion (US$316 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH OF MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION INDEX SETS RECORD LOW

TEXT.P: The growth of Taiwan's manufacturing production index (MPI) and its industrial production index (IPI) in the first quarter of this year both registered five- year lows, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The statistics show that the MPI grew 0.99 percent in the first quarter over the same period of last year, while the IPI registered a year-on-year growth of 0.89 percent in the first three months.
The IPI stood at 143.51 in March, representing a slight growth of 0.12 percent over the same period of last year and a significant increase of 24.06 percent over February.
The MPI stood at 148.18 in March, representing a year-on-year growth of 0.62 percent and an increase of 25.31 percent over February.

On the IPI in the first quarter, the production of the water, electricity and fuel sector increased 3.01 percent over the same period of last year, while that of the mining and construction sectors decreased by 18.61 percent and 4.9 percent, respectively.

Regarding the MPI in the January-March period, the production of the information and electronics industry represented a year-on-year growth of 2.47 percent, followed by that of the chemical industry at 2.29 percent, while the production of the metal and machinery sector, and the consumer product industry, decreased by 2.83 percent and 0.98 percent, respectively.

Feng Tien-chi, deputy director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, said the increase of MPI in the first quarter reflected the stable growth of the country's manufacturing sector after suffering recession last December.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH RETAILER TO OPEN 3 STORES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: One of Britain's top retailers, Marks & Spencer (M&S) , is scheduled to open three stores in Taiwan after forming a joint venture with Taiwan's President Chain Store Corp., operator of the island's 7-Eleven chain, an executive of M&S said Tuesday.

Stephen Walker, managing director of M&S Taiwan, said the retailer's first store will be located in the "Dream Mall" in the southern port city of Kaohsiung that is scheduled to open in early May; the other two stores will open in Taipei City later this year.
Founded in 1884, M&S now has 530 stores in Britain and 220 stores in 35 countries, Walker said, adding that the retailer offers more than 10,000 products, but sells only its own brand-name products.
The retailer controls more than half of the venture, which will target Taiwan's well-heeled, fashion-conscious consumers, Walker said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTOMS SEIZES 38.8 MILLION UNDECLARED JAPANESE YEN

TEXT.P: A man had 38.8 million Japanese yen (US$326,614) confiscated by Taiwan customs authorities last week when he failed to declare the foreign currency while trying to take the money out of the country, customs officials said Tuesday.

Travelers are required to declare any foreign currency exceeding an equivalent of US$10,000, and the man was discovered to be carrying the Japanese money in his suitcase when he was going through customs inspection at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport April 20, the officials said.
The man claimed he was unaware he needed to declare the foreign currency upon departure, even though he had declared it upon entering the country, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF WINTER DAYS WITH CLEAN AIR DECREASING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Air monitoring data has shown that in a period of around 100 winter days when the northeast monsoon prevails in Taiwan, the number of days with clear sky over the island has decreased over the past three years, an official of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) revealed Tuesday.
Chang Shun-chin, who is in charge of pollution monitoring, said there were only 46 days when Taiwan people had clean air to breathe during the monsoon season this winter, which lasted 111 days.

In comparison, there were 59 "clean days" in the last monsoon season, which lasted 116 days, while 77 clean days were recorded in in the season before that, which lasted 112 days, Chang said, attributing the situation to pollution by particulate matter carried by monsoon winds to Taiwan from China and Southeast Asia.
The pollution caused by overseas pollutants was worst in the Taipei area, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR SENTENCE COMMUTATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that he asked the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) last week to work out a plan to grant sentence commutations to prison inmates.

Noting that the previous commutation was meted out 16 years ago to celebrate the 80th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, the president said another commutation is appropriate for this year as it is the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law and the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident.
The 228 Incident refers to a revolt of local people against the government in 1947 during which many were killed in an ensuing government crackdown.
Chen made the announcement during a meeting with visiting Archbishop Emeritus of Cape Town Desmond Mpilo Tutu at his office.
Meanwhile, Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung said that his ministry is working on a draft of a punishment reduction bill in line with Chen's instruction to commute some sentences this year.

Lee said the MOE's Department of Prosecutorial Affairs has organized meetings with the Judicial Yuan, the National Police Agency, the Investigation Bureau, the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office and military legal authorities to work on the draft that will be sent to the Executive Yuan next week for approval.
The draft, Lee said, will neither cover criminals who committed serious crimes nor be applied to people who committed serious financial crimes after 1991.

Quoting Article 40 of the Constitution of the Republic of China, Lee said the president has the power to grant amnesties, pardon, cut sentences and reinstate civil rights in accordance with the law. Taiwan has granted four general commutations since the promulgation of the Constitution in 1947, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFESSION, FORGIVENESS KEY TO RECONCILIATION: NOBEL LAUREATE

TEXT.P: National reconciliation of a democracy emerging from dictatorship lies in the acknowledgement by the perpetrators for past cruelty and the forgiveness of their victims, visiting Archbishop Emeritus of Cape Town Desmond Mpilo Tutu said Tuesday.

Speaking at a symposium organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, Tutu, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984, said reconciliation is a long process in which every citizen, in addition to the victims and perpetrators, should be involved.

The former chief of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, who was invited by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy to offer his advice on Taiwan's search for transitional justice and national reconciliation, said he has no ready answer for Taiwan.

He said he was surprised by the keen desire of Taiwan to come to terms with its past, but just as each of the other 20-some countries in the world that have emerged from the shadows of their past dictatorships, Taiwan has to grope for its own way out of its historical dilemma.
However, Tutu said his country's experience in healing the rift caused by apartheid may shed light on the way ahead for Taiwan and may serve as a catalyst for reconciliation.

After the end of apartheid in South Africa, Tutu said, his country faced calls to put those who perpetrated crimes under the cover of apartheid on trial, similar to the war criminals tried at Nuremberg after World War Two.
However, there were also calls for a general amnesty to all perpetrators and for the country forget about the past and move on, Tutu said.
The Truth and Reconciliation Commission headed by Tutu opted for another way, offering pardons only to perpetrators who confessed their crimes and apologized to the victims in public hearings.
In this way, Tutu said, old wounds were reopened, treated and bandaged again, and South Africa avoided a division between its people.

Wu Naiteh, a research fellow at Academia Sinica, echoed Tutu's opinion in the symposium by calling for tolerance on behalf of the victims toward their persecutors, which he said is the key to national reconciliation.
Tutu, who arrived April 18, will wrap up his visit Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70 STUDENTS IN HUALIEN COUNTY TO BE TESTED FOR TB

TEXT.P: More than 70 students from a middle school in Hualien County will be tested for tuberculosis Wednesday after a teacher who had frequent contact with them was found last week to have contracted the disease.
Health officials with the Hualien County government confirmed Tuesday that the female teacher developed a cough in early April but thought it was merely a cold symptom at the time.

The officials, who declined to name the teacher, said that on April 18, the teacher's cough became so bad she had to go to the Tzu Chi General Hospital in Hualien for treatment, where doctors diagnosed her with opening pulmonary tuberculosis.
Tuberculosis bacteria can spread through the air. The phlegm of patients with opening pulmonary tuberculosis carries the highly contagious bacteria.

The teacher has been isolated at the hospital for further treatment, the officials said, adding that the more than 70 students who were in close contact with her will be given chest X-rays and will have their phlegm tested.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOAN RATIO OF TAIWAN BANKS DROPS TO 2.32%

TEXT.P: The overdue loan ratio of domestic banks stood at 2.32 percent as of the end of March, down 0.06 percentage points over the month-earlier level, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) reported Tuesday.

Loans granted by domestic banks amounted to NT$17.38 trillion as of the end of March, up NT$3.5 billion over the month-earlier level, while overdue loans amounted to NT$404 billion, a decrease of NT$8.9 billion from February, according to FSC officials.
Among the 41 domestic banks, 33 saw their overdue loan ratios register below 5 percent as of the end of March, with 25 below 2.5 percent, the officials said.

The allowance for uncollectible accounts by domestic banks as a ratio of the coverage of overdue loans stood at 53.91 percent as of the end of March, up 0.61 percentage points from 53.3 percent in February, they said.
FSC officials said they will continue to monitor banks with high overdue loan ratios and encourage them to take measures to improve their financial structures.

New York Times: Democrats Back Date for Start of Iraq Pullout
Congressional Democrats agreed Monday to ignore President Bushs veto threat and send him a $124 billion war spending bill that orders the administration to begin pulling troops out of Iraq by Oct. 1.
On Iraq, the American people want a new direction, and we are providing it, said Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, a leader of the Congressional negotiators who came to terms on the legislation that has become a test of wills between Mr. Bush and the Democratic majority on Capitol Hill.
Wall Street Journal:How an Email Rant Jolted a Big HMO
On a Friday morning last November, Justen Deal, a 22-year-old Kaiser Permanente employee here, blasted an email throughout the giant health maintenance organization. His message charged that HealthConnect -- the company's ambitious $4 billion project to convert paper files into electronic medical records -- was a mess.
In a blistering 2,000-word treatise, Mr. Deal wrote: "We're spending recklessly, to the tune of over $1.5 billion in waste every year, primarily on HealthConnect, but also on other inefficient and ineffective information technology projects." He did not stop there. Mr. Deal cited what he called the "misleadership" of Kaiser Chief Executive George Halvorson and other top managers, who he said were jeopardizing the company's ability to provide quality care.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 25, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, doing so in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The U.S. Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, Calif., to organize the United Nations.
1946: The foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends U.S. troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington, D.C.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motion pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio" and "Roberta."
2000: President Lee Teng-hui bestows a medal on Steve Forbes, president and CEO of U.S.-based Forbes Magazine, in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and coorperation between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that the ROC government will take steps to develop the island into a "competitive country with a knowledge-based economy" within five years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."
