DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
NOBEL LAUREATE TUTU CONCLUDES TAIWAN TRIP

TEXT.P: Former South African Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, departed Taiwan Wednesday after an eight-day visit to the island.
At the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Tutu expressed his thanks for the Taiwan people's hospitality and gave them his blessing.

Tutu, in the company of his wife, Leah Nomalizo Tutu, arrived in Taiwan April 18 for a visit at the invitation of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy. During his stay, he met with President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, former ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, and family members of the victims of the 228 Incident of 1947, one of the most tragic chapters in Taiwan's history.
Tutu also attended a forum held by the foundation Tuesday on the subject of transitional justice and national reconciliation.
Tutu said that Taiwan is in a situation similar to that of South Africa during apartheid. In those days, he recalled, it was difficult for him to obtain a visa with a South African passport.

Nowadays, the Taiwan people's rights and interests are still ignored by the international community, Tutu said, adding that he will speak up for Taiwan at gatherings of any international organizations when the opportunity presents itself.
Tutu, rising to worldwide fame during the 1980s as an opponent of apartheid, is recognized for his contribution to ending the inhumane system and facilitating reconciliation in his country.
As head of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Tutu has played a leading role in his country's post-apartheid campaign to heal its historical wounds and boost ethnic harmony.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 24 (CNA) 04/25/07 12:48:26 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A high-ranking U.S. military official reaffirmed Tuesday the United States' commitment to provide Taiwan with the necessary assistance to defend itself against possible Chinese invasion.

The United States is examining Taiwan's defense needs by sending observers to survey the island's annual "Han Kuang" military exercise, according to Timothy Keating, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command (USPACOM).

"USPACOM will continue to make available to Taiwan advice, training and support for congressionally-approved equipment to defend against the potential military aggression by the PRC, " Keating said during a Senate Committee on Armed Services hearing.
He said the United States is monitoring cross-Taiwan Strait relations closely and that the country's military interactions with Taiwan and China focus on efforts to preserve cross-strait stability.

"We continue to encourage Taiwan to improve its own defenses and create a credible deterrent to any attack. We have advocated inexpensive hardening practices as well as the acquisition of a combination of defensive weapons and systems," he said.

However, Keating emphasized the United States' position remains that Taiwan's actions should be defensive, rather than offensive, in nature, and he expressed confidence that Taiwan understands this point clearly.
"But it is very much in their interest not to conduct themselves, either by speech or by action, in a way that could be misconstrued by China in unfortunate ways," he said.

Keating said that while China's military modernization efforts do not yet challenge U.S. military capabilities in the Asia-Pacific region, the opaqueness of Chinese defense budgets and intentions, as well as the introduction of new capabilities, are causes for concern.

The military-to-military interaction between the United States and China is aimed at increasing transparency between their respective militaries, breaking down barriers to understanding and reducing the potential for miscalculation, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: MM expects growth to hit top end of 4.5- 6.5% forecast.
Singapore's economy is likely to grow at the top end of the official 4.5 to 6.5 per cent growth estimate this year, as long as the United States economy holds up, Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew said yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Extradition treaty won't harm Singapore's economy: MM Lee.
The agreement between Singapore and Indonesia to sign an extradition treaty will not scare wealthy Indonesians away from Singapore, nor will the pact harm the Republic's banking and property sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY TO U.S. SOLICITS SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 24 (CNA) 04/25/07 14:24:52 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, paid a courtesy call on Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), a co-chair of the U.S. Congress Taiwan Caucus, Tuesday to solicit support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).

Wu, who formally assumed his post in Washington, D.C. April 16, first conveyed President Chen Shui-bian's appreciation to Taiwan-friendly members of Congress, particularly Rohrabacher and three other Taiwan Caucus co-chairs, for their staunch and longstanding support for Taiwan.

Wu said that despite the United States' support, Taiwan's WHO bid has made little progress over the past 10 years due to China's obstruction, adding that even in its efforts to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer have failed.

He further said that Taiwan is adopting a new strategy this year for a change -- preparing to apply directly to join the WHO as a full member under the name "Taiwan" -- to let the international community know that the 23 million people of Taiwan have the right to join the world health regulatory body.

For his part, Rohrabacher said he understands that Taiwan and the People's Republic of China are two different countries and that Taiwan deserves more positive treatment in the international community.

Rohrabacher said that Taiwan, which has made more contributions to WHO efforts than China has, deserves fairer treatment, adding that he will relentlessly work to help Taiwan gain entry into the WHO as a full member.

Meanwhile, Rohrabacher also expressed his hope and the set policy of the U.S. administration that Taiwan will maintain more direct contact with the Chinese people in efforts to sell Taiwan's democracy in China and thus help change the Chinese people's mindset and vision.

Wu responded that he had made strenuous efforts during his stint as the chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council -- Taiwan's top China policy planning agency -- to let the Chinese people better understand Taiwan's democratization, including the freedom of speech and the freedom that Taiwan media outlets have enjoyed, by inviting media members, scholars and even officials from China and Hong Kong to visit Taiwan in person.

Meanwhile, Wu also appealed to the U.S. Congress for its support for Taiwan's bid to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States to better facilitate business and trade exchanges between the two countries.

Wu stressed that the U.S.-South Korea FTA, signed earlier this month, has put Taiwan at a disadvantage and that it will undermine its economic development as South Korea is a major rival of Taiwan's in terms of foreign trade.

For his part, Rohrabacher said that he will continue to push for the signing of a U.S-Taiwan FTA since he has always advocated that it is only natural that free countries forge free trade pacts among themselves.

Rohrabacher, however, added that he is afraid he cannot be too optimistic at present on this issue under the current circumstances in which the United States needs to curry favor with China for its support on the North Korea issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CHINESE SPIES' ARE ACTUALLY ESCAPED ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS: NSB

TEXT.P: The "5,000 Chinese spies" alleged to be operating in Taiwan are actually "escaped illegal immigrants," rather than "genuine" spies, a National Security Bureau (NSB) official said Wednesday.

Wang Hsi-tien, a deputy secretary-general of the NSB, said during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan that there are roughly 5,000 Chinese citizens who have been living a clandestine existence in Taiwan since entering the country illegally.
Wang said the figure of "5,000" was arrived at based on cumulative calculations over the past several years, stressing that these illegal immigrants are not spies.

The NSB official made the remarks in response to a question raised by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang about whether former Deputy Defense Minister Lin Chong-pin's recent claim that there are more than 5,000 Chinese spies operating in Taiwan is true.
Lin Chong-pin was quoted in the latest edition of the U.S. weekly "Defense News" as saying that he believes more than 5,000 mainland Chinese spies are operating in Taiwan.

Lin Chong-pin was also quoted as saying in the weekly report that he himself had stumbled upon one "Chinese spy" who was working as a cab driver in Taiwan in 1995. He said the driver spoke in perfect Pekingese and admitted that he was from Beijing, that he had been briefed by the Taiwan Research Institute (affiliated with the People's Republic of China's National Security Ministry), that he had a master's degree in hydraulic dynamics from Tsinghua University, and that he was in Taiwan to 'serve the broad masses by comparing the strengths and weaknesses between the capitalist and socialist systems."

When asked by Legislator Lin Yu-fang whether it was possible that Chinese authorities, unable to send spies to Taiwan from Xiamen, Fujian Province -- which lies across the Taiwan Strait from Taiwan, had decided to send spies from Beijing, Wang responded by saying that if he were a Chinese official in charge of espionage work, he would have sent spies from Fujian Province, rather than from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO MORE ACTIVE IN CUTTING GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS

TEXT.P: A senior researcher at the Academia Sinica urged the government Wednesday to be more active in working to reduce the amount of greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan, as the country's image has been deteriorating in the international community due to what he called the record-high rate of increase of such emissions in the country in recent years.

Liu Shaw-chen, chief of the Academia Sinica's Research Center for Environmental Change, made the call while delivering a report on Taiwan's preparations against climate change and global warming at the Legislative Yuan.
Liu indicated that Taiwan's per capita greenhouse gas emissions is now double the level in 1990.

Citing the results of a survey on the amount of greenhouse gas emissions produced in countries with over 10 million people, Liu said Taiwan's per capita carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions was half those of France and Britain in 1990.

However, Taiwan surpassed the industrialized European nations in 2003 in terms of per capita CO2 emissions, Liu said. He added that although Taiwan's per capita CO2 emissions is lower than those of the United States, Canada and Australia, Taiwan tops the global list in terms of the rate of increase in greenhouse gas emissions.
"Because of this, Taiwan's international image is being tarnished, " Liu claimed.
The scientist stressed that Taiwan possesses the technological know-how to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, adding that he believes it is the government's duty to strive to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 60.36 points to close at 7,984.65.
The bourse opened at 8,035.74 and fluctuated between 8,041.27 and 7,984.65 during trading. A total of 3.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.78 billion (US$2.82 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, construction issues at 1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.7 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 809 to 352, with 207 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOULD HAVE TO FIGHT ALONE FOR FIRST 10-14 DAYS IF ATTACKED: NSB

TEXT.P: Taiwan would have to fight on its own for the first 10 to 14 days in the event of a large-scale military attack by China, a National Security Bureau (NSB) official said Wednesday.
The estimate is based on the presumption that the United States would provide military support to Taiwan, according to NSB deputy chief Wang Hsi-tien.

Wang said that while the United States is expected to intervene in the event of a Chinese attack against Taiwan, it might react differently if the attack were the result of provocative moves by Taiwan beforehand.

Wang made the remarks during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee while briefing legislators on the results of a computerized warfare simulation held recently by the military as part of the country's annual "Han Kuang" military exercise.

On Tuesday, Timothy Keating, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command (USPACOM) , said the United States will continue to make available to Taiwan advice, training and support for congressionally-approved equipment to defend against a military attack by China.
However, Keating emphasized the United States' position remains that Taiwan's actions should be defensive, rather than offensive, in nature.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Cabinet approves immigration reform bill.
The Cabinet approved Tuesday an immigration reform bill which would loosen restrictions on immigrants. The government claimed that the legislation is aimed at reducing illegal immigration by allowing foreigners easier to enter the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER OPPOSES `PORK BARREL' DRAFT BILLS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang expressed opposition Wednesday to "pork barrel" draft bills that have been put forth by individual legislators or legislative caucuses of political parties.

At a regular Executive Yuan meeting, Su instructed Cabinet agencies to stay firm on carrying out government policies but to do their utmost to consult and communicate with members of the legislature in the face of "pork barrel" draft bills.

Su said these draft bills -- projects that are given a lot of government money in order to win votes -- should be avoided, as they will have a profound and longstanding impact on the nation's finances.

Su issued the instruction after the opposition-dominated Legislative Health and Environment Committee passed 23 amendments to a law governing higher annuity payments for the elderly. The committee meeting decided later that the ruling and opposition parties should consult with each other and negotiate before referring final amendment proposals to the legislative floor for debate.

Meanwhile, Su lamented that the legislature has passed only 30 bills so far this legislative session, with 90 other "priority" draft bills submitted by the Executive Yuan remaining up in the air. The session is scheduled to wrap up May 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: MURDERERS, MAJOR FINANCIAL CRIMINALS TO BE EXCLUDED FROM AMNESTY: MOJ

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Wednesday that prison inmates serving sentences for murder or major financial crimes will not be included in a presidential amnesty now being studied by the ministry.

Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung made the remarks one day after President Chen Shui-bian said he had instructed the Executive Yuan to study commuting some sentences to coincide with the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law and the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident, which refers to a civilian revolt against the then corrupt government in 1947 that led to a bloody crackdown.
Lee said that under a draft bill planned by the ministry, those who are eligible for sentence commutation will be fewer than in past sentence reductions.

To carry out a carrot-and-stick policy as espoused by the president, those who have seriously damaged national and social interests will not see their sentences commuted, but those who have committed minor transgressions and are serving short prison terms will be given the chance of a fresh start, he said.
Lee pointed out those who are convicted for corruption or major financial crimes, and those have sexually assaulted children or have murdered people will be excluded from the plan.
He also said that the ministry will continue to keep track of the inmates released after commutation.
Asked if he is concerned about law and order after the exodus of inmates under the amnesty, Lee cited a previous amnesty in 1991 as an example.

He noted that between 1991 and 2000, the recidivism ratio of imnates who were released earlier after commutation was only 16.21 percent compared with the recidivism ratio of 49.9 percent of prisoners who completed their terms and the recidivism ratio of 50.7 percent for those who were released on parole between 1996 and 2006.

The government granted amnesties in 1971 and 1991 to mark the 60th and 80th founding anniversary of the nation, respectively. Two other pardons were granted in 1975 and 1988 to mark the deaths of the two late presidents -- Chiang Kai- shek and Chiang Ching-kuo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU UNHAPPY WITH DPP'S `STEALTHY' MOVE

TEXT.P: A top official of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Wednesday of having "lured" TSU elite to join the DPP in a scheme to enlarge the DPP support base so that the party can win in the year-end legislative elections.
Unhappy with "constant" moves that the DPP have made to lure TSU members, TSU Secretary-General Chien Cheng-shan said the DPP's "stealthy" actions have damaged the harmony between the two parties.
"The DPP should take all the responsibility should DPP-TSU consultation and negotiation on the legislative elections fail, " Chien said.

Chien said the TSU -- an ally of the DPP -- and the DPP have reached a consensus that the two parties will cooperate in order to garner the greatest possible victory for the "pan green camp" in the legislative elections slated for December this year.
Nevertheless, Chien noted, even before the two parties have begun to talk, the DPP has "cut the ground from under the TSU's feet" by luring away one more of the TSU elite.

Even DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun traveled south Tuesday to Yunlin to witness a ceremony marking former TSU County Councilor Liao Ching-hsiang's joining of the DPP, Chien noted. Liao quit the TSU several days ago.
Chien said the TSU condemns the DPP's "unfriendly" action in the strongest terms.
He urged the DPP to apologize to the TSU and to stop immediately its "headhunting" scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved down 78 points to close at 7,960, with 38,631 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June dropped 75 points to finish at 7,950, with 384 contracts traded, while September futures lost 63 points to close at 7,762, with 106 contract transactions. December futures lost 72 points to close at 7,756, with 56 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,038 for May, 8,025 for June, 7,825 for September, 7,828 for December and 7,841 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

May TE futures dropped 2.6 points to close at 336, with 2,489 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 0.95 points to finish at 335.05, with 31 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

May TF futures moved down 9.2 points to close at 973, with 1,233 contracts traded, while June TF futures lost 10.6 points to finish at 975, with 16 contract transactions. September TF futures dropped 17.4 points to close at 962.2, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.009 to close at NT$33.192.
A total of US$1.058 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.183 and fluctuated between NT$33.181 and NT$33.206.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT AMENDMENTS ON ELDERLY STIPENDS PASS PRELIMINARY SCREENING

TEXT.P: The legislative committees of health, the environment and social welfare passed 23 amendment proposals targeting provisional regulations on welfare stipends for the elderly Wednesday, despite strong opposition from several social welfare organizations.

Nine of the controversial amendment bills focus on a raise in the stipend, with some proposals suggesting a boost in the amount from the present NT$3,000 (US$90) per month to NT$4,000, NT$5,000, NT$6,000, or even NT$10,000.
The draft bills also propose striking off the existing regulations that ban repeated issuance of various stipends, as well as a provision that excludes rich people from stipend programs.

A group of social welfare organization representatives described the bills a day earlier as "money pits, " accusing some politicians of attempting to "buy votes" through raising the stipends ahead of the year-end legislative elections and the 2008 presidential election.

At the committee meeting, Vice Minister of the Interior Lin Chung-sheng said that any increases in welfare subsidies have to take the government's finances into account, must exclude rich persons and must ban repeated issuance.
If the elderly stipend were to be expanded to NT$6,000 a month, the government would have to find an extra NT$157.9 billion per year, Lin warned.
The draft bills will undergo negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties before being delivered to the Legislative Yuan's plenary session for further screening.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO DISCUSS DRAFT AMNESTY BILL NEXT WEDNESDAY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will discuss a draft amnesty bill for prison inmates in its next Cabinet meeting, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday.

The premier made the remarks one day after President Chen Shui-bian announced that he had instructed the Executive Yuan to study commuting some sentences to coincide with the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law and the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident, which refers to a civil revolt against the then-ruling Kuomintang in 1947 that led to a bloody crackdown.

Su noted that the Ministry of Justice worked out a draft bill on the commutations a day earlier that will be sent to the Executive Yuan after more discussion with the Judicial Yuan and other related government agencies.
The premier noted that Chen instructed last week that commutations should be studied for inmates serving time for minor transgressions so as to relieve the overcrowded prisons.
He said such commutations are carried out both here and abroad, but added that those who have committed major or financial crimes, or who have been convicted of corruption, should be excluded.

Asked if the proposed amnesty is part of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's strategy to win the year-end legislative elections and the 2008 presidential election, Su said the public should only make a judgment after seeing the draft bill.
He said that not every inmate is "unforgivable" and that some should be given the opportunity of a fresh start.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET WEB SITE ON KMT ASSETS OPENS

TEXT.P: A Web site run by the Executive Yuan aimed at allowing the public to gain an understanding of the government's efforts to recover the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) illegally or improperly acquired assets was launched Wednesday.

Premier Su Tseng-chang presided over the opening of the Web site following an Executive Yuan weekly meeting earlier in the day, during which Su was briefed by officials from the Ministry of Finance and the Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission (RDEC). Minister without Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung, Finance Vice Minister Lee Ruey-tsang and RDEC Vice Chairman Chen Chun-lin were also present.

Su called on the public to support the government's drive to make the KMT return its ill-gotten assets to serve transitional justice and encouraged the public to visit the site at http//igpa.nat.gov.tw.

According to Su, an Executive Yuan task force has been working on the issue since late August last year, and then-KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou promised to provide the public with a detailed explanation of how the party has dealt with its property and land plots. But Ma failed to honor his pledge and in turn sold much of the KMT assets in a short time, he said.

The KMT still has assets worth more than NT$45 billion registered under its name, but the actual value far exceeds this figure, Su said, describing the KMT as "the world's wealthiest political party."

The government's efforts to recover the KMT's assets can be dated back to 2001, when the Control Yuan, Taiwan's highest government watchdog agency, requested that the issue be addressed, Su said, adding that a bill initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) serving that end has been stonewalled in the Legislative Yuan.

According to Hsu, the Executive Yuan has since the 2000 power transfer been tracking the KMT's assets -- a complicated task that he called "very difficult" due to the fact that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan.
However, Hsu pointed out, the DPP administration will continue pursuing the goal and plans to sponsor a series of seminars in August across the country to delve into the issue.

Finance Vice Minister Lee brushed aside allegations that the Executive Yuan's efforts in this regard are aimed at seeking voter support in the coming elections, describing the rhetoric as a smear tactic. The public now has a sense of urgency and hopes that the KMT's assets can be quickly dealt with, he said.

According to the Executive Yuan's accounts, the value of the KMT's unlawfully obtained assets might amount to at least NT$45 billion, ranging from real-estate and zero-interest bank loans to KMT-run companies and special government subsidies for its affiliated organizations and personnel.

Earlier in the day, KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chang Che-shen told a news conference at KMT headquarters that the party will live up to Ma's promise to stop running any businesses by the end of June this year.
He also said that the DPP administration has attempted to spoil the KMT's lawful business deals by extorting potential buyers of KMT companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT AMNESTY BILL TO CUT SENTENCES OF OVER 10,000 PRISONERS

TEXT.P: A preliminary draft of a national sentence commutation act will benefit more than 10,000 prison inmates, Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung said Wednesday.

The preliminary plan of the national amnesty legislation, in line with President Chen Shui-bian's directive last week, will only commute sentences for criminals serving time for crimes committed before a certain date, Lee said, adding that the date will be decided by the MOJ.

The draft of the national amnesty will not include criminals convicted of serious crimes and crimes that endanger society, Lee said, adding that crimes against the Prevention and Punishment of Sex-Trade Act and special financial crimes will be excluded.
Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus whip Ker Chien-ming said the draft will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval before being sent for deliberation by the Legislative Yuan.

Kao Yung-cheng, the executive director of the Judicial Reform Foundation, said he is not against the amnesty or commutation as it is allowed by the Constitution. However, he went on, an amnesty on death-row inmates is a better way to show the DPP's political ideal o f a nation built upon the principles of human rights.
Vice Chairman of the International Federation for Human Rights Siobhan Ni Chulachain has requested an amnesty for prisoners on death row, but has received no response from the government, Kao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO DISPOSE OF CENTRAL INVESTMENT HOLDING CO. BY END OF JUNE

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will divest itself of all its shares in the Central Investment Holding Co. -- the last KMT-owned enterprise still in its possession -- by the end of June, a senior KMT official said Wednesday.

KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chang Che-shen claimed at a press conference that although quite a few potential buyers had expressed interest in acquiring the company, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government "scared them off through intimidation tactics."

The Cabinet and the DPP have been mustering support from voters for a referendum to be held alongside the next election on whether the KMT should give its "ill- gotten" assets to the national coffers.

Chang, who is also director-general of the KMT Administration and Management Committee and chairman of Central Investment Holding, claimed that the DPP and the government do not really want to see the KMT resolve its party assets problems because it would give them a good excuse to assault the KMT and win votes in this year's elections.

The KMT will try to find buyers for its shares in Central Investment Holding within the next two months, Chang said, adding that after it gets rid of the company, the KMT will no longer own or operate any businesses.
Central Investment Holding was established in 1971 and became an open company in 1995, with capital totaling NT$34.9 billion (US$1.04 billion).
The KMT has denied that its assets are "ill-gotten" and insists that its total assets as of the end of 1999 totaled only NT$69.6 billion, not the NT$600 billion claimed by the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WARNS AGAINST RISKS OF FOCUSING INVESTMENT ON CHINA

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) warned Wednesday that Taiwan businessmen should think about the risks of focusing too much on the China market.

Liu Te-hsun, vice chairman of the body in charge of Taiwan's China policy planning, made the remarks during a meeting in the central city of Taichung with 300 Taiwanese businessmen wanting to invest or having invested in China.

Liu noted that in recent years, Taiwan businessmen have listed China as their main investment destination or the major market for their products instead of diverting their investments and exports to other countries.
"Focusing on a single market has potential risks, " Liu said, adding that Taiwan businessmen should seriously consider the negative impact of such a move.

Businessman Lee Jung-fu, speaking on the same occasion, said China no longer welcomes all enterprises. Those enterprises that are highly polluting and high- energy consuming might be told to move to China's hinterland instead of staying in the more prosperous coastal provinces, he said.
Labor-intensive enterprises are no longer suitable for investing in China and Taiwan businessmen should take heed of this trend, Lee added.
He said that the digital and service sectors still have development opportunities in China, although they will be hard to develop if they are small- scale.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WHIP CALLS FOR NO AMNESTY TO 2 OPPOSITION FIGURES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus convener said Wednesday that a proposed sentence commutation plan should not be applicable to former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Legislator Chiu Yi because they committed major crimes.

Ker Chien-ming made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian instructed the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) last week to study the feasibility of a national commutation of sentences or partial amnesty for prison inmates.

The proposal is aimed at commuting sentences for those who committed minor crimes and who have shown remorse, Ker said, adding that as Chiu is a violent criminal and shows no repentance, he is not eligible for a sentence reduction.

Chiu Yi was sentenced to 14 months in prison for his leading role in a violent demonstration in the southern port city of Kaohsiung after the 2004 presidential election in which the joint KMT-PFP ticket lost by a razor-thin margin.

As for Ma, who has not been convicted of any offense, Ker said he has been indicted for allegedly siphoning funds from his special allowance fund when he was mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006. Embezzling public funds is not a minor crime, Ker added.

On whether the commutation proposal will be written into law before the May 20 anniversary of President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration, Ker said it cannot be made that soon, as a draft of the sentence reduction bill should first be drawn up by the MOJ, followed by approval by the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan.
Ker added that the proposal is a response to calls from human right groups, legislators across political spectrum and grassroots representatives. Prison overpopulation is also a factor, he added.
As most provisions in the existing commutation statute are outdated, Ker said a new set of rules should be enacted to prescribe targets and qualifications for commutation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune : Mourners say farewell to Yelstin in Moscow.
Thousands of somber and tearful mourners shuffled past the open coffin of former President Boris Yeltsin at Christ the Savior Cathedral, as foreign dignitaries headed to Moscow to pay their last respects.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIAOLI COUNTY COUNCILOR ARRESTED FOR WRONGDOINGS

TEXT.P: Law enforcement agents arrested a Miaoli County councilor early Wednesday on charges of intimidation, extortion and taking forcible possession of other people's property.

Hsieh Wen-chun and eight accomplices were taken into custody during the wee hours of the morning when local police and agents from the Investigation Bureau of the Ministry of Justice, working under the instructions of a Miaoli public prosecutor, raided their homes.
According to a spokesman for the Investigation Bureau's mobile unit in central Taiwan, Hsieh tried to take over a sand and gravel company at a reduced price, but the company's owner refused to sell.
Hsieh brought in gangsters and destroyed an access road used by the company after making up an excuse that the company had been excavating sand and gravel illegally.
Having scared off the owner through intimidation, Hsieh and his accomplices took possession of the company's hydraulic crane, truck and other equipment and sold them for NT$9 million.

According to the spokesman, Hsieh and his accomplices also beat a video game shop owner and his workers and detained them for hours at Hsieh's residence after they refused to pay the county councilor a monthly "protection fee".
The Miaoli Public Prosecutors' Office is investigating whether Hsieh has committed other wrongdoings against the people in his constituency.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES GERMANY TO SUPPORT TAIWAN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the German government Wednesday to speak up on behalf of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) , a goal which has remained unfulfilled over the past 10 years owing to China's obstruction.

Addressing the issue during video conference with a group of German politicians, academics and media representatives, Chen suggested that Germany make a case for Taiwan during the upcoming annual World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the highest decision-making body of the WHO -- based on the precedent of the former East Germany.

Chen pointed out that the status of East Germany as a "country" was challenged when it applied to become a member of the WHO in 1968, but the request was nonetheless included on the WHA's agenda for consideration by the organization's member nations.
The WHO invited East Germany to participate in the 1972 WHA as an observer, and during the 1973 WHA, East Germany's application for WHO membership was approved, Chen noted.

Chen said he requested that Taiwan be allowed to become a member of the WHO in a letter addressed to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan April 11, and hopes that Germany will offer Taiwan its support so that the country's application could be put on the WHA's agenda and be discussed by WHO member nations.
Also, Taiwan hopes that Germany will help Taiwan take part in the WHA as an observer before it gains membership in the WHO, Chen said.

"I hereby sincerely urge the international community, especially European Union countries, to pay attention to China's diplomatic suppression and military intimidation of Taiwan, and speak up for Taiwan so as to promote the values of freedom, democracy, peace and human rights that we share," Chen said.
The president said China's obstruction of Taiwan's bid to take part in the WHO has deprived the island's 23 million people of their rights to life and health.

While China has never renounced the use of force against Taiwan and has been increasing its military budget over last 20 years, there is no collective security mechanism or platform for dialogue that would allow for international mediation of cross-Taiwan Strait disputes, Chen pointed out.

"It is extremely unfair to the 23 million Taiwanese people that Taiwan must face the increasingly strong military threat by China. This also poses a latent hazard to the security and stability of the Asia-Pacific region," he said.

Calling the international community's attention to China's military threat a result of the emergence of China as a super-power, Chen said the number of missiles China has deployed to target Taiwan has increased from 200 in 2000 to nearly 1,000 in 2007.
Also, Beijing enacted the so-called Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan in March 2005, despite opposition from the international community, Chen noted.

He urged the German government to exert its influence and lobby the European Union to maintain its arms embargo against China until China democratizes its political system and improves its human rights record.

The Washington Post:Kaine May Seek More Data for Gun Sales. Order Would Address Buyers' Mental Health.
Virginia Gov. Timothy M. Kaine said yesterday that he is considering an executive order to make sure that gun sellers have more information about the mental health of potential buyers, a move that would have kept Seung Hui Cho from purchasing the handguns he used to kill 32 people at Virginia Tech last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Bush and Cheney Chide Democrats on Iraq Deadline
President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney aggressively challenged the motives of Congressional Democrats on Tuesday, as the House and Senate prepared to consider a war spending bill that would order troops to be withdrawn from Iraq beginning later this year.
In separate appearances that served as a prelude to an inevitable veto showdown, Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney accused Democrats of political opportunism in forging ahead with a $124 billion measure that sets a timetable for leaving Iraq.
Wall Street Journal:Why Korea Makes The World's Best Women Golfers
Why are there so many great Korean women golfers?
South Korea is hardly golfing nirvana. A small country roughly the size of Indiana, its mountainous terrain leaves room for only 250 golf courses. Indiana has 470. With green fees averaging over $200 per round, most players in South Korea are politicians and businessmen out on the company dime. Men outnumber women on Korea's courses by almost 9 to 1.
Yet in the past decade, South Korean women have come to dominate the world's top women's golf tour, the U.S. Ladies Professional Golf Association, or LPGA. In 1997 there were no Koreans in the LPGA. Now 14 of the LPGA's latest class of 33 rookies, first-time tour players who have survived the sport's competitive winnowing process, hail from South Korea. And among the 138 women golfers in the elite category who are automatically qualified to play in each LPGA tournament, 34 -- almost a quarter -- are Korean.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE COMES OUT MAY 12

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will by May 12 at soonest determine its candidate for the 2008 presidential election, party sources said Wednesday.

The party's Central Standing Committee determined that the presidential primary's public opinion poll will take place from May 9-11, bringing the 4-horse race to a conclusion the next day, attendees of the close-door meeting said.

Results of the telephone poll will weigh 70 percent in determining who will represent the party, the other part of the primary procedure - a vote by party members - has been set to take place on May 6.
The meeting also decided that a third platform forum will be held in Kaohsiung on May 3, as advocated by Vice President Annette Lu, party officials said.
The DPP has on April 14 and 21 held two televised forums, which were attended by all four runners: Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, party chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former premier Frank Hsieh.

The Central Standing Committee set a date for public poll in early May out of the concern that a prolonged competition and a late result would be unfavorable to party solidarity, though Lu suggested that the poll be held later in the month, party sources said.
The date for the official nomination of the DPP's presidential candidate had been set on May 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF VOWS TO FIGHT 'FALSE' DPP CHARGES

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung vowed Wednesday to take legal action against what he called "false charges" made by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) concerning the party's assets.

Wu made the comments after Premier Su Tseng-chang earlier presided over a ceremony in the Executive Yuan marking the launch of a Cabinet Web site on the KMT's assets. Su encouraged the public to visit the Web site and called for widespread support of the government's drive to demand that the KMT return its ill-gotten assets to the national coffers.

In the face of the DPP administration's efforts to re-appropriate KMT's assets, Wu said that his party will undoubtedly file lawsuits for each of the groundless accusations made by the DPP in order to defend its name.

Labeling the KMT's assets a historical legacy, KMT Secretary-General Wu Duen-yih asked the DPP to stop rehashing these issues before every election, and urged it to devote its energy to improving Taiwan's economy.

If the KMT had been found to have committed crimes in obtaining its assets, the DPP would have already dealt with it over the past seven years, Wu said, arguing that it is "awful" that the DPP should seek to deal with the KMT in this regard with the legislative and presidential elections slated to be held in December and March next year, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS COMPLAIN OF QUOTA REQUIREMENT REGARDING KMT ASSETS

TEXT.P: Several ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers complained Wednesday of a quota requirement that the party plans to impose on its public office holders regarding liquidating the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) assets, arguing that the issue must not become a liability for the DPP.

DPP legislative caucus whip Wang Tuoh voiced the concern in a Legislative Yuan news conference and urged the party central to refrain from implementing the drastic measure, which he warned might strain party unity.

Wang made the comments after it was reported that the DPP intends to impose quotas on its public office holders, requiring them to collect enough signatures to endorse a DPP-initiated campaign demanding that the KMT return its illegally acquired assets.

According to local media reports, the DPP is planning to adopt the measure in a party congress slated for late June that will suspend for one year the membership rights of those who fail to obtain the number of signatures allocated by the party central. The DPP has been seriously lagging behind in the campaign second-phase schedule of targets in terms of signatures collected, the reports stated.
According to Wang, the party central should not approve the controversial measure at this sensitive time in the run up to the legislative and presidential primary elections.
Suspending someone's party membership might be viewed or misunderstood as a scheme to rule out potential candidates, thus hobbling party unity, Wang said.

In addition, he said, putting the KMT assets issue to a national referendum alongside the presidential election will be a development of major significance. Although getting back unlawfully obtained assets for the national coffers serves social justice, he said, it is worth noting that the issue will be ineligible from inclusion in public referenda for three years should it fail to pass in the first attempt.
Wang suggested the DPP central encourage party members by offering substantial incentives instead of punishments so as to not upset party unity.

DPP lawmaker Cheng Yun-peng said he cannot accept the logic behind the party's planned imposition of the measure, questioning "Why must responsibility for the KMT's wrongdoing be assumed by the DPP? "
Such a wrongheaded move will hurt the DPP, and the issue must not be turned into a weapon with which to defeat opponents in the party's legislative primary, he said.

Wu Ping-jei, a DPP Central Standing Committee member, also voiced his worry that the quota allocation proposal might spark disputes within the party, particularly at a time when the party's legislative primary is entering the final stage. The party central must give the issue a second thought, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOFTEX TAIPEI SPRING COMPUTER SHOW SET FOR MAY 3-7

TEXT.P: The 2007 spring computer show, Softex Taipei, will take place May 3-7 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Hall 1, with 120 exhibitors operating 620 booths, organizers said Wednesday.
Softex Taipei, a popular annual event showcasing various software and hardware products from major computer suppliers, is in its 21st year. The 2006 show attracted nearly 300,000 visitors.
According to the Taipei Computer Association (TCA), organizer of the exhibition, entry to this year's show will be free for the first time -- seen as good news for both the visitors and exhibitors.
TCA executives said this year's show ground will be divided into three areas to feature the themes of family amusement, technology in action and LCD TVs.

In addition to the latest high-tech products from various major suppliers, the exhibition will present products by Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., Acer Group, MiTAC International Corp. and Asustek Computer Inc., which have won prestigious iF (International Forum) Design Awards for excellence and innovation in Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL CONTRIBUTION ACT TO BE OVERHAULED

TEXT.P: Domestic political parties will be barred from making extravagant donations to their candidates for various political elections if a draft package of amendments to the Political Contribution Act passes the legislature, officials said Wednesday.
According to the draft, political parties will be allowed to contribute no more than NT$25 million to its nominee for the presidential election.

The package also sets caps on donations by political parties to their candidates for other elections -- NT$1 million for each of its nominees running for legislative seats; NT$3 million for each candidate running for mayor or magistrate; NT$300,000 each for those running for county or city council seats and township chief; NT$100,000 for each party nominee for borough or village chief elections.
The same caps also limit political party spending on campaign activities in support of their candidates at various levels of elections, according to the Cabinet-initiated draft amendment package.

Executive Yuan spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling said the Cabinet had already approved the draft package of amendments at its weekly meeting held earlier in the day. The package will soon be referred to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and approval, Chen added.

The Political Contribution Act was promulgated in March 1993 as part of the "sunshine laws" to curb corruption in politics and enhance government transparency, Chen said, adding that the law requires a major overhaul as a series of elections held over the past years have revealed flaws and deficiencies in its provisions.

In order to create a legitimate and ethical political environment for fair competition among political parties, Chen said, the proposed amendments will also impose caps on individual political parties' contributions to various political groups. The maximum annual contribution to a particular political group by a political party is set at NT$2 million, and the annual limit of its contributions to various political groups is capped at NT$ 4 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAINT LUCIA BECOMES TAIWAN'S 25TH DIPLOMATIC ALLY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that Saint Lucia has become Taiwan's 25th diplomatic ally.

Su made the remarks while attending a ceremony marking the establishment of a supporter group in Taoyuan County's Chungli City in northern Taiwan for his bid to represent the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to run in the 2008 presidential election.

Cabinet spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling confirmed later that Saint Lucia's foreign affairs minister announced in his country's parliament this evening that Saint Lucia is resolved to forge diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
"We are pleased with Saint Lucia's announcement and our foreign ministry will handle the follow-up proceedings," Chen said.
According to Chen, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang will give a background briefing for the local news media Thursday.
The East Caribbean nation first eastablished diplomatic ties with Taiwan in in 1984 and switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in 1997.
Premier Su said the resumption of diplomatic ties with Saint Lucia is one of the most encouraging news events since he assumed premiership early last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER PROMOTES FUND RAISING FOR KIDS' DRAMA IN TOWNSHIPS

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank C.T. Hsieh called on the public to participate in a fund raising activity initiated by the Paperwindmill Theater -- a kids' drama troupe -- to take their performances for kids in townships around the island.

Hsieh, who is running for the Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run in the 2008 presidential election, made the appeal together with the troupe's leader Jen Chien-cheng at a news conference at Hsieh's campaign headquarter Wednesday morning.

Hieh invited greater participation in the activity, called "Art Project for Kids in 319 Townships -- First Mile Kid's Smile, " which aims to solicit donations to enable the troupe to perform for kids in each of Taiwan's 319 townships.

Participants may donate money to "adopt a performance" for townships that they designated, and when designated funds for a township reach NT$350,000 (US$10,545) , the troupe will make arrangements to present a performance for the area's children.

Hsieh said he was touched by the headquarter's two volunteer workers, who donated NT$60,000, and immediately followed suit, donating funds to sponsor performances in Penghu County's Makung City and Nantou County's Chushan Township.

Explaining his reasons for choosing the two places, Hsieh pointed out that he changed his household registration to Penghu County in the past in order to avoid being arrested by the Kuomintang, and the Kaohsiung City government built more than 100 prefabricated temporary houses in Nantou for victims of 921 earthquake during his tenure as Kaohsiung City mayor.
Hsieh said the activity will allow children in remote places to take in performance art that is not usually easy for them to access as townships office cannot often afford the expense.
Hsieh hopes that more people will join in this activity, with each individual donating NT$100 to help expand the horizons of kids in far away townships.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO ENFORCE QUOTA REQUIREMENTS ON KMT ASSETS REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Key members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) may be disciplined if they fail to collect sufficient signatures in the party's drive to force a referendum on appropriating opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) ill-gotten assets, aDPP Central Standing Committee resolution affirmed Wednesday.

The DPP is pushing for a referendum to deal with the Kuomintang's ill gotten assets alongside the 2008 presidential election and is currently trying to collect the signatures of 1 million citizens to back the initiative.
The DPP imposed quota requirements on its members holding party or public offices, compelling them to gather signatures, but so far the drive is well behind schedule, according to the party.

The DPP's acting Chairman Trong Chai suggested during the Central Standing Committee meeting that the committee propose disciplining key members who fail to collect the required numbers of signatures by suspending their party memberships for one year. This proposal would then be taken up at the party's National Congress, scheduled for July.

However, several committee members, including the party's legislative caucus leader Ker Chien-ming, argued that such matters regarding penalties against party members should not be determined by the committee.
The committee eventually reached a resolution that such cases be referred to the Central Review Committee for a decision over discipline.

Legislator Lawrence Gao said it is already stated in the party's constitution that the partyshall deliberate and take appropriate disciplinary action towards members whose statements or conduct violate the constitution or resolutions, or are deemed to destroy Party reputation, and therefore the new resolution came only as a reaffirmation, adopted to remind members of the need to help achieve the party's goals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 26, or the 10th day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper" and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1946: Chinese communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: A White House commission recommends that Communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China on Taiwan retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers in Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the U.S. Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe and causing grave pollution. It was the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard. There were only seven survivors.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions along their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, a senior leader of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
1999: NATO planes destroy the Zezeljev railway bridge in Novi Sad during the Kosovo war.
2000: Rodolfo T. Reyes, the new defacto Philippine representative to the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian pays a visit to former Premier Hau Pei- tsun for talks on a wide range of issues.
2001: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulates Junichiro Koizumi on his election as Japanese prime minister.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM NEEDED TO MAKE TAIWAN 'NORMAL COUNTRY': CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/07 13:59:28 (By Lin Yu-li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Wednesday the country's need to reform its constitution to make Taiwan a "normal country."

Speaking during a video conference with a group of German politicians, academics and media representatives, Chen said that many of the problems that Taiwan faces today are related to its constitutional system and that the country urgently needs a new constitution that is viable and up to date.
First of all, Chen noted, Taiwan's current Constitution was enacted in China 60 years ago without the consent of the people in Taiwan.
In addition, the constitutional system is confusing because it is neither a parliamentary system nor a presidential system, he pointed out.

The president said various civil groups in the country have put forth a total of 15 different versions of draft amendments to the Constitution, including some that touch on sensitive issues such as changing the country's official name to "Republic of Taiwan" and forming a "second republic."

However, no matter which versions are adopted, they will have to be approved by the Legislative Yuan first and passed in a public referendum before they can be written into the Constitution, Chen said.

While Taiwan, like other emerging democracies, faces problems such as vicious partisan struggle, transitional justice and constitutional reform, none of them are as serious as the differences over national identity, he said.

Chen claimed the rise of Taiwan consciousness in the country in recent years proves that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is on the right track and that more and more people believe the party stands a good chance of winning the 2008 presidential election.
On Taiwan's relations with China, Chen said unification between the two sides is impossible at present because Beijing continues to deny Taiwan's status as an independent sovereign state.

The president noted that the National Unification Council and the National Unification Guidelines, which set unification with China as the ultimate goal and which ceased to function and apply last year, were adopted by the former Kuomintang government without the people's consent.

He pointed out that the former government followed a "one China" principle and used to compete with Beijing for the right to represent "China, " but the present government recognizes that "one China" refers to the People's Republic of China.
Asserting that Taiwan is a separate country from China, Chen said Taiwan now hopes to apply to join international organizations such as the United States under the name of "Taiwan."
Chen pledged that he will continue to strengthen the Taiwanese identity during the remaining year of his term.
Meanwhile, Chen expressed the hope that he will be able to visit Germany as the president of Taiwan.
Chen said he was meeting with the German friends via video conference because no president of Taiwan has been able to obtain a visa to visit Germany or any other European Union countries.

Even though Taiwan has maintained diplomatic relations with the Holy See for more than 60 years, no president of Taiwan had been able to set foot on Vatican soil until 2005, when he was granted permission to make a transit stop in Italy in order to be able to attend the funeral of the late Pope John Paul II, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA PANNED OVER OPPOSITION TO TAIWAN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) slammed China Thursday over its opposition to Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) , saying China's hidebound intolerance toward Taiwan people's desire for inclusion into the global health care system signifies its contempt for human rights.
The MAC, a Cabinet-level body in charge of Taiwan's China policy planning, issued the press statement after China unleashed ugly invective the day before against Taiwan's WHO membership bid.

A spokesman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office said Wednesday that Beijing strongly opposes Taiwan's new bid to join the WHO under the name of "Taiwan" because Taiwan, as part of China, is not eligible to join the WHO as a member or quasi-member.

The spokesman also claimed that Taiwan is not qualified to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the WHO's highest decision-making body, as an observer. The statement further accused Taiwan of using the WHO bid as a ploy aimed at elevating its pro-independence secessionist activities to an international forum.
In response, the MAC deplored in the press statement China's obstinate bigotry against the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait do not belong to each other.
Noting that health care is a basic human right, the MAC statement said epidemics prevention and control know no borders or political doctrines and stances.

With an overwhelming majority of the 23 million Taiwan people keenly yearning for their country's participation in the WHO, the MAC statement warned China that its indifference to their health rights as shown in its persistent obstruction of Taiwan's WHO membership bid will only enrage them and drive the two sides of the Taiwan strait further apart.

Since 1997, Taiwan's annual drives to become an observer at the WHA as a "health entity" have invariably been thwarted by Beijing. This year, Taiwan adopted a new strategy, with President Chen Shui-bian writing to the WHO Secretariat to express Taiwan's intention to join the WHO as a full member under the name of "Taiwan." Due to China's opposition, the bid failed again.

In the press statement, the MAC also condemned China for denying a visa to Kaohsiung City Deputy Mayor Cheng Wen-lung to attend an annual meeting of the General Association of International Sports Federations (GAISF) which opened in Beijing Wednesday. Cheng originally planned to take advantage of the event to brief the participants on progress in preparations for the 2009 World Games to be hosted by Taiwan's southern port city.

The MAC urged the international sports community to pay heed to China's perennial obstruction of Taiwan's attempts to participate in international activities, even such non-political ones as the GAISF.

On the April 28-29 economic and cultural forum to be held in Beijing under the auspices of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China, the MAC said the event is just another example of China's "divide and conquer" tactics against Taiwan. The MAC reminded Beijing that its scheme to debase Taiwan's popularly elected government by collaborating with Taiwan's opposition party will never succeed and will turn out to be a disservice to cross-strait relations.

For the well-being of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the MAC statement said, Beijing should resume dialogue with Taiwan's legally elected government on a range of issues of mutual concern, including opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists and launching of more cross-strait charter flights, so that bilateral relations can move in a positive, peaceful and stable direction.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN ASKS CABINET TO STUDY RAISING MONTHLY STIPEND FOR ELDERLY FARMERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he has asked the Executive Yuan to study the issue of raising the monthly allowance for elderly farmers by NT$1,000 (US$30) to NT$6,000 if a proposed national pension program fails to clear the legislature by July.

The president made the remarks while inspecting a lychee farm in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan. Accompanying him were Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary- general of the Presidential Office, and David Lee, director-general of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs.

Recent reports said that a draft bill on the national pension program mapped out by the Ministry of the Interior will be sent to the Executive Yuan for screening May 2. The Executive Yuan hopes the draft bill can clear the Legislative Yuan by November so that the program can be put into practice in January 2008, the reports said.
Under the draft bill, the ensured persons will start to pay a monthly premium of NT$618 at that age of 25 and will be entitled to a monthly pension of NT$7,603 when they reach 65.

The draft bill calls for the integration of four current monthly allowances -- the NT$3,000 monthly allowance for seniors, the NT%5,999 for elderly farmers, the NT$3,000 for aboriginal seniors, and the NT$6,000 for seniors in low-income households.

The allowances for the four groups of people will be scrapped in due time so as to prevent political parties from proposing increases in allowances ahead of every election to curry favor with voters, thus exacerbating the government's already strained financial situation, according to the draft bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER MUM ON DATE OF COMMUTATION IMPLEMENTATION

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang refused to say Thursday whether the plan to grant sentence commutations to prison inmates will be implemented May 20, saying only that all matters in this regard will be conducted in accordance with the law.

After President Chen Shui-bian instructed the Executive Yuan Tuesday to work out a plan for a national amnesty, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) produced a preliminary draft of a national sentence commutation bill that same day, Lee said, adding that the MOJ will consult the Interior Ministry before referring the draft bill to the Executive Yuan May 2 for approval.

Lee noted that the draft bill will only commute sentences for criminals serving time for minor offenses, adding that it will not commute capital sentences to life sentences nor include those convicted of serious crimes and crimes that endanger society. Crimes against the Prevention and Punishment of Sex-Trade Act and special financial crimes will also be excluded, he added.
He made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Home and Nations Committee.
The previous commutation was meted out in Taiwan 16 years ago to celebrate the 80th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China.
Chen said recently that another commutation is appropriate for this year, as it is the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law and the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident.
More than 10,000 prison inmates are expected to benefit if the bill is passed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 18TH IN GLOBAL CO2 EMISSIONS: IEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks 18th in the world in terms of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, with per capita emissions standing at 11.26 tons in 2004, a spokesman for the International Energy Agency (IEA) said Thursday.

The IEA spokesman was responding to an inquiry by CNA about the exact figures of Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions after a Taiwan environmental researcher warned a day earlier that Taiwan ranked first in the world in terms of per capita CO2 emissions growth between 1990 and 2005.

Liu Shaw-chen, chief of the Academia Sinica's Research Center for Environmental Change, also warned that Taiwan ranked fourth in the world in terms of per capita greenhouse gas emissions, behind only the United States, Australia and Canada.
The IEA spokesman, however, said that according to the IEA's 2006 study, Taiwan ranked 18th in per capita CO2 emissions, and not fourth, in the world in 2004.

Nevertheless, the IEA tallies showed that Taiwan outstripped other East Asian countries in terms of per capita greenhouse gas emissions in 2004, with South Korea ranking 25th in the world and Japan ranking 26th.

According to the IEA data, Qatar ranked first in terms of per capita greenhouse gas emissions at 49.64 tons, followed by Kuwait, Luxembourg, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, the United States, Australia and Canada, in that order.
