DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 15.39 points to close at 8,000.04.

The bourse opened at 8,046.72 and fluctuated between 8,052.55 and 8,000.04 during the day's trading. A total of 3.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.42 billion (US$2.9 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues decreasing 0.8 percent and cement stocks dropping 0.3 percent.
Construction issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 611 to 494, with 264 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER CONFIRMS RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF TAIWAN-ST. LUCIA TIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang reconfirmed Thursday a revelation the day before that his Saint Lucian counterpart has announced the eastern Caribbean island nation's decision to re-establish diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Huang expressed the hope that the two nations can sign a communique marking the official re-establishment of ties as soon as possible and said his ministry is working to complete all the relevant follow-up procedures.

Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that Saint Lucia has become Taiwan's 25th diplomatic ally after Saint Lucia's minister of foreign affairs announced the news. Su described the resumption of diplomatic ties with Saint Lucia as one of the most encouraging news events since he assumed the premiership early last year.

In response to reporters' questions, Huang said that while negotiating for the resumption of Taiwan-Saint Lucia ties, Taiwan never once asked the island nation to severe its diplomatic relations with China. And Saint Lucia has no intention of doing so, he added.

Asked about the anticipated protest from Beijing, Huang stressed that diplomacy is "not a zero-sum game." He added that Taiwan does not want to compete with China, its political rival, in the diplomatic field, pointing out that "all we hope is that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will expand their respective diplomatic territory on their own."
Huang said it is no secret that Taiwan has been seeking to re-establish diplomatic relations with Saint Lucia.
Over the past four months, Huang said, he made two separate visits to the country, including one in March at the invitation of his Saint Lucian counterpart.
The East Caribbean nation first established diplomatic ties with Taiwan in 1984 but then switched diplomatic recognition to China in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION INTRODUCES POSITIVE WAYS TO DISCIPLINE CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Humanistic Education Foundation (HEF) presented Thursday the Chinese version of a guidance manual from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) on how to discipline a child.

At the presentation ceremony held in Taipei, HEF founder and Executive Chairman Shih Ying said the manual offers teachers and parents positive ways to teach their children, instead of traditional discipline practices such as corporal punishment.

In the manual, titled "Positive Discipline in the Inclusive, Learning-Friendly Classroom, " the educational experts suggest that teachers and parents respect the child's dignity; develop pro-social behavior, self-discipline, and character; maximize the child's active participation; respect the child's developmental needs and quality of life; respect the child's motivational characteristics and life views; assure fairness and transformative justice; and promote solidarity among children.

The experts also suggest that teachers and parents reward and recognize good behavior in four manners: describe the appropriate behavior, provide clear reasons, request acknowledgement, and reinforce correct behavior.

By giving eye-contact, a nod or a smile, an extra five minutes of play time, extra credit points, or having good behavior praised in front of a class or a school is the best way of rewarding a good deed by children, which the experts say will have strong and positive effects in disciplining children, the manual suggests.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved up 42 points to close at 8,002, with 30,959 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June rose 40 points to finish at 7,990, with 345 contracts traded, while September futures increased 34 points to close at 7,796, with 85 contract transactions. December futures gained 28 points to close at 7,793, with nine contracts traded, while March futures moved up 27 points to finish at 7,790, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,960 for May, 7,950 for June, 7,762 for September, 7,765 for December and 7,763 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

May TE futures gained 1.4 points to close at 337.4, with 2,204 contracts traded, while June TE futures rose 0.5 points to finish at 335.55, with 54 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

May TF futures moved up 4.6 points to close at 977.6, with 1,488 contracts traded, while June TF futures gained 3.2 points to finish at 978.2, with 22 contract transactions. September TF futures increased 12.4 points to close at 979, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11% OF NEW GRADUATES HAVE EDGE IN FOREIGN LANGUAGE ABILITY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Only 11 percent of recent graduates in Taiwan consider themselves to enjoy an advantage because of their foreign language ability, although many agree the ability is crucial to their competitiveness in the job market, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.
The survey was conducted by the Council of Labor Affairs' Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training from March 5-27 among 3,287 job-seekers and 492 employers.

The survey found that 85 percent of new graduates had begun to look for jobs before graduating and the electronics, information technology and service industries are the most popular employment fields.
However, 13 percent of the employers said they are not hiring new graduates because they lack experience and because there are few positions suitable for them.

The survey shows that in addition to academic background and proficiency on the part of job applicants, the major criteria used by employers in hiring workers also include sales ability, professional skills, computer skills and foreign language ability.

While 58 percent of the new graduates surveyed said they believe a higher education background will facilitate their job searches, 46 percent of the employers said the educational background of job applicants will affect their hiring decisions.

However, most of the employers surveyed do not care whether job applicants are graduates of famous universities or not, with 52 percent saying there is no direct connection between their hiring decision and the universities from which the applicants have graduated.

Meanwhile, 33 percent of the employers said they will not hire job applicants who are self-righteous and arrogant, 27 percent will reject applicants who are unable to express themselves clearly and 20 percent will say no to those who lack manners.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSED AMNESTY FOCUSES ON PETTY CRIMINALS: DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: The proposed national commutation of sentences will apply only to prisoners serving sentences of less than one year, Democratic Progressive Party caucus whip Ker Chien-ming said Thursday.

Ker said the planned amnesty will reduce sentences for prisoners who "unintentionally" committed minor crimes, but will not affect sentences of those convicted of serious crimes that endanger society, such as murder, corruption, sexual assault or economic crime.

The Ministry of Justice is drafting a commutation statute in line with President Chen Shui-bian's directive to implement a reduction of sentences to acknowledge the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law and the 60th anniversary of the 228 incident.

The reduction of sentences will ease prison overcrowding and give petty criminals the chance to start anew, Ker said, adding that 64,000 inmates are imprisoned in Taiwan's jails, which are designed to hold only 53,000 prisoners.
Criminals who committed crimes or received verdicts or indictments before a certain date might be eligible for the amnesty, although exact dates have not yet been decided, Ker said.
The MOJ will submit the draft of the National Commutation Bill of 2007 to the Executive Yuan session May 2 for approval, after which it will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONVENIENCE STORES MOVE TO GRAB EATING-OUT MARKET SHARE

TEXT.P: In view of the growing eating-out market, convenience store chains have developed new practices to grab a larger share of the market, which is estimated to be worth NT$140 billion (US$4.2 billion) a year, market sources said Thursday.

Billions of dollars are now being spent on eating outside the home, the market sources said, adding that in addition to convenience stores, hypermarket chains and restaurants are also eyeing the market.
However, based on their distribution channels, convenience store chains take the lion's share, offering millions of boxed meals annually.
Among them, the 7-Eleven chain supplied 60 million boxed meals last year, while the Hi-Life chain, with over 1,000 affiliated stores, sells an average of 7 million annually, according to the sources.

The revenue stream from 7-Eleven's fresh food amounts to NT$14 billion, representing a 10 percent share of the eating-out market. To extend its market share, 7-Eleven has recently launched new and diversified boxed meals.
A 7-Eleven spokesman added that the chain hopes to reach the goal of selling 70 million boxes in 2007 and expand to 100 million boxes annually in the near future.
The stores will continue to widen their appeal by developing diversified menus and offering fresh products, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 256 KG DRUGS BURNED AS PRELUDE TO NATIONAL ANTI-DRUG CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Investigation (BOI) burned 265 kg of various drugs seized by law- enforcement personnel over the past year Thursday as a prelude to the 2007 National Anti-Drug Conference slated for June 3.

Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin presided over a public ceremony at the incineration, which was monitored by Chien Han-liang of the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office, as well as Ling Li-yi, a consultant to the John Tung Foundation, Miao Yi-fan, deputy secretary-general of the Consumers' Foundation and Teng Chao-fang, chief executive officer of the Foundation for Poison Control.

According to the BOI, the drugs named as criminal evidence by the court which ordered their destruction included 242.54 kg of heroin, 21.29 kg of marijuana, 691.24 g of morphine and 1,175.86 g of cocaine.

It was the largest amount of drugs the BOI has destroyed since 1993, when the bureau opened an office to store and manage narcotic evidence. The destruction has been since then conduced once per year in accordance with the annual anti- drug conference, the BOI said.

A BOI analysis on drug offenses shows that the amount of ketamine recovered in the past two years recorded two-fold growth, while marijuana gained in popularity among office workers and people in show business.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FORCES WELCOMED, BUT NOT EXPECTED IN CROSS-STRAIT CONFLICT

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Lee Jye said Thursday that it is not within the Ministry of Defense's assessment whether U.S. forces will come to Taiwan's aid in the event of military conflict across the Taiwan Strait.

Saying that the Republic of China military will defend the country independently without depending on any outside support, Lee said the U.S. forces would be welcomed if the United States is willing to extend a helping hand, but that Taiwan will never harbor that kind of expectation.

Lee made the remarks in an interpellation session at the Legislative National Defense Committee, during which opposition Kuomintang Legislator Su Chi asked Lee about the Defense Ministry's countermeasures to the Chinese military's "lean and mean, limited but precise" warfare mindset.

The defense minister responded that the ROC military has the same mindset, adding that "we have always planned and prepared based on the tactical targets that have been maintained by the Chinese military."

As to the design of the annual Han Kuang Exercise program, Lee said, the military has taken drill policies against the worst-case scenario in order to hone the armed forces' combat ability to handle the most undesirable situations.

In response to Su's accusation that the war games conducted by the military have been tampered with politically, Lee said the military has kept its political neutrality and has allowed no "backstage manipulation."

A total of US$970 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.19 and fluctuated between NT$33.18 and NT$33.23.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM ON WHO MEMBERSHIP BID: DOH OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan stands firm on its bid to pursue membership of the World Health Organization (WHO) , despite remarks made by a WHO official denouncing Taiwan's application, a government official said Thursday.

According to Chang Wu-shiu, director-general of the Bureau of International Cooperation under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) , the government will not deviate from its goal of becoming a full WHO member, even though its latest bid was crushed by the WHO a day earlier.

A WHO official called Taiwan's application a "non-issue" late Wednesday and said that the WHO will not deal further with it after thorough study and legal consultation, on the grounds that Taiwan is ineligible to apply for membership, which requires statehood recognized by the United Nations.

Noting that the DOH has yet to verify the remarks by the WHO official to determine whether his comments represented the WHO's official stance concerning Taiwan's membership bid, Chang said that the government will continue soliciting support of its bid from the member states of the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the WHO's highest decision-making unit.
The issue pertaining to Taiwan's WHO membership is up to the WHA member states to decide, Chang said.
In an April 11 letter sent to WHO Director-General Margaret Chan, President Chen Shui-bian stated the country's desire to join the WHO as a full member under the name of Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Acting Spokeswoman Yeh Fei-bi said that the ministry had not received WHO notification of the bid rejection.
Despite the setback, Taiwan remains committed to pursuing its WHO membership and seeking support from allied countries to back its bid, Yeh said in a routine news conference.
This is the first time the government has applied to enter the WHO in the name of Taiwan in more than a decade, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET HOPES LEGISLATURE WILL PASS PENSION PROGRAM BILL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will send a draft bill on a national pension program to the Legislative Yuan next week, hoping that it will pass the bill quickly, Cabinet spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling said Thursday.

Chen Mei-ling made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian said earlier the same day during an inspection tour in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan that he has asked the Executive Yuan to study the issue of raising the monthly allowance for elderly farmers by NT$1,000 (US$30) to NT$6,000 if the proposed bill fails to clear the legislature by July.
The Executive Yuan recently said that in view of current financial strain and the promotion of a national pension program, it would not favor an increase of the monthly stipend for elderly farmers.

Asked if President Chen's remarks run counter to that of the Executive Yuan's stance as well as a resolution reached at a national economic development conference last year, the spokeswoman said the Cabinet's stance on "no increase prior to the implementation of the national pension program" remains unchanged.
She said the Executive Yuan will do its best to communicate with the Legislative Yuan, hoping for speedy passage of the draft bill.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) has estimated that around 700,500 elderly farmers receive monthly allowances of NT$5,000. If they were to get an additional NT$1,000, it would cost the government an extra NT$8.4 billion annually.
Meanwhile, lawmakers from across the party spectrum were unanimous in supporting the increase for farmers.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said the party still hopes that the national pension program should be given priority, but added that if the bill cannot clear the legislature by July, then raising the monthly allowance for farmers is also an option.
Legislator Hsu Shao-ping, a caucus whip of the main opposition Kuomintang, said a hike of NT$1,000 is acceptable to the party.
Recent reports said the Executive Yuan hopes the draft pension bill can clear the Legislative Yuan by November so that the program can be put into practice in January 2008.
Under the draft bill, insured persons who start to pay a monthly premium of NT$618 at the age of 25 will be entitled to a monthly pension of NT$7,603 when they reach 65.

The bill will cover those aged 25-65 who are currently not paying military, civil servant, teacher or labor insurance, as well as farmers under 65. It is estimated that 3.53 million will be included in the national pension program.

The draft bill also calls for the integration of four current monthly allowances -- the NT$3,000 monthly allowance for seniors, the NT$5,999 for elderly farmers, the NT$3,000 for aboriginal seniors and the NT$6,000 for seniors in low-income households.

Once the national pension program is implemented, the allowances for the four groups will be scrapped so as to prevent political parties from proposing increases in allowances ahead of every election to curry favor with voters, thus exacerbating the government's already strained financial situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER TO ORGANIZE 10,000-PEOPLE RALLY FOR SUHUA FREEWAY

TEXT.P: An opposition legislator sponsored a meeting in the eastern city of Hualien Thursday, calling for Hualien residents to launch a rally in Taipei May 3 in favor of the building of the controversial Suhua freeway connecting Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan with Hualien County.

It was resolved at the meeting that 10,000 Hualien residents, to be led by three legislators from across the political spectrum and four former Hualien magistrates, will proceed to Taipei May 3 and march to the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan, the Environmental Protection Administration and the Landis Hotel Taipei to rally support for the freeway and protest against those who oppose the development plan, according to Fu Kun-chi, an opposition People First Party legislator representing Hualien.

Fu called for Hualien residents to demonstrate esprit de corps, saying that it is high time the Hualien people voice their cause before the development plan is aborted under environmental protection considerations.

Meanwhile, Hualien County Council Speaker Yang Wen-chih, who co-sponsored the meeting, claimed that the freeway is now a "common wish of the Hualien residents, " although a related environmental analysis review that will decide the fate of the freeway's development has become stuck due to intervention by the environmental protection authorities and private environmental groups.
Yang called for the Hualien residents to go for broke "to defend their rights and interests."

Meanwhile, members of the Hualien tourism sector said they will also stage a protest in front of Ritz Landis Hotel Taipei May 3 to vent their anger at Stanley Yen, chairman of the Landis hotel group, who has voiced his opposition to the freeway development plan recently, saying that the Suhua freeway development plan is an ethical rather than a political issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONCERNED WITH EU ANTI-DUMPING TAXATION AGAINST PET
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/07 19:46:02 (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has expressed concern to the World Trade Organization (WTO) over the European Union's decision to continue imposing anti-dumping tax against polyethylene terephthalate (PET) imported from Taiwan, officials from Taiwan's Representative Office to the WTO said Thursday.

In a WTO anti-dumping committee meeting earlier in the week, Taiwan also refused to accept a decision formed early this year in the EU's sunset review of anti- dumping duties on Taiwan-produced PET, and denied what the EU claims is deliberate dumping by Taiwan, the officials noted.

The EU began the anti-dumping taxation against Taiwan PET in 2000, with PET imports from Taiwan's Far Eastern Textile Co. facing a 3.5 percent tariff and those from Shinkong Textile Co. slapped with a 6.5 percent tariff.
In 2005, the EU started the sunset review targeting the ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HELPS SETTLE DISPUTE OVER TAINAN UNDERGROUND RAIL PROJECT

TEXT.P: A long-term dispute over the funding of a Tainan underground rail project was settled Thursday after Premier Su Tseng-chang gave his word Thursday that the Tainan city government will only have to shoulder 12.5 percent of the cost.
Su, who is bidding to represent the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the 2008 presidential election, met with Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair and legislators from the southern city.
The premier said the city government will only have to shoulder 12.5 percent, or NT$3.7 billion of the total budget, with the central government providing the balance.

According to an estimate by the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC) , a budget of NT$29.58 billion (US$896.36 million) is required to make a 7.55-km section of the railway in the city run underground.

Su expressed hope that construction of the project can start soon so that further city development will not harm the preservation of the numerous heritage sites in the city, which is dubbed as Taiwan's "cultural old city."
Tainan proposed the project to the Executive Yuan in 2004 but it never got off the ground because both the central and city governments could not afford the cost.
The MOTC asked the city to put up NT$7.14 billion, but the financially strapped local government complained that it could not afford to.

The city government even suggested that the central government make available the full amount needed for the project, or else allow the city government to repay the central government at a rate of either NT$2.5 billion over 15 years or NT$4 billion over 25 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER REVISES TAIWAN'S PROJECTED ECONOMIC GROWTH UP TO 4.09%

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) revised Thursday its forecast for the country's 2007 economic growth up 0.02 percentage points to 4.09 percent.

The private think thank predicted that private consumption will expand 2.69 percent this year owing to the improvement of the unemployment and credit card debt problems, while the value of exports is expected to increase 9.6 percent from US$21.32 billion last year to US$21.59 billion this year.

Meanwhile, a survey conducted by the TIER in March on the business climate for the manufacturing sector shows that 44.9 percent of manufacturers think conditions will improve over the next six months, down from 55.1 percent in a February survey.
A total of 9.1 percent of the respondents predicted that conditions will be worse over the next six months, down from 9.8 percent in the previous month.
Meanwhile, 45.9 percent said they think conditions will remain the same, up from 35.1 percent in February.
The composite business climate indicator for the manufacturing sector stood at 115.79 in March, up 1.37 points compared with the previous month, TIER officials said.
The composite business climate indicator for the service sector registered 110.36, down 0.77 points from February, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Court Asked to Limit Lawyers at Guantanamo
The Justice Department has asked a federal appeals court to impose tighter restrictions on the hundreds of lawyers who represent detainees at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, and the request has become a central issue in a new legal battle over the administration detention policies.
Saying that visits by civilian lawyers and attorney-client mail have caused intractable problems and threats to security at Guantanamo, a Justice Department filing proposes new limits on the lawyers'contact with their clients and access to evidence in their cases that would replace more expansive rules that have governed them since they began visiting Guantanamo detainees in large numbers in 2004.
Wall Street Journal:German Giant Siemens Faces Leadership Crisis
For Klaus Kleinfeld, chief executive of German engineering giant Siemens AG, the end came swiftly as he lost the backing of key members of his board, who went so far as to try to recruit a new CEO over the weekend. Yesterday, amid a widening corruption probe at Siemens, Mr. Kleinfeld abruptly said he wouldn't stay beyond September.
The exit leaves a vacuum at the top of Siemens and marks a dramatic reversal for Mr. Kleinfeld, a hard-charging 49-year-old who is one of Europe's leading corporate executives. Mr. Kleinfeld has won plaudits from Siemens shareholders for aggressively restructuring the sprawling industrial conglomerate and boosting its profits since he took over in January 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CHIEF AGAINST AMNESTY FOR VIOLENT CRIMINALS

TEXT.P: National Police Agency (NPA) Director-General Hou Yu-ih said Thursday that he is against granting amnesty or reducing jail terms to those convicted of violent crimes or under a sentence of death.

Hou made the comments during a question-and-answer session in the Legislative Yuan in response to questions from a group of the main opposition Kuomintang lawmakers who are concerned that demonstrating leniency would deal a blow to public order and assert that most of the rank-and-file policemen are opposed to the idea.

Under instructions from President Chen Shui-bian, relevant government agencies recently proposed an act to reduce prison terms or a partial amnesty for criminals. One of the authorities' arguments in support of the idea is that "all the prisons are packed."

Hou replied that the NPA has not conducted polls to gauge the opinions of grass- roots policemen and said that he would not oppose reduced terms for those convicted of minor offenses carrying a sentence of less than one year.

But Hou added that in his capacity as the highest police officer charged with maintaining the rule of law and public order across the country, he would "object" to the proposed amnesty if it were to include those convicted of violent offenses.

"Granting amnesty must not hinder public order or social morals," he said, adding that "we would clarify our position and offer recommendations if the there were a chance that the proposed amnesty might affect public order."

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS OF PHARMACEUTICAL PRODUCTS INCREASE US$18.6 MILLION

TEXT.P: Exports of Taiwan's pharmaceutical products increased NT$620 million (US$18.6 million) during the last year for a year-on-year growth of 4 percent, according to the statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Thursday.

Officials of MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) attributed the growth in exports to the 2005 establishment of three alliances for pharmaceutical product exports targeting markets in United States, Europe and Japan, which collectively account for more than 80 percent of the global pharmaceutical market.

Officials noted that the establishment of the three alliances, under the coordination of Pharmaceutical Industry Technology Development Center (PITDC), have helped local pharmaceutical products manufacturers set up their own brands and strengthen their marketing in global markets.

In addition to helping local companies better understand American pharmaceutical enterprises' preferences, the alliances are also assisting domestic firms to develop a presence in the European market as early as possible, the officials added.

The efforts of the export alliances have encouraged some domestic groups to invest more than NT$200 million in biotechnology industry and several others are negotiating business with British firms, which is expected to result in new orders worth NT$300 million, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO ALLOWANCE HIKE EVEN IF BILL FAILS TO CLEAR LEGISLATURE: CABINET

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will not raise the monthly allowance for elderly farmers even if a draft bill on a national pension program fails to clear the Legislative Yuan by July, Cabinet spokeswoman Chen Mei-ling said Thursday.

Chen said the Executive Yuan will abide by a resolution passed by a national economic development conference last year which stated that no more increase on any stipends will be allowed before the implementation of the national pension program.

Chen Mei-ling made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian said earlier the same day during an inspection tour in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, that he has asked the Executive Yuan to study the issue of raising the monthly allowance for elderly farmers by NT$1,000 to NT$6,000 if the proposed bill fails to pass the legislature by July.

Chen Mei-ling stressed that the Cabinet is "not out of sync" with the president on this point, saying that the president's main intention is that "the Executive Yuan will do everything possible to promote the draft bill so that it can clear the legislature soon. "

She said that after sending the draft bill to the legislature next week, the Cabinet will ask the Ministries of the Interior and Economic Affairs to actively communicate and coordinate with the Legislative Yuan on this matter.
Asked if the legislature, which will end its current session at the end of May, will pass the bill in time, she only said that the Cabinet will make every effort to do so.
Moreover, the legislature may convene an extraordinary session whenever there are major bills pending, she added.

Under the draft bill, insured persons who start to pay a monthly premium of NT$618 beginning at the age of 25 will be entitled to a monthly pension of NT$7,603 when they reach 65. It is estimated that 3.53 million persons will be included in the national pension program.

The draft bill also calls for the integration of four current monthly allowance programs -- the NT$3,000 monthly allowance for seniors, the NT$5,999 for elderly farmers, the NT$3,000 for aboriginal seniors and the NT$6,000 for seniors in low-income households.

Once the national pension program is implemented, the allowances targeting these four groups will be scrapped so as to prevent political parties from proposing increases in allowances ahead of every election to curry favor with voters, thus exacerbating the government's already strained financial situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAUNCHES INSPECTION TOUR IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan Thursday to hear the opinions of local entrepreneurs regarding their businesses.

Accompanied by Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Chen first visited Paokai Electronic Enterprise Co., which manufactures electronic gaming machines and vending machines.
Paokai, which originally produced condom machines, diversified into electronic gaming machines by designing its own chips. Now the company has orders from countries around the world, mainly Japan.
Chen later visited the Dafa Industrial Park, where he hailed the enterprises established in the industrial park for their contributions to the country's economic development.

During a meeting, some entrepreneurs suggested that the government should not increase the minimum wage to a level that is unbearable for entrepreneurs, a suggestion Chen said he would pass on to the relevant agencies.

In Tashu village, producer of high-quality pineapples and lychees, Chen promised to serve as spokesman of Tashu village's Yu Her Pao lychees at a pineapple and lychee festival scheduled to open May 26.

Tsai Fu-ching, director of the Kaohsiung county government's Agricultural Department, said that around 2,200 hectares around the country is dedicated to the cultivation of Yu Her Pao lychees, with Kaohsiung County accounting for 1,870 hectares, 65 percent of which is located in Tashu village.
After leaving Tashu village, Chen and his entourage visited a famous eco- friendly park near Kaohsiung County's old bridge.

According to Yang, the park, occupying 120 hectares, includes 13 wetland areas, can manage the county's household and industrial waste water by purifying it and them dumping it into rivers. It is also the habitat of more than 100 species of birds.
With the help of volunteer bird-watchers, Chen watched some of the birds and praised the park for combining ecological, economic and tourism functions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
House Passes Iraq Pullout Timetable.
The House last night brushed aside weeks of angry White House rhetoric and veto threats to narrowly approve a $124 billion war spending bill that requires troop withdrawal from Iraq to begin by Oct. 1, with a goal of ending U.S. combat operations there by next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS, PRIVATE SECTOR NOT IN TUNE ON MINIMUM WAGE

TEXT.P: The country's trade and industrial sectors were out of tune with the administration Thursday over the issue of a minimum wage hike.

At a meeting called by Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen on the minimum wage adjustment plan, representatives of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) and the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China (GCCROC) did not agree with a 10-percent hike in the minimum wage proposed by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

The CLA recently suggested a 10-percent rise in the minimum wage to make it more commensurate with Taiwan's general economic situation and consumer price index. The wage has remained frozen at the same level for the past 10 years.

Ho Yu, a standing board member of the CNFI, said that if the minimum wage is to be raised, it should be capped under five percent, while GCCROC Secretary- General Chiu Chao-hsin said that the GCCROC's bottom line is five percent and no higher.
Firmly opposing a 10-percent rise, Ho said the industrial sector will have to pay an extra NT$3.6 billion (US$1.09 billion) to workers if the minimum wage is hiked by one percent.
The industrial sector will add an extra NT$14.5 billion to its overhead costs if the minimum wage rises by five percent, and NT$39.4 billion if the minimum wage is hiked 11 percent, Ho continued.

Ho also quoted a recent poll conducted by the CNFI as indicating that 56 percent of the federation's members are opposed to a minimum wage hike, while four percent of the members agree with a three-percent hike, 25 percent agree with a five-percent rise and the remaining 15 percent favor a hike that exceeds five- percent.

Chiu said that it is untrue that the minimum wage has been frozen for 10 years, arguing that over the past 10 years the average work week has been shortened while employers have been made to pay for overtime hours and various welfare measures.

According to Chiu, certain businesses, including traditional manufacturing industries, small- and medium-size enterprises, restaurants and other commercial services, will be among the first sectors to bear the brunt of a minimum wage hike.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY SIGNS DISASTER RELIEF COOPERATION PACT WITH NTU

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government signed a cooperation agreement with National Taiwan University (NTU) Wednesday aimed at instilling science and technology into disaster prevention and post-disaster rehabilitation.

County Magistrate Chou Hsih-wei signed the agreement with NTU President Lee Si- chen on the cooperative ties, which involve the two sides jointly working out plans to train local communities in skills and know-how needed in disaster prevention and rescue operations.

The two parties will also collaborate with each other in integrating data banks on disaster control and prevention, mapping out a plan to evacuate personnel in case of massive landslides, and develop a flood warning system, according to the county fire department.

Addressing the event, Chou said it's the county government's duty to safeguard the lives of residents and their property, and natural disasters such as typhoons, earthquakes and landslide have been occurring more frequently in the past few years.

Against that backdrop, Chou said his government budgeted NT$9 million this year to continue its work with NTU in upgrading disaster prevention operations through the application of advanced technologies. The work was undertaken as a part of the central government-initiated national technology program on disaster control and prevention, which ended last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN AIRLINES TO OPEN KAOHSIUNG-HO CHI MINH CITY FLIGHT SERVICE

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines, a local airline carrier, will open regular direct flights between the southern port city of Kaohsiung and Ho Chi Minh City in southern Vietnam, starting April 29, a spokesman for the company said Thursday.

The new service will benefit those Taiwanese businessmen who often need to travel to the Southeast Asian country, Vietnamese spouses of local citizens, and travelers in southern Taiwan, the spokesman noted.
The flight will take around 3.5 hours, the spokesman said, adding that the tickets for the first flight have been sold out.
The airline company will offer a discounted ticket price for flights between April 29 and May 12 to celebrate the opening of the new route, the spokesman pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORLD'S 6TH MOST FAVORABLE INVESTMENT MARKET: BERI

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked the 6th most favorable investment market among 50 countries, according to an evaluation report released Thursday by the Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI).

Ranked after Switzerland, Singapore, the Netherlands, Japan and Norway, Taiwan received 72 points from the BERI for its investment environment, and rated as a Grade A1 environment -- the highest grade available -- indicating a country with low risks and a positive investment environment.
Taiwan's ranking in this, the first evaluation of 2007, is consistent with the previous evaluation from the latter part of 2006.

Taiwan's operational risk index was only lower than that of Switzerland and Singapore, its remittance and repatriation factor ranked 5th, while its political risk index was ranked 15th, moving down one point due to the upcoming year-end legislative election.
The BERI expects continuous improvement in Taiwan's general investment environment, with ranking remaining unchanged but growing to 73 point within one year, and 74 points in five years.

Moreover, the BERI forecasts that Taiwan's operational risk index will be stable or improve during 2007-2008, and that the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) will increase thanks to a vigorous supply and demand market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REJECTS BEIJING'S PLAN FOR OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan rejected China's offer Thursday to include the island on the torch-relay route for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, saying Beijing's proposed route purposely denigrates Taiwan's sovereign status.

According to China's plan, the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei, Taiwan's capital, and the torch would then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing.

Yang Jong-her, Minister of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, and Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee Chairman Thomas W. Tsai quickly decided to reject Beijing's offer on the grounds that Taiwan's sovereign status would be compromised.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING-PROPOSED OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY ROUTE WORSE-CASE SCENARIO: MAC

TEXT.P: Beijing's proposed route for the 2008 Olympic torch relay is unacceptable as it deliberately denigrates Taiwan's sovereign status, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Thursday.

The official who took part in the government's decision-making process with regard to the Olympic torch relay made the remarks after organizers for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games announced what will be the longest torch relay in the games' history earlier in the day. The route covers five continents and makes politically sensitive stops in Taiwan and Tibet.

According to China's plan, the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing.
The MAC official said Taiwan cannot accept the Beijing-proposed torch relay route because it purposely includes Taipei as in its "domestic leg" relay.

According to the official, the government would have welcomed the arrival of the Beijing Olympic torch should it come to Taipei via a third country and travel next to a fourth country. He said Beijing can consider having the torch come to Taipei from Pyongyang, North Korea and then travel to Ho Chi Minh City. "The ball is in Beijing's court," he added.

Stressing that Taiwan is more than willing to take part in all sorts of International Olympic Committee-sponsored activities, the official said Taiwan, however, cannot accept any arrangement that denigrates its sovereign status.

Yang Jong-her, Minister of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, and Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee Chairman Thomas W. Tsai also said shortly after the Beijing's announcement that the torch relay route was unacceptable on the grounds that Taiwan's sovereign status would be compromised.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. VOICES CONCERN OVER CHINA'S HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Belgium, April 26 (CNA) 04/27/07 11:43:32 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The European Parliament adopted Thursday its 2006 annual report on human rights in the world, in which the parliament expressed concern about the situation in China.

The report, adopted during the parliament's plenary session held in Strasbourg, France, said China's human rights record remains a matter of "serious concern" and should "receive more focus in the build-up to the Beijing Olympic games."
The report emphasized the need to strengthen and improve the human rights dialogue between the European Union and China, suggesting that the question of Tibet be raised in talks with Beijing.
In addition, the report said the European Union's trade relations with China should be contingent upon human rights reform.
Meanwhile, the report also expressed "deep concern regarding the deterioration of the human rights situation" in Iran, especially the intensification of the repression against human rights defenders.
On the human rights situation in Russia, the report expressed regret that the European Union has had only limited success in bringing about policy change.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING-PROPOSED OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY PLAN UNACCEPTABLE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that Beijing's proposed route for the 2008 Olympic torch relay is unacceptable to Taiwan, adding that Taiwan's sovereign status should not be undermined under any circumstances.

Commenting on China's plan that the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing, Su said at the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan belongs to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) as an independent sports entity and has taken part in Olympic competitions on an equal footing for years.

Nevertheless, he said, China has persistently schemed to belittle Taiwan, trying to downgrade Taiwan to the level of a province of China, and the torch relay plan -- announced by organizers for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games the day before -- is another example of China's attempt to undermine Taiwan's sovereign status.

On a reporter's question on whether Taiwan will resume negotiations with China if the Beijing Olympics organizers are willing to revise the torch relay route, Su said that Taiwan will be willing to talk to Beijing so long as Taiwan's sovereignty is not belittled or compromised.

Su, meanwhile, declined to speculate on whether Taiwan will boycott the 2008 Olympic Games altogether because of Beijing's attempt to downgrade Taiwan through the torch relay plan, saying that "currently, we are only handling issues of the moment."

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) rejected Beijing's torch relay plan soon after the plan was publicized late Thursday. MAC officials said the plan is unacceptable as it deliberately undermines Taiwan's sovereign status.

Saying that the Chinese officials have played politics with the torch relay plan, MAC officials insisted that Taiwan cannot accept the Beijing-proposed torch relay route because it purposely includes Taipei as part of the "domestic leg" of the relay.
MAC officials added that the government would welcome the arrival of the Beijing Olympic torch if it were to come to Taipei via a third country and then head on to another third country.
The 2008 Olympic Games are scheduled to be held in Beijing Aug. 8-24 next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
ABOUT 25,000 INMATES TO BE SET FREE UNDER AMNESTY PLAN: MOJ

TEXT.P: An estimated 25,000 prison inmates serving sentences for petty crimes or minor transgressions will be set free soon after a national commutation bill takes effect, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Friday.

If the proposed presidential amnesty plan comes into effect in June, Shih added, about 7,500 inmates can be freed from prison in the near term under the new working guidelines of "simplified procedures and convenient operations."

Noting that the National Commutation Bill of 2007 is being drawn up in line with the country's new punitive criminal justice policy that calls for leniency for occasional minor offenders and harsh penalties for those who have committed felonies, Shih said about 150 types of crimes will be excluded from the amnesty list.

According to Shih, serious offenses inapplicable to the proposed amnesty will include violent crimes, particularly cases of kidnapping for ransom and murder, serious cases of carjacking for ransom and telephone fraud, sexual offenses committed against children and women, economic crimes, serious violations of national interests, such as corruption, and serious violations of the National Security Law.

"While mulling the scope of offenses to be eligible for commutation of sentences, we just weighed the categories of crimes and gravity of sentences and didn't touch on any individual cases. As a result, it's not known at this moment whether any particular inmate will be excluded from the amnesty list or not," Shih said.

As of the end of March, 8,581 of those who had received sentences of less than one year were still serving time behind bars. If the amnesty plan is implemented from June, about 7,500 of the inmates in this group can be set free within a month, Shih said, adding that the exact number will require a further check after the draft commutation bill clears the legislature.

Acting on President Chen Shui-bian's directive, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is drafting the commutation statute to implement a reduction of sentences to mark the 20th anniversary of the lifting of martial law and the 60th anniversary of the 228 Incident of 1947, a civilian uprising against the then-Kuomintang government that led to a bloody massacre.
Shih said the draft bill will be ready for delivery to the Executive Yuan for further review next week, after which it will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and approval.

Responding to complaints by an advocacy group calling for the abolishment of capital punishment that the MOJ has ignored President Chen's previous directive on suspending execution of death sentences, Shih said phasing out capital punishment is an established national policy.
Nevertheless, Shih added that the MOJ cannot ignore public sentiments and opinions about such a reform move.

"The ministry has been contemplating complementary measures in preparation for the abolishment of the death penalty in line with the president's directive. On the other hand, we are also endeavoring to strike a balance between the policy demand and public response to the proposed reform," Shih explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY ISSUE POSES TEST FOR TAIPEI, BEIJING, IOC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's snub of China's offer to include its capital city of Taipei on the Olympic torch relay route for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games poses a test to the governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and to the International Olympic Committee (IOC), analysts said Friday.

Within hours of Beijing's announcement of what would be the longest torch relay in Olympic history -- a 137,000-kilometer route that would cross five continents and scale Mount Everest, Taiwan rejected being included on the route.
According to Beijing's announcement, the Olympic torch would arrive in Taipei from Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam before traveling to China-controlled Hong Kong and Macau.

"It is something that Taiwan's government and people cannot accept because the route is defined by Beijing as a domestic route, which constitutes an attempt to downgrade our country's sovereignty," Thomas W. Tsai, chairman of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC), said at a late night news conference.

Speaking on the same occasion, Yang Jong-her, minister of the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, echoed Tsai's view, saying the arrangement announced by Beijing downgrades Taiwan's status as an independent sovereign state because Taipei is included as a leg on China's domestic route.

A senior official of the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward China, also described Beijing's proposal as the worst route. "Beijing was simply trying to belittle Taiwan, " said the official who preferred anonymity.

Taiwan wanted the torch to come from a third country and leave for another third country, the official said, adding that Hong Kong is considered part of China and that Taiwan cannot accept the relay through the former British colony back to Beijing.
It marked the first time since the Olympic torch relay was inaugurated for the 1920 Brussels Olympic Games that an IOC member has rejected being part of the torch relay.
CTOC Chairman Tsai said protests will be lodged with Beijing and with the IOC. "An adjustment to the route is necessary," Tsai said.

As the IOC has already approved the Beijing-proposed relay route, analysts said, it's up to Beijing to resolve whether and how the route will be changed. "The ball is in Beijing's court, " an analyst said.
According to the analyst, Beijing could easily settle the issue by agreeing to have the torch come to Taipei from Pyongyang, North Korea before heading to Ho Chi Minh City.
Given Beijing's obstinate opposition of refusing to treat Taiwan on an equal footing, the analyst said he is not optimistic about the prospect of Beijing making any concession on this issue.

After announcing the torch relay route in Beijing Thursday evening, Jiang Xiaoyu, executive vice president of the Beijing Olympic organizing committee, repeatedly referred to Taipei, Hong Kong and Macau as "overseas Chinese cities" and stressed that they were not included as part of the relay's international route.
Taiwan returned to the IOC in 1981 under the name of "Chinese Taipei" after a 10-year hiatus following its ouster from the United Nations in 1971.

Sports and political analysts reminded the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee that it should carefully handle subsequent issues besides seeking a change to the torch relay route. It should not overlook the possibility of being denied IOC membership following its snub of the 2008 torch relay, they cautioned.

Sports minister Yang said that although Taiwan rejects the planned arrival of the torch, Taiwan athletes will by no means be absent from the Beijing Olympic Games to be held next summer. Asked whether Taiwan would pull out of the games if Beijing were again to deliberately make discriminatory moves to downgrade Taiwan's status, Yang said he couldn't answer such hypothetical questions.

Commenting on the government's torch relay snub, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative whip Ker Chien-ming said he is convinced that Taiwan is better off rejecting the offer since the Olympic torch has become a "political torch."
In contrast, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) issued a statement late Thursday night saying that politics should be kept out of sports.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, a KMT stalwart, said he feels deep regret over the DPP administration's decision to refuse to allow Taiwan to be part of the torch relay.

"I hope the government will change its mind and agree with the inclusion of Taipei in the relay route, " Hau said, adding that the government should not mix sports and politics, which he claimed only damages Taiwan's international image and reputation.

Wu Ching-kuo, Taiwan's member in the International Olympic Committee who is now in Beijing to attend IOC activities there, also expressed "shock and regret" over Taiwan's rebuff, saying he hopes remedies can still be worked out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI'S TOP-END HOUSING PRICES 6TH HIGHEST IN WORLD

TEXT.P: Taipei's top-end residential properties are the sixth most expensive among those of 16 major cities around the world, according to a survey released Thursday by a local real estate brokerage company.

The survey conducted by Century 21 Real Estate shows that top-end housing prices in Taipei average more than NT$600,000 (US$18,127) per ping (3.3 square meters) , ranking behind London's NT$3.6 million, Paris's NT$1.31 million, Seoul's 1.25 million, Sydney's NT$830,000 and Vancouver's NT$660,000.

Ranking from seventh to 16th on the list are: Athens' NT$560,000, New York's NT$550,000, Tokyo's NT$440,000, Shanghai's NT$420,000, Singapore's NT$320,000, Istanbul's NT$200,000, Johannesburg's NT$185,000, Moscow's NT$150,000, Bogota's NT$137,000 and Mexico City's NT$86,000.

The survey found that in cities with a high population density, such as Taipei, Paris and Singapore, top-end housing tends to be smaller in size and located closer to the downtown area, with the commuting time ranging between 10 minutes and 20 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION CONDEMNS TAIWAN'S REJECTION OF OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY PLAN

TEXT.P: Members of the opposition parties condemned Friday the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's rejection of Beijing's proposed route for the 2008 Olympic torch relay, saying that the government is unilaterally barring the Olympic torch from passing through Taiwan for ideological reasons.

Hsu Shao-ping, a whip of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus, said that Taiwan has been concerned that it is increasingly being marginalized in the international community. Nevertheless, she continued, rejecting the passage of the 2008 Olympic torch through Taiwan for political reasons will only do Taiwan a disservice by seriously damaging the country's image in the international community.

Huang Chih-hsiung, an Olympic silver medalist-turned KMT legislator, expressed his concern that the rejection may cause the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to punish Taiwan by repealing Taiwan's membership in the IOC, consequently leaving Taiwan athletes out of the Olympic Games.
If that were to occur, Huang asserted, the DPP government should take all the responsibility.

Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that Beijing's proposed route for the 2008 Olympic torch relay is unacceptable to Taiwan, adding that Taiwan's sovereign status should not be undermined under any circumstances.

Commenting on China's plan that the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing, Su said at the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan belongs to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) as an independent sports entity and has taken part in Olympic competitions on an equal footing for years.

Yang Jong-her, Minister of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, and Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee Chairman Thomas W. Tsai also said shortly after the Beijing's announcement Thursday that the torch relay route was unacceptable on the grounds that Taiwan's sovereign status would be compromised as the Beijing-proposed torch relay route purposely includes Taipei as part of the "domestic leg" of the relay.

Commenting on the government officials' remarks, KMT Legislator Yang Li-huan said that Taiwan should grasp every possible opportunity to gain exposure on the world stage and that the Olympic torch relay would provide Taiwan with an opportunity to expand its tourism. "Taiwan should open itself to the world, rather than shutting itself off," Yang added.

Kuo Su-chun, a deputy whip of the KMT legislative caucus, suggested that a nationwide referendum be held to gauge the Taiwan public's opinions on whether Taiwan should accept the Beijing torch relay route or not.

Meanwhile, Lee Hung-chun, a spokesman for the opposition People First Party, attributed the DPP government's rejection of the Beijing-proposed torch relay route to the DPP's preparation for the 2008 presidential election.
Lee said he believes that in order to consolidate its support base for the 2008 presidential election, the DPP must alienate itself from the international community as well as China.
Lee said he wonders how the DPP will explain to the international community the reasons for rejecting the Beijing-proposed Olympic torch relay route.
The DPP government owes an explanation to the Taiwan public and the world over this issue, Lee added.
He urged the government not to sacrifice Taiwan athletes' rights on the world sports stage because of politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved down 56 points to close at 7,946, with 38,300 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June dropped 53 points to finish at 7,937, with 541 contracts traded, while September futures fell 54 points to close at 7,742, with 83 contract transactions. December futures lost 57 points to close at 7,736, with 20 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,002 for May, 7,990 for June, 7,796 for September, 7,793 for December and 7,820 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

May TE futures dropped 2.7 points to close at 334.7, with 2,420 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 2.5 points to finish at 333.05, with 54 contract transactions. September TE futures moved down 2.85 points to close at 326.05, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

May TF futures moved down 5.6 points to close at 972, with 1,442 contracts traded, while June TF futures dropped 2.8 points to finish at 975.4, with 13 contract transactions. September TF futures rose 0.8 points to close at 970.2, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUS DRIVER PUNISHED FOR VIOLATING PASSENGERS' PRIVACY

TEXT.P: A Taipei city government official said Friday that a bus driver who posted online the contents of videotapes from the bus video camera had broken the law by violating the privacy of the passengers.

Loh Hsiao-hsien, director of Taipei city government's Department of Transportation, made the remarks after a public bus driver working for Shin-Shin Bus Corp. posted the video content on the Internet.

The bus driver argued that he made the video to protect himself in the event of disputes with passengers or misconduct by passengers. He added that he did it mainly to change the public's impression of bus drivers.
Chen stressed that the video content from the monitors is usually offered by bus companies to judicial authorities when there is an accident or dispute between drivers and passengers.

However, the Shin-Shin Bus driver posted the video content on the Internet, and the video has now become entertainment for Web browsers, Chen said, adding that this has seriously violated the passengers' privacy.

Liu Chi-hwa, general manager of Shin-Shin Bus Corp., said that his company's monitors are generally aimed at drivers and the view outside the bus. Noting that he was surprised by the driver's move, Liu said his company has suspended him from his job.

Chen urged all managers of bus companies to improve their supervision of their drivers, adding that, otherwise, any misbehavior by their drivers will result in demerits for the bus companies in their evaluation reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Italian Premier Romano Prodi and federalism-seeking Northern League Party chairman Umberto Bossi achieved an agreement on electoral reform in their meeting held Thursday in Milan. The Northern League forms part of the center- right opposition alliance "Freedom House" led by former premier Silvio Berlusconi.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA airs concern on poll violence
President Arroyo yesterday ordered the Philippine National Police (PNP) to keep a tight watch on potential election hot spots as she expressed concern over the rising cases of poll-related violence.

MANILA, Philippines -- A big majority of Filipinos vote according to social interest rather than self-interest and follow their conscience rather than jump on the bandwagon, results of a survey conducted by the poll group Social Weather Stations (SWS) on April 14-17 showed.
The Philippine StarG More Army troops in Metro after polls
After the May elections, the Armed Forces of the Philippines National Capital Region Command (NCRCOM) is planning to deploy 12 additional Army teams in Metro Manila ostensibly to conduct civil-military operations.
The Manila TimesG Vital BI task force scrapped
Only days after assuming administrative control of the Bureau of Immigration, the Department of Justice has disbanded the bureaus Special Legal Task Force on Deportation, which has been blamed for the escape of the Vietnamese-American terrorist Vo Van Duc.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR EARLY PASSAGE OF NATIONAL PENSION BILL

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the Legislative Yuan Friday to pass a draft law on the national pension program as soon as possible to facilitate an early start to the program.
Stressing that the program will provide a complete system to take care of disadvantaged citizens, Su said the Cabinet will finalize the bill next week and submit it to the legislature for review.
However, Su would not indicate if the government will increase the monthly allowance for elderly farmers in the event of the bill failing to pass the legislature.
If the law is not enacted, the government has a responsibility to take some other measures to take care of disadvantaged citizens, especially elderly farmers, he said.

The premier made the remarks during a question period in the Legislative Yuan, when asked to comment on President Chen Shui-bian's proposal that the monthly allowance for elderly farmers be raised by NT$1,000 (US$30.12) to NT$6,000 if the national pension bill does not pass the legislature by July.

Cabinet spokesman Chen Mei-ling said Thursday that the Executive Yuan will not hike the monthly allowance for elderly farmers even if the law is not enacted by July, sparking speculation that there are differences between the Cabinet and the president on the issue.

Currently, three kinds of monthly allowances are provided for senior citizens 65 or over: NT$3,000 per month for those who have registered their households in Taiwan and have lived in the country for more than 183 days per year over the past three years and who are not receiving government-subsidized shelter placement or retirement pensions for military personnel; NT$5,000 per month for those who made a living from farming or fishing; and between NT$3,000 and NT$6,000 per month for low-income families.
Officials tallies show that the government paid out NT$71.2 billion between January and November 2006 in allowances for the senior citizens, with the number of beneficiaries totalling 1.63 million.

DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Govt to fork out record $2b for tech projects.
The public sector will spend a record $2 billion this year - double the previous high in 2005 - on technology to improve service and security, and protect the environment.
