DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL COUNTER-DENGUE FEVER WORKING MEETING HELD IN KAOSHIUNG

TEXT.P: Local officials in charge of health affairs from around the country gathered Friday at the Kaohsiung city hall for a national working meeting to review efforts in the prevention and control of dengue fever outbreaks.

The annual event came three months earlier this year after signs appeared showing that the mosquito-born disease has been well placed to create an outbreak on the island since the beginning of this year.

According to statistics of the Department of Health (DOH) -- the meeting organizer -- 16 indigenous cases of dengue were recorded Jan. 1 - April 24, and a further 22 cases were imported during that period.

It is necessary for Taiwan to hold meetings of this kind earlier than usual schedule, said Lin Ting, deputy director of the Center for Disease Control, explaining that World Health Organization online data show increasing dengue outbreaks in countries in Southeast Asia and Latin America.
Taiwan needs to be well prepared in the face of the possible inflow of overseas dengue virus and to strengthen its risk management against viral stowaways, Lin said.
The working meeting was presided over by DOH chief Hou Sheng-mou, who said in his address to the event that he is confident in existing dengue prevention and control measures.

Over the past years Taiwan has been successful in stemming outbreaks of dengue fever. That success has been most obvious in Kaohsiung county, southern Taiwan, one of the most dengue-affected areas of the country. In 2002 the county was hit by over 1,900 dengue cases, but five years later, only 185 cases were reported, according to the DOH.
Kaohsiung County Magistrate Wu Yu-wen attributed the successful disease control to cooperation between the Kaohsiung county and city in efforts to wipe off sources of disease-carrying mosquitoes.
However, Wu suggested that governments must continue to make a coordinated effort to reinforce and promote the strategy of "regional joint defense" in the fight against dengue epidemics.
Dengue fever is a flu-like viral disease spread by the bite of infected mosquitoes which often breed in stagnant water close to human dwellings.

The disease usually begins suddenly and is characterized by high fever, rash, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, muscle and joint pain, accompanied by nausea, vomiting and loss of appetite. It may take a month for a patient to recover.
The most severe and potentially fatal infection by the virus is the hemorrhagic type.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S ATTITUDE KEY TO OPENING OF TOURISM: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top China policy planner said Friday that when Chinese citizens will be allowed to visit Taiwan as tourists hinges on Beijing's attitude.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong said during a question-and- answer session at the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan and China have engaged in five rounds of talks on the matter and he believes that cross-strait negotiations over the issue have entered the final stage.

It is now up to Beijing to determine when Chinese citizens will be allowed to travel to Taiwan for sightseeing this year, Chen said, adding that so long as Beijing gives a green light, the program could be implemented within the year.

Chen made the remarks in response to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Huang Chien-ting, who said that Chinese tourists would be a major force helping to rev up Taiwan's sagging tourism and asked Chen when the government will open Taiwan's doors to Chinese tourists.

Also answering questions at the Legislative Yuan on this issue, Premier Su Tseng-chang said that welcoming Chinese citizens to make sightseeing tour of Taiwan is an established governmental policy, although some related issues, including the exercise of Taiwan government's public authority, should first be discussed.

Meanwhile, Su also said that opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists is a part of the country's strategy to attract international tourists, but not the whole of it, pointing out that welcoming the Chinese in no way minimizes Taiwan's resolve to attract more tourists from around the world.

The pop group F4, which has recently visited Japan and South Korea to promote Taiwan's tourism industry at the invitation of the Tourism Bureau, drew 5,000 of its Japanese and Korean fans to Taipei last week, Su added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 50.62 points to close at 7,949.42.
The bourse opened at 8,019.49 and fluctuated between 8,026.51 and 7,949.42 during trading. A total of 3.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$91.78 billion (US$2.76 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent, and construction issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.5 percent.
The two other major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks increasing 0.9 percent and cement stocks rising 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 804 to 335, with 219 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELOCATION OF GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AWAITS ASSESSMENT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-Chang said Friday that the relocation of government agencies involves many factors and decisions will have to be made after a comprehensive assessment.

The premier made the remarks during a question-and-answer session of the Legislative Yuan after being asked when the Executive Yuan will deliver on its promise to relocate government agencies to help balance the development of southern and northern Taiwan.

Legislator Huang Chao-shun of the main opposition Kuomintang noted that except for the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture, which is scheduled to relocate to Kaohsiung from Taipei in October, she has not heard any progress on the relocation of other government agencies.
The premier said that the relocation program is still awaiting a comprehensive assessment that has not yet been concluded.

The premier first said during an interpellation session in February that government agencies or state-owned enterprises can assess for themselves whether relocating to central or southern Taiwan would help them to better serve the public or business.

Asked whether Chunghwa Telecom will also be relocated to southern Taiwan, Minister of the Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei said that it will depend on whether the relocation will have positive or negative effects on its operations.

If moving will provide benefits, then the ministry will support it, but if a relocation proves not to be feasible, then the company should explain to the public why it makes more sense for its headquarters to remain in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.049 to close at NT$33.265.
A total of US$772 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.215 and fluctuated between NT$33.11 and NT$33.274.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVELATION OF TIES WITH ST. LUCIA SPREADS GOOD NEWS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that he wished to share his joy when he announced that Taiwan will re-establish diplomatic relations with St. Lucia.

The premier, while meeting a supporter group in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, said Wednesday night that St. Lucia has become Taiwan's 25th diplomatic ally after St. Lucia's Minister of Foreign Affairs announced the news. He described the resumption of diplomatic ties with St. Lucia as one of the most encouraging news events since he assumed the premiership early last year.

Su made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan when asked about questions Vice President Annette Lu raised concerning Su's appropriateness of his announcement of the resumption of diplomatic ties, which is properly the domain of President Chen Shui-bian. Lu also said that Su's act aimed at currying favor with the voters.
Both Su and Lu are bidding to become the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate in the 2008 election.
The premier denied that his announcement was a "slip of tongue" brought about by pressure prior to the presidential primary of the DPP, saying that he wanted to "share the good news with the public."
The premier said that he received the approval of the Presidential Office prior to the announcement.
He said the re-establishment of diplomatic ties with St. Lucia has been conducted in an open way, and is by no means a product of "secret diplomacy."

Su noted that St. Lucia's Foreign Minister Rufus Bousquet said Wednesday morning that the nation intends to establish diplomatic ties with Taiwan, although it did not rule out maintaining relations with China.
Foreign media also reported the news later that day, meaning that it was by no means a secret, he added.

He stressed that diplomatic policy is with the purview of the president and that the resumption of diplomatic relations with St. Lucia has been the result of efforts by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang expressed the hope Thursday that the two nations can sign a communique marking the official re-establishment of ties as soon as possible and said his ministry is working to complete all the relevant follow-up procedures.
The east Caribbean nation first established diplomatic ties with Taiwan in 1984, but then switched diplomatic recognition to China in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO QUIT 2008 OLYMPICS IF CALLED 'TAIPEI, CHINA': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that Taiwan would not take part in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games if China insisted on referring to the country as "Taipei, China, " instead of the more commonly used "Chinese Taipei."
Su said the reference "Taipei, China" would represent a downgrading of Taiwan's status as a sovereign country, a situation which he said is totally unacceptable to the government.
"Taiwan would never participate in the Games only to be dwarfed and humiliated, " Su said during a question and answer session in the Legislative Yuan.

The government has rejected China's offer to include the island on the Olympic torch-relay route on the grounds that Beijing's proposed route purposely downgrades Taiwan's status to that of a local administrative region of China.

According to China's plan, the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS CALLS FOR SWITCH TO PARLIAMENTARY GOVERNMENT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A group of scholars and professionals appealed to the major political parties Friday to change the goverment's system to a parliamentary system through the implementation of constitutional amendments.

Lu Ya-li, professor emeritus of Political Science at National Taiwan University, and Chou Yan-shan, professor of political science at the Chinese Cultural University in Taipei, urged the ruling and opposition parties of the legislature to initiate a motion to revise the Constitution and change the system of government.

Claiming that their opinions represent those of more than a hundred political science scholars and professionals, Lu and Chou said the general provisions of the current constitution, which deals with the sensitive issues of the country's name and territory, should remain intact.

However, they said at a news conference the central government's system should be converted to a parliamentary system, with its members chosen by a popular election system under which the voters cast one ballot for their favorite candidates and one for their favorite political parties.
They also called for an relaxation of the current criteria for amending the Constitution.

Noting that both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the major opposition Kuomintang have been in favor of a system of parliamentary government, Lu and Chou urged them to come up jointly with a motion for constitution revisions before May 5 and put it to a national referendum held in conjunction with either the legislative elections at the year end or the presidential elections early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 TAICHUNG INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL FAIR ATTRACTING LARGE CROWDS

TEXT.P: The 2007 Taichung International Travel Fair (TITF), being held at the Taichung World Trade Center April 26- 29, has attracted tens of thousands of visitors during the first two days of the exhibition, organizers said Friday.

Fair visitors include large numbers of bargain hunters looking for discount tour package deals offered by the 265 exhibitors from Taiwan and abroad, according to officials from the Taichung city government, which is holding the annual exhibition in conjunction with the Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation of Communications.

Exhibitors at the fair this year include the central government and city and county governments from around Taiwan, as well as foreign and domestic hotels, theme parks, travel agencies, tourism organizations and travel magazines.

As one of the measures to attract crowds, the organizers have been awarding the first 500 visitors to the show each day with various gifts, including plane tickets, hotel vouchers, discount coupons, health spa vouchers and various souvenirs.

Many tour operators at the exhibition are offering package deals at markedly reduced prices, including a tour package of NT$1,999 (US$60) for three nights at any of the 89 hotels in Taiwan, China and the Philippines which have joined the plan.

Malaysia, which has declared 2007 "Visit Malaysia Year" with the goal to increase the number of tourist arrivals to 20 million this year, is represented at the exhibition by the Malaysia Tourism Promotion Board.
The board is offering three tour plans, each of five days, within Malaysia, starting from NT$9,999.
As part of the fair's activities, the organizers have invited troupes from Russia, Ukraine, France, Ghana and Malaysia to stage various performances at the exhibition ground each day.

The Taichung International Travel Fair has become a major annual event in central Taiwan since the fair was first held in 2000. Last year's exhibition drew more than 70,000 visitors, up 12.5 percent over 2005, according to figures compiled the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$17,000 MONTHLY WAGE STILL NOT ENOUGH TO IMPROVE LIFE: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 80 percent of respondents to a recent survey opined that the proposed raise of the minimum monthly wage to NT$17,000 (US$511) is still insufficient to improve the lives of socially less privileged workers.

The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) publicized Friday the results of the survey, conducted by a private marketing firm April 20-23, which aimed to review the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) labor policies since it took power in 2000.

The poll shows that 80.7 percent of respondents agreed that the DPP government's efforts to bolster the economic development of the country over the past seven years did not profit workers by raising their wages in the least.
Moreover, 76.7 percent of those surveyed thought the employment market had been unstable over the past few years and that the instability was still increasing.
The survey shows that the postgraduates appeared more concerned about employment situation than did other job-seekers.
KMT Legislator Lin Teh-fu blamed the DPP for its failure to improve the life of 8 million blue-collar workers around the country during its seven-year administration.
A total of 1,077 adults, aged 20-65 years, answered the questionnaire properly. The survey enjoys a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE UP SLIGHTLY IN APRIL: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence indicators increased slightly in April, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the National Central University's Research Center for Taiwan Economic Development.
The consumer confidence index stood at 67.67 in April, up 0.55 points from the previous month, the survey shows.

While five out of the six indicators used in the survey rose in April, the "timing for investing in the stock market over the next six months" indicator registering the greatest increase, gaining 2.20 points from March to stand at 73.20.
Coming in second was the "next six months' domestic consumer price" indicator, which rose 0.95 points from March to 39.45.

The "next six months' domestic economic outlook" indicator hit 51.80, up 0.40 points from the previous month, while the "next six months' employment opportunities" indicator rose 0.35 points to 74.90. The "next six months' family financial status" indicator stood at 53.85, up 0.15 from the month-earlier level.
The only indicator that declined in April was the "timing for buying durable goods over the next six months, " which dropped 0.70 points from March to 112.85.
The survey, conducted by telephone April 19-21 among 2,349 adults around Taiwan, has a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC RULES CHUNGHWA TELECOM MUST CUT ADSL RATES BY 5.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) ruled Friday that the partially state-owned Chunghwa Telecom Corp. must cut its monthly charges by 5.4 percent for data transmission services through asymmetric digital subscriber lines (ADSL).

NCC officials said at least 3.7 million ADSL users will benefit from the rate cut, enactment of which will date from April 1. The officials anticipated that the drop will boost the popularity of broadband online services.

The cut will mean that the 256K/64K monthly charge will drop from NT$200 to NT$180, while 1M/64K will drop from NT$410 to NT$388, 2M/256K will fall from NT$440 to NT$416 and 8M/640K will drop from NT$650 to NT$615.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD-RENOWNED FLUTIST ARRIVES IN TAIWAN FOR RECITAL

TEXT.P: Internationally renowned flutist Gary Schocker, who arrived in Taiwan Thursday, will give a recital Saturday at the National Concert Hall in Taipei City.
Schocker started performing at the age of 3 and has been composing since 5, earning him acclaim as "the Mozart of the flute world" and a "musical genius".

This versatile musician, one of the finest flutists in the world, is also a noted pianist, and a prolific composer who has written many music works ranging from chamber music to musicals, and has attracted a wide audience for his poetic and virtuoso style.
The most published contemporary flutist said he was very glad to learn at Thursday's arrival news conference that his last name in Chinese carries the meaning of "Chevalier."

At Saturday's recital, Schocker will perform with another famous flutist, Anders Norell and Taiwan's up-and-coming pianist Tang Wan-chun to present pieces including Schocker's newly composed "Two Flutes on the Loose in Fujien" that took Taiwan as his inspiration during composition, and the "Ambidextranata, " in which Schocker will demonstrate his special skills by simultaneously playing the flute and piano.

DOC.HEADLINE: TORCH RELAY SHOULD FOLLOW EXAMPLE OF TOKYO OLYMPICS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games' torch relay route should follow the practices adopted at 1964 Tokyo Olympics so that Taiwan will not be downgraded by representation as a part of China.
Chen made the remarks after Chinese organizers of 2008 Olympic Games announced Thursday night that Taipei would be included as a stop in torch relay's domestic route.
According to Beijing's announcement, the Olympic torch would arrive in Taipei from Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam before heading to China-controlled areas of Hong Kong and Macau.
The government of Taiwan rejected being included on China's domestic torch relay route several hours after Beijing's announcement.

Intent on not being downgraded, Chen, while presiding an opening ceremony for a digital and electric products exhibition in Taipei, said the 2008 Olympic torch relay should adopt the practices used at 1964 Tokyo Olympics, in which the torch entered Taipei from the Philippine, before traveling to Japan.
Chen expressed the hope that the 2008 Olympic torch would enter and depart Taiwan via a third country other than China.
Chen said the government's refusal to be included on China's domestic route protects Taiwan's dignity, and urged the public not to speculate overly regarding the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF DISMISSES REPORTS ABOUT OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong dismissed reports Friday that after his meeting with President Chen Shui-bian, the fate of the Olympic torch passing through Taipei was sealed.
He was responding to reports by the China Times, a local newspaper, that Taipei's rejection of the torch relay was decided after a meeting between the MAC chief and the president in mid-April.

According to the reports, during that meeting President Chen was indignant about the possible arrangement of the torch either entering or leaving Taiwan from China via a third country, which Chen reportedly said would give Beijing a boost in its propaganda that Taiwan is a province of China and would be detrimental to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, particularly in light of the 2008 presidential election.
Chen Ming-tong said the reports were wrong, pointing out that since his swearing-in as chairman of the nation's top China policy planning agency April 12, he had not even met the president.

According to the Olympic torch relay route unveiled the previous day, the torch would enter Taipei from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh city and proceed to Hong Kong and Macau. Taiwan rejected this arrangement, insisting that the torch should both enter and leave Taiwan via third countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOLD SUMMIT WITH AFRICAN ALLIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Friday that a summit meeting between Taiwan and its African allies is scheduled to take place in Taipei in September.
Huang made the remarks on the sidelines of a birdwatching trip with ambassadors and representatives to Taiwan in the scenic Aowanda National Forest Recreation Area in central Taiwan's Nantou County.

He said the theme of the summit will be to help Taiwan's allies cope with the challenges of globalization. Issues to be discussed at the summit meeting will include environmental protection, biotourism, solar energy, medical care and health, and agriculture.

He said the purpose of the summit is not to compete with China for "dollar diplomacy, " noting that Taiwan cannot afford such egregious spending, although it is able and willing to help its allies cope with globalization.
China spent about US$20 billion when it hosted the Forum on China-African Cooperation recently, according to Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAIR TRADE COMMISSION INVESTIGATING CONSUMER PRICE HIKE

TEXT.P: Officials of the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission (FTC) said Friday that they have formed an ad hoc group to investigate whether there is any manipulation of commodity prices by traders in local market.
The officials made the announcement after media reports said that prices of several daily necessities, including dairy products, imported meat, flour, soybean oil and feeds surged recently.

The officials stressed that they will respect consumer prices hikes if the situation was the result of fair competition or under the normal market mechanism. Otherwise, the traders may be found to have violated related regulations if they force up the prices by manipulating the market.

The FTC will also regularly offer information related to consumer products and the market situation to the media in order to clear up any doubts among the public regarding consumer prices, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM OPPOSES PROPOSAL THAT FUTURE LEADERS SHOULD BE BORN IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that he disapproves of a proposal that future presidential candidates should be born in Taiwan, as such a move would be targeting specific persons.

Su made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to questions about the proposal by several ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang.

The DPP lawmakers' proposal was apparently aimed at pushing Ma Ying-jeou, the former KMT chairman who is widely considered the KMT's best bet for the 2008 presidential election, from the competition. Ma was born in Hong Kong.

Su, who is also a hopeful in the DPP's presidential primary, added that he also disapproves of Hsieh's recent proposal that future Taiwan presidential candidates should pass the general English proficiency test at the intermediate level.

Hsieh claimed that since the president has to represent the country's interests on many international occasions, a certain level of English-speaking ability is a must, to which Su responded that he had never heard of another country requiring their presidential candidates to have a certain degree of proficiency in a foreign language, saying that the country's president is not a tour guide.

Su said presidential candidates should have a global vision but that proficiency in English is not necessary, especially when the majority of Taiwan's diplomatic allies are not English-speaking countries.

Los Angeles TimesG State Seeks $7.4 Billion for Prisons.
Facing mounting pressure from the federal courts, legislative leaders and Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger agreed Wednesday to spend $7.4 billion on new jail and prison beds while doing more to help inmates succeed once released. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

The Moscow TimesGPutin Delivers a Hawkish Final Address
President Vladimir Putin announced Thursday that Russia would suspend its participation in a key Soviet-era arms treaty and accused foreign sponsors of financing discord in the country. [By Chang Hung kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Senate Passes Bill Seeking Iraq Exit; Veto Is Expected
The U.S. Senate on Thursday sent President Bush a US$124 billion war spending measure that he has promised to veto, forcing Democrats to begin confronting the difficult question of what to do after the president acts. The White House reaction was swift and harsh. "Eighty days after President Bush submitted his troop funding bill, the Senate has now joined the House in passing defeatist legislation," said Dana Perino, the administration spokeswoman.
Wall Street Journal: How Motorola Fell A Giant Step Behind, As It Milked Thin Phone, Rivals Sneaked Ahead On the Next Generation
A year ago, Motorola Inc. appeared headed for a third straight year of rich profits under Chief Executive Ed Zander, driven by its hit cellphone the Razr. But behind the scenes, Motorola was working furiously to get a successor phone to market by the second half of 2006, according to people familiar with the matter. When it failed to do so, profit margins on handsets narrowed and the company swung to a loss. Motorola's travails illustrate the risks for a company that rides high with a big consumer hit. Amid its success with the Razr, it fell behind on developing a phone with the next generation of technology. Missing a beat is especially hazardous in cellphones, where it can take two to three years to develop a new line.

DOC.HEADLINE: G-TELP NOT APPROVED BY CENTRAL PERSONNEL ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: The General Tests of English Language Proficiency (G-TELP) was not included in the criteria for the promotion of civil servants, an official of the Central Personnel Administration said Friday.

The official made the announcement to clarify that the information posted on the Web site of the G-TELP Co. -- the agency of G-TELP tests -- concerning their inclusion in the administration's list of promotional criteria is incorrect.
The official said the G-TELP Co. did not apply to the administration for inclusion in the criteria, nor did the administration approve all applications submitted by language test organizations.

The administration informed all language test organizations in 1996 that language tests following the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages: Learning, teaching, assessment (CEF), will be taken as qualified to examine the English proficiency of civil servants, but governing authorities will have the final say on whether or not they are adopted, the official stated.

Furthermore, according to the official, the University of California accused the American Life Learning Co. of introducing the G-TELP into Taiwan without authorization, and its issuance of certificates is an act of fraud.
The official said the administration has asked the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Economic Affairs to deal with the issue of authorization on G-TELP in order to avoid future disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST FINANCIAL HOLDING, AVIVA TO SET UP INSURANCE CO. IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's First Financial Holding Co. (FFHC) and Aviva, the largest insurance services provider in the U.K., will jointly set up a new insurance company in Taiwan in the second half of this year, an FFHC spokesman said Friday.

The currently operating Taiwanese chapter of Aviva -- the world's fifth-largest insurance group -- will have its operating licence recalled after the new insurance company is set up with a starting capital of NT$5 billion (US$150.32 million), the spokesman said.
He forecast that the new joint venture's business will grow at a rate of 10-20 percent annually and that the company will reach the break-even point in its fourth year of operations.
By 2011, the spokesman said, the joint venture will post an estimated profit of NT$130 million, with a total asset of NT$75 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG UNIVERSITY HOLDS INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON TRANSLATION

TEXT.P: The 2007 International Conference on Translation and Interpretation, organized by the Department of English of National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology, took place Friday, with some 300 people taking part.
Discussions at the conference centered around the theme, "Translation and Interpretation -- Theory, Teaching and Practice."
The one-day conference presented five speeches by professors from Taiwan and abroad.
Robin Setton, a professor of the University of Geneva who has done extensive research on interpretation and translation, gave two speeches at the conference.
He spoke on "Understanding Interpreting in Terms of a General Theory of Communication" and later on "Interpreter Training: Unavoidable Universals vs. Possible Local Adaptations."

Father Daniel Bauer, associate professor of English language and literature at Fu Jen Catholic University in Taipei County, spoke on "Cross-Cultural Problems in Short Translations of Literature," using works by Taiwanese writers Ping Lu and Tien Hsin-bin as examples.

Paul Cox, a lecturer at Fu Jen Catholic University's Graduate Institute of Translation and Interpretation Studies, gave a speech on "Fundamentals of Legal Translation for Instructors and Practioners," while Chen Pi-chu, a lecturer at National Taiwan Normal University's Graduate Institute of Translation and Interpretation, presented a paper on "The Task of the Translation Editor."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EXPLAINS REJECTION OF OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY PLAN

TEXT.P: The government's decision to refuse to allow the Olympic torch relay of the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games to pass through Taiwan was made after group discussions and not by any individual, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday.

Su said after a Legislative Yuan session that the National Security Council (NSC), the Mainland Affairs Council, the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee met to discuss the issue before deciding that the proposed route planned by China "dwarfed Taiwan's status."
The NSC then reported the decision to President Chen Shui-bian before notifying the Chinese Olympic Committee in Beijing and the International Olympic Committee (IOC), Su said.

Su insisted that China's moves of downgrading Taiwan's sovereignty in the route plan will not be accepted by the government, including a name change from the commonly used title "Chinese Taipei" to "Taipei, China" and calling the relay route from Taipei to Hong Kong a domestic route rather than an international one.
Taiwan rejected the plan to guard its sovereignty and rights as an independent sports entity in the Olympic games, Su added.
He said the government will come up with solutions to deal with the consequences following Taiwan's refusal of the route plan, such as the possibility of being denied IOC membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT RECOGNIZES TAIWAN'S EFFORTS TO IMPROVE INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan (ECCT) expressed approval Friday of the government's sincerity in making efforts to improve the investment environment.

ECCT representatives made the remarks after a two-day government-ECCT annual coordination meeting, co-chaired by Thomas M.F. Yeh, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), and ECCT Chairman Ralf Scheller.
Discussions in the meeting focused on issues listed in the ECCT 2006-2007 report of its proposals for the government.

The ECCT participants praised the authorities' efforts in the past year to answer various calls from the business organization, including those for an amendment to the Civil Aviation Act to allow liberalization of the aviation market, reinforced efforts in intellectual property rights protection and the formation of the National Communications Commission.

Yeh said the European business representatives expressed concern over the promotion of cross-Taiwan Strait trading, as well as other issues concerning whether Taiwan will remove excessive economic restrictions, accelerate the development of the service sector and build a preferential taxation system.

While some of the issues touch political concerns, the government will adopt a deliberate attitude in dealing with the ECCT's requests, Yeh said, adding that the CEPD will continue efforts to push for solutions in an open manner.

The CEPD was commissioned to serve as the coordinator between the government and foreign chambers of commerce in 1997, working to promote communication and assist foreign businesses in resolving investment problems.
According to the CEPD, there is a close bond between the Taiwanese and European trade and economic sectors, with statistics showing that bilateral trade amounted to 40 billion euros in 2006.
European Union investment in Taiwan reached US$14.6 billion last year, making it the largest foreign investor and the country's fourth-largest trade partner, according to CEPD tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS CENSURE PREMIER FOR PORK BARREL PROJECTS

TEXT.P: Three presidential hopefuls of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) issued a joint statement Friday accusing their rival, Premier Su Tseng-chang, of misusing government funds to aid his campaign and turning the pary primary into an "unfair competition."

Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Chairman Yu Shyh-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh issued the statement after the Chinese-language United Daily News reported that Su has agreed to use NT$26 billion (US$782 million) to help Tainan City and Chiayi County with construction projects.
In a rebuttal issued later in the day, Su termed the accusation "the biggest insult" to him and claimed that he has attached great importance to integrity throughout his career as a public servant.
Su said the decision to allocate funds for the two local governments was a continuation of previous central government policies.

He pointed out that the project to make a section of railway in Tainan run underground was mapped out 14 years ago, while the decision to establish an herbal science and technology park in Chiayi County was finalized in 2003.
The premier said the nation has an election almost every year and that Taiwan's construction and development cannot be put aside just because an election is going to take place.
Meanwhile, the vice president told reporters that she will withdraw from the DPP primary if President Chen Shui-bian throws his support behind any particular candidate.

Queried by reporters on which candidate would be his choice as the DPP's nominee for the 2008 presidential election, Chen did not answer directly, but replied -- apparently jokingly -- that he only supports himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY ROUTE ONCE ACCEPTED BY TAIWAN DELEGATE: BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/07 23:38:02 (By Chang Ming-kun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An official with the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games organizing committee claimed Friday that Games organizers had discussed the route for the 2008 Olympic torch relay with Taiwan's top Olympic delegate and reached a consensus on the part concerning Taiwan.

Jiang Xiaoyu, an executive deputy chairman of the Olympics, called a news conference in Beijing Friday in which he presented a copy of the minutes of a meeting in February between the Beijing Olympics organizers and Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee Chairman Thomas W. Tsai, during which a four-point consensus was reached on the torch relay route. The minutes carried Tsai's signature, Jiang added.

Jiang claimed that Tsai signed the minutes to endorse the consensus on the 2008 Olympic torch relay route, which indicated China's plan that the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing.
He called it a "breach of agreement" that some people in Taiwan are now voicing opposition to the Beijing-proposed Olympic torch relay plan.
Premier Su Tseng-chang said earlier Friday that the proposed route is unacceptable to Taiwan as the route reflects Beijing's attempt to undermine Taiwan's sovereign status.

Thomas Tsai and Yang Jong-her, Minister of Taiwan's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, also said shortly after Beijing's announcement Thursday that the torch relay route was unacceptable on the grounds that Taiwan's sovereign status would be compromised as the Beijing-proposed torch relay route purposely includes Taipei on the "domestic leg" of the relay.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO FORMAL AGREEMENT ON TORCH RELAY: CTOC CHAIR

TEXT.P: China's deliberate moves to dwarf Taiwan to the level of a province under its jurisdiction are the main reasons behind Taiwan's refusal to be included in the Olympic torch relay route for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) Chairman Thomas W. Tsai said Friday.

Tsai made the remarks after an official of the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games organizing committee claimed earlier in the day that Taiwan's snub of Beijing's offer for inclusion in the Olympic torch relay is a "breach of agreement."

Jiang Xiaoyu, an executive deputy chairman of the Olympics, called a news conference in Beijing Friday in which he presented a copy of the minutes of a meeting in February between Tsai and the Beijing Olympics organizers, during which a four-point consensus was reached on the torch relay route. The minutes carried Tsai's signature, Jiang added.

Jiang claimed that Tsai signed the minutes to endorse the consensus on the 2008 Olympic torch relay route, which indicated China's plan that the Olympic torch would travel from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City to Taipei and then continue on to Hong Kong, Macau and several other Chinese cities before arriving in the host city, Beijing.
He called it a "breach of agreement" that some people in Taiwan are now voicing opposition to the Beijing-proposed Olympic torch relay plan.

In response, Tsai said in Taipei that conference minutes were not a formal agreement. "We have never been formally committed to accepting whatever Beijing's proposal about Taiwan's role or place in the torch relay," he said.

While both sides pledged in the minutes that Taiwan should be called "Chinese Taipei" as its official designation in the IOC, Tsai said Beijing officials and Chinese journalists and media executives have typically referred to Taiwan as "Taipei, China" -- a characterization they feel makes it sound as if Taiwan were part of China.

Without elaboration, Tsai further said that over the past month, Beijing's attempts to describe Taiwan as a province under its jurisdiction have even become ever more evident in bilateral engagements.

"During the period, we have on many occasions expressed our stance and bottom line to Beijing. Without Beijing's positive response to our request and for the sake of safeguarding our sovereign status and national dignity, we sent a letter to Beijing April 20 expressing our decision to reject the Beijing-proposed Ho Chi Minh City-Taipei-Hong Kong relay route," Tsai said.

In an April 24 response to Tsai, the Beijing Olympic Committee failed to promise to improve its attitude toward Taiwan and make an adjustment to the relay route. As a result, Tsai said, Taiwan felt compelled to turn down Beijing's route arrangement.
"It's now up to Beijing to decide whether to change the route to have the torch arrive in Taiwan via a third country and leave via another third country," he added.
Premier Su Tseng-chang said earlier in the day that the proposed route is unacceptable to Taiwan as the route reflects Beijing's attempt to undermine Taiwan's sovereign status.

As a matter of fact, Chinese officials have never hestitated to claim in public that Taipei, Hong Kong and Macau are "overseas Chinese cities" and that their inclusion in the torch relay should not be regarded as "international route."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, May 28, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: French physician and revolutionary Joseph Ignace Guillotin is born. He developed the execution device which was so heavily used during the "reign of terror" in the French revolution that it would later bear his name.
1754: George Washington, then in the service of the British Crown, destroys a French regiment under Jumonville near Uniontown, Penn., in the first battle of the French-Indian Wars.
1759: English statesman William Pitt the Younger is born. He became prime minister at the age of 24, the youngest-ever British prime minister.
1912: Patrick White, the Australian novelist who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1973, is born.
1934: Cecilie, Emilie, Marie, Annette and Yvonne Dionne are born to Olivia Dionne in Callender, Canada. They are the world's first surviving quintuplets.
1932: Dutch engineers complete the world's biggest dam, a major victory in their 900-year battle to push back the sea. The new dam, or dike, is 29 km long and turns the Zuider Zee into a vast freshwater lake, called the Ijsselmeer.
1933: Chinese Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang revolts at Kalgan Pass, near Changkiakow, capital of China's Chahar Province.
1956: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh informs Philippine Ambassador Narciso Ramos that the ROC has full sovereignty over the Nansha, or Spratly Islands.
1959: The United States launches its Jupiter rocket into space with two monkeys aboard. The monkeys return to earth safely, opening the way for manned space flight.
1966: Construction of Taiwan's Northern Cross-Island Highway is completed. An inauguration ceremony is held at Tahsi, Taoyuan County.
1966: The Cultural Revolution begins in mainland China after the central committee of the Chinese Communist Party sets up a "central cultural revolution group" to lead the movement.
1967: Francis Chichester, a 65-year-old British yachtsman, receives a hero's welcome when he arrives in Plymouth 119 days after setting out on a solo round- the-world trip.
1972: The Duke of Windsor, the British king who abdicated to marry American divorcee Wallis Simpson, dies in Paris at the age of 77.
1974: The Pacific-Asian Congress of Municipalities opens its third conference in Taipei.
1978: Chiang Ching-kuo, who was sworn in as the 6th president of the ROC on May 20, tells Reader's Digest that "our interests and those of America cannot be divided. If we stick together, both will benefit. If we go our separate ways, both will suffer. In any case, the Republic of China will persist."
1981: The ROC Executive Yuan approves Premier Sun Yun-suan's appointment of Konsin Shah as ambassador to the Republic of Uruguay and Loh I-cheng as ambassador to the Republic of Guatemala.
1982: Pope John Paul II arrives in Britain for the first papal visit to Britain since 1531.
1985: President Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs protests an Argentine gunboat attack on an unarmed ROC trawler in the seas off the Falkland Islands that left one dead, one missing, and six injured.
1987: Mathias Rust, a West German teenager, flies his Cessna light plane from Helsinki to Moscow and lands in Red Square, evading the entire Soviet air defense system. Both the Soviet defense minister and the air defense commander were sacked as a result of the prank.
1989: The Ching Kuo, the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, successfully completes its first test flight.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks the Russian Far East oil-producing town of Neftegorsk on Sakhalin Island, killing more than 1,980 people.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus is the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such a level of relations with the ROC.
1998: Pakistan conducts five nuclear test blasts and declares a state of emergency, triggering economic sanctions by Japan and the United States.
2000: Taiwan's Tseng Hsin-feng wins Japan's three-day Kosaido Ladies' Golf Tournament in the Tokyo suburb of Ichihara.
2001: The New Taiwan dollar plunges three percent, or 1.0005 against the U.S. dollar to close at 34.5 on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange market.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men of totally different principles can never act together."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. BID UNDER NAME OF TAIWAN `DIFFICULT': EX-FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 27 (CNA) 04/28/07 12:45:52 (By Jaw-Pyng Hwang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's bid to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" involves great difficulty, a former Republic of China minister of foreign affairs said Friday.

Addressing the issue during a conference titled "Taiwan and Its Contexts" held at Yale University, Fredrick Chien said the ROC has been "unfairly and unreasonably" ignored by the international community since its seat at the United Nations was replaced by the People's Republic of China in 1971.

While promoting a campaign to re-enter the United Nations over the past 14 years, Taiwan has not tried to challenge Beijing's representation at the United Nations but has emphasized the "unfairness" of the world organization excluding Taiwan, Chien said.

According to Chien, "it will be a very difficult matter" if Taiwan is to apply for U.N. membership under the name of "Taiwan" because Taiwan must be a "new country" in order to enter the United Nations as a new member, which brings up the issue of declaring independence.

In addition, Chien pointed out, any application for new U.N. membership is required to obtain the unanimous consent of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council -- one of which is China.
Therefore, "there will be a very big problem" if Taiwan is to apply to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan" this September, he said.

Meanwhile, analyzing the democratic development of Taiwan at the conference, Chu Yun-han, a professor of political science at National Taiwan University, said the problems of partisan struggle and split national identity in Taiwan are not expected to be resolved in the near future.

While the people hinged high expectations on President Chen Shui-bian when he was elected in 2000 and again in 2004, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has failed to obtain a majority status in the Legislative Yuan in the past two legislative elections, Chu noted.
Despite this fact, the DPP has refused to relinquish the right to appoint the premier, resulting in a continuation of confrontation between the ruling and opposition camps, Chu said.
