DOC.HEADLINE: 7.5-9.5% MINIMUM WAGE HIKE EXCEEDS `ACCEPTABLE RANGE': MOEA

TEXT.P: The minimum monthly wage adjustment range recommended by a wage review committee goes beyond the level acceptable to bosses, Economics Minister Steve R.L. Chen said Saturday.

Chen made the remarks after the wage review panel under the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) recommended the day before that the minimum monthly wage be raised by 7.5 percent to 9.5 percent, pending final approval by the Executive Yuan.

Chen said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has been in close contact with major industrial and business associations and senior business executives in the past few weeks in the hope of winning their support for a hike in the minimum wage.

"After difficult negotiations, they have finally agreed to a maximum 5 percent hike. Perhaps, a 6 percent hike is a barely tolerable ceiling. The recommended figures go far beyond the range bosses are willing to pay," Chen said.

Noting that franchised stores, small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and micro-businesses are usually most vulnerable to a minimum wage hike, Chen said the ministry will step up communications with various business associations to seek their support.

Moreover, Chen said, the ministry will flesh out various complementary packages of measures to help the industrial and business community weather challenges that may arise from the impending wage hikes.

Among the measures in contemplation are offering soft loans through the SME Development Fund as well as organizing on-the-job manpower training programs to help small- and medium-sized enterprises upgrade productivity and competitiveness, Chen said.
CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan chaired a meeting of the wage review committee Friday to discuss the issue.

Lee said the 22 members on the panel -- comprised of representatives from employers' associations, labor unions, academics and government officials -- came to a compromise after more than three hours of heated debate and intensive consultations.

While labor groups sought a steep 20 percent hike in the minimum monthly wage in light of soaring living costs and a 10-year freeze of the minimum wage level, employer representatives attempted to limit the rise to between 5 percent and 6 percent.
Lee said that the conference goers settled the proposed hike at a range between 7.5 percent and 9.5 percent after using the 7.5 percent increase in the consumer price index over the past decade.
An estimated 1.7 million low-wage workers are expected to benefit from the adjustment, Lee said.
At Friday's meeting, the panel also decided to change the formula for calculating wages for part-time workers whose average wage per hour will rise to between NT$93 and NT$95 from the current NT$66.
Lee said the CLA will submit the package to the Cabinet for a final review. "We are hopeful that the wage hike can be implemented from July 1," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REBUTS BEIJING'S ACCUSATION ABOUT OLYMPIC TORCH CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's refusal to be included in the Beijing-proposed route for next year's Olympic torch relay is an issue of "sovereignty" and "respect" rather than of "credibility or routing," a senior official said Saturday.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun made the remarks after Beijing Organizing Committee for the 2008 Olympic Games (BOCOG) Vice President Jiang Xiaoyu accused Taiwan the day before of "breach of commitment" by reneging on a previous agreement to host a leg of next year's Olympic torch relay.
Jiang said he was surprised at Taiwan's snub of China's proposal that the Olympic flame would arrive in Taipei from Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam before heading to China-controlled Hong Kong and Macau.
Jiang claimed that the BOCOG had been discussing the relay issue with Taiwan sports officials since November and received a letter detailing Taipei's agreement to the route March 27.
However, Liu rebutted Jiang's claim by elaborating on the negotiation process over the torch relay.

Liu said that on Feb. 12, Taiwan's Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) Chairman Thomas W. Tsai traveled to Beijing to meet with his Chinese counterpart and was given a briefing on the torch relay route. Tsai was told that the Olympic torch would be entering Taipei from Vietnam before leaving for Hong Kong.

Tsai presented Beijing's proposal to the government authorities, and on March 27, Tsai sent a letter to BOCOG saying the CTOC would not object to the plan as long as China refrains from using it to belittle Taiwan.

Over the past month, Liu claimed, Beijing has changed its tune. "We have discovered that China started spreading propaganda claiming that Taiwan would be the Olympic torch's first leg on the `interior route.' Worse still, China has typically referred to Taiwan as `Taipei, China' instead of using its formal designation in the International Olympic Committee (IOC) of `Chinese Taipei, '" he added.

According to Liu, Olympic committees on both sides of the Taiwan Strait reached a consensus in 1989 that Taiwan should be addressed as "Chinese Taipei" when it takes part in IOC-sponsored competitions and activities in China.
Regrettably, Liu said, Chinese officials and media personalities have not observed that accord while talking about the 2008 Olympics-related activities.

Against this backdrop, Liu said, the CTOC sent a letter to Beijing again April 20 protesting its abuse of the torch relay route for political manipulation and stressing that Taiwan could not accept China's attempt to downgrade its sovereign status.

To avoid a situation in which the Olympic torch might be described as traveling from "Taipei, China" to "Hong Kong, China, " Liu said the CTOC requested in its April 20 letter that the flame enter and exit Taiwan via third countries.
"However, Beijing ignored our request and announced the route Thursday, " Liu said, adding that Taiwan was surprised at Beijing's announcement.
For the sake of safeguarding Taiwan's sovereignty and national dignity, Liu said, Taiwan must reject the Beijing-dictated torch relay route.

In the process, Liu said, the CTOC has approached the IOC for assistance, calling attention to Taiwan's plight that Beijing is deliberately attempting to belittle Chinese Taipei -- an independent member of the IOC -- as an integral part of China.
At the moment, Liu said, Taiwan will not rule out the possibility of hosting a leg of the relay, although it requires further discussion.

The Olympic flame has come to Taiwan only once -- in 1964 for the Tokyo Olympic Games. President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that Beijing should consider the relay route that Japan used in 1964, which entailed having the flame travel to Taiwan from a third country and then passing it on to another third country.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEARNING-ORIENTED SOCIETY FORMING THANKS TO COMMUNITY COLLEGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is becoming a learning-oriented society, attributed to a mushrooming of community colleges around the country over the years, former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday.
Ma made the remarks at a national community colleges conference, a two-day event that kicked off Saturday at Ling Tung University in the central city of Taichung.

Representatives of over 100 community colleges around the country attended the annual conference, organized by the Taichung City Bureau of Education and the National Association for the Promotion of Community University, for talks on the development of informal education.
Ma, also a former chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, cited cases in Taipei to point out the popularity of community education.
Institutes offering such opportunities have become one of the key learning channels in Taiwan, he added.
Ma also noted that a community college can act better than formal colleges and universities in promoting coherence of community commonsense and arousing community vitality.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMALL, MEDIUM ENTERPRISES COMPLAIN ABOUT PROPOSED MINIMUM WAGE HIKE

TEXT.P: A recommended minimum monthly wage hike of 7.5 percent to 9.5 percent goes beyond the level acceptable to bosses, the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises said Saturday.

Association President Lin Ping-pin made the remarks one day after the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) convened a wage review committee to decide the level of adjustment, which will be sent to the Executive Yuan for approval. CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan noted that since the consumer price index has risen by 7.5 percent over the past decade and the minimum monthly wage has not increased at all in the same period, the hike should be at least 7.5 percent.
Lin said the increase is higher that the maximum level of 5 percent acceptable to bosses.

Lin argued that while the consumer price index has "only" risen by 7.5 percent, the shortened working hours and a new labor pension system that was put into practice last July have incurred a 30 percent increase in expenses for employers.
He claimed that many small- and medium-sized enterprises will have to close if there is a 7.5 percent minimum wage increase and that if they do, jobs will also decrease.

Under the new pension system, employers must deposit at least 6 percent of an employee's salary into their pension account each month, which the employees can carry with them whenever they change jobs. Under the old system, an employee would get his or her pension after working for 25 consecutive years for the same enterprise or when they reached the age of 55 years and had worked for the same company for 15 consecutive years.
Also under the old system, employees would receive their pension in one lump sum, while under the new system, retired workers are eligible to receive a monthly pension for the rest of their lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY SHOWS FIRST SIGN OF GROWTH IN 9 MONTHS

TEXT.P: The monitoring indicators for Taiwan's economic climate flashed a green light for March, signalling steady growth, according to a report released Friday by the Council for Economic Development and Planning (CEPD).
The total monitoring score gained four points from 19 in February to 23 in March, with the indicators turning from yellow-blue that indicated a slowdown in February, CEPD officials said.
The change marked the first green light for the last nine months since May 2006, the official said.
Among the nine component indicators, three showed improvement, namely bank clearings and remittances, exports and industrial production, they said.
The composite index of leading indicators -- a barometer for the economy's outlook in the coming three months -- stood at 109.4 in March, up 0.9 percent from the month-earlier level, they said.

Among the seven indicators comprising the composite index, six made positive contributions, including new orders for the manufacturing sector, customs- cleared exports, money supply M1B, wholesale price change from six months earlier, average work hours in the manufacturing sector and stock prices, according to the CEPD.
The index of coincident indicators, which represents the current economic situation, registered 110.2 in March, up 1.1 percent from February, the officials said.

Among the six indicators making up the index, five made positive contributions, including bank clearings, manufacturing production, industrial production, manufacturing sales and average monthly earnings of manufacturing workers, they said.
Meanwhile, a CEPD survey of manufacturers in March indicated that 14 percent of the respondents expected conditions to improve over the next three months, down from 29 percent in a February survey.

A total of 13 percent of the respondents predicted that conditions will be worse, up from 8 percent in the previous month, while 73 percent said they think conditions will remain the same, up from 63 percent in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The appeal court of Turin sentenced Anna Maria Franzoni Friday to 16 years in prison. Franzoni was charged with murdering her own three-year-old child in 2002. She was sentenced to 24 years in jail by a lower court.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HAS EXPLAINED GOVERNMENT'S STANCE IN TORCH RELAY

TEXT.P: Officials of the Government Information Office (GIO) said Saturday that they have informed the world press regarding Taiwan's refusal to be included in China's "domestic route" in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Game's torch relay.
The officials said that in order to clarify Taiwan's stance, GIO personnel informed the world's major media as soon as Taipei decided to reject being included in the 2008 Olympic torch relay route.

The Chinese Olympics organizers announced Thursday that Taipei would be included as a leg in the torch relay's "domestic" route. According to Beijing's announcement, the Olympic torch would arrive in Taipei from Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam before heading to the China-controlled areas of Hong Kong and Macau.

While unveiling the route, Jiang Xiaoyu, executive vice president of the Beijing Olympic organizing committee, referred to Taipei alongside with Hong Kong and Macau as "overseas Chinese cities, " a description that downgrades Taiwan's sovereign status.
Taipei, indignant at being "downgraded" to the level of a Chinese province, insisted that the Olympic torch must enter and depart Taiwan via a country other than China.

According to information collected by GIO personnel stationed around the world, a total of 25 major news media had reported the issue, with Japanese media accounting for the largest coverage, followed by other Asian media.

GIO officials said the majority of the world news media had reported objectively on the Taiwan government's stance and the situation between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, and that few made any editorial comments. An AP report said the episode underscores the deep mistrust between Taipei and Beijing.
Due to the objective coverage of the issue, there has been no damage to Taiwan's image related to its rejection of the torch relay, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T WILL NOT INTERFERE IN CIVIC CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will not interfere in civic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, but insists that such exchanges be conducted under the law and that issues involving public rights and power be dealt with by the government, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan said Saturday.
Tung made the declaration at a Taiwan Thinktank conference while talking about a high-profile Beijing forum hosted by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC).

The two-day cross-strait economic, trading and cultural forum opened earlier in the day in Beijing, with KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan and CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao attending the opening ceremony. It is the third forum of its kind since they began in 2005.

Commenting on the event, Tung said the conclusions from the forum will still serve as nothing but a channel of propaganda for the KMT and CPC, as the forum will have no direct dialogue between government officials.
However, he also said Beijing often takes advantage of the forum's informal conclusions in an attempt to sow dissent in Taiwan.

Expressing hope that Beijing will stop disturbing Taiwan's politics and delaying real cross-strait talks, Tung said there are several issues on which authorized talks are currently taking place. The two sides could reach agreement on the issues eventually if they continue negotiations, he noted.
Tung also reiterated the government's determination to maintain the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and Taiwan's democratic system, as well as the hopes of the Taiwan people for cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES RESTRAINT AMONG PRESIDENTIAL ASPIRANTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Saturday the four presidential aspirants of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to "show restraint" lest they damage party solidarity.
The president made the remarks after visiting ailing Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu at Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital. The mayor was hospitalized Thursday due to high blood pressure.

With the presidential primary set to begin next month, the spats among the hopefuls -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun -- have grown fiercer. Lu, Hsieh and Yu convened a joint news conference Friday accusing Su of misusing the national resources to aid his campaign, which Su angrily denied.
The president expressed the hope for a "positive competition, " saying that elections are "transient" and urging the hopefuls to take the primary "in their stride."
"They must show restraint even when attacking their rivals," he said, lest the wounds become too big to heal completely.
On the question of who he will support, he said all four are excellent candidates but that he will maintain neutrality without favoring any specific ones.

He said the true rival of the DPP is not within the party itself, or Ma Ying- jeou, former chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, but China, which has relentlessly obstructed Taiwan in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19% OF TAIWAN PEOPLE HAVE FOOD ALLERGIES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: As many as 19 percent of people in Taiwan are allergic to certain kinds of food, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

The survey, released during an annual meeting of the Taiwan Pediatric Association held in Taipei, was conducted by the Taipei Veterans General Hospital, the Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital, the Tri-Service General Hospital, the Taichung Veterans General Hospital, the Kaohsiung General Hospital and the Tzu-chi Buddhist General Hospital.

Among the more-than 30,000 people surveyed by the hospitals, 13 percent of those 0-3 years of age, 20 percent of those 6-12 years of age and 17 percent of adults have food allergies, the survey shows.
The survey found that chicken, eggs, milk, mangoes and peanuts, as well as shellfish such as crabs, clams and shrimps, are the most common kinds of allergy-causing foods.
There are also people who are allergic to cod and cuttlefish, according to the survey.

Yao Tzung-chieh, a pediatrician at Chang Gung Children's Hospital, noted that symptoms of food allergies can include itchy skin, rashes, abdominal pain and diarrhea, and he urged people who display the symptoms but have had no idea of the source of their allergies to receive allergy tests, available at most hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE DIET DELEGATION TO INSPECT HIGH-SPEED RAIL SYSTEM
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/07 16:55:03 (By Yang Ming-chu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A parliamentary delegation from Japan will arrive in Taiwan in early May to inspect the country's first high-speed railway, built partly on a model from Japan's Shinkansen system.
The 15-member delegation, led by Hisaoki Kamei, secretary-general of the Japanese People's New Party, will depart for Taipei May 2-3.

It will be the first time members of both the Japanese House of Representatives and House of Councillors will have formed a delegation to congratulate Taiwan since the high-speed railway began full operations in early March.
The system, which uses electrical machinery equipment and coaches from the Shinkansen system, has received much attention in Japan.
Political observers said the delegation's visit is expected to elevate further the profile of the 345-km railway in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEDIATRIC ONCOLOGIST RECEIVES LIFETIME CONTRIBUTION AWARD

TEXT.P: Lin Kuo-hsin, founder of the Children's Cancer Foundation of Taiwan, was awarded Saturday for his lifetime contributions to medical care for children suffering from cancer.

Lin was one of eight pediatrician and pediatric nurse specialists presented with "Taiwan Medical Contribution Awards" by the non-profit Juei Hsin Children's Medical Care Foundation and the Taiwan Pediatric Association.

Lin, a retired pediatric oncologist from the prestigious National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH), is also the founder of the Taiwan Thalassemia Association. Currently serving as chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese Blood Services Foundation, Lin is recognized as the man who built a medical care environment in Taiwan for young cancer patients to enjoy proper medical treatment, according to the award organizers.

Two decades ago, only a third of young cancer patients could get proper medical care in Taiwan, but now the number has increased to more than 80 percent, the organizers said, attributing this achievement to Lin.
Commenting on the award, Lin said he only did his duty.

Other award recipients included NTUH blood oncologist Lin Tung-tsan, pediatrician Lin Hsiu-chuan of the Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University Hospital, pediatrician Chou Kuo-ying of the Cardinal Tien Hospital, NTUH pediatrician Lu Meng-yiu and allergist Yiao Chung-chie of the Chang Gung Children's Hospital, NTUS charge nurse Fang Kuei-ling for pediatric care, and charge nurse Fang Huei-chen at the newborn intensive care wards in the Kaohsiung Medical University's Chung Ho Memorial Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REGRETS ATTACKS BY PARTY RIVALS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday that he regrets the attacks on him by his three rivals in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) primary for the 2008 presidential election.

The premier, one of the frontrunners in the primary, made the remarks while attending a clam festival in Yunlin County a day after Vice President Annette Lu, former Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, held a news conference to accuse Su of misusing national resources to aid his campaign. Su angrily denied the accusation.
He described the "pork barrel" accusation from his rivals as lamentable, saying he would only have expected such a slur from the main opposition Kuomintang.
He said the DPP supporters do not want to see internal strife in the party and added that only solidarity within the party is needed.

Meanwhile, Hsieh told a supporters' group that "a fair" primary is crucial to ensure that all aspirants can gladly accept the outcome. The primary will consist of a member vote May 6 and a series of public opinion polls before it announces the candidate later that month.

Lu continued to question if President Chen Shui-bian is favoring any specific hopeful prior to the primary, saying that Chen should "make his stance clear" as "integrity is crucial for a national leader."
In fact, President Chen has on a number of recent occasions clearly and unequivocally professed his neutrality as regards the DPP aspirants.
Meanwhile, Wang Toh, a party whip of the DPP in the legislature, accused all four aspirants of campaigning as if they have lost their senses as the primary draws near.
"They should calm down, otherwise the DPP will have no hope of winning the presidential election next year," he added.
Former DPP Legislator Lin Cho-shui also said that the attacks on the premier by his three rivals have DPP supporters worried.

He also said DPP acting Chairman Trong Chai should refrain from attending news conferences of the hopefuls Friday, saying that he should observe decorum as a chairman instead of interfering in an election.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TAX, HOUSE TAX CAN BE PAID AT CONVENIENCE STORES

TEXT.P: Taxpayers can now pay their business tax and house tax at designated convenience stores from this year if payment due does not exceed NT$20,000 (US$602) , Taipei National Tax Administration officials said Saturday.
The business tax will be collected from May 1-10 and the house tax will be collected from May 1-31, the officials said.
They said more than 29,000 small businesses with a turnover of below NT$200,000 per month in Taipei now see their business taxes amount to no more than NT$20,000.
The stores that can collect payments include Hi-Life, Family Mart, Nikomart, 7-Eleven and OK, which have a total of more than 8,000 outlets around the country, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS OLYMPIC TORCH BUT NOT CHINA'S DOWNGRADING: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan said Saturday that Taiwan would welcome the passage of the Olympic torch through the country but rejects the intention of China downgrading Taiwan to the level of one of its provinces.
Tung made the remarks at a seminar held in Taipei on the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Tung said it is an honor for Olympic member nations to have the torch pass through their countries and that Taiwan would like to share this honor.
However, he added, Taiwan opposes Beijing's political intervention in sports affairs and the torch relay route proposed by Beijing.
The Olympics organizers announced Thursday that Taipei would be included as a leg on the torch relay's "domestic" route.
According to Beijing's announcement, the Olympic torch would arrive in Taipei from Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam before heading to the China-controlled areas of Hong Kong and Macau.

Announcing the route, Jiang Xiaoyu, executive vice president of the Beijing Olympic organizing committee, referred to Taipei, Hong Kong and Macau as "overseas Chinese cities, " a description that downgrades Taiwan's sovereign status.
An indignant Taipei insisted that the Olympic torch must enter and depart Taiwan via a country other than China.

Tung noted that the Taiwan government has stated repeatedly that the torch arrangement should adopt the Olympic courtesy by obtaining the approval of the country through which the torch is scheduled to travel.
According to Tung, Beijing Olympic Games organizing committee has since March 2005 included Taiwan in China's "domestic route" for the torch relay.

In addition, Chinese officials and journalists have repeatedly referred to Taiwan as "Taipei, China, " which Tung said violates the agreement reached between the Chinese Olympic Committee and the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee in 1989, in which both sides agreed to use "Chinese Taipei" when referring to Taiwanese sports teams when they visit China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS FOR MORE SCOPE FOR EASY CARDS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin called for the central government's support for the city's plan to transform the Easy Card into a kind of electronic money that can be used at gas stations, convenience stores, or to pay for entrance to the City Zoo.

Hau made the call at an activity hosted by the Taipei Smart Card Corp. to celebrate breaking the 9 million mark for issuance of the multi-purpose IC cards for Taipei's mass rapid transport system, buses and parking lots.

Hau expressed approval of the company's efforts, which have made Easy Card the largest-circulation card of its kind in Taiwan, and the sixth-largest among Asian cities. He said that in the near future when the cable car between the zoo and the Maokung tea-production area in the Mucha district is inaugurated, people can also use the card to pay for the cable car and for visits to the zoo.

The city government has also been working with the Taipei County, Keelung City and Taoyuan County in an effort to expand Easy Card applications to public transport all over northern Taiwan, Hau added, noting that the city government has also begun efforts to encourage the railway and high-speed railway system operators to adopt the card.

In the celebration, professional tennis players Chan Yung-jan and Chuang Chia- jung, who reached the finals in the women's doubles in the Australia Open earlier this year, touted the smart card and hosted a charity auction for limited edition Easy Cards carrying their images.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHI CHARITY FOUNDATION TO CELEBRATE 41ST ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation will hold a series of activities in May to mark the 41st anniversary of its inception, foundation officials announced Saturday.
Tzu Chi, a non-profit organization founded in 1966 by Dharma Master Cheng Yen, has come to prominence because of the relief aid it has provided to many corners of the world.

According to Tzu Chi officials, in addition to the foundation's missions of charity, medicine, education and culture, Tzu Chi volunteers have spared no efforts in education on recycling over the years. In 2003 alone, Tzu Chi's 40,000 volunteers helped recycle 123,000 tons of garbage in Taiwan.

Responding to the issue of global warming, Tzu Chi will also hold a two-week large-scale exhibition from May 6 in front of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to arouse the public's environmental protection awareness.

In addition, the philanthropic group will hold several activities around Taiwan on Mother's Day, May 13, to wash the image of Buddha, a ceremony traditionally held on his birthday, and at the same time express appreciation to mothers around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS TO BEGIN QUESTIONING FUND USE OF DPP BIGWIGS

TEXT.P: Several audit and cashier officials handling the "special allowance fund" of several prominent figures of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will be questioned next week in a probe into alleged misuse of the fund, a special investigation panel under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Saturday.
Chen Yun-nan, director of the panel, said that since those cases were assigned to two teams of prosecutors earlier this month, the prosecutors have been examining related evidence.
"The prosecutors have yet to summon any of the defendants to explain their fund use," Chen said.

The indictment of former Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who used to enjoy a reputation as "Mr. Clean" until his indictment for alleged embezzlement of his "special allowance fund" this February, has triggered a debate on the nature of the fund given to senior officials around the country for their discretionary use, a practice that has been going on for decades without anyone's questioning.

Prosecutor Hou Kuan-jen alleged that Ma misused half of the fund that went directly into his personal banking accounts during his two-term mayorship between 1998 and 2006. The indictment forced Ma to resign from the chairmanship of the main opposition Kuomintang. Ma, who has denied any wrongdoing, has registered to represent the party in the 2008 presidential election.

But another prosecutor in Tainan, in a similar probe of the "special allowance fund" for Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, dropped the case last month, saying that half of the "special allowance fund" that went directly to the mayor's banking accounts was an "actual subsidy."
The Supreme Prosecutors Office will convene a meeting of the prosecutors in early May to decide a coherent interpretation on the nature of the fund, Chen said.

But he also said the panel will investigate each case based on facts and evidence and that the consensus reached at the meeting will only be used as a reference and will not affect the probe into the current cases.

All dossiers related to the alleged misuse of the fund of the DPP bigwigs were turned over from the now defunct anti-corruption center to the special investigation panel, which was formally inaugurated April 2.

The panel also formally began probes April 14 into alleged discretionary fund misuse cases involving the four DPP aspirants for the next presidency -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh. Their cases were assigned to three prosecutors -- Hou Kuan-jen, Shen Ming-lun and Chou Shih-yu.
Hou's team will also handle a similar case involving another DPP bigwig -- National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen.

The case involving Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng's alleged misappropriation of the "special allowance funds" budgeted for his discretionary use will be handled by three prosecutors -- Chu Chao-liang, Wu Wen-chung and Lee Hai-lung. Chu is the prosecutor who cleared the Tainan mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONUMENT UNVEILED TO COMMEMORATE FOREIGN WORKERS WHO DIE ON JOB

TEXT.P: A memorial monument was unveiled by the Taipei municipal government at the city's Sports Park Saturday to commemorate foreign workers who died on the job.

Addressing the unveiling ceremony, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said many of the city's landmark buildings and public facilities, including Taipei 101 Tower and the Metro mass rapid transit system, were completed with the assistance of many foreign laborers.

"Without their contributions, Taipei could not have developed its modern urban style so quickly. Over the years, their sweat and labor have helped enhance our city's beauty, grandeur, breadth and depth," Hau said emotionally, adding that the city government has built the monument to express its gratitude for all foreign workers who have sacrificed their lives in their work for Taiwan's progress.

The monument, dedicated to commemorate all foreign workers who died from workplace accidents since 1991, is engraved with grateful words in many Asian languages that read: "These venerable workers dedicate their precious lives. They will be remembered by all city dwellers forever."

The city government invited Buddhist monks from Thailand to perform religious rituals and an Indonesian choir from the Bread of Life Christian Church to sing hymns in praise of the God and pray for the souls of all deceased foreign workers at the ceremony.

The heads of representative offices of the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam were also invited to attend the monument unveiling ceremony. They joined Hau and other city government officials in laying wreaths at the memorial monument.

According to Hau, Taipei now have more than 36,000 foreign workers, most of whom work as caregivers or family helpers. Only a small portion of them work in the manufacturing and construction sectors, with Thais accounting for the largest ratio of these two categories of foreign workers.

A total of 26 foreign workers have died from workplace accidents in Taipei City since 1991, city officials said, adding that the city government will step up workplace security inspection, education and publicity in order to minimize workplace deaths and injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Proposal Would Allow Oil Drilling Off Virginia. Five- Year Plan Would Also Open Alaskan, Gulf Waters.
The Interior Department will announce a proposal Monday to allow oil and gas drilling in federal waters near Virginia that are currently off-limits and permit new exploration in Alaska's Bristol Bay and the Gulf of Mexico, according to people who have seen or been told about drafts of the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:The White House Scales Back Talk of Iraq Progress
The Bush administration will not try to assess whether the troop increase in Iraq is producing signs of political progress or greater security until September, and many of Mr. Bushs top advisers now anticipate that any gains by then will be limited, according to senior administration officials.
In interviews over the past week, the officials made clear that the White House is gradually scaling back its expectations for the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. The timelines they are now discussing suggest that the White House may maintain the increased numbers of American troops in Iraq well into next year.
Wall Street Journal:The Debt Collector vs. The Widow
Heart surgery halted Viola Sue Kell's work sewing carpets in a rug mill in 2001. It was the end of 40 years of cleaning motel rooms, restaurant jobs, "just hard stuff," says Mrs. Kell, a 64-year -old widow. She applied for Social Security disability, and her monthly $827 benefit now is her only income.
But when Mrs. Kell tried to pay her mortgage and electric bills in 2004, her checks bounced. Every cent of the Social Security check, which went straight to her bank each month, had been taken by a debt collector that had garnished her bank account.That's not supposed to happen, but the practice is widespread and exacerbated by direct deposit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM ON '3RD COUNTRY IN, 3RD COUNTRY OUT' STANCE: NCPFS

TEXT.P: The government remains firm on its stance that the Olympic torch for the 2008 Beijing Olympics should enter and exit Taiwan both via a third country if China would include the island on the flame's relay route, an official said Saturday.

Chou Jui, head of the office of the minister of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) , made the remarks after International Olympic Committee (IOC) Chairman Jacques Rogge was quoted as having said in India earlier in the day that he hopes Taiwan and China can settle their disputes over the torch relay route through consultations.
Beijing announced next year's Olympic torch relay route Thusday, in which Taipei would be the 21st stop, behind Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City and before China- controlled area of Hong Kong.
Within hours of Beijing's announcement, Taiwan explicitly rejected the Vietnam-Taiwan-Hong Kong route, saying it implied Taiwan was part of China.

Rogge refrained from giving direct comments on the dispute during his visit in India Saturday. He instead said that the dust has not yet settled and that he looks forward to seeing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reach an agreement on the issue through further talks.
Responding to press inquiries about the NCPFS' views on Rogge's remarks, Chou said the council cannot make any comment until after getting full information about the IOC's position on the dispute.
But he added that one thing is certain that the government will stick to its gun that the Olympic torch to be acceptable to Taiwan must follow a "third country- Taiwan-third country" route.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan said earlier in the day that Taiwan would welcome the passage of the Olympic torch through its territory but reject the intention of China downgrading Taiwan to the level of one of its provinces. The MAC charts Taiwan's policy toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REPLACE ENVOY TO HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The government has decided to name Yang Jia-jiun, director of the Department of Legal Affairs under the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), to serve as Taiwan's new representative to Hong Kong, a senior official said Saturday.
Yang will replace Pao Cheng-kang, who will reach his full retirement age soon, said the official who preferred anonymity.

Because of the complexity in Taiwan's relations with China and Hong Kong, Taiwan's representative to Hong Kong is referred to in Taiwan as director of the MAC's Hong Kong Affairs Bureau and in Hong Kong as managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service.

According to the MAC official, the council already referred the personnel replacement plan to the Cabinet for approval. If all goes well, Yang's job transfer plan will be formalized soon. Nevertheless, it remains unclear when Yang can get a work permit from Hong Kong authorities.
It took Pao six months to get a working visa from the Hong Kong government, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 29, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1429: French military leader and heroine Joan of Arc enters Orleans, France, and defeats English forces. She was later tried for heresy and witchcraft and was burned at the stake in Rouen.
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1667: John Arbuthnot, Scottish physician and writer, is born. He was noted for his satirical anti-Whig pamphlets published in 1712 as "Law Is a Bottomless Pit" and later retitled "The History of John Bull."
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1818: Alexander II, the czar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is born. He was assassinated in 1881 after severe repression of political opposition.
1863: William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper and magazine publisher, is born. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire, comprised of 28 major newspapers.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo- Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a "Resist Russia" volunteer corps.
1937: American chemist Wallace Hume Carothers commits suicide just two months after he patented nylon.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: U.S. forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi death camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1948: Li Tsung-jen is elected vice president of the Republic of China in the republic's fourth ballot.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, the incumbent minister of finance.
1975: The last U.S. troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopter from the roof of the American embassy.
1976: Edward Y. Kuan, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs, is named by the Executive Yuan as first ambassador to South Africa.
1976: The Sino-U.S. Seminar on Food Science and Nutrition opens in Taipei with 24 food scientists attending.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the silver screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang cross-strait talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second round of talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.
1998: North Korea publishes an open letter by its leader Kim Jong-Il calling for unification with South Korea.
2000: Premier-designate Tang Fei checks out of Taipei Veterans General Hospital after fully recovering from surgery removing a benign thymoma on April 16.
2001: The Ministry of National Defense says that in accordance with relevant government laws, military generals on active service will not be allowed to travel to mainland China either for meetings or visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REPLACE ENVOY TO HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The government has decided to name Yang Jia-jiun, director of the Department of Legal Affairs under the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , to serve as Taiwan's new representative to Hong Kong, a senior official said Saturday.
Yang will replace Pao Cheng-kang, who will reach his full retirement age soon, said the official who preferred anonymity.

Because of the complexity in Taiwan's relations with China and Hong Kong, Taiwan's representative to Hong Kong is referred to in Taiwan as director of the MAC's Hong Kong Affairs Bureau and in Hong Kong as managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service.

According to the MAC official, the council already referred the personnel replacement plan to the Cabinet for approval. If all goes well, Yang's job transfer plan will be formalized soon. Nevertheless, it remains unclear when Yang can get a work permit from Hong Kong authorities.
It took Pao six months to get a working visa from the Hong Kong government, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM ON '3RD COUNTRY IN, 3RD COUNTRY OUT' STANCE: NCPFS

TEXT.P: The government remains firm on its stance that the Olympic torch for the 2008 Beijing Olympics should enter and exit Taiwan both via a third country if China would include the island on the flame's relay route, an official said Saturday.

Chou Jui, head of the office of the minister of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) , made the remarks after International Olympic Committee (IOC) Chairman Jacques Rogge was quoted as having said in India earlier in the day that he hopes Taiwan and China can settle their disputes over the torch relay route through consultations.
Beijing announced next year's Olympic torch relay route Thusday, in which Taipei would be the 21st stop, behind Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City and before China- controlled area of Hong Kong.
Within hours of Beijing's announcement, Taiwan explicitly rejected the Vietnam-Taiwan-Hong Kong route, saying it implied Taiwan was part of China.

Rogge refrained from giving direct comments on the dispute during his visit in India Saturday. He instead said that the dust has not yet settled and that he looks forward to seeing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reach an agreement on the issue through further talks.
Responding to press inquiries about the NCPFS' views on Rogge's remarks, Chou said the council cannot make any comment until after getting full information about the IOC's position on the dispute.
But he added that one thing is certain that the government will stick to its gun that the Olympic torch to be acceptable to Taiwan must follow a "third country- Taiwan-third country" route.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Tung Chen-yuan said earlier in the day that Taiwan would welcome the passage of the Olympic torch through its territory but reject the intention of China downgrading Taiwan to the level of one of its provinces. The MAC charts Taiwan's policy toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
CHEN PROTESTS AGAINST WHO OVER TAIWAN'S MEMBERSHIP BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lodged "a protest in the strongest terms" against the secretariat of the World Health Organization (WHO) Sunday, saying that Taiwan's bid to join the WHO is not an issue that could be denied or decided by the secretariat or any individual working for the WHO.
Taking the former East Germany as an example, Chen said whether Taiwan should be admitted into the WHO as a full member is an issue that should be determined by all member countries of the WHO.

Chen appealed to the WHO Secretariat and WHO Director-General Margaret Chan for handling Taiwan's accession bid in accordance with the WHO laws and spirit and referring Taiwan's membership application to the World Health Assembly, so that all WHO members can discuss the issue and reach a decision when they meet in mid-May.

Chen made the call in his speech at the opening of a workshop on Taiwan's bid to join the WHO under the name of Taiwan, marking the first and formal response to a WHO Secretariat's response to his letter dated April 11 to the WHO director- general about Taiwan's membership bid.

The WHO Secretariat responded in an April 25 letter to Chen by calling Taiwan's application a "non-issue" and saying that after a thorough study and legal consultation, the WHO had decided not to deal further with the issue, on the grounds that Taiwan is ineligible to apply for membership, which requires statehood recognized by the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 9,600 PEOPLE INDICTED FOR CORRUPTION SINCE JULY 2000

TEXT.P: The nation's public prosecutors have handled 3,700 corruption cases and prosecuted more than 9,600 people since the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) began an operation in July 2000 to crack down on organized crime and corruption, according to statistics released by the MOJ Sunday.

The statistics show that during the 81 months from July 2000 to March 2007, a total of 9,677 suspects involved in 3,731 cases were prosecuted for benefiting from illegal gains through corruption and related offenses, and that of this total, 2,043 have been sentenced to various prison terms.
The illegal gains involved in cases resulting in a conviction totaled NT$28.91 billion (US$869.47 million), according to the MOJ.
The 9,677 indicted suspects include 532 senior government officials, 583 elected public officials, 1,718 middle-level government officials, 2,892 basic civil servants and 3,952 members of the public.

Since July 2000, public prosecutors' offices throughout Taiwan have dealt with 7,840 cases, representing a decrease of 27.55 percent over the 81-month period from Oct. 1993 to June 2000 prior to the crackdown on organized crime and corruption.
The number of prosecuted cases also dropped 6.35 percent to 3,731 from 3,984, while the number of indicted suspects increased 3.61 percent to 9,677.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LODGES PROTEST AT WHO OVER TAIWAN'S MEMBERSHIP BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lodged "a protest in the strongest terms" against the secretariat of the World Health Organization (WHO) Sunday, saying that Taiwan's bid to join the WHO is not an issue that could be denied or decided by the secretariat or any individual working for the WHO.
Taking the former East Germany as an example, Chen said whether Taiwan should be admitted into the WHO as a full member is an issue that should be determined by all member countries of the WHO.

Chen appealed to the WHO Secretariat and WHO Director-General Margaret Chan to handle Taiwan's accession bid in accordance with the WHO laws and spirit and refer Taiwan's membership application to the World Health Assembly so that all WHO members can discuss the issue and reach a decision when they meet in mid- May.

Chen made the call in his speech at the opening of a workshop on Taiwan's bid to join the WHO under the name of Taiwan, marking the first and formal response to the WHO Secretariat's reply to his letter dated April 11 to the WHO director- general about Taiwan's membership bid.

The WHO Secretariat responded in an April 25 letter to Chen by calling Taiwan's application a "non-issue" and saying that after a thorough study and legal consultation, the WHO had decided not to deal further with the issue, on the grounds that Taiwan is ineligible to apply for membership, which requires statehood recognized by the United Nations.

The president reiterated that Taiwan is a sovereign state which has every right to apply to join the world health regulatory body as a full member based on the WHO's spirit of protecting the health of all peoples around the world and the notion that medical care knows no borders.

Noting that asking for a WHO membership is the exercise of collective human rights of the 23 million Taiwanese people, Chen asserted that this is not a matter that could be unilaterally denied or deprived of by the WHO Secretariat or the WHO director-general.

Chen quoted the WHO's organizational law as indicating that the WHO's membership is open to all countries from around the world. He added that the procedural rules of the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the WHO's highest decision-making unit -- have also stipulated that countries intending to apply for membership in the WHO should submit its application to the WHO chief 30 days before the convening of the next WHA and the WHO chief should then refer the application to the WHA so that the application could be put on the WHA agenda for debate by all member countries.

He argued that whether Taiwan is a sovereign state and whether Taiwan is entitled to applying for a full WHO membership are issues that should not be decided unilaterally by the WHO Secretariat but rather be determined in concert by all WHO member countries.

Based on the WHA procedural rules, Chen said it is the WHO chief's duty and responsibility that after he or she receives a membership application, 30 days before a new round of the WHA, that the application be placed on the WHA agenda for debate -- a job that should never be handled solely by the WHO Secretariat.
It is beyond question that Taiwan is a sovereign state, Chen stated, adding that Taiwan maintains formal diplomatic relations with 23 WHO member countries and one WHO observer.

On what basis could the WHO Secretariat have denied Taiwan's sovereign status by saying that Taiwan is ineligible to apply for membership, and how on earth could the WHO Secretariat cast doubt on the political decisions that 23 WHO member countries have made concerning Taiwan, Chen questioned, ridiculing the decision.

He lamented that Taiwan's bids to enter the WHA as an observer have all failed over the past 10 years due to China's obstruction, thus the country's efforts to "meaningfully participate" in WHO activities have also been frustrated as a result of a memorandum of understanding struck secretly between China and the WHO authorities in 2005.

The president stressed that Taiwan will only incur more suppression and humiliation if the country fails to work to defend its rights or continues to restrict itself on the global arena and it is the reason why he has insisted that Taiwan applies for a full membership in the WHO under the name of Taiwan.

He said Taiwan is not the only country in the world which is not a U.N. member state but tries to gain accession into the WHO, adding that in 1968, the then East Germany was not a U.N. member, but it became a WHO full member that year after the then WHO director-general asked to include East Germany's application into the WHA agenda, with an attachment of the WHO Charter and the WHA rules of procedure to serve as the reference of all other WHO member countries.

Chen stressed that Taiwan is not challenging the WHO Charter or the WHA rules of procedure, adding that Taiwan is just asking the WHO Secretariat and the WHO chief to allow Taiwan's application to be included on the agenda of the next WHA so that all WHO member countries could debate it and come to their own decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND PASSENGERS UP 2.49% IN Q1: TOURISM BUREAU

TEXT.P: The number of inbound visitors reached 881,292 in the first quarter of this year, marking a 2.59 percent year-on-year increase, according to statistics released by the Tourism Bureau Sunday.
Japan remained the top source of visitors to Taiwan, while the number of passengers from South Korea posted the largest growth, Tourism Bureau officials said.
Japanese people made 306,898 visits to Taiwan in the first three months of the year, up 4.21 percent, according to the official tallies.

In March alone, the number of visitors from Japan hit a new single-month high of 120,599, up 10.18 percent from the year-earlier level. Moreover, both business travelers and leisure travelers registered solid gains during the month, the officials said without providing exact figures.

They attributed the upbeat records to a combination of factors, including the practice of many Japanese companies to organize tours for their employees in March -- the final month of the traditional Japanese fiscal year; a number of festive activities, such as colorful lantern exhibitions, held throughout Taiwan during the month; and an increase of flights offered between the two countries in March.

Another encouraging development during the first quarter of the year was a 16.58 percent year-on-year growth in the number of visitors from South Korea, the officials said, adding that the annual growth rate even reached 27 percent in March.

South Koreans made 63,521 visits to Taiwan during the first quarter, according to the Tourism Bureau tallies. In March alone, 9,528 South Koreans made sightseeing trips to Taiwan, up 66 percent from a year ago. The steep increase might be attributable to Lantern Festival and tourism promotional activities launched by noted Taiwanese pop group F4, the officials said.
In contrast, the number of South Korean business travelers during the same month decreased 5.75 percent to 6,129, the officials said.

During the first quarter, the number of visitors from China-controlled areas of Hong Kong and Macau also registered a rare decline of 5.48 percent to 95,451, while the number of American visitors rose 2.21 percent to 92,648.
Meanwhile, the number of visitors from Singapore surged 7.15 percent to 37,982 and the number of Malaysian visitors also increased 4.97 percent to 28,668.

During the same period, the number of visitors from European countries posted a 6.48 percent growth to 45,706, while the number of visitors from Australia and New Zealand jumped 10.34 percent to 13,740.

According to a Tourism Bureau analysis, the number of tourists or leisure travelers to Taiwan from its major tourist markets totaled 372,653 in the January-March period, up 5.74 percent from the year-earlier level, but the number of business travelers from its major trading partners slid 3.68 percent to 228,436.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOP BICKERING OR FACE BOYCOTT: DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus whip of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Sunday called for the four DPP presidential aspirants to immediately stop bickering among themselves or they will risk being boycotted by the ruling party in the upcoming DPP presidential primary.

Wang Sing-nan said that grass-roots DPP members have become "extremely upset" about the smear and mudslinging campaign tactics that the four hopefuls -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- have engaged in their attempts to broaden their support prior to the DPP primary next month.
If these four continue to conduct undesirable and tasteless campaign schemes, they will be dumped by DPP supporters sooner or later, Wang claimed.
Wang added that the DPP legislative caucus will publicize at a news conference Monday its "countermeasures" against those who continue to lodge personal attacks on rivals.
The DPP whip made the remarks after Lu, Yu and Hsieh teamed up at a news conference Friday in criticizing Su for allegedly using public resources in his campaign for the party's presidential primary.

Lu, Yu and Hsieh reportedly called for mayors and county chiefs of the seven cities and counties in southern Taiwan -- traditionally DPP ballot barns in major elections -- to keep neutral in the upcoming DPP presidential primary.
Unexpectedly, all the seven southern mayors and county chiefs appeared at Su's speech dais when Su was on campaign trail in southern Taiwan Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT LABOR RIGHTS GROUP CALLS FOR LARGER HOURLY WAGE HIKE

TEXT.P: A student labor rights advocacy group urged the government Sunday to set a higher minimum hourly wage for part-time workers than what the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has recommended.

A spokeswoman for the activist group known as the Young Laborers 95 Alliance said the minimum hourly wage should be raised to between NT$101 and NT$103 in terms of the new CLA-proposed hourly wage calculating formula, not the CLA- recommended NT$93 to NT$95.

After a three-hour meeting on Friday, the CLA's wage reviewing committee came up with a package of recommendations to adjust the country's minimum monthly and hourly wages, both of which have been frozen for 10 years.

According to the committee's recommendations, the minimum monthly wage should be raised by 7.5 percent to 9.5 percent. That means the minimum monthly wage will be adjusted upwards to between NT$17,028 and NT$17,345 from the current NT$15,840.
In response to calls from part-time workers, the committee also suggested that the minimum payment for those paid by hour be raised to between NT$93 and NT$95 from the present NT$66.

The recommended minimum hourly wage reflects a shortened work week that has been in place for monthly wage earners for several years. The new calculating formula also allows for a weekly off day for part-time workers. At present, the minimum hourly wage is calculated on a 30-work-day-per-month and eight-work-hour-per-day formula. The new calculating formula is based on a criteria of 182.66 work hours per month.
The 95 Alliance spokeswoman claimed that the minimum hourly wage calculated in terms of the CLA recommended new formula should range between NT$101 and NT$103, rather than between NT$93 and NT$95.
If the rise in the consumer price index over the past decade is taken into account, the spokeswoman said a more reasonable minimum hourly wage would be NT$125.
The most unbearable point in the CLA-proposed adjustment package lies in its failure to allow hourly wage earners to ask for double pay when they work on national holidays, the spokeswoman said.

"The CLA has violated the Labor Standards Law in its ban on part-time workers or hourly wage earners to claim double pay for working on national holidays since the law has such a provision," she said, adding that the 95 Alliance will organize a protest at the Executive Yuan Monday to push for a removal of such an illegal ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GARMENT MANUFACTURERS EYEING MARKET IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's brand name textile manufacturers are setting their eyes on China's vast market where consumers' purchase power has been steadily increasing.

A delegation representing 10 well-known garment companies in Taiwan, led by officials from the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTD), visited department stores in three of China's major cities -- Chengdu, Tianjin and Beijing -- in mid-April before returning to Taiwan last week.

TTD officials told reporters Sunday that members of the delegation have felt after the trip that China, with its vast population, is a market full of business opportunities and one that Taiwan's textile producers cannot afford to neglect.

The officials added that if Taiwan's garment producers want to make inroads into the Chinese market, they should distinguish themselves from textile producers of other countries by supplying high-end elegant, tasteful, brand name products.

They said the Taiwan Textile Federation will organize another trip to Beijing by Taiwan brand name garment manufacturers in November and present a fashion show there to allow them to promote their products.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNDREDS FAMILIES RALLY TO SUPPORT 'SPANK OUT DAY'

TEXT.P: More than 2,000 people from some 400 families rallied on Taipei streets Sunday to support "International Spank Out Day" which was initiated in 1998 by a U.S. group to bring widespread attention to its campaign to end the physical punishment of children.

Activists from several dozen other Taiwan civil groups, including Homemakers' Union and Foundation, also took part in the rally -- a walk from National Taiwan University to Daan Forest Park -- sponsored by the non-profit Humanistic Education Foundation (HEF).

HEF volunteers called on Taiwan parents and teachers not to spank their children or students, while offering educational information to parents and caregivers about non-violent discipline alternatives.

Group members suggested that adults, rather than smacking a child on a sudden impulse, place a phone call for educational consultation, exchange pithy formulas encouraging non-violent solutions -- particularly during periods of anger -- and seek supportive resources in order to help end the resort to violence.
"Angry" parents and teachers are also encouraged to hit drums, play ball, or clean the house to channel their sudden impulses or dissipate bad moods.

Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng, who was among several celebrities invited by the HEF to offer their "pithy formulas" to beef up April 30 "International Spank Out Day, " said: "Respect and understand children to avoid treating them violently."

Noting that even a little child is a human being whose individuality should be respected by adults, Tu said that spanking will actually deal only with superficial problems while leaving the core issues unsolved.
Similar "No Smacking Day" activities were held in Taichung in central Taiwan, and the southern port city of Kaohsiung Sunday.

HEF officials said that various countries around the world, including the United States hold various events every year to observe the "Spank Out Day, " which is sometimes called "No Hitting Day, " or "Day of Non-Violence for Children." The day of action was initiated by the U.S. Center for Effective Discipline in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUALIFYING ROUND FOR MAHJONG WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP BEING HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A qualifying round for the 2007 Mahjong World Championship began in Taipei Sunday, with 150 contestants taking part in three days of competition.
The competition in Taipei is part of a series of regional qualifying tournaments in Asia, Europe and North America.

The eight top winners in the Taipei event will qualify to move on to the semi- finals, to be held in June in either Denmark or Japan. A total of 20 finalists will earn the right to join the grand finale, the Mahjong World Championship, in November in the city of Chengdu in China's Sichuan province.

GigaMedia Global Limited, a provider of online entertainment software and services, has secured a five-year exclusive right to co-host the Mahjong World Championship in conjunction with the World Mahjong Organization -- the official international body that sets the rules of the game and competition standards.
A spokesman for GigaMedia said the company plans to hold a Mahjong World Championship in Taipei within the next five years.
Mahjong is said to have originated in China about 2,500 years ago, but the four- person game assumed its current form in the 19th century.

Organizers of the Mahjong World Championship have indicated that they plan to turn the competition into an event "as big as the World Series of Poker," with television programming, corporate sponsorships and awards totaling millions of dollars.
They said that playing the game for fun should also be accepted, instead of merely focusing on it as a form of gambling.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPAQUE PROCESS FOR BUYOUT HURTS TAIWAN: U.S. BUSINESS GROUP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/07 19:46:52 (By Michelle Tsai and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A U.S. business group claimed Sunday that Taiwan's lengthy delays and lack of formal process for leveraged buyout deals hurts Taiwan chip companies.

In a press release posted on its Website Sunday, the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, which is dedicated to fostering trade and business relations between the United States and Taiwan, said Taiwan's government should set up a thorough, transparent, and straightforward process for mergers and acquisitions in Taiwan's semiconductor industry.

The lack of a permanent and timely process for reviewing mergers and acquisition activity in the chip sector adds costs that may inhibit foreign investment from even exploring Taiwan's market, according to the press release.

In addition, the council said, it leads to delays that may ultimately cause deals to collapse -- a contributing factor in the recently scuppered plan by U.S.-based Carlyle Group to buy out Kaohsiung, Taiwan-based chip packager Advanced Semiconductor Engineering (ASE).
Carlyle offered to buy ASE for NT$39 per share in November, 2006, but called off the bid early this month over the failure to clench a deal with the ASE.

Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council said that increased merger and acquisition activity in the semiconductor industry would have a positive impact on the overall value of Taiwan's economy as well as increasing the capital available to companies.

Noting that the semiconductor sector is a jewel in Taiwan's economic crown, Hammond-Chambers warned that legacy policies on chip investment in China, and the lack of formal processes for merger and acquisition activities in the sector are set to undermine the efforts of Taiwanese companies to become industry leaders through partnerships with global capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS BIG IN INTERNATIONAL BADMINTON CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Taiwan won big at the International Badminton Federation World Senior Championship, concluded here Sunday, garnering seven gold medals.
Germany came in second place with five golds, while Japan and Thai shared third place with four golds a piece.
Taiwanese player Chang Wen-shong stole the show during Sunday's playoffs by capturing the gold both in men's single, and men's double for 45-year-olds.
The championship, which is held every four years, was hosted for the first time by Taiwan, in this its third edition and has drawn 300 foreign and 75 local competitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S 'OPEN' POLICY GREETED WITH COLD SHOULDER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China's open policy toward Taiwan, announced in a forum between the Communist Party of China (CPC) and Taiwan-based Kuomintang (KMT) in Beijing, was greeted with cold shoulder in Taiwan Sunday.

Notable among Beijing's announcement was the opening of six more destinations, namely Chendu in Sichuan Province, Nanjing in Jiangsu Province, Hangzhou in Zhejiang Province, Shenzhen in Guangdon Province, Dalian in Liaonin Province and Guilin in Guangxi Province, for direct charter flights to and fro Taiwan.

However, Taiwan's Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei said that no direct charter flights between Taiwan and these six destinations could be launched without the approval of Taiwan authorities.

He said the announcement made by Beijing at the CPC-KMT forum which was not attended by Taiwan officials is not going to be translated into Taiwan's policy automatically before negotiations were held and agreement was reached between Beijing and Taipei, Tsai said.

China's another remarkable announcement Sunday that Taiwan colleges and universities which are plagued by the scarcity of students will be allow to recruit students from mainland China will turn out to be another pie in the sky unless it get the endorsement from the Taiwan authorities, according Liu Chao- hsuan, president of Soochow University in Taipei.

Much as local universities and colleges like to recruit talented students from China, Liu, who also serves as the president of the Association of Private Universities and Colleges, Taiwan, Republic of China, said the government has to acknowledge diplomas issued by Chinese schools before mainland Chinese students could enroll in Taiwan schools.

Vice Education Minister Lu Mu-lin referred journalists who asked for his ministry's comment on the issue to the Mainland Affairs Council saying it is within that council's authorities to decide whether local schools may take in students from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Rebuilt Iraq Projects Found Crumbling
In a troubling sign for the American-financed rebuilding program in Iraq, inspectors for a federal oversight agency have found that in a sampling of eight projects that the United States had declared successes, seven were no longer operating as designed because of plumbing and electrical failures, lack of proper maintenance, apparent looting and expensive equipment that lay idle.
The United States has previously admitted, sometimes under pressure from federal inspectors, that some of its reconstruction projects have been abandoned, delayed or poorly constructed. But this is the first time inspectors have found that projects officially declared a success X in some cases, as little as six months before the latest inspections X were no longer working properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Washington Times: Most Katrina Aid From Overseas Went Unclaimed. As the winds and water of Hurricane Katrina were receding, presidential confidante Karen Hughes sent a cable from her State Department office to U.S. ambassadors worldwide. Titled "Echo-Chamber Message" -- a public relations term for talking points designed to be repeated again and again V the Sept. 7, 2005, directive was unmistakable: Assure the scores of countries that had pledged or donated aid at the height of the disaster that their largesse had provided Americans "practical help and moral support" and "highlight the concrete benefits hurricane victims are receiving."
