DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS TO U.S. CITIZENS STUDYING CHINESE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) 04/30/07 12:28:44 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government is offering scholarships to U.S. citizens who live in American cities and areas that maintain sisterhood ties with Taipei to learn Chinese in Taiwan, Taiwan's representative office in Washington, D.C. said in a news release Sunday.

The scholarships -- NT$25,000 (US$750) per student -- are part of Taipei City's efforts to promote "city diplomacy" aimed at expanding international exchanges, according to the news release by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington (TECO).

A total of 10 applicants from 12 of Taipei City's sister cities in the United States will be awarded scholarships. The 12 cities are Houston, Marshall (Texas) , Dallas, Phoenix, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Atlanta, Oklahoma City, Boston, Cleveland, Indianapolis and Guam.

The U.S. students who receive the scholarships will take classes from September this year to next February at the language centers of National Taiwan University, National Taiwan Normal University or National Chengchi University.

Interested individuals are welcome to visit the Web site of the Taipei City Education Department at www.edunet.taipei.gov.tw/public/ ReadNews for more information. The registration period ends May 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S 'OPEN' POLICY RECEIVES COLD RECEPTION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China's open policy toward Taiwan, announced in a forum in Beijing between the Communist Party of China (CPC) and Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , was greeted with a cold reception in Taiwan Sunday.

Notable in Beijing's announcement was the opening of six more destinations, namely Chendu in Sichuan Province, Nanjing in Jiangsu Province, Hangzhou in Zhejiang Province, Shenzhen in Guangdon Province, Dalian in Liaonin Province and Guilin in Guangxi Province, for direct charter flights to and from Taiwan.

However, Taiwan's minister of transportation and communications, Tsai Duei, said that no direct charter flights between Taiwan and these six destinations can be launched without the approval of Taiwan authorities.

He said the announcement made by Beijing at the CPC-KMT forum which was not attended by Taiwan officials will not automatically translate into Taiwan's policy, adding that an agreement must first be reached between Beijing and Taipei.
Also notable in Beijing's announcement was that Chinese citizens will be allowed to study at Taiwan's colleges and universities, which suffer from a shortage of students.

Liu Chao-hsuan, president of Soochow University in Taipei, said that an agreement must first be reached between Beijing and Taipei on this issue before Taiwan's universities and colleges will be allowed to recruit students from China.

Much as local universities and colleges like to recruit talented students from China, Liu, who also serves as the president of the Association of Private Universities and Colleges, Taiwan, Republic of China, said Taiwan's government must first agree to recognize degrees issued by Chinese schools before Chinese students will be able to enroll in Taiwan schools.

Vice Education Minister Lu Mu-lin referred journalists who asked for his ministry's comment on the issue to the Mainland Affairs Council, noting that the council has the authority to decide whether local schools will be allowed to recruit students from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
PLANNING NEEDED ON ALLOWING CHINESE CITIZENS TO STUDY IN TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will conduct careful planning before allowing Chinese citizens to study in Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Sunday.
In particular, the government needs to break through the current legal restrictions and work out a management plan to regulate the students' stay in Taiwan, the officials said.

The officials were responding to a proposal, put forth during a Beijing forum between the Communist Party of China and Taiwan's Kuomintang, that Taiwan colleges and universities recruit students in China to promote cross-Taiwan Strait educational exchanges and cooperation.

According to the MAC, although allowing China students to study in Taiwan will help some Taiwan universities increase their student numbers and enhance understanding of Taiwan by China's younger generation, the policy involves a number of issues, such as requiring the students to find a guarantor, providing them with guidance on life in Taiwan, permitting them to accept part-time jobs and including them in insurance programs.

There will also be other issues that will arise after the students' graduation, including their residence, employment, marriage and over-staying of their visas, as well as these issues' impact on national security, MAC officials said.

Noting that most Taiwan universities still rely on government funding and do not set different tuition rates for domestic and foreign students, the officials said that allowing Chinese students to study in Taiwan under these circumstances will not help increase the universities' financial resources but will dilute Taiwan's higher education resources.

While the government has always supported exchange activities that are helpful to promoting positive cross-strait interaction and expects cross-strait exchanges in all areas, it will not help if China only targets some selected activities, they said.
The officials pointed out that there are a lot of problems in cross-strait exchanges that remain unresolved and urged China to resume talks with Taiwan as soon as possible to resolve the problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT TO SUPPORT TAIWAN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the European Parliament Monday to continue to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) , a goal which is being pursued this year under the name of "Taiwan."

Addressing the issue while receiving members of a pro-Taiwan group in the European Parliament, Chen stressed that Taiwan is applying to join the WHO under the name of "Taiwan" not because the country is changing its official title but because the name is more familiar to the international community than its official title "Republic of China."

On the WHO Secretariat's claim that Taiwan is not a sovereign country and therefore not qualified to become a WHO member, the president asserted that Taiwan's status as a sovereign country is "unquestionable" because Taiwan maintains diplomatic relations with 23 official members of the WHO and one observer in the organization.
Chen pointed out that Taiwan has tried but failed to join the WHO for the past 10 years and that even the country's bid for "meaningful participation" in the organization has been unsuccessful.

He reiterated that the 23 million Taiwan people's right to health should not be ignored, denied or restricted, while expressing his gratitude to the European Parliament for adopting resolutions in support of Taiwan's WHO bid on many occasions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO DEAL WITH PERSONNEL INVOLVED IN LEAKING HAN KUANG DRILL INFO

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will deal squarely with personnel who are found to be responsible for the leakage of information about the 23rd Han Kuang military exercise to be held in May, an MND official said Monday.

Fielding questions at the legislative Defense Committee, Deputy Defense Minister Ko Chen-heng admitted that part of an Apple Daily report Monday saying that details of the 23rd Han Kuang drill can be viewed at the FOXY Web site was correct, including the time and item names of the drill, but part of the report, including the names of forces to take part in the exercise, was wrong.
Ko said that investigations into the leakage of the information have begun and that the personnel responsible will be severely punished.
This marked the fourth time this year that information about the 23rd Han Kuang exercise has allegedly been leaked.

The exercise will be based on a simulated scenario regarding the cross-Taiwan Strait military situation in the year 2010, according to Chiu Kuo-cheng, an MND deputy chief of the general staff for operations and planning.

In the scenario, Taiwan has to defend itself against a Chinese invasion attempt launched due to Taiwan's refusal to participate in unification talks, Chiu said, adding that Taiwan's military capability in the scenario is the same as at present due to a lack of progress in terms of arms procurement. He further said that this year's Han Kuang drill has two phases: full-scale maneuvers and computer war game simulations.

According to Chiu, the full-scale maneuvers will be carried out in areas of Penghu, Hualien, Yilan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Changhua and Pingtung as scheduled by the MND, with some of the maneuvers open to the public to watch at certain times. The computer war game simulations will proceed for five consecutive days at all command centers, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL CONFIRMS KAOHSIUNG MAYOR HAD LIGHT STROKE

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital (KMUH) confirmed Monday that Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu has suffered a light stroke leaving her right leg paralyzed and needing immediate rehabilitation.
KMUH Vice President Lai Wen-teh made the confirmation at a press conference at the hospital with Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san and City Director of Information Hsiao Yu-cheng.
Lai said Chen's blood pressure was still high since suffering a stroke last week.

She was admitted to the KMUH last Thursday. On the Friday, she still needed assistance getting out of bed because of dizziness and motion dysfunction in her right leg, Lai said, noting the hospital is trying to control her blood pressure.
Chiu said he will act for Chen while she is absent from work and will attend ongoing question-and-answer sessions of the city council on her behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 30, or the 14th day of the third month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his mistress Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the U.S. armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent ceasefire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurates Taiwan's first tap water museum.
2001: The Second Asian Physics Olympiad concludes in Taipei after more than 10 days of competition with Seven gold medals, five silvers and 11 bronzes, as well as 16 honorary citations awarded to the winners.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before the day is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 74 points to close at 7,875.42.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,956.03 and dipped to a low of 7,843.05 during trading. A total of 3.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$83.18 billion (US$2.5 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 3 percent, construction issues at 2.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.7 percent, cement stocks at 1.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers more than 1,055 to 184, with 131 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 70 PERCENT OF TAIWAN WORKERS WORRY ABOUT KAROSHI

TEXT.P: Nearly 74 percent of Taiwan workers worry that they might become victims of karoshi -- a Japanese term for death from overwork and stress and fatigue from long working hours -- according to the results of a public opinion poll released Monday.

The poll, conducted by 1111 Job Bank April 13-27 to mark May 1 Labor Day, found that 90 percent of the respondents have worked overtime, with overtime hours averaging 8.2 hours per week or 1.64 hours per work day.
Of this group, nearly 50 percent were not paid for their overtime, the poll found.

Wu Jui-ying, a 1111 vice president, quoted a 2003 report compiled by the Lausanne, Switzerland-based International Institute of Management Development as indicating that the Taiwanese worked an average of 2,282 hours a year in 2002, more than anyone else in the world.

Wu said that according to similar tallies compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan workers worked an average of 2,170 hours a year in 2006, or 180.8 hours per month.

The 1111 poll found that Taiwan's salaried men and women worked 8.18 more hours per week than the normal weekly work hours so far this year, marking an increase of 1.52 hours over the average of 6.66 hours recorded in 2004 in terms of weekly overtime hours.

In terms of overtime hours, the poll found that 71.7 percent of the responding office workers work overtime in the evening after their normal work, 19.38 percent work overtime when the need arises and 17.6 percent work at the weekend.

The poll also found that 73.79 percent of the office workers worry that they might die from overwork, as they often suffer from symptoms of fatigue, including sore, numb neck and shoulders, declining memory, difficulty concentrating and mood swings.
The poll, conducted online, had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of 2.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE OVER 50 URGED TO CHECK FOR COLON CANCER EVERY YEAR

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Health Promotion urged people over 50 years of age Monday to receive yearly screening for colon cancer, which is the third-most common kind of cancer among people in Taiwan.

Kung Hsien-lan, head of the bureau's Cancer Control and Prevention Division, noted that colon cancer is the result of colorectal polyps turning malignant and that there is a 46 percent chance of malignant cells existing in polyps larger than two centimeters in diameter.

While 90 percent of colon cancer patients can survive if the cancer is discovered at stage I, the survival rate is less than 20 percent if it is discovered only at the terminal stage, Kung pointed out.

According to Kung, colon cancer is most prevalent in people over 50 years of age, and experiences of Europe and the United States show that receiving fecal occult blood tests every one to two years can help early discovery of colon cancer and reduce the death rate by 18 percent to 33 percent.
Advising people over 50 to receive screening every year, Kung said the government now subsidizes fecal occult blood tests for citizens 50-69 years of age every two years.

Tallies from the Department of Health indicate that colon cancer has the third- highest cancer-related death rate in Taiwan. While 3,898 of 7,366 people diagnosed with colon cancer in 2002 died within two years, 4,111 of 8,238 people diagnosed in 2003 died within two years, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH 23 SHOULD BE 'TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE DAY': VP

TEXT.P: Taiwan is a sovereign state and "formally became independent" the day Taiwan people cast their votes to elect their president for the first time March 23, 1996, Vice President Annette Lu claimed Monday in the eastern city of Hualien, adding that March 23 should therefore be set as Taiwan's independence day.
In a speech to her supporters in the Hualien area, Lu said Hualien could be a "defensive frontline zone " instead of a safe place in the rear in the event of military attacks by China.

She lambasted Beijing for downgrading Taiwan's sovereign status when announcing a 2008 Olympic torch relay route plan recently that included Taiwan as a "domestic leg." She also blamed the administrative department for failing to take preventive or remedial measures beforehand in this regard.

Noting that only people in sovereign states are given the right to elect their own presidents, Lu claimed that presidential elections have made Taiwan not only a de facto independent country, "but also a de jure independent one."
Knowing this fact well, she went on, China fired intimidating missiles into the seas off the coasts of Keelung and Kaohsiung on the eve of the March 23 presidential election in 1996.

She added that one of the missions that the new Taiwan president to be elected in 2008 should strive to carry out is to normalize Taiwan's sovereign status in the international community, claiming that so far none of the other presidential aspirants is as capable and devoted as she is in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS FIVE AWARDS IN HOUSTON FILM FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, April 29 (CNA) 04/30/07 17:27:48 (By Chang Hui-yen and Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan took five awards at the just-concluded 40th Worldfest-Houston International Film Festival, Taiwan's representative office in Houston said over the weekend.

The winning films included Amour-Legende by director Wu Mi-sen; Visions of Taiwan's Mountains and Digitized Operations in Taiwan -- both of which are documentaries made by the Government Information Office -- and Kuanwu Formosan Salamander and Taipei MRT -- both directed by Chen Chin-fa.
Amour-Legende is a story about a young man who suffers from memory loss and begins to question his own existence after going on a journey to a remote island.
The film was shown at the 2006 Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival and won the Global Vision Award in the 31st Hong Kong International Film Festival held March 20-April 11.
Chen's Kuanwu Formosan Salamander deals with an endangered species of amphibian endemic to the Kuanwu area in the northern Taiwan county of Miaoli.
Chen, who has been dedicated to ecological conservation for 18 years, has made many documentaries on endangered species in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORAL REEF CONSERVATION WEEK IN KENDING NATIONAL PARK KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: A series of activities designed to call attention to the need for coral reef conservation kicked off Monday at the Kending National Park in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan.

The Coral Reef Biodiversity and Conservation Week activities coincide with the spawning season for the coral off the southern Taiwan coast, according to the Kending National Park Administration (KNPA) , one of the event organizers along with the Taiwanese Coral Reef Society, the Academia Sinica Research Center for Biodiversity, the Underwater Photography Association and the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium.
The Kending coral spawning season usually begins on the second Sunday of the third month of the lunar calendar.

The seven-day event will include a series of seminars on the sustainable management of coral reefs, beach and coastal water cleaning activities in the Kending park and a free concert slated for May 5 along the Maobitou coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May moved down 96 points to close at 7,850, with 38,588 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June dropped 96 points to finish at 7,841, with 469 contracts traded, while September futures lost 92 points to close at 7,650, with 88 contract transactions. December futures lost 95 points to close at 7,650, with 23 contracts traded, while March decreased 106 points to end 7,658, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,946 for May, 7,937 for June, 7,742 for September, 7,745 for December and 7,764 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronic shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

May TE futures dropped 1.65 points to close at 333.05, with 2,744 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 1.85 points to finish at 331.2, with 46 contract transactions. September TE futures decreased 1.55 points to close at 324.4, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTBOOKS PUT LABORERS IN BAD LIGHT: TEACHERS' GROUP

TEXT.P: The textbooks used by the country's high schools present laborers in a bad light, a teachers' group complained Monday.

In a press conference called to mark May 1 Labor Day, Wu Chung-tai, president of the National Teachers' Association, said the current textbooks, published by various companies with the approval of the Ministry of Education, either fail to prepare students for the labor markets they will face after graduation or portray laborers and labor unions in an unflattering light.

He claimed that all the current textbooks, regardless of their publishers, are skewed in favor of capitalists, although a majority of the students who have to use the textbooks are likely to end up as laborers living on salaries.

It is a shame that these textbooks, instead of priming students with information about laborers' rights, ways to solve labor disputes and the negative impact brought about by globalization, offer an unrealistically rosy picture of economic development and globalization, Wu went on.

Citing examples, labor activist Chen Chu-po said at the news conference that a history textbook published by the Taiyu Company for vocational senior high schools "unfairly" lays the blame for the exodus of local firms in the 1980s on environmentalists and high labor costs.
It is an insult to the country's laborers that textbooks discriminating against them have been approved by the Ministry of Education, Chen said.

They urged the education authorities to invite labor activists to sit on its panel responsible for working out guidelines for compiling textbooks and revise the guidelines to embody respect for labor rights and instil students with the ideas of socialism.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STUDENTS WOULD DILUTE TAIWAN'S EDUCATION RESOURCES: MOE

TEXT.P: The education resources enjoyed by Taiwan students would be diluted if the government were to allow China citizens to study in Taiwan without working out proper complementary measures, a Ministry of Education official claimed Monday.

According to Szu Chi-pu, executive secretary of the ministry's Mainland Affairs Task Force, there are more than 150 colleges and universities in Taiwan, with public institutions receiving 80 percent of their funding from the government and private institutions receiving 18 percent to 20 percent of their funding from the government.

In assessing whether to allow Chinese students to study here, the government needs also to take into account the possible decline in the quality of education and the policy's possible impact on the country's public order, Szu said.

Citing the example of Japan, Szu said approximately 70,000 China students have studied in Japan since Japanese universities started recruiting Chinese citizens, but he claimed that the policy has resulted in worsening of Japan's public order.

In one case, a Chinese student killed a family of five in Kyushu around four years ago, which prompted the Japanese government to sponsor a racist advertisement urging its citizens to "beware of Chinese, " Szu said, adding that the advertisement was removed after protests by the Chinese government.

Szu made the remarks in response to Beijing's announcement Sunday that Taiwan colleges and universities are welcome to recruit students in China to promote cross-Taiwan Strait educational exchanges and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS TAKE WAIT-AND-SEE ATTITUDE IN COMMITTEE MEETING

TEXT.P: Because of discontent with the Kuomintang's (KMT) delay in furthering coordination on the coming legislative polls, People First Party (PFP) lawmakers will attend Tuesday's Procedure Committee meeting but might not vote on a bill aimed at ex-KMT Chief Ma Ying-jeou, a PFP lawmaker said Monday.

The decision was made during a PFP legislative caucus meeting earlier in the day, in a gesture to express PFP lawmakers' dissatisfaction with the KMT's postponement of two-way talks to better coordinate candidacies in December's legislative elections.
The Procedure Committee is slated to address the bill designed to squeeze Ma out of the 2008 presidential election for the third time Tuesday.

The KMT fails to control a majority in the Legislative Yuan and needs PFP collaboration to kill the bill, which carries tremendous significance for the party's future as the presidential election approaches.

According to PFP legislative caucus whip Fu Kun-chi, PFP lawmakers will attend Tuesday's meeting after several of them expressed displeasure with the KMT's attitude, but they will refrain from voting on the Ma bill.

Since PFP lawmakers joined forces with their KMT peers during the April 17 Procedure Committee in blocking "the Ma exclusion bill" put forward by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) after the two parties reached an initial seven-point agreement on the legislative elections, the KMT has not held new talks with the PFP to advance cooperation, despite pledging that it would do so within two weeks.
PFP lawmakers will certainly take part in the coming Procedure Committee meeting, but how they will act depends on how the meeting progresses, PFP lawmaker Feng Ting-kuo said.
"There will be room for negotiations if the KMT honors its promise to allot seven constituencies to the PFP in the seven-point agreement," Feng said.

Ma is viewed as the opposition's best bet for the 2008 presidential race, but the former KMT chairman has been indicted on corruption charges by Taipei prosecutors in a case related to allegations that he embezzled over NT$11 million from a special monthly municipal allowance earmarked for his discretionary use when he served as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.
Ma stepped down from the KMT's top post in mid-February and announced his desire to run for president immediately after being indicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE OFFICIAL SUGGESTS 2008 KMT-CPC FORUM IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/07 19:28:25 (By Chang Ming-kun and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A senior Chinese official said Monday that he would like to see the 2008 Cross- Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) held in Taiwan.

Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, expressed the wish while he was seeing off Lien Chan, honorary KMT chairman, at the airport after the KMT and the CPC held their third cross-strait forum in Beijing April 28-29.
Chen said that each time the two sides prepare to hold the annual forum, there are people in Taiwan who heap negative or abusive remarks on the meeting.
"Yet we have been going from strength to strength, and I would hope that the next forum can be held in Taiwan," he said.

Lien, who led a delegation consisting of more than 100 senior KMT officials and Taiwan business leaders, told reporters at the airport that the people of Taiwan "will welcome the achievements of the 2007 forum."
He urged the government in Taipei to "reap the forum's fruitful results" for the sake of the Taiwan people.

Some 500 participants attended the two-day forum and discussed various issues, including cooperation in education, sightseeing trips by Chinese tourists to Taiwan and direct flights across the Taiwan Strait.
Among the new measures announced by Beijing during the forum was a decision to allow students from China to apply to study in Taiwan.

Lien met with Chinse President Hu Jintao at the opening of the forum. It was the third time they had met since the KMT and the CPC held their first forum in Beijing in April 2005 -- the first top-level talks between the two political parties in 60 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF URGES BEIJING TO REMOVE POLICY BARRIERS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong urged Beijing Monday to remove barriers to its policy to help bail out ongoing negotiations with Taiwan.
Chen issued the call at a seminar in Kaohsiung City attended by representatives of the local tourism, business and industry sectors.
Chen's comments came after the third economic cooperation forum held between Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) concluded a day earlier in Beijing.

Although the KMT and the CPC reached agreement in several fields, including allowing Taiwan-based universities and businesses to recruit students in China and to invest in Chinese shipping and container companies, Chen, Taiwan's top China policy planner, pointed out that the conclusions are invalid because the KMT does not represent the Taiwan government.

"What the KMT and the CPC have done is more burdensome than beneficial, further complicating the situation, " the MAC chief said, adding that "any agreement reached between them must be approved by the government."
Chen called on Beijing to remove barriers to its existing policy toward Taiwan so as to help push forward real negotiations already underway between the two sides.

Pointing to the long-expected opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists as an example, Chen said that the "simple" issue remains unsolved following Sunday's KMT-CPC forum and ascribed the failure to Beijing's continuous attempts to rehash political issues. "But bilateral negotiations on the issue must go on," he said.

As to the issue concerning Beijing's plan to relay the 2008 Olympic Games torch through Taiwan as part of its domestic route, Chen said that the government will never yield to China's "two-faced" scheme to make Taiwan one of its provinces and thus will not accept the Beijing-proposed relay route.
The main obstacle to Taiwan-China dealings and permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait resides in Beijing's reluctance to recognize this country's existence as an independent sovereignty, he said.

In the face of Beijing's increasing bullying of Taiwan, he also called for concerted efforts from the opposition parties and local governments to forge national consensus and common ground toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Maliki's Office Is Seen Behind Purge in Forces. Some Commanders Had Pursued Militias.
A department of the Iraqi prime minister's office is playing a leading role in the arrest and removal of senior Iraqi army and national police officers, some of whom had apparently worked too aggressively to combat violent Shiite militias, according to U.S. military officials in Baghdad.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION OF MAIN STADIUM FOR 2009 WORLD GAMES AHEAD OF SCHEDULE

TEXT.P: Construction work on the main stadium for the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung is ahead of schedule, an executive of Fu Tsu Construction Co., which won the bid to build the stadium, said Monday.

Laio Nien-chi, vice chairman of Fu Tsu, told Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Cheng Wen- lung during the later's inspection of the construction site that the project is now 16.17 percent complete, slightly ahead of the scheduled progress of 16.08 percent.
The stadium, covering an area of 19 hectares, will cost N$5 billion (US$150.6 million). It will have world-class track and field facilities, and a seating capacity to accommodate 55,000 people.
The stadium has been designed to be the world's first multifunction stadium powered by solar energy. Its solar power generators will be capable of supplying 1 million kilowatts of electricity a year.

The generators can meet the stadium's power needs for lighting and air conditioning during the World Games. When no sports events are taking place, the surplus electricity can be sold to Taiwan Power Co. and net NT$5 million per year in revenue for the Kaohsiung city government, according to officials from the Kaohsiung city government's Public Works Bureau.
The project is scheduled for completion by January 2009, allowing enough time to prepare for the World Games, to be held July 16-26, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU PARLIAMENT MEMBER: TORCH REJECTION DEFENSE OF STATUS QUO

TEXT.P: Chairman of the Taiwan Friendship Group in the European Parliament, Georg Jarzembowski, suggested Monday that Taiwan's government better communicate to the international community its reasons to reject the Beijing-proposed Olympic torch relay route.

Noting that he was not in an appropriate position to comment on whether or not letting the torch in would be more advantageous for Taiwan, Jarzembowski said it is clear that Taiwanshould avoid any situation as to present the image to a third country that Taipei is of the same status as Hong Kong and Macau.

Jarzembowski made the remarks while talking with a number of reporters at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. He and other three European Parliament members, also from the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, are on a six-day visit in Taiwan and met with President Chen Shui-bian earlier the day.

Jarzembowski said he does not consider the government's decision to reject the torch route to be election-driven as some elements in Taiwan claim. Rather, he said he believes that Chen made the decision in order to defend the status quo and Taiwan's status as a sovereign state.

China announced next year's Olympic torch relay route Thursday, in which Taipei is defined by Beijing as the first stop on Chinese soil, after Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City and before China's Hong Kong. Taiwan quickly rejected the plan, insisting the torch should enter and exit Taiwan via third countries.

Over the issue of Taiwan applying for full membership to the World Health Organization (WHO) , Jarzembowski said although no positive answers can be expected in near future, the issue of Taiwan's participation in the WHO should be kept on the table.

Jarzembowski said it is always important for Taiwan toraise the flagshowing that Taiwan is a sovereign state and has the right to contribute its expertise in health regulations. As for what the best strategy to achieve those goals will be, he said it is a decision best left to the country's government.

He reiterated that at the moment the European Parliament, the United States and Japan support the idea of Taiwan becoming a World Health Assembly observer, and the European Commission is in favor of the arrangement allowing for Taiwan to engage in "meaningful participation."
He said he hopes Margaret Chan, the new WHO Director-General from Hong Kong, will not hinder Taiwan's cooperation with the organization.
Jarzembowski said there needs to be official dialogue between the government of People's Republic of China and the government of Republic of China if cross- strait tensions are to be eased.

Europe is closely watching human rights situation in China, Jarzembowski said, China has to know that it is not a question of 'Western stylehuman rights requirement, but a question of China's own destiny, because in the long run it can not have economic prosperity while depriving people of their liberty.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO ACT IN CROSS-STRAIT NEGOTIATION MECHANISM

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) suggested Monday that China act within existing cross-Taiwan Strait engagement mechanisms while proposing to open more access points for cross-straits chartered flight services.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun made the remarks in response to media inquiries on several controversial announcements by Chinese authorities at a two-day forum co-hosted by Taiwan's largest opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Community Party of China (CPC) in Beijing that ended Sunday.

The announcements include the opening of six more Chinese cities, namely Chengdu, Hangzhou, Nanjing, Shenzhen, Kueilin, and Dalian, to serve as cross- strait chartered flight destinations, and the opening of Taiwanese colleges and universities to enroll students from China.

Liu explained that the two sides talked about the issue concerning destinations of the chartered cargo and passenger cross-strait flight services during authorized negotiations, and that the KMT-CPC forum only served to exchange opinions between two political parties and any agreements arising from such an event cannot be implemented without governmental authorization.

As to the issue of Chinese student enrollment, Liu stressed that educational resources in the country are shared by all Taiwanese people. Providing local students with the best educational resources on the one hand, while on the other hand resolving the difficulties of some local colleges and universities in recruiting students is a challenge the Ministry of Education has to face, he said.

Commenting on recent media reports saying that Beijing has defined Chinese people's sightseeing visits to Taiwan not as "travel between two countries, " the MAC official stated that the government hopes that Beijing will deal with the issue concerning Chinese tourists' visits to Taiwan in a pragmatic manner, meaning on an economic basis, not a political one.
Any unnecessary political barriers will certainly cause difficulties in the cross-strait dialogues on the issue, Liu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAWMAKERS SPEAK OUT FOR TERTIARY-EDUCATION GRADUATES

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Monday urged the government not to allow further enrollments at tertiary education institutes, citing the huge supply-demand gap between college graduates and the domestic job market.
The group of TSU lawmakers, led by legislative caucus whip Tseng Tsahn-deng, issued the call in a Legislative Yuan news conference on the eve of the May 1 Labor Day.

Calling on the government to pay greater heed to a high unemployment rate of 4.36 percent among Taiwan's university graduates and master's and doctoral degree holders, Tseng said that aglut of "unqualified" higher education manpower is already having an impact on starting salaries.

Citing the latest statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs, Tseng reported that the starting monthly salaries for tertiary degree holders new to the job market averaged NT$31,500, while those for new university and college graduates stood at NT$26,700 and NT$23,800, respectively.

The earnings of Taiwan's university graduates and higher-degree holders are little compared by their tuition fees, which have markedly risen in recent years, Tseng said, noting that salaries for Taiwan's higher education diploma holders have bogged down over the latest 10 years.
Furthermore, Tseng pointed out, a local graduate from a private college or university typically carries student loan debts of at least NT$400,000.

The TSU lawmakers' call came after Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) concluded an economic cooperation forum with the Communist Party of China (CPC), the third of its kind, a day earlier in Beijing.
The CPC offered several overtures to Taiwan, including allowing Taiwan-based universities and colleges to recruit students in China, among others.

Commenting on the issue, TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei voiced his opposition on the grounds that Taiwan's higher education resources have been insufficient due to rapid expansion, with each college student receiving only NT$10,000 in government subsidies per year, a drop from the previous level of NT$30,000.

Against such a backdrop, there is no reason for Taiwan's colleges and universities to court Chinese students -- a situation which Huang predicted would further stretch educational resources for local students.
What the government should do, Huang opined, is adopt adequate measures to phase out poorly-performing higher education institutions.

According to TSU Secretary-General Chien Chen-shan, Taiwan cannot pin its hopes on China to address such a problem. Many more complications involving employment and immigration will arise from such an opening to Chinese students and a recognition of Chinese academic degrees, he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Filler in Animal Feed Is Open Secret in China
As American food safety regulators head to China to investigate how a chemical made from coal found its way into pet food that killed dogs and cats in the United States, workers in this heavily polluted northern city openly admit that the substance is routinely added to animal feed as a fake protein.
For years, producers of animal feed all over China have secretly supplemented their feed with the substance, called melamine, a cheap additive that looks like protein in tests, even though it does not provide any nutritional benefits, according to melamine scrap traders and agricultural workers here.
Wall Street Journal:65,000 Airplanes Tracked Globally
Nearly 30,000 commercial airliners fly around the world, and Alexandre Avrane tracks each of them.
Through a telescope in his penthouse apartment, Mr. Avrane can spot planes miles beyond Paris. But his real intelligence lies in a global network of airplane fanatics from Tehran to Lima to Shanghai. The Frenchman even has a pair of eyes in Goma, near war-torn Congo's border with Rwanda.
Maximo J. Gainza, a fellow enthusiast from Buenos Aires, in February emailed Mr. Avrane an interesting nugget: A Boeing 727 that had been in the fleet of Bolivian flag carrier Lloyd Aereo Boliviano for 37 years was still flying, Mr. Gainza wrote, setting a record for the longest time served by a plane with a single airline.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF OF YOUNGSTERS IN TAIWAN BUY ON IMPULSE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly half of Taiwanese youngsters practice impulsebuying, although over 70 percent of them agree that it is worthwhile to think it over before making a decision, according to results of a survey released Monday.

The survey, conducted by ACNeilson Taiwan Limited at the request of Citibank Taiwan and Taiwan Women's Rescue Foundation, obtained satisfactory answers from 1,742 high school students throughout Taiwan between Sept. 18, 2006 and Jan. 19, 2007.

The results show that 45 percent of youngsters surveyed acknowledged that they would buy on the spur of the moment. Of the girls surveyed, 53 percent said they would purchase what they like this way, compared to 34 percent of the boys who would do the same.

The survey found that 84 percent of the young people believe that they should be held responsible for their own behavior, and 90 percent said they understand that a person's bad credit history will make it difficult to get bank loans in the future.
The study also found that an on-campus educational program on personal financing could increase the number of students with good knowledge of personal finance from 21 percent to 41 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC TAIWAN NETS NT$780 MILLION IN FIRST QUARTER PROFIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run shipbuilding company, CSBC Corporation Taiwan, has netted after-tax profits totaling NT$780 million (US$23.44 million)in the first quarter of this year, according to initial performance results released by the company Monday.

CSBC Corporation Taiwan, which changed its name from China Shipbuilding Corporation in early March in accordance with government policy, recorded revenues of NT$5.88 billion, about NT$200 million more than its target for the first quarter.
The company's records show that March was the best month, with business totaling NT$2.83 billion, much higher than the target of NT$1.73 billion, making for a single-month profit of NT$362 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO HOLD FORUM ON TAIWAN ePASSPORT

TEXT.P: Scores of foreign experts on electronic passports have been invited to attend a seminar to be sponsored Tuesday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to offer tips on Taiwan's e-passport issuance plan, a diplomatic official said Monday.

According to the official, the MOFA is organizing the Taiwan ePassport Forum in cooperation with the Asia Pacific Smart Card Association in preparation for its planned issuance of e-passports from next year.

Electronic passport specialists from Germany, France, Australia, the Netherlands and several other countries will deliver keynote speeches at the forum, the official said, adding that foreign participants will also exchange views and technological know-how with relevant local software and hardware manufacturers.

Noting that the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs began preparations for the e-passport issuance in 2005, the official said the ministry hopes to obtain expert views and counseling on Taiwan's e-passport program through the forum.

In addition to MOFA staff members, the official said senior officials from 10-plus relevant government agencies have also been invited to attend the seminar to keep them abreast of the latest development and technological know- how in related fields.

Stressing that the issuance of an e-passport is an integral part of passport renewal to stamp out forgery and other related frauds, the official said e-passport issuance will not affect existing passport application procedures and will follow the principles of convenience and accessibility.
The official further said the data to be stored in the e-passport's integrated circuit or memory chip will be same as those recorded in the present version of passport.

"The chip embedded in the back cover of the passport will not carry such controversial items as fingerprints and iris scans, " the official said, adding that special devices will also be introduced to prevent stealing or hacking of information stored in the chip.
Meanwhile, the official said the MOFA has referred a package of amendments to the passport statute to the Legislative Yuan for approval to provide a legal basis to the issuance of e-passports.
Thanks to active promotion by the United States and formulation of relevant standards and regulations by the international civil aviation organizations, 37 advanced countries have issued e-passports.

As sophisticated technologies have been introduced to protect the personal information of e-passport holders, the official said the issuance of e-passport will help prevent passport falsification and even help speed up immigration procedures.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 INJURED IN HONG KONG TOUR GROUP BUS MISHAP IN CHIAYI

TEXT.P: A tour bus carrying 15 passengers -- 13 of them tourists from Hong Kong -- accidentally hit an electric pole in a scenic mountainous area in the southern county of Chiayi, leaving three men and one woman injured, local police said Monday.
Among the injured, a Taiwanese tour guide was more seriously injured than any of the other three Hong Kong tourists, the police said.
All are conscious and none are in critical condition, the police explained.
After treatment, two Hong Kong tourists were discharged from the hospital and joined the tour group to continue their journey.
Only the Taiwan tour guide and one Hong Kong tourist still remain in the hospital for observation.
The bus was touring Alishan, a mountain resort in the southern county, when the accident occurred, police said, adding that visibility at the time was very poor due to heavy fog.
The police are still investigating the cause of the accident.
